title: Truck Blows Up, Driver Killed: 3 Accused of Murder
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 30 (AP) A dynamiteladen truck, operated by a struck company, was blown up today after it apparently was hit by a snip er's bullet. The driver was killed.

title: Wright Cards 69 for 145 and Takes TwoStroke Lead in Metropolitan Open
Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
Kohler Views Soviet Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Foy Kohler, former United States Ambassador to the So viet Union, told Congress today that the Soviet Union did not fear Communist China militari ly at present but in terms of the future this is their major national concern. Mr. Kohler, now a professor at the Univer sity of Miami, testified before a House foreign affairs sub committee.

title: 3 Employes Who Save City Millions Get $1,000 Awards
Slow Progress Reported By G.M. and Auto Union
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) Both General Motors and the United Automobile Workers re ported progress today in soly ing locallevel issues, but 29, 376 of these still stood in the way of settlement of the un ion's 17day strike against G.M.

title: GasField Find Is Reported
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The McCullouch Oil Corpo ration and Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis reported today they have found a new gas and condensate field in the Aanadark Basin in Dewey County, Okla. The discovery wel flowed at a rate of 6.4 million cubic feet of gas a day and 900 barrels of condensate from depths of 9,570 to 10,945 feet.

title: Radhakrishna Ramani, 68, Dies; Malaysian Ambassador to U .N
description: Radhakrishna Ramani, Malay sia's Ambassador to the United Nations, who had undergone openheart surgery here in 1966, died yesterday in his suite at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. His age was 68.

title: Battle of 2 Incumbents Gives State Unusual Race
description: The campaign in New York State's 29th Congressional Dis trict is the only race in the country this fall with two in cumbent House members run ning against each other, and it is unusual for other reasons as well.

title: Striking Auto Workers Optimistic, Still Enjoying the Time Off
description: FLINT, Mich., Sept. 29 John Stevens, one of the 50, 000 auto workers on strike here, sank the eight ball, put down his pool stick, wan dered over to a table at Teddy's Bar opposite the Fisher Body plant and talked to his friends about the strike. I didn't lay away a nickel, he said, running has mus cular hands through his silver crewcut. I didn't think we had the guts to take on a machine like General Motors.

title: POST ASKS ACTION ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30Charles W. Yost, the chief delegate of the United States to the United Nations, today called on all parties in the Middle East to start moving toward peace negotiations. He added, however, that to achieve this it was necessary to restore lost faith in the in tegrity of the armistice agree ment along the Suez Canal zone.

title: Landlords Accuse City of Breaking Agreement
description: Landlords charged in Su preme Court yesterday that the city administration was seek ing to cut rents immediately in the 16dayold Bronx apart ment strike despite the un derstanding to the contrary in open court that such cuts would not take effect until November.

title: Judge Zavatt to Retire
description: Federal Judge Joseph C. Za vatt, 70 years old, notified Pres ident Nixon yesterday of his intention to retire from active service effective Dec. 31. Judge Zavatt, who is serving in Brook lyn, was appointed to the Fed eral bench in August, 1957 by President Dwight D. Eisenhow er. He later became Chief Judge in the Brooklyn courts in 1962, but voluntarily stepped down last June.

title: MACHINISTS REJECT PACT WITH 4 PAPERS
description: Machinists have rejected tentative agreement on a new contract with the city's four major newspapers.

title: YOEL SHARR PLAYS JERUSALEM JAZZ
description: Jerusalem Jazz is the iden tification given to the music played by the Yoel Sharr Trio, which will be at the Top of the Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, through Sunday. Mr. Sharr, a pianist from Israel, is squeez ing in an appearance at the Top of the Gate between an engagement at El Avram, the Israeli cabaret on Grove Street, where, he says, he did humor ous things and a role in an Israeli revue, To Be or Not to Be  What Kind of Question Is That? which opens Oct. 13 at the Barbizon Plaza Theater.

title: Vassar Chair Endowed
description: POTJGHKEEPSIE, N. Y. Sept. 30 (UPI)Vassar College has received a $750,000 donation from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation in New York to establish an endowed profes sorship. The college, which is trying to raise $27.2million for its academic program, said the chair will be known as the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation Professorship in the Humani ties, but will not be perma nently restricted to any one department or area of study.

title: The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Books of The Times
description: George Bernard Shaw (18561950) and Hilaire Belloc (18701953) were contem poraries, and It's a pity they never struck up an enduring correspondence; what disputatious volumes it would have filled! The Irish Puritan from Dublin and the Roman Catholic from Paris lived most of their long lives in London, disagreeing about almost everythingChristianity, so cialism, the Boer War, the eating of animal flesh, and Prussians. Both had a hard time

title: HelpWanted Indicator Showed August Decline
description: Business and industry put up fewer helpwanted signs in August, continuing a trend that set in late last winter.

title: Guerrilla Group Vows to Stay in Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 30 They will never get our part of Amman! boasted Ahmed Shabibi, a guerrilla commander and a member of the 27man Palestine liberation move ment's Central Committee. They can never get it.

title: Perc Westmore, MakeUp Artist, Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30 (UPI) Perc Westmore, a member of the famous Westmore family of makeup artists, who trans formed 2,500 women into Queen for a Day on the orig inal television show of that name, died today at the age of 65.

title: Edward Everett Horton Is Dead; Comic Character Actor Was 83
description: ENCINO, Calif., Sept. 30 Edward Everett Horton, a char acter actor who was a master of comic befuddlement, died last night at his home in the San Fernando Valley. He was 83 years old.

title: Electronic Data Chairman To Offer 300,000 Shares
description: H. Ross Perot, chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, disclosed yester day he intends to sell publicly about 300,000 company shares he owns. The offering, to ob tain a wider distribution of the shares, would be valued at more than $19million, based on yesterday's overthecounter quotation of 64 bid, 66 asked.

title: Group Shortens Name as Service Widens
description: The National Industrial Conference Board, a non profit business and economic research organization, will present a new image to the world in the form of a shorter name, a new insignia and a major restructuring of its re search and service activities.

title: ALBATROSS RULES A STRONG CHOICE
description: YONKERS, Sept. 30  Any one who was at Yonkers Race way last Monday night and saw Albatross win the $27, 747 Star Pointer Pace by eight lengths would agree that Bert James's colt should be favored to win Saturday night's $53, 495.63 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace here.

title: Market Place:
description: Remember those winter days long ago when you hud dled around the fireplace in your long winter woolies as icy winds howled outside? The flickering flames seemed a frail ally in your fight for survival.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: One meal a week of fish taken from most mercury contaminated waters is prob ably safe, according to a re port in the September Bulle tin of the Sport Fishing Insti tute.

title: Connecticut Town Lives With Fear
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Sept. 30 Fearful parents in this town of 50,000 have taken extraordinary precautions to protect their children since the discovery in a wooded area here on Tuesday of the body of a 5yearold girl ab ducted in nearby New Haven on Sept. 21.

title: TRANSIT OFFICIALS EXPECTING U.S. AID
description: State transportation officials said yesterday that the $3.1 billion Federal mass transit bill approved by the House Tues day could bring to New York more than $400million for sub ways, buses, commuters rail roads and other transit projects through 1975.

title: Equity Theater Lists Plays
description: Ben Bagley's Shoestring Revue will open the Equity Library Theater season on Oct. 15 at the Master Theater, Riverside Drive and 103d Street. Also set for the season are Johnny NoTrump, by Mary Mercer, Nov. 12; Greenwillow, by Lesser Samuels and Frank Loesser, Dec. 3; Present Laugh ter, the Noel Coward play, Jan. 14; Heloise, by John Forsyth, Feb. 4, and Ruddi gore, the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, March 4.

title: BIG BOARD TAKES THE MIDDLE ROAD
description: The stock market closed yes terdaythe final trading ses sion of the third quarterwith small price changes appearing in most issues.

title: Sperry and Hutchinson Elects a New President
description: Directors of the Sperry and. Hutchinson Company elected Frederick. A. Collins Jr. as president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest tradingstamp company yes terday. He succeeds Frank P. Rossi, 64 years old, who be comes chairman of the execu tive committee, a post which had been vacant for four years. William S. Beinecke, 56, chairman and chief execu ive officer,. said the changes were effective today.

title: Miss Joys, a Colorado Alumna, Betrothed to Patrick D. Burke
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 Mr. and Mrs. J. Hartley Joys have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Joys, to Pat rick Dennis Burke, both of New York. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Burke of Sun City Center, Fla.

title: Gertrude Keller's Rites
description: A memorial service for Gert rude I. Keller, who taught at Columbia University for 43 years, will be held at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia cam pus Saturday at 3:30 P.M. Miss Keller, an associate in theater and speech at the university, died Aug. 19 at the age of 65.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: 1970, bY Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
SCHERING MERGER WITH PLOUGH SET
description: Shareholders of the Schering Corporation and Plough, Inc., at separate meetings yesterday approved a previously an nounced plan to consolidate the two companies. Under the agreement dislosed in June, Schering and Plough will op erate as wholly owned but separate subsidiaries of a new company to be known as Scher ingPlough Corpo ration. The merger is one of the larg est of the year. When it was announced on June 24, the market value of the two companies was close to $1.5billion.

title: The Whats Ride Up Front
description: People who regularly sit back in steerage when they make an airplane voyage often ask what goes on among us elegant folk up in first class after the curtains are drawn. Baccarat at $16,000 a hand, the laying of lascivi ous hands on the stewardess, exchanges of inside stock exchange information worth a king's ransomsuch are the impressions of our activities likely to be drawn by secondclass passengers when they see the curtain being dropped to shield us from second class prying.

title: Cancer League to Present a Check
description: At a luncheon for more than 300 to be given by the Cancer Service League at the Americana Hotel on Tuesday, a check for $10,000 will be presented to a representative of the department of ophthal mology at the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. The money will go toward the department's research pro gram in the treatment of ocular tumors. Dr. Miles A. Galin heads the program, which received $10,000 from the league last year also.

title: WALKER REHIRED AS ASTROS' PILOT
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Harry Walker was rehired to day as manager of the Hous ton Astros for another year. He said he believed the club showed signs of becoming a pennant contender.

title: SWAP REPAYMENTS TRIM U.S. RESERVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Treasury Department to day attributed the decline in the nation's total reserve assets during the first part of this year to repayments by Britain and France of their currency swap lines, or reciprocal credit agreements.

title: Home in Police Cars
description: The Iast hostages held in Jordan since their jets were hi jacked early this month re turned yesterday, to be met by police cars that whisked three of them home before sundown and the start of the Jewish New Year.

title: Two Voices Speak Of Nazi Darkness
description: Two voices have come to us lately from the heart of darknessNazi Germany of the nineteenthirties and for ties. One is the voice of a living man. The other is the voice of a dead man.

title: TITO TELLS NIXON BIG POWERS ALONE CAN'T MAKE PEACE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30  President Nixon came to Yugoslavia today and heard President Tito warn that universal peace and stability cannot be achieved by the big powers alone.

title: Labor Party Rejects Narrowly Measure Against Market Entry
description: Blackpool, England, Sept. 30 By a slim margin, the leader ship of the Labor party with stood a determined attempt to day to turn the party against British membership in the Com mon Market.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, Oct. 1, 1970

title: SCHOOL CLASHES EASE IN SYRACUSE
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 Racial tension between white and black schoolchildren lessened here today following two days of violence that forced the closing of three of the city's four high schools.

title: Theater Fund Allocates $350,000 for Aid
description: The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit corpora tion that financially assists commercial products of artis tic merit, has allocated $350, 000 for such aid this season, according to Hugh Southern, fund executive director.

title: Brush Fires in California Have Destroyed More Than Homes
description: MALIBU, Calif., Sept. 30 The Presbyterian Churcit had given Amelia Harrison a pair of blue jeans and a work shirt, but they could not give her back her house. That was gone, a big mound of smol dering, ashen rubble.

title: W. F. Mertz Jr. Weds Miss Farmer
description: Miss E. Wylie Farmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Farmer of Yokohama, Japan, and London, was mar ried yesterday in the Episco pal Church of the Transfigu ration (the Little Church Around the Corner), to Wil liam F. Mertz Jr., president of Mertz Industries, Inc., a textile firm here.

title: Illinois Expels 2 Students For Disorders on Campus
description: Special to The New York Times

title: The Fire of Life
description: On his 75th birthday Walter Savage Landor wrote his most famous poem:

title: RED SOX BOW, 43, AS M'DANIEL HELPS
Brandeis Graduate Is Held In Holdup and Slaying Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (UPI)A Brandeis University graduate was held in $50,000 bail today pending a further hearing on an accessory charge in the bank holdupslaying of a Boston pollceman.

title: And Last Call for Statesmanship
description: Coming on top of the tragic events of the past fortnight in Amman, the sudden death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser constitutes a dreadful blow to the prospects for peace in the Mid dle East. At first sight it extinguishes the flicker of hope for a peaceful set tlement between the Arabs and Israel. More immediately, it throws into un certainty the fate of the ceasefire in Jordan.

title: Dr. Hans Kronberger, 50; Led Nuclear Plant in Britain
description: LONDON, Sept. 30Dr Hans Kronberger, director of reactor development for the Atomic Energy Authority's industrial development group was found hanged in his garage yesterday.

title: House Votes Air Fare Tax To Pay for Plane Guards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The House voted today to in crease air passenger taxes to pay for the use of trained guards on commercial airliners. The bill, passed by a vote of 323 to 17, now goes to the Senate for final action.

title: Interesting Job, Boring Materials
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 William Cody Wilson is the sort of chap who could come out of the movie I Am Curi ous (Yellow), and remark, I thought the politics more interesting than the sex. The movie portrays a young Swedish girl wrapped up in politics and unwrapped in amorous esca pades. Dr, Wil son, 44 years old, is the executive director of the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography, which made public today a report on smut in America. The wiry, sandyhaired social psychologist supervised the commission's staff and the 50 research projects con tracted by the commission.

title: HIGH HEALTH AIDE QUITS CITY POST
description: Dr. James G. Haughton, the city's secondranking health of ficial, has resigned to accept an appointment in Chicago as executive director of the Cook County Hospital Govern ing Commission.

title: Money
description: Wednesday, Sept. 30, 1970

title: CHESTER R. HARRIS
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 30 Chester R. Harris, a past president and former chair man of the board of the Kerite Company in New York, makers of insulated wire and cable, died yesterday at a nursing home in Montclair. He was 88 years old and lived at 123 Bev erly Road.

title: UMPIRES SALARY BID POSES STRIKE THREAT
The City: Reluctant Landlord
description: The political, strike conducted by Bronx landlords against the city's newly modified rentcontrol standards has obliged municipal officials to take over the role of landlord in several hundred apartment houses that have been deprived of hot water, garbage removal and other services.

title: Hungarian Breed Captivating Fanciers
description: While the six finalists were gaiting around the ring at Croton Point Park as the halfcenturyold Westchester Kennel Club show drew to a close, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gilmore were arriving home at Annapolis, Md. But in the few hours they had been at Westchester showing their Halmaji Aranyos, few dogs had at tracted the at tention of their Komondor. Aray nos, which means golden in Hungarian, had done well in her breed, leading her sex and taking best of winners.

title: Emotions High in Cairo on Eve of Nasser's Funeral
description: CAIRO, Sept. 30MIG21 jet fighters screamed low over Cairo today in rehearsal for the pageantry that is to be part of the funeral tomor row of President Gamal Ab del Nasser.

title: Gillette Hansen Engaged to Wed Fred W. Pool 2d
description: CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 30Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Leighton Hansen have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gillette Kilburn Hansen, to Fred Weckesser Pool 2d, who is serving with the Air Force at Fort Carson in Colorado Springs. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Pool of Lit tleton, Colo.

title: Delay in Israeli Move Seen
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30There was no sign here that any pris oners would be released, despite persistent reports that the Is raelis, plan to release two Al gerians and 10 Lebanese as a humanitarian gesture.

title: ThreeRing Show in New York
description: Buckley can win, a White House staff man said the other day, if Goodell can only take enough votes away from Ottinger. This is not nec essarily what will happen in the New York Senatorial campaign, but that it could even be said is the measure of this bizarreand importantcon test.

title: WOMETCO RAISES PROFIT TO A PEAK
description: Wometco Enterprises, Inc., whose diversified interests range from television, radio broadcasting and a theater chain to soft drink bottling, vending, fastfood restaurants, outdoor advertising and the Miami Seaquarium, posted records in sales and earnings for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 12.

title: Host to President in Belgrade
description: President of Yugoslavia... first Easternbloc leader to defy Soviet Union  Com munist, nationalist and in tense individualist at the same time, he developed economy and society unlike any other  called both Titoism and market socialism, it has brought prosperity ... earned a large measure of respect for creator despite persecu tion and jailing of critics in classic totalitarian mold  born Josip Broz on May 25, 1892, in village near Zagreb, largest city of Croatia, then part of AustroHungary, sev enth of 15 children ... cafe waiter at 15 and then metal worker drifting around East ern Europe . . . fought in Croatian regiment in World War I ... captured by sians learned langune, escaped, fought with Bolsheviks in Leningrad streets ... re turned to Yugoslavia, a new nation, in 1920 ... became important Communist and was jailed for five years in 1929 . . . during World War II became chief of Yugoslav partisans and was overshad owed by Draja Mikhailo vitch, leader of Chetniks, whom he executed after war ... impressed the Allies, who sent military aid . . . irked by Russians, who promised aid, sent little, beginning rift between Tito and Stalin that was formalized in 1948 ... married three times, most recently in 1952 to statuesque former resistance fighter ... loves good food, dry white Dalmatian wines . . . recent ly announced he would be succeeded by a collective ... didn't when.

title: Nets Win Exhibition, 12091
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 30 The New York Nets got Lou Carnesecca's professional coaching career off to a win ning start by drubbing the Pittsburgh .Condors, 12091, in their opening American Basket ball Association preseason game, tonight.

title: Pussyfooting on Hijacking
description: While the last of hundreds of hostages from three hijacked and destroyed airliners were emerging from their ordeal in Jordan this week, the governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization was meeting in Montreal to consider new measures to curb aerial piracy. The results of that meeting are discouraging.

title: BLAIR & CO. SUED BY FOUR LENDERS
description: Four creditors of Blair & Co., a major brokerage house in liquidation, charged yester day that the concern and 10 of its officers had fraudulently solicited $4million in subor dinated loans from the cred itors, while withholding infor mation about Blair's financial distress.

title: DELAY IS LIKELY IN THE SST VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Sources close to the supersonic transport program indicated, to day that the Senate's crucial vote on his year's $290million appropriation would probably be held: pp;, until after the No vember election.

title: THOUSANDS GIVEN DRAFT LOOPHOLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Nixon Administration opened a new hole in Selective Service regulations today that could allow thousands of young men to escape the draft.

title: Merger Plans Announced By Two ClosedEnd Funds
description: The United States Trust In vestment Fund, operated by the United States Trust Company of New York, and the Mad International Fund, organized by Banca Commerciale Italiana, of Milan, and the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, Paris, announced plans yesterday to merge the two closedend funds, which are registered in Luxembourg.

title: Hendrix to Be Buried Today
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 30 (AP)Six boyhood friends of Jimi Hen drix will serve as pallbearers tomorrow when the 27yearold pop singer is buried during pri vate funeral services here. Mr. Hendrix died Sept. 18 in Lon don. His family has canceled plans for a public memorial service. A spokesman said there was insufficient time to make adequate plans.

title: COMBAT G.I. PULLOUT BY SUMMER FORESEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Senate Republican leader, said today that the last United States com bat troops will be coming out of Vietnam by next summer.

title: Miss Ader Fiancee Of David Ostrow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ader of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felice Eileen Ader, to David W. Ostrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ostrow of New York, Rock ville Centre, L. I., and Holly wood, Fla.

title: 29th Congressional Dist. New York
description: POPULATION409,265, in cludes cities of Albany, Sche nectady and Amsterdam, with large sections of middle class government and indus trial workers, plus rural areas of Montgomery County.

title: A Proposal for Mideast Peace...
description: The reaction to the latest Mideast ern nightmare has been typical; horror at the destruction of those nice shiny airplanes, at the abduction of innocent tourists, at the blood bath that fol lowed in Jordan, shock at the death of President Nasser.

title: STOCKS RISE A BIT ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market fin ished moderately firmer yester day as trading slowed from the recent brisk pace.

title: Burd Alane Captures $28,450 Discovery Handicap at Belmont by 9 Lengths
description: As V. J. (Lefty)Nickerson, the horse's trainer, might have de scribed it, Burd Alane won big yesterday. End of statement.

title: The Members of the Commission
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Following are members of the Commission on Obscen ity and Pornography:

title: Aronson and Mielziner Win Stage Design Prizes
description: The sixth annual Maharam Foundation Theatrical Design Award, which carries a prize of $1,000, will be shared this season by Boris Aronson and Jo Mielziner, designers, re spectively, of Company and Child's Play. Theoni V. Aldredge won the $500 costume award for her con tribution to Peer Gynt.

title: Erie Welfare Rolls Rise
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 30 (AP) Welfare applications have reached a 10year high in Erie County, the Department of So cial Services reports. The de partment said yesterday that about 3,000 persons applied for county aid in July and August. About 1,800 applied in the same period last year.

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: By The Associated Press,

title: CIOCIOSAN IS SUNG BY JEANNETTE PILOU
description: In the season's first Madame Butterfly at the Metropolitan Opera, on Tuesday night, there was a soprano new to the title role, Jeannette Pilou. The Greek artist, who is now in her fourth year with the company, is a likable and sensitive singer. Her voice is neither large nor very sensuous, yet it projects well and is skillfully used.

title: Advertising: Six Agencies Off and Running
description: According to his aides, Howard J. Samuels, the presi dent of the new OffTrack Betting Corporation, considers advertising a crucial part of the effort.

title: BOND PRICES RISE; NEW ISSUES SELL
description: Bond prices rose yesterday as this week's heavy volume of new issues sold to investors quickly enough to encourage investment bankers and trad ers.

title: Security Guards at the U.N. Threaten SickLeave Action
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 United Nations security guards are threatening a mass sickleave job action during the 25th anniversary celebration unless promotion policies are improved.

title: MAYORS ENDORSE NEW URBAN PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The Nixon Administration an nounced today its plan to use the Model Cities program as a means of decentralizing au thority in Federal grants. The plan was promptly endorsed by the nation's mayors.

title: Action on Gasoline Tax Delayed By House Panel Past Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to postpone until after the election any further consideration of the tax the Administration wants to put on lead additives to gasoline.

title: Interpublic Trims Top Salaries to Economize
description: Executives and profession als at all of the domestic of fices of the giant Interpublic Group of Companies learned yesterday that, because of the economic picture, some would be taking pay cuts for the fourth quarter. Only those who make more than $20,000 a year will be affected, with the size of the cut increasing with the salary.

title: WPIX Head Recalls News Aide Demotion At F.C.C., Hearings
description: WPIX's former Chief of news was demoted following a re ported, misrepresentation of news film by the station, Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, said yesterday.

title: Little Community on L.I. Welcomes Big Neighbor
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., Sept., 30 The population of this min uscule North Shore village has shot up in the last dec ade, from 164 to 500 people. Otherwise the tiny cominu nity on 100 acres of wood land and bluffs dr6pping down to the Scalloped shore line of Long Island Sonnd has successfully resisted change for half cen tury. Now that all may be chang ing. Nearby, in the community of Rocky Point, the Atomic Energy Commission held hearings last week on the application of the Long Island Lighting Company to construct Long Island's first nuclear power plant a few miles east of this village.

title: East Berlin Operagoers See Joe Hill
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 30 The latest opera by Alan Bush, 70yearold British composer, whose works are much per formed in East Germany, had its world premiere at the East Berlin State Opera yesterday. Entitled Joe Hill, it treats the imprisonment and execu tion of the I.W.W. labor movement composer on Nov. 19, 1915, in Salt Lake City. The libretto is by New Yorker Barrie Stavis, based on his play The Man Who Never Died.

title: 108th Diphtheria Case Listed
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 30 (UPI)A 9yearold girl has become the city's 108th con firmed diphtheria case of the year. In addition, 10 suspected cases were under hospital ob servation today and 29 other cases have been diagnosed as diphtheria but have not yet been confirmed by tests.

title: Safety Lenses Will Be Required For Nearly All New Eyeglasses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Food and Drug Administra tion announced steps today to make safety glass mandatory in virtually all the new eyeglasses Americans wear.

title: South African Black Leader Is Sentenced to 15 Years
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 30A sentence of 15 years' imprisonment was im posed today on Benjamin Ramotse, a militant black leader who was found guilty yester day of terrorist activities.

title: Court Rebuffs City's Investigation Chief,
description: The city's Commissioner of Investigation does not have the authority to jail three police men until they answer ques tions about alleged graft, State Supreme Court Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. ruled yesterday.

title: FRENCH GOLFERS LEAD BY 4 SHOTS
description: MADRID, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Two superb rounds gave France a fourstroke lead today over the United States team in the Espirito Santo women's world amateur golf champion ship.

title: Major League Leaders
description: By The Associated Press

title: Elsey Installed as Red Cross Head
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)George ]VI. Elsey was installed today as president of the American Red Cross, taking the place of Gen. James F. Collins.

title: NIXON AIDES ACCEPT JOB PLAN FOR IDLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP); The Nixon Administration ac cepted today a multimillion dollar program for putting the unemployed into federally sup ported publicservice jobs as part of a major overhaul of the Government's manpowertrain ing system.

title: No Clear Picture Is Discerned Of Political Future for Egypt
description: CAIRO, Sept. 30  The death of President Gamal Ab del Naiser has raised grave questions among diplomats and analysts here about the politi cal future of the United Arab Republic.

title: Howard M. Ernst, Founder Of Bond Brokerage, Dead
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 30  Howard M. Ernst, founding partner of Ernst & Co., bond brokers of 120 Broadway, New York, died yesterday in his home on Woodlands Road. His age was 75. He also lived in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: U.S. Seeking to Arrange Meeting Between Kosygin and Richardson After Funeral
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The United States is seeking to arrange a conference on the Middle East between Premier Aleksei M. Kosygin of the Soviet Union and Elliot L. Richardson, the representative of President Nixon, after the funeral of Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Busing as Legal Racism

title: Soviet Outlines Proposal On Berlin at Big 4 Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Soviet proposals on the future of West Berlin were outlined today at a meeting of the Big Four in Berlin, informed sources said today.

title: Chou Hails China's Gains
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 30  Premier Chou Enlai today hailed revolutionary gains in Communist China and pledged continued support for revolu tionaries abroad in a keynote speech in Peking on the eve of celebrations of Communist China's 21st anniversary.

title: Cardinal Aloisi Masella Dies; Had Reputation as Conciliator
description: ROME, Sept. 30Benedetto Cardinal Aloisi Mnsella, a for mer papal diplomat who for many years was a pillar of the Roman Catholic Church's cen tral administration, the Roman Curia, died here after a short illness today. He was 91 years old, the oldest member of the Sacred College of Cardinals.

title: Personal Finance
description: A high rate of return and safety are in the minds of many small investors, especially older ones worried about inflation. This group has found it difficult to find the right investment combi nationsyet one in denomi nations small enough for their wallets.

title: Excerpts From Panel's Majority Report, Dissenting Opinions and Other Views
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Following are excerpts from the majority report of the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography; from dissents by Charles H. Keating Jr. and by the Rev. Morton A. Hill and the Rev. Winfrey C. Link, with Mr. Keating concurring; and from separate statements by Dr. Morris A. Lipton and Dr. Edward D. Greenwood and by Prof. Orton N. Larsen and Prof. Marvin F. Woljgang:

title: At the Top: 3,182 Whites, 3 Blacks
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30 (UPI)Results of a survey released today showed that, of 3,182 senior officers and directors in the executive suites and board rooms of the nation's top 50 corpora tions, three were black.

title: De Gaulle Makes Public His Letter of Condolence
description: PARIS, Sept. 30 Former President Charles de Gaulle today made public a personal letter of condolence to the United Arab Republic's Am bassador in Paris on the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: NEW JOB BIAS CURB WINS SENATE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Twentytwo years after Presi dent Truman made such a pro posal, the Senate acted today to give a Federal commission power to enforce nondiscrimi nation in employment through out the nation.

title: Bombing Figure Put on Probation For Up to 6 Years
description: John D. Hughey 3d, who ad mitted being part of a bombing conspiracy that was led by Samuel J. Melville to plant ex plosives in eight Manhattan of fice buildings a year ago, was placed under supervision of the Federal Board of Parole for up to six years yesterday.

title: INEZ HAYNES IRWIN, AUTHOR, FENINIST, 97
description: NORWELL, Mass., Sept. 30 Inez Haynes Irwin, an author and suffragette, died here Fri day in a nursing home. She was 97 years old and was the widow of Will Irwin, the reporter and writer.

title: Canadian Contract Signed
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press)  Telesat Canada and Hughes Aircraft Company of California signed a $31  million contract today to build this country's first domestic com munications satellite.

title: Missing Pilot Found Dead
description: BAR HARBOUR, Me., Sept. 30 (AP)The body of Robert McGaunn of Texas, a pilot missing three months since taking off on a transAtlantic flight, has been found here. Another pilot spotted the wreckage of Mr. McGaunn's small single  engine plane on Cedar Swamp Mountain yester day. The body was alongside the wreckage.

title: Wholesale Prices Show A Sharp Rise for Month
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.  The index of wholesale prices, which generally foreshadows retail price trends by a few months, rose sharply again in September, partly, but not en tirely, because of increased food costs.

title: F.T.C. Seeks 3Day Cooling off Period in DoortoDoor Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Federal Trade Commission moved today to protect house holders from highpressure doortodoor salesmen.

title: JUDGE BARS ORDER TO DROP 14 TRAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The Interstate Commerce Com mission allowed the insolvent Penn Central Transportation Company today to discontinued 14 of 34 longdistance passen ger trains, but a Federal judged later blocked the move.

title: Jets Put Maynard on Notice
description: The mysterious case of Don Maynard continues as the New York Jets approach Sunday's game with the Buffalo Bills.

title: Atlantic City Results
description: By The Associated Press

title: Fire Damages Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)A fire that apparently originated in a malfunctioning computer caused an estimated $750,000 damage early today at the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of History and Tech nology. A spokesman said most of the damage was in the com puter display section on the third floor, but that there was heat and smoke damage to a puppet theater, a graphics ex hibit hall and a coin section.

title: TEMPLE VANDALIZED BY PAINTED SLOGANS
description: Vandals painted slogans on a Brooklyn synagogue early yesterday. The eightinchhigh red lettering read Palestine Liberation, Free Bobby Now and Free Lila.

title: Credit Cards Weighed For City Bet Parlors
description: Howard J. Samuels, presi dent of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yes terday the corporation might issue credit cards in an effort to draw business away from illegal bookmakers.

title: Rooney, 5 Sons Purchase W. Palm Beach Dog Track
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP)  Art Rooney, owner of the Pittsburgh Steel ers, and his five sons have pur chased the Palm Beach Kennel Club for about $7million.

title: Jewish Defense League To Aid Hijacking Suspects
description: The Jewish Defense League is trying to raise bail for the young Brooklyn couple who were arrested Sunday as they allegedly prepared to board flight for London with fraudu lent passports, four revolvers and a live hand grenade.

title: Police Decoy Thwarts Escape of 2 in Holdup
description: A patrolman disguised as a SkidRow derelict used his bottle of wine yesterday to help thwart the escape of two suspects after a bar holdup in Greenwich Village, the police reported.

title: Abrams Collapses, Is Hospitalized
description: VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, com mander of United States forces in Vietnam, was rushed to a hospital today after he collapsed during a ceremony honoring Australian troops fighting in Vietnam.

title: 4 ARE ARRESTED IN FILM SEIZURE
description: A film distributor and three theater managers were arrested yesterday after a criminal court judge here authorized the seizure of the film Censorship in Denmark: A New Approach.

title: George Axt, Architect, Dies; ExDean at Pratt Institute
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 30 George Francis Axt, a retired architect, died today of a heart attack in his home at 442 Val ley View Road. His age was 72.

title: Adams Predicts Defection of Upstate Democrats
description: FISHKILL, N. Y., Sept. 30 Dr. Paul L. Adams predicted to day that many upstate Demo crats would vote for him on Nov. 3 because they were disillusioned with the make up of their party's statewide ticket.

title: Trashing the Record
description: There is little hope for a return to an atmosphere of reason in the relationship between the students and the American people if Vice President Agnew's distortions of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest are a preview of the Nixon Administration's response.

title: GOVERNOR SPEAKS ON BRONX HOUSING
description: Governor Rockefeller cited yesterday the accomplishments of the twoyearold New York State Urban Development Cor poration, set up by his adminis tration two years ago, as he joined in groundbreaking cere monies at two Bronx housing projects.

title: CUT IN BANK RATE BY RESERVE SEEN
description: A reduction in the 6 per cent interest charge the Federal Re serve System imposes on loans to its member banks may hap pen any time, the chairman designate of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday.

title: Canine Corps Patrolman Slain in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Thursday, Oct. 1 (UPI)  A 27yearold Canine Corps patrolman was shot to death about midnight when one of two men he stopped to question raised a shotgun to his neck and fired.

title: MAO, LOOKING FIT, AT PEKING PARADE
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Chairman Mao Tsetung, apparently in excel lent health, strode today into Tien An Men Square in Peking amid cheers to watch a parade marking Communist China's 21st anniversary, the Peking radio reported.

title: Improved Berlin Prospects
description: Moscow's initial proposals for a provisional Berlin set tlement hint at willingness to accept West Berlin's eco nomic ties to Bonn and its right of access to the West. This first indication of concessions in six months of talks was on the table at yesterday's critical meeting of the Big Four ambassadorstheir first since the Soviet German treaty.

title: WOMAN PANTHER RETURNED TO JAIL
description: Mrs. Afeni Shakur, one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plot ting to bomb public places, was sent back to jail yesterday and her $100,000 bail returned to the people who posted it.

title: Federal Jury Indicts Four In Bombing in Wisconsin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)A Federal grand jury in dicted today on three charges four young men sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the ex plosion Aug. 24 at the Univer sity of Wisconsin's Army Mathematics Research Center.

title: Patience a Key in Colorado Ambush
description: Penn State's loss to Col orado last Saturday was not completely unexpected. The Nittany Lions, who went through 31 games without a loss since the third contest of 1967, just had to lose some time.

title: Nine Arrested at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. (AP)  Eight men and one wo man were arrested by Pentagon. security officers today when they attempted to plant small pine trees at an inside mail as a protest against the use of chemical and biological agents by United States forces. There was no violence. About 15 men and woment took part.

title: Off Duty Patrolman Shot While Going To Aid of a Friend
description: An offduty patrolman was critically wounded yesterday when he was shot as he came to the aid of a Bronx auto wrecking shop operator who, the police said, was arguing with two men over a $100 de posit.

title: Moody's to Charge For BondGrading, Beginning Oct. 15
description: Moody's Investors Service, Inc., the oldest securities rating agency, announced yesterday that it intends to charge for grading, corporate and other taxable bonds, beginning Oct. 15.

title: Moss Faces United G.O.P. in Race for Senate Seat
Famous Mother Judges Decorating
description: Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss, a pillar of Newport and Washington society and the mother of Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, spent the whole day yesterday doing something that she thinks will help raise the stand ards of taste in American homes.

title: Epithets Greet Agnew in Salt Lake City
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 Vice President Agnew came here today to deliver a political lecture on decency and wound up telling antiwar demonstra tors they should make their points with your minds, not with your butts.

title: MERGER ACTIVITIES DECLINE IN QUARTER
description: Merger moves dropped sharp ly in this year's third quarter, W. T. Grimm & Co., merger and acquisition consultants, said yesterday.

title: W. GERMANY ENTERS TEAM IN HORSE SHOW
description: West Germany will send fourman team, headed by Hans Gunther Winkler, former Olym pic goldmedal winner to the National Horse Show for the first time since 1963.

title: Executive Changes
description: Thomas J. Galligan Jr., president of the Boston Edison Company, has been made chief executive officer, succeeding Charles F. Avila, who will con tinue as chairman.

title: BONN AND MOSCOW SET SCIENCE TALKS
description: BONN, Sept. 30SovietWest German talks on the detailed aspects of future cooperation in science and technology will get under way in Moscow in November, Bonn's Minister of Science and Education, Hans Leussink, said here today at a news conference.

title: First Trial in Songmy Case Scheduled to Start Tuesday
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 30 (UPI)Formal pretrial hearings for S. Sgt. David Mitchell ended today, and Sergeant Mitchell's trial on charges that he at tempted to murder 30 Viet namese civilians in March, 1968, was scheduled to begin next Tuesday.

title: U.S. ADMITS A FOE OF CHIANG REGIME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The United States has issued a visa to Peng Mingmin, a mem ber of the Taiwan independence movement who escaped from house arrest in Taiwan early this year and fled to Sweden.

title: RICHEY SETS BACK MOORE BY 62, 64
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI)All of the favorites scored impressive victories to day in the $32,000 Pacific Coast international tennis open, but the tournament director, Barry MacKay fell to the way side.

title: 3 Governors Form Transit Commission To Study Financing
description: The formation of a nine member Governors' Special Commission on Financing Mass Transportation, set up to study ways and means of obtaining Federal financial aid adminis tered on a coordinated basis, was announced yesterday by the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: City and 6 States Sue 3 Biggest Auto Makers on Fleet Discounts
description: New York City and six states sued the three largest auto mobile manufacturers yester day, charging them with illegal pricefixing in refusing to grant discounts to state and local gov ernments that buy fleets of vehicles from them.

title: City Opera Offers Its Fourth Figaro; Louise Lebrun Sings
description: The New York City Opera's production of The Marriage of Figaro, which underwent its fourth performance of the fall season on Tuesday night, is scarcely the last word in aristo cratic Mozart styleat one point, for instance, the Count Almaviva wins a bellylaugh by threatening to hit the Countess with a sledgehammer. So when the musical performance fails to transcend the dramatic mud dle, as happend on this occa sion, Figaro is in trouble.

title: Rabbis Plead for Free World as Rosh haShanah Starts
Sports of The Times
description: Johnny Sample, cornerback (retired), on his former job: An offensive ballplayer, other than maybe a guy in the line, he can finesse you, but a defensive ballplayer, he's got to like to hit people. What does that mean? Well, you want to be the first one there to get the ballcarrier. It gives you a real good feeling to give a guy a good lick, stuff him, nut your helmet in there. You uet up and he doesn't he lies there and he moans and he groans, you know the guy coming in to replace him isn't as good as he is or he would of been in there in the first place. And that makes your job a little easier. When you make an outstanding play like that, you know it, nobody has to tell you, you don't have to listen for the applause or wait for your friends to tell you after the game. You know. And a really out standing play, when you've really done something good, not just for your contract negotiations, but for your teammates, the good feel ings bubble up inside you.

title: U.S. Pledges $15Million to Aid LFC Merger
description: The Government has pledged $15million to $20million to help in the takeover of the LFC Financial Corporation, a $1billion saving and loan holding company based in Los Angeles that has experienced serious financial problems.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President left Naples and flew to Bel grade. Yugoslavia, for meet ings with President Tito.

title: A FEDERAL PANEL ASKS RELAXATION OF CURBS ON SMUT
Saints a Blessing in Disguise to Giants
description: Jim Trimble always is treated so well when he scouts the Giants next oppo nent that he tries to wish every team into sounding like a sure Super Bowl win ner.

title: Both Sides Begin Amman Withdrawal
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 30 The Jordanian Army and the Palestinian guerrillas began withdrawing from Amman to day under the terms of a truce agreement reached in Cairo Sunday.

title: College Hiring Guards
description: NEWARK, Sept. 30 (AP) Officials on the Newark campus of Rutgers University have be gun hiring offduty policemen to cope with a rash or muggings, assaults and bomb scares plagu ing the school's student center. A university spokesman said the muggings, which are be lieved to be related to drug abuse, have averaged three a day since school opened Sept. 14. There have been five bomb scares since classes began.

title: Blast Rocks Powder Plant
description: ST. MARKS, Fla., Sept. 30 (UPI)Nine persons were in jured early today when an ex plosion rocked the Olin Corpo ration smokeless gunpowder plant. The cause of the explo sion was not known immediate ly. It was the third at the new gunpowder plant in less than a year.

title: 5 City Regulations Urged for Movers
description: The city's Consumer Af fairs Commissioner, Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, proposed five regulations yesterday designed to protect house holders from inconvenience, abuse and deception on the part of moving companies.

title: U.S. Airline Jobs Increase
description: Employment rolls on Ameri can scheduled airlines rose to 312,000 by the end of 1969 with an annual payroll of $3.3bil lion, according to the Air Trans port Association, the magazine Aviation Week and Space Tech nology reports.

title: Lindsay Dedicates Biggest Liquefied Gas Tank
description: Mayor Lindsay on a jovial, quipping trip to Staten Island yesterday took in some new sightsthe world's largest tank for storing liquefied natural gas and a sprawling containership terminal now in the full flurry of construction.

title: Appellate Division Upholds Badillo's Nomination in 21st District
description: An appellate court validated yesterday former Bronx Bor ough President Herman Badil lo's Democratic nomination for Congress in the new three borough 21st District, counter manding a Queens Supreme Court justice's order that a new primary be held next Thursday.

title: Ban Urged on Woodcock Hunting
description: The National Audubon So ciety notified Federal health and conservation officials yesterday that some recent tests show that woodcocks, are so high, in DDT content that eating them may be hazardous to human health.

title: Women'sRights Debate Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, told the Sen ate today that he planned to bring up next Tuesday a House approved constitutional amend ment providing that equal rights shall not be denied or abridged on account of sex.

title: Award to Actress Upheld
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (AP)  The California Supreme Court upheld today a $750,000 damage award to Shirley Mac Leine, the actress, from 20th Century Fox studios. She had contracted in 1965 to play the lead in a movie, Bloomer Girl, but the studio decided not to produce the picture and instead offered her the lead in a film called Big Country, Big Man for the same pay. Vliss MacLaine rejected the of fer and sued.

title: RANGERS FARM OUT DEMARCO, 3 OTHERS
description: KITCHENER, Ontario. Sept. 30The New York Rangers broke training camp today and assigned four players to the OmahaKnights of the Central League.

title: Setting Is Connecticut, but Cooking Is Right Out of Old Russia
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn.One of the most fascinating colonies in America is a small, 200acre community that lies within the town of Southbury and in the direction of Danbury.

title: State Will Appeal Ruling On Sale of Forger's Art
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he would appeal a ruling Monday by State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein permitting the sale here of paintings by master forger David Stein.

title: Agnew Opposes Goodell, C.O.P. Chief Backs Him
description: Vice President Agnew, cam paigning in Minot, N. D., de clared yesterday that Senator Charles E. Goodell was a radi cal liberal who has left his party.

title: Allende Rebuffs Some Demands of Chile's Ruling Party as Unnecessary
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 30 Dr. Salvador Allende, the Marx ist candidate who won a plurality in Chile's presidential election on Sept. 5, issued a sevenpage statement today that rejected as unnecessary demands by the governing Christian Demorcatic party that he forego, at least for a while, the right to name commanders of the nation's armed forces.

title: HUMPHREY EARNS DRAW IN DEBATE
description: ALEXANDRIA, Minn., Sept. 28Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey sat this week at the same table with Representative Clark Mac Gregor, his Republican op ponent, with only a moderator separating them.

title: LACEY CALLS AIRPORT CRIME'S OPEN CITY
description: Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, described Kennedy In ternational Airport yesterday as an open city where a union and a trade association cooperate with criminals to steal $7million worth of cargo each year.

title: Levitt Accuses City on Nursing Claims
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30Signif icant weaknesses in managerial controls and a $2million ex cess claim for nursinghome care were laid to New York City today by Arthur Levitt, the State Controller.

title: AIRLINER WITH 29 DOWN NEAR DANANG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 (Reuters)An Air Viet nam airliner carrying 26 pas sengers and a crew of three crashed today in mountains about 10 miles north of Da nang.

title: Orchids and Emeralds Revive Memories of Gould Era at Lyndhurst Gala
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 30Thousands of purple and white orchids, flown in from Hawaii, tumbled with fragile grace from the gilt epergnes on the dinner tables.

title: In Memoriam
description: DREWCharles Verner. Oct 1, 1872Sept. 26, 1937. In loving and greatful memory of a good man. Daughter and grandson.

title: ASTRODATA WOES AFFECT MARKET
description: The financial difficulties of a company whose stock is traded on the American Stock Exchange brought a sharp drop yesterday in the price of an other company, whose stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHANNEL 13 SHIFTS ITS NAME TO WNET
description: Channel 13 will be formally renamed Station WNET this morning as the Educational Broadcasting Corporation and National Education Television are consolidated into a major producing unit providing both national and local programing.

title: DOUGLAS E. AHRENDT
description: Douglas E. Ahrendt, an agent with the Penn Mutual Life In surance Company, died Monday of Hodgkin's disease in Stam ford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 9 Juniper Road, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Cubs Beat Mets, 20, and Tie for 2d Place
description: Wringing every ounce of sus pense out of an otherwise lost season, the New York Mets suf fered a 20 defeat to the Chi cago Cubs yesterday and fell back into a tie for second place with one game to go.

title: Connecticut Calls Assembly Session On Unemployment
EVER PRICES OFF IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Silver futures fell again yes terday in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Ex change, with the price of the nearby December contract, the busiest with 1,319 sales drop ping to $1.689 an ounce from $1.732 the day before.

title: BRITAIN RELEASES WOMAN HIJACKER
description: LONDON, Sept. 30Leila Khaled, the Palestinian woman commando who tried unsuccess fully to hijack an airliner 24 days ago, was released from prison tonight and flown out of the country.

title: Public Schools Will Hear A Series on Drug Abuse
description: The Board of Education will start a radio series on drug abuse on Monday. The five program series will be broad cast to public school classes over the school system's own radio station, WNYEFM.

title: Rituals of Death Simple And Quick for Moslems
description: Although the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser has been marked by overt and widespread grief in the Arab world, the Moslem religion frowns upon excessive weeping and vocal displays of grief.

title: STEEL UNION CALLS FOR LIBERAL VOTE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 30The United Steelworkers of America called today for the election of more liberals to Congress to counter what a convention resolution described as the antilabor direction of the Nixon Administration.

title: Entertainment
description: Theater

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Fire in Brooklyn Subway Forces Evacuation of 500
description: A smoky fire in the Nostrand Avenue subway station in Brooklyn yesterday forced the evacuation of close to 500 pas sengers aboard three IND trains.

title: Portnoy Loses Complaint
description: PARIS, Sept. 30 (AP) Armand Portnoy's complaint about Portnoy's Complaint has been rejected by a magis trate's court. Mr. Portnoy, a garage owner, had sought a ban on the sale of the book Philip Roth's American best seller in France. The magistrate said yesterday that he did not think there was enough of parallel between the Paris Por tnoy and the Roth Portnoy.

title: Israelis Pause for a ThreeDay Holiday and for a Respite in Their Crises
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 The people and politics of Israel called a pause in a season of exhausting up heavals tonight, opening a threeday holiday to mark the Jewish New Year. The calendar and the pace of events coincided to permit Israel a moment of rest and of national stocktaking.

title: Yankees, Nets Hailed By a FirstPlace Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay sent a non partisan, waittillnextyear letter yesterday to both the Mets and the Yankees.

title: Nigeria, Independent a Decade, Shows Signs of Living Up to Hopes
Cocoa Exchange Celebrates
description: A dinnerdance marking the 45th anniversary of the New York Cocoa Exchange will be held in the New York Hilton Hotel tomorrow night.

title: Nixon Aide Assails Trade Bill; Administration Appears Split
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The President's special repre sentative for trade negotiations, Carl. J. Gilbert, warned today that passage of the proposed Trade Act of 1970 might be playing with fire.

title: Tobacco Spokesman Calls Charges by Nader False
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  A cigarette industry spokes man termed specifically and categorically false today charge by Ralph Nader that hazardous nontobacco elements were being added to cigarettes, cigars and cigarillos.

title: PulitzerPrize Nominations For Letters Set for Nov. 1
description: The deadline for nominations to be submitted for the 1971 Pulitzer Prizes in letters is Nov. 1, it was announced yes terday.

title: MOSCOW SCOFFS AT SUBBASE ISSUE
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30  The Soviet Union scoffed today at the White House's expressions of concern about possible So viet construction of a state gic submarine base in Cuba. It accused the United States of fanning a war psychosis.

title: U. of Miami's Tate Unexpectedly Quits As Football Coach
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 30 (UPI)Charlie Tate, in the final year of a sevenyear con tract, resigned today as head football coach and athletic di rector at the University of Miami.

title: Nixon Said to Plan Veto of Cost Limit In TV Campaigning
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Nixon was reported by key political advisers today to be preparing to veto the bill limiting campaign expenditures for radio and television.

title: Launching Change Is Urged
description: LONDON (UPI)  The wine makers circle of the Navy Department has proposed that Britain launch its ships with homemade elderberry wine in stead of foreign wines since it would save the British Treas ury about 12s 6d ($150) a launching.

title: Rabbi From Salem, Mass., Is Seized in Hashish Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The Treasury De partment said today that a rabbi from Salem, Mass., had been charged with the trans portation and concealment of 10 pounds of hashish.

title: A Wage Floor for Domestics? Some Anticipate Drawbacks
description: That would be lovely, sighed Mae Alston.

title: Speed Limit Rises Today
description: The New York State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, Vincent L. Tofany, reminded motorists yesterday that the maximum speed limit on all highways within the state unless other wise posted beginning today would be 55 miles an hour.

title: AGNEW'S COMMENTS QUESTIONED BY FINCH
description: LACEY, Wash., Sept. 30 (AP) Robert H. Finch, counselor to the President, disagreed to day with some of Vice Presi dent Agnew's criticism of the report of the Presidential Com mission on Campus Unrest. Mr. Finch said he did not know if Mr. Agnew had read the report.

title: 3 Boston Doctors Share Award With Their Hospital
description: One of the largest cash awards ever granted in the field of medical science, the $100,000 Alfred Jurzykowski Award, was presented last night to The Chil dren's Hospital Medical Center in Boston and three of its senior physicians.

title: NEW HEALTH RULES FOR APOLLO FLIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The space agency an nounced drastic new measures today to try to insure that no Apollo astronaut will get sick during a moon flight.

title: Lou Novikoff Dead at 54; Mad Russian of Baseball
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) Lou Novikoff, baseball's Mad Russian, died today at the age of 54.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: The American Stock ex change scored its sixth con secutive advance yesterday al though some late weakness erased a portion of the earlier gains.

title: Ballet: Still Point Revived by Joffrey
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet's first new production of the season is, in fact, something borrowed rather than something entirely new. The Still Point, seen for the first time in this produc tion at the New York City Center last night, was first choreographed by Todd Bol ender in an earlier version in 1955 for a modern dance company led by Emily Frank el. A year later he revised it for the New York City Bal let, where the leading roles were danced by Melissa Hay den and Jacques d'Amboise.

title: Goldberg Calls Election a Referendum on Nixon Administration
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 Arthur J. Goldberg, Democrat icLiberal candidate for Gov ernor of New York, told steel union delegates today that the November elections were a cru cial referendum on the Nixon Aenew Administration.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Sept. 30, 1970

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: *Apprentice.

title: Murphy Reported Seeking New Top Police Command
description: Patrick V. Murphy, New York's new Police Commis sioner, is understood to have decided that a new generation of top commanders should run this city's 37,000man police force. From conversations with numerous police experts in and out of the department, it appears that Mr. Murphy's decision will mean the depar ture in the coming weeks and months of many of the high police officials now in power.

title: MONSANTO PRICES UP ON PLASTIC BOTTLES
description: The Monsanto Company an nounced yesterday that it would follow OwensIllinois, Inc., in raising prices on all high and lowdensity poly ethylene plastic bottles by 4 per cent, effective Nov. 1.

title: Bridge:
description: The first suit bid by a player whose opponents have opened the bidding almost always shows at least a five card suit. Awareness of this rule makes some spectacular bids possible. An example is the diagramed deal, played last Sunday in the New York New Jersey regional cham pionships.

title: A POLLUTION WATCH URGED BY SCIENTISTS
description: ROME, Sept. 30  Scien tists from 42 countries today endorsed a proposal that the United Nations organize and operate a global system of sta tions on land and sea and in orbit to watch for subtle but potentially disastrous changes in the environment.

title: Napoles Brings Knockout Punch Into Garden Match
description: In the last seven years Jos Napoles, the Cubanborn resi dent of Mexico City, has won 36 of 37 fights and 32 of them by knockout. Those feats have earned him a rep utation as one of the most exicting and most efficient professional boxers in the world.

title: Passive Policy Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  A Harvard economist urged to day that the United States con duct a passive balanceof payments policy and pursue monetary policies that are best for domestic goals.

title: TORY RIGHT ATTACKS GUERRILLA'S RELEASE
description: LONDON, Oct. 1The Gov ernment faced an attack from the right today for having re leased Leila Khaled and flown her and six other Arab terror ists from Europe to Cairo.

title: Jersey G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 1 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Sgt. Gus Pippins, a soldier from Burling ton. N. J., had been killed in action in Indochina.

title: THOMAS M. BAINBRIDGE
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 1 Thomas M. Bainbridge, former controller of the CocaCola Ex port Corporation in New York, died at Princeton Hospital yes terday after a long illness. He was 72 years old and had lived here for several years.

title: GRAEBNER BEATEN BY KOCH ON COAST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI)  Fifthseeded Clark Graebner was upset today by Thomas Koch of Brazil in the third round at the Pacific Coast international open tennis tour nament.

title: Schering Corp. Announces Management Realignment
description: W. H. Conzen, president of the Schering Corporation, an nounced yesterday that Donald R. Longman had been appoint ed executive vice president in a realignment of the company's corporate management.

title: Peru Cancels Concessions Held By Asarco on Copper Deposits
description: The Peruvian Government said yesterday in Lima that it had canceled concessions on rich copper deposits held by the American Smelting and Re fining Company in the north ern part of the country and had returned these mineral rights to Peru.

title: Newspaper Week Is Set
description: ALBANY, Oct. 1 (UPI)Gov ernor Rockefeller proclaimed today Oct. 4 to 10 as newspaper week and Oct. 10 as newspaper boy day.

title: Appellate Court Rules Against Conservation Party
description: ALBANY, Oct. 1  The Ap pellate Division of State Su preme Court today reversed a lower. court decision and ruled unanimously that Richard L. Ottinger cannot use the Con servation party in his bid for the U.S. Senate.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
Catholics Plan $50Million Drive To Combat Poverty in the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1The Unit ed States Catholic Conference announced today a campaign to raise at least $50million in an effort to break the hellish circle of poverty.

title: French Increase Lead to 7 Shots In Women's Golf
description: MADRID, Oct. 1, (Reuters) France increased its lead over the favored United States from four to seven strokes today as scores soared in heavy winds on the second day of the world women's amateur team golf championship.

title: Albatross Draping His Owner With Nothing but Good Fortune
description: YONKERS, Oct. 1As many a baseball general manager would admit, the best deals are often the ones he fails to make. For example, a pitcher he had tried to sell and didn't devel oped into a consistent winner, or an outfielder taken off the market because the price was not right helped win a pennant.

title: FIVE ARE INDICTED IN POLICE KILLING
SEX CASE DEFENDANT A SUICIDE IN JERSEY
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 1  William J. Bonforte, 26 years old, one of the seven suspended Long Branch police men awaiting sentencing on charges of misconduct in of fice stemming from alleged mo ral offenses involving a 17 yearold West Long Branch girl last May, died today from a selfinflicted bullet wound in the head, according to the po lice.

title: DOROTHY ALLEN
description: Dorothy Allen, a former stage and film actress, died Wednes day at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. She was 74 years old and lived at 425 West 57th street.

title: Lightweights Get Ultimatum
description: MANILA, Oct. 1 (UPI)The World Boxing Council an nounced today that Pedro Car rasco of Spain and Mando Ramos of the United States had 15 days to sign for a fight to fill the vacant W.B.C. ver sion of the world lightweight championship. The fight was ordered to fill the vacancy caused when Ismael Laguna of Panama was stripped of the title for failing to defend the championship under an Olym pic Boxing Club of Los An geles contract.

title: A Firm Investigator
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 It was a stifling August day in Jackson, Miss. In a motel banquet room, flanked by huge photographs of a dormi tory sprayed with bullet holes, a television reporter talked about the night of May 14. Would you play the tape? he was asked. And then the Presi dent's Commis sion on Campus Unrest heard the sounds that ac companied two deaths and 12 injuries at Jackson State College.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, Oct. 1, 1970

title: Ford Foundation Gives $2Million To Assist the Arts
description: The Ford Foundation has announced a new series of grants totaling $2million for support of the arts and scholar ship in the humanities.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yes terday as volume dropped be cause of the religious holiday.

title: $10Million Merchant Marine Institute to Open in 71
description: A $10million training in stitute to provide merchant marine officers with the lat est, technology in ship opera tions will open next year near Baltimore, shipping in dustry and labor officials an nounced yesterday.

title: Celanese to Pare Workers by 2,000
description: The Celanese Corporation an nounced yesterday that it planned to reduce its domestic work force of 25,600 by about 2,000 persons between now and June 1, 1971.

title: John Replaces Johnny For Quick Shot on TV
description: When television announcer Ed McMahon called out, And here's John last night at the start of the ninth year of The Johnny Carson Show on N.B.C. there was a sur prise walkon  Mayor John Lindsay.

title: Slowing Pace Indicated In Monetary Expansion
description: The pace of monetary ex pansion may be slowing a bit, figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

title: Barbara Hershey Stars in Bridges's The Baby Maker
Mrs. Dempsey Cards a 75 To Win Long Island Prize
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 1  Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock scored 35, 40 75 today to win low gross in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's oneday tourna ment at the North Hempstead Country Club. Par for the 5,748 yard course is 36, 3874.

title: A Boutique for Men, but It Has a Wider Appeal
description: It's called The Men's Bou tique, and Saks Fifth Avenue has done it up with ostrich walls, a beamed ceiling, indi rect lighting and a Portu guese carpet, but neither the name nor the ambiance has discouraged female shoppers. The boutique, sectioned off from the men's department on the main floor, is home to a vari ty of fashions for the man who likes to put to gether his own outfit, rather than rely on the traditional suit. There are jersey shirts in Jacquard and geometric patterns ($30 to $42.50), Shetland sweaters in a multitude of colors ($20 and $25), pigskin sports jackets ($135 to $215) and a jersey blazer that is particularly popular ($95).

title: Mrs. Nixon Pays a Visit To a Children's Center
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Mrs. Rich ard M. Nixon visited a children's recreation center here today, where she shook hands with several children and was serenaded by a 4yearold girl singing about a bear.

title: Bonn Seems Pleased
description: BONN, Oct. 1  The West German Government said to day that it regarded the course of yesterday's fourpower meeting in Berlin as a sign) that the current series of con tacts was getting down to business.

title: Rarities in Antiques Plentiful As Hartford Opens a Season
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 1The first important antiques show of the season in the East opened here today at the State Armory, the focus of specialized collectors and of dealers hoping to detect an upturn trend in trade.

title: Tax Commissioner Named
description: Herbert Dicker, a lawyer, was named yesterday as a member of the City Tax Com mission by Mayor Lindsay. Mr. Dicker succeeds Benjamin G. Browdy, who resigned last month from the $12,250ayear post.

title: GREYHOUND SEEKS REST OF ARMOUR
description: The Greyhound Corporation, which owns 86 per cent of the common stock of Armour & Co., announced yesterday it would make a proposal to minority shareholders of the packing company to acquire their stock.

title: WEAVER STAYS OR AS ORIOLES' PILOT
Life, Citing Costs, to Cut Circulation and Ad Rate
description: Life magazine, following an industry trend triggered by ris ing costs, will cut its circula tion and its advertising page rates and increase its subscrip tion costs. It will also kill its international editions because of inadequate advertising reve nues.

title: F .T .C . Defers TarListing Rule on Cigarette Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Federal Trade Commission, giv ing the tobacco industry an op portunity to act voluntarily, has temporarily set aside a reg ulation requiring that tar and nicotine content be disclosed in cigarette advertisements.

description: Thursday, Oct 1, 1970

title: 2 Children Found Dead in the Bronx; Mother Questioned
description: Two girlsone 3 years old and the other 4 months old, were found dead in their Bronx apartment last night, and preliminary examination indi cated they had been dead from one to two months.

title: Major League Baseball

title: Launching Sites Other Than Cape Kennedy Studied for Space Shuttle Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is con sidering sites other than Cape Kennedy, Fla., as headquarters for its manned flight activities as part of a postApollo change of direction that could include participation by other nations.

title: Dakota Indians Ask Aid of Reservations For Protest Drive
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., Oct., 1 (AP) Indian protesters at Mount Rushmore National Me morial in the Black Hills, 25 miles southwest of Rapid City, are keeping their protest point manned and seeking support on South Dakota reservations for their movement.

title: Port Operations Leave Pennsy Head Gloomy
description: The Penn Central's new president, William H. Moore, looked over the railroad's vast port operations here yesterday and was not happy with them.

title: Draft Aide Doubts Loophole Users Would Make Good Soldiers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1A Se lective Service System spokes man said today that the new regulation making it possible for certain young men to avoid the draft had been issued be cause some draft boards were not enforcing the old rule and because men who were willing, to go to great lengths to es cape the draft would not make good soldiers anyway.

title: Rocket Firing Postponed
description: WALLOP'S ISLAND, Va., Oct. 1 (UPI)  Unfavorable weather at a tracking station on the North Carolina coast forced the postponement today of the firing of a rocket carry ing a device to spread a 300 milelong cloud of pastel bari um gas over the Eastern Sea board. The test is designed to gain information about elec tronic and magnetic fields in the upper atmosphere.

title: EDWIN CLARK, 66, TRANSPORT AIDE
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y. Oct. 1  Edwin Frederick Clark, who was credited with having conceived the plan of a oneway traffic movement in Normandy known to G.I.'s as the Red Ball Highway, died today in Phelps Memorial Hos pital. He was 66 years old and lived at 2 Highland Avenue.

title: Snow in New Hampshire
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Oct. 1 (AP)New Hampshire's 6,288foot Mount Washington and a halfhundred other 4,000 footers in the White Mountains were topped with snow as September ended, weather observatory officials reported today.

title: C. & O. RAIL PROFIT DIPS IN QUARTER

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of Ameri can forces in South Vietnam, is recovering satisfactorily after collapsing yesterday, a military spokesman said today. He re ported that the general was resting comfortably in an army hospital.

title: Robustelli's Status Doubtful
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 1 (AP) Rick Robustelli, University of Connecticut quarterback, will likely miss Saturday's game at the University of New Hamp shire. He jammed the fourth finger on his nompassing hand in the first half of last week end's game against Yale.

title: SWITZERLAND BANS SALES OF I.O.S. FUND
Kosygin Assures Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1 (UPI)  The Soviet Union assured Egypt to day of continued support in all fields and expressed confi dence that the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser would not create a vacuum that would weaken the country.

title: Princeton Eleven Is Cramming For Columbia Psychology Test
description: The last time a Columbia football team beat a Prince ton team was in 1945. A great deal of emotion can be built up over that fact, and that is what worries Jake McCan dless, the Tiger coach. Allud ing to the possibility of Columbia's psychological edge, McCandless said yester day, If I were on that end of the stick, I would use guns, firebombs, hand grenades and piano wire to win. Speaking of weap ons, McCandless has a few of his own, notably Rod Plummer, Brian McCullough and John Bjorklund. Bjork lund and McCullough ran round, through and over Rut gers last week and Plummer, a junior quarterback, handled the proset offense with poise, as well as running and passing.

title: Jordan Now Conciliatory Toward Al Fatah
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 1 The new Jordanian government said today that it would deal with and support the main com mando group, Al Fatah, as the sole legitimate Palestinian guer rilla organization.

title: Policing the Airports
description: Congress can make an immediate and substantial con tribution to the war against organized crime by author izing extension of the policing powers of the Waterfront Commission to include airports in the metropolitan area. The urgency of such action was highlighted by this week's declaration of Frederick H. Lacey, United States Attorney for New Jersey, that Kennedy Airport has become an open city for underworld syndicates.

title: Arabs March in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Fifteen Arab youths were ar rested in Israel today as tens of thousands of Arabs marked President Nasser's funeral with mourning processions. The pro cessions and religious services were held in the occupied ter ritories and in Israel herself.

title: Drug Aides Protest
description: Thirteen workers who dis pense methadone to 200 out patients at Harlem Hospital ended a threehour work stop age yesterday after the hospi tal director, Elliot Roberts, met their demand for $100 each as part of eight weeks back sal ary due them. Mr. Roberts said they had been hired in August before financing for an expan sion of the hospital's detoxifi cation center was completed.

title: Congressional Race: Reapportioned 9County 28th District Favors the G.O.P. Candidate
