description: The stock market finished yesterday on an even keel as trading fell to its slowest pace in six weeks. Volume on the New York Stock. Exchange amounted to 9.7 million shares.

title: Johnson Takes Batting Title

The hits raised Johnson's average to .3289. Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox finished with a .3286 average.

description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 1  Nine European countries and the United States agreed today to prepare a plan to help bear the cost of keeping American troops in Europe while increas ing West Europe's contribu tion to its own defense.

title: Screen: Story of a Student Filmmaker
description: "Cover Me Babe," which opened yesterday at the Astor and Baronet Theaters, is the sort of movie that needs the words of a critic less than it requires the services of an analyst, displaying, as it does, a compulsive need to ridicule itself, to deny its basic intelligence and to fail. It accomplishes all of these things with an idiocy that should warm the neurotic heart.The film is the second feature to be directed by Noel Black, the young man who gained a worthy reputation in some circles for his first feature, "Pretty Poison," although the good things in that film seemed to me then (and even more so now) to have been the contributions of the scriptwriter, Lorenzo Semple Jr., and the star, Tony Perkins, rather than the decisions made by the director.In "Cover Me Babe," Mr. Black and his scriptwriter, George Wells, are presenting a portrait of an artist as a student filmmaker. The movie opens with a long excerpt from a surreal short made by the hero, Tony Hall, and it's so terrible, so full of the clichs of the avant-garde, that it seems  at least at firstthat Mr. Black and Mr. Wells have some perspective about their subject. However, it's quickly apparent that they didn't.Tony is a rude, quarrelsome fellow who refuses to knuckle under to Establishment procedure. He turns down a chance to work for a major company, saying they'd probably want him to make movies with plots and characters. Instead, Tony seeks to capture reality on screen by running around town with a hand-held camera, shooting such things as a couple making love in a car, which he then juxtaposes with a shot of a mother trying to revive her drowned child, accompanied by a laugh track. (Just one of the film's many improbabilities is that the other film students take Tony seriously. The ones I know would have booted him out of the hall.)When his girl says that his new script makes no sense, Tony comes back with: "Does war make sense? Does cancer? Does a freeway smashup?" Lines like these prompt Melisse to go to bed with Tony: "He makes me feel alive. He shows me the way things are."They also create the impression that Mr. Black and Mr. Wells have probably made just the kind of film that Tony would have, had he been given the opportunity by a major studioplotless and characterless, all right, but loaded with its own clichs of dialogue, attitude and style. The crowning (I assume, unintentional) irony, of course, is that although Tony keeps railing against the studio system, "Cover Me Babe" was financed by 20th Century-Fox, which should really know better. The cast is headed by Robert Forster, who wrestled somewhat more successfully with problems of illusion and reality in "Medium Cool," and who seems a little elderly to be entirely convincing as a student filmmaker.Although "Cover Me Babe" is a second feature, it looks very much like a first and had it been a novel, instead of a movie, it would have probably stayed in somebody's trunk. The one truth that the movie presents has to do with the terrible economics of moviemaking. Because of the huge investments involved, even mistakes like this can't be allowed the honor of decent obscurity.

title: Dr. Douglas Maynard Named Provost of Hunter College
description: The appointment of Dr. Doug las Maynard as vice president and provost of Hunter College was announced yesterday. He bad previously served as dean of humanities and the arts, and as acting president.

title: Spiro Agnew vs. the Republican Party
description: The strength of Vice President Agnew's political campaign against the Democrats is that he has been as plain as a punch in the nose. At a time when people are confused and bored with the complexities of modern issues, he came on clear and strong against sin and blamed it all on the wicked Democrats.

title: Market Place:
description: Perhaps you've heard story like this. The irate cus tomer brings his new car back to the dealer several times, complaining about a mysterious rattle. Bafflement turns to shock when it is dis covered that a production line worker had deliberately welded the gas tank together with a pop bottle inside.

title: Adams Says Rockefeller Hides Need for New Tax to Win Votes
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 1 Dr. Paul L. Adams accused Governor Rockefeller today of postponing until after the elec tion a monumental $1billion tax increase the state will in evitably need just to keep up with current spending pro grams and costs mandated this year for next year.

title: Cambodia's 3 Major Highways Are Cut or Attacked by Enemy
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 1 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces have cut or attacked Cambodia's three post important highways lead ing from Pnompenh to major centers to the southeast, south west and northwest.

title: Drama: The Ritual of Dracula Sabbat
China at 21
description: Premier Chou Enlai turned in a lowkey performance in his speech on the eve of yesterday's celebration of the 21st anniversary of the Chinese People's Republic. While he sounded no major new themes, he strengthened the impression that China's rulers now seek a return to more normal conditions after the ravages of the great proletarian cultural revolution.

title: Share in French Ediscience Acquired by McGrawHill
description: McGrawHill, the American publishing company, has ac quired a major interest in Edi science, a small French scien tific textbook publishing house with headquarters in Paris, it was announced here yesterday.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE FELL 5.2% IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept 26 were both below the volume for the corresponding week of last year.

title: Nicklaus Trails by 2 Shots
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Jean Garaialde of France shot a twounderpar 69 today and increased his lead over Jack Nicklaus of Co lumbus, Ohio, to two strokes in the Volvo open golf tourna ment. The 35yearold profes sional has a tworound total of 136 at the halfway mark in the tournament. Nicklaus carded a 70.

title: Miss Myers To Be Bride
description: SLATE HILL, N. Y., Oct. 1 Miss Margaret Elizabeth Myers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Daniel Myers, plans to be married in April to Stephen Ackley Towl of Briarcliff Manor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Theodore Towl of Rhinebeck, N. Y.

description: were killed and 344 were wounded last week, an in crease of 11 in each category over the previous week. The toll raised to 43,737 the num ber of Americans killed in the war since Jan. 1, 1961.

description: The notion that this year's crop of 2yearolds was some thing less than special had to be revised yesterday at Bel mont Park after Hoist the Flag won the $65,200 Cowdin Stakes.

title: Germany Reports Surplus
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The Federal Bank said today that West Ger many's basic balance of pay ments in August showed a sur plus of 169million marks against a 458millionmark sur plus in July and a deficit of 1,453,000,000 marks in August, 1969.

title: Access to the Village Green
description: Those who favor unlimited television spending in political campaigns are not giving up just because Con gress has finally passed a bill to impose some restraints. There is increasing pressure on President Nixon to veto the measure, much of it on plainly spurious grounds.

title: Creaks in the Machinery
description: At the time of the AllStar game.in mid July, the Cincinnati Reds were doing such a steamroller job on the opposition that their overjoyed supporters in the American Rhineland were carried away by the spirit of Gemtlichkeit and were extravagantly referring to their heroes as The Big Red Machine. The nickname was also grudg ingly accepted by those not quite so deeply in love with them.

title: Brave Horse, Cruel Rider
description: A Tennessee walking horse was originally a trotter who would not trot. Instead, he had an odd but attrac tive gait, halfway between a walk and a trot. Because he could move at a speed of six to eight miles an hour and give his rider a comfortable, rocking chair kind of ride, the Tennessee walking horse became a favorite of overseers and plantation owners in the South who had to ride great distances every day.

title: JIMI HENDRIX RITES ARE HELD IN SEATTLE
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 1Jimi Hen drix, the rock guitarist who died in London on Sept. 18 at the age of 27, was buried in Greenwood Cemetery in subur ban Renton today after a brief and simple funeral service in the Dunlap Baptist Church.

title: Books of The Times
description: There's more to this Beethoven book than meets the eye. On the surface it bears all the stigmata of a coffee table book: elaborate makeup, tinted paper, pages of glossy prints in black and white and at tractive color. It is large in size and reason ably expensiveall in all a fit and hand some contribution to the Beethoven bicen tenary that falls this year. It can be thumbed through with pleasure. There are samples from the scores In Beeth oven's handwriting with corrections and cancellations. There are portraits of various and sun dry people who were in one way or another connected with Beethoven: princes and page turners, fiddlers who played his quartets, women he loved, music publishers who profited from him, good friends who bore his tantrums. Virtually all the likenesses and sketches of Beethoven have been included, among them the pow erful sculpture by Franz Klein and the death mask by Joseph Danhauser. There are all sorts of pleasing prospects of Vienna and its suburbs, places the composer lived in or which were the scenes of his triumphs and failures. Some of the illustrations are enticing in minor ways. Did you know that one of Beethoven's patrons, Prince Kinsky, wore gold earrings?

title: The Monitor Goes to 15c
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The Christian Science Monitor said in today's editions that it was raising its newsstand price from 10 cents to 15 cents im mediately. The newspaper said it was also increasing its an nual subscription rate to $30, except $28 in London.

title: Bridge
description: It pays to remember that bridge players, being human, are liable to error. On the diagramed deal, played last Sunday in the Swiss team event in the New YorkNew Jersey regionals, South was in a hopeless situation and knew it. But he gave his opponents a chance to be generous, and they took it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: When the Canadian Gov ernment announced last month that there would be no hunting season for wood cock in New Brunswick prov ince this fall, it was, to this writer's knowledge, the first time in North America that a game bird had been ruled offlimits because concentra tions of DDT it contained were considered a menace to public health.

title: Heart Transplant in 3d Year
description: VALPARAISO, Chile, Oct. 1 (UPI)Elson Oreliana Sanchez, 22 years old, the only Latin American to survive a heart transplant operation, completed the second year of life with his new heart today in the Almirante Naval Hospital here. Although he is still in the hos pital, he lives an otherwise normal life and is in good health, hospital officials say.

title: Advertising: Slalom Day at Della Femina
description: Jerry Della Femina, author and talkshow celebrity, is also an ad man and president of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners. And it was in that capacity yesterday that he was able to announce a new piece of business  Sea & Ski Corporation. The client says the billings are over $2 million a year.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate Finance Committee ten tatively agreed today to give 26.2 million Americans a 10 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, effective next Janu ary.

title: Brewster Is on Tour to Improve Image of University
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1  Kingman Brewster Jr., the pres ident of Yale University, flew here today on the first leg of a tour through the Midwest that is intended to convince the public that not all students are crazies, not all faculty members are enemies of pub lic order.

title: Radiation Standards Bill Seen As Yielding Federal Authority
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The House passed yesterday a bill that would restrict the author ity of the new Environmental Protection Agency to set radia tion protection standards. Op position to the bill was forming in the Senate today.

title: Fear of Sabotage Spurs Industrial Security Drive
description: Corporate managers in all parts of the country, concerned about the increasing frequency of bombings and other forms of sabotage, are taking strong measures to protect their em ployes and their plants.

title: LAWRENCE ZIMMER, EXN.Y.U. PROFESSOR
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 1 Lawrence W. Zimmer, a retired associate professor of manage ment at New York University School of Commerce, died to day in Nassau Hospital, Mine ola, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 74 Kenwood Road.

title: CeaseFire in the North
description: RAMTHA, Jordan, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Guerrillas began handing in their guns and dis arming their road mines today after Jordanian Army and Pal estinian guerrilla officers signed an agreement to restore peace in northern Jordan.

title: Martha Graham, 76, to Dance No More
Pulaski Parade Set Sunday
description: More than 100,000 Americans of Polish descent are expected to march in the 34th annual Pulaski Day Parade, which will be held this Sunday on Fifth Avenue. The line of march will extend from 26th Street to 52d Street and will begin at 1 P.M. The parade marks 191st anni versary of the death of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, who was killed while fighting in the American Revolution.

title: SOFTWARE MAKER FILES BANKRUPTCY
description: Computer Applications, Inc., one of the nation's first and largest computer software con cerns, filed a petition yester day for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Ballgivers Ball Planned in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1The Ball givers Ball, a tribute to the organizations that annually stage benefit balls and other fundraising events in the Greater Boston area, will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the SheratonBoston Hotel here next Thursday.

title: Excerpts From Panel's Report on Shootings at Jackson State College
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Following are excerpts from the findings and conclusions of the President's Commis sion on Campus Unrest in its special report, The Killings at Jackson State, released today:

title: Byrd Besting Rivals as an Independent
description: MANASSAS, Va., Sept. 30 With the luck and shrewd tac tics that helped the Confeder ates win the Battle of Bull Run, Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. is fighting off the emerging politi cal center and left in this Northlooking Southern state in a leisurely reelection campaign that he seems almost certain to win.

title: Emotional Announcers In Cairo Break Down
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1 (AP)Sev eral Cairo radio announcers (broke down with emotion as they described the funeral procession for Gamal Abdel Nasser today and had to be replaced.

title: ChiliBeef Dish Is on Weekend Menu
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Emerson Overcomes Pilic In Rich Canadian Tennis
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) Roy Emerson, 33yearold Aus tralian, defeated Nicki Pilic, 76, 16, 64, in a match, which lasted nearly two hours, in the $40,000 international tennis tournament last night.

title: Senate Votes Federal Powers To Enforce Ban on Hiring Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate marked the probable end of a decade of controver sial civil rights legislation to day by passing a bill giving the Federal Government the power to move against discrim ination in employment.

title: Hundreds Reported Injured
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1 (AP)Hun dreds of people were reported to have been injured and at least one was killed today in the crush as President Nasser's funeral procession passed by.

title: Prisoners Seize Hostages, Take Over Jail in Queens
description: Rioting prisoners took over the Long Island City branch of the Queens House of Detention yesterday, seizing seven hos tages and demanding a parley with city officials on live tele vision.

title: 5,000 Polls to Open For a 3Day Period To Register Voters
description: More than 5,000 polling places will be open here to register voters during a three day period beginning tomorrow and continuing on Monday and Tuesday.

title: 28th Congressional District Facts
description: POPULATION  409,030, based on 1960 Census figures, for large predominantly agri cultural area comprising Co lumbia, Delaware, Greene, Otsego, Schoharie, and Ulster Counties as well as parts of Dutchess, Montgomery and Sullivan counties. Largest city is Kingston.

title: 600 ArabAmericans March Up Fifth Avenue Here in Display of Grief Over Nasser
description: A procession of 600 chanting ArabAmericans marched slow ly up Fifth Avenue yesterday in an outpouring of grief over, the death of Gamal Abdel Nas ser.

title: Senate Leaders in Both Parties Denounce Findings of Pornography Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate expressed strong opposition today to the findings of the Federal Commis sion on Obscenity and Porno graphy, which were made pub lic yesterday.

title: Bronx Landlords Lose Rent Cut Suit
description: A State Supreme Court Jus tice upheld yesterday the city's authority to begin rent reduc tion proceedings when services to apartment house tenants are reduced, even in cases when the diminution of services re sults from a strike.

title: SCHOOL IN SYRACUSE CLOSED BY VIOLENCE
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 1  The pupils of Eastwood Junior High School here were sent home today after Adolph Miller, an industrial arts teacher, received minor cuts while attempting to take a meat cleaver away from a 14yearold girl. Another girl received an arm injury after being pushed into a wall dur ing a fight.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: DRUGMERGER BAR SOUGHT BY CELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Anti trust Subcommittee, asked the Justice Department today to prevent a merger between the WarnerLambert Pharmaceutic al Company and Parke, Davis & Co.

title: PUBLIC LINKS PRO CARDS 70 FOR 288
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 1As his sixstroke lead vanished for the metropolitan open golf title, the defending champion, Jimmy Wright, finished in a tie with Jim Albus, the professional from the Latourette course, Staten Island, a New York City public layout.

title: Mary Marston, '65 Debutante, Fiancee of Andrew S. Gagarin
description: Miss Mary Collier Marston, an editorial researcher with Reader's Digest in New York, and Andrew Serge Gagarin, who attends the Columbia Graduate School of Business, plan to be mar ried.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON EDGE DOWN A BIT
description: The London stock market closed slightly lower yesterday as profittaking and caution on the Middle East situation com bined to reverse the recent ad vance. Trading was quiet.

title: A's to Name Pilot Today
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. I (AP)Charles 0. Finley said he would announce tomorrow the manager of his Oakland Athletics baseball club for next season.

title: Officials Decline Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Gov. John Bell Williams and Mayor Russell Davis of Jackson said they would make no com ment until reading the com mission's report.

title: ACTION BY SENATE ON INSURANCE DUE
description: An interindustry task force working for the passage of legislation to create a Federally backed investorinsurance pro gram received word yesterday that the Senate version of the bill might be voted on next week.

title: Nixon Aide Says He Misjudged Scope of a Segregation Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The Nixon Administration's long awaited guidelines prohibiting segregation within individual schools have been delayed be cause of underestimation of the scope of the problem, an Ad ministration official said today.

title: U.S. AIDS A PLAN FOR LINCOLN TUBE
description: The Federal Government an nounced yesterday a $500,000 grant for an experiment de signed to move people faster through the Lincoln Tunnel during the morning rush hour using a special access lane re served for buses.

title: Directory to Dining
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: ART MUSEUM BEGINS CHABROL FILM FETE
description: Fourteen movies by Claude Chabrol, the French director who became one of the leading exponents of the New Wave, will be presented today through Oct. 14 at the Museum of Mod ern Art.

title: Tigers Expected to Name Martin as Manager Today
description: DETROIT, Oct. I (AP) The Detroit Tigers announced today that a news conference would be held tomorrow at Tiger Stadium, but declined to dis close the subject.

title: Fair for Nassau Hospital
description: Special to The New York Times

title: LARGE G.O.P. FUND IS GIVEN TO TEXAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Figures compiled by Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon showed today that Senator John G. Tower, chairman of the Republican Senate Cam paign Committee, had allotted nearly twice as much in party funds to his fellow Texan, George Bush, as to any other, Senate candidate.

title: Avco Sets BillPaying Plan
description: The Avco Savings and Loan Association, Los Angeles, has moved to take advantage of new Federa 1 regulations that permit associations to make payments to third parties from the accounts of depositors. Avco thus becomes one of the first associations in the nation to announce a billpaying sav ings account, which has the, ef fect of increasing the amount of time that deposits earn in terest before money is paid out to creditors.

title: NORTON CO. SLATES 6% PRICE INCREASES
description: Price increases averaging 6 per cent on most of its product lines were announced yesterday by the vacuum equipment divi sion of the Norton Company.

title: Senate Votes Money For New ABM Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The Senate completed ac tion today on a $19.9billion military procurement bill au thorizing expansion of the Safeguard antimissile system.

title: Thieu Proposes a Budget Of $16.9Billion for 1971
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (Reuters)President Nguyen van Thieu submitted to the lower house of the legislature a proposed national budget for 1971 of $16.9billion, it was disclosed today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Philip Burton is a practitioneran actor, director and teacher who has worked in the theater here and abroad for nearly 50 years. And he is right, of course. Shake speare was meant to be staged, and many of us have lost sight of that in our zeal to understand his art exactly. Hamlet may very well be an expression of the bafflement of [its] creator in the face of his artistic problem, as T. S. Eliot wrote in a famous essay. And the play may be what Francis Fergusson called ritual and improvisation. But Hamlet also plays, as they used to say along Shubert Alley. And in order for it to keep playing in future productions, the actors who act it must indeed not be concerned with the signifi cance of a character, but only with its truth, as Mr. Burton writes. And the director must figure out what happens in Hamlet stage.

title: Congressional Awards Given
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP)  Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey Jr., Republican of California, received the Na tional Congressional Award for their work to improve the quality of the environment at the closing session of the Na tional Recreation and Parks Association convention.

title: MRS. TERESA G. FISCHER
description: Mrs. Teresa Golffing Fischer, consumerrelations manager of MEM Company, manufacturers of men's toiletries, in North ville, N. J., died in Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 250 East 65th Street.

title: Linda Beard Betrothed To J. H. Brandi, Yale 70
description: The engagement of Miss Linda Osborn Beard, a debu tante of 1965, to James Howell Brandi, who attends Naval Officer Candidate School in Newport, R. I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah R. Beard of New York and East Hamp ton, L. I., parents of the future bride Her fianc is the son of Frederic H. Brandi, chairman of Dillon, Read & Co., Inc., investment bankers, and Mrs. Brandi of New York and Great Barrington, Mass.

title: Obscenity Report to Be Book
description: A Bantam Books paperback edition of the report of the Na tional Commission on Obscen ity and Pornography will be made available at $1.65 by the publishing company within two weeks. The book, which will carry the entire report, in ad dition to the dissenting opinions and appendix material, has an introduction written by Clive Barnes, dance and drama critic of The New York Times. A hardcover edition will be pub lished Nov. 3 by Random House.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 4 More Destroyers Raise 6th Fleet's Strength to 55
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Four more destroyers joined the sixth Fleet in the Mediter ranean today.

title: GLADWIN SCORES IN $130,320 RACE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP)  Gladwin, owned by Hastings Harcourt, smashed the Haw thorne Park 1mile record today in scoring a 3length victory in the $130,320 Haw thorne Gold Cup.

title: A Poignant Display Of Eakins's Photos
description: The exhibition of about 200 photographs by or about Thomas Eakins that opened Wednesday at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle should by any reason able premise have been in cluded as an appendix to the big Eakins show at the Whit ney. It surely cannot be more than a mildly interesting ex hibition to anyone who is not familiar with Eakins's paint ing, but to anyone who is, it is a collection of vivid, poign ant and instructive docu ments. Hence the advice is to visit the Whitney a few times and then get to Colum bus Circle.

title: 4 Sparmates Jolt Ali In 14Round TuneUp
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP)Muhammed All was rocked several times by four sparring partners today as the former heavyweight champion went 14 rounds in an endurance test.

title: ANTIBUSING LAW FOR STATE VOIDED BY FEDERAL COURT
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1  New York State's socalled anti busing law, which has served as a model for Southern school districts seeking to avoid ra cial integration, was declared unconstitutional today by a threejudge Federal Court here.

title: G.O.P Names Mrs. Swanke
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Mrs. Albert Homer Swanke of New York, formerly of Louisiana, was named today as chairman of the women's divi sion of the Republican National Finance Committee. She served as vice chairman of the Repub lican State Central Committee and president of the State Federation of Women's Repub lican Clubs when she lived in Louisiana.

title: INSURANCE IN SLUMS UPHELD IN COURT
description: The State Superintendent of Insurance has the authority to compel a reluctant insurance company to provide extend ed coverage to a business in a slum area, State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein ruled yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
Boycott Plan Gains
description: MONTREAL, Oct, 1 (Cana dian Press)  The council of the International Civil Aviation Organization narrowly ap proved today a United States proposal calling for a multi lateral agreement to end air services to countries involved in hijacking planes for inter national blackmail.

title: A STRONG ISRAEL LINKED TO PEACE
description: A strong Israel, emphasizing democratic ideals and princi ples, is necessary for a per manent peace in the Middle East, a Conservative rabbi said yesterday in his Rosh ha Shanah sermon.

title: Theater: An Enticingly Titled Wuziz?'; Donald Kvares Play Is at the Old Reliable; Cave Man and Woman Portrayed in Skits
description: The Old Reliable is a friendly neighborhood tavern in the depths of the Lower East Sideon Third Street between Avenues B and C. Its cozy back room is a friendly neighborhood theater pre senting mostly new plays; free, all season long, Mondays through Fridays. The current production is Wuziz! an enticingly titled new play by Donald Kvares whose 16 previous works have appeared all over the off Off Broadway circuit.

title: Construction Surges
description: Contracts for new construc tion work in the continental United States bounded upward in August, indicating a recov ery from the decline in con tract placements experienced last spring.

title: Nasser Funeral Is Disrupted by Frenzy of Millions
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1President Ga mal Abdel Nasser was buried today after a tumultuous, fren zied funeral procession through streets packed with millions of the Egyptians he had led for 18 years.

title: New Realism, Old Reality
description: President Nixon's European journey, capping the series of September crises, must have confused foreign analysts as much as it befuddled American experts. Both, for their own reasons, had thought increasingly that the United States was withdrawing from extensive world commitments into neo isolationism.

title: Extemporizing Singer Goes Out on Limb With Ideas
description: Steve DePass is a daring young man who steps out on the floor of the Rainbow Grill and makes up most of his songs as he goes along. They are, as a rule, amusing, gay, witty, maybe a little bit ri bald. At the same time, he says a great deal more about contemporary life than is usually heard on a supper club floor.

title: Letter Linked to Bond
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)Wes tinghouse Broadcasting Com pany's WBZTV said tonight that Bond had identified him self as commanderinchief, Revolutionary Action Force East.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
BEMAN'S 63 LEADS AZALEA OPEN BY 2
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Oct. 1 (AP)Deane Beman shot an eightunderpar 63 to take the firstround lead by two strokes in the $60,000 Azalea open golf tournament today. Beman had eight birdies and 10 pars in his 30, 33 round to tie the Cape Fear Country Club course rec ord.

title: Two Named at Columbia
description: Dr. William J. McGill, presi dent of Columbia University, has announced the appointment of K. Mark Lyons 2d as director of development and John Well ington as director of alumni relations. Mr. Lyons, 43 years old, will head a national effort to solicit major gifts from cor porations, foundations and individual donors. Mr. Welling ton, 36, will coordinate the activities of Columbia Univer sity clubs throughout the coun try and the International Alum ni Programs and organize a greater New York area alumni program.

title: JOHN MARTOCCI, 84, OF LITHOGRAPH FIRM
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Sept. 30 John Martocci, retired presi dent of the Empire Color Li thographers, Inc., 200 Varick Street, New York City, died in Memorial Hospital here today of pneumonia while on a vaca tion. He was 84 years old and lived at 686 Harless Place, West Hempstead. L. I.

title: When Is Christ Coming?; The Twenty Signs Of the Bible Give Us a Clue
description: Millions of Americans are caught up in a desperate attempt to know the future. The phenomenal rise in the sale of crystal balls, Ouija boards and Vien nese fortunetelling tarot cards is only a part of the new groping into the future.

title: CHARLES P. BARRY
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 1 Charles P. Barry, a vice presi dent of Union Carbide's Con sumer Products Division in New York, died at Hackensack Hospital today after an illness of several months. He was 64 years old and lived at 286 Edgewood Avenue.

title: ManMade Fuel Crisis
description: It comes as a stunning surprise to most Americans realize that a temporary shortage of coal, oil and natural gas may produce power blackouts and brownouts this winter. That surprise is heightened by the state's notice to New Yorkers that fuel rationing might be necessary here for the first time since World War II. The ordinary citizen's astonishment is justified. If ever there was a manmade crisis, this is it.

title: TATE DEFENDANTS OUSTED BY JUDGE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1The four defendants in the Sharon Tate murder trial were barred from the courtroom this after noon for singing and disrupting the trial.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1970

title: Doric Is Scratch Boat of 24 Off on 125Mile Race Today
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1When turning marks for a distance yacht race that will be re newed tomorrow by the Amer ican Yacht Club were being discussed the New Haven Light was accepted as one of them. The late Roger Sherman, in whose honor the race is held, was graduated from Yale in 1910 and Yale is in New Haven, so what better choice for such a mark than one off the Elm City.

title: World Air Unions To Boycott Nations That Aid Hijackers
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 1 (AP) Airline trade unions from 21 countries agreed today to boy cott airliners representing any nation that harbors or helps aircraft hijackers or saboteurs.

title: $30Million More For Black Colleges Ordered by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Nixon Administration responded to complaints that it is insensitive to Negro ed ucation by announcing today a 30 per cent increase in Fed eral aid for predominantly black colleges.

title: Women in Pants: Even Staid Offices Concede It's Fait Accompli
description: Without any confrontation, demon stration or even artful campaigning, women are securing for themselves an other human right: the right to wear pants to work. The privilege is being granted by men in industry, government, and financial institutions who have long since given up the struggle to keep women from wearing pants at home.

title: White House Aides Strive to Get Nixon To Back Buckley
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Not content with enlisting Vice President Agnew, White House advisers hostile to Senator Charles E. Goodell are work ing to swing President Nixon behind the New Yorker's Con servative opponent, James L. Buckley.

title: Cairo Operators Weep
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP)Inter national telephone operators re ported difficulties today in get ting through to Cairo because operators in the Egyptian capi tal were weeping and emo tional because of the funeral of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Stricken Coach Improved
description: BILBOA, Spain, Oct. 1 (UPI) The condition of Lester E. Lane, coach of the touring American basketball team, im proved today after he was taken to a hospital last night after a heart attack. Lane is a former United States Olympics coach.

title: NearHysterical Sorrow And Despair Grip Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct.1Gamal Ab del Nasser's people were in the street all night, and long before dawn broke over Cairo their cries could be heard.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Thursday, Oct. 1. 28th day. Weather clear, track fast

title: Injuries to McDole and Tatarek Weaken Bills for Game With Jets Sunday
description: The New York Jets, who have found it difficult to beat the Bills in Buffalo over the years, may find the pickings rather easy there Sunday against a Bills team further weakened by recent injuries. Also, Buffalo plans to start its rookie quarter back, Dennis Shaw, of San Diego State.

title: SILVER FUTURES RECOVER LOSSES
description: Silver futures, which had dropped sharply on the Com modity Exchange here on Wednesday, bounced back yes terday. Most of the previous day's declines were recovered. Trading, however, was consid erably slower with only 2,049 transactions, compared with 5,163 contracts moved the day before.

title: Executive Changes
description: Paul Thayer, chairman and president of Ling TemcoVought, Inc., has been elected chairman Jones & Laughlin Industries, Inc., a subsidiary. George Griffin, senior vice president of the parent company, was elected president.

title: Goodell Plans Counterattack
description: Governor Rockefeller attempt ed yesterday to arrange a cease fire in the battle between Vice President Agnew and Senator Charles E. Goodell, but the Sen ator planned to attempt to capitalize on the Agnew attack by making a major issue of what he called the Vice Presi dent's hot rhetoric.

title: Max Rolnik, an Accountant And Teacher. Dies at 80
description: Max Rolnik, a senior partner in the accounting firm of Ly brand, Ross Brothers & Mont gomery, died yesterday, after a long illness, in his home at 1503 East 22d Street in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old.

title: Berthe Gronfein Dies at 59; ExSocial Work Professor
description: Professor Gronfein joined the Adelphi faculty in 1953 and served as a consultant to the school after her retirement in 1969.

title: TAX SCRUTINY DUE IN FIGHT ON CRIME
Raises Voted for Steel Union Leaders
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1  Delegates to the convention of the United Steelworkers of America approved today, by a close vote, substantial salary increases for top officers and directors of the union.

title: A Plea for Experiment
description: On Dec. 1, 1969, the President hand ed me his advance copy of the Com mission Statement on Violent Crime under the chairmanship of Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower and asked me to state my philosophy on this problem.

title: Big Question in Amman: Will Fighting Resume?
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 1  Despite the ceasefire in Am man, guerrillas, army officers, and diplomats all are weigh ing the prospects for another round of fighting between Jor danian troops and Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Cahill Drafts Plan On Transportation
description: Gov. William T. Cahill be lieves that transportation has been his biggest disappointment during his first nine months in office and plans to submit a comprehensive mass trans portation program for northern New Jersey to the Port of New York Authority by the end of the year.

title: Mrs. Helen Crosby West Dead; President of Women's City Club
description: Mrs. Helen Crosby West, president of the Women's City Club from 1961 to 1964 and for many years director of the Bureau of Social and Health Agencies at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday at New York Hos pital after a brief illness. She lived at 309 Avenue C and was 78 years old.

title: Mack Stadium ClosesFans Start Razing Job
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (UPI)  A wild demonstra tion by fans tonight, after the Phillies ended their season with a 21 victory over the Montreal Expos, marked the end of Connie Mack Stadium's (formerly Shibe Park) 61year old history and caused can cellation of postgame cere monies.

title: U.S. Urges Cairo to Help In Reviving Truce Talks
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1  The United States today urged the Egyptian leadership to redouble efforts to get Middle East peace talks back on the track despite the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, who originally accepted the American initiative.

title: Cubs Topple Mets, 41, on 2Hitter by Jenkins and Finish Second in East
description: Year Nine in the history of the New York Mets ended at Shea Stadium last night with the Mets in third place in National League East after a 41 loss at the hands of the Chicago Cubs.

title: From Atlantic to Persian Gull, Arabs March to Honor Nasser
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1 From Dakar on the Atlantic to Qatar on the Persian Gulf, in oases in the Sahara and in the Holy Land, Arabs in the millions marched in mourning today for a man they identified with their national aspirations.

title: Cambodian Regime Firm 6 Months After the Coup
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 1Half a year after the Na tional Assembly deposed the vacationing Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, set ting off a war with Vietna mese Communist troops in bor der sanctuaries, Pnompenh and the roads and waterways with in 50 miles of it are under usu ally secure Government control.

title: N.Y.U. CHIEF SCORES STUDENT RADICALS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1The cause of student idealism is being badly damaged by the oppor tunism and selfindulgence of many of the radical leaders ion campus, Dr. James M. Hes ter, president of New York University, said tonight.

title: Appeal for U.N. Action
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP)  The General Assembly was asked today to explore, as a matter of urgency, international action to deal with aerial hijacking.

title: Soviet Urges Strict Fulfillment Of CeaseFire in the Middle East
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1  The So viet Union, in another plea for a political settlement of the Middle East crisis, called today for strict fulfillment of the ceasefire agreement between Israel and the United Arab Re public and Jordan.

title: Kent Testimony Nears End
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Oct. 1 (UPI) Robert Balyeat, head of the special grand jury investigation into the slaying of four students at Kent State University by National Guardsmen, said today that the testimony should be completed by the middle of next week.

title: Dinner on Oct. 13 Is Set to Benefit A Vassar Drive
description: A dinner will be given on Oct. 13 in the Grand Ball room of the Plaza to benefit Vassar College's $50million capital campaign begun in September of last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mindless Protest at C.C.N.Y.

title: Social Security GrabBag ...
description: The Senate Finance Committee, which has dragged its feet for five months on the Administration's construc tive plan for a guaranteed minimum income for all families, is back at its favorite sport of playing pre election politics with the Social Security system.

title: William Grafenecker, 69, Dies; An Expert on Crime Syndicates
description: William J. Grafenecker, a retired acting police captain, who headed the District At torney's detective squad under Thomas E. Dewey and later under Frank S. Hogan, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 2160 Newbold Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Ottinger Camp Sees Buckley as the Main Target
description: Members of Representative Richard L. Ottinger's campaign staff said yesterday that recent pronouncements by the Nixon Administration had reaffirmed for them that James L. Buck ley is the man to beat.

title: Market Place
description: Baffled Wall Street ana lysts who watched airline is sues soar in yesterday's exu berent stock market think the rises took place in the face of so much bad news that levita tion is perhaps the best ex planation for the strength.

title: Pittsburgh: A Brawny City Puts On a Silk Shirt
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1Pitts burgh's Golden Triangle is gleaming in the October sun, its sometimes acrid air washed clean by the breezes of fall. United States Steel is moving into its downtown skyscraper. And the Pirates are moving into the National League playoffs Saturday with Cincinnati at their sparkling new stadum just across the Allegheny from the glories of Gateway Center.

title: U.S. Offices in Argentina Hit in a Series of Bombings
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Bombs were thrown in a series of simultaneous at tacks on offices of United States and West German com panies and banks and homes of police and university officials in three major Argentine cities.

title: 2 Women Panthers In Rackley Case Freed on Probation
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2Two Black Panther women charged in the kidnaptorture of Alex Rackley 16 months ago, were given suspended sentences and released on probation today.

title: The Politics of Despair
description: My temptation today is to give a rip roaring speech, because we in Georgia and South Carolina live hard, we work hard, and we are proud of our prog ress. But, somehow it strikes me that we have had enough rips and roars in our society today and What is needed most is a talking of sense to our people, For truly America is fed up

title: More Power to the. President
description: As a result of examining the ac cumulation of powers by the President some years ago, in a book called The Enlargement of the Presidency, I came to the conclusion that the situation was becoming potentially more dan gerous as time passed, and had be come critically dangerous when geno cidal weapons were perfected. That was some years ago, and experience since, especially Vietnam, has con firmed the conclusion.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS GOES UP TO 5.5%, CONTINUING TREND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Un employment continued to rise in September, the Labor De partment reported today.

title: Fundamentalist Gadfly
description: For 35 years, the Rev. Carl McIntire, a deposed Presby terian minister who is a right  wing Fundamentalist radio preacher, has tirelessly accused the World Council of Churches, the National Council of Churches and most of the major Protestant denominations of leftish tendencies and softness toward Communism. His latest move was an invitation to Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky. of South Vietnam to speak at a March for Victory rally in Washington today. Protes tantism in general favors a dovish stance and supports withdrawal of United States forces from Southeast Asia.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: Football Transactions

title: ICKX SETS MARK AT WATKINS GLEN
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP)Jacky Ickx, of Belgium, the hottest driver on the cir cuit, broke the Formula One track record today as he led the first round of practice and qualifying for the $250,000 United States Grand Prix, the world's richest road race, which will be run Sunday.

title: Smog Alert in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (UPI) The ninth firststage smog alert of the year was called for Los Angeles County yesterday, making this the worst smog season in frequency of alerts since 1956. During the alerts, motorists are requested to cur tail driving and schoolchildren are asked to refrain from stren uous activity because of poten tial respiratory damage.

title: Agnew vs. Spock
description: Vice President Spiro T. Agnew speaking in Milwaukee, Wis., on Sept. 25, 1970:

title: Sports of The Times
description: Finishing second is better than finishing third, Gil Hodges had said in Pittsburgh last weekend, especially when you think you should have won to start with. And now it had come to the last game of the season on a cool evening, smudged by the plumes of jet planes over Shea Stadium. The Mets and Cubs were tied, and the winner of the game would be second in the Eastern Division and the loser would be third. Two years ago, the prospect of second place would have excited New York. tour years ago the Cubs, since World War II a perennial loser, would have seen second place as a long step forward. But the Mets are all but defeated by last year's amazing standard, and the Cubs, after two respectable thirdplace finishes and two spectacular failures to win the division, seem drained and almost ready to slip back among the alsorans.

title: Narcotics Suspect Killed In Brooklyn Gun Battle
description: A narcotics suspect was killed and another seriously wounded yesterday in a gun battle that began after they allegedly attempted to hold up two undercover Federal nar cotics agents carrying $13,000 in Government funds that was to be used to buy cocaine.

title: Other College Football Games on Today's Card
Strong Challenge by Democrats Has Vermont G.O.P. Worried
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 1 Campaigns of unusual intensity and bitterness are under way here as Democrats pose serious challenges to two Republican incumbents, the Governor and the junior United States Sena tor.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Oct. 2, 1970

title: Afraid of Revolution?
description: A group of protesters gathers in the streets to decry government policies  they are angry, they are loud and abusive, they are demanding disobedience. Facing them is a unit of militia, their rifles loaded, their bay onets fixed, their young faces betray ing their fright and inexperience. The situation grows more tense, more heated, more dangerous.

title: Princeton Defeats N.Y.U., Rutgers in CrossCountry
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 2 The Princeton crosscountry team took five of the top 11 places today to defeat New York University, 2531, and Rutgers, 1839, in a triangular meet. N.Y.U. defeated Rutgers, 2629.

title: Bribery Trial Delayed
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Oct. 2 (UPI)  Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, will not be able to stand trial on a Federal bribery charge for at least three months because of a spinal operation performed yesterday. Mr. Dowdy, 58 years old, had to face trial next Mon day. He is charged with accept ing a $25,000 bribe in return for stopping a Justice Depart ment investigation into a now defunct Maryland home im provement concern.

title: Pentagon Appoints Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Pentagon today named a former Representative, Armi stead I. Selden Jr. of Alabama, as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for international se curity affairs.

title: CUBA, IN U.N., OFFERS PACTS ON HIJACKERS
Top I.B.M. Executives Visiting Soviet Union
description: Top executives of the In ternational Business Machines Corporation left yesterday for a visit to the Soviet Un ion. The group, including Thomas J. Watson Jr., was invited by the Russian State Committee for Science and Technology.

title: Alcindor Paces Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 (UPI) Lew Alcindor scored 32 points as the Milwaukee Bucks de feated the Atlanta Hawks, 105 90, tonight in a National Bas ketball Association exhibition game.

title: HENRY SIMON DIES; AUTHOR AND CRITIC
description: Henry William Simon, author and former music critic who had also served as executive editor and vice president of Simon & Schuster, died here Thursday night. He was 68 years old and lived at 435 East 57th Street.

title: Suspect in Boston Slaying Ordered to State Hospital
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)Wil liam M. Gilday, 41 years old, of Amesbury, one of five per sons indicted for murder and armed robbery in the holdup slaying of Patrolman Walter A. Schroeder, 41, of Boston nine days ago, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk Superior Court today.

title: 14,000 Russians Play Big Role in Egypt
description: Some 14,000 Russians  soldiers, sailors and airmen, engineers, economists and technicians  exert the Soviet Union's growing influence on vital areas in the life of the United Arab Republic.

title: Report of Progress Denied
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 2 .United States diplomatic sources here deny that any substantial prog ress has been made among the Big Four powers toward im proving the situation in Berlin.

title: BaggyHose Ban?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) A Congresswoman asked today why the Federal Governmentsince it can dress an astronaut to withstand the perils of the moonisn't able to develop pantyhose for women that can survive a day's wear on earth.

title: Hunt for Habash Is Pressed in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 2  Jordanian authorities are hunt ing for Dr. George Habash, the Marxist commando chief, de spite the ceasefire between the troops and the guerrillas, Army sources said today.

title: LeadPoisoningTests Slated
description: Two mobile medical units will administer free lead poisoning tests to children in the Park Slope area of Brook lyn tomorrow, the New York City Health Service Adminis tration announced yesterday. The mobile units will circulate in Park Slope between 9 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. The area in volved runs from Sterling Place to Sixth Street between Fourth and Eighth Avenues. Children between one and 6 years of age, who are most susceptible to lead poisoning, will be tested.

title: Mrs. Meir Sees U.S. Gain From Its Action on Jordan
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 2 (Reuters) Premier Golda Meir said here today in a recorded radio inter view that United States action on the Jordanian civil war last week had been taken seriously by the Soviet Union and had improved United States credi bility in the area.

title: Major League Baseball
description: FINAL STANDINGS OF THE TEAMS

title: Deaf Couple Found Dead

title: ALL BUT ONE BLAZE IN CONTROL ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (AP) Firefighters held the upper hand today on most of the large brush and timber fires still burning in California, al though much depended on the winds remaining calm.

title: Jersey School Athletes Can Let Hair Down
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The State Education Depart ment ruled today that high school athletic coaches in New Jersey have no right to regulate the hair length of members of their teams.

title: Shuvee, Only Filly in Field, Faces 7 Colts in Woodward at Belmont Today
description: An equine variation of the boymeetsgirl theme is expect ed to heighten the suspense to day in the 17th running of the $110,900 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: DU PONT PRICE CUT ON ACRYLIC FIBERS
description: Price reductions and roll backs affecting acrylic fibers, newsprint and steel were an nounced yesterday by a num ber of producers.

description: UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP) A State Supreme Court jury here has awarded a verdict of $33,862 against the owner of a car that was stolen and subse quently involved in a fatal collision.

title: Red Cross Officials Are Summoned to Geneva to Speed Relief to Jordan
description: GENEVA, Oct. 2The Inter national Commit)ee of the Red Cross has brought in Red Cross officials from the United States and European countries to speed up the departure of medi cal teams, medical supplies and food for Jordan.

title: SENATOR POSTPONES HEARINGS ON ARMY
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Baseball Vows to Open Playoff Series Today in Face of Strike by Umpires
description: On the eve of the opening of the major league playoffs, members of the Major League Umpires Association voted yes terday to refuse to work in the playoffs and World Series as their dispute with baseball offi cials over pay for the series remained unsettled.

title: G.M. Strike Impact Begins to Spread
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2The ef fects of the General Motors strike, now in its third week, are beginning to creep across the country.

title: A Fight Against Unsafe Plates
description: The plate you are eating from may be hazardous to your health. But the Federal Food and Drug Administra tion is taking steps to see that others won't be.

title: JOHNSTON AVERY, 69, LED A MINE CONCERN
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2Johns ton Avery, president of the Li berian AmericanSwedish Min erals Company (Lamco), died of leukemia here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived in Wilmington, N. C.

description: Game 4 P.M. New York time.

title: Two Galleries Acquire Governor's Art
description: As of last winter, the exten sive art collection of Governor Rockefeller included The Foot ball Players, a 1912 painting by Albert Gleizes; City Square, a bronze sculpture by Alberto Giacometti, and Nude in the Studio, a pencil drawing by Henri Matisse.

title: Urtain Stops Jamaican
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  Jos Manuel (Urtain) Ibar, a Basque from Spain and the European heavyweight boxing champion, scored a thirdround knockout tonight over Stanford Harris of Jamaica in a nontitle fight.

description: BASEBALL

title: Bernadette Kaulakis Is Betrothed
description: CHATHAM, N. J., Oct. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Arnold F. Kau lakis of Chatham and of London have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Bernadette Marie Kaulakis, to Paul Carr Settel meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Settelmeyer of Short Hills. A December wedding is planned.

title: F.A.A. Disputes Report on Jet Failure
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration disputed yesterday the contention of the National Transportation Safety Board that a recent jet engine failure on a Boeing 747 airliner could have been catastrophic.

title: PENNSY LEASE LINES END PAYOUTDELAY
description: Two railroads that are leased to the Penn Central Transporta tion Company, which is in re organization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, yesterday brightened the day for their stockholders and bondholders.

title: Lufthansa Orders Airliners
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (UPI)The Boeing Company announced to day that Lufthansa Airlines has ordered an additional 747B jumbo jet airliner and two 727700's.

title: CORN CROP DOWN AS BLIGHT SPREADS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Department of Agriculture sharply reduced its estimate of the nation's 1970 corn crop to day because of the spread of the Southern corn leaf, blight. The result could be a rise in meat prices to consumers.

title: SOLDIER BARTFIELD
description: Jacob Bartfield, a former welterweight boxer who fought as Soldier Bartfield from 1912 to 1923, died yesterday in Brooklyn State Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: ALLENDE CONSENTS TO CHARTER STUDY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2 Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist who is Chile's prob able next President, agreed to day to form a committee to study possible constitutional changes in cooperation with the Christian Democratic party, whose support he needs if he is to win.

title: Brink's Suspect Captured
description: NEWPORT, Ky. Oct. 2 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of In vestigation announced today the capture of Carmen Merlino., 44 years old, who was wanted connection with the $1million robbery of a Brink's armored truck in Boston in 1968. The F.B.I. said seven agents were staked out at a nightclub here last night and took Merlino into custody. The agents said he had surrendered without resitance.

title: Laird Assures Greeks That U.S. Will Fulfill NATO Commitment
description: ATHENS, Oct. 2Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird as sured Greece today that the United States would stand by its commitments and obligations to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the face of the Soviet Union's growing naval challenge in the Mediterranean.

title: Nixon, in Madrid, Stresses Its Role in Area Security
description: MADRID, Oct. 2  President Nixon, flying into brilliant sun shine and a friendly public welcome, began a brief visit to Spain today by expressing hope for continued military and eco nomic links between Washing ton and Madrid.

title: Brezhnev Says Israel and U.S. Bar Peace
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, stressed again today the need for a political solution of the Middle East crisis, but ac cused Israel and the United States of blocking efforts to reach a negotiated settlement.

title: Plaza Suite Filming Starts With Mayor's Good Wishes
description: Mayor Lindsay went to the Plaza Hotel yesterday morning to wish Maureen Stapleton and Walter Matthau luck in the filming of Plaza Suite.

title: REV. ARTHUR A. SULLIVAN
description: The Rev. Arthur A. Sullivan, pastor of the Sacret Heart Ro man Catholic Church, Adelphi Street and Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: ALBATROSS IS 45 IN $53,495 PACE
description: YONKERS, Oct. 2With four of the nine colts entered in tomorrow nights Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace at Yonkers Raceway being Canadian owned, a solid bet would be that the winner of the $53, 495:63. stakes will hail from across the northern border.

title: U. S. and Agency Bonds
description: Friday, Oct. 2, 1970

title: HOLDERS APPROVE DRUG MAKERS' TIE
description: Shareholders of the Warner Lambert Pharmaceutical Com pany approved yesterday the acquisition of Parke, Davis & Co., after Stuart K. Hensley, chairman of WarnerLambert, defended the pro posed merger at special meeting of the shareholders. Mr. Hensley, re iterating what he said Thursday, when both companies disclosed that the proposed merger of the two large drug concerns was un der study by the antitrust division of the Justice Depart ment, stated:

title: Friends Mourn an ExAddict, 74
description: More than 200 residents of Phoenix House dressed in their best clothes yesterday and went to a dimly lighted funeral par lor on Madison Avenue to pay homage to William (Donkey) Reilly.

title: ... and Climbing Unemployment
description: The harshest of economic indicators in its impact on people is the one that measures unemployment. That index rose last month to 5.5 per cent, the highest level in nearly seven years. It is undoubtedly true, as Admin istration economists were quick to note, that statistical quirks attendant on the return of youngsters to school tended to inflate the figure somewhat. But it is also undoubtedly true that the upereep in the jobless total has not stopped and that it will take another substan tial jump next month when the secondary unemploy ment caused by the General Motors strike shows up for the first time. When the rise in joblessness coupled with the fourtenths of 1 per cent increase wholesale prices last month, it is plain that the Admin istration is still a long way from victory in its battle against the twin threats of recession and inflation.

title: Jets Down Knights, 3728, And Take Lead in A.C.F.L.
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP) The Bridgeport Jets, scoring early and leading all the way, defeated the Hartford Knights, 3728, in an Atlantic Coast Football League game to night.

title: Pipeline Project Is Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) The Texas Eastern Transmis sion Corporation has received authorization from the Federal Power Commission to build $23.2million of new pipeline facilities in Louisiana.

title: Landlords in Bronx Planning to Appeal RentCut Decision
description: A Bronx landlords organiza tion announced yesterday that it would appeal a State Su preme Court ruling that upheld the city's authority to cut rents when tenants in struck apart ment houses were deprived of services.

title: WINNDIXIE LIFTS QUARTER PROFIT
description: WinnDixie Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of more than 800 food markets, about 300 of which are in Florida, increased its net income in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 19 to $6,126,275, or 48 cents a share, from $5,238,054, or 41 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.

title: MARKET RALLIES AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market pulled an other surprise yesterday, run ning ahead in a snappy rally on a day when most analysts had expected another hohum section.

title: A Soviet Credibility Problem
description: In the wake of the death of Egyptian President Nasser and other disruptive developments in the Middle East, the Soviet Union has gone to some pains to emphasize its continuing interest in a political settlement of the ArabIsraeli dispute. There are even reports that Moscow is preparing a new peace initiative.

title: Drama: Children in the Rain Arrives
Kapp Signs With Patriots, but He Is Not Likely to Play Tomorrow
description: Joe Kapp, the colorful 32 yearold quarterback who had sought a $1.25  million, five year contract with the Minne sota Vikings, joined the Boston Patriots yesterday as a free agent. He declined to discuss the financial terms, but pre dicted, We're going to be a winner.

title: Britain's Gold Reserves Declined in September
description: LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) Britain's reserves of gold and convertible currency backing the pound fell by $86.4milion last month to a total of $2.66 billion on Sept. 30, the Treas ury said today.

title: Suharto Ousts Generals
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  President Suharto announced today a purge of highranking officers that in formed sources said included 25 per cent of the country's 170 army generals.

title: EDWARD WILSON, ILLUSTRATOR, 84
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Oct. 2 Edward A. Wilson, an illus trator of many books, as well as magazines and advertise ments, died today in Dobbs Ferry Hospital after a long ill ness. His age was 84.

title: They All Tried That Chanel Copy
description: You don't have to believe in the Paris mystique to like the French couture copies at Lord & Taylor. Twice a year the store selects from the couture showings styles it thinks its customers would like to wear and has them reproduced relatively inex pensively by local manufac turers in domestic fabrics.

title: Rival Latin Marxists Begin to Cooperate
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 LatinAmerican Marxists, who have increasingly found com mon cause with such tradition al enemies as Roman Catholic priests and army generals, are now extending the spirit of co operation to the bitterest ad versaries of allrival leftists.

title: MITCHELL TAKES 2SHOT GOLF LEAD
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Oct. 2 (AP)Bobby Mitchell of Dan ville, Va., shot a sevenunder par 64 today for a 36hole total of 130, the lowest tworound score on the Professional Golf ers Association tour this year, to take the lead at the halfway mark in the $60,000 Azalea open tournament.

title: RICHEY AND MRS. KING GAIN NET SEMIFINALS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI)  Cliff Richey and Mrs. Billie Jean King both were pressed to three sets today be fore winning their quarterfinal matches in the Pacific Coast in ternational open tennis tourna ment.

title: G.O.P. Gain Seen in Jersey's First District
description: CAMDEN N.J., Oct. 2  When the bridge across the Delaware River between here and Philadelphia was opened 44 years ago, the American humorist Will Rogers re marked: Now we have a bridge, we can get out of Cam den when we want to.

title: Saints Choice to Bedevil Giants; Jets Favored to Trounce Bills
description: The New Orleans Saints, rarely a favorite, are the choice by 3 points over the Giants tomorrow. Against the Buffalo Bills, who have won just five of their last 30 games, the Jets are fa vored by 14 points. Both contests will be on televi sion, the Jets at 1. P.M., Channel 4, and the Giants at 2 P.M., Channel 2, followed by the Minnesota  Green Bay game. Here is a preview of the games with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Mao Is Designated Leader Of Both Nation and Army
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 2Mao Tsetung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, was given a new title  Supreme Commander of the Whole Na tion and the Whole Armyin official news reports of yester day's observances in Peking of the 21st anniversary of Com munist rule in China.

title: Swift Due to Close MeatPacking Units In 2 Cities in Texas
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP)  Swift & Co. announced today it would shut down its meat packing operations in Fort Worth and San Antonio, Tex., by April 3, 1971, as part of a threeyear program to stream line its activities.

title: Girl Born to Toomeys
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. Oct. 2 (AP)Mrs. Mary Rand Toomey, Britain's gold medal winner in the long jump at the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo gave birth to a 7pound4 ounce girl yesterday. The girl, Samantha, was the first child for Mary and Bill Toomey, the Olympic champion and world recordholder in the decathlon.

title: DOUBTS ARE CAST ON MRS. KY'S VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  It was an onagain, offagain kind of day for the March for Vic tory Committee. The big ques tion was whether Mrs. Nguyen Cao Ky, wife of the Vice Presi dent of Vietnam, would be here tomorrow afternoon to address a rally.

title: Knicks Beat 76ers, 113100, As Bradley Gets 22 Points
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Bill Brad ley, starting for the first time in exhibition play, scored 22 points tonight to lead the New York Knickerbockers to a 113100 victory over the Phila delphia 76ers. The triumph was the Knicks' fifth in six games while the setback was the first for the 76ers in three outings.

title: FOE IN CAMBODIA WIDENS CONTROL
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 2(AP)Communist forces were reported to have expanded their control of Cambodia's princi pal highways today.

title: TRIAL IS RESUMED WITHOUT MANSON
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3Tes timony continued in the Sharon Tate murder trial here today after the four defendants were banished from the courtroom a second time.

title: PRISONERS REBEL IN 2 MORE JAILS; 23 HELD HOSTAGE
description: The revolt of city prisoners demanding speedier trials, low er bail and improved prison conditions spread yesterday from the Queens House of De tention in Long Island City to two other municipal jails.

title: Bail Set for 3 in Blast Case
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. Oct. 2 (AP)Bonds of $100,000 each have been set for three persons accused of seconddegree mur der in the explosion of a truck load of dynamite and the death of the driver. Those held in jail ponding a preliminary hearing Oct. 21 are Bobby Lee Shuler, 29 years old, Gerald Lee Bow dan, 27, all of Joplin, Mo. They pleaded not guilty yesterday to the charge in Magistrate Court.

description: The 22d annual dinner dance to aid the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue will be held Thurs day in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

title: Archibishop E. J. Hunkeler of Kansas Is Dead at 76
description: CROOKSTON, Minn., Oct. 2 (AP)  The Most Rev. Edward J. Hunkeler, retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Kansas, died yesterady of injuries re ceived in an automobile acci dent Tuesday in the northern part of this state. He was 76 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: Russell M. Barnes has been elected vice presi dent of Pan American World Airways' aerospace services division.

title: Kennedy Center in Capital Invites Sunday Sightseers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  The stillunfinished John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts will admit visi tors on Sundays this month.

title: For These Wives, the Price of a Glamorous Life Comes High
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 2The lives of these women are glamorous enough. They travel all over the world, spend money freely, live in handsome homes and wear the latest clothes.

title: Telephone Co. Will Give Scores During Playoffs
description: New York's baseball fans will get the latest scores of major league division play offs, starting today, by dial ing 6371212, the telephone company's time bureau.

title: Feliciano's Style Adds Steam to Songs
description: It was two years ago at the World Seriesthe last time there was a World Se ries without the Metsthat Jos Feliciano burst upon the awareness of a mass Ameri can audience. He did it by performing the pregame ritu al of singing one chorus of The StarSpangled Banner.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON CLOSE ON UPTRACK
description: The London Stock Exchange closed on the uptrack yester day after opening lower. Trad ing throughout the session was quiet.

description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP)Billy Martin was named today to manage the Detroit Tigers, re placing Mayo Smith, whose contract expired yesterday.

title: Innovations Everywhere At a Smithsonian Party
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Mrs. William McCormick Blair, in a black Givenchy dress, said she had to leave the party early because she had left her 8yearold son Robert up in a tree house. But the other 1,000odd guests at the Renwick Gal lery's curtainraiser ball danced and gaped at the exhibits until after midnight.

title: Routes from New York To Watkins Glen Track
description: Watkins Glen is situated on the Southern end of Sene ca Lake in the Finger Lakes region of south, central New York. It is at the intersection of Routes 14 and 414, 20 miles west of Ithaca, 20 miles north of Elmira, 20 miles northeast of Corning and 40 miles south of Geneva.

title: 5 HELD IN ROBBERIES OF 3 BANKS ON L.I.

description: The Vietnamese village that was the scene of the slaying of civilians in MS derives its name from its lo cation near two hillsEle phant Hill and Horse Moun tain. Son means hill and my means pleasant.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP)A newly remodeled and expanded hydrodynamics labo ratory was dedicated last night at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in honor of Ralph M. Parsons, a California engineer.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Sen ator John G. Tower, chairman of the Republican Senate Cam paign Committee, said today that he had not considered candidate's ideology when he allocated party funds for cam paign spending.

title: Marion Digney Will Be Bride Of Martin Delin Next Month

title: 'Tropical Ecstasy' Opens at the Rialto
description: One cannot but admire the power that draws Isabel Sarli again and again to taste the passion of Armando Bo, her writer, producer, director, husband and perennial leading man. For this couple, no longer in their first youth (no longer, really, in their second) display a durability of desire that must inspire old lovers everywhere and that in the past considerably toned up the dirty movie businessof which their new "Tropical Ecstasy," which opened yesterday at the Rialto, is not, alas, a very exciting example.The fault is not Miss Sarli's. Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale the infinite voracity with which she vamps anything that is, or possibly could be, male. Friends, enemies, a doorjamb, even an old fish netseem to bring on the strange fits of passion, the undulating hips, the heaving breasts that are her trademark, and, indeed, her stock in trade.Combining as she does the body English of Mae West with an apparent nostalgia for the moral universe of Louisa May Alcott, Miss Sarli has always striven to express the dilemma of a pure spirit fighting the proclivities of the too eager flesh supporting it.It is, of course, the struggle and not the outcome that matters. But in "Tropical Ecstasy," in which Miss Sarli plays a home-loving prostitute who flees her bordello boredom (". . . will I ever find true love of man?") only to fall into instant bliss and lasting domesticity in the household of Mr. Bo, a simple fisherman, there simply isn't enough struggle.Certain complications develop as Miss Sarli recalls her sordid pastusually in the midst of present pleasure, so that she has both sexual climax and remorseful flashback at the same timebut they are both too few and too timid to lift the film above the dullest ordinary.Armando Bo's direction is mostly a way of filling in between the points of his own minimal screenplay. Meaningless mood shots, interminable pans across the same sea and landscapes, repeated returns to Miss Sarli writhing in the surfor to the couple awkwardly locked in a strenuous embrace that no longer seems wholly worth the effortit all looks as if there were nothing to do and too much time to do it in.

title: Saved by the Court

The law not only prohibited school boards from busing pupils for purposes of racial integration without parental permis sion but also blocked the redistricting of school zones. Despite efforts to cover up the real intention of the law, its essential aim has turned out to be just as clear to the court as it was to the law's original proponents.

title: Books of The Times
description: Andrew Carnegie, for historians of the postCivil War Gilded Age, has been an ideological philosopher's stone. His prog ress from boyhood poverty in Scotland to his retirement from industry as probably the richest man in the world has been variously interpreted as that of a robber baron a paragon of the Protestant Ethic, of Social Darwin ism and of feudal capitalism. His subsequent career as a philanthropist has been indul gently dismissed as useful if cranky eccentricity or Victorian hypoc risy. In this first major biography of Carnegie since Hendrick's author ized Life of 1932, Joseph Frazier Wall makes an impres sive unity of Carnegie the in dustrialist, phil osophizer and philanthropist. Wall shows that Carnegie was a superb salesman from the start. As an 8yearold in a Scottish classroom of more than 150, Carnegie was immediately able to establish himself as the teacher's favorite. As an immigrant telegraph boy in Pittsburgh he quickly caught the eye of Pennsylvania Railroad executives. With their help he parlayed a series of sharp speculations into an income of $50,000 a year by the time he was 33, in 1868. Discovered in a particularly blatant speculation in 1871, he turned fulltime to steelmaking.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: BOB AND RAYTHE TWO AND ONLY, a twoman show written by and star ring Bob Elliott and Ray Goulding, was cheered by 9 of the 11 critics. The other two thought it only mildly amusing. Clive Barnes: The inescapable fact is that Bob and Ray The Two and Only is one of the zaniest shows to hit town in many a season. It is also firstrate theater. Their humor is re laxed and idiosyncratic it is easy to understand how it has become a con noisseur's cult. Each deft ly characterized inter view seems more hilarious and more wickedly apt than the last. It would be very easy to suggest that Bob and Ray write funny sketches and are accomp lished comedians  true enough. Yet they are much more than this. Their humor has the warmth of truth. For Walter Kerr, see Page 3.

If President Nixon and the Republican party are successful in their vigorous cam paign effort, then 1970 will be a pivotal election year.

title: Along the Banks of the Nile And Deep in the Jungles of Mexico

title: The Terrible Toll of Brush Fires
description: LOS ANGELESIn Southern California, fire ranks right below death and taxes on the scale of inevitability, and considerably above salvation. During the last 10 days, dozens of brush fires have scorched more than 600 square miles and destroyed or damaged more than 1,000 homes. At week's end, most of the blazes were contained, but the threat of new outbreaks remained. What causes these fires? And why, when everyone expects them, do they happen anyway? There are essentially three major ingredients for disaster. The first is that the rolling hills of Southern California are blanketed with a plant called chaparral, a sort of scrub evergreen that practically ex plodes into flame when ignited. Second, this area of California is, naturally, almost a desert. Water to supply Los Angeles is piped in from as far as the state of Wash ington. The third, and most freakish, ele ment is the Santa Anas, or devil winds, hot, dry gusts that sweep in from the Mohave Desert at speeds approaching 100 miles an hour. These winds aggravate the dryness, fan the flames when they start and then make it very difficult to fight the fires from the air. What can be done? Ap parently, very little. Brush cutting helps save some houses, but the areas involved are far too vast to consider clearing them on a major scale. Sprinklers are another answer, but often a fire will cut the water pressure. Asbestos siding, tile roofs and other fireresistant building materials also help. But the only real answer is constant watchfulness, and public education cam paigns to make people aware of the fire hazard.
