title: The making of a general and how it came abo
description: Historians of the last great war have all duly noted that fighting, like most human affairs, is now in the hands of bureaucracy. Hence there are no great generals any more, no strategic brilliance, scarcely even room for the exercise of imagination. Nothing in Stephen E. Ambrose's long and extraordinarily fascinating book argues the contrary. But if from the viewpoint of its victims, bureauc racy may be the quiet, faceless horror that Kafka saw, at the directors level, people still act like people and their world is as rich in the drama of interacting personalities as a castle of old courtiers or a ship of fools. It is Mr. Ambrose's special triumph that he has been able to fight through the memoranda, the directives, plans, reports, and official selfserving pie ties of the World War II establish ment to uncover the idiosyncratic people at its center. At the center of that center Gen. Dwight Eisen hower comes remarkably alive.

title: Why Do I Go? Here's Why
description: IT is quite remarkable how successfully we manage to keep in our heads, simultaneously, two en tirely different things: the theater as we imagine it to be, and the theater as it is. You see, we really know the facts all the time. We know that most theater is humdrum, if not a good bit worse than that; we can be fairly certain, on setting off for a playhouse, that the ex perience will be less than worldshaking tonight. Yet we always go with that worldshaking sense alive and alert, ready to be tapped, begging to be tapped. We honestly believe it's going to happen in the face of cer tain knowledge that it won't. I don't know whether this is good of us or treacherous of the theater, but it's true.

It is adapted from a newly published cookbook, Greek Cooking for the Gods, by Eva Zane.

title: Child to the R. L. Sterns
description: A daughter was born on Sept. 17 in University Hospi tal to Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Stern. Mrs. Stern, the for mer Stephanie Roumell, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen T. Roumell of New Buffalo, Mich. Mrs. Roumell is editor and publisher of The New Buffalo Times, a weekly newspaper, and Mr. Roumell is city counsel and a tax specialist.

title: The Puritan as politician and military leader
description: Oliver Cromwell is one of the most controversial figures in the history of the English speaking people, and Christo pher Hill's book is an impor tant contribution to our under standing of him and of the age in which he lived. One thing should be made clear at the start. This is not a bi ography in the conventional sense of the word. Mr. Hill is not much interested in Crom well's private life, and he treats his military career only insofar as it was the cause of his formidable influence on the course of the English Revolution.

title: Ickx Gains the Pole for $250,000 U. S. Grand Prix Today
Mary Ann Hughes Wed
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 3Miss Mary Ann Hughes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Hughes of Durham, N. C., was married here this morning in the Roman Cath olic Church of St. John and Paul to Ens. William Kenny Harris, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard C. Harris of Larchmont. The Rev. Henry Mansell performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is stationed at the Naval Base in Norfolk, Va.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 126 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Jane M. Mullikin Wed To Andrew Heikaus
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 3 Miss Jane Marie Mullikin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Mullikin of Lloyd Harbor, was married to Andrew Heikaus, son of Mrs. George Jernigan of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Robert Heikaus of Stamford, Conn., today in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Michael J. O'Leary.

title: New Era in Spanish Ties
description: MADRID, Oct. 3President Nixon ended his oneday visit to Spain this morning announc ing that a new era had begun in the relations between the United States and Spain.

title: GAIN BY CATHOLICS ON RACE BIAS SEEN
description: The Southern Regional Coun cil says that the reputation of the Roman Catholic Church in the South as an organization indifferent to racial prejudice has begun to change.

title: Farm Workers Hearing Set
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Union must ap pear in court Thursday to show why its members should not be permanently restrained from picketing grocery stores throughout California.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: What can public financing do for the small or medium size apparel manufacturer? Quite a lot, if the company is growthminded and is seek ing to fund its debt and thus avoid attrition in the short term money market.

title: ARGENTINA DEFERS RETURN TO VOTING
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3  Legal political activity in Ar gentina, which was prohibited by the military regime four years ago, apparently will have to wait another half decade to resume.

title: DWYER CAPTURES SECTION OF RUN
description: To most youngsters cross country running is no laughing matter. But as Vince Dwyer neared the end of a grueling 2mile race yesterday, he burst out laughing.

title: Miss Power Married Here
description: Miss Rosemary Power, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Power of New York and Sea Girt, N. J., and Christopher Sparks Dorment, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Dorment of Montclair and Monmouth Beach, N. J., were married here yesterday after noon in the Holy Family Ro man Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph O'Connell of Washington. A reception was given at the Colony Club.

title: Franlynne Katz to Wed
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Lieut. John B. Crosby Jr. Weds Elizabeth Busch, 66 Debutante
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. 3  Miss Elizabeth Thomsen Busch, daughter of Alfred E. Busch and the late Mrs. Elinor Thomsen Busch, was married here this after noon to Lieut. (jg.) John Bethune Crosby Jr., U.S.N.R., who is stationed in Newport, R.I. He is the son of Mr. Crosby of Barnstable, Mass., and Mrs. Robert Scott of San Juan Island, Wash. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Herbert H. Cooper.

title: E. D. Preate Jr., Lawyer, Weds Sally Edwards
description: DALTON, Pa., Oct. 3  The marriage of Miss Sally Dartt Edwards to Ernest D. Preate Jr. took place here this afternoon in Our Lady of the Abingtons Roman Catholic Church.

title: AGNEW ENTERING TOUCHY CONTEST
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 3 The announcement yesterday that Vice President Agnew will campaign in South Carolina Oct. 26 for the Republican candidate for Governor, Albert W. Wat son, brings the Nixon Admin istration into a contest in which charges of racism are a central issue.

title: DARTMOUTH HAILS MEDICAL CHANGE
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 3 Dartmouth College completed today a twoday convocation marking the reestablishment of a full degree program at the Dartmouth Medical School. The program will allow the student to complete all the require ments for Doctor of Medicine in three calendar years.

title: NixonTito Parley Is Termed Success
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3President Nixon, who left here yesterday after a success ful 42hour visit that consoli dated official YugoslavAmer ican relations with personal cordiality, gave as good as he got in long talks with his host, President Tito, knowledgeable sources said there.

title: Miss Donahue, Stephan V. Gray Plan Marriage
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Oct. 3Dr. and Mrs. Leo C. Dona hue of Somerville and North Scituate have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Patricia Donahue, to Stephan Vail Gray, an assist ant manager with the First National City Bank of New York.

title: Two Memorable Winters at New Jersey's Valley Forge
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  A truism of American historical lore: George Wash ington slept virtually everywhere. But few of his way stops were as signifi cant to the American Revolution as the two winters he and the Continental Army spent in the outskirts of this com munity 30 miles west of New York.

title: Dartmouth Defeats Holy Cross As Simms Scores Twice, 5014
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3 Dartmouth's football team took its cue from Jim Chasey, the quarterback, today and drove to a crushing 5014 victory over Holy Cross before a crowd of 13,222 at Fitton Field. It was the Crusaders' third loss in as many games.

title: U.S. Discloses Assurances
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The interim leaders of the United Arab Republic have privately informed President Nixon that they intend to continue Presi dent Nasser's policy of seeking a peaceful settlement to the ArabIsraeli conflict, State De partment officials disclosed to day.

description: FICTION

description: Selected Movies (R)Repeat (P)Premiere

title: PRIESTS' PARLEY OPPOSES CELIBACY
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Oct. 3The Congress of Groups of Solidarity, a Roman Catholic organization formerly known as the European Priests Assembly, ended here today with an overwhelming vote in favor of ending compulsory celibacy for priests.

title: NEVADA'S CANNON IN TOUGH CONTEST
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 2 Offyear Congressional elec tions are almost always inter preted as referendums on the Performance of the President.

title: Telephone Co. Will Give Scores During Playoffs
description: New York's baseball fans will get the latest scores of major league division play offs, starting today, by dial ing 6371212 the telephone company's time bureau.

title: Art Notes
description: IN case you've been won dering, the U.S. show did go on at the Venice Biennale this summer, despite the crippling with drawal of 25 artistpartici pants in protest against U.S. Government policies of rac ism, sexism, repression and war. And here, before the Biennale decamps (Oct. 25) from its Grand Canal roost, are a few particulars.

title: MGOVERN URGES OTTINGER SUPPORT
description: Senator George S. McGovern stumped the city yesterday in support of Representative Rich ard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for Senator.

title: Trials Inside San Quentin Are Ruled Out by Judges
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP)Inmates of San Quentin Prison will not have to stand trial inside the prison, Marin County Superior Court judges said this week.

title: Iowan Left U.S. $34,239
description: NEW HAMPTON, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP)The Federal Government will be $34,239 richer because of an 83yearold woman's love of country. HuIda Kalkbrenner, a retired nurse who died April 22, 1969, of a heart attack, listed the United States of America as beneficiary of the bulk of her estate, which had a total value of $40,239.

title: Tricia Nixon, Surrounded by Republican Candidates, Drops Into the Danbury State Fair
description: DANBURY, Oct. 3  Tricia Nixon, surrounded by Secret Servicemen and Republican candidates, dropped into the Danbury State Fair today as it opened for its 101st year.

title: 3 Areas Abutting Kennedy Airport Oppose Expansion
description: The proposed construction of two new Kennedy Inter national Airport runways in Jamaica Bay was vigorously opposed in a statement re leased last week by 62 Brook lyn, Queens and Nassau County public officials.

title: Ellen Hubbell Fiancee Of Richard N. Bayley
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Hubbell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen G. Hub bell, to Richard N. Bayley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Bayley of Natick and Salis bury Mass.

title: New and Recommended
description: THE DRIVER'S SEAT, by Muriel Spark. The state of spiritual anomie of a life lived absent from grace is at the, center of this selfmurder mystery about a spinster and her fated lover.

title: Up the Mad Avenue ladder, rungbyrung
description: Not everyone can be a super visor in a popsicle factory while working his way through college. Anyway, how many businesses care for this kind of experience? Well, advertis ersthe master confectioners of Madison Avenue  care.

title: Western Michigan Triumphs
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 3 (AP)Western Michigan struck for a pair of first quarter touch downs today and then made two stout defensive stands in the following period to high light a 233 MidAmerican Con ference victory over Bowling Green.

title: Sickness of Frogs Causes New Delay Of Space Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) A contagious disease called redleg has eliminated a team of frog astronauts from the space program, the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration said today.

title: This Is Bob (PoliticianPatriotPublicist) Hope
description: As you know, we asked your son and another soldier to pose for photographs with Miss Dianna Lynn Batts (Miss U,S.A.) when she arrived in Los Angeles in prepara tion for her upcoming trip to Viet nam with the Bob Hope troupe. Your son requested a photograph and Mr. Ted Pettit of my office took his name and address. We then had Miss Batts autograph them for the boys.

title: PEKING REPORTS ECONOMIC GAINS
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 3Re ports of economic growth that emanated daily from Peking as a buildup for Communist China's 21stanniversary cele brations on Thursday were re garded here as more solidly based this year than such re ports have been for many years.

title: Bonn Says Kissinger Visit Tomorrow Is Canceled
description: BONN, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The West German Foreign Ministry said tonight that Henry A. Kis singer, President Nixon's ad visor on national security af fairs, would not visit Bonn on Monday as planned.

title: Books:
description: It has been less than 200 years since economics, as an independent discipline, split off from political science. In 1776, when Adam Smith brought forth the first mod ern treatise on economics, The Wealth of Nations, the two fields were firmly joined.

title: Carol A. Dukes Is Jersey Bride
description: CONVENT STATION, N. J., Oct. 3Miss Carol Ann Dukes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus A. Dukes of Mor ristown, was married here today to William Hethering ton Browne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Browne of Convent Station. The Rev. J. Francis Feenan performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: BILL WOULD LIMIT COUNCIL RACE COST
description: Proposals to limit campaign costs for City Council candi dates and to require local poll takers to file data on which, their reports are based with thee, city's Consumer Affairs Depart ment have been put before the Council.

title: Styles in Gods and Heroes Change
description: IT GOES too far to say that there are no gods or heroes in Herbert von Ka rajan's Gtterdrnmer ung, but it goes in the right direction. The final install ment of von Karajan's com plete version of Wagner's Ring makes no effort, at any rate, to carve its place in history merely as a singer's performance: vocal heroics, even when they appear, stand back in favor of Karajan's flowing, narrative concep tion of this score, so that one comes away from hearing the 12 longplaying sides with an uncommonly clear and comprehensible idea of what the conductor, and per haps the composer, too, had in mind (DGG 2716001, ste reo).

title: 18YearOld Vote By Next Primary In New York State
JASPER HARRIERS TOP ARMY, ST. JOHN'S
The consumer vs. Jolly Green Giants
description: In their zeal to be heard over the din that prevails in the market place of ideas, reform ers sometimes overstate their case. But the competent reform er retains sharp perspective, so that his proposals have a rea sonable relation to the need.

title: Carina Wins Sherman Trophy Sailing
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 3Carina, the 48foot sloop that won the NewporttoBermuda race for Richard S. Nye of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in June, won the American Yacht Club's race, from Rye round the buoys and back to Rye, for the Roger Sherman Trophy today.

title: U.S. TO MAKE PLEA FOR DRUG CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3More than 100 countries pledged to stamp out illicit narcotics pro duction will be told by the United States next week that the time has come to redeem the promise or to accept inter national help to that end.

title: Melanie Is a State of Mind
description: LEFTOVER WINE: Melanie (Buddah BDS 5066), A performance by Mel anie, as with so many of the newly emerging singer/ songwriters, is a state of mind, a feeling, an aliveness. Or, as she puts it, If all your living is done on stage, your life depends on it. But whether one responds or not is almost totally dependent upon how receptive you are to the very special qualities of her musical magic.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Marriages

title: To Make Hijackers Unwelcome
description: While governments continued to play international politics with the safety of air travelers last week, air line trade unions from 21 countries took independent action that could help significantly to reduce the threat of aerial hijacking.

title: Parade Today
description: The 34th annual Pulaski Day parade will be held on Fifth Avenue today beginning at 1 P.M. The line of march is from 26th to 52d Street on the avenue, which will be closed to traffic. The march ers are to begin forming at noon on 26th, 27th, 28th, 30th and 31st Streets, which will be closed to traffic be tween Third and Sixth Ave nues.

title: Katharine Lee and John Keefe, Art Museum Curators, Married
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, Oct. 3  In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Katharine Caecelia Lee and John Web ster Keefe, former assistant curators at the Toledo Mu seum of Art, were married by the Rev. Chave Mc Cracken.

title: World
description: old Wilson told jokes about the Tories.

title: A word'seye view of the musical stage
description: That Patrick J. Smith has under taken in The Tenth Muse a serious, comprehensive history of the opera libretto as an art form may surprise some casual operagoers who believe that most librettos are irrational ab surdities to be endured for the sake of the music.

title: FILIPINO CHILDREN HURT BY POOR DIET
description: MANILA, Oct. 3The neatly built but unpainted community center of San Andres Bukid, a village just off the capital's plush Ermita district, stands at the end of a narrow, muddy road flanked by hundreds of shanties. It was almost 3 P.M. and 60 village children were there with their mothers for the usual feeding session, part of a broad program to combat the malnourishment prevalent among young children in the Philippines.

title: Medicine
description: Mayor Lindsay's announce ment last week that the city would sponsor a major meth adone maintenance program for heroin addicts marked a change of direction in his ef forts to deal with an increase in a serious medical and so cial problem.

title: Angry Sample Spells Out Differences
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 3In the years when Johnny Sample was a cornerback with the New York Jets, a club official once described him as our most volatile player.

title: Above the Ruhr with the R. A. F.
description: By now one formula at least is set for popular historical writing. Take a momentous event that occurred over a short time period. Capsulate within it a mass of people in volved, great and small, of widely different perspectives and positions. Then, as if to regain bulk, follow their sepa rate actions moment by mo ment. Shift scenes rapidly;

title: U.S. TO ASK CURBS ON POWER PLANTS IN POLLUTION STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Dr. Edward E. David Jr., the Presi dent's new science adviser, said today that very early in the next session the Administra tion would send legislation to Congress providing for govern mental control, chiefly at the state level, over the location of new electric power plants and extrahigh voltage trans mission lines.

title: Viewpoint:
description: The danger involved in de ciding whether or not insti tutions should enjoy member ship on the New York Stock Exchange is that the issue will be settled without ade quate discussion and debate.

title: City's Jail Population Rated 183% Above Capacity
description: Although more than 2,600 prisoners have been moved to jails upstate in the last two months, the population of New York City's prisons was 183 per cent over capacity as of a week ago, State Senator John R. Dunne, Republican of Nassau, said yesterday.

title: 100proof Old Ernest, most of it anyway
description: By Ernest Hemingway. 466 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $10.

title: Movies
description: SHE is smiling cinematically, ex hibiting all those flawless teeth, but something is wrong. At first, one assumes that she is simply a little tired. In 12 hours, Sophia Loren has flown from Rome, faced the sort of mob that goes all the way out to air ports to see movie stars step off planes (Pope Paul's reception was slightly larger), displayed her renowned infant son to the reporters (in Italy, the Christ Child is slightly more revered), stayed Up until 8 A.M. rearranging the Hemp shire House suite to accommodate the baby, changed into boots and a grape colored midi dress, received David Frost, suffered the jocular publicity man from Avco Embassy, which is releasing her latest film, Sunflower (produced by her husband, Carlo Ponti), agreed to something called a global press confer ence on the stage of Radio City Music Hall, dealt with the maid, the secre tary, the nurse, the fawning hotel clerks, and a strange little man who resembles Toscanini and scurries around the suite inexplicably measuring things with a green tape. Her grin is firm, as if sewn at the temples; there is something brit tle in her eyes, and her posture is too good.

title: The Nation
description: The General Motors strike, now ending its third week, is a battle of industrial and union giants with crucial im plications for the value of every American's dollar. But these larger overtones of the battle are nowhere in view in the frantic negotiations that have been under way since the 350,000 members of the United Automobile Work ers walked out in plants of the world's largest manufac turing enterprise.

title: Ithaca Tops Cortland
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., Oct. 3 (AP)John Anselmo capped a 90yard scoring drive with a 4yard rollout into the end zone in the third period today to give Cortland State a 70 foot ball victory over Ithaca Col lege. It was Cortland's first victory this season after two losses. Ithaca has lost its three games this fall.

title: Rugged Road Pursues A Corkscrew River
description: ROOSEVELT, Ariz.This is the story of a riverArizona's Salt River  and a road known as the Apache Trail. The road follows the river over a cir cuitous shunpike route in the Arizona outback only a whoop and holler from Phoenix. It is a rough ride at points, but the scenery is often genuinely spec tacular.

title: 1,100 VOLUNTEERS TO HELP TEACHER
description: Housewives, businessmen and grandparents are among the 1,100 volunteers who will teach children reading and conversa tional English and will assist teachers in the classroom in 97 of the city's public schools this year.

title: Reader's Report
description: The Courtney Entry

title: Choate Conquers Exeter, 140; Kuchar Passes for Both Scores
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 3A strong defense and the offen sive play of Ed Kuchar and Al Giandomenico led Choate School to a 140 openinggame victory over Exeter today. The losers twice penetrated the 5 vard line but were turned back.

title: Toys: Soon the Season
description: Parents facing this year's lineup of Christmas toys will find that the toy industry, affected as many others are by the recession, has decided to play it safe with old fa vorites.

title: Quotes
description: KINGMAN BREWSTER JR., president of Yale, during a goodwill tour of the Midwest: It's damn important to society to encourage the university to be a place where assumptions can be questioned, even though it's very pain ful to an uptight society.

title: Headliners
description: For half a century, Martha Graham has been near center stage of the dance worldas a performer of unusual stature and as the driving personality behind the moderndance company that bears her name. The creator of 144 works, she has been acclaimed for her theatrical genius, and her innovations in defiance of classical ballet conventions. Now 76, Miss Graham has reluctantly acknowledged that her body can no longer obey her will. So last week, when her company opened a new season in New York, Miss Graham stayed in the wings. It is a bitter thing with me not to be able to dance again, she said. And she said she hoped to dance at least once more in the spring.

title: The Struggle for the President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Con gressional election campaign is a little like Winston Churchill's famous pud ding. At a political luncheon in the Savoy Hotel, a waiter brought him what Harold Macmillan describes as a rather equivocal and shapeless mass of goo. Sir Winston looked at it in horror and summoned the waiter. Pray take away this pudding, he said. It has no theme.

title: PERSONALITY WINS $109,900 STAKES IN 3HORSE PHOTO
description: Personality nailed a shaky plank into his Horse of the Year platform yesterday at Belmont Park by winning the $109,900 Woodward Stakes in a desperate, threehorse photo finish.

title: Egypt and Soviet Assert They Seek Peace in Mideast
description: CAIRO, Oct. 3  Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the So viet Union and the interim leadership of the United Arab Republic have agreed during four days of intensive consulta tions here to continue efforts toward a political settlement, of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: In Brief
description: The Art of James Thurber

title: Nolan Victor for Reds
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3  A tightly pitched duel between Cincinnati's Gary Nolan and Pittsburgh's Dock Ellis came unglued on Ellis's side of the ledger in the 10th inning today and the Reds defeated the Pirates, 30, in the first game of the threeoffivegame play offs for the National League Pennant.

title: Miss Welch Bride Of John W. Bauer
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Swedish Hockey Captain Suspended for Fighting
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The Swedish Hockey Federation handed the national team captain, Ulf Sterner, a two  month suspension today for hitting a referee during a game Sept. 10 against the Czecho slovak club, Ducla Jihlava.

title: MISSISSIPPI TOPS ALABAMA BY 4823
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 3 (AP)  Archie Manning threw three touchdown and scored twice, and Vernon Studderd raced 100 yards on a kickoff return tonight as Mississippi belted Alabama, 4823, in a na tionally televised game.

title: WORLD FOOD CROP SAID TO STAGNATE
description: ROME, Oct. 3 (AP)For the first time in 12 years there was no increase in the com bined output of the world's farms, fisheries and forests in 1969 while population continued to grow.

title: Wall Street Mood
description: On Wall Street last week the mood of stock brokers, a breed of men who auto matically put a hand to their hearts when the market tape stops chattering, waswell, ebullient?

title: Accounting and. Rails Woes
description: Accounting methods used by American railroads, as re quired by the Interstate Com merce Commission, may be an important factor contrib uting to their financial woes, a Chicago certified public ac countant believes.

title: R. F. Schultz Jr., Officer, to Marry Judith A. Tucker
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Oct. 3 Mr. and Mrs. R. Worthing ton Tucker have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Tucker, to Second Lieut. Rob ert F. Schultz Jr. of the Army Transportation Corps. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schultz of Annandale, Va.

title: Jesse Greer, 74, Composer For Broadway Shows, Dies
description: COLUMBIA, Conn., Oct. 3 Jesse Greer, a composer who wrote the music for several Broadway productions during the 1920's, died at his home today at the age of 74. At his death, he was vicepresident of the ElectraMotive Manufactur ing Company.

title: Of Malcolm X, Who Truly Overcame
description: THERE are thoseand I include myself among themwho will never weary of hearing the words left to us by Malcolm X.

title: UMPIRES PICKET PITTSBURGH PARR
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3Major league umpires struck for the first time in baseball history today. They picketed outside Three Rivers Stadium while four minor league umpires worked the opener of the Na tional League playoff between Cincinnati and Pittsburgh.

title: California Leads Nation With 3Million Veterans
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 3 (UPI) The Veterans Administra tion has estimated that Cali fornia maintained its status as the state with the largest number of veterans.

title: W. VIRGINIA TOPS INDIANA BY 1610
description: BLOOMINGDALE, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP)West Virginia's unbeaten Mountaineers struggled to a 1610 victory over Indiana to day before 44,482 fans in Indiana's stadium.

title: SPRINGFIELD IS 3D IN A FIELD OF 9
description: YONKERS, Oct. 3Even at odds of 310, Albatross proved a bargainbuy for those chalk players who backed the Mead ow SkipperVoodoo Hanover colt in the seventh edition of the Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Light on Jackson State
description: The detailed analytical report by the President's Com mission on Campus Unrest on last May's police violence at Jackson State College in Mississippi confirms the worst suspicions about an episode that left two Negro students dead and twelve others injured.

title: Blast Rocks Downtown Athens As Laird Meets Greek Leaders
description: ATHENS, Oct. 3  Hopes of increased United States mili tary aid were voiced by Greek officials today as Defense Sec retary Melvin R. Laird and Ath ens leaders ended a day of talks.

title: Barbados Storm Moves On
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The tropical storm that damaged Barbados yesterday receded Northward and Westward today to threat en other islands in the Eastern Caribbean. A report from Sea well Airport, Barbados, this morning said the storm was westsouthwest of St. Lucia and moving westward at eight miles an hear.

title: BOTTLES AND CANS ARE A COAST ISSUE
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Oct. 3 Last spring it was an academic project in political science. To day it has emerged as one of the most thoroughly discussed, and apparently most widely supported, proposals before the voters of the state of Wash ington.

title: City Opera Listing Return of Pelleas For Its 7th Week
description: The New York City Opera will give its first perform ance this season of Debussy's PeIlas et Mlisande on Oct. 22, during the seventh week of its season at the New York State Theater. The production, which was new last spring, has sets and costumes by Lloyd Evans and was directed by Frank Corsaro.

title: Perth Group Enters 73 Cup Picture
description: PERTH, Australia, Oct 3.A challenge for the America's Cup exceeding anything Australia has undertaken before became a possibility this week when Alan Bond, a 32yearold Perth multimillionare, said that he hoped his syndicate would finance two or even three 12 Meter yachts for 1973.

title: Freud, Jung and the Collective Unconscious
description: ON Nov. 24, 1912, Sigmund Freud and Carl Gustav Jung, who Freud once hoped would succeed him as the leader of the psychoanalytic movement, met for next to the last time in Munich, Germany. It was ostensibly a business meeting, but all those among the small group of psychiatrists who attended were aware of the imminent break between the Father of Psycho analysis and his chosen heir.

title: Guerrillas Demand Israel Free Group of Prisoners
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine today called on Israel to re lease a group of prisoners in return for the hijacking hos tages recently released in Jor dan.

title: PublicInterest Law Group Aided by Ford Foundation
description: The Ford Foundation has an nounced a grant of $375,000 to the Center for Law and So cial Policy, a publicinterest law group in Washington.

title: WILLIAMS SCORED ON UNION INQUIRY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3Nelson G. Gross, Republican candidate for United States Senator, accused Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. today of failing to carry out a Senate investigation of the murders of the president of the United Mine Workers and his wife and daughter and an in quiry into the union's election and pension practices.

title: For 11 Years I Was Just a Ballplayer
description: ON his first show as WABCTV's 11 o'clock Eyewitness News sports announcer a short while back, Jim Bouton was uncharac teristically modest. Some people say I can't pitch, others say I can't write, now we'll find out if I can't broadcast, he said.

title: Bergenfield Tops Hackensack; Passaic Valley, Ridgewood Win
description: Bergenfield snapped a 77 thirdperiod tie on a 19yard touchdown pass from Ralph Messina to Carl Mittlehammer yesterday and went on to a 207 victory over Hackensack at Bergenfield.

title: NIGERIANS CALM ON MILITARY RULE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 3The news that Nigeria's military Government expects to stay in power for six more years was accepted calmly here today.

title: Tennessee Eleven Sends Army to a 483 Defeat, Cadets Worst Since 1956
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 Army tied a record against Tennessee today, but the sta tistic is not likely to be passed around the Pentagon. The cadets lost, 483.

title: AL UNSER TAKES TRENTON 300 RACE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Al Unser, who already owns the 1970 Indianapolis 500 title and the United States Auto Club's driving championship, won the rainshortened Trenton 300 mile race at Trenton Speedway today.

title: The Viceroy and the General
description: By David Dilks. Vol. 1: Achievement. 296 pp. Vol. 2: Frustration. 307 pp. Illustrated. New York: Taplinger Publishing Company. $10 each.

title: Aerospace Lab to Assess New Mass Transit Ideas
description: Management techniques borrowed fom the Aerospace industry have been applied to accelerate the nation's slow moving efforts to create bet ter ways of moving people to and through the nation's con gested big cities.

title: Reri Grist: Private Is Private
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE is, of course, the perfect place. You can be a raging transvestite, and no one gives a damn. You can stand on any street corner and champion the most unpopular cause, and no one will jeer. You can be black walking arm in arin with a whitemaned Swede, and who cares? Everything is still possible in the Village. It is, for example, still possible to rent an extremely charm ing town house in an outoftheway Village mews even if you happen to be a married couple of decidedly mixed color.

title: Springfield Triumphs, 2724, Despite Albright's Late Rally
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 3 Springfield College scored 21 points in the first half today and held on for a 2724 victory over Albright College.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: ECONOMIC INDEXES of new orders dropped in Au gust. Manufacturers orders declined 1.7 per cent to $56.1 billion, while manufacturers shipments dropped 0.2 per cent. Orders for machine tools, often viewed as an indi cator of things to come, plunged to $46.15million in Au gust, a drop of 40 per cent from July. Inventories increased. The index of wholesale prices, which generally foreshadows retail prices by a few months, rose 1.3 per cent in Septem ber to 117.7 per cent of the 19579 base.

title: RANGERS SCORE, 65, ON SELLING'S GOAL
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (UPI) Rod Seiling scored in the third period tonight to give the New York Rangers a 65 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in an exhibition game.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: Cup Race Aftermath

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: PRAGUE IS PURGING SCIENTISTS' UNIONS
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The Communist party paper Rude Pravo indicated today that scientists were defying de mands to purge their ranks of reformists.

title: Columbia Downs Princeton For 4th Soccer Victory, 20
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 3  Columbia's undefeated soccer team gained its fourth victory today, downing Princeton, 20.

title: Kol Nidre, Masses, Cantatas
description: NEXT Saturday is Yom Kippur. Part of the ritual connected with this Jewish Day of Atonement is the recitation of the prayer called Kol Nidre. According to A. Z. Idelsohn's Jewish Liturgy, around 1500 a tune was composed to voice the sentiments of the recitants during the prayer. It expressed the fear, horror,fervent pleading, and stern hope for ultimate salvation. It became popular among the Ashkenazim, the Jews from middle and northern Europe, who took it with them wherever they migrated.

title: MRS, KING LOSES TO NANCY RICHEY
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., upset form in the Pacific Coast International open tennis tournament today by defeating toprated Mrs. Billie Jean King, 75, 57, 64. Miss Richey was seeded third.

title: Miss Sarah L. S. James Is Affianced
description: Miss Sarah Lispenard Stew art James and Sergio Modigliani, students at Har vard University's Graduate School of Design, plan to be married Nov. 28 in the Me morial Church at Harvard.

title: Bryant Bozarth Weds Pamela Ellis
description: HADDONFIELD, N. J., Oct. 3  In Grace Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Pamela Atkinson Ellis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward H. Ellis Jr., became the bride of Bryant Wynkoop Bozarth. The Right Rev. Al bert W. Van Duzer, Episcopal Suffragan Bishop of New Jersey, performed the cere mony. He was assisted by the Rev. Allen S. Bollinger.

title: A Modest District In Newark Stays Proud and Stable
Reds Cline Is WellTraveled Hero
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3  Ty Cline's problem started before he was born. The Pi rates problem began when Cline came to bat as a pinch hitter in the 10th inning today.

title: Columbia George Scores
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP)Columbia George, owned by Mitzi Stables of Bryam, Conn., won the 536,000 Tatter salts pace in two heats today at the Lexington trots, increas ing the 3yearold's earnings this year to over $240,000.

title: Public life of a Founding Father
description: This year is open season on Jefferson. Dumas Malone's study of Jefferson The Presi dent was reviewed in these pages on Feb. 15. Now we have a massive onevolume biog raphy by the able historian whose work on The Jefferson Image in the American Mind has become the definitive his tory of Jefferson's changing reputation from 1826 to ap proximately 1950.

title: GREENWICH COVE WINS ENSIGN RACES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3 Greenwich Cove skippers de feated representatives of the Western Long Island Sound fleet, 2 races to 0, in their an nual Ensign Class team match, a twoofthreerace series, sailed off Greenwich Cove today in a 1518 knot southwest breeze. Lee Kowalski Jr. and J. Roy Galloway paced the Greenwich Cove victories in the match postponed from June 27 when small craft warnings were flown.

title: Dr. Hollace D. Jackson, Interne, Affianced to leffrev S. Tullman
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. 3 Dr. Hollace Dawne Jack son, a surgical interne at the Metropolitan Hospital in New York, plans to be mar ried in December to Jeffrey Stephen Tullman, a lawyer with the New York firm of Chadbourne, Parke, White side 14, Wolff

title: Suit Would Bar Ohio Guard
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 (UPI)The American Civil Lib erties Union of Ohio says it will file a suit in Federal District Court in Cleveland next week in an attempt to keep the Ohio National Guard off state uni versity campuses. Benson Wol man, executive director of the organization, said the suit would be filed on behalf of students at Kent State University, where four students were killed last May 4 in a confrontation with National Guardsmen.

title: Ripon Society Backs Courts As Main Tool of Integration
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Oct. 3 (UPI)The Ripon Society, a liberal Republican research or ganization, has called for re liance on the Federal courts to integrate the nation's schools rather than on guidelines from the Health, Education and Wel fare Department.

title: U.S. ACTION URGED BY U.M.W. FACTION
The Years of MacArthur
description: He was the type of man around whom rumors and apocryphal tales flourished like crab grass in August. To many he seemed to identify with God, to others with the devil. He attracted adjectives, both compli mentary and profane. He is immor talized by nicknames, savage and magnificent; and in World War II countless ballads extemporized in jungle C.P.'s and ships wardrooms recorded his achievements or lack of them. There were few neutralists as far as he was concerned; you were for him or agin him.

title: Jackson State and Orangeburg
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Presi dent's Commission on Campus Unrest has accused Mississippi policemen of needlessly causing two deaths by gunshot at Jackson State College and of thereafter lying to their superiors and to the F.B.I. It has asserted that a Mississippi grand jury refused to indict anyone after a number of in accurate findings, and it found the state police unwilling to take further action in the matter.

title: BAY SHORE UPSET BY LINDEN HURST
description: Bay Shore's two season 11  game victory streak was mapped yesterday by talented Lindenhurst, 280. Joe Leahy's aerials and the running of Tom Palladino and Richard Roses highlighted the Lindenhurst at tack. Palladino scored two touchdowns.

title: Rudolph, Tom and Gretchen
description: The two sons and one daugh ter of Axel Jordache, a small townontheHudson baker, form the triangle on which this novel as on an armatureis un shakably constructed. The boys are Rudolph, bright, studious, and Tom, tough, pugnacious,cynical and (at first) repellent though as a prickly charac ter his goingson stir your in terest. Finally, there is Gretchen, a teenager who is far from convinced that her frigid moth er's diatribes against sex are the whole story.

title: Uncorking Britain's Pub Hours: Thirsty Work
description: LONDONTrying to change the British licensing laws is like trying to move Everest six inches to the left. The body of regulations governing drinking in these islands has all the attributes of an immovable object, and then some. It is a mass of ancient law, prejudice and 19thcentury morality whose peaks are permanently obscured in mists of his torical absurdity and mindshattering confusion.

title: Purdue Upsets Stanford, 2614, as Five of Plunkett's Passes Are Intercepted
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)  Purdue's defensive troops, led by Randy Cooper and Arnold Carter, helped con vert Stanford mistakes into three touchdowns, a field goal and a safety today as the Boil ermakers upset the fifthranked Indians, 2614.

title: Shaw saw a man of genius
description: Gabriel Pascal, the late movie producer who is portrayed in this memoir by his widow Val erie, led a life more bizarre than any of his films. Unknown and impoverished, he obtained screen rights to some of George Bernard Shaw's plays, succeed ing where many moguls had failed. His meteoric career and association with G.B,S., ob served at close hand and through their correspondence, provide the chief elements of an absorbing book.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1970

title: TOUGH HOUSE RACE EXCITES COLORADO
description: DENVER, Oct. 1  Craig S. Barnes comes on understated, head cocked to one side in the rough brick cellar of his politi cal headquarters under the creaking floor joists as feet pound noisily above.

title: Soviets Give First Details On Study of Moon Rocks
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (AP)  The Soviet Union published today a report on its initial examina tion of the moon rock brought back to earth Sept. 24 by Luna 16.

title: Some New Books for Collectors
description: COIN grading has long been a major problem in numismatics and the publications avail able to collectors and deal ers that deal with this im portant subject have often proved inadequate. Some show only one side of the specimens being described and others are illustrated with line drawings or poor photographs that are hard to analyze.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: Final Standing

title: DR. JACOB BERKMAN
description: Dr. Jacob Berkman, a general practitioner for 50 years, died Thursday of a stroke in Roose velt Hospital. His home was at 16 West 77th Street and his office at 1882 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Nixon in Europe Some Gains Amidst the Problems
description: LONDONAs Richard Nixon and Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia finished their review of the honor guard, a line of specta tors on the upper balcony of the airport at Zagreb last week broke into applause. Reflexive ly, Mr. Nixon looked up, smiled broadly, flashed his arms sky ward in a familiar campaign gesture.

title: SCIENTISTS HOARD OLD GRAIN SEEDS
description: ROME, Oct. 3 Within five years, according to agricul tural specialists here, a proc ess known as genetic ero sion threatens to wipe out a large proportion of the food crop strains on which future farming will have to depend.

description: Engagements

title: New Drive on Pnompenh Is Predicted
description: PNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 3 (AP)A Cambodian military spokesman said today that ene my forces apparently were massing for new attacks on the outer defense ring of Pnom penh.

description: Special to The New York Times

title: Pompidou Is on Soviet TV As He Prepares for Visit
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3President Pompidou of France told the Soviet people today in a na tionally televised interview that he was coming to their country this week to join with their leaders in a search ofr peace.

title: Education
description: Presidential commissions on critical social issues have come and gone in such profusion in recent years that the question is less what they said than who listened. This will be particular ly true of the President's Com mission on Campus Unrest be cause its diagnosis and recom mendations followed a rash of earlier assessments by experts. And like many of the earlier surveys it drew criticism, this time from Vice President Ag new.

title: KINGS POINT ROUTS ADELPHI TEAM, 438
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 3 The United States Merchant Marine Academy, led by its quarterback, Dave Duzanoski of Southington, Conn., defeated Adelphi, 438, today.

title: Mrs. Sabra P. Schad Is Remarried
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Oct. 3 Mrs. Sabra Packard Schad and Roger Oakley Wheel wright were married here to day at the home of the bridegroom's father, Richard Wheelwright.

title: No Way to Get There
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 3 (UPI)If you take Exit 16 on Interstate 89 going northwest from Concord, don't bother trying to get to Purmont. There's no such place. When the exit sign was posted, high way crews failed to note that Purmont, instead of Piermont, was painted on the exit marker.

title: Dedicated to Sue Captures $100,000 Matchmaker Stakes
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) The Walnut Hill Farm's Dedi cated to Sue forced the pace and won the $100,000 Match maker stakes by a length and a half from Alfred G. Vander bilt's Cold Comfort at the At lantic City track today.

title: Virginia Fox, 65 Debutante, Wed to Cleric
Is a Mustache Politically Relevant?
description: MOSCOW (UPI)Hundreds of Ameri can tourists have run afoul of Soviet laws this year, most of them snarled in customs or passport infractions. But at least seven were involved in inci dents that led to expulsion.

title: Stokowski: Off to a Wild Start
description: IT was last season that Leopold Stokowski, per haps with a twinkle in his eye, programed Liszt's Hungarian Fantasy for piano and orchestra  the Hungar ian Fantasy, so popular in the 1920's, so neglected to day. Earl Wild was the solo ist, and those who attended the concert are still talking about it. Wild is a sensational virtuoso with a remarkable flair for music like this, and the critics reported that he shook down the heavens. The piece was unanimously con ceded to be great fun, and thanks were offered to Sto kowski for reviving it.

title: Best & Co. Announces Its Decision to Terminate Business
description: Best & Co., a 15store chain that has operated in New York City since 1879, will go out of business in about a month, with the main store building at 51st Street and Fifth Avenue to be demolished and replaced by a large office building.

title: More Apartment Settlements Reported by Union in Bronx
description: Striking Local 32E, Building Service Employes International Union, asserted yesterday that 925 apartment buildings had been signed up for contracts since the Bronx apartment strike started.

title: Allende Sees Chile Finding Her Own Way to Socialism
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 3Capitalism has failed in Latin America, according to Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, and Chile under the government he expects to head for the next six years is to search out a new, independent way to socialism.

title: U.S. Sees Soviet Gain in NuclearSubmarine Operations Off the East Coast
LEGISLATORS FAVOR SHARING OF REVENUE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3The board of governors for the Na tional Society of State Legisla tors ended the society's annual meeting here today by going on record in support of Federal revenue sharing.

title: 4 Touchdowns for Kosins
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 3 (AP) Gary Kosins, Dayton halfback, scored four touchdowns and gained 204 yards in leading the Flyers to a 2811 victory over Louisville today.

title: McCall's Six Scores Spark New Utrecht
description: Bob McCall, a halfback, went on a scoring spree last night as New Utrecht crushed Midwood, 5020, in a P.S.A.L. game on the loser's field in Brooklyn.

title: CLUE TO HEPATITIS FOUND IN ANTIGEN
Miss Carolyn Sullivan Is Married
description: MILTON, Mass., Oct. 3 Miss Carolyn Sullivan, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sullivan Jr. of Milton and Wianno, was married this afternoon in St. Agatha's Roman Catholic Church to F. Henry Savage Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Savage of Scars dale, N. Y. Msgr. George W. Casey performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Farmers Delay Tokyo's New Airport
description: NARITA, Japan, Sept. 30  The rolling hills and meadows just outside this city, where Tokyo's new international air port is being built, resembled a medieval battlefield this week as farmers armed with bamboo spears and supported by stu dents pushed against the bright metal shields of bluehelmeted riot policemen.

title: Ann L. Taft Betrothed To Carlton Cooke 3d
description: The engagement of Miss Ann Louise Taft to Carlton Perry Cooke 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Bowers Taft of New York and Lakeville, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooke Jr. of Buf falo.

title: Miss Brenda Marsh Johnson Married to John H. Dick
description: MARION, Mass., Oct. 3 Miss Brenda Marsh Johnson, a descendant of Francis Le wis, a signer of the Decla ration of Independence, and John Howard Dick, son of Al bert Blake Dick 3d of Lake Forest, Ill., chairman of the board of the A. B. Dick Com pany, Chicago, were married here this afternoon.

title: HOWARD U. AIDING MISSISSIPPI POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Students and faculty members at Howard University have started a campaign against blight, pestilence and apathy in Quitman County, Miss.

title: Times Writer Expelled From 2d Malaysian State
description: LABUAN, SABAH, Malaysia, Oct. 3The Malaysian state of Sabah, today expelled Henry Kamm, a correspondent of The New York Times. No reason for the action was disclosed.

title: Wind Helps Rhode Island Triumph Over Maine. 236
description: ORONO, Me., Oct. 3  The University of Rhode Island, helped by winds that gusted up to 40 miles an hour today, scorecl a touchdown and a safe ty in the space of 1 minute 18 seconds in the second period and went on to defeat the Uni versity of Maine, 236, in a Yankee Conference football game.

title: Saigon Takes Steps To Fight Inflation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 3The Government announced today a dual exchange rate for its currency as part of a reform package aimed at halting in flation.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The First National City Bank, in a $20million deal, has leased nine full floors in 810 Seventh Avenue, the 43 story building nearing com pletion on the southwest cor ner of 53d Street.

title: S.M.U. WINS, 2120, ON HIXSON'S RUNS
description: EVANSTON, III., Oct. 3 (AP) Chuck Hixson, suffering the worst passing game of his ca reer, took to the ground today to lead Southern Methodist University to a 2120 victory over Northwestern.

title: CAMBODIA BOMBS AROUND REFUGEES
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 3A Government spokesman acknowledged today that Cam bodian planes had bombed a region around a Vietnamese refugee village in northwestern Cambodia.

title: Presidential Panel Ponders Minority Capitalism
description: CHANGE IS SOUGHT ON AID TO BLACKS WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A Presidential committee is ex pected to recommend the con solidation of several Federal agencies, including the Small Business Administration and the Economic Development Admin istration, and the budgeting of nearly $1billion, to make the sagging minority capitalism programs more effective.

description: In Financing, a New Wrinkle

title: GEORGE CABOT LEE
description: WESTWOOD, Mass., Oct. 3 George Cabot Lee, a vice presi dent of John P. Chase, Inc., of Boston, an investment counsel ing concern, died yesterday at his home. He was 70 years old.

title: Bryant Park Show
description: THE big top will re turn to Manhattan Thursday for the Bry ant Park Flower Show. Flowers, gardens, house plants and arrangements will be shown under a huge can vas tent with covered walks leading to several special ex hibits In smaller tents. There will be daily schedules of lectures and films. The show will be open free to the pun lic from 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. through Oct. 13. Bryant Park is located behind the New York Public Library at Sixth Avenue and 42nd Street.

title: GROUND SUBSIDENCE A PROBLEM IN TAIPEI
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 3  Taipei is sinking, and the mu nicipal government this week announced its determination to stop the process.

title: Danzig to Be Main Speaker At Vermont Sports Dinner
description: Allison Danzig will be the featured speaker at the annual University of Vermont Athletic Hall of Fame dinner Oct. 16 at the Ramada Inn in Burling ton. Vt.

title: U.N. Panel Warns of the Hazards of Peaceful Nuclear Power
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3  Peaceful uses of nu clear power have outstripped bomb tests as a threat to world health through radiation, the United Nations has been told by a group of scientists that has followed such developments for 15 years.

title: Iowa State Scores, 1613, On Shoemake's 3d Goal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Iowa State converted two pass interceptions and a fumble recovery into a 1613 victory over Utah today. Reggie Shoemake kicked a 41yard field goal  his third of the gamein the fourth period for the deciding points.

title: PITT TURNS BACK KENT STATE, 276
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP) Pitt's football team scored two firsthalf touchdowns on a 34 yard run by Dennis Ferris and a 5yarder by Dave Havern and went on to defeat Kent State, 276, today. Ferris was the rushing star of the game, gain ing 137 yards on 18 carries.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercialagricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: Bridge
description: THE world of bridge is thickly peopled with two antagonistic but complementary species. There are the aggressive and dominant No trump Fanatics, who announce their favorite declaration far more often than they should, and ignore indi cations from their partners that a suit contract would be preferable. For some reason the female of this spe cies is comparatively rare.

title: Private lives join time
description: A woman 71 years old looks back at her life and likes it, pain and all. An unlikely pros pect for a novel, if the life is lived by conventional wisdom or recovered in a geriatric voice. But Lael Wertenbaker is an un conventional woman (she wrote Death of a Man to commem orate her cancerdoomed hus band's suicide) and a writer who speaks to the present. Unbidden Guests is a supe rior fictionintelligent, perti nent, gleaming with style.

title: Heads Education Center
description: NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP) Jerrold Zacharias, professor emeritus of physics at Massa chusetts Institute of Technol ogy, has been appointed acting president of Education Develop ment Center, one of the coun try's oldest and bestknown centers for reform of the school curriculum.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Miami of Ohio Wins, 480
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 3 (UPI) Jim Bengala threw three, touchdown passes to Mike Palija and a defensive tackle, Bob Williams, made 20 tackles for Miami of Ohio the nation's No. 1 defensive team, in a 480 triumph over Northern Illinois today.

title: Whitney Young Appointed To M.I.T. Trustee Board
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the Na tional Urban League, has been named to a fiveyear term on the board of trustees of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it was announced yesterday.

title: Where the Mystery of Language Was Revealed
description: TUSCUMBIA, Ala.It's called the Song of the Stone Well, and a simple plaque at the iron pump tells the visitor: At this well, Anne Sullivan revealed the mystery of language to 7yearold Helen Keller by spelling the word water into her hand as water flowed over the other hand. Thus be gan a most remarkable story.

title: Berries and Foliage for Landscaping
description: Now is the time to see flamboy ant foliage and berries. While on strolls around the parks and countryside to look at nature's wonders, keep in mind what plants might be grown. Many attractive fall display trees and shrubs are readily available for home landscapes.

title: Art Sale to Aid Temple Israel
description: Temple Israel of the City of New York will benefit from an art sale and loan exhibition entitled Peace Through Art, to be held at the Bernard Danenberg Gal lery, 1000 Madison Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets.

title: Brown U. Names Trustee
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 3 (AP)Henry A. Ittelson, 33 years old, of New York City was named today a trustee of Brown University. Mr. Ittelson is vice president of Universal C.I.T. and C.I.T. Leasing Corpo ration.

title: 37th Pheasant Dog Futurity Begins Upstate on Friday
description: The 37th pheasant dog futu rity starts Friday at Three Rivers Game Management Area, Baldwinsville, N. Y., with the national open pheasant cham pionship to be held immediately afterward.

title: Waiter Kerr Reviews Bob and Ray
description: I T is possible to tell Bob and Ray apart but, what with all the laughing go ing on, it's hardly worth the effort. Ray, who is one half of The Two and Only occupying the Golden these bemused and madcap nights, has more eyebrows than Bob, many more. Bob has very lit tle hair anywhere on his head, and he leans. He is notlimp or lazy. He is a straight leaner, right into the wind, which is usually coming from Ray. Bob's mouth is surround ed by two tight curved lines, as in a Dolly Dimple draw ing, though in his case the effect is severe, yet patient. His pale blue eyes seem pre occupied and even perma nently betrayed, but not an gry. Ray is occasionally an gry, because he is a sorehead, but only in a Father Bear sort of way. He is, for in stance, completely at home with a menu shaped like a longeared bunny when he decides to order a children's dinner in a restaurant. For himself. Ray has longer side burns than Bob, but that fig ures. I told you it wasn't important.

title: Law Student Fiance Of Lois S. Silverman
description: Miss Lois Susan Silverman, a graduate student in educa tion at the University of Michigan, and Robert David Kaplow, a law student there, plan to be married in May.

description: N.Y.U. Wins in Soccer, 30

title: Fires in '69 Killed 12,110; Damage Was $2.4Billior
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP)De structive fires took 12,110 lives and destroyed $2.44bil lion in property in the United States in 1969, the National Fire Protection Association reports.

title: Frank Kluckhohn, Author, Dies; ExCorrespondent. for Times, 62
description: MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 3Frank L. Kluckhohn, author and newspaperman, died last night in King's Daughters Hospital of injuries suffered earlier in the day in an auto accident. He was 62 years old and lived in Shep herdstown.

title: A LongHaired Safari Across Middle America
description: IT WAS with considerable apprehen sion that we pulled out of Pittsburgh on a sunny Monday afernoon in July and headed for the Badlands of South Dakotafirst stop on a sixweek, 11,400mile crosscountry trek. We were aiming for the heartland of America, our heads filled with Easy Rider images, rel atives' warnings about our shoulder length hair and horror tales of beatings and police harassment. We had planned a carious photography and camping trip, and were in no mood to spend our time hassling about our appearancewe had even packed a pair of scissors in our Volkswagen bus in case things got too rough.

title: Running by Klos Leads Nutley To 140 Defeat of East Orange
Michigan Blacks Wary on School Change
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3A Federal hearing examiner's ruling that a suburban school district near here was deliberately segre gated and in violation of Fed eral law has not met with over whelming enthusiasm, even among blacks.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 3 A Cohasset, Mass., team de feated Western Long Island Sound skippers, 20, today in their annual 210 Class Inter fleet team match.

title: Moore, Junior Back, Helps Oregon Beat Wash. State, 2813
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 3 (UPI) Oregon received a twotouch down performance from its junior halfback, Bobby Moore, and beat Washington State, 2813, in a Pacific 8 game to day.

title: News of the Camera World
description: AIR travelersespecially those on overseas flightsare being ad vised by Eastman Ko dak of the possibility of dam age to films carried in their baggage as it is being load ed aboard international flights. Although there is no definite confirmation from anyone in authority as yet (including both Government and airline officials), it seems increasinely likely that someof the secret security de vices being used to check passengers baggage for pos sible weapons or explosives include detectors that make use of Xrays. A roll of pho tographic film, exposed or unexposed, that is subjected to Xray is usually ruined in the process (the film becomes fogged or light struck). Pure ly magnetic detectors, which some agencies are rumored to be using, will not harm the film.

title: 1964: Exhilaration 1968: Frustration 1970: Hopelessness
description: A former Times correspondent, concluding his third Vietnamese tour, looks at the war and the people, then and now, and peers uncertainly ahead

title: Defense Rise of $1Billion, First in 3 Years, Is Due
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The White House has told the Pentagon to plan on seeking an increase in defense spending next year. The increase would be considerably smaller than the Pentagon had been counting on, but it would represent the first upturn in military spend ing in three budget years.

title: Manhattan Downs Siena
description: The Manhattan College Foot ball Club defeated Siena, 27 14, yesterday. The Jaspers rai led for two touchdowns in the final period to gain the victory. The score was tied at 14all at halftime.

title: Miss Carol Colman, Bank Aide, Wed to Ralph Lynn DeGroff Jr.
description: CHENEQUA, Wis., Oct. 3 Miss Carol Lucinda Col man, a securities analyst with the United States Trust Company in New York, and Ralph Lynn DeGroff Jr., who is with Dillon, Read & Co., the investment bankers there, were married here this after noon at Grace Holy Inno cents Episcopal Church.

title: Valencia Water Court Where Justice Is Swift
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Many longestab lished institutions are feeling stresses and strains nowadays, but the weekly proceedings of Valencia's El Tribunal de las Aguas, or Water Court, flow as smoothly as the Turia River over which it has jurisdiction.

title: F.T.C. Reversed on Stamps
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, reversing a decision by the Federal Trade Commission, has ruled that trading stamps must be redeemed only at established centers maintained by the stamp companies themselves.

title: C.C.N.Y. Beats Kings Point In Conference Soccer, 21
description: Ronnie Zuckerman and Ivan Mino scored secondperiod goals yesterday to pace C.C.N.Y. to a 21 victory over Kings Point in a Metropolitan Soccer Con ference game at Lewisohn Sta dium.

title: the traveler's world
description: WHEN YOU want a passport in Texas, Michigan and Connecticut these days you go down to the post office rather than search out the Passport Office's nearest agency. In Connecticut, you may also apply to the probate court where the clerks will accept applications and forward them to the Passport Office.

title: Central Connecticut Puts Bridgeport to Rout, 3213
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 3  Central Connecticut routed Bridgeport, 3213, today in an Eastern Football Conference game.

title: Greeley Wins, 26 to 0, As Crean Scores Twice
description: Horace Greeley extended Westchester County's longest undefeated streak to 15 games, including one tie, at Lincoln Field in Yonkers by defeating SaundersCommerce, 260.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Yawns at Chile's Vote
description: WASHINGTONIt is not known yet what Marxist Presidenttobe Salvador Al ende in Chile will do in the way of seizing United States investments there. The situa tion is evidently different, as usual, among banks, mines, communications and other American enterprises.

title: ARKANSAS HANDS T,C.U. 4914 LOSS
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 3 (AP) Bill Burnett of Arkansas, the leading touchdown scorer in Southwest Conference history, added four against Texas Chris tian University tonight in a 49 14 victory for the 11thranked Razorbacks.

title: Keith Whiting Colburn Weds Miss Betsy J. Patterson on L.I.
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Oct. 3 The marriage of Miss Betsy Jean Patterson to Keith Whiting Colburn, took place in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary here today. The ceremony was performed by the bride's fa ther, the Rev. Thomas J. Pat terson, a vice president of Family Circle Magazine and an Episcopal priest. The Rev. Gerald Gardner, rector of the church, assisted.

title: The View From Butler's Pool
description: The house of John Mulcahy, an in ventive IrishAmerican millionaire, stands on the windswept shore of County Kerry where the westernmost fringe of Europe slopes out from Ireland toward the distant United States.

title: Coast Candidate, 27, Hopes That He and Other Insurgents Can Gain Strength to Make Congress Responsive
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 3Gary Hart folded his arms, rubbed his jaw and twirled a ruler. The scene was the engineering building at the University of California cam pus here, and the fidgety youth at the head of the class could have been a candidate for stu dent body president. He wasn't. He was a candi date for Congress.

title: M.I.T. Honors a Benefactor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)The Massachusetts Insti tute of Technology has dedi cated its remodeled and ex panded hydrodynamics labora tory to Ralph M. Parsons, the chairman of the board of a Los Angeles construction and engi neering company. Dr. James R. Killian Jr., chairman of the M.I.T. Corporation, praised Mr. Parsons's generous suport for making possible the doubling of the size of the building.

title: Corporate Envoys
description: The average senior Wash ington representative of an American business corpora tionhe abhors the designa tion lobbyistis 53 years old, is married, has three children and lives in Chevy Chase or Potomac, Md., Alexandria, Va., or one of the other af fluent suburbs of the nation's capital. He earns $38,000 to $44,000 a year.

title: One Rockefeller Who May Make It
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. THE John D. Rockefeller, dead now these 33 years, used to have this saying: Sons of wealthy parents have not the ghost of a chance, compared with boys who come up from the country with the determination to do some thing in this world.

title: $67,500 in Scholarships Offered for Science Study
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Westinghouse Science Talent Search announced this week that $67,500 in scholarships and grants would be available in its 30th annual competition, in which thousands of high school students are expected to parti cipate.

title: Frost Phenomena
description: GARDENERS many ex pect to hear forecasts of scattered frost anytime this month. For some, the first frosts of the season will end most dis plays and harvests. For other homeowners, even living near by, gardens may be untouched for weeks longer.

title: TEMPLE FIELD GOAL NIPS BOSTON U., 107
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Nick Mike Mayer kicked a 27yard Field goal with 10 seconds left to play to give Temple a 107 victory over Boston University today.

title: GOVERNOR TO SEEK NARCOTICS COURTS
description: Governor Rockefeller prom ised yesterday that if reelected he would seek legislation to create special narcotics courts and give financial aid to local ities so that they could hire more policemen.

title: Fiber Chief
description: Charlie W. Jones has been appointed president of the ManMade Fiber Producers Institute effective November 1. Mr. Jones, who was for merly, assistant to the vice president of the Signal Com panies, will fill the vacancy created by the resignation of E. Fontaine Broun. He for merly served as vice presi dent of the American Carpet Institute and as Washington representative for the Na tional Cotton Council.

title: POOR ORGANIZE OREGON COUNCIL
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 3 Oregon's poor people, express ing frustration at working through existing social agen cies, have organized a council of the Poor in an attempt to gain greater political power.

title: Simpson Means Business Against Jets Today
Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayGrand Prix of the United States at Watkins Glen, N.Y., 2 P.M.

title: Penn's Law Library Acquires Letter From Thomas Jefferson
description: Is this life? Thomas Jeffer son asked as he drudged away at answering people's letters, and he answered himself: At best it is but the life of a mill horse, who sees no end to his circle but in death. To such life, that of a cabbage is para dise.

title: Bob and Ray On Broadway? Good Gravy!
description: IT all goes back, maybe, to a farm expert from Pioneer Valley in Mas sachusetts, getting red in the face while being inter viewed about artificial in semination, Ray Goulding said. The wife and kids are at home, glued to the radio, and you ask him the key question, and he looks at the microphone and says, Well, Ray .. . and turns red. What we do is basically based on observation, on watching people. It's not necessarily a, style.

title: Lafayette Subdues Madison, 228, on Cioffi's 3 Touchdown Passes
SEA IS DISCOUNTED AS SOURCE OF FOOD
description: A scientist at the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institution has sharply chal lenged the repeated predictions of demographers that the ocean can always produce enough fish to meet the protein needs of the world's exploding popu lation.

title: Sara Ellen Stauffer Is Engaged To Arthur J. Smadbeck, Student
description: BROOKVILLE, Pa., Oct. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Stauffer have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sara Ellen Stauffer, to Arthur James Smadbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Smadbeck of New York.

title: Toledo Teachers Accept Pay Rise and End Strike
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 3The strike of Toledo teachers, inter rupted on Sept. IS by a court injunction, ended yesterday.

title: East. Michigan Wins, 2521
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Oct. 3 (AP)Eastern Michigan trailed Indiana State today until 19 seconds remained in the game, then Dade Makins passed 25 yards to Tim Turbin for a touchdown and a 2521 victory. The victory left Eastern Michi gan with a 301 wonlosttied record, while Indiana State is now 22.

title: Mary Heaney Is Bride Here
description: Miss Mary Catherine Hea ney, daughter of Mrs. James F. Sweeney, and Edmund James McCarthy, son of Joseph F. McCarthy and the late Mrs. Mary R. McCarthy, were married here yesterday afternoon by Msgr. James G. Wilders in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: MITCHELL WIDENS LEAD TO 4 STROKES
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Oct. 3 (UPI)Bobby Mitchell shot threeunderpar 68 today and increased his lead to four strokes after three rounds of the $60,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  When King Edward III picked up the Count es of Salisbury's garter in 1348, he issued a royal opinion on ob scenity: Evil to him who thinks evil. Since then and before, states, mayors, chiefs of police and boards of censors have tried to draw the obscenity line, say ing that all to this side is, all to that is not.

title: Football Records to Begin
description: Records of college football teams and schedules of their remaining games will appear in Monday's edition of The New York Times and every Monday thereafter until the completion of the season.

title: News of the Rialto
description: A LOT of folks probably think that the Thea ter of the Absurd has played its hour upon the stage and gone off to the bookshelves. Not so. One of the species is coming back  with music  and to Broadway.

title: Carol Ann Michaelsen Bride of Robert Owens
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3Miss Carol Ann Michaelsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Michael sen, was married here this afternoon in the First Con gregational Church to Robert Michael Owens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard T. Owens of Bridgeport.

title: Arizona State Wins, 523, On Spagnola's Passing
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 3 (UPI) The Arizona State Sun Devils, directed by Joe Spagnola, who threw four touchdown passes, crushed Wyoming, 52  3, in a Western Athletic Conference game today.

title: Lighthouse to Benefit By Westchester Fete
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 3The fourth an nual DayintheCountry to benefit the Westchester Lighthouse will be held Oct. 11 at Croton Air Park. There will be a box lunch and aer ial show, which will feature radio models, gliders, a STOL plane, parachutists, balloon ascent and exhibits. Tickets are $10 each.

title: NEW CANAAN GETS ITS 27TH IN A ROW
description: New Canaan, possessor of Connecticut's longest active winning streak, made it 27 straight yesterday by outlast ing Greenwich, 2820, and a oneman scoring performance by Don Ward.

title: Goodell Aides Call Agnew Tactics Helpful
description: With barely a month to go in their campaign, the men who advise Senator Charles E. Goodell are pondering whether Vice President Agnew's denun ciation of their man will turn out to be the smite of a politi cal giant or an unintended blessing from what one aide termed a bogeyman.

title: Accord on Reforms Is Reached in Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 3  The Gov ernment and organized labor reached agreement this week on significant social reforms, including the creation of a na tional health service that stops just short of socialized medi cine and measures to spur the building of lowrent housing.

title: An Out looks at an In
description: In his inaugural address as Governor of California, Ronald Reagan declared: For many years now, you and I have been shushed like children and been told there are no simple an swers to the complex problems which are beyond our compre hension. Well, the truth is there are simple answers. Well, the truth is, there aren't. And to Edmund G. Brown, Governor Reagan's basic mis reading of government and so ciety lies at the root of his disastrous record as the chief executive of the nation's most populous state.

title: Law
description: A Royal Air Force plane left London last Wednesday for Cairo with a single pas senger, Miss Leila Khaled, a Palestinian commando who had successfully comman deered a T.W.A. jet to. Syria a Year ago but had failed in her attempt on an El Al air liner on that fateful Sept. 5 when three other hijackings succeeded. On the way, the R.A.F. plane picked up three other Arab commandos awaiting trial in Munich fol lowing bombings at the Munich airport in February, and three more in Zurich who had already been convicted and given 12year sentences for a machinegun and gre nade attack on an El Al plane at Zurich airport. This was the price of freedom for the 300 passengers and crew of the illfated airliners brought to Dawson Landing, Jordan, early last month. The last six hostages, apparently held until details of the ex change could be completed, were released on Tuesday.

title: 4 States Join in Malacca Strait Survey
AUBURN DEFEATS KENTUCKY, 3315
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 31 (UPI)Wallace Clark's touch down on an 84yard bickoff re turn and the fullback's 167 yards rushing sparked Auburn, to 24 secondhalf points today as the Tigers defeated Ken tucky, 3315.

title: Bright Frost Wins by Neck In $10,000 Freehold Pace
description: Special to The New York Times

title: WISCONSIN SCORES ON RALLY, 29 To 16
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 3 Penn State suffered its second successive defeat today when Wisconsin took full advantage of Nittany Lion mistakes to score a 2916 upset.

title: Torable, Torable, Torable
description: FROM the moment you read the ads for Tora! Tora! Tora! (The Most Spectacular Film Ever Made!), you are aware that you're in the presence of a film possessed by a lack of imagination so singular that it amounts to a death wish. As it turns out, this poverty of fancy has gripped not only the advertising copywriters but just about everyone connected with the film, from the directors and writers and cameramen on down to the uncredited artists who painted some terrible Pearl Harbor backdrops, which, from time to time, are seen through office windows and look like old Orpheum circuit scenic drops against which jugglers used to perform.

title: Premier Karami Resigns With Cabinet in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 (AP)Premier Rashid Karami and his cabinet resigned today. Suleiman Franjieh, Lebanon's new President, accepted the resignation.

title: An Old Maryland Family
description: Dr. Byrd, who in his youth had a shock of curly black hair, hence his nickname, was born Feb. 12, 1889, in Crisfield on Maryland's Eastern Shore, where his family line went back to the 17th century.

title: How Much of Charles Manson Do His Songs Reveal?
BORNEO'S DYAKS LIVE IN COMMUNES
description: KAMPONG PUEH, Sarawak, Sept. 26The Dyak tribesmen of Borneo are far from hippies, but they have been living in communes as far back as any one remembers.

title: Janet A. White Wed to Ensign
