description: SILVER PLUME, Colo., Oct. 5 ((UPI)Federal officials will take apart the engines of a plane that crashed Friday, kill ing 30 persons, to see if the charter carrier for football play ers had full power, a spokesman said today.

title: Schools to Be Open Oct. 15
description: A Board of Education spokes man said yesterday he antici pated no change in the board's policy of noting student and teacher absences during war protests, such as the latest Viet nam Moratorium Day set for Oct. 15. Schools will be open that day, he said, and in full operation.

title: TOBIAS STERN DIES; A JEWELRY MAKER, 72
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 5 Tobias Stern, president of thel Kreisler Manufacturing Corpo ration, maker of watchbands and other jewelry, chiefly, for men, died in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains, on Saturday. He was 72 years old and lived at 5 Dolma Road.

title: TV: N.E.T. Offers Pros and Cons of Sex Education
description: The reorganized structure of noncommercial television, which has seen the consoli dation of National Education Television over Channel 13, opened its fall season last night with Realities, a weekly hour of rotating spe cials on public affairs and cultural personalities and events.

title: New Presidents Named At Two Seagram Units
Bonn and Warsaw Begin Another Round of Talks
description: BONN, Oct. 5 (Reuters) An other round of talks between Polish and West German nego tiators to draw up a treaty to improve relations began today. Their talks are expected to last until Wednesday.

title: WORLD OF TANGENTS IN KEUTER'S DANCES
description: Cliff Keuter presents the or dinary under an extraordinary aspect. For him sex is not mere ly sensual, it is surreal; social contracts are meant to be frac tured in a variety of interesting ways and the commonplace is fraught with complications. Last night at the Cubiculo he presented a program of four dances, two of which were premieres.

title: Radiation Control Amendment Held No Threat to U.S. Power
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Rep resentative Chet Holifield, chairman of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic En ergy, said today that an amend ment to the Atomic Energy Act he had sponsored is not intended to interfere at all with the authority of the new Environmental Protection Agen cy to set radiation protection standards.

title: Bankruptcy Petition Filed
description: Computer Applications, Inc., filed yesterday a bankruptcy (petition in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. The petition came three I days after the court had denied the company's petition to re organize under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: TWO COUNCILMEN ASSAIL SECRECY
description: Two city councilmen charged yesterday that the Lindsay ad ministration was drawing an illegal veil of secrecy over the operations of city government by refusing to permit the public full access to public informa tion and documents.

title: Strike at Sewage Plants Perils Health in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 5 About 100 million gallons of raw or partly treated sewage were discharged into England's waterways today as a strike for higher wages by municipal workmen entered its second week.

title: Northwest Industries Will Sell C.& N.W. Assts to Employes
description: The Chicago & North Western Railway signed an agreement yesterday with its employes to sell them the railroad's trans portation assets.

title: 2 COUPLES, YOUTH SLAIN IN FLORIDA
description: NEW PORT RICHEY, Fla., Oct. 5 (UPI) Five persons two married couples in a tavern and a youth on a beachwere shot to death with 22caliber bullets early today.

title: America's Sung Heroes
description: WASIINGTON, Oct. 5Great lock er room interviews:

title: U.S. Troops Fly to Europe
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Oct. 5 (AP)The first of 11,400 combatready United States Army troops being air lifted from the United States arrived in Frankfurt today for maneuvers near the Czecho slovak border. At the same, time, 100,00 Eastbloc troops are carrying out the large maneuver, between the West German border and West Ber lin.

title: BALLET GROUP BOWS AT THE CLARK CENTER
description: Contemporary Ballet En semble is a charmingly mis leading title for a company that is balletically inclined rather than adequately trained in that discipline. Over the weekend the group made its first appearance at the Clark Center with a pro gram that was a mosaic of dance styles.

title: City Orders Rent Cuts for 400 in 8 Bronx Apartment Houses Because of Loss of Services
description: The city administration re duced rents yesterday for the first time in an apartment strike, announcing cuts for ten ants who had suffered a loss of services in eight Bronx build ings with 400 apartments.

title: ALL HOSTAGES OUT; HOLDOUT INMATES IN QUEENS YIELD
Retired Gurney Plans Own Teams
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 5 Dan Gurney, who ranks as America's top international driver, reiterated today his intention to retire from rac ing. He was busy at his plant, AllAmerican Racers, making his plans for the future. Chief among them is the fielding of a team called Dan Gurney Racers in the top competi tions.

title: Redemptions Imperil Gramco's Fund
description: LONDON, Oct. 5Heavy re demptions are threatening the giant offshore real estate fund sponsored by Gramco Manage ment, Ltd., a United States oriented company with admin istrative offices here.

title: Wedding Planned By Elise Donaldson
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Oct. 5Miss Elise du Pont Donaldson and Thomas James Bulger 4th plan to be mar ried in December.

title: Train Order Set for Review
description: I A threejudge Federal court has been formed in Pittsburgh to review a District Court's issuance last week of a tem porary injunction restraining the Penn Central Transporta tion Company from dropping 14 EastWest passenger trains. The restraining order was issued after the Interstate Commerce Commission had authorized the railroad to stop running the trains, effective Oct. 1. The threejudge court comprises R. J. Aldisert of the appellate court and District Judges Wallace S. Gourley and Louis Rosenberg. Judge Gourley issued the temporary injunc tion.

title: BAIL REINSTATED FOR FIRS. SHAKUR
description: Mrs. Afeni Shakur, one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places, was released from the Women's House of Detention yesterday after Justice John M. Murtagh reinstated her $100,000 bail.

title: Volpe Denies U.S. Resolution On Hijacking Curb Was Diluted
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 5John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transpor tation, denied today that the United States hijacking resolu tion approved last week by the council of the International Civil Aviation Organization, was a diluted version of the original.

title: The Quest for Justice
description: There is little disagreement among the men who fill the cellblocks of the city's jails almost to a man they want speedy trials, lower bail and better jail conditions. There is little disagreement among the men outside the cellblocks, eitherthe politicians and the judges and the correction offi cers. They've got good gripes, a guard said on Sun day, after three days as a hostage in the Tombs. Most of what they say, Cor rection Commissioner George F. McGrath said, I have said many times over the past months.

title: ExGovernor Settles on Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Internal Revenue and for mer Gov. W. W. Barron of West Virginia have agreed to settle a $10,000 tax deficiency claim for $5,000, accordingly to United States Tax Court records.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: ORIOLES HIT PEAK IN TWINS PLAYOFF
description: BALTMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles cele brated with relative calm after winning the American League pennant today, perhaps look ing forward with more resolve to the coming World Series.

title: Lions Rally in 2d Half to Topple Bears, 2814, for Third Straight Victory
description: DETROIT, Oct. 5 (AP)The Detroit Lions scored 21 points in the third quarter and got a fourthquarter touchdown after a key interception to beat the Chicago Bears, 2814, tonight and take possession of first place in the Central Division of the National Conference of the National Football League.

title: NIXON, BACK HOME, CITES ROLE OF U.S. FOR WORLD PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Pres ident Nixon pledged tonight, as he returned from Europe and the Mediterranean, that the power of the United States, if necessary, will be used to de fend freedom, but never to destroy it.

title: Nixon Visits Kildare
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 5President Nixon toured the green flats and hills of County Kildare to day, gave his endorsement to a disputed, finding that his an cestors lie buried there, and in voked their Quaker spirit to pledge himself to the works of peace.

title: Families of Indonesian Prisoners Are Losing Hope
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept, 20At a conservative estimate, 70,000 people remain impris oned in Indonesia on suspicion of having been connected with the abortive Communist coup d'tat five years ago this month. Fewer than 200 have been tried.

title: BUCKLEY STRESSES A U.S. DRUG ROLE
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 5The Con servative party's senatorial can didate, who customarily advo cates a smaller Federal role in the solution of citizens prob lems, indicated tonight that he believed that only the Federal, Government could effectively attack drug abuse.

title: MITCHELL CALLS U.S. BLAMELESS IN UNREST
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 (AP)  Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the suggestion by the President's Commission, on Campus Unrest that Federal leadership could halt campus disturbances was not viable.

title: Army, Slowed by Injuries Finds LongRange Booking Backfires
description: Problems created for Army about 10 years ago when the cadets unrealistic 1970 foot ball schedule was arranged are being compounded each week by injuries to front line players trying against heavy odds.

title: Turkey Questioned By U.S. on Transit Of Russian Jeeps
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 5 The transport of Soviet mili tary aid in the form of some jeeps to an Arab country through Turkey has resulted in some diplomatic exchanges be tween Turkey and the United States.

title: Transit Police Seek Dogs to Combat Crime
description: John T. Maye, president of the Transit Patrolmen's Ben evolent Association, urged the city yesterday to supply the 3,200member transit force with trained guard dogs to help police the sub ways.

title: West Virginia Trooper Killed
description: SWANDALE, W. Va., Oct. 5 (AP)A State Police trooper was shot and killed by a high powered rifle while attempting to serve a warrant near this rural central state community today, the State Police re ported. Killed was Trooper H. D. Swartz. A suspect, Ray Miller, who was named in the warrant was arrested.

title: Beira Boat Sinks With 53
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, Oct. 5 (UPI)A ferryboat carrying 53 persons ran aground and sank south of here today, the Portu guese press agency said. The bodies of at least 12 victims were reported recovered.

title: SLOBODY ANIK OFFERS 24 ETUDES BY CHOPIN
description: In his own chosen territory, Aleksandr Slobbdyanik, the So viet pianist who played at Philharmonic Hall Sunday after noon, was peerless. His tone was pearly, his fingers very fleet and he had highly individ ual musical ideas to offer.

title: Pell Urges Ocean Controls
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, Oct. (UPI)Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, called today for concerted na tional and international efforts to prevent destruction of the world's oceans. He warned the annual conference of the North east Industrial Developers As sociation of increasing cumula tive pollution of the oceans with lead, mercury, DDT, oil and other waste products.

title: KUHN AND UMPIRES CONFER TOMORROW
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 (AP) Major league umpire represent atives will meet Wednesday in New York with Commis sioner Bowie Kuhn, Harry Wendelstedt, an umpire in the National League playoff series, said today.

title: J. P. Morgan's Earnings Up 33.5% in 3d Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Co., Inc. whose principal subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany of New York, two weeks ago led the banking industry in reducing the prime lending rate, reported yesterday a 33.5 per cent increase In earnings for the third quarter.

title: U.S. QUESTIONS THAIS ON BASE FOR B52'S
Flood Threat in Caribbean
description: MIAMI, Oct. 5 (AP)A tropi cal depression dumped heavy rains on the Antilles today, and forecasters warned residents of the Dominican Republic to be prepared for extensive flooding. The center of the depression was about 200 miles southeast of the Barahona Peninsula of the Dominican Republic and was drifting northwesterly at a rate of 5 miles an hour.

title: A Rocket's Green Glare Visible Along Seaboard
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va. Oct. 5 (UPT)A fourstage Javelin rocket released an ar tificial cloud of Barium today that was visible along much of the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Mail Dates for Vietnam Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) Christmas packages weighing more than five pounds and go ing to Vietnam by surface mail should be mailed between Oct. 12 and Nov. 7, the Defense De partment said today. Those weighing less than 5 pounds and carrying regular postage should be mailed between Oct. 19 and Nov. 21, it said. Regular air mail should be posted be tween Nov. 30 and Dec. 12.

title: More Tupamaro Blackmail
description: Uruguay's Tupamaro terrorists are tryingunfortu nately with some successto regain their aura reasonable reformers and defenders of freedom with their latest offer to ransom the kidnapped American soils expert, Claude L. Fly. Ostensibly, all they ask the chance to put their case against President Pacheco's Government before their countrymen and the world.

title: Dream of Student Theater Becomes a Big Business
description: Our parents thought we were crazy for wanting to go into show business, but we weren't deterred, the young, slim, athleticlooking woman said, smiling reflec tively.

title: PALMER FANS 12, BEATS TWINS, 61
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5  For the second straight year, the Baltimore Orioles brushed aside the Minnesota Twins for the third straight game to win the championship of the split Amer ican League. Today's score was 61, with Jhri Palmer pitching a sevenhitter in which he struck out 12 men.

title: Polish Hijacker Sentenced
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 5 (UPI)A 29yearold Pole who hijacked a Polish Airlines plane to Denmark received a sixyear sentence today. Zgig niew Iwanick of Warsaw hi jacked the plane and its 23 pas sengers to Copenhagen last June 5 by threatening to ex plode two hand grenades.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This has been a glorious year for those who seek giant bluefin tuna with rod and reel, with the previous world record of 977 pounds, set in 1950 off St. Ann Bay, Nova Scotia, being broken four times.

title: Reds and Orioles Sweep Playoffs and Will Open World Series on Saturday
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5  The Cincinnati Reds succeeded the New York Mets as champions of the National League today when they defeated the Pitts burgh Pirates, 32, and com pleted a threegame sweep of their playoff for the penant.

title: Quarry, Trainer Suspended
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP)Jerry Quarry, the heavy weight boxer from Bellflower, Calif., and his trainer, Teddy Bentham, have been suspended again by the California Ath letic Commission. Today's sus pension was for failure to pay fines assessed after a fight in New York in which Quarry knocked out Mac Foster of Fresno, Calif. The fines were levied because the fight was staged while both were still un der a previous suspension.

title: Life Asked in Aramburu Case
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 (Reut ers)A public prosecutor today asked for life sentences for two persons charged with complicity in the kidnapping and assassi nation of former President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu. He also requested prison sentences of from six to eight years for a Roman Catholic priest and two women accused of aiding and abetting the abduction.

title: MRS. JOHN M. KYLE
description: Mrs. Virginia Tuxill Kyle, widow of John M. Kyle, chief engineer of the Port of New York Authority, died Sunday at Memorial Hospital for Can cer and Allied Diseases, after a long illness. She was 63 years old and lived at 356 East 50th Street. Mr. Kyle, 65, died last Wednesday of a heart attack.

title: Hanoi Officials Begin Talks in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. Thailand and North Vietnam resumed negotiations here to day over the repatriation of approximately 40,000 North Vietnamese refugees living in this country. The flow of returnees was halted in 1965 when the Hanoi Govern ment declared that American bombing prevented Its continua tion.

title: Ruling in Riot Victim's Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (UPI) A coroner's jury ruled today that Ruben Salazar, a. former columnist and television news director, died at the hands of another during rioting in East Los Angeles last Aug. 29. Mr. Salazar was killed by a tear gas projectile fired into a bar by a deputy sheriff.

title: Feeney Sisters Will Be Brides
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., Oct. 5 Mr. and Mrs. John J. Fee ney at Glen Rock and Monte Sereno, P. R., have announced the engagement of their two daughters. Miss Kathleen Mary Feeney will be married to George Winter Jr. of Aga na, Guam, and Miss Rose mary Feeney to James Rey nold (Jim) Lonborg, the Boston Red Sox pitcher.

title: Drunk Who Used a Knife To Hijack Jet Gets 15 Years
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) A man who in 1969 hijacked a jetliner armed only with a pen knife was sentenced today to 15 years in Federal prison.

title: Phone Company Gets Writ Barring Building Squatters
description: The New York Telephone Company obtained a court order yesterday barring squatters from several apartment build ings it has taken over on the Lower East Side for construc tion of a switching facility.

title: There Are Two Worlds on Quemoy, and One Is Underground
description: QUEMOYThis Chinese Na tionalist outpost off the Com munist  held mainland has a splitlevel existence.

title: JETS LURE MATHIS FROM RETIREMENT
description: To ease the loss of Matt Snell for the season, the New York Jets have lured Bill Mathis out of retirement.

title: Congress Leaders Fail to Agree on Adjournment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Par tisan maneuvering broke out today between the Democratic and Republican leaders in Con gress over whether to adjourn the 91st Congress before or after the November elections.

title: The Land and the Past
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4The incred ible size of a Boeing 747, the first time you fly in one, is not especially reassuring. If, as the passenger service people are eager to tell you, all the plane's wiring would stretch from Philadelphia to New York, with some left over, that is an awful lot of wiring that could go wrong.

title: No Guns on Campus
description: The tragedy of Kent State is a tragedy of irresponsible leadership. This grim picture emerges from the scrupu lously objective review by the President's Commission on Campus Unrest of the disorders which last May took the lives of four students at the Ohio university.

title: MRS. HARRY H. OSHRIN
description: Mrs. Emma Guttman Oshrin, widow of Harry H. Oshrin, theatrical lawyer who was co producer of Tobacco Road, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 81 years old and lived at 120 Central Park South. Mr. Oshrin died in 1961 at the age of 72.

title: Red Cross Asks Inquiry
description: Special to The New York Times

title: It Was Complete BedlamPunching and Screaming
SENATE PANEL HEARS RURAL HOUSING PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Federal housing programs are being ignored in some parts of the South and rural slums are being perpetuated to drive out blacks who might exercise new voting muscle, a Mis sissippi civil rights leader charged today.

title: Facts in Race for Fourth District
description: POPULATION: About 500, 000, mainly lower middle class, with black and Puerto Rican residents primarily in Trenton, and a large repre sentation of vegetable and dairy farmers.

title: MITCHELL REPORTS WIRETAPPING RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5At torney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that the Fed eral Government was rapidly expanding its use of wiretap ping against suspected crim inals.

title: The President Visits de Valera and Hears of Family Link to Ireland
Longer Middle East Truce Is Termed Likely by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The prospects of extending the Middle Eastern ceasefire, due to expire on Nov. 5, were rat ed extremely good today by senior officials of the Nixon Administration.

title: The Route to Jail Reform...
description: Now that a measure of surface calm has returned the city's riottorn prisons, neither the city nor state can afford to wait for the next inevitable explosion before undertaking drastic reform of the entire system of criminal justice.

title: Scientists in Venice Combat City's Sinking and Floods
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 26 By study of the air, the sea, the land and the water be neath the land, scientists here believe, and by feats of mathematics and technology to match the faith, genius and pride that built this city, Venice can be saved from the ravages of time.

title: CARLETON A. RANSOM
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Oct. 5 Carleton A. Ransom, who re tired in 1961 after 40 years with the Metropolitan Insur ance Company in New York, died Saturday in Princeton Hospital. He was 75 years olds, and lived at 1003 Midwood Ave.

title: Mara, Giants' Head, Unruffled Despite Team's Poor Start
description: While the Giant coaches and players try to work out of their threegame losing streak, the owner of the foot ball team looks at life from a longer viewpoint.

title: BOSS GETS ASSIST FOR TOLAN'S PLAY
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5  Bob Howsam, dripping with perspir ation and champagne, thrust his large hand through the crowd surrounding Bob Tolan and congratulated Cincinnati's center fielder for getting the hit that had just made the Reds the National League cham pions.

title: Senate Sends Nixon 3.1Billion Measure For Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Senate sent to president Nixon late today a $3.1billion mass transit subsidy bill de signed to help cities revive or build subway and bus systems.

title: Middle East and Mankind's Future
description: LONDONThree recent events have cast long shadows over the Middle East. These are, in chronological order, the forward movement of missile sites by Egyptians and Russians in the Canal Zone in violation of the stand still agreement, the Jordanian tank victory over the Syrian invaders, and the death of President Nasser. Wecannot yet tell their consequences. It is only certain that the tangle of rela tions in the area will not be the same again. Just conceivab,ly their disparate impact could open possibilities for peace.

title: Money
description: Monday, Oct. 5, 1970

title: BOYCOTT STAGED AT FRANKLIN H.S.
description: Almost all 4,400 students at Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem boycotted class es yesterday to protest the Board of Education's refusal to appoint a popular former teach er as principal.

title: State Reassigning Judges in Move to Reduce Heavy Backlog in Criminal Cases Here
description: Six weeks ago the State Supreme Court's chief admin istrative judge for Manhattan and the Bronx warned sharply of an impending crisis in the administration of justice be cause of a huge backlog of criminal cases.

title: TRANSIT POLICEMAN ACCUSED IN ROBBERY
description: A Transit Authority police man shot a masked man trying to hold up a subway change booth yesterday and then dis covered that the gunman was the policeman he had relieved on post an hour earlier, the police said.

title: Explosion in Chicago Rips Statue of a Policeman
description: CHICAGO, Oct 5An ex plosion ripped apart the statue of a policeman on Haymarket Square early this morning, a day less than a year after the monument had been blown up on the eve of the Weatherman demonstrations here.

title: Race in Fifth District at a Glance
description: POPULATION: 577,383, ac cording to the 1970 census, an increase of more than 170,000 since 1960: It com prises Morris and Somerset counties, which were once essentially rural, with large homes and estates, but in recent years it has grown more suburban and indus trial. The largest municipal ity is ParsippanyTroy Hills Township.

title: Vonnegut Is Having Fun Doing a Play
description: For Kurt Vonnegut Jr., whose Happy Birthday, Wanda June opens tomor row at the Theater de Lys, it has been a 20year climb from culthero to culture hero. And one indication that Vonnegut has arrived, with full literary celebrity and fi nancial success, is the ease with which his play reached Production.

title: Film: Andy Warhol's 'Trash' Arrives:Heroin Addict's Life Is Theme of Film Techniques of 30's on View at Cinema II
description: The opening credits ("Andy Warhol Presents Trash . . . ") appear as words spelled out in little light bulbs of the sort still used on old theater marquees. On the soundtrack can be heard some breathless, tinny movie music taken from Josef von Sternberg's "The Blue Angel." Even if you don't get the point immediately, you will soon after "Trash" begins. This second film by Paul Morrissey (his first was "Flesh," described as a tribute to John Ford) is a relentless send-up of attitudes and gestures shanghaied from Hollywood's glamorous nineteen-thirties and forties.The joys of "Trash," which opened yesterday at the Cinema II, are not inexhaustible, but compared to things like the pretensions of "Cover Me, Babe" and the calculating heart of "Sunflower," "Trash" is true-blue movie-making, almost epic, funny and vivid, though a bit rotten at the core. I'm writing this on Monday and I'll say, quite simply, that it's the best American film made in New York that I've seen all day.Like "Flesh," to which it is a kind of moralizing sequel, "Trash" is a circular odyssey, only this time Joe (Joe Dallessandro), the male hustler of "Flesh," is a heroin addict. In spite of pimples on his rump and face, his physique is still so magnificently shaped that men as well as women become disconnected at the sight of him, all of which does no one any good, since Joe is impotent."Trash" is the story of Joe and his lover-protector Holly (Holly Woodlawn) who, in real life, is a female impersonator, though in the film the matter of Holly's sex is ambiguous. Joe and Holly try to make a go of things in their lower East Side basement, from which Holly goes forth from time to time to cruise the Filmore East and to scavenge garbage cans, while Joe's journeys are in search of real junk. The film takes its shape principally from his encounters, which have the style (and the substance) of grotesque grass fantasies.There is a sweet, absolutely round-breasted go-go dancer (Geri Miller) whose philosophy sounds as if it could have been learned at Judge Hardy's knee: "If you're sexy, you can be sexy doing anything. Sex is from the inside." There's a soft-headed girl from Grosse Pointe (Jane Forth), whose apartment Joe intends to rob. Instead, he gets propositioned for a rape."I'm only a rich newlywed with no furniture," she says by way of introduction. Later, while the camera is in a tight close-up on Joe's arm as he gives himself a fix, Jane whines at her husband:"Oh, Bruce, we don't have fun any more. Do you know how long it is since I slept with another man?"All feelings, all values are turned upside down and played for laughs, with the result that it's difficult for me to take "Trash" more seriously than it takes itself. In spite of the grubbiness of the scene and the ineffectuality of the various disguises and escapes employed by Joe and Holly and the rest, there is no sense of despair. At heart, the film is a kind of exuberant exhibition of total apathy.Mr. Morrissey is, I think, a talented moviemaker, even though much of the effect of "Trash" depends on outrageous shock or on rather curious plays on pathos. I assume that the performers have been handled with skill, in spite of the fact that it's not always possible to tellin this sort of moviejust what the performers themselves have brought to their roles.Holly Woodlawn, especially, is something to behold, a comic book Mother Courage who fancies herself as Marlene Dietrich but sounds more often like Phil Silvers. I shall also remember for some time the very funny performance by Michael Sklar as a welfare investigator who comes to call on Holly and becomes enchanted by her silver shoes, which, he thinks, would make a marvelous lamp."Trash" is alive, but like the people in it, it continually parodies itself, and thus it represents a kind of dead end in filmmaking.

title: Earth Energy Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) A bill designed to encourage private development of the earth's natural heat energy for generation of electric power was passed by voice vote in the House today.

title: U.N. Unit Needs $3Million To Repair 2 Amman Camps
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5The head of the United Na tions relief operations for Pal estinian refugees estimated to day that his agency needed $3million to make up for the heavy damage inflicted on the two refugee camps in Amman during recent fighting.

title: Campus Panel's Future
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 When the President's Commission on Campus Unrest issued its third and final report yesterday, it completed its work in only the most superficial sense. As the President himself suggested be fore leaving for Europe, the de cisive phase will take place one day soon when he sits down with William W. Scranton, the commission chair man, to discuss what to do about the commission's recommendations. Considering only the immediate, angry at tacks on the commission by Vice President Agnew and other defenders of the President, the outcome appears obviousand negative.

title: ROCKEFELLER GAINS POINT WITH LABOR
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 5Gover nor Rockefeller turned what might have been an embarrass ment into political profit today when about 200 Rochester fire men refused to allow him past their picket line and into City Hall.

title: New Pearl Harbor Shrine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) The House approved today and sent to the White House legislation authorizing $118,000 to put up a flagpole so that the flag may fly over the hull of the battleship U.S.S. Utah as, another Pearl Harbor memorial. One flies now over the U.S.S. Arizona, also sunk in the Japa nese attack of Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Germany's Money Reserves Raised by Foreign Inflows
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Oct. 5 (Reuters)Ger many's total monetary reserves rose by 278 million marks ($75 million) to 42.86 billion marks in the week to Sept. 30.

title: Growing Number of Colleges Taking Tougher Stand in Guidelines on Protests
description: A growing number of col leges and universities around the country are issuing new guidelines on campus dissent that generally take a firmer stand against disturbances by students, nonstudents and fac ulty than in previous years.

title: 6 TORTOISES TO GET JET TRIP TO HAWAII
description: The Bronx Zoo began yester day to crate its six surviving giant Galapagos tortoises, rare and endangered species, for shipment to the Honolulu Zoo and the Galapagos Islands. The purpose: breeding.

title: Manson Leaps at Judge in the Tate Murder Trial and Declares Someone Should Cut Your Head Off
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 Charles M. Manson leaped at the judge in the Sharon Tate murder trial today and said after being subdued that someone should cut your head off.

title: JAIL SURVEY ASKS LESS TRIAL DELAY
description: The State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction said yesterday that it would seek legislation mandating trials within 60 days of arrest as a means of avoiding overcrowd ing in prisons.

title: Harcourt Brace Acquires Munich Publishing House
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has purchased the publishing house of Johann Ambrosius Barth in Munich. The purchase price was not revealed.

title: U.S. Agency Urges Denial Of Appeal on Busing Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to dismiss an appeal from a decision invalidating North Carolina's antibusing law.

title: For 2 Weeks There'll Be a Roman Holiday on 34th St.
London Gold Price Soars
description: LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The London Free Market gold price soared to $36.75 today its highest level for nearly a year.

title: A Correction
description: The obituary of Henry Wil liam Simon, author, former music critic and publisher, that appeared in The New York Times on Saturday inadvert ently omitted the name of a surviving sister, Mrs. Elizabeth S. Seligmann, wife of Dr. Arthur Seligmann of the staff of New York Hospital and Cornell Uni versity Medical Center.

title: Fairchild Hiller Move Set
description: The Fairchild Hiller Corpo ration announced yesterday that it had decided to move its Stratos division operations from Bay Shore, L.I. to Man hattan Beach, Calif. In a letter to all StratosBay Shore em ployes the company said that if it is to achieve its future ob jective of establishing a sound, broad technological base from which to compete more ef fectively in chosen markets and product areas this reloca tion is necessary.

title: Carolina Golf Course Told By Court to Desegregate
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 5 (AP) Reversing a Federal district court, the United States Court of Appeals for The Fourth Cir cuit today directed the granting of a preliminary injunction re quiring desegregation of a golf course in Durham, N. C.

title: Price Changes Hit TV Sets and Steel
description: The RCA Corporation hinted lat a trend yesterday when it raised distributor prices an av erage of 3 per cent on its pres ent line of color and black andwhite television receivers.

title: CARDINALS TRADE ALLEN TO DODGERS
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers traded today Ted Sizemore, an infielder who was rookie of the year in 1969, and Bob Stinson, a minorleague catcher, to the St. Louis Cardinals for heavy hitting Richie Allen.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, Oct. 5, 1970

title: Texas Diphtheria Toll Up 2
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP)  Confirmed diphtheria cases rose by two to 116 today, health officials said. Uncon firmed cases in the city's grow ing epidemic stood at 36. The latest cases were two girls, ages 3 to 9.

title: Stocks in Surprise Rally Advance 10.54 to 776.70
description: This market looks incred ibly strong, a Wall Street broker declared at noon yes terday. I'd say it is essentially a continuation of Friday's rally.

title: Deborah Randell to Be Married In December to Robert Taggart
description: PINELAND, Fla., Oct. 5 Miss Deborah Louise Randell and Robert Wallace Taggart will be married in December in Miami at the home of the future bride's grandfather, Charles H. Crandon, for whom Crandon Park on Key Biscayne is named.

title: Moody's Fund Deal Dropped
description: Vance, Sanders & Co., the big Bostonbased mutual fund advisor and distributor, an nounced yesterday that it had terminated its agreement to take over Moody's Capital Fund, Inc., and Moody's Fund, Inc., from Moody's Investors Service. Dun & Bradstreet, parent company of Moody's, announced last week that shareholders of Moody's Capi tal Fund had approved the con troversial deal, but the con tract for the deal had expired and Vance, Sanders decided not to extend it.

title: 3 FREED IN SAIGON AFTER JOINT FAST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5Three student leaders were released from prison to day after a protest fast by them and by fellow students and sympathetic university professors.

title: The Princeton Plan
description: The current assault on campus vio lence may do more harm to student moderates than to bombthrowing radicals. The aims of those spear heading the campaigns are hard to fault: they want to stop the appalling arson and disruptions of learning.

title: Variety of Cancer Tissues Found to Share a Type of Chemical Abnormality
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 More than two dozen kinds of cancer tissue, including some human cancers, have been found to share a fundamental type of chemical abnormality.

title: The Confessions of Nelson Gross
description: Early in his campaign for United States Senator from New Jersey, Nelsbn G. Gross incensed conservative Republicans and surprised everyone by taking sharp issue with the Nixon Administration on several major issues. Then in midcampaign, Mr. Gross abruptly changed direction, became an ardent Nixon man and impliedor let someone writing in his name implythat his early liberal positions owed more to expediency than conviction.

title: End Boston College R.O.T.C.
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP)The board of directors of Boston College has approved resolu tions for severance of ties be tween the college and the Army Reserve Officers Training Corps, by September of 1971.

title: Stage: Opium, Farewell to Addiction
description: Opium seems to be the narcotic of poets. Perhaps they are attracted to it by its ritual, for it seems that the smoking of this alkaloid grandfather of morphine and heroin requires a ceremony that might by itself inflame a romantic imagination.

title: SALTY TIGER WINS IN 250MILE SAIL
description: LITTLE CREEK, Va., Oct. 5 Walter S. (Wally) Frank's Salty Tiger, the 47foot alumi numhulled yawl out of Cedar Point Y.C:, Westport, Conn., was named winner today of the third annual Storm Trysail Club race from Sandy Hook to Ches apeake Bay. The 270mile race ended late last night.

title: Quads Born in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 5 (UPI) Quadruplets, four boys weigh ing less than three pounds each, were born in St. Raphael's Hospital here today, the first birth of quads in the hospital in 30 years. Their condition was described as guarded. The mother, Mrs. Charles Loh renz, was reported in good con dition.

title: Senate Shelves Direct Election Even With Compromise by Bayh
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  Unable to reach agreement even on a watereddown com promise, the Senate shelved the controversial electoral reform issue today.

title: 3DMARKET DEALINGS ARE FOUND STABLE
description: No significant decline in thirdmarket dealings has re sulted from the volume dis counts in commission rates in stituted by the New York Stock Exchange in December, 1968, according to a study by two assistant professors at the University of Wisconsin's School of Business Adminis tration.

title: Books of The Times
description: Three variations on a theme of madness: (1) White madness. In Donald New love's remarkable novel, Gabriel is an artist living in the East Village near Seventh Street and Avenue B. His message is on canvas, and consists of wind, the burning city and the Holy Ghost. But Gabriel is con siderably more than a delivery boy for God; to get his message, he wrestles with de mons, drinks gin, smokes pot, ponders mys tical texts, listens to a lot of Bruckner and goes insane. He is assisted in these activ ities by a writer, a psychoanalyst, a Scien tologist, a theosophist, a Polish carpenter, a homosexual hustler, several failed proph ets and the Puerto Ricans who rob his apartment and mug his friends.

title: Posts Filled by R. H. Macy
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., has announced the appointments of Henry T. Emmons to vice presi dentexecutive development; Elias S. Gottlieb to vice presi dentresearch; Mortimer B. Leavitt to vice president and assistant controller; G. Menzies Rodgers Jr. to vice president and assistant treasurer, and Julian L. Glass and Ray L. Treiger to vice presidents real estate.

title: Cambodian Base Repels Attack
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 5 (AP) Communist troops re portedly tried for 11 hours to overrun a Cambodian military base 57 miles southwest of here but were driven off early today in heavy fighting.

title: An Agnew L.P. Album Used for Fund Raising
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Republicans are pushing one of their stars in the polit ical hit parade with a long playing album, Spiro T. Ag new Speaks Out.

title: Some Charges on Metal Move Downward
description: Prices for some grades of coldrolled sheet steel, an im portant product category, ap peared yesterday to be headed significantly downward.

title: 12 Blacks Deny Gun Charges
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 (AP)Twelve black militants charged with attempted mur der in a gun battle with the police last month at a Negro housing project pleaded not guilty today. The defendants were returned to prison after their arraignment. They are being held on $100,000 bond each while efforts to reduce the bonds are pending in court.

title: Bridge:
description: The capture of the world team title by the Dallas Aces in Stockholm in June some what overshadowed another significant American triumph: the victory of Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles and Marilyn Johnson of Oakland, Calif., in the world women's pairs in the Olympiad.

title: Mrs. Mary D. Harrington Is Bride
description: Mrs. Mary Denson Harring ton and William Edwards Murray, a lawyer and finan cier here and in Atlanta, were married in Newport, R. I., on Aug. 21.

title: Maryland's Friedel Concedes
description: BALTIMORE, Oct.. 5 (UPI) Representative Samuel. Friedel, a Maryland Democrat who has been in Congress 18 years, conceded defeat today to Par ren Mitchell, a Negro candidate, in the Sept. 15 Democratic pri mary in the state's Seventh Congressional District. Mr. Frie del previously had requested a Congressional investigation of official returns that showed Mr. Mitchell winning by 38 votes, after unofficial figures had shown Mr. Friedel winning.

title: GOLDBERG ASSAILS STATE ON DRUGS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg renewed his attack on Governor Rocke feller's antinarcotics program yesterday, terming it a $345 million flop that has been an expensive failure for a state faced with a narcotics epi demic.

title: JOHN BUCKLEY, 79, RETIRED PUBLISHER
description: John R. Buckley, a former vice president of Hearst Maga zines and publisher of Good Housekeeping, died in St. Thom as, Virgin Islands, last Thurs day. He was 79 years old, and had retired, in 1956. He and his wife, Dorothy who sur vives, lived at Flagg Hill, St. Thomas.

title: RumrillHoyt Gets Irish Airlines
description: RumrillHoyt, most of whose airline experience has come from flying its executives between its New York and Rochester offices via Mohawk, has just landed the Irish International Airlines account. It bills $1.5million, which is a good piece of change, even in Rochester.

title: AMMAN REPORTS A DUAL PULLOUT
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 5 King Hussein's Government said today that roughly 1,500 Arab commandos pulled out of Amman yesterday and that thousands of Jordanian troops had left the Amman area for positions along the front line with Israel.

title: 2d Ave. Subway Hearings To Open at City Hall Today
description: The public will have the op portunity at City Hall today to propose various locations for subway stops on the proposed Second Avenue Subway.

title: No Loner in Love With Cardin, but Faithful to His Clothes
description: Jeanne Moreau is 42 now, but you wouldn't guess it with her new fringe of youthful blond bangs. The face still has its slightly devastated look, the upper lip is as pouty as ever, and, of course, she's wearing a Pierre Cardin dress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Nasser's Greatness

title: New Postal Rules Due Soon
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (UPI) Assistant Postmaster General Frank J. Nunlist said today that changes in postal regulations and procedures would be dis tributed shortly to postmasters in the 15 national regions to improve mail service. He said that the new procedures would be made public well before Thanksgiving.

title: Big Stores in September Showed Slim Sales Gains
description: Bigstore sales in New York City in September again re flected strong buying reluc tance among consumers, al though overall results were somewhat better than those of other recent months.

title: The Pope and the President
description: ROMEIn his role as global peace maker, the Pope can be used by the Church's friends much more easily than by its enemies. Current Papal policy indicates that the Holy Father will receive the head or emissary of any nation desirous of visiting him, no matter what the religious belief or political persuasion of the, national leader or his people.

title: Brandeis Dinner to Honor 2 News Sales Executives
description: Brandeis University will en tertain at a dinner dance at the Plaza Hotel here next Tuesday to honor Robert B. Cohen of Englewood, N. J., and G. B. McCombs of Swarthmore, Pa., for their services to higher ed ucation.

title: Chevalier Here to Lure Readers, Not Listeners
... and Saving Legal Services
description: One of Washington's most successful endeavors helping the man in the streetthe Office of Economic Opportunity's legal services for poor clientsis being harassed on two fronts: administrative and financial. The comparatively new notion in American jurisprudence that equal justice must be practically applied to the indi gent will suffer a setback unless O.E.O.'s 2,000 lawyers in 850 offices around the country are allowed to continue in their dedicated work.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: By Reuters

title: A Correction
description: The caption under a photo graph of an urban transit ve hicle that appeared in The Times last Sunday erroneously indicated the vehicle was made by the Dashaveyor Company. It should have said that the man ufacturer was the Alden Self Transit Systems Corporation.

title: 4 WHITE BOYS SHOT IN PONTIAC CLASH
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 5 Four white youths were shot and wounded today, one se riously, during a dispute with a group of about 20 Negro youths outside Pontiac Central High School, the police said.

title: Columbia Gets $1,627,500 In Ford Foundation Grants
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, dean of the School of International Affairs at Columbia University, announced yesterday grants totaling $1,627,500 from the Ford Foundation.

title: CHARLES R. STRYKER
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 5 Charles R. Stryker, retired re search instrument designer in the medical and scientific field, died Saturday evening at Nor walk Hospital after a short ill ness. His age was 79 and he lived at 270 Newtown Avenue.

title: Yemen Area, Dry 5 Years, Flooded by a 30Day Rain
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, Oct. 5The Tihama region of neigh boring Yemen, rainless for more than five years and now desert, has been flooded by continuous rain over the last 30 days.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
INSURANCE POLICY LINKED TO STOCKS
description: The New York Life Insurance Company, the fourthlargest in surer in the country, said yes terday, that it would introduce a new kind of life insurance policy next year based on the performance of the stock mar ket.

title: White Is Leaving Jets'
description: Ask Lee White if he minded sitting on the bench for two years while Matt Snell played fullback most of the time for the New York Jets and his honest answer is no.

title: ROBBERIES UP 34.6% IN REPORT BY CITY
description: The number of robberies re ported to the New York City Police. Department in August was 34.6 per cent higher than for the same month last year, the nonce said yesterday.

title: Garelik Calls Rand Study Of City's Police a Failure
description: A $500.000 consultant study of the Police Department by the Rand Corporation was termed a failure and was abruptly terminated, Council President Sanford D. Garelik said yesterday.

title: NOSTALGIA SHAPES NEW PARSONS DANCE
description: Elements of the new nostal gia and contemporary brutal, ism were seen last night at Choreoconcerts first program of the season at the New school. The evening showed four new works, all commis sioned by the sponsoring or ganization.

title: 25th Test of Navy Missile
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP)A Poseidon missile was Fired from a submarine through stormy seas today on the 25th Plight test for the Navy's new weapon system

title: Cadmium Price Is Cut
description: American Metal Climax, Inc., cut the price of cadmium yes terday to $2.75 a pound from $3.25 a pound, effective imme diately. At the same time, the Anaconda Company, a major copper producer, raised its quo tation for selenium to $9 a pound from $8 a pound for commercial powder at points in the United States.

title: A CHILE NEWS UNION VOTES OUT LEFTISTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 6 The union leadership of report ers and editors on Chile's largest newspaper, El Mercurio, has been overthrown in a series of events arising from the coun try's tense presidential politics.

title: Market Place.
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 6The Financial Analysts Federation convention began its second day here in a buoyant mood. As counterpoint, the broad tapenever far from sight beat a pleasant tattoo telling of rising stock prices and heavy trading activity.

title: House Votes to Cut Off Funds For I. L. O. for First Half of 71
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The House of Representatives voted today to cut off the United States contribution to the In ternational Labor Organization for the first half of 1971. The action virtually assured the first refusal of the United States to pay a financial obligation to an international body.

title: Suspension of Talks Sought
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6The United States an nounced today that it wished to suspend Middle East talks among the deputy delegates of Britain, France and the Soviet Union at the United Nations pending rectification of re ported violations of the stand still agreement along the Suez Canal.

title: CHANGES PLANNED IN EXCHANGE RULE
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed plans yester day to make important changes in the net capital, requirements of its member firms, apparently in response to shortcomings in capital rules that became evid ent in the recent stock market decline.

title: PAYOFF 2D HIGHEST OF LOCAL SEASON
description: While a 431 shot and a 221 shot combined for a $1,265.60 daily double, another long shot attracted attention at Belmont Park yesterday by picketing the track for the second straight day.

title: CONNECTICUT ADDS TO JOBLESS HELP
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 6In spe cial session that lasted 24 min utes, the Connecticut General Assembly today passed with out debate a .bill enabling un employed workers to receive Federal funds for extended compensation payments.

title: MARAVICH MAKES LOCAL PRO DEBUT
description: The Knickerbockers, who handed out many onesided thrashings last season as they were moving to their first Na tional Basketball Association championship in 24 years, were on the receiving end of one last night.

title: MANSON AND WOMEN BARRED FROM COURT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6  Charles M. Manson and three women codefendants refused today to promise not to disrupt the court, and the judge ordered them kept out of the courtroom.

title: Television
description: James Drury, left, and Stewart Granger in The Men From Shiloh, Ch. 4 at 7:30 PM.

title: Bronx Landlords Caution Tenants To Pay Full Rents
description: Bronx apartment owners whose employes are on strike declared yesterday they in tended to warn their tenants that they were responsible for full rent and would be liable to a penalty or additional rent if they did not pay up in full.

title: Berlin Traffic Slowed By the East Germans
description: BERLIN, Oct. 6East Ger many closed the autobahn checkpoint of Marienborn at the West German border for 15 minutes today, hampering traffic to and from West Berlin.

title: City Club to Honor Mrs. Lasker
description: The City Club of New York will hold its annual Award Dinner in the Imperial Ballroom at the Americana Hotel on Oct. 20. Robert W. Dowling and Elmer H. Bobst are cochairmen for the event, at which Mrs. Albert D. Lasker will receive the club's Distinguished New Yorker Award for her con tributions in the fields of health and medicine, for her devotion to many philan thropic causes and, particu larly, for her efforts toward the beautification of New York and the United States.

title: Chaos vs. Liberty
description: It is high time that we discarded once and for all the idea that crime is rooted in economic conditions. This was impressed upon me not long ago by a young man who wrote to me from Guatemala, where he had been living in an extremely impoverished Indian village. Crime, he said, was virtually unknown there. Thievery was extremely rare. The people were im poverished, to be sure, but they had moral code, and that code was firmly implanted in the children so that was transmitted from one generation to the next. What made this a peace ful, crimefree village was not eco nomic affluence, but the moral char aeter of the people.

title: Missile Cone Intercepted In 2d Test of Safeguard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) A Spartan missile intercepted a ballistic missile nose cone high over the Pacific in the second successful test of the controversial Safeguard anti ballistic missile system, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Elizabeth Taylor's Son Wed
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Michael Wilding, 18yearold son of Elizabeth Taylor, mar ried Beth Clutter, 19, of Port land, Ore., today after an en gagement of one week

title: British Football Results
description: By Reuters

title: Deputy Minister Is Named Soviet Ambassador to Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Soviet Union has designated Deputy Foreign Minister Vladi mir M. Vinogradov as ambassa dor to Egypt to succeed Sergei A. Vinogradov, who died in Au gust, the newspaper Al Akhbar said today.

title: Parks for America
description: A sudden flurry of activity raises hope that the 91st Congress may at last acquit itself well in the matter of creating new parkland for the American people. Besides the Apostle Islands Lakeshore bill, already signed into law by President Nixon, the House has already approved four other noteworthy projects. Since it is usually the Senate that takes the lead in park legisla tion, prospects are bright that all four will become realities this year.

title: 54 LBS. OF COCAINE IS SEIZED ON PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Customs officials at Dulles International Airport tonight seized cocaine that they esti mated had a potential maxi mum value of $10million and arrested two Colombian citi zens.

title: I. C. C. SEEKS LAW ON HOLDING UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission asked Congress to day for broad authority over conglomerate and holding com pany activities such as those involved in the bankruptcy pro ceedings of the Penn Central Railroad.

title: Equitable Life Returning to TV
description: This Saturday after a nineyear absence, Equitable Life is bounding back into network television aboard the World Series on N.B.C. After that it will be sports, sports, sports all the way. The whole thing is so athletic you wouldn't believe it.

title: Executive Changes
description: William A. Marquard Jr., has been made chief operating officer and a director, Laurence C. Ward becomes chief financial and administrative officer and Thomas M. Sheridan and William Lyon were named executive vice presidents at American Standard, Inc.

title: P.O.W. Tax Relief Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  American servicemen miss ing in action or held as pris oners of war would be ex empted from income taxes under a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Repub lican of Pennsylvania.

title: Information on Sixth District
description: POPULATIONAbout 594, 000, according to the 1970 census; predominantly white AngloSaxon Protestant and Scandinavian, with heavy recent infusions of Puerto Ricans and blacks, notably in the western urban sections and in the central agricultu ral areas.

title: Times Discussing Acquisition Of Certain Cowles Properties
description: Possible acquisition by the New York Times Company of certain properties of Cowles Communications, Inc., has been discussed by the two enter prises.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES A $2BILLION CUT IN DEFENSE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The House Appropriations Commit tee cut the Administration's rock bottom defense budget by $2billion today, approving $66.6billion in new funds for the Pentagon.

title: Gielgud, Richardson Due Here in Home
Business Records
description: Southern District

title: The Quest for Civilization
description: LONDONWe have no idea where we are going, and sweeping, confident articles on the future seem to me, in tellectually, the most disreputable of all forms of public utterance. The sci entists who are best qualified to talk have kept their mouths shut. J. B. S. Haldane summed up the situation when he said: My own suspicion is that the universe is not only queerer than we suppose, but queerer than we can suppose. I saw a new heaven and a new earth, for the old heaven and the old earth had passed away. Which reminds us that the universe so vividly described in the Book of Revelation is queer enough; but with the help of symbols not beyond description. Whereas our universe cannot even be stated symbolically.

title: Advertising: Marketing OffTraCk Betting
description: We'll have to do a hell of a lot of advertising before We'll have a hell of a lot of business, said Howard J. Samuels, head of the Off Track Betting Corporation, which is now trying to make up its mind about picking one of six ad agencies.

title: EXCONVICT'S BODY FOUND IN CAR HERE
description: Salvatore (Sally Burns) Gra nello, reputedly a Mafia figure, was found in the trunk of an automoble, shot to death, on the Lower East Side, the police reported last night.

title: Catholic Lawyers Propose Aid For These in Church Disputes
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6A committee of Roman Catholic canon lawyers proposed today the establishment of a legal aid program to protect the rights: of individuals involved in disputes within the church.

title: Service Teams to Keep Rough Schedules
description: Army, Navy and the Air Force have no intention of downgrad ing their football schedules.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Before Bill Klein arrived on the scene about six decades ago to give his profes sion dignity and direction, the only dress ing rooms the umpires had in most ball parks were the groundskeepers tool sheds. So they came to work in their blue serge suits, hung their derby hats on a peg, took their blue caps from a back pocket, switched from patent leather shoes to spikes and were ready for action.

title: Tower Satisfies G.O.P. on Disbursal of Election Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Sen ator John G. Tower, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, evidently satisfied the Republican Policy Committee today that he had disbursed campaign funds fairly.

title: RICHARD A. LIPMAN
description: Richard A. Lipman, president of the L. J. Newton Company, a furniture importing and dis tributing subsidiary of W. & J. Sloane Inc., died yesterday in his home at 480 Park Avenue. He was 62 years old.

title: 4 Senators and 2 Scientists Urge End of Manned Space Flights Within 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Four Senators joined two leading sci entists today in urging that the manned space program be ended within three years, a po sition that is drawing increas ing support in Congress.

title: Wichita State in Doubt On Completing Season
description: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 6 (AP)A Wichita State Uni versity spokesman said to day no decision had been made on whether the final six games of the football season would be played. The scheduled game with South ern Illinois this Saturday was canceled.

title: Chiefs Dawson Sidelined Again By Knee Injury,
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 6 (AP) Len Dawson, the Kansas City Chiefs star quarterback, was sidelined again today with an other knee injury.

title: Times Wins Wildlife Prize For Conservation Editorials
description: The New York Times yester day became the first newspaper to receive the World Wildlife Fund's Certificate of Merit. The Times was cited by the fund for taking the national lead in editorially supporting the con servation of endangered spe riec

title: Police Officials Endorse Senate Bills Aimed at Curbing Urban Guerrilla Warfare
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Law enforcement officers and offici als opened Senate hearings to day on urban guerrilla warfare by endorsing several tough bills aimed at curbing snipers, bomb ers and attacks on policemen.

title: Seventh District Race at a Glance
description: POPULATION440,000 in northwestern Bergen Couuty, a predominantly white, afflu ant suburb with neighbor hoods of bluecollar workers in the southern part of the district.

title: Red Sox Complete Deal
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 6 (UPI) The deal that sent Bob Bolin, a Milwaukee pitcher, to Boston was completed today, when the Red Sox sent the Brewers Al Yates, an outfielder from Louis ville of the International League.

title: BOREK IS SECOND ON CREEK COURSE
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 6Billy Farrell played The Creek course for the first time in practice yesterday. To day the 36yearold son of Johnny Farrell, the former United States Open champion, led the first round of the Met ropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship with a record sixunderpar 64.

title: Film Festival Revenues Fall Below Last Year's
description: The eighth New York Film Festival proved disappointing at the box office, as predicted at the end of the event last week. Figures released yester day by Martin E. Segal, presi dent of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, sponsors of the festival, showed a total gross of $104,063 against $124,481 last year.

title: Foss Concert Off to Dec. 15
description: The concert of Lukas Foss's music originally scheduled for presentation at the Metropoli tan Museum of Art on Oct. 13 has been postponed to Dec. 15. The performance was to have been the first in a series of five events entitled Composers in Performance. : The series will begin with what was to have been the second presen tation, a concert of works by George Crumb on Nov. 10.

title: Panel Agrees to Curb Crimes Swiss Accounts Hide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  A HouseSenate conference com mittee reached agreement to day on a comprehensive bill to combat massive tax evasion, stock fraud and other crimes by the prosperous under the cover of secret Swiss bank ac counts, Congressional sources said.

title: 4 Die in South Africa Crash
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A twin engine Douglas DC 3 transport crashed and exploded shortly after taking off from nearby Rand Airport today, killing four and injuring 11 persons on board. It was on a regular flight to the Orapa mine of the AngloAmerican Corpora tion in Botswana.

title: Vice President Renews His Attack on Goodell
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct., 6Vice President Agnew renewed his frontal attack on Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, here tonight while backing gingerly Way from a potential confrontation With one of Goodell's de fenders, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, the Senate minority leader.

title: Canada Rejects Ransom Terms For Kidnapped British Official
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 6The Ca nadian government refused to night to meet in full the ran som demands of the kidnappers of James R. Crois, a British of ficial who was abducted at gunpoint from his Montreal home yesterday morning by Franch Canadian separtists.

title: 22 Car Freight Train Plunges Into the Passaic River
description: NEWARK, Oct 6Seven teen freight cars and five en gines, which had been On three separate tracks in a Jersey Central freight yard here, were assembled surreptitiously into a train early this morning and sent rolling off an open draw bridge into the Passaic River.

title: RULINGS DELAYED BY SONMY JUDGE
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 6 Lastminute legal technicalities were apparently cleared away today in the pending courtmar tial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell, who is charged with participat ing in the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians in the vil lage of Sonmy more than two years ago.

title: GEORGE HARSTEDT SR.
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 6 George W. Harstedt Sr., a re tired insurance executive, died yesterday at his home, 3 Homestead Path. He was 81 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1970

title: 2 Drown as Floods Ravage Puerto Rico After Storm
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 6 (AP)  Two persons drowned, about 200 homes were destroyed and more than 4,000 persons were evacuated as flooding occurred over most of Puerto Rico today after three days of torrential rains.

title: Lindsay Says U.S. Needs Unified Fuel Policy to Bar Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Mayor Lindsay of New York City told a House subcommittee today that the Federal Govern ment, while conducting a num ber of studies on the fuel short age, had no strategy for dealing with the problem on a fixed timetable.

title: White House Attempts To Bar Chef's Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A White House spokesman acknowledged to day that the Washingtonian magazine had been asked not to print a comment by Presi dent Nixon's chef that Mr. Nixon likes to have a mar tini before dinner and mixes it himself.

title: SALIGER CITES RISE IN U.S.I.F. REDEEMING
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Redemptions of United States International Fund (U.S.I.F.) real estate have reached mas sive proportions, deputy chair man of Gramco, Ltd., Pierre Salinger said today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Commerce. President Nixon established the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Ad ministration in the Commerce Department and ordered the transfer of certain programs and activities to the Com merce Department.

title: In the Audience, Another Fashion Show
description: The affluent, shepherded by Josephine Hughes of Berg dorf Goodman, had a guided tour through the fashion pas ture yesterday. Miss Hughes, whose talents as a sales woman are said to be per suasive enough to sell a Cor sair to Ralph Nader, does this sort of thing semiannu ally, always in the name of charity.

title: Delaware, Montclair State Keep Lead in Lambert Polls
description: Despite a 3431 loss to Vil lanova last Saturday, Delaware remained in first place yester day in the weekly voting for the Lambert Cup, awarded for outstanding performance by a middlesized college football team in the East.

title: Couve, on a Private Journey, Is Welcomed by Peking
description: PEKING, Opt. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Premier Maur ice Couve de Murville of France flew into Peking today for a private twoweek visit.

title: Ball to Aid Hospital
description: The Utopian Ball for the benefit of the Greater New York Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital and Research Center will be held on Oct. 17 at the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Gerson Gordon is chairman of the ball, and Mrs. Harold Rosenthal and Mrs. Ben Arber are cochair men. Tickets at $125 a couple are available at the hospital's New York office, 49 West 45th Street.

title: GREYHOUND ASKS ARMOUR SHARES
description: The Greyhound Corporation, which owns 86 per cent of the common stock of Armour & Co., yesterday made a proposal to minority shareholders of the meat packing concern tb ac quire their shares.

title: U.S. FILES A BRIEF IN 3 SCHOOL CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to rule that communities might base their school desegregation plans on the neighborhood school concept even if some Negro children remained in allblack schools.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Decline in Hand Washing Called A Factor in the Spread of Disease
description: Modern antibiotics and ad vanced medical practice have caused a slackening in basic personal hygiene that contrib utes to the continued spread of disease, a medical seminar was told yesterday.

title: Arcade Lined With Shops Set For Building on Site of Best's
description: A throughtheblock arcade is part of the skyscraper plan ned to replace the Best & Co. store building on Fifth Avenue that is to be torn down early next year.

title: CONGRESS REFORM VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Senate passed today a bill re forming longtime Congres sional procedures but leaving untouched the seniority system that younger members had sought to sweep away.

title: Charriere Attacks Horrors of Prison Life
description: The timing of an escape artist must be exact, and somehow the timing of the visit of Henri Charrire, for merly of Devil's Island, to New York City seemed just right. It coincided perfectly with a spasm of prison riots here.

title: Savannah Auto Race Off
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP) The 100mile NASCAR Grand American Challenge ser ies race scheduled for Sunday, Oct. 11, at Savannah Speedway in Savannah, Ga., was canceled today.

title: WEIGHT OF PLANE STUDIED IN CRASH
description: James R. Greenwood, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said last night that the airliner that crashed in the Rocky Moun tains, killing 30 persons on a Wichita State football trip, may have been 4,000 pounds overweight on takeoff.

title: ARISTOTLE SOUVAL
description: Aristotle Souval, a lawyer who specialized in international maritime law, died Monday, ap parently of a heart attack, in his home at 60 East Eighth Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, Oct 6, 1970 (Volume 5,098,535 shares)

title: SILVER FUTURES REBOUND SHARPLY
description: Silver futures, which had dropped sharply on Monday bounded back even more steeply yesterday in active trading on the New York Com modity Exchange on no par ticularly bullish news.

title: Annapolis Bans War Foes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 6 (UPI)  Antiwar speakers are banned at Annapolis, accord ing to the commandant of the United States Naval Academy. Opponents of the Vietnam war will not be allowed to address the 4,370 midshipmen, nor may students denounce the war in public, Rear Ad miral Robert P. Googan said to the Marines Memorial Club here yesterday. Whether we would encourage views con trary to the Administration is debatable. After all, when we are in uniform we are work ing for the President.

title: Poinier Cards 71 and Leads By 5 in Jersey Senior Golf
description: Special to The New York Times

title: TV: WNET Focuses on Black Policemen's Group
description: Station WNET took its mobile coverage unit out of the garage last night for a fascinating live report of the Guardians Association, the city's largest group of black police officers, at its club house, 504 Marian Street, Brooklyn.

title: ISRAEL HELPS PLAN ARAB UNIVERSITY
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 6Israeli authorities disclosed today that they were coordinating plans for the establishment of an Arab university on the occu pied westbank area of Jordan.

title: ENEMY STEPS UP MORTAR ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP)Intensified enemy mortar and rocket attacks re portedly carried through the third day today, most of them in the coastal provinces of the central and northern parts of South Vietnam.

title: Autopsy in SelfImmolation Indicates a Brain Tumor
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 6 (AP)An autopsy on a Se ton Hall University prelaw student who burned himself to death has shown that he had a massive brain tumor.

title: The Fruits of Inflation
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 6Pub lic indignation over the failure of governments to solve the problem of inflation by conven tional monetary and fiscal measures  without causing more unemployment than is politically tolerableis starting to force a breakup of economic dogmas and political align ments throughout the Western world The trend is corn parable to the im pact on politics and economics of persistent mass unemployment in the 1930's. But, now as then, public demands for improve ment in economic policy are in advance of what either the eco nomics profession or the poli ticians are yet prepared to of fer.

title: LINE STANDOUTS HARD TO REPLACE
description: The Giants have begun prep arations to meet yet another team without a victory, the Philadelphia Eagles. But the plans may have to be impro vised because of injuries.

title: Widnall Challenged on War by Opponent in 7th District
description: HACKENSACK, N. J.,A Re publican incumbent who sup ports President Nixon's poli cies on Vietnam is defending his House seat against a vigor ous antiwar Democrat in New Jersey's suburban Seventh Con gressional District. But neither candidate is making the war the major theme of the cam paign. Vietnam is no longer a to is sue, says William B. Widnall, the 64 year  old Republi can who has been in Congress since 1950. The withdrawal is being accom plished, and I expect by Oct. 15 there will be an additional an nounced withdrawal that will be of a substantial nature.

title: Alcoa Plans Retrenchments
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would tempor arily close one production unit in Tennessee and would slow the construction of a second unit at the same location.

title: Ky, in London, Ordered By Thieu to Come Home
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said to day that he had been ordered by President Nguyen Van Thieu to return to Saigon im mediately.

title: U.S. Silent on Events
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The United States Government maintained official silence to day on the events in La Paz.

title: Youth Says He Was Arrested And Held Unjustly in Suffolk
description: WESTBURY, Li., Oct. 6 Federal, state and local officials were asked today to investigate the circumstances surrounding the arrest and imprisonment of a 20yearold black college freshman who is a son of an official of the New YOrk City Housing and Development Ad ministration.

title: $30,000 Grants for Film Study Are Awarded to 2 Young Men
description: Two young filmmakers have been awarded the first $30,000 Schlitz Fellowships, the largest ever given for the study of moviemaking arts and crafts. They are Ken Dixon, 20 years old, of Wyn newood, Pa., a graduate of New York University's In stitute of Film and Television, and Albert Glover, 25, of Oakland, Calif., who earned his degree in film at San Francisco State College.

title: 3 YOUTHS ARRESTED IN EXPLOSIVES THEFT
description: DANVILLE, Ill., Oct. 6Fed eral agents have arrested three Danville youths and charged them with violations of the Federal Gun Control Act after the agents seized more than 350 pounds of explosives stolen from the Material and Service Company near Fairmount, Ill.

title: HAROLD HALPERN
description: DEAL, N. J., Oct. 6Harold Halpern, magistrate of this bor ough and a lawyer with offices at 299 Broadway, New York, died in New York today, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 76 Parker Avenue.

title: Reds and Orioles Evenly Matched
description: The Cincinnati Reds some how have been determined to be a slight favorite over the Baltimore Orioles in the World Series, but Dave Bris tol, a man who is familiar with both teams, says, They might play all winter before they decide a winner.

title: Japan Move Seen On Textile Accord
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6  The Jap anese Government appears to be taking the first ginger ly steps toward reviving textile negotiations with the United States.

title: OTTINGER STUMPS IN BUCKLEY AREA
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 6 James L. Buckley's campaign was depicted as a mailed fist today by Representative Rich ard L. Ottinger as he sought support from Democrats against a possible Buckley tide in this Republican area.

title: Letter Says Weathermen Blew Up Statue in Chicago
description: A special delivery letter as serting that fugitive leaders of the Weathermen were respon sible for blowing up a statue of a policeman in Chicago's Haymarket Square early Mon day was received here yester day.

title: Negroes Assert F.A.A. Reneges on Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 6The Federal Aviation Administra tion was accused today of dangling highpaying jobs in air traffic control before thou sands of black men it never intended to hire.

title: Referee Names a Receiver For Computer Applications
description: A receiver was appointed yesterday in the bankruptcy of Computer Applications, Inc. Federal Referee Asa S. Herzog appointed David P. Alterbaum of New York.

title: The Rights of the Majority
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The wars in Vietnam and the Middle East have placed upon the American people a burden for which few of them were prepared by personal experience. Sel dom have the voters been expected to pass judgment on such delicate, com plicated and dangerous matters. Ac cordingly, we are bombarded and al most stunned by an endless debate in which the Administration and the Op position try to persuade or coerce the people into believing or accepting whatever thumping conclusion the speaker is peddling at the moment.

title: Kidnapped British Official
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 6  Some 50 Canadian and Brit ish businessmen were to gather for cocktails this eve ning in the highceilinged first floor at 1297 Redpath Crescent, a stately mansion of thick stone walls that overlooks downtown Mon treal from the side of Mount

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: 1970, by Triangle PublIcation, Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Governor Sees Threat to State G.O.P. State
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 6  Declar ing that outside intervention would be prejudicial to the state Republican ticket, Gov ernor Rockefeller said today that he had asked the White House to please let us handle our own political problems.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Agnew's Purge of Goodell

title: MRS. WALTER COLLINS
description: Mrs. Anna Ware Collins, the mother of Macrae Sykes, senior partner of the brokerage con cern of Shields & Co., died yesterday at the Bayside Gar dens Nursing Home in Queens after a long illness. She was 88 years old and lived at 3924 211th Street, Bayside, Queens.

title: RANGER HOLDOUTS NEARING DEADLINE
description: The four Ranger holdouts, who have dismissed as inadequate the salary offer made by an arbitrator, will re ceive what may be their final offer tomorrow from Coach Emile Francis.

title: House Is Told Capsule Sale Is Under Eye of the Police
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Spokesmen for two major drug companies testified today that millions of tiny gelatin capsules used by drug peddlers were sold to pharmacists under police instructions.. One com pany has suspended such sales.

title: After a Strong Opening, Stocks On Amex End Session Lower
description: The American Stock Ex change finished lower yester day after a strong opening in active trading.

title: The Campus Awaits Mr. Nixon
description: When Mr. Nixon received the report of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest, a White House aide quoted him as having said: I can assure you that your report will be controversial. But don't worry about that. Worry if it, isn't controversial.

title: BOND SALES HEAVY AS RATES DECLINE
