description: A $1billion avalanche of fi nancing hit the money and capi tal markets yesterday, and yet it failed to crush the wide spread current belief that in terest rates were headed down ward.

title: DRIFTER IS SEIZED AS SLAYER OF FIVE
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP)Federal agents here ar rested tonight a 27yearold drifter charged with commiting five murders an one night dur ing robberies that the police said had netted him $500.

title: Day of Bread Marked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  Administration, Congres sional and wheat industry representatives joined today in a ceremony marking the ob servance of a Day of Bread as part of National Harvest Week.

title: Mr. Nixon's Vietnam Plan ..
description: The hopes of the country and the world for an era of peace ride with the major new proposals President Nixon is to announce tonight for the Vietnam negotia tions in Paris. EastWest relations as a whole and the prospects for general dtente could be advanced further by a Southeast Asian settlement than by any other diplomatic achievement now pending, except only for a solution in the Middle East.

title: Parents in Charlotte, Even Those Who Favor Integration, Deeply Resent Racial Busing
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  When Mrs. Jane Love found out that her young son would have to be bused this year to a school 12 miles from their neighbor hood, she cried.

title: Music Has No Charm To Lull Nixon Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) A young, longhaired, mus tached violinist was almost arrested today as he stood in the main hall of the White House with his violin case.

title: Regina Joy Singer Engineer's Fiancee
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 6Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Singer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Regina Joy Singer, to Robert N. Fagnoni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Faenoni of Scarsdale.

title: Campus Query on Security
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that he was querying about 300 colleges and univer sities to determine whether their officials agreed with a Nixon Administration proposal for the use of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in con nection with campus disturb ances.

title: Health Cost of Environment Misuse Estimated at $35Billion a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Man's misuse of the environ ment is costing Americans $35 billion a year through ill health and related losses alone, an ex pert estimated today.

title: Damage Put at $33Million In Town Struck by Tornado
description: SHAWNEE, Okla., Oct. 6 (AP) The death toll rose to four and the damage estimate to $33million today as a result of yesterday's tornado here.

title: Monsanto Expects a Drop In Profit for 3d Quarter
description: Edward J. Bock, president of the Monsanto Company, told security analysts in San Fran cisco yesterday that the com pany expected to report a 50 per cent drop in earnings for the third quarter, while sales should be close to 1969 levels.

title: American Motors Raises 71 Car Prices About $200
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6The Amer ican Motors Corporation raised its 1971 model car prices ap proximately $200 a car in line with similar increases by other manufacturers.

title: EDITH G. HALPERT, ART DEALER, DIES
description: Edith Gregor Halpert, a noted art dealer and collector, died yesterday at New York Hos pital after a long illness. She was 70 years old and lived at 136 East 56th Street.

title: Nixon Names Housing Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) President Nixon announced today the nomination of David O. Maxwell, the Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner, to be general counsel of the Depart ment of Housing and Urban Development. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Maxwell, who is 38 years old, will succeed Sherman Unger in the $38,000 post. Mr. Unger has been nomi nated to the Federal Communi cations Commission.

title: Student Program At Straford to Gain
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Transsexual Seeks Divorce From Wife; Wants to Remarry
description: A 37yearold Navy veteran Is going to State Supreme Court this morning in hopes of win ning a ruling that will broaden the rights of the transsexual.

title: Audie Murphy Jury Picked
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (UPI) Four men and eight women were selected today to try Audie Murphy, World War II's mostdecorated soldier, on charges of assaulting a dog trainer. The former movie star, 45 years old, is accused of hitting David Gofstein, 51, who also said that the Medal of Honor winner, who is cred ited with killing or capturing 240 Germans, fired a gun at him during an argument.

title: FEDAYEEN START PULLOUT IN NORTH
description: IRBID, Jordan, Oct. 6Arab truce observers said today that Palestinian commandos, as well as troops of the Palestine Liberation Army, were begin ing a mass pullout from the towns or northern Jordan.

title: NONLETHAL WEAPONS ASKED BY OHIO GUARD
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP)  The Ohio National Guard has asked the Army for nonlethal weapons for use in future disorders but will con tinue to carry highpowered rifles and to load them on command of a superior officer, Adjutant General Sylvester T. Del Corso said today.

title: Quality Design With Amenities
description: Just one year after the master plan for Welfare Is land was unveiled with some political fanfare at the Metro politan Museum, the design development of the first stage of the plan is being presented at the same institution, suit ably in advance of Election Day. It is the showpiece andstar pertorm ance of the New An York State Ur ban Develop ment Corpora tion, which was created by the State Legisla ture to expedite housing and urban renewal. As such, it can't do Governor Rockefel ler any harm. But this is more than a political event; it is a planning event of the first magnitude.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Says TV Uses Few Blacks in Ads
description: A survey of television com mercials here and in three Southern cities leads to the conclusion that blacks are to a great extent excluded from ap pearances in the television ad vertising of many of the coun try's largest industries. Where blacks have been shown, their exposures has been limited to momentary flashes.

title: Oiler Get Refiner Replacement
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) The Houston Oilers lost a guard, Tom Regner, for the season with a knee injury to day and lured Ken Gray, a former St. Louis Cardinal star, out of retirement to replace him.

title: GUTHRIES UNCLE SINGS AND TALKS
description: Crossroads country music was offered Monday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West 4th Street, by Jeff Guthrie, a fiddler and singer. He is the uncle of Woody Guthrie and granduncle of Arlo Guthrie. Buster Jackson, a pian ist, appeared with Mr. Guthrie.

title: Bridge:
description: Writers of ability are gen erally in short supply in the world of bridge. A welcome addition to the pool of talent manifested itself four years ago when an unknown Scots man named Hugh Kelsey pub lished a book on defensive play that was an immediate success.

title: Fanny May Results for the Week
description: Special to The New York Times

title: PRESIDENT OF PATHE RELINQUISHES POST
description: Martin S. Ackerman an nounced here yesterday his resignation, as president of Pathe Industries, Inc. He said he had taken the action to fa cilitate the payment of back dividends from Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation on Perfect's $3.50 series B con vertible preferred held by Pathe.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: French Firm Pays $75,000 For Weanling at Lexington
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6 (UPI) A French firm, Office du Pur Sang of Paris, paid the top price of $75,000 for a horse among the 135 head auctioned at to day's session of the first annual Kentucky Fall Sale of thorough breds by the FasigTipton Com pany.

title: S.S. East River Tube Begins Its Maiden Voyage
description: PORT DEPOSIT, Md., Oct. 6 An immense steel tube, as long as a Saturn V moon rocket, was launched from a small riverside shipyard here today to begin a long journey to its final resting place as a rapid transit tunnel under New York's East River.

title: Crew That Gets Along Is Called Important on Long Space Flight
description: CONSTANCE, West Germany, Oct. 6The experience of the Soviet member of an interna tional crew that accompanied Thor Heyerdahl on his two at tempts to cross the Atlantic by raft has convinced Soviet scientists that personality will be far more important on pro longed space voyages than na tional origin.

title: Soviet Test Pilot Killed
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6 (UPI)Lieut. Valentin I. Danilovich, a Soviet test pilot who helped develop techniques for the world's first extravehicular space activity, was killed while testing a new supersonic catapult system, Pravda, the government news paper, said today. It said he had ejected at high altitude from an aircraft flying at supersonic speed. The report did not give the date of the accident.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, Oct. 6, 1970 (Rates in per cent)

title: Football Poll
description: COACHES' RATINGS

title: Pompidou Is Welcomed Warmly in the Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6President Pompidou arrived today for an eightday visit to the Soviet Union and promptly called for joint RussianFrench exploita tion of Soviet mineral wealth.

title: Columbia Eleven Is Growing Up; Pass Defense Plagues Princeton
description: Close but no cigar is a phrase associated with los ers. Coach Frank Navarro, whose Columbia team almost beat Princeton last Saturday, expressed it this way yester day: It was upsetting to me. So many people thought we won something by losing. Our kids lost with a tremen dous effort and I'm proud of that, but in rebuilding we have to win something. The young Lions showed that they were ma turing rapidly into a sound team, and there was a prom ise of better days in the per formances of Jesse Parks, Don Jackson and Paul Kaliades, all sophomores.

title: ... and the Forgotten War
description: In November 1968 the American air war against North Vietnam came to a halt. But the squadrons that had pounded the Communists almost daily for 45 months remained. They were shifted to ground support missions in South Vietnam and Laos, attacks on the Ho Chi Minh Trail and, more recently, to targets in. Cambodia. The headlines gradually faded, but the air war did not.

title: Drawings and Models Put On Display at Metropolitan
description: Architectural drawings and models by a host of leading architects for the first stage of the proposed $200million new town on Welfare Island were put on display yester day in the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art.

title: Search to Resume Today For 3 Balloonists at Sea
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 6 (AP) A local pilot be lieves there is a strong possi bility that three balloonists missing in the Atlantic since Sept. 21 are still alive.

title: Communists in Sarawak Revive Insurgency on Border in Borneo
description: KUCHING, Malaysia, Oct. 3 Communist terrorists have reportedly revived their dor mant insurgency in the Malay sian state of Sarawak in north western Boreno, giving great concern to federal and state authorities and causing nerv ousness among the population of about a million.

title: Jersey City G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Specialist Kenneth J. Koch of Jersey City, of the Army, had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Cambodian Relief Team With Troops
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 6  When Cambodian troops pushed into the shattered town of Taing Kauk the other day, they brought with them a 13 member community develop ment team.

title: Nixon Coming to U.N. Oct. 23
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reu ters)President Nixon will ad dress the United Nations Gen eral Assembly Oct. 23 and give a dinner at the White House the next day for leaders at tending the United Nations 25th anniversary celebrations, the White House announced today.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW AN ADVANCE
Togo, After Years of Unrest, Exhibits Stability and Makes Gains on Poverty
Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: 2 Robbers Flee in Boat
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Chemical New York Gains
description: Two of New York's largest banking companies reported substantial gains in profits yes terday for both the third quar ter and the first nine months of 1970, as well as an improved rate of return on their stock holders' investment.

title: Record Voter List Forecast on Basis Of 2Day Turnout
description: A record registration for New York City in a guberna torial election year was fore cast last night by Maurice J. O'Rourke, president of the Board of Elections, on the basis of the 72,520 names add ed to the voter rolls in the first two days of local regis tration.

title: 10TH JUROR PICKED FOR PANTHER TRIAL
description: A retired longshoreman and a supervisor for the Welfare Department were added yes terday to the jury that will hear the case of 13 Black Pan thers accused of plotting to bomb public places. The jurors were the ninth and 10th se lected.

title: JOSEPH S. SCHIRALDI
description: Joseph S. Schiraldi, who re tired last Jan. 1 as assistant to the president of W. R. Grace & Co., the chemical, transpor tation and shipping concern, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 8823 Narrows Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Haughton Entry Is 21 Choice For Billy Direct Pace Friday
description: YONKERS, Oct. 6  The return to Yonkers Raceway of America's top freeforall stars for the $21,250 Billy Direct Pace, on Friday night brings into the fold Billy Haughton's Rum Customer and Laverene Hanover, and the entry was immediately installed as the 21 favorite today. Rum Cus tomer drew the No. 5 post po sition and Laverne Hanover No. 6.

title: Lindsay, Goldberg Share Platform at Liberals Dinner
description: Mayor Lindsay and the man he mightor might noten dorse for Governor, Arthur J. Goldberg, shared a platform last night for the first time this political campaign season.

title: Bomb Wrecks Office Of Palestine Group
description: The offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization were extensively damaged by a bomb blast last night. Several other offices on the third floor of the Architects Building at 101 Park Avenue, near 40th Street, were also damaged. No one was hurt.

title: In Memoriam
description: GRIMSHAWAnn Russell. FiHh Anniversary Mass and Rosary, Friday, Oct. 9, 5 P.M., St. Catherine Siena Church, 409 E, 69th St.

title: RAILROADS, UNION AVERT STRIKE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Labor Department officials said today that the possibility of a rail strike early Thursday had been averted.

title: Military Tells of Ousters For Illegal Drug Activities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) More than 7,000 marines and sailors will probably be discharged from the service this year for illegal drug ac tivity, Congress was told to day.

title: Lieut. Stephan Frank to Wed Miss Hope Ashley McAdams
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Mc Adams have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Hope Ashley Mc Adams, to Lieut. Stephan Andrew Frank, U.S.A., son of Mr. and. Mrs. Walter S. Frank of Darien. Conn.

title: LOUIS J. GREENBURG
description: Louis J. Greenburg, a lawyer, died yesterday of hepatitis in the New York University Med ical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 838 West End Avenue.

title: TV and Radio Networks To Carry Nixon Speech
description: President Nixon's policy speech to the nation on Viet nam tonight at 9 o'clock will be carried live by the tele vision and radio outlets of the three major networks.

title: Congress Leaders Agree To Take Campaign Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Con gressional leaders of both par ties concluded today that they could not complete the business of the 1970 session in the next three weeks and agreed to take a campaign recess.

title: EXHIBITION HOCKEY
description: St. Louis 4, Minnesota 2.

title: Court Clerks to Be Armed
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  United States District Court clerks will be armed and law yers will carry identification cards in the Dirksen Federal Building, it was announced yesterday. The increased secur ity measures stemmed from the kidnapping and fatal shooting of a California judge in August.

title: Perlman Will Become President Of the Western Pacific Railroad
description: Alfred E. Perlman, former vice chairman of the Penn Central Company and its rail road subsidiary, the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company, has gotten himself a job run ning trains again. Effective Dec. 1, he will be president of the Western Pacific Railroad.

title: Vietcong Hopeful
description: PARTS, Oct. 6 (AP)  A spokesman for the Vietcong del egation to the peace talks said today that he hoped President Nixon would announce accept ance of the Vietcong terms when he made his broadcast.

title: Suzanne Farrell Joins Bejart
description: Suzanne Farrell and Paul Mejia, who resigned from the New York City Ballet in May, 1969, have joined Maurice Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century. They will perform with the Belgian company when it makes its American debut at Brooklyn Academy of Music, from Jan. 25 to Feb. 7.

title: Miss Davenport, David S. Pollock To Be Married
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md., Oct. 6 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Daven port have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Davenport, to David Stanton Pollock, son of Mrs. David G. Dickson and stepson of Mr. Dickson, of Malvern, Pa.

title: Davenport Gets Phoenix Post
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 6 (UPI) Jimmy Davenport was named manager today of the Phoenix Giants of the Pacific Coast League, replacing Hank Sauer. Sauer will return to his former job as scout for the San Fran cisco Giants.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Faces a Boycott Of Its 2d Session on Rockefeller
description: A possibility developed last night that there could be an organized boycott of the meet ing of the state A.F.L.C.I.O., scheduled for a week from today to reconsider the Sept. 4 endorsement of Governor Rockefeller by the group.

title: SUBWAY PROPOSAL ANGERS RESIDENTS
description: The Metropolitan Transit Au thority's tentative plans to build a Second Avenue subway with two tracks and with three stops between 57th and 125th Streets was condemned by East Side residents, community leaders and public officials at a public hearing yesterday.

title: Treasury Chief Doubts Nixon Will Seek to Postpone Tax Reductions Scheduled for 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that, even if the Nixon Admin istration should discover it needs more revenue in the coming fiscal year, he did not think it would propose post ponement of the reductions in the individual income tax that are scheduled to go into effect then.

title: Policeman Offers Hope, Not Fear, to Drug Users
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 An upstate New York detec tive sergeant was honored as Policeman of the Year here today for a oneman fight against drug and narcotics addiction that began to pay off only when he admittedly began taking the law into his own hands.

title: Pacifica Station in Houston Silenced Again by Blast
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) An explosion knocked out the transmitter of the con troversial Radio Pacifica here early today for the second time in six months.

title: At Suez, Guns Are Silent and Trucks Move Openly
description: ALONG THE SUEZ CA NAL, United Arab Republic, Oct. 6Like a line of swift black beetles, the Israeli truck convoy darted toward the northeast.

title: U.S. Aide Warns on Costs Of Britain's Market Entry
description: PARIS, Oct. 6The State De partment's leading economic policy maker has warned Euro peans that the United States cannot be expected to accept economic costs in connection with possible British member ship in the Common Market.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Newspaper Guild Strikes Post; Publisher Shuts Down the Plant
description: Members. of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Poet went on strike yesterday in a bid for benefits and con tract improvements beyond threeyear, 41.69 per cent wage package offered by the news paper.

title: Damage by Inmates Makes Queens Jail Unusable
description: The Department of Correction displayed yesterday an arsenal of several hundred spears, clubs, molotov cocktails and booby traps that rebellious inmates had fashioned during a four day rampage that made the Queens Branch House of Deten tion uninhabitable.

title: NIXON WILL OFFER MAJOR PROPOSAL ON WAR TONIGHT
Alcoa Fund Gives $100,000 to Mount Stein Exhibition
description: The Alcoa Foundation has given the Museum of Mod ern Art $100,000 to assemble and mount its major winter exhibition, Four Americans in Paris: The Collections of Gertrude Stein and Her Fam ily.

title: Chain's Sales Set Mark
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, the nation's larg est food chain; made minor gains in sales but managed to set records for the three and siX months ended Aug. 31, ac cording to the company's semi annual report issued yester terday. Earnings were up 8.2 per cent and four per, cent, respectively, marking the sixth consecutive quarterly increase in profits.

title: AllNight Soul Will Mark Five Years of Jazz Vespers
description: The fifth anniversary of the weekly Jazz Vespers services at St. Peters's Lutheran Church Lexington Avenue And 54th Street will be celebrated Sun day with a 13hour program called AllNight Soul.

title: Sports Today
description: GOLF

title: Dance: Moiseyev Troupe Pays Us a Return Visit
description: Of course there are many folk dance companies, but only one Moiseyev Dance Companythe first, the orig inal, the grandfather of them all, and still the greatest.

title: Forsythe Faces Yates in Contest for Seat in Sixth District
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Oct 6A phenomenal growth in population, new industry and residential construction under way in Burlington County are creating massive problems, par ticularly in the area of taxa tion. Finding new sources of revenue to sustain such pros perity is the major challenge controntmg the contenders in New Jersey's Sixth Con gressional District Congress election. The dis trict has not been represented in the House of RepresentatiVes since William T. Cahill resigned his seat to become Governor of NeW Jer sey in January. Seeking to re place Mr. Cahill, who had rep resented the area since 1958, are State Senator Edwin B. Forsythe of Moorestown, a Re publican, and his Democratic opponent, Charles B. Yates of Willingboro, a newcomer to state politics.

title: Schmidt Putting Lions House in Order
description: The unbeaten Detroit Lions, on a track toward the Super Bowl, are proof that a chaotic pro football operation can be turned round and it doesn't take forever. Attention, Giant loyalists.

title: LEADER OF BOLIVIA FORCED TO RESIGN; PALACE IS BOMBED
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 6 Pres ident Alfredo Ovando Candia resigned today, bowing to de mands by Bolivian Army offi cers. His action touched off a struggle for power between left ist and rightist military forces in which leftists troops and planes attacked rightist strong points.

title: The Succession in Egypt
description: The Egyptian leadership has taken an encouraging first step toward assuring stability and continuity in Cairo by choosing Acting President Anwar Sadat to succeed Gamal Abdel Nasser as President.

title: BRAZILIAN SAYS REDS SUBSIDIZE A BISHOP
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 The struggle between Brazilian officials and leftwing priests brought harsh words today over the controversial Arch bishop of Recife and Olinda, the Most Rev. Helder Camara.

title: Senator Hartke Running Hard in Close Race With Roudebush
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 5  The actor dressed in a Viet cong uniform loaded his rifle and aimed it at the viewer.

title: Bronx Grand Jury, and Perhaps Others, Will Investigate Violence in Prisons
description: At least one and possibly as many as four grand juries will be asked to investigate the in mate violence that swept parts of five city jails over the last five days.

title: Allied Planes Bomb Village
description: TAING KAUK, Cambodia, Oct. 6 (AP)Jet bombers from air bases in South Vietnam bombed a suspected enemy bunker complex hidden in a village outside Taing Kauk to day after Cambodian troops ran into fire from the wellcon cealed positions.

title: In the Wake of Mr. Nixon
description: PARISThe next diplomatic phase in the troubled Mediterranean basin is almost bound to feature renewed efforts to foster some form of neu tralism in the area and it is logical to expect French initiatives in encourag ing the search.

title: Books of The Times
description: Jorge Luis Borges has observed that one never feels anything in a Russian novel to be true because the characters are always explaining themselves to each other. Per haps. But this morning we have two first novels by young writers of definite promise. Both debuts are, of course, flawed, clumsy and sentimental; however, if Mr. Dostoyev sky and Mr. Nabokov keep at it, there may be a future for Russian fiction.

title: SHIFT TO HOUSTON SET FOR OIL UNITS
description: The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) will move three of its major divisions to Hous ton, the company confirmed yesterday.

title: MISSILE REMOVAL BARRED BY EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6  Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad de clared tonight that the United Arab Republic, despite the loss of the leadership of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, would never remove a single anti aircraft missile from the Suez Canal military standstill zone mid would refuse even to dis cuss the subject:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ethel Merman Honored
description: Ethel Merman, starring in Hello, Dolly!, was honored yesterday by the Actors Fund of America for outstanding service and generosity during the many years she has en riched the musical stage. A gold medal was presented by the fund's president, Louis A. Lotito, on the occasion of Miss Merman's visit to the fund's retirement home in Englewood, N. J.

title: Congress Criticized Again by President On Spending Level
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  President Nixon criticized Congress again today for what he called its lavish spending.

title: Umpires Renewing World Series Pay Demands Today
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn will meet with the presidents of the two major leagues and the law yer for the umpires today in an effort to forestall another walkout by major league um pires before Saturday's World Series opener.

title: Bobby Isaac Leads By Only 50 Points For StockCar Title
description: Mile by mile the auto racing season is running to its finish and lap by lap the drivers are whirling toward completion of their bids for champion ships. The world driving title has definitely gone, posthu mously, to Jochen Rindt, and Al Unser has been racing for nearly three weeks as the new American champi on, the best in the top division of the United States Auto Club compe titions.

title: CONSUMER DEBT LAGS IN GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Consumer installment credit rose $232million in August, the smallest rise since the $198 million increase in March, the Federal. Reserve Board said today.

title: Decision on Next Start For Nijinsky Delayed
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 6 (UPI) Vincent O'Brien, trainer of Nijinsky, who lost for the first time in his career at Longchamp on Sunday, said it would be another week before a decision is taken on whether he runs again.

title: Two Sides of Computers: New Lines and Layoffs
description: It was an active day yes terday in the computer in dustry on the positive and negative sides. These were the developments:

title: ARTHUR J. M'CUSKER, INVESTMENT AIDE, 69
description: Arthur J. McCusker, who re cently retired as a vice presi dent and investment research officer of Hayden Stone, Inc., stockbrokers, now CBWLHay den Stone, Inc., died Tuesday in Maimonides Hospital, after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 9437 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

title: A Plan to End the War
description: President Nixon's farreaching fivepoint proposal for the Paris talks, including a ceasefire in place, fully war rants its advance description as a major new initiative for peace. Along with the recent eightpoint Vietcong plan, it provides for the first time a realistic agenda both sides can accept for the serious private negotiations needed to achieve a compromise solution.

title: HalfLight on Wiretaps
description: Attorney General Mitchell's speech the other day call ing attention to the Justice Department's wiretapping activities may have strengthened the Nixon Administra tion's crimefighting image in this highly political season, but it was something less than a satisfactory discussion of a complex issue.

title: Watson Doubtful of Soviet Computer Deal
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7  Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the board of the International Busi ness Machines Corporation, said today that he had just com pleted two days of talks with officials of the Soviet Union on the possibility of establish ing some relationship be tween I.B.M. and the Russian computer industry.

title: Selling the Harewood Jewels
description: LONDON, Oct. 7Twenty six pieces of jewelry that belonged to the late Princess Royal, an aunt of Queen Elizabeth II, fetched $188,964 at auction here today.

title: Elaine Comparone Plays RedBlooded Harpsichord
description: If there are any oldtimers left who still think of the harpsichord as a quaint and fragile relic alien to red blooded musicmaking, they should hear Elaine Comparone play it. At Carnegie Recital Hail, where she made her New York recital debut Tues day night, this young woman had the place jumping with propulsive rhythms and color ful sounds, as she made her way through a hearty pro gram that included sonatas by Scarlatti, Bach's Partita No. 4, Haydn's Sonata in B minor and pieces by Rameau.

title: Atlantic City Results
description: By The Associated Press

title: CommunistBacked Group Wins New Stature Among Fedayeen
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 7 A Communistbacked commando group, Al Ansar, has gained a measure of stature within the Palestinian guerrilla movement in one of several shifts of in fluence that have resulted from the recent civil war.

title: Parliament in Cambodia Amends the Constitution
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 7 (Reuters) The Cambodian Senate and National Assembly, as expected, have unanimously approved an amended Consti tutionfrom which references to the monarchy have been de letedand also decided on the design of a new flag, it was reported today.

title: Goldberg and Rockefeller Found To Differ on ChurchSchool Aid
description: Governor Rockefeller and Ar thur J. Goldberg, rival candi dates in this fall's gubernatorial election, have split sharply over the state's socalled Blaine amendment, in differing on a variety of civil liberties issues.

title: Increase in Political Awareness Is Indicated in Jail Riots Here
description: One of the aspects that dis tinguished the disorders at five of the city's jails from earlier prison riots was the abundance of slogans and revolutionary rhetoric suggesting a growing political consciousness among inmates.

title: Federal Prosecutor Declares That Everything Has a Price in Corrupt. Hudson County
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7  Freder ick B. Lacey Jr., United States Attorney for New Jersey, charged today that the plun der by officials in Hudson County, just across the river from Manhattan, is unmatched in anything in my experience.

title: Rudolph Wild
description: Rudolph S. Wild, director of magazine reference book pro grams of the Council of Better Business Bureau and vice presi dent Of its predecessor, the Na tional Better Business Bureau, died Tuesday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS BID RUNS INTO TROUBLI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Senate opened debate today on the equal rights amendment to the Constitution but then laid it aside until tomorrow, amid considerable uncertainty as to its fate.

title: Medeiros Installed Before 2,500 as Boston Archbishop, Succeeding Cushing
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7A Portu guese immigrant who once swept the floors of a textile mill for 62 cents a day was installed amid solemn cere mony today as the spiritual shepherd of Boston's 1.9 mil lion Roman Catholics, most of whom are Irish.

title: Unveilings
description: BAILEYA memorial In memory of Dr. John H. Bailey will be unveiled on Sunday, Oct. 11, at 10 A.M.

title: MANSON ASSERTS JUDGE IS BIASED
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 Charles M. Manson led his three women codefendants in another revolt in their murder trial today.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES MINE AGENCY HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 President Nixon today nomi nated Dr. Elburt. Franklin Os born, a geochemist who is vice president for research at Penn sylvania State University, to head the troubled Bureau of Mines.

title: Pope Paul's Coming Visit Causes Dissension Among Australian Protestants
description: SYDNEY, Australia. Oct 7 A decision by the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney, the Most Rev. Dr. Marcus L. Loane, a conservative, to stay away from an interdenominational prayer service for Christian unity to be attended by Pope Paul VI has caused dissension among Australian Protestants.

title: Message to Continue: Love Your Neighbor
description: Discovering probably that it will take more than just one year to sell the idea, Re ligion in American Life will continue its Love your neighbor campaign for an other year.

title: Allende May Offer Chilean Post To InterAmerican Bank Head
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 7 Dr. Felipe Herrera, the Chilean lawyer who is president of the InterAmerican Development Bank, dined last night with Salvador Allende, the Marxist politician, amid reports that Mr. Herrera might be offered an economic post in Dr. Allende's expected government.

title: Packers' Back Has Surgery
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 7 (UPI)Dave Hampton, hero of the Green Bay Packers' 1310 victory over the Minnesota Vikings last Sunday, was re covering at St. Vincent's Hos pital today following surgery to remove a pelvic abscess. Hampton underwent surgery last night and a club spokes man said it would take a day or two to determine how long the secondyear running back would be sidelined.

title: Conferees Agree on a Farm Aid Bill.
News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1970

title: RULE IS CHANGED TO HELP RANGERS
N.Y.U. Wins in Soccer, 21
description: The undefeated New York University soccer team defeated Fairleigh Dickinson University, 21, at Ohio Field in the Bronx, yesterday for its third victory.

title: GILBERT D. KITTREDGE
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Stage: Happy Birthday, Wanda June
description: Kurt Vonnegut Jr., the novelist and youth folk hero, has written a play. It is called Happy Birthday, Wanda June, it opened last night at the Theater De Lys, and Mr. Vonnegut himself describes it as a simple minded play about men who enjoy killine.

title: Paul Mauriat Adds Comic Effect To His Easy Listening Concert
description: What is one to think of an orchestra conductor who is, apparently, so conscious of the triviality of his music that he has a comedian plant ed in the saxophone section to distract the audience? One could call him a realist.

title: Comparison of the Positions on Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 7 Fol lowing is a comparison of pro posals made by President Nixon tonight with the latest ones by the Vietcong, made on Sept. 17, plus proposals made by Mr. Nixon in June, 1969, and by the Vietcong in May, 1969:

title: Poll Finds Fears That Jobless Rate Will Continue Rise
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 7 Three times as many Americans expect unemployment to in crease during the next six months, as believe it will de crease, the Gallop Poll reported today.

title: The Father Whose Dream Came True
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The fondest dream of many an American father came true last summer for Walter Neaterly. His son Leroy had his hair cut.

title: AMEX PRESSURED ON TRUST FUND USE
Fire Union Protests Public Dialing of 911 To Report a Fire
description: The city's firealarm dis patchers appealed last night to Mayor Lindsay to counter mand his order that the public report fires on the police emer gency telephone number, 911.

title: BUCKLEY FOCUSES ON DOMESTIC ILLS
description: HORSEHEADS, N. Y., Oct. 7 Domestic problems are the meat in the diet of political discussion that James L. Buck ley, the Conservative party candidate, is providing upstate New Yorkersand he says he is going to win because he has accurately assessed the voters' mood.

title: Orioles, With. Palmer, Cuellar and McNally, Are Rated Superior in Pitching
description: Jim Palmer, Mike Cuellar and Dave McNally will try to do to the Cincinnati Reds this year what they couldn't do to the New York Mets last year beat them in the World Series.

title: CHARTER MERGER ON L.I. IS BARRED
description: The New York State Bank ing Board denied yesterday the application of the Charter New York Corporation to acquire the Hempstead Bank, a $172million institution based in Nassau County. Charter, which re ported assets of $6.5billion at midyear, is the parent com pany of the Irving Trust Com pany here.

title: A Strange Place for a Geisha
description: Emancipation has come to the Japanese geisha. She has her own union. And she can even get permission to dance at Macy's.

title: DR. CHARLES G. HAYDEN
description: NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP) Dr. Charles G. Hayden, pres ident since 1948 of Massachu setts Blue Shield and a pioneer in the Blue CrossBlue Shield movement nationally, died to day at NewtonWellesley Hos pital. He was 59 years old and lived in West Newton.

title: Inn Burns at Alton, N.H.
description: ALTON, N. H., Oct. 7 (AP) The Village Inn, a landmark for many years, was destroyed by a fire early today. No injuries were reported.

title: An Insurance Study on Autos Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Nixon Administration informed Congress today that it would not be ready until next year to recommend improvements in the automobile insurance system.

title: Timothy T. to Start From No. 7 In $76,351 Kentucky Futurity
description: LEXINLITON, Ky., Oct. 7  With men and women who know trotters best, John Simp son's Timothy T. is the pro hibitive favorite to defeat 11 rival 3yparolds in the Ken tucky Futurity at the Red Mile Friday afternoon. The oldest major harness racing stakes in the country dates to 1893.

title: To Austrians, Montclair Is Other U.S.
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 7  Hans Ihle of Graz, Austria, believes that he has found in this suburb the other Amer ica so few in the world know anything about  and Mr. Ihie is enthusiastic about al most every aspect of his dis covery.

title: Executive Changes
description: Daniel E. Lyons, Stephen E. O'Neil and Peter C. R. Huang have been elected to the board of the City Investing Company.

title: NIXON'S DINNER PLANS SURPRISE U.N. CHIEFS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7Diplomats and United Nations officails today voiced their surprise and misgivings, over the announcement from the White House yesterday that President Nixon intended to give a dinner in Washington Oct. 24 for foreign dignitaries attending the 25th anniversary session of the United Nations Assembly.

title: Advertising: ExAgency Head Sounds Off
description: There is apparently noth ing like being a former agen cy executive to cause a loos ening of the tongue and loss of inhibitions. And Rich ard W. Tully, chairman of the board of Foote, Cone & Belding until last spring, really laid it on the line at the Broadmoor in Colorado Springs Tuesday. Clients got hit first, then agencies, the commission system, agency gladhanders and the trade press. You would have loved to have been there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Revolution in Monetary Policy Urged

title: Screen: Romantic Pose
description: Dedicated to the memory of the great pianist Dinu Li patti, bathed in a rush of gorgeous images and sounds, First Love adopts a Ro mantic posture so intense that it achieves not the con dition of romance but rather an illustration of romance in the service of larger ideas. This is to say that Maximilian Schell's first movie, which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, strives for more in teresting ends than the es sentially trivial Elvira Mad igan, with which it has already (not unreasonably) been compared. And despite its pretentiousness, its pret tiness, its 1,000 excesses  and to a degree perhaps be cause of themit succeeds as vision even while it looks as if it were being suffocated by style.

title: Russian Visits Schtz
description: BERLIN, Oct. 7 Pyotr A. Abrasimov, Soviet Ambassador in East Germany, met for five hours today with Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin in an apparent move to brief the Mayor on the fournation talks over Berlin.

title: WEAPONS MONEY BILL SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Pres ident Nixon signed today a $19.9billion defense weapons authorization bill and a $5.2 billion public works appropria tion bill.

title: LAYOFFS OF 4,000 ARE BEGUN BY J.&L.
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's sixth largest steel producer and the most troubled member of that financially unhappy industry, announced yesterday in Pitts burgh that it would lay off almost 4,000 workers, about 20 per cent of its hourly rated la bor force, in a series of moves to curtail production next week.

title: Hickel Sees Start by Spring On Building Alaska Pipeline
Belmont Entries
description: EXHIBITION HOCKEY

title: John L. Richards, Officer In Investment House, 60
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 John Lowell Richards, a vice president of Lazard Frres, in vestment bankers, in New York, died today of a heartat tack at his home, 53 Old Mill Road. He was 60 years old.

title: Gain for Mine Safety
description: President Nixon's appointment of Dr. Elbert F. Osborn to head the Bureau of Minis seems likely to bring a start toward effective enforcement of the new Federal Mine Safety and Health Act after months of administra tive footdragging. Dr. Osborn, now vice president for research of Pennsylvania State University, is widely re spected not only for his expertise but also for his inde pendence of politiCal or industrial ties.

title: First CourtMartial in Killings At Sonmy Begins at Fort Hood
Bishop Glenn R. Phillips, Fostered Church Merger
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct 7 (UPI) Retired Methodist Bishop Glenn R. Phillips, who was instru mental in the 1968 merger of the Methodist Church and the Evangelical United Brethren Church, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Franklin Also Advances
description: The two largest banking con cerns in New York City and the largest on Long Island re ported yesterday sharp  and in one case spectacularad vances in profits for the latest quarter and the first nine months of 1970.

title: Medical Award Given
description: The Markle Scholars, a group of American medical educators, have presented the annual John M. Russell Medal to Dr. Arthur Kornberg, head of the biochemistry department at Stanford University. Dr. Kornberg was a corecipient of the Nobel Prize in physiology and medicine in 1959. The Russell award, given for outstanding contribution to academic medi cine, was set up in 1962 in honor of the former president of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation.

title: Working Dogs Faring Best in Caribbean
description: Ozzie Akow of Trinidad is a man with a mission: My goal is to develop a liaison between the Caribbean is lands and South America, so that we can get together, share expenses and bring top judges to our shows from the United States and Eu rope. I'm working with ken nel clubs in Puerto Rico, Bar bados, Venezuela and Colombia. rd like to have a circuit, but unfor tunately we still have a six month quarantine. However, we have hopes to have it lifted.

title: Met to Delay Un Ballo
description: The Metropolitan Opera per formance of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera to be given on Saturday evening will begin at 8:30 rather than at the custom ary hour of 8. The change has been made to allow those who observe Yom Kippur, which ends at sundown on Saturday, to arrive at the opera house on time for the beginning of the performance. The opera will end at 11:30. P.M.

title: Beck Industries Expecting a 'Modest Operating Loss
description: Beck Industries, Inc., a troubled retailing empire that has recently been coughing up several undigestible acquisi tions, has some more divesti tures on the way on its road to profitable operations.

title: U.S. Aide Says Population Rise Slows
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  The population bomb in the United States is being defused, George H. Brown, director of the Census Bureau, said today.

title: Miss Ryland, J. J. Esteve Jr. Plan to Marry
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 7Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Ryland have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Elizabeth Alexan der Ryland, to Joachim Jos Esteve Jr., son of Mrs. June Anderson Esteve of Sa Paulo, Brazil, and Dallas and the late Joaquim Jos EsteveCampdera of Barce lona, Spain, and Sa Paulo.

title: Mayor Studies Payless Paydays To Offset Losses in City Revenue
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that his administration was considering payless paydays, pay cuts and some layoffs last imposed on city employes by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia during the Depression before the advent of municipal unions  to offset anticipated revenue losses caused by the recession.

title: Soviet Scientist and Party Aide Clash on the Freedom of Ideas
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7 A promi nent Leningrad mathematician who tried to explain to a Com munist party official why sci entists were agitating for more political freedom was reportedly told bluntly that Soviet author ities never would allow anyone to write anything that comes into his head.

title: Pension Equality Is Key Issue As Guild Continues Post Strike
description: The Newspaper Guild's de mand for a pension plan com parable to one granted craft unions appeared yesterday to be a key issue in the twoday old strike at The New York Post.

title: Harlem's Theresa Hotel Thriving in Office Role
description: Harlem's Theresa Hotel, which declined during re cent years from its onetime prominence, stands today re incarnated as a modern, well equipped office building catering mostly to a black, communityoriented clientele.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SET STEADY PACE
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange were steady yester day. Trading was quiet in an ticipation of Wall Street's re action to President Nixon's speech on Vietnam.

title: Morrison Gets Coach's Sympathy, but No Ball to Carry
description: When Alex Webster was a fullback for the Giants, he used to growl and ask to carry the ball, over and over again.

title: Directors Approve Cooper Acquisition Of Chemway Corp.
description: Cooper Laboratories, Inc., an overthecounter company, is acquiring the Chemway Corpo ration, whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Ex change. Directors of both com panies announced yesterday ap proval of the proposed merger. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Chemway shareholders. Un der the agreement each share of Chemway common stock would be ex changed for $2 in cash, onefifth of a share of Cooper common stock and $4 principal amount of a 7 per cent subordinated debenture convertible at $22 a share into Cooper stock.

title: Charge of Inciting Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) The Government has dropped a charge of inciting to riot filed against Sgt. 1st Cl. James R. Kerns, a Green Beret veteran in Vietnam, who was accused of ripping up a Vietcong flag Saturday at the March for Victory rally here. The United States Attorney's office cited lack of prosecutive evidence.

title: White Plains Luncheon For Channel 13 Friends
description: The Westchester Chapter of Friends of Channel 13 will give its first annual luncheon Tuesday at the White Plains Hotel. Kingman Brewster Jr., the speaker will discuss education and its place in the national scene.

title: Ship Construction Bill Sent to White Mollie
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a maritime program calling for construction of 300 ships over the next 10 years.

title: The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System
RCA Computer Sales Brisk
description: The RCA Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had received orders for lease or purchase of more than $80mil lion of its new computer series in the first three weeks follow ing the introduction of the line. L. E. Donegan Jr., division vice president and general manager of the RCA computer systems division, said that the orders already exceeded the com pany's expectations for all of 1970.

title: Frances Rogers To Be the Bride Of D. A. Zilkha
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Y. Rogers of New York and Prouts Neck, Me., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Porteous Rogers, to Daniel Abdulla Zilkha, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abdulla K. Zilkha of Paris.

title: ALAN RUSKIN, 65, OF ART GALLERY
description: Alan D. Gruskin, founder and director since 1932 of Midtown Galleries, 11 East 57th Street, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and lived in Stockton, N. J., and at 200 East 57th Street.

title: CURBS ON CRIME AND DRUG ABUSE GAIN IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Con gress moved swiftly today to give President Nixon legisla tion he has sought to control organized crime, campus bomb ings and narcotics use and traffic.

title: McNamara Joins Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (UPI)  John McNamara, who was dismissed as manager of the Oakland Athletics last Fri day, was hired today as a coach for the San Francisco Giants. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MIXED AT CLOSE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yester day in slower trading.

title: Patricia Louis Is Betrothed
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 7Mr. and Mrs. N. Herbert Louis have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Louis, to Wil liam Herbert Call, son of Mrs. Norman Campbell of Burlington, Vt., and the late William Byrd Call of New Canaan. Conn.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Several seasons ago, the Devil challenged the Celestial Baseball Team. to a game of nines. Astounded, the Great Manager cried, But we have the Babe and the Peach and the Big Train, you don't have a chance. The Devil merely snickered, Sure, sure, but we got all the umpires. Like most major league baseball stories, this one may be apoc ryphal, but it has appeared in so many anecdote collections and is told at banquets by so many players, club execu tives, league officials and, alas, umpires, that it should hardly have been a surprise when baseball treated its top umpires as unnecessary evils, replacing them with minor leaguers for last Saturday's playoff games rather than deal with their demand for a larger fee.

title: MONDAY FOOTBALL DISPLACES GAVETY
description: The Monday nignt broadcasts of The Dick Cayett Show have been discontinued through Dec. 14, because of the Amer ican Broadcasting Company's telecasts of professional foot ball games on those nights.

title: 2 BIG 8 COLLEGES PUT ON PROBATION
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) The Big Eight Conference placed Kansas State University on pro bation tonight for a period of three years for football viola tions, and the University of Kansas on probation for two years in all sports.

title: RIGHTS OF WOMEN IN CHURCH SOUGHT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7 The professional organization of Roman Catholic canon law yers charged today that cur rent church practices discrimi nated against the dignity and inalienable rights of women.

title: Eastern Elevens Sag Against Intersectional Foes
Screen: The Drama of Monte Walsh
Diplomats Turn Out for Benefit at Meridian House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7A wooden alligator lapped at a pair of bronze cupids. A stuffed gorilla rode a make believe zebra, and an un likely giraffe peered with in terest over a supper table laden with African dishes.

title: Karenga Arrested on Coast After Mitsing Arraignment
SST Builders of 3 Nations Join on Pollution Problems
description: PARIS, Oct. 7(AP)Amer lean, French and British build ers of supersonic transport planes have joined to solve noise and polution problems. They signed an accord yester day that presents a common Western front against charges of degradation of the environ ment.

title: Shipping/Mails

title: Mask's Many Faces: Primitive to Modern
description: With Halloween but three weeks away, there's a lot of inspiration for making face masks at the Museum of Contem porary Crafts. The show, called Face Coverings, includes masks that range from those used by primitive man to personify spirits to those worn today, such as the snouted, black leather ones worn for quelling riots. Examples of early masks show how men whipped together some bark, a few feathers and a handful of cowrie shells and presto, they were the personification of evil, in just the right facial outfit for rites of passage. And then there's modern man, wearing the skulllike, white plastic helmet of the hockey player, or slipping into a papiermach structure to walk out on stage. Nonfunctional masks are shown that were created as art or decora tion to make an esthetic statement about faces and faades. Unfortunately, the visitor can't try on the masks in the show however sorely temptedbut can try out some facial adornments. Visitors can watch in a mirror as preprogrammed light pat terns are projected on their faces to show how they look in colored cobwebs or multicolored stripes. There is also a transparent plastic, mask that shows the wearer how she would look in curls and painted cheeksor beards and moustaches (one woman said she was surprised to discover she looked best in a Fu Manchu moustache). At a makeup bar, Edrie Anne Blackwelder paints fanciful designs on visitors faces. There's no charge, beyond the 75cent admission to the show. The show continues through Jan. 3.

title: Rangers Bow to Bruins, 86, Despite 4 Goals by Ratelle
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The Boston Bruins overcame a four goal performance by Jean Ra telle tonight to defeat the New York Rangers 86, in the final preseason National Hockey League game for both clubs.

J., Oct. 7In Bergen County's ninth Congres sional District, Representative Henry Helstoski is once again going to test the question: Can a Democrat with an outstand ing liberal record in Congress find reelection in a district that is overwhelmingly Repub lican? Hoebel, a member of the County Board of Freeholders who has been waging an energetic campaign.

title: Two Weeks After They Wed, He Told Her  He Likes to Hunt
Screen: Jagger as Outlaw
description: In "Ned Kelly," the combined talents of Tony Richardson and Mick Jagger, as a legendary outback outlaw, illustrate scenically, if not emotionally or definitively, the parallel between our Old West and Australia of a century ago. The film clattered into the DeMille yesterday with "Underground," starring Robert Goulet as a daring but all too familiar World War II maverick-hero. "Underground" hardly seems to be worth all the gunfire, derring-do and color film.As the impressively better one of these adventures, "Ned Kelly" bears all the signs of dedicated movie-making. Unfortunately, Mr. Richardson's direction and script, on which he collaborated with Ian Jones, do not delve too deeply into character. Nor are the principals' motivations projected with relevance to untutored American viewers. "Ned Kelly," with intrusive, explanatory songs by Shel Silverstein sung by Waylon Jennings, emerges as somewhat pretentious folk-ballad fare that often explains little more than its action.Like Jesse James and family, Ned Kelly, his mother, brothers and sisters are depicted as wronged, poor Irish farmers harried by English landowners and constabulary. Freed, after an unjust, three-year prison term for horse stealing, Kelly and his boys, with prices on their heads, conduct a gory but eventually tragic campaign to free their kind from their oppressors.Filmed in lovely colors on authentic Australian locales, "Ned Kelly" shimmers fitfully with varied beauties. A homecoming dance to a wild Irish reel is memorable, as are horsemen racing on a wooded hillside and a bare knuckle, friendly fight at a village fair. Equally impressive is the iron armor devised by Kelly as protection against pursuers. But these are colorful vignettes that only touch on but do not fully reveal the drama or the history behind the events.As the ill-fated titular hero, Mick Jagger, the rock singer, with a beard that makes him appear more Amish than Australian, is, sadly, simply a dour renegade who rarely becomes the "wild colonial boy" of the legend. Only a few members of the large supporting cast, notably Clarissa Kaye, as his mother; Janne Wolmsley, as his girl, and Martyn Sanderson, as a villainous Irish constable, are momentarily meaningful. "Such is life, Mick Jagger flatly states before being hanged, an observation that can't quite be applied to "Ned Kelly."Lifelike also does not apply to "Underground," which has Mr. Goulet successfully spiriting an important Nazi general out of France to England with the aid of the brave Maquis. "You'd better be worth it, general," the glum, tough but tortured hero says at one point. The general and "Underground" are not.
