title: Gramco Weighing Sales Suspension For U.S.I.F. Fund
Books of The Times
description: The news of Charles E. Silberman's Crisis br the Classroom is out, of course, and already getting stale around the edges. (In case you missed it: Mr. Silberman has sailed, up the shallow creek of American education, surveyed the landscape, and pro nounced it joyless, mindless, barren. The na tives. he says. are pinched and crabbed. and stand before their children mumbling empty incanta tions; the children stare back silently, holloweyed, and pick their scabs. What with the big guns Silberman has on boardthe Carnegie Founda tion, which com missioned his ex ploration; his team of able research ers; his own formi dable reputation as Fortune editor and reporter, teacher and sur veyor of the Crisis in Black and Whitethere Is now some hope that the natives will stop what they're doing and pay attention.) But there still remains the question of what it's like to read Mr. Silberman's report, for though it's news, it's also a book, and it's a book that absolutely must be read by everyone who can read and even some who can't.

title: Biggs Replaces Turner as Jet Kickoff Man in Move to Stop Long Runbacks
description: In an attempt to reduce the possibility of being stunned for a touchdown on a kickoff re turn, as they were in each of their two losses, the Jets have assigned Verlon Biggs as their kickoff specialist for Saturday night's game with the Miami Dolphins at Shea Stadium.

title: Poetry and Gospel Blend In HandClapping Revue
description: The first half of Don't Bother. Me, I Can't Cope is a handclapping, fOottapping, skyreaching, fingerjabbing, bodyswaying, earsplitting musical revue, mostly gospel with some Langston Hughes poems and some Talley Beatty choreography that looks like a W.P.A. poster melodramatic yet overly composed. The show is so unabashedly oldfashioned as to be an anomaly, which in itself is sort of refreshing.

title: Rutgers Seeks Bombing Data
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 7 (UPI)Rutgers Univer sity announced today it will offer a $5,000 reward for in formation concerning persons who made bomb threats against the university. Earle W. Clif ford Jr., dean of students, said there had been 21 bomb threats on, the school's three campuses since Sept. 8, disrupting classes and other activities.

title: Maravich in Encore Tonight
description: About four minutes after he entered the game in the second quarter Tuesday night, Pete Maravich stole the ball and went in for an uncontested layup, and the crowd cheered the milliondollar Atlanta rookie, wildly. Every circuslike pass Maravich made or shot he took thereafter brouggt additional loud applause, a sign of the attention and popularity he will en joy this season.

title: Dip in Airline Bookings Reported Over
description: Airline business has returned virtually to normal after a small but noticeable dip in bookings because of last month's Middle East hijackings, according to travel authorities.

title: Dr. Russell Potter, 76, Is Dead; Led Columbia Adult Program
description: WEST CORNWALL, Conn., Oct. 7Dr. Russell Potter, di rector of the former Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University, died yesterday in nursing home in Torrington. He was 73 years old and lived on Town Street here.

title: THIEU SEES BUNKER AFTER NIXON SPEECH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 8  There was no immediate comment this, morning from President Ngu yen Van Thieu on the pro posals by President Nixon for settling the Indochina conflict, although Mr. Thieu is expected to support the United States, position.

title: History on Roe's Side in Facing Fontanella in Eighth District
description: PATERSON, Oct. 7  With Passaic County history on their side, political observers follow ing the race between Repre sentative Robert A. Roe, al Democrat, and his Republican opponent, Assemblyman Alfred E. Fontanella, in New Jersey's Eighth Congressional District agree that incumbents are not likely to be de feated, no matter what the national trend. They also agree that up county will vote Republican and downcounty will vote Democratic. Another point of agreement is that per sonal popularity plays a major role in determining the winner.

title: JERRY D. RYAN, LED AUTO CLUB TRAVEL
AIRLINER IN CRASH HELD UNAPPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The Federal Aviation Admin istration said today that the airliner that crashed Friday in the Colorado Rockies, killing 13 members of the Wichita State University football team, had received no valid flying certif icate when taken out of stor age.

title: Snead Gets HoleinOne
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 7 (UPI)  Sam Snead scored the 18th holein one of his long golfing career today. Snead's ace came on the 18th hole of the old White Course at Greenbrier, where he is the pro. It was his fourth holeinone on the 163yard, par3 hole. He used a No. 7 iron all four times.

title: Hewlett Introduces Product
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)  The HewlettPackard Company said today it was marketing an instrument that uses a beam of invisible light, to measure distances accurate ly for up to two miles. The light meter can measure with an accuracy of about onehalf inch to a mile. It sells for less than $5,000. One important use, for it would be to measure sway in large structures.

title: Relief Cases Here Rising At 3 Times Expected Rate
description: Skyrocketing relief rolls for the first two months of the city's new fiscal year have (tripled the increase forecast in Mayor Lindsay's budget and 1could add as much as $60mil lion in new costs if the new Irate keeps on.

title: Tass Reports Proposal
description: Special to The New York Times

title: TEAR GAS QUELLS STUDENT PROTEST
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 8 (UPI) The police fired tear gas tonight to break up an angry, chanting crowd of 500 Marshall University students protesting drug raids on cam pusarea student residences.

title: City to Push Work On Repairing Jails Damaged in Riots
description: Mayor Lindsay gave high priority yesterday to a program to repair damages caused by rioting prisoners recently in four city jails.

title: Hanoi's Negativism
description: The automatic negativism of the initial Communist reaction in Paris to President Nixon's new fivepoint Vietnam peace proposal is not surprising, and there is every reason still to hope for an ultimately favorable response.

title: Unpublished at Home
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8A year ago a local official of the Soviet Writers Union asked Aleksandr Isayevich Solzhe nitsyn why his novels, for bidden here, were published abroad, to the detriment of the image the Soviet Union would like to present to the world. Answer me first,

title: Arab Group Offers Reward
description: The Action Committee on ArabAmerican Relations yes terday offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of any member of the Jewish Defense League who might be found guilty of bombing the offices of the Palestine Liberation Or ganization, at 101 Park Avenue, at 40th Street, Tuesday night. Dr. M. T. Mehdi, head of the committee, said the reward would be only $1,000 for any average sick person, not a member of the Jewish Defense League, who was implicated in the bombing. No one at the league was immediately avail able for comment.

title: N.B.A. MINIMUMS TO REACH $17,500
description: The National Basketball As sociation players and owners agreed yesterday on a new threeyear contract that in creased minimum salaries, playoff and meal money.

title: Family of 3 on L.I. Wins MillionDollar Lottery Prize
description: A poised and prosperous threemember Long Island family that has yet to buy its first New York State lottery ticket was proclaimed the winner yesterday of the $1 million first prize in the state's special summer lottery.

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON A BROAD FRONT
description: The stock market beat a re treat yesterday after the ap parently negative Hanoi reac tion in Paris to President Nix on's Indochina peace proposals delivered in a widely awaited Wednesday evening address.

title: Foe Hopes to Oust Rodino in 10th With Big Ad Campaign
description: Special to The New York Times

title: In Memoriam
description: PRUSANSKYLt. Joseph. In cherished mem ory of our beloved son and brother. Joseph, who died Oct. 9. 1945, in the service of his country. His loving memory is with us always and forever.

title: U.S. AIDE REPORTS FUEL SUPPLY GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  George A. Lincoln, director of the Office of Emergency Pre paredness, said today that fuel supply prospects for this winter are vastly improved as a re sult of decisions by several do mestic oil companies to increase production of residual oil.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Special to The NeW York Times

title: Tories to Approach Rhodesia In New Attempt at Settlement
description: LONDON, Oct 8  The Brit ish Government will approach the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, in a new attempt to reach a settlement of the Rhodesian independence issue, the Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, told the Con servative party conference today.

title: INTEREST IS SOLD BY LONGCHAMPS
description: Longchamps, Inc., operators of a major chain of restaurants, announced yesterday the sale of its 53 per cent interest in Steak N Shake, Inc., which op erates more than 50 drivein restaurants in the Middle West, for $10.3million in cash and notes. Larry Ellman, president of Longchamps, said the sale of its interest in Steak N Shake was made to the White Capital Cor poration, a pri vately held corpo ration that is an affiliate of White & Co., Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. However, White & Co. is not a party to or in any way connected with the pur chase.

title: Savannah Turns Out for the President
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 8 On a quick visit to this con servative Southern city today, President Nixon said, There's nothing like a Georgia wel come.

title: Boycott in Indiana
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 8 (UPI)About 40 to 50 per cent of the students at LaSalle High School here stayed away from classes today as school offi cials attempted to organize a biracial committee to study black protests that their chil dren are inadequately pro tected.

title: Solzhenitsyn Is Awarded Nobel Prize in Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 8  Al eksandr I Solzhenitsyn, the in ternationally acclaimed So viet author whose works are banned in his homeland, won the 1970 Nobel Prize for Liter ature today.

title: Governor Skeptical About Plan For Payless Paydays in the City
description: Governor Rockefeller sharply questioned yesterday Mayor Lindsay's raising the threat of payless paydays for city em ployes with the city's fiscal year only three months old.

title: Class 44: Educational Theories Meet Reality
description: On a bulletin board in the office of Public School 198, next to the time clock on which the teachers punch in and out, was a newspaper clipping making nearly of ficial a constant theme of the most fervent school re formers.

title: A Serene, Elegant Show of Asian Art
description: The new exhibition at Asia House Gallery, consisting of 70 sculptures and ceramics (with a couple of paintings) from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, celebrates Mr. Rockefel ler's founding of The Asia Society 10 years ago and is an impressive combination of modesty and magnifi cence, the former serving as a kind of seasoning to bring out the flavor of the latter. The installations at Asia House from exhibition to ex hibition are object lessons in that craft, or art, but in this case the designers have out done themselves by way of understatement.

title: Candidate Seized at College
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP)Peter Camejo, Massachusetts Socialist party candidate for the United States Senate, was arrested to day at Northeastern University and charged with trespassing. A university spokesman said Mr. Camejo had set up a sound system on the steps of the student senate but had not ob tained the school's permission.

title: Ojukwu, Former Bictfran Chief, Is Ousted by the Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The former Biafran leader, Odumegwu Ojukwu, has been told to leave the Ivory Coast, his sanctuary since the end of the Nigerian civil war in January.

title: PRICE RISES ARE SET ON VARIETY OF GOODS
description: The prices to be paid for gypsum wallboard, paper and plastic cups and plates and at least one line of General Elec tric color television sets moved upward yesterday.

title: 3 in Senate Race Hail Peace Move, but Goodell and Ottinger Have Reservations
description: President Nixon's proposal for a standstill ceasefire throughout Indochina drew mixed reactions from New York's three Senate candidates.

title: Jets to Start Foley
description: Where was Dave Foley the last time Joe Namath, the Jets quarterback really need ed him? The 6foot 5inch of fensive tackle was out for the season with severely rup tured ligaments in his right knee that required an opera tion.

title: Here to Spur Boycott of Lettuce, Farm Workers Urge: Remember the Grape
description: A straggling group of field workers from California's Salinas Valley walked up Broadway from 68th Street one day earlier this week, waving homemade flags and stopping in supermarkets to tell store managers about the boycott against nonunion, solidhead lettuce.

title: Nikolai I. Konrad, 79, Dies; Soviet Specialist on Japan
description: Nikolai I. Konrad, a leading Soviet specialist on Japan, died in Moscow last Friday, Izvestia, the Soviet Government news paper, announced. He was 79 years old.

title: Theodore A. Garfield Is Dead; Chairman of Goldsmith Bros.
description: Theodore A. Garfield, chair man of the board of Goldsmith Bros., leading stationers, died Wednesday of a heart ailment in New York University Medi cal Center. He was 56 years old and lived on Pleasant Ridge Road, Harrison, N.Y.

title: Women Sue on Job Hours
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8 (UPI)Ten women factory workers filed suit yesterday to ask the courts to approve a limit on the num ber of hours women must work in Michigan. The suit, filed in Wayne County Circuit Court, asks for a finding that the United States Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not invalidate a state law setting a limit of a 54hour workweek. The law bars discrimination in employ ment against women.

title: Quebec Kidnappers of Diplomat Bargain Indirectly on Release
Ratelle Agrees to Ranger Contract
description: By the way, said Emile Francis yesterday as he rode an elevator to his office at Madison Square Garden, Jean Ratelle has agreed to terms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Nolte Analysis Disputed

title: TV: Helen Hayes Narrates Her Life
Travel Group Elects Head
description: Mrs. Mary De Van, passenger travel manager of J. P. Stevens & Co., has been elected presi dent of National Passenger Traffic Association, Inc. The as sociation consists of 500 travel managers and buyers for many of the nation's largest indus tries and businesses.

title: Youth Gangs Rampage Sixth Night in Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Gangs of youths set fire to the Registrar General's Office here early today as they rampaged through Hamilton for the sixth consecutive night.

title: Vietcong and North Vietnamese Arrive at Peace Talks
From the Prose of the Writer's Three Principal Works
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has been described as an author who has insisted upon holding a mirror up to Soviet society and accepting the perils and trials he knew would be inflicted upon him. In One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich, the author's mirror captures daytoday life in a Soviet pris on camp in Stalin's day, as in the following excerpt:

title: Gubernatorial Candidates to Debate 3 Times on TV
description: Governor Rockefeller agreed yesterday to participate in three televised debates with his two major gubernatorial oppo nents in the last week of the campaign.

title: Market Place:
description: Before you settle back to the comforting thought that in the years ahead the stock market will exhibit the vigor that has characterized it in the past, you should be aware that there is a growing cadre of doubters.

title: Hospitals in Quebec Struck On Plan for Medical Care
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (AP)  hospitals in Quebec were lim ited to emergency service to day as medical specialists be gan a general strike to protest the province's proposed medical care plan.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Profits Drop Sharply in Quarter
description: Sharply lower earnings for the third quarter and a cutback in one of its major aluminum production facilities were an nounced yesterday by the Kai ser Aluminum & Chemical Cor poration.

title: U.S. WAR DEAD 38, LOWEST SINCE 1966
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP) The United States com mand reported today that 38 American servicemen were kill ed in action last weekthe lowest number in four and a half years.

title: CHALLENGE IS ISSUED TO RESERVE SYSTEM
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia called on the nation's central banking system yesterday to make a greater contribution to dealing with social problems some of which the Federal Re serve itself may have helped to create.

title: PACE IS OFF A BIT IN MONEY GROWTH
description: The pace of expansion in money and bank credit slowed a bit in the last two weeks, banking data published yester day showed. The figures indi cated, analysts said, that the Federal Reserve System was continuing its moderately easy credit policy.

title: Mrs. Cudone, on 153, Leads By 12 Shots in Senior Golf
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP)Mrs. Carolyn Cu done increased her lead to 12 strokes in the United States Golf Association women's championship today with a secondround 75 at Coral Ridge Country Club.

title: Patient, 24, Dies in Plunge
description: A 24yearold patient at the New York University Medical Center plunged to his death from an 18thfloor window, the police said. He was identified as Gary Licalzi of 126 Belmore Road, East Meadow, L. I. A spokesman at the hospital said Mr. Licalzi had been admitted Oct. 4 suffering from chronic hepatitis.

title: George A. Ronus, Manager Of Dorchester in London
description: George A. Ronus, managing director of the Dorchester Ho tel in London since 1939, died in London yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: 4 GIRLS AND YOUTH SEIZED IN HOLDUPS
description: Four girls and a youth were arrested yesterday in connec tion with the holdups of five Manhattan banks, according to the police.

title: YALE STORM CENTER QUITS BASKETBALL
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8 (AP) Jack Langer, the basketball player who was the central fig ure in Yale University's chal lenge to the National Collegiate Athletic Association last sea son, has quit the Yale basket ball team.

title: RIGHTS VIOLATED, SEALE SUIT SAYS
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8  Bob by G. Seale, the national chair man of the Black Panther party, and his codefendant in a pend ing kidnapmurder trial here filed a Federal suit today, claim ing their constitutional rights as persons presumed innocent were being violated.

title: U.S. TO RESUME SALE OF ARMS TO PAKISTANI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The United States has decid ed to sell Pakistan an unspeci fied quantity of arms for the first time since the 1965 Indian Pakistani war, the State De partment said today.

title: Nicklaus and jacklin Gain Semifinals in Piccadilly Golf
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 8The prospect of a re peat of the duel in the 1969 Ryder Cup final match looms tomorrow when Jack Nicklaus, the British Open golf champion from the United States, meets Tony Jacklin, the United States Open champion from Britain.

title: ALEXEI A. MYURISEP, ESTONIAN PRESIDENT
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (AP) Alexei Alexandrovich Myurisep, President of Estonia, died yes terday after a short, severe ill ness, Radio Moscow reported today. He was in his late 60's.

title: Britain Backs Nixon, Seeks Further Geneva Talks
description: LONDON, Oct. 8  Britain today welcomed President Nixon's initiative to end the fighting in South Vietnam and gave her support to the recon vening of the Geneva Confer ence on Indochina.

title: Vessel Commisioned
description: MIAMI, Oct. 8 The nation's most advanced ocean survey ship, the Researcher, was com missioned today as Dr. Edward E. David Jr., the president's science adviser, forecast that it would play an important role in combating pollution of the seas.

title: F .T .C. Seeks to Help Consumers In Credit Fights With Computers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Federal Trade Commission pro posed today rules designed to ease some of the problems en countered by consumers in their dealings with compu terized credit accounts.

title: The Only Living Soviet Classic
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the great young Soviet poet, calls Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn the only living classic in Russia.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although these novels differ in every way imaginable, treatment, style, tone, setting, they have one device in common. In each, a single happening or act is pivotal to the movement of the fiction. In Robert Flynn's book, everything flows from this single event; in the Alonso, everything leads up to it. In each case it is the expectations that derive from these oc currences that hold the reader. The devices succeed; it's what follows that doesn't. One measure of the failure in both books is the gap between the promises and their ful fillment.

title: Bay State Justice Sworn
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP)Judge G. Joseph Tauro became Chief Justice of the Masachusetts Supreme Court today. He was sworn in by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: 7 DEMOCRATS GET AGNEW CHALLENGE
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 8 Vice President Agnew chal lenged Senator Edward M. Ken nedy of Massachusetts and six other Senate Democrats tonight to follow his example and drive radicals out of their party.

title: IMPRESSIVE PROGRAM BY JOHN HARTFORD
description: John Hartford is a bit coun trified and slick for folk music; a bit informal and folksy for country and western, but he does give an impressive per formance.

title: Couve Meets With Chou
description: PEKING, Oct. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)Maurice Couve de Murville, a former Premier of France, today met Premier Chou EnIai, Mr. Couve de Murville arrived here two days ago.

title: Department Store Sales Rise
description: Special to The New York Times

title: DEFENSE OF IRISH A TEST FOR ARMY
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 8 (AP)Coach Ara Parseghian of the Notre Dame No. 3 ranking football team has been trying hard this week to think of a reason he should fear unrated Airny Saturday in Trish Sta dium. He finally came up with the comment that Notre Dame's punt return coverage had been weak.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Gramco Suspends U.S.I.F. Sales
description: LONDON, Oct. 8 Assets were frozen for 23,000 foreign investors today when Gramco Management, Ltd., announced it was temporarily suspending redemptions and sales of its U.S.I.F. Real Estate Fund.

title: Biography Due Next Year
description: Praeger Publishers disclosed here yesterday that it planned to publish a biography of Alek sandr Solzhenitsyn next June.

title: HOUSE VOTES CUT IN PENTAGON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The House approved today a $2 billion cut in the Nixon Ad ministration's defense budget but shouted down proposals for further reductions in military spending or the withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Birds on Wing
Humphrey's Lease Of Car at Discount Confirmed by Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  Former Vice President Hu bert H. Humphrey used his chairmanship of a taxsupport ed scholarship center to obtain a cutrate lease on a Lincoln Continental from the Ford Mo tor Company.

title: CITY TAKES BEAM TO COURT ON PACTS
description: The Lindsay administration obtained an order in State Su preme Court yesterday for Con troller Abraham D. Beame to show cause why he should not pay $250,000 to McKinsey & Co. for a completed consultant contract. The McKinsey Compa ny obtained a similar order.

title: Mitchell Leaves Behind His Unguided Missile
description: RENO, Nev., Oct. 8 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell's wife, Martha, was ill yesterday and was unable to accompany him here for a speech.

title: Joyless Classrooms
description: The report by Charles E. Silberman on the nation's public schools confirms what a wide variety of critical studies have charged for years  that a great many children's desire to learn is turned off by oppressive, unimaginative and joyless classrooms.

title: Music: Concert Season Starts Well
description: Wednesday night was a beginning of sorts for two of New York's concert audi toriums. Alice Tully Hall had its first concert of the sea son at 6 P.M. Micheline Rene sang her Joy in Sing ing award recital. Two and a half hours later, Judith Raskin opened the Fairleigh Dickinson Concerts, directed by John Harms, at the New York Cultural Center.

title: Nixon Wants NATO to Furnish Troops, Not Cash
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  President Nixon has told the North Atlantic alliance that the United States favors a greater European military effort rather than cash subsidies to help sup port American forces in Europe.

title: The Cinderella Boys
description: It wasn't long ago that Sparky Anderson of the Cincinnati Reds and Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles were riding rickety old buses in the bush leagues, trying to feed themselves on $3aday meal money and trying to sustain both life and hope under the most discouraging circumstances. They were young enough at that time to sustain life without undue difficulty, but fragile had to be the hope of eventual es cape to that earthly paradise, the big leagues.

title: CeaseFire in the Bronx?
description: By winning agreement of the Bronx landlords and their striking building service employes to consider arbitration of their wage dispute, Mayor Lindsay has made a con structive start toward ending the tieup that has inflicted severe hardship on thousands of Bronx families for nearly four weeks.

title: ARBITRATION TALK DUE ON BUILDINGS
description: Shortly after Mayor Lindsay assailed some Bronx property owners as Weatherman land lords, both real estate repre sentatives and union officials agreed to consider binding arbi tration to end the 24dayold strike of apartment house workers.

title: Executive Changes
description: Raymond H. Marks has been named president and Stanley R. Sheeran has been apponited executive vice president of Tenneco Chemicals, Inc., subsidiary of Tenneco, Inc.

title: Greetings
description: HOCHBERGEsther & Lottie wish everyone a Year of good Health ft. Happiness. May everlasting WorIdWide Peace be realized this year.

title: Jack Vaughn Is Named Urban Coalition Head
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 8 (AP) Jack Hood Vaughn, former director of the Peace Corps, will become president of the National Urban Coalition, it was learned today.

title: Advertising: Improving a Policeman's Lot
description: George Lois, the big Greek agency man, learned to hate policemen while growing up in the Bronx. Now he's taken on the job of trying to keep others from doing the same.

title: HUGE WASTE LAID TO U.S. IN VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 8  Congressional investigators re ported evidence today of ap palling waste in the supply system behind the United States war effort in South Vietnam.

title: Bring Back the Railroads
description: AMENIA, N. Y.The problems of transportation are still being discussed in such narrow terms that no adequate solution is possible. As long as we attempt piecemeal measures, aimed merely at retaining an already insuffi cient train schedule, or providing new equipment for a deliberately neglected suburban service, the rate of deteriora tion will increase. What is needed is nothing less than a new national policy aimed at overcoming the trans portation crisis, which is approaching the disaster point.

title: Gurdon Wallace Wattles Weds Santha Rama Rau
description: Santha Rama Rau, the Brah manborn writer who has been called a link between the Orient and the Occident, and Gurdon Wallace Wattles, an American international lawyer with the United Na tions, were married here yes terday afternoon Twice.

title: In the Men's Shop, It Was Drama at High Noon
description: Tense salesmen stood to gether in groups, whispering and giggling. One was such a nervous wreck that he called in sick. No, there wasn't much selling going on yesterday morning in the University (men's) Shop in Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: News Summary and index
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1970

title: BULLETS SET BACK PISTONS IN OPENER
description: The defending champions of the National Basketball Associ ation will start the 197071 campaign Tuesday night against the Boston Celtics with a four game losing streak.

title: KIRKMAN IS AILING, FOREMAN FIGHT OFF
description: The heavyweight bout be tween George Foreman and Boone Kirkman scheduled for next Thursday night at Madi son Square Garden was post poned indefinitely yesterday.

title: NIXON IS QUERIED ON CENSOR'S NAME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  President Nixon was asked to day to disclose the name of the nation's chief censor, a private citizen now on standby duty who would assume office in a national emergency.

title: Zero Draft Goal by 1973 Expected by Defense Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that he hopes to reach by 1973 a goal of zero draft, in which all young men will sign up but no one will be called.

title: Atlantic City Results
description: By The Associated Press

title: Saigon Backs Nixon's Proposals And Again Offers Free Election
Rule Book Making Waves This Year
Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: PARK PATROLMAN TRIED ON CHARGES
description: No decision was reached after a fivehour departmental trial of charges against Patrol man John Bal, the longhaired patrolman facing 20 complaints from superior officers.

title: Peace Accord in Jordan Is Violated by Both Sides
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 8Vi olations of the accord that end ed the fighting between the Jordanian Army and the Pales tinian guerrillas were visible throughout Jordan today.

title: Dale E. McConaughy Is Betrothed to Robert M. Hart
description: Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Robert A, Wharton of West Hartford, Conn., of the en gagement of Mrs. Wharton's daughter, Miss Dale E. Mc Conaughy, to Robert M. Hart, both of New York. Mr. Hart, who is with the New York law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Hart of La Grangeville, N. Y.

title: BRANDT'S MAJORITY IS CUT IN TEST VOTE
description: BONN, Oct. 8A fourth of Chancellor Willy Brandt's 12 vote majority in the West Ger man Bundestag failed him to day in a critical vote test. The three defectors were all Depu ties of his tiny coalition part ner, the Free Democratic party.

title: 3 Copters Reported Down
description: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 9 (Reu ters)  North Vietnamese and Vietcong ground fire shot down three United States Army heli copters yesterday, two of them onehalf mile from Laos, the United States command report ed today. It said four crewmen were wounded in the crashes.

title: Tax to Finance Air Guards Protested by I.A.T.A. Chief
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 8Knut Hammarskjold, directorgeneral of the International Air Trans port Association, protested to day the Nixon Administration's plan to levy an extra tax of $2 on international departures to help pay for placing armed guards on United States air liners.

title: Upstate G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The Defense Department today identified three United States servicemen killed in action in Southeast Asia. Among them was Specialist 4 Stanley H. Barrett of Troy. N. Y.

title: Murtaugh of Pirates Named Big League Pilot of Year
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (UPI)  Danny Murtaugh, who led the Pittsburgh Pirates into the Na tional League playoffs this year, was named major league manager of the year today in a poll of managers conducted by The Sporting News.

title: LEO M. RUMELY JR.
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 8 Leo M. Rumely Jr., secretary of the Norwalk Zoning Commit sion, died yesterday in Little Rock, Ark., where he was on a business trip. He lived on Cricklewood Lane here.

title: Cambodia Quiet on Plan
description: Special to The New Teak Times

title: Cahill's Plan to Reduce Drug Penalties Enacted
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8  Gov. William T. Cahill's controver sial plan to reduce the crimi nal penalties for possessing small amounts of marijuana and to establish state aid to private and parochial schools cleared the Legislature this evening.

title: MOSCOW DENIES MIDEAST BREACH AND ACCUSES U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8The Soviet Government angrily denied to night that it had participated in any violation of the Middle East ceasefire agreement and accused the United States of unscrupulous distortion of the facts.

title: I.R.S. TO RESTUDY TAXEXEMPT UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Internal Revenue Service is planning to reconsider and pos sibly revoke the taxexempt status of certain organizations that engage in litigation against private parties, such as those currently filing suits against corporations allegedly, pollut ing the air and water.

title: Princeton Is Fearful That Dartmouth Will Settle an Old Score Tomorrow
description: Last season Dartmouth stormed through eight oppo nents, then went to Palmer Stadium to play Princeton in a game the Indians hoped would cap an undefeated campaign and another Ivy League championship.

title: Solzhenitsyn Is Willing to Go To Accept if Moscow Permits
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8  Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn today ac cepted the Nobel Prize for Liter ature with gratitude and said he hoped to travel to Stockholm to receive the award.

title: Maurer Is Out of Danger
description: PARIS, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Pre mier Ion Maurer of Rumania, injured recently in a car acci dent, is out of danger, Ruma nian sources here said today. Two French doctors who flew to Bucharest to treat the Pre mier have returned home.

title: Post Is Ordered to Show Cause Why It Locked Out Pressmen
description: Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan signed an order yesterday directing The New York Post to show cause next Tuesday why it should not be enjoined from violating its contract with Pressmen's Union No. 2 by locking out members of the local.

title: PENN CENTRAL PLEA REJECTED BY COURT
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (UPI) A threejudge Federal panel reissued today an order that bars the insolvent Penn Central Transportation Company from, discontinuing 14 passenger trains serving the area be tween New York City and St. Louis.

title: Democrats vs. Hoover
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  There is no more traditional Democratic appeal than to the wallet and the pocketbook. The Democratic professionals call it running against Herbert Hoover because it is based on the belief that the great De pression so scarred the work ing man and his sons that they will never again trust the Republi cans with their economic fate. For almost 40 years, it has served the Democrats in election after election.

title: Urban and Airborne Terror
description: PARISArmed guards will ride shotgun on all forms of public trans portation, it was predicted in a re port by the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Vio lence, and President Nixon's decision to create such a force for civilian aircraft seems but a first step along this gloomy road. For simmering vio lence in American cities has a direct parallel in violence aboard interna tional planes and is not unrelated.

title: Injury Sidelines Hatoum
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Oct. 8 (AP)The Van couver Canucks, who open their National Hockey League season tomorrow against the Los Angeles Kings, learned last night that Ed Hatoum, a right wing, would be out for at least six weeks. Hatoum suffered a shoulder injury during a prac tice session yesterday.

title: Receiver Is Eager for More Passes, Chance to Score
description: While struggling, through their first three games, the New York Giants have not used their wide receivers as much as their running backs in Fran Tarkenton's passing attack. One reason may be that Tarkenton is working his passes off a high rate of play action which puts backs in short receiving roles.

title: 3 Oil Companies in Management Shifts
description: The oil industry was aflutter yesterday with a series of top level and puzzling executive changes.

title: ExJohn Hancock Head Chosen As President and Chief of I.O. S.
description: GENEVA, Oct. 8  Inves tors Overseas Services an nounced today the appointment of Robert E. Slater, former head of the John Hancock Mu tual Life Insurance Company, as top man in its troubled mu tual fund empire.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON TURN DOWNWARD
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned lower yester day. There was some profit taking, although selling was not heavy.

title: Ailey Dancers Fill Soviet Theater
description: A standingroomonly house that cheered a moderndance work in the jazz idiom and a meeting with a Soviet rock band highlighted the second week of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's current Soviet tour.

title: G.O.P. Liberal Pitted Against Incumbent in 11th District
Bridge:
description: New York bridge enthusi asts will have an opportunity to participate in an unusual event later this month. It is the World Bidding Contest, sponsored by the Interna tional Bridge Academy, to be played here Sunday, Oct. 18, at the Mayfair House of Bridge, 119 West 57th Street, and the Gallerie of Bridge and Games, 236 West 57th Street.

title: Ryan Cards a 72 to Lead Long Island Senior Golf
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, Oct. 8, 1970

title: North Korean Role Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 8 (AP)North Koreans were reported today to be fighting in Cambodia on the Communist side.

title: Moynihan Tells College Heads Leadership Is Needed to Get Aid
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Counselor to the President, challenged col lege administrators today to or ganize themselves better so as to influence Government policy on the support of higher educa tion.

title: 4 UNIONS TO SHUN STATE CONVENTION
description: Leaders of four major unions backing Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor announced yesterday that they would boycott the State A.F.L.C.I.O. convention next Wednesday at Kiamesha Lake, where a previous en dorsement of Governor Rocke feller is scheduled for recon sideration.

title: LICENSES LIFTED IN AIRLINE CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The Government rescinded today the licenses of the com pany that owned the Wichita State University charter plane that crashed last, Friday and of the concern that supplied the crew, contending that their business arrangement was ap parently a facade to evade air safety regulations.

title: Cutting the I.L.O. Purse Strings
description: The House has now joined the Senate in a decision to cut off United States payments to the International Labor Organization, thus putting this country on the dishonor roll of international defaulters.

title: 'The Valor of Ignorance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Part of the endless tragedy of Vietnam is that the men running the war know so little about one another or the people on the other side. Washington mis judged the history and psychology of the Vietnamese people for years, and this has cost us over 40,000 American lives and over a hundred billion dol lars, and now Hanoi and the Vietcong seem to be misjudging President Nixon's latest peace offer and the temper of the American people.

title: Schoolgirls Stitch Hastily Improvised Flag for New Cambodian Republic
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 8  At 2 o'clock this morning Mrs. Sim Song Lung received a telephone call telling her what the new flag of the Khmer Republic, to be proclaimed tomorrow, was to look like. Parliament had just decided.

title: SEARS' SALES ROSE 7.3% LAST MONTH
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest retailer, re ported yesterday that sales rose 7.3 per cent last month, com pared with September, 1969. It was the largest monthly in crease since Sears current fis cal year began Feb. 1.

title: A JAZZ GUITAR DUO SHOWS VIRTUOSITY
description: Guitar duos in jazz have been few but distinguished In the early nineteen  thirties, Eddie Lang and Carl Kress re corded some guitar duets. After Mr. Lang's death in 1933, Mr. Kress made several records with Dick McDonough. In both cases the duos existed only in the recording studio.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Fell from 108.8 to 108.3
description: The wholesale commodity price index fell yesterday to 108.3 from 108.8 last week.

title: Memoirs of de Gaulle Set a Record for Sales
description: PARIS, Oct. 8 (Reuters) Gen. Charles de Gaulle's lat est volume of memoirs set a record for sales today as Frenchmen bought 175,000 copies in two days.

title: Metropolitan Museum to Institute Admission Charge
description: Starting Tuesday, visitors will be asked to pay an ad mission fee to the Metro politan Museum of Art. Flush ed with the success of an ex perimental fee plan, in effect since last August at the Cloisters, its medieval out post uptown, and since last July for special exhibitions at the main building, the museum has decided to initi ate an experimental general admissions charge.

title: Lowery Responds to Critic On Use of 911 in Fire Calls
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery diagreed yesterday with critical remarks made by the chairman of the Fire Alarm Dispatchers Union on the 911 police emergency telephone number to report fires.

title: Cleveland Musicians Reject Raise of $25 to End Strike
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (UPI) Striking musicians of the Cleve land Orchestra rejected yester day, 70 to 27, a threeyear contract offer that met all their requEsts except wages.

title: Nobel Award
description: The 1970 Nobel Laureate in literature, Aleksandr Sol zhenitsyn, is one of the recognized giants of the contem porary world of letters, a master of the Russian language in the great tradition that runs from Pushkin through Dostoyevsky and Tolstoy to Pasternak. As the Nobel Prize Committee noted, there is an ethical force in his writing, a compassion for suffering humanity that has permitted his work to transcend the limits of his personal experience and to shed new light on the human condition. It is to Nikita Khrushchev's credit that a decade ago he permitted the publication of Solzhenitsyn's first masterly novel, A Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich. That moving and unforgettable account of the horrors a Soviet slave labor camp established Solzhenitsyn's reputation at home and abroad almost overnight. But more recently Khrushchev's successors have deemed politically necessary partially to rehabilitate Joseph Stalin. That infamous decision brought in its wake a shameful effort to silence and disgrace Solzhenitsyn in his native land. It is this tragic background which explains why Solzhenitsyn's later superb novels, The Cancer Ward and The First Circle, have been banned in the Soviet Union while Solzhenitsyn himself has been proclaimed a pariah unworthy even of membership in the Union of Soviet Writers.

title: E. M. Forster to Open ANTA Series
description: The 15th season of the ANTA Matinee Series, the experimental and showcase program, will begin on Oct. 26 and Oct. 27 with Peggy Wood and Teresa Wright co starring in A Passage to E. M. Forster, it was an nounced yesterday by Lucille Lortel, artistic director of the series.

title: Russians to Join Space Rescue Panel
New Books
description: Che Guevara, by Andrew Sinclair (Viking, $4.95: paperbound, $1.65). A study in the Modern Masters series.

title: BOMBINGS DAMAGE 3 PLACES IN WEST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 Early morning bomb blasts hit a courtroom in San Rafael, Calif., an armory in Santa Bar bara, Calif., and a Reserve Of ficers Training Corps building on the University of Washing ton campus in Seattle today. A bomb was disarmed before it exploded in a building at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Boycott, SitIn and Resignation Keep Franklin High School Shut
description: A casual sitin by parents land teachers; an orderly boy cott by more than 4,000 stu dents and the voluntary resig nation of the acting principal shut down Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem yesterday. The school is ex pected to be closed again to day.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: New Women's Magazine Making Debut in February
description: A courageous woman down in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has decided to enter the national women's magazine field which could easily be called cutthroatand has sent an other brave woman to New York to scrounge advertis ine for it.

title: 5 HURT IN CRASH ON PENN CENTRAL
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Oct. 8A Bostonbound passenger train, the Patriot, slammed into a de railed caboose on the Penn Central's main line here to night, injuring at least five persons, none seriously, and tearing up a 200yard section of track.

title: Lemmings on Way to Sea Stall Train in Norway
description: TRONDHEIM, Norway, Oct. 18 (Reuters)Lemmings stalled an express train about 95 miles from here yesterday.

title: Dining Here Is Better Late Than Early
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: El Al Disciplines the Pilot in Abortive Hijacking
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8  The pilot of the El Al airliner in volved in an abortive hijack ing Sept. 6 is being punished for violating a security regu lation.

title: U.S. BIDS SOVIET AID ON INDOCHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  The United States publicly urged the Soviet Union today to use its considerable influence with North Vietnam and the Vietcong to persuade them to accept President Nixon's proposal for a cease fire in Indochina.

title: Trainer's Informal Garb Seems His Winning Suit
description: Just before yesterday's program at Belmont Park, Bobby Frankel, the talented 29yearold trainer from For est Hills, took a studied sar torial stand.

title: Jersey Standard Reports New Oil Accord With Libya
description: The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday re ported a new agreement be tween its affiliate, Esso Stand ard Libya, Inc., and the Libyan government covering taxes and posted prices for crude oil.

title: Pill to Stop Heart Attacks
description: LONDON (Reuters)A pill to prevent men from dying from heart attacks will be available in a few years, Dr. Walter Somerville recently told the world congress of cardiology. I can see men taking their pill daily in the same way as women now take the contra ceptive pill, the London Middlesex Hospital doctor said.

title: A Report on Vietnamization: Aides in Saigon Feel Allies Have Never Been Stronger
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1United States and South Vietnamese officials here be lieve that as Vietnamization has progressed, security has improved in large parts of the country and the effectiveness of the South Vietnamese Army has increased.

title: Dr. Samuel Standard Dies at 71; A Professor of Clinical Surgery
description: Dr. Samuel Standard, pro fessor of clinical surgery at the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday of a cardiovascular ailment in University Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 140 East 28th Street.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR INDICTED IN BRIBE
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 8 (UPI) Mayor Frank Curran, president of the National League of Cities, was indicted with eight other persons today on bribery and conspiracy charges stem ming from a taxicab rate in crease in 1967.

title: Rush of Crime Bills Voted By Senate in Night Session
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  Seeking to build up a pre election image as a lawandorder Congress, the Senate acted speedily today on a stack of anticrime bills, including one to protect Federal law makers.

title: State Senator Says Many Die Because of the Nurse Shortage
description: State Senator Roy M. Good man charged yesterday that numerous patients had died in municipal hospitals because of the shortage of nurses.

title: Ky Leaves Paris for Saigon
description: PARIS, Oct. 8 (AP)  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam left for Saigon today after a twoweek stay in Paris and London. He refused to see reporters and give his reaction to President Nixon's proposals for a ceasefire in the Vietnam war.

title: Reforms in Procedure Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Congress gave final ap proval today to a revision of its procedures that dilutes some of the powers of corn mittee chairmen, ends secret House voting and opens House committees to televi sion coverage.

title: Books of The Times
description: Reviewing, a novel by Peter DeVries is like reviewing a machine. You can de scribe it at length, but the basic question about a machine is: What does it do? The DeVries machine makes you laugh, that's what it does, most of the time. Some of the time it makes you weep, a healthy sort of weeping, as if to say, yes, we're foolish, although possibly not al together evil. Well, then, how does the DeVries machine make you laugh and weep? By grinding out jokes and people, and 111 sometimes people who are jokes, in quantity, according to cer tain principles of mechanics only Mr. DeVries and S. J. Perelman and the late H. H. Munro (Saki) ap pear to have grasped. Open Mrs. Wallop to almost any page and you will finda rock group called The Single Girl and Red China . . . A Greek liqueur whose name I forget, which works minutes faster than the four other leading nasal decongestants . . . dining out on catfood Bolognese or cowchips Aqui taine . . . a short story about a modern young wife and mother, who after a typical day of cleaning, sewing and cooking for a family of six, is seized with labor pains in the middle of the night and rushed to the hospital, where she gives birth to an eightpound pot roast.

title: MISS COSSOTTO SINGS ADALGISA IN NORMA
description: In Bellini's Norma the chief vocal tests rest with the ladies. For its new production last spring and in every subsequent performance, the Met has relied on Joan Sutherland and Marilyn Horne, two very capable sing ers more than equal to the ardu ous demands of Norma and Adalgisa.

title: GOLDBERG URGES REFORM OF TAXES
description: Arthur J. Goldberg pledged yesterday that as Governor he would seek tax reforms to close loopholes and make the wealthy and special interests pay a fair share while avoiding an unfair burden on the least able to pay.

title: BlackOriented Card Concern Confident
description: On the surface, yesterday's annual meeting of the Mer chant Prince Corporation was just like any other stockhold er meeting. There were the legal formalities, the lineup of products on display, the stockholders eargerly listen ing for earnings forecasts and the other trappings of this corporate ritual.

title: Pentagon Wary on a CeaseFire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  In the view of senior American military planners, a ceasefire, in place throughout Indochina, as proposed last night by President Nixon, could be dis astrous to the Saigon Govern ment unless it was effectively supervised.

title: RIDERS THREATEN EQUAL RIGHTS BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Extraneous amendments of ferred by both Northern and Southern Senators added new threats today to a proposed constitutional amendment to guarantee women equality with men.

title: CITY OPERA WORK STRESSES ACTION
description: Once upon a time, opera was for the most part a medium in which singers in costume stood around on a stage and sang, and audiences were content to imagine what the appropriate dramatic action would be if the singers were sufficiently lithe and skilled to enact It.

title: RAIN THREATENS FUTURITY TODAY
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8  Twominute miles, the delight of all breeders, owners, train ers and drivers, were nowhere in sight this damp, chilly aft ernoon at the famed Red Mile, where 22 magic miles were achieved the previous two aft ernoons and where tomorrow the $76,351 Kentucky Futurity is scheduled to be trotted.

title: Cambodian Army Problem
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 8 (UPI)A Pnompenh news paper Independent Khmer, said today it had discovered through a census taken among Cam bodia's women soldiers that quite a number of them are pregnant. Women have been trained to do clerical functions for the Cambodian Army in order to release more men for field duty. But there also are women soldiers in the field.

title: Race at a Glance In 10th District
description: POPULATION: About 428, 000 people (as of January, 1969) in an extremely diverse district that includes slum neighborhoods and middle class areas of Newark and bluecollar sections and af fluent suburbs of smaller Essex County towns to the northwest.

title: Swiss Announce Antihijacking Actions
description: GENEVA, Oct. 8  The soldiers guarding the Geneva and Zurich airports carry loaded rifles and have been authorized to shoot in case of an attempted hijacking or other threats to aircraft, the Swiss Military Department disclosed today.

title: GRAIN PRICE RISE PARED NEAR CLOSE
description: Profit taking near the close, drastically trimmed the price advances in grains and soy beans futures that had taken place earlier in the pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday. The result was that prices closed lower or mixed.

title: Dana Corporation Registers Record Sales and Earnings for the Fiscal Year
description: The Dana Corporation, which derives the bulk of its sales from original equipment prod ucts for truck and passenger cars, turned in record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, John E. Mar tin, chairman, reported yester day.

title: NIXON TALK FAILS TO BOLSTER BONDS
description: The bond market drifted lower yesterday in the wake of President Nixon's proposal for a supervised truce in Southeast Asia.

title: Stage: Savage Alice in Wonderland
description: Fantastic! Indeed, add any other hooray words you like. They celebrate Andre Greg ory's staging of Alice in Wonderland. It is set in a rabbit hole called The Exten sion, which is roughly at Park Avenue and 21st Street, and it plays from Thursdays to Sundays. There must be allof 100 seats at every per formance, and everyone in New York mildly interested in the theateror with simi lar pretensions to nourish is going to be fighting for them. There is probably going to be blood found outside the box office.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS NIXON'S PROPOSAL ON WELFARE, 141
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  The Senate Finance Committee rejected President Nixon's wel fare reform plan today by a 14to1 vote, dealing a serious blow to the Administration's toppriority domestic legislative program.

title: Jews Will Mark Start Of Yom Kippur Tonight
description: Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sa cred event on the Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown today with services in temples and synagogues.

title: Reserve Bank Names Aides
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston announced today the election of two new directors for three year terms. They are Ralph A. McIninch, president of the Merchants National Bank, Man chester, N. H., and G. William Miller, president of Textron, Inc., of Providence, R. I.

title: STUDENTS' WEAPONS SHOWN TO SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) University of Buffalo student revolutionaries and some of the ideological colleagues from the faculty are producing a virtual arsenal of deadly weapons and antipolice rhetoric in their war against the establishment, Con gress was told today.

title: Mrs. Nixon Comments
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 8 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that she thought her husband's Southeast Asia peace address was marvelous and add ed, I hope they were listening abroad. She arrived here for a long weekend of relaxation with the President.

title: Facts on Race in the 11th District
description: POPULATION  About 429,000, includes members of black and white ethnic mi norities and the poor, the middle class and the wealthy. The district, which is part of Essex County, embraces the predominantly black Central and racially mixed West wards of Newark, closein bluecollar communities and welltodo suburbs.

title: ARTHUR WHITMAN, 45, WRITER AND TEACHER
description: Arthur Whitman, a freelance writer and author, died of hepatitis Wednesday at New York University Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived at 25 Fifth Avenue.

title: 45 Seized in Pontiac
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 8 (UPI) The police arrested today 45 black and white high school students after stones and nails were thrown from the bus they were riding home and a small bomb was found on it.

title: Federal Guarantee Given Bonds Sold For Jonathan, Minn.
description: The first issue of bonds guaranteed by the Federal Gov ernment and sold to finance de velopment of an entirely new community  Jonathan, Minn.  was offered to investors yes terday.

description: THURSDAY'S GAMES

title: City Betting Corporation Hires 2 Experts on Organized Crime

title: Robinson Group Rebuffed By Court on Trust Fund
description: Customers of Robinson & Co., a brokerage house in bank ruptcy proceedings, suffered an initial setback yesterday in their efforts to get the New York Stock Exchange to cover their potential losses with its Special Trust Fund.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Board of Estimate Kills 3d Ave. Housing Plan
description: Over the opposition of Mayor Lindsay, the Board of Estimate voted 18 to 4 yesterday to kill a hotly controversial plan for mixture of 1,630 luxury apart ments and 418 lowincome units on lower Third Avenue. The four votes were Mr. Lindsay's.
