description: Francis Brown, the editor of The New York Times Book Re view for the last two decades, will retire at the end of the year, it was announced yester day by Arthur Ochs Sulzberg er, publisher of The Times.

title: FRANK MACINA
description: Frank Macina, president of the: Williamsbridge Parkway Garage and Service Station, Inc., 2027 Williamsbridge Road, the Bronx, a Jeep and Fiat agency, died of a stroke yester day in Glen Cove (L. I.) Hos pital. He was 51 years old and lived at 41 June Avenue, Bay vine, L. I.

title: NEGRO VIEWPOINT IS CITED BY ADAMS
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 8  Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conserva tive party candidate for Gov ernor, said today that there were few blacks in his party because they took a stereotype view of it.

title: Nixon Gets Wide Press Support on Truce
description: Newspapers supporting Pres ident Nixon's Vietnam policy and newspapers that have op posed it joined yesterday in approval of his new ceasefire proposals.

title: Detergent Makers Agree to Finance An Enzyme Study
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The soap and detergent industry tentatively agreed today to fi nance an immediate study of the possibly harmful effects of using laundry detergents con taining enzymes.

title: A Gala Cruise Helps Cancer Society
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Bobst don't attend many charity benefits because, ac cording to Mrs. Bobst, there are so many you can spend your life doing nothing else.

title: You Order in N.Y., It's Made in Paris
description: Among the French haute couture, the name of Meren lender is synonymous with leather. For a quarter of a century Merenlender pre et fils have supplied such houses as Dior, Lanvin, Patou and Saint Laurent with marvel ously supple and exotic leath ers for their designs while maintaining a custom order salon on the Rue du Fau bourgSt. Honor for a small but exacting clientele.

title: Senator Scott Appears Far Ahead in 3d Term Bid
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 What's the name? the tele phone operator responded when asked for the number for Ses lerforSenate headquarters here.

title: Palmer Recalls One Bench Clout
description: The bases were loaded and Jim Palmer was about to face a 19yearold batter he knew nothing about. It was 1967, and Palmer was pitch ing for Rochester in the In ternational League, trying to work his right arm back into sound condition.

title: Book Sales Up, But Lag Noted In Growth Rate
description: The book business had another boom year in the United States in 1969, but its growth rate was not so high as it had been in previous years.

title: NIXON PEACE PLAN ASSAILED BY REDS AT TALKS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 8  The Com munist delegations to the Viet nam peace talks denounced President Nixon's five peace proposals today as a maneuver to deceive world opinion and held fast to their demands for unconditional and total Amer ican troop withdrawal and the overthrow of the puppet lead ers in Saigon.

title: PEKING AID PACT HAILED BY HANOI
Scarecrows, by Gunter Grass, Delights Berliners as a Ballet
description: BERLIN, Oct. 8Political al legory or personal nightmare? The question remains open as to what the third ballet sce nario, The Scarecrows, by Germany's much acclaimed postwar author Giinter Grass (The Tin Drum) actually means, but fortunately it makes for exciting theater. Both the author and the com poser, youthful Aribert Rei mann, were cheered by the West Berlin audience at last night's premiere in the Deutsche Opera.

title: Education Nominee Denies Seeking Big U.S. Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)  Dr. Sidney P. Marland, Presi dent Nixon's choice for United States Commissioner of Educa tion, has denied a charge that he is part of an industrialed ucation complex seeking mil lions of dollars in Federal con tracts.

title: Laos Halls Proposal
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Laotian Government today hailed President Nixon's peace proposals as very reasonable and said it believed they would facilitate the settlement of the Laotian crisis.

title: They've All Got Automobiles
description: GLENDALE, Calif1 came up to the big league 58 years ago this fall in Brooklyn, and if you ask me if I'm discouraged by the state of the world these days, I'd have to say I am dis appointed by a few things.

title: 3 Bank Holding Units in City Show Mixed Earnings Results
description: Three of New York's bank holding companies reported yesterday mixed earnings results for the third quarter and the first nine months of 1970. The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, parent of the Bankers Trust Company and six other affiliates, showed an indicated 24.1 per cent earnings gain from opera tions for the JulySeptember period. Including the effect of transactions in invest ments, the concern showed a gain of 27.3 per cent.

title: Train to Be Discontinued
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP)The Illinois Central Railroad an nounced today plans to discon tinue as unprofitable its Panama Limited, a luxury train between Chicago and New Orleans.

title: Drillings Indicate Mediterranean Is Smaller
description: American scientists reported here yesterday that sediments just drilled from the bottom of the Mediterraflean Sea indi cated that the continental mass of Europe and Africa are slowly pressing together.

title: More Released by Jordan
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Jordanian authorities today released more than 3,000 pris oners detained as suspected guerrilla fighters during battles in Amman and Zerqa, last month, it was officially an nounced in Amman.

title: Quebec Premier Hopeful On Luring U.S. Investors
description: Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec asserted here yesterday that the kidnapping by French Canadian separatists of a Brit ish trade official had not changed the climate of confi dence in New York's financial circles.

title: Plea Entered in Boston
description: BOSTON; Oct. 9 (AP)Robert J. Valeri, 21 years old, one of five persons charged in a bank holdup and the slaying of a Boston policeman Sept. 23, pleaded not guilty today to murder and armed robbery. He was taken under guard to the Suffolk Superior Court for the arraignment and was held with out hail.

title: Throwing a Hat in the Rink
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)Six months after the Boston Bruins won the Stanley Cup in hockey, President Nixon sent a telegram to Weston A. Adams, the Bruins president, yesterday wishing the squad his warmest greetings and best wishes as you begin defense of your Na tional Hockey League cham pionship.

title: Shelley to Offer Musical
description: A Day in the Life of Just About Everyone, which has book, music and lyrics by Earl Wilson Jr., will be presented off Broadway early in December by Robert Shelley.

title: Rockefeller Pond to Open
description: The outdoor iceskating rink in Rockefeller Plaza will open for its 35th consecutive season today at 10:30 A.M., weather permitting.

title: Day to Honor Free China
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday des ignated today as Free China Day in the city to commemo rate the 59th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China. He presented the official proclamation to Henry T. Chan, president of the Chinese Con solidated Benevolent Associa tion.

title: Common Market Steps Up Its Pressure to Prevent Passage
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 9The Eu ropean trading partners of the United States are stepping up pressures to try to prevent pas sage of the new trade bill be fore Congress.

title: Arthur Blakemore, Surgeon and Teacher, Dead
description: Dr. Arthur Hendley Blake more, an internationallyknown surgeon and medical teacher, died Thursday after a long ill ness. He was 73 years old and lived at 11 Maple Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Wagner Campaigns Here for Ottin ger
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner walked the streets of Yorkville yesterday to an nounce his support for Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.

title: Boar Runs Wild in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI)A wild boar terrorized a group of children and ran wild on a main Moscow street, the news paper Leninskoye Znamya said today.

title: Kidnappers Set Final Deadline In Quebec and Threaten Briton
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 9In a final ransom note, the kid nappers of James R. Cross demanded tonight that 23 po litical prisoners be freed by 6 P.M. tomorrow or the Govern ment would never see Mr. Cross again.

title: Bridal Planned By Jay Sargent, Brian J. Flynn
description: DOVER, Mass., Oct. 9 Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts and Mrs. Sar gent have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Jay Sargent, to Brian Joseph Flynn, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Edward Flynn of Med field. They made the an nouncement at a private din ner party for family and close friends at their home here tonight

title: 5 Killed and 173 injured In Japanese Train Crash
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 10 (UPI)An electric train carry ing 1,300 passengers rammed into a dump truck at a rural crossing 35 miles north of here last night in one of Japan's worst railway accidents.

title: New Rugs and Old, With Colors That Are Startlingly Bright
description: The more rugs change, the more they stay the sameor so two collections of rugs at the Stark Carpet Corpora tion, 979 Third Avenue make it seem. Both the Tibetan collection of 28 old rugs, ranging from $1,200 to $18, 000, and the modern de signs, which are $245 for a 6by9foot size, include geo metric patterns, bold color ings and flat weaves.

title: Termination of Operations Expected by Technamation
description: Technamation, Inc., which makes training aids and ani mated displays, said yesterday that it expected to terminate its operation activities because of a marked decrease in sales, together with an operation loss that had exhausted the com named working capital.

title: War Seems Far Away as Cambodia Becomes Republic
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 9  Cambodia became a re public today while hundreds cheered and the war seemed far away.

title: JUDICIAL REFORM URGED BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay delivered a strongly worded white paper to the state's highest adminis trative judges yesterday in which he was understood to have called for sweeping re forms of court procedures.

title: Flood Recedes in Genoa and Helicopters Bring Aid to Isolated Villages
description: GENOA, Italy, Oct. 9 (Reu ters)  Helicopters tonight dropped food and medical supplies to isolated Italian villages cut off by flooding rivers, which have caused about 30 deaths in the past two days.

title: Miss Ellen Brody Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Ellen Brody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Brody of Yonk ers, to Derek Mali took place here yesterday afternoon. Su preme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment

title: GREAT WESTERN IN PACT FOR LFC
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest savings and loan hold ing companies, agreed yester day to take over the troubled LFC Financial Corporation in a transaction heavily subsi dized by the Federal Govern ment. The two companies, which have combined assets of $3.3 billion, are both based in Los Angeles.

title: Rose Considers Series Opener Decisive if Reds Beat Palmer
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 (UPI) Pete Rose says the World Series can be settled Saturday.

title: Orioles Now Series Choice; Reds Are Favored Today
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct. 9 (AP) The betting public has forced Las Vegas bookmakers to change their odds on the World Series and install the Baltimore Orioles as 1110 favorites over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Mars Parachute Tested
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The space agency launched today a 3,052pound payload to an altitude of 57 miles from Wallops Island, Va., in a test of a parachute being developed to land instruments on Mars.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dilemma in Senate Race

title: Space Record Holders From Soviet to Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Two Soviet astronauts, who hold a space endurance record for their 18day, earth orbital flight in June, are to visit the United States this month.

title: BOLIVIAN GENERAL NAMES A CABINET
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 9 Gen. Juan Jos Torres was ap parently secure as President of Bolivia today for the first time since he seized power on Wednesday. He named a Cabi net consisting mostly of mod erate leftists.

title: DUKE HEAD SCORES COLLEGE CRITICS
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9Terry Sanford, president of Duke University and former Gover nor of North Carolina, lashed out today against those in society who turn their con fused resentment against hieher education.

title: FRANCIS PERKINS, MUSIC CRITIC, 72
description: Francis D. Perkins, for many years a music critic and editor of the old New York Herald Tribune, died of a coronary oc clusion on Thursday night. He was 72 years old and lived at 125 Riverside Drive here.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Oct. 9, 1970

title: CAR OUTPUT FIGURES LISTED FOR THE WEEK
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP) Fol lowing are the auto production figures for the week:

title: Off Broadway PrOducers Approve 3Year Contract
description: A tnreeyear contract cover ing working conditions of direc tors and choreographers has been signed by the Society of Stage Directors and Choreog raphers and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Pro ducers, Inc.

title: The Peace Corps Is Unworkable
description: The Peace Corps is now ten years old and still with us, durability being at the moment its most obvious ac complishment. That it has managed to survive the last decadestill traf ficking, as it must, in promises and dreamsis saddening in a way and even somehow obscene. One does not care to be reminded that it was pos sible, not very long ago, to put one's ideals to work by entering the service of the American Government.

title: Goldberg Presses Rockefeller To Lift TV Blackout Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Oct 9  Con vinced that, he has found an excellent campaign issue, Ar thur J. Goldberg scored Gov ernor Rockefeller today for his refusal to debate him face to face on upstate television sta tions.

title: 35 Are Dead or Missing in Puerto Rico Floods
description: SAN JUAN P. R., Oct. 9  Thirtyfive persons have been reported dead or missing in floods and landslides caused by a sevenday downpour in Puerto Rico, the authorities said today.

title: Arbitration Talks in Bronx Building Strike Make Little Headway
description: Hopes for a settlement of the 25dayold strike by Bronx apartmenthouse workers were dashed yesterday when union officials and landlord represen tatives concluded nine hours of meetings without agreeing to submit their dispute to arbitra tion.

title: L.I. Wife Accused of Plot To Murder Her Husband
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Oct. 9 (AP)  The police have arrested a Nassau County housewife and accused her of plotting with another man to kill her hus band, who was found lying on a road with a fractured skull and leg and eye injuries.

title: SUPPLY LINES IN LAOS TARGET OF B52 RAID
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP)The United States concentrated all its B52's on Laos today as nearly 30 of the bombers pounded the enemy supply lines.

title: Equal Rights
description: Women suffer serious and widespread discrimination in many fields of American life. The question for the Senate as it debates the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution, already approved by the House, is not the fact of discrimination but whether a constitutional amendment is the right way to remedy it.

title: REDS HOST TODAY IN SERIES OPENER
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 Base ball will open its 67th World Series tomorrow  and its first ever on artificial grass  when the Baltimore Orioles meet the Cincinnati Reds in the new Riverfront Stadium.

title: CHARLES A. BRIND, A STATE OFFICIAL
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) Dr. Charles A. Brind, retired general counsel to the State Education Department, died Wednesday in Geneva General Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: City Tax Aide Sworn In
description: Mayor Lindsay swore in Her bert Dicker as a member of the city Tax Commission yesterday Mr. Dicker, a 45yearold law yer, succeeds Benjamin G Browdy, who resigned from the $12,250 post last month

title: E. J. ROSENWALD, 68, AD FIRM EXECUTIVE
description: Edward J. Rosenwald, an advertising executive in this city for many years, died yes terday at his home, 1192 Park Avenue. His age was 68.

title: Negotiating Session Scheduled In 4DayOld Strike at The Post
description: The two mediators in the strike by the Newspaper Guild against The New York Post an nounced yesterday that they had scheduled a negotiating session between the two sides, for 5 P.M. today in Automation House, 49 East 68th Street.

title: Mrs. Lois S. Register Remarried
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 9 Mrs. Lois Spreckels Regis ter, granddaughter of the late Adolph Spreckels, founder of the Spreckels Sugar Com pany, was married here today to William A. Steffan of Sacramento. The ceremony was performed in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Chapel by the Rev. John P. Tierney.

title: Soviet Writers Union Criticizes Nobel Prize Given Solzhenitsyn
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 The Soviet Writers Union said today that the awarding of the 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature to Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn was de plorable.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: What Mr. Nixon Could Mean
description: LONDON, Oct. 9 After all the turns of American policy in Vietnam, all the deception of ourselves and others, any new peace plan must face critical scrutiny. President Nixon's initiative has inevitably met, along with praise for the effort, skepticism about its real meaning and its chance of moving the two sides any nearer a settlement.

title: PROBATION ORDER STAYS IN EFFECT
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9  Den ny McLain, the only pitcher to win 31 games in a season in the last 29 years, was reinstated yesterday by Commissioner Bo wie Kuhn and traded to the Washington Senators by the D troit Tigers as part of an eight player exchange.

title: Goodell Seeks to Debate Agnew, Who Appears Cold to the Idea
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9 Wearing a Spiro T. Agnew wrist watch and winning in stant response whenever he mentioned his squabble with the Vice President, Senator Charles E. Goodell campaigned in suburban Westchester Coun ty today.

title: Men's Lobe: Another Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)First it was women's liberation, to fight for equal rights. And now it's Men's Lobe, to fight for the right of male civilian Government workers to wear sideburns down to the ear lobe if that's what they want.

title: HADFIELD SIGNED TO RANGERS PACT
description: Vic Hadfield signed his New York Ranger contract yester day afternoon on the plane that took the club to St. Louis for the team's opening game of the 197071 National Hockey League season against the Blues tonight.

title: Greetings
description: STARRMr. and Mrs. Jacob, 1095 Park Ave., wish all their relatives and friends a very healthy and happy New Year and thank them for their kind New Year wishes.

title: Antiques: From America
description: Fine 18thcentury Ameri can furniture is hard to lo cate in runofthemill an tiques shops, but great pieces have been turning up in shops specializing in Ameri cana.

title: Trevino and Nicklaus Advance To MatchPlay Final in Britain
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 9Lee Trevino demolished Dave Stockton, 7 and 6, and Jack Nicklaus trounced Tony Jack lin, 5 and 4, today to set up, an allAmerican final tomorrow in the Piccadilly world match play golf championship.

title: A Correction
description: The funeral service for Dr. Samuel Standard, professor of clinical surgery at the New York University School of Med icine, will be held tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. at the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. The time was given incorrectly in yesteday's New York Times. Dr. Standard died Thursday at the age of 71 at University Hospital.

title: 3 GERMANSGUILTY OF MISSILE THEFT
description: DUSSELDORF, West Ger many, Oct. 9 (UPI) A West German court convicted three men today of stealing an American Sidewinder missile from an air base in 1967, ship ping to to Moscow as regular airfreight for 483.88 and re ceiving $81,000 from the So viet Union.

title: The Scranton Report: A Critique
description: Alienated intellectuals, observed Prof. Lewis Feuer of the University of Toronto, suffer from the ailment that they have ideas but no power  they regard themselves as an lite fit to rule. It is an alienation stemming from the obstructed will to rule.

title: Led Employes Unit
description: Dr. Brind held something of a record. He served under six, commissioners in the State Ed ucation Department, and held several high positions outside the agency.

title: JOINT UNIT SET UP BY PALESTINIANS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9  A joint military committee to coordinate the moves of the principal Palestine guerrilla groups bras been set up in Am man, according to a spokes man for one of the groups.

title: Queens Courthouse Damaged by Bomb; Warning Is Given
description: A bomb exploded early this morning in a trafficcourt building next to the Queens Branch House of Detention in Long Island City, where prison ers rioted last week and early this week.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO OPEN MICROWAVE FIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Justice Department urged to day that, new common carriers be licensed to compete against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and West ern Union in transmitting specialiied communications by microwave.

title: Symphonic Embrace for Twin Cities
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 9In the history of uneasy symbiotic relationships  Cain and Abel, Jonah and the whale, Gilbert and Sullivan, the Blue and the Graythe pairing of Minneapolis and St. Paul holds a modest but certain place. For more than 120 years me Twin cities have faced one another across the Mississippi River and nursed a sibling rivalry that today is still real and strong, though fading appreciably as the twins find themselves more and more entangled in each other's commercial, so cial and cultural lives.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ExSenator Is Freed Of Bribery Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  A Federal judge dismissed today all five charges of accepting bribes against former Senator Daniel B. Brewster of Mary land on the ground that he was protected by Congression al immunity.

title: Didn't Set Your Hair? Do It in the Car
description: It would seem that every possible accessory had al ready been dreamed up for automobiles. Well, here's a new one: a set of heated curlers to be plugged into the dashboard lighter.

title: Cereal Shipments Halted
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP)The Quaker Oats Company an nounced today that it was vol untarily halting distribution of some cereal shipments because the food had picked up odor and flavor from freshly painted railroad boxcars. The cereal involved is King Vitamin, and the shipments were in the northeastern and some mid western areas. All areas west of the Mississippi, except St. Louis, were not affected, the company said.

title: MARY ALICE SMITH
description: Mary Alice Smith, editor and publisher of Handweaver & Craftsman, a trade journal of the weaving industry, died yes terday of a heart attack in Medical Arts Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 79 Barrow Street.

title: Louis PasteurVallery Radot, French Physician, Dies at 84
description: PARIS, Oct. 9 Prof. Louis PasteurVallery Radot, a dis tinguished physician and mem ber of the French academy, who was a grandson of Louis Pasteur, died here today ap parently of heart failure. He was 84 years old.

title: LUCIEN GOLDMANN, SOCIOLOGIST, IS DEAD
description: PARIS, Oct. 9Lucien Gold mann, the Rumanianborn Marx ist philosopher and sociologist, died here last Saturday at the age of 57.

title: 3 Memphis Realty Concerns Barred From Blockbusting
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 9 (AP) Consent orders forbidding three Memphis real estate con cerns to practice blockbusting in a previously allwhite neigh borhood were entered today in United States District Court in Memphis, the Justice Depart ment announced.

title: City Police Get New Computer To Help in Curbing Car Thefts
description: New scientific techniques were brought to bear this week on one of the nation's major crime problemscar thefts.

title: Nixon Orders F.B.I. Effort to Find Coast Bombers
description: REY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 9 (UPI)President Nixon ordered a new crackdown on terrorist bombings today and pledged vigorous enforcement of the antibombing legislation now nearing final Congressional ap proval.

title: Ivy. League Gets Down to. Brass Tacks
description: The Ivy League begins in earnest, Boston College, Georgia Tech and North Carolina await stern tests, Nebraska faces Missouri, Texas is back on national television, and Jim Plunkett returns for a final shot at Southern California.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert C. Sullivan has been appointed vice president of the corporation law department at the Sperry Rand Corporation.

title: Tray System Keeps Meals at Proper Temperatures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 More than 50 hospitals use insulated trays that are said to keep the patients hot food hot and cold food cold for two hours or more. The Temp  Rite tray and system were patented this week on behalf of Aladdin Indus tries, Inc., Nash ville. Each plastic tray car ries a set of disposable dishes, with the necessary covers, to hold a complete bedside meal. The dish com partments are insulated with plastic foam at the sides so that the main course will not warm the salad and dessert. Little protection is needed at the bottom, as the trays are carted about in stacks, with the hot and cold dishes above others in the same temperature range.

title: Hopes Voiced as G.M. Talks Resume
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9  Bargain ing teams of the United Auto mobile Workers and the Gen eral Motors Corporation talked about wages and costofliving protection today for the first time since the strike began on Sept. 14.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1970

title: Volpe Orders Full Inquiry Into Air Charter Business
description: Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe ordered yes terday a sweeping investigation into the charter airplane business and the adequacy of Federal Aviation Administra tion rules on how charter planes may operate.

title: JEWS IN NEW LEFT SCORED BY RABBIS
description: Yom Kippur, the 24hour ob servance of fasting, selfevalua tion, prayer and repentence, be gan at sundown yesterday.

title: TOP SHELL OFFICERS MOVING TO HOUSTON
description: The Shell Oil Company yes terday announced it was mov ing its executive headquarters from here to Houston.

title: MEFISTOFELF SUNG BY CITY OPERA AGAIN
description: The New York City Opera's spectacular production of Boi to's Mefistofele, with Nor man Treigle's sensational per formance in the title role dazzled yet another audience at the New York State Theater on Thursday night and could prob ably play nightly to packed houses for weeks or months if it were only possible to perform it steadily.

title: Money
description: Friday, Oct. 9, 1970

title: The Public's Business
description: The Office of Science and Technology could hardly have made legislative recommendations more timely and sensible than those in its study on Electric Power and the Environment. The proposed legislation, which the Administration plans to send to the next Congress, would make public utilities and state governments partners in the location of power sites in order to reconcile the need for electric power and the need to preserve our environment'?

title: Upheaval in Jails
description: A hundred years ago, jails were run solely at the discre tion of the wardens, and a prisoner, as a Virginia judge said in 1871, was for the time being, the slave of the state.

title: M. Troisgros Sings of Wines and Women
description: ROANNE, FranceIt is the hour of the aperitif, and the cafes here fill with their regular clients. Occasionally the conversation slows as the habitus scan the arrival of a newcomer.

title: DR. EMANUEL DONHEISERF
description: Dr. Emanuel Donheiser, urological surgeon, who had practiced medicine here 50 years, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 210 West 90th Street.

title: JEAN GIONO DIES; FRENCH NOVELIST
description: PARIS, Oct. 9Jean Giono, one of this century's most suc cessful French novelists, died last night of a heart attack in Manosque, a small city in Pro vence. He was 75 years old.

title: MURPHY IS SWORN, VOWS CRIME FIGHT
description: Patrick V. Murphy, pledging himself to fight crime and cor ruption, was sworn in yester day as New York City's 29th Police Commissioner.

title: MARINE MIDLAND SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a $7billion statewide bank holding company, reported yesterday an 8.6 per cent de cline in operating earnings for the third quarter. It reduced the ninemonth gain to 3 per cent.

title: 3 Panthers Are Sentenced For Having Guns, Powder
description: JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 9 (AP)Three Black Panthers who had been charged with ma chine gunning a Jersey City po lice station in 1968 were sen tenced today on lesser charges.

title: Chapin Predicts Upturn in A.M.C. Fortunes
Israeli Army Maintains School For Its Undereducated Soldiers
description: HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 1  On the slopes of Mount Carmel, in a residential area of this port city, units of the Israeli Army quietly perform one of their thoroughly nonmilitary functions.

title: Jury Tamperer Jailed
description: BUFFALO, Oct 9 (UPI) A reputed Mafia leader, Salvtore Pieri, was sentenced to five years today for tampering with a Federal Court jury during a $300,000 jewel  theft case. He could have received up to 20 years and a $20,000 fine.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week end Oct. 6.

title: Veri and Jamanis, Duo Pianists, Show Buoyancy in Debut
Soft Electoral Voice
description: In a time of continuing violence, when exaggerated rhetoric threatens to drown out reasoned discourse, the even voice of the League of Women Voters especially deserves to be heard. It is a valuable, nonpartisan voice which explains issues and urges responsible participa tion in the electoral process.

title: W. P. GOLDMAN, 95, MEN'S CLOTHIER
description: William P. Goldman, founder and president of William P. Goldman & Bros., Inc., manu facturers of GGG's men's cloth ing died yesterday in Beth Is rael Hospital, after a short ill ness. He was 95 years old and lived at 955 Fifth Avenue.

title: PEACE GROUP GAINS $9,000 AT AUCTION
description: Literary manuscripts, type scripts and autographs, modern first editions, posters and watercolors brought $9,000 on Thursday night at an auction sponsored by Publishers for Peace, a book industry group opposed to the war in Indo china. The proceeds will be used to help elect Congressional candidates who oppose the con flict.

title: 3 Men Killed in Gas Leak At Jersey Sewage Plan
description: KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 9 (AP) Three men were killed today when a gas leak developed as they were transferring sewage from a tank truck to a storage vat.

title: Firebirds Dim Jets, 30 to 26
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 9 (AP) The Pennsylvania Fire birds turned back a late rally by the Bridgeport Jets tonight and posted a 3026 victory in an Atlantic Coast Football League game at Kennedy Sta dium.

title: AGNEW CAUTIONS ABOUT REPRESSION
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 9Vice President Agnew voiced a note of caution tonight about repres sion of political terrorists, warning that it could play into the hands of those who want to destroy the American sys tem.

title: Planetarium Honors Artist Whose Heavens Delight
description: Helmut K. Wimmer has not yet painted pies in his skies, but he has cooked up other stellar fancies: magnets that keep the planets in place, great spinning arrows of gravitational force, a sun god in a chariot, stars suspended on celestial wires.

title: Edmond Michelet Dead at 71; Minister of Culture in France
Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the telephone com pany's time bureau.

title: Carl W. Ackerman, Columbia Dean, Dies at 80
description: Carl W. Ackerman, who, in a quartercentury as dean of the Columbia University Grad uate School of Journalism transformed it from a literary ivory tower to a practical training ground for newsmen, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: STOCKS REGISTER A STEADY DECLINE
description: passed almost every sector ex cept for the gold stocks..

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Bahamas Airways Ends Operation, Citing Recession
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Britishowned Bahamas Airways announced today it had decided to go into liquidation. It called an imme diate halt to operations.

title: Labor Pains in Britain
description: Most Americans will find it incomprehensible that Britain is about to choose sides in a fierce legislative battle over principles of labormanagement relations that have been standard in this country for a third of a century.

title: U.S. Diplomat Returning
description: CAIRO, Oct. 9 (AP)Donald C. Bergus, the ranking United States diplomat in the United Arab Republic, will fly to Wash ington tomorrow for consulta tions, American officials here said today.

title: Sadat Said to Balk Plan For U.A.R. Power Shift
description: The United. Arab Republic's Acting President, Anwar Sadat, backed, by a coalition of left ists, security offiCers and army leaders, has reportedly turned back an attempt by three of Gamal Abdel Nasser's closest associates for a dramatic shift in the Egyptian political sys tem.

title: MRS. SAMUEL C. FISH
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 9 Mrs. Elizabeth Donaldson Fish, a longtime resident of South ampton, L. I., who had been living here since 1956, died to day at the age of 88. She was the widow of the Rev. Samuel C. Fish, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Southamp ton, who died in 1941.

title: Truce: A Jigsaw Puzzle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 South Vietnamese and Amer ican officials are puzzling over the kind of truce President Nixon has suggested for Indo china.

title: Bank in Kentucky Is Closed By State Banking Officials
description: BEREA; Ky., Oct. 9 (UPI) The Berea Bank & Trust Com pany, a familyowned bank with assets of $5million in this midKentucky community, was closed today by State Banking Department officials and de clared insolvent.

title: MARCUS SENTENCED TO YEARFOR BRIBERY
description: James L. Marcus, the city's former Water Commissioner, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to, one year in prison on bribery and conspiracy charges.

title: STOCKS REGISTER A STEADY DECLINE
description: The stock market marched downhill yesterday for the second session in a row after President Nixon disclosed new peace proposals for Indochina on Wednesday.

title: CUDDY CAPTURES TITLE IN U.S. SAIL
Minutemen Chief Sentenced To 10 Years on Arms Counts
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Oct. 9 (AP) Robert DePugh, lead er of the Minutemen organiza tion, was sentenced today to nine concurrent Federal prison terms of 10 years each on nine counts of violating Federal firearms regulations.

title: Separate Senate Inquiry
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 9 (UPI)The Senate Aviation Subcommittee will conduct its own investigation into Federal Aviation Administration regula tions governing chartered air planes, Senator James B. Pear son, Republican of Kansas, said today. Mr. Pearson is a mem ber of the subcommittee.

title: U.S. URGES HANOI TO ACCEPT PLAN OFFERED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.The Nixon Administration publicly urged North Vietnam today to accept President Nixon's new peace plan for Indochina, with the added inducement that most American troops would be out of combat there by May 1.

title: INMATE TESTIFIES ON TATE KILLINGS
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9Mrs. Virginia Castro, a check forger, testified today that Susan Den ise Atkins had spoken to her for hours about the details of the slaying of Sharon Tate, the actress, and five others.

title: Sobell Barred From Travel To Coast to Address Dinner
description: Morton Sobell, who served 17 years for conspiracy to com mit espionage, failed to get per mission yesterday from the United States Court of Appeals to travel to Los Angeles to ad dress a fundraising dinner for The People's World, a radical newspaper.

title: Equity Honors Thompson
description: Representative Frank Thomp son Jr., Democrat of New Jer sey, was made an honorary member of Actors Equity Asso ciation yesterday in recognition of his legislative service in behalf of the arts. A gold mem bership card was presented to the Congressman by Frederick O'Neal, Equity president, at a luncheon in the Belasco Room of Sardi's Restaurant. Brooks Atkinson, former drama critic of The New York Times, was the last person to be so honored by the actors union.

title: SOVIET DISPLAYS FILMS OF SOYUZ 9
description: CONSTANCE, West Ger many, Oct. 9 Never before has the world outside the So viet Union had so vivid an ex perience of Russian space flight as was enjoyed here today by delegates to the International Astronautical Congress.

title: A Few World Series Sinkers
description: The dedicated baseball fan is a man who likes to kid himself. He'll get to a World Series game early, see a ballplayer yawning and take it as a sign of nervousness. He'll see anervelessly relaxed body leaning against the batting cage and con sider it merely feigned indifference. He'll watch an outfielder casually scratching his nose and count it as a tic. He's wrong. In tact, what looks like boredom on behalf of the people involved in the World Series is most often just that.

title: Probable Batting Order For First Series Game
description: UmpiresKen Burkhart, NL, plate; John Flaherty, AL, first base; Tony Venzon, NL, second base; Bob Stewart, AL, third base; Billy Williams, NL, left field foul line; Emmett Ashford, AL, rightfield foul line.

title: Neversink, Dry Since 1935, Faces New Bid by the Wets
description: NEVERSINK, N. Y., Oct. 9 In 1935, two years after Prohibition ended, the voters here outlawed the sale of beer and hard liquor. Three times since then they have rejected proposals to end that ban.

title: North Penn Gas Net Slips
description: The North Penn Gas Com pany reported yesterday a de cline in net income for the fiscal year ended June 30 de spite higher operating reven ues and gas sales. Gas sales rose to $27.2 billion cubic feet from 25.5 billion a year ago while total operating revenues reached $15.5million, up from the $14.3million of a year ago. However, net income dropped to $600,609, or $1.33 a share, from $704,225, or $1.56 a share in fiscal 1969.

title: 3 Tennessee Students Wounded By Gunfire in Wake of a Protest
description: MORRISTOWN, Tenn., Oct. 9 Three black students were wounded today when shots were fired from a passing car into the administration build ing at Morristown Junior Col lege.

title: The Ballet: Arpino's Topical Trinity
description: One of the most enjoyable works ever presented by the City Center Joffrey Ballet has arrived at the New York City Center. It is Gerald Arpino's Trinity, it is pure fun, and probably Mr. Arpino's most considerable work to date.

title: KOSYGIN FORGOES VISIT TO THE U.N.
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9Soviet of ficials said today that Moscow had decided against, sending Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin to the United Nations for the 25th anniversary session this month because of what they called an officially inspired antiSoviet campaign in the United States.

title: Baptist Official Resigns To Assume Paris Pulpit
description: The Rev. D. Edwin H. Tul ler, general secretary of the 1.5millionmember American Baptist Convention since 1959, has resigned his post to become minister of the his toric American Church in Paris.

title: CHAMPAGNE LISTS FIELD OF 16 TODAY
description: Sixteen hopefuls were listed overnight to take part in to day's $125,000 added Cham pagne Stakes at Belmont Park. If all start, the purse for the onemile fixture for 2yearolds will be worth $205,025 and the winner's share a whopping $145,025. The stakes is the richest on the New York Rac ing Association agenda.

title: COAST BOMBING TIED TO REVOLUTIONARIES
description: SANTA BARBARA. Calif., Oct. 9A revolutionary group in the nearby university community of Isla Vista said today it had com mitted the bombing yesterday of the Santa Barbara National Guard Armory.

title: Books of The Times
description: One of the beguiling items in James Trager's catchascatchcan history of food down the ages is the American allegiance to beef. This shouldn't come as a complete surorise. Americans generally haven't given much thought to food, judging at least by American cuisine and the service accompanying it. No American worker or stockbroker is likely to drool at the idea of an up and coming dinner of sweetbreads and vintage wine any more than he will anticipate the pleasures of eating ground glass. For most Americans the food of the gods is a large steak (or larger) accompa nied by a raft of French fried potatoes topped off by apple pie and coffee. The grace note is in the salad curled cozily in a wooden bowl. Still, the statistics are im pressive. The per capita consumption of beef, according to the author, is 114 pounds a year in contrast to the consumption of only four pounds of lamb and four pounds of veal.

title: The Leader of independent Fiji
description: SUVA, Fiji, Saturday, Oct. 10  Among the emerging leaders in the South Pacific islands, Chief Sir Kamisese Kapaiwai Tumacilai Mara is a towering figure, politically as well as physically.

title: Nixon Aide Tells Senate Panel Present Plan Is Unacceptable
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate Finance Committee, meeting in violation of the Sen ate's rules, began a brief hear ing today on the trade bill and heard President Nixon's chief trade negotiator say that the Administration cannot accept the entire bill as is that was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: A Synopsis of 12th District Race
description: POPULATION: More than 400,000, mixed ethnically. Blacks, who account for less than 5 per cent of the total, are heavily concentrated in cities such as Union and Plainfield, the scene of racial disturbances.

title: Market Place:
description: Ask an embezzler why he didn't rob someone instead of taking money from his employer and he may react indignantly, What do you think I am, a thief?

title: MET'S FIRST TOSCA TO BE MISS CRESPIN
description: Regine Crespin will take the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's first performance this season of Puccini's Tosca, which is to be given Nov. 7. Appearing with Miss Crespin will be Placido Domingo as Cavarodossi, Tito Gobbi as Scarpia and Fernando Corena as the Sacristan. Francesco Mo linariPradelli will conduct.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: FRIDAY'S GAMES Springfield 5, Hershey 4. Providence 4, Quebec 2. Baltimore 5 Rochester 3.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Drive to Stop Lead Poisoning Begins
description: Based on a new public awareness, a fragmented but growing movement to eradi cate lead poisoning has begun around the country.

title: CHARGE OF LAXITY IS DENIED BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation, has denied that the agency carried out a superficial investigation of the killing of three Negroes and the wound ing of 27 others near the South Carolina State College campus at Orangeburg in 1968.

title: Adams Questions Marijuana Penalties
description: LYONS, N.Y., Oct. 9  Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conserva tive party candidate for Gov ernor, said today that the pen alties against marijuana might be altogether too harsh.

title: Lundy Is Newcomer Facing Strength of Mrs. Dwyer
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 9 Outside the mammoth shopping centers and inside the carpeted living rooms of the 12th Con gressional District, an energetic and handsome political new comer is taking on a redoubt able Republican grandmother who has the habit of trouncing her opponents.

title: Decentralized Legal Aid To Poor Scored by Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  An attempt to decentralized control of the legal services program of the Office of Eco nomic Opportunity was termed an antiblack, facist move to day by.a spokesman for Negro lawyers, involved in the pro gram.

title: SOYBEANS PRICES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Soybeans futures rose yester day on the Chicago Board of Trade but grain futures there were lower or irregular. Soy bean oil and meal future prices were higher but iced broilers futures declined.

title: Facts on World Series
description: Participants  Baltimore Orioles American League, vs. Cincinnati Reds, National League.

title: Governor Calls Goldberg a Dupe for Democrats
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day stepped up his direct at tacks on his Democratic oppo nent, Arthur J. Goldberg, by charging that Mr. Goldberg was a dune for Democrats.

title: TV: Big Bands Return on Channel 13
description: The era of the big band, once the dominant force in popular music before film houses dropped stage shows, hotels economized and rock took the youthful fancy, was appreciatively and winningly remembered last night in the debut of Homewood on Channel 13 of the public broadcasting network. The program originated at KCET, Los Angeles.

title: A Million Will Buy A Nice New Shop, Dr. Gucci Learns
description: Mama Mia! the distinguishedlooking Italian ex claimed, his hands waving wildly in the air. I have spent $1million on our new New York shop, and my two brothers haven't forgiven me yet.

title: Iona Club Eleven Victor Over Fairfield by 318
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 9Iona College observed home coming tonight with a 318 foot ball victory over Fairfield. The Gaels piled up a total offense of 406 yards compared with the Stags' 105.

title: Dumping Study Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 19 (AP)  The Treasury Department an nounced today it was acting against alleged dumping on the United States market of Japanese glass products and British ceramic tile at less than fair market value.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX ROSE LAST MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The pace of, inflation in the key industrial sector of the econ omy did not slacken at all in September, the Labor Depart ment's final estimate of whole sale prices showed today.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Todayat Cincinnati, 1 P.M.

title: Dr. Frank FieldF.Y.I.
description: BEMIDJI, Minn., Oct. 9 (AP) Snow forced postponement today of tomorrow's Northern Intercollegiate Conference foot ball game between the Univer sity of Minnesota at Norris and Bemidji State until Monday.

title: Killing of Hijacker Is Ruled Lawful Homicide in London
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Diversion of Port Funds Termed Payoff by Koch
Civil Service Orders End of Loyalty Oath Oil Federal Forms
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 9 (AP) The Civil Service Commission ordered Federal agencies today to cross off the loyalty oath that still appears on a form each new Federal employe must sign.

title: Young Lottery Winner Explains His Absence
description: Gregorio Contreras Pere des, the winner of the $100, 000 second prize in the state's milliondollar lottery, said yesterday that he had not yet collected his money because he wanted to like you , cool it awhile.

title: OVERWEIGHT MALOY IS PLACED ON BLOCK
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (UPI) Mike Maloy, the No. 1 draft choice of the Pittsburgh Con dors of the American Basket ball Association, was offered for sale tonight by General Manager Marty Blake. Blake said the only club to show in terest was the New York Nets.

title: Lipizzan Stallions Come to the Garden
description: Fortytwo of the most enchanting performers you'll ever see anywhere put on a beautiful display of talent and taste at Madison Square Garden last night. These horses18 Lipizzans, 4 An dalusians, 6 Arabians, 12 Al binos and 2 quarterhorses really have it in the show that arrived last night and will run through Oct. 12.

title: Background on the 13th District
description: POPULATIONThe most populous Congressional Dis trict in New Jersey, with an estimated 450,000 residents. Ethnic concentration is Irish, Italian and Polish, with blocs of Jewish, Spanishspeaking, German and black voters. The district is one of the most highly industrialized of any in the country, with re fineries, utilities, shipping and rail complexes.

title: Iranian Mane With 44 Hijacked to Baghdad
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, Oct. 10 (AP)A Boeing 727 jet of Iran National Airlines with 44 passengers and crew members aboard was hi jacked today and ordered to Baghdad, officials here said.

title: State Dinners Away From the Capital Draw a Chiding
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Carolyn Hagner Shaw, whose annual Social List of Wash ington, D. C., decidessemi officially at leastwho is in and who is out of the capi tal's social circle, yesterday strongly criticized President Nixon for holding state din ners away from the White House.

title: Mrs. Cudone Wins 3d Title In Seniors Golf by 8 Shots
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP)  Mrs. Carolyn Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S.C., won her third consecutive United States Golf Association senior women's amateur golf championship today, a record. She carded a 78 for a three round total of 231.

title: Stans Sees Export Gains
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP)  Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans predicted to day the United States would export $3billion more goods than it imports this year. But he warned that foreign compe tition and trade barriers were increasing and threaten a major impact on our economy and on our role in the world we serve.

title: SIMPSON TROTTER TAKES 2 EVENTS
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9  Favored Timothy T., victimized by a traffic jam that messed up the first heat of the 74th Kentucky Futurity, survived ninthplace finish and trotted off with the next two onemile dashes to capture harness rac ing's oldest major stakes to day. For this efforts, the son of Ayres and Flicka Frost won $30,540.40 of the gross purse of $76.351.

title: Ford Raises 1971 Prices Again; Average Increase Is Put at $14
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9The Ford Motor Company today raised prices on its 1971 cars again, the second increase in a month.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS TRADING EASES
description: Declines outnumbered ad vances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by more than a twotoone ratio as the list moved steadily downward throughout most of the session in slower trading.

title: The Politics of Crime
description: In an atmosphere thick with hypocrisy and fear, members of Congress are rushing to get themselves on record against crime before they face the voters another three weeks.

title: The Defense Won't Rest Against These Men Tonight
Rights Groups and Labor Split on Job Agency Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 9Civil rights organizations and organ ized labor appeared split today over whether to support legis lation designed to strengthen the enforcement powers of the Equal Employment Opportu nity Commission.

title: Board at Rutgers U. Rejects Proposal For Coed College
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 9After two years of con troversy, Rutgers, University's board of governors today re jected a recommendation by the Rutgers College faculty that the 204yearold allmale unit be made coeducational. The vote was 10 to 1.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9The Epic of Denny McLain, star pitcher, cocktail lounge organist, private pilot and failed bookmaker, a story that just might contain less than meets the eye, took a happy turn today. The commissioner of baseball, in his third major news conference this year on the subject, announced that McLain had been rein stated, and was now the property of the Washington Senators. In an unfortunate introductory phrase, Bowie Kuhn said that a psychiatric report, in a nutshell, de clared that McLain was not mentally ill, only un der emotional stress, and a change of location was suggested.

title: Art: Vitality in the Pictorial Structure
description: Although it is no longer me unquestioned darling of the sophisticated art public, the art of painting nonetheless continues to flourish in inter esting ways. The death of painting, predicted and even proclaimed with such regu larity by all manner of artists, critics and ideologues, re mains a figure of speech rather than a cultural or esthetic fact.

title: Indian Bus Plunge Kills 42
description: SIMLA. India, Oct. 9 (Reu ters)Fortytwo people were killed and 10 injured today when a bus plunged off a mountain road into a 200foot ravine in the Chamba district of northern India today.

title: STOCKS CLOSE OFF ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices on the London stock exchange closed lower yester day despite a minor rally that helped many issues to recover from opening lows. Trading was light.

title: Burlington to Consolidate
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., will consolidate its retail fabrics division with that of Klopman Mills, Inc., a subsidiary. The combined organization will be under the direction of James Ritchie who has headed the Klopman unit and will be known as the KlopmanBurling ton Retail Fabrics division.

title: M'LAIN IS READY FOR A NEW START
description: TAMPA, Fla, Oct 9 (AP) Denny McLain, the controver sial Detroit Tigers pitcher who was traded to the Washington Senators today, called the trade a chance to start over.

title: NIXON AIDE FAILS TO DISSUADE I.R.S.
ExMinister Seeks to Return
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (AP)Antonio Arguedas, a former Interior Minister of Bolivia who was charged with treason after he defected to Cuba, has request ed a visa to return to Bolivia, the Havana radio said today. Mr. Arguedas was credited with delivering the diary of Ernesto, Che Guevara to Cuba after the guerrilla leader was killed by the Bolivian Army.

title: Embittered Coloreds of Capetown Must Make Way for Whites
Berio Sinfonia, Expanded, Is Given by Philharmonic
description: One of the more success ful works commissioned by the New York Philharmonic for its 125th anniversary sea son was Luciano Berio's Sin fonia, which had its premiere on Oct. 10, 1968. At that time it was in four move ments, but the composer added a fifth last year and in its new version it was given its first New York perform ance by the orchestra in Phil harmonic Hall on Thursday night.

title: Discount Rates on Bills Mixed At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Treasury bill rates were mixed at today's auction compared with last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: ACCORD IN CHILE ASSURES ALLENDE OF WINNING VOTE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9 Chile's leftwing parties and her major moderate party reached a broad agreement today that in effect assured the installa ition of Dr. Salvador Allende, a Marxist, as President.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: COMMENT

title: Mrs. Molfetta Is Wed on L.I.
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 9 Mrs. Margaret Earle Salant Molfetta, daughter of Robert Stephen Salant, chairman of the board of Salant & Salant, Inc., New York apparel man ufacturers, was married here this evening to Thomas Root Vickery of Brookville.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Friday, Oct. 9, 35th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Rogers Denounces Denial by Moscow Of Suez Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Secretary of State William P. Rogers accused the Soviet Union today of using stri dent rhetoric reminiscent of coldwar days in its denial that it had participated in any violation of the Middle East ceasefire agreement.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9 (UPI)  Warren Armstrong, A.B.A. rookie of the year two seasons ago, was dimissed from the Kentucky Colonels squad today for disciplinary reasons.

title: WPIX QUESTIONED ON A 1968 REPORT
description: The Federal Communications Commission and lawyers repre senting Forum Communications, Inc., persisted yesterday with attempts to find out the source of a November, 1968, audio news report from Caracas, Venezuela, which was men tioned unexpectedly during the WPIX license hearings this week.

title: Fiji Raises the Flag of Independence After 96 Years of Rule by British
description: SUVA, Fiji, Saturday, Oct. 10 The South Pacific islands of Fiji became an independent country this morning, ending 96 years of British colonial rule.

title: Mrs. Robinson Fund Set Up at City College
description: Mrs. Robinson, a character played by Anne Bancroft in the popular movie, The Grad uate, has now had a scholar ship fund at City College named after her.

title: Clearing House Association Appoints a New President
description: The New York Clearing House Association yesterday elected William S. Renchard, Chairman of the Chemical Bank, as president to succeed R. E. McNeill Jr., chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Walter B. Wriston, chairman of the First National City Bank, was elected chair man of the Clearing House Committee.

title: Market Summary
description: Friday. Oct. 9, 1970

title: AUTO PRICE LISTS FACE F.T.C. CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Federal Trade Commission has drafted regulations designed to end what it said was the auto mobile industry practice of list ing prices for new cars that do not accurately reflect the cost to the consumer.

title: NIXON TV ADDRESS HELD UNPOLITICAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Department of Justice ruled to day that corporations that sponsored rebroadcasts of Pres ident Nixon's recent speech on campus unrest did not violate the Federal Corrupt Practices Act, which forbids corporate contributions to political cam paigns.

title: Parking Ban Lifted for Day
description: Traffic Commissioner Theo dore Karagheuzoff said that alternate side of the street parking regulations would be suspended for the Yom Kippur holiday today. Other parking regulations, including the use of meters, remain in effect.

title: Amex Will Help Robinson Customers
description: The American Stock Ex change, while disclaiming any legal or financial responsibility, agreed yesterday to assume role in helping the customers of Robinson & Co., an insol vent brokerage house involved in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Italian Senate Approves Bill Establishing Divorce
description: ROME, Oct. 9Despite op position from the Roman Cath olic Church; Italy's Senate voted today to legalize divorce for the first time in the history of this nation. The vote was 164 to 150.

title: Berlin Talks Are Slowed As Soviet Stiffens Stand
description: BERLIN, Oct. 9  The Big Four Powers met today on means of improving the situa tion of Berlin, but the talks slipped into low gear again after a momentary Sovietin spired acceleration, according to several Western informants.

title: GUARD IS KILLED IN BANK ROBBERY
description: A 59yearold bank guard guard was killed and an al was killed and an alleged hold up man critically wounded yes terday in an exchange of shots in a branch of the Dry Dock Savings Bank at 518 Seventh Avenue at 38th Street.

title: $16.7Billion Military Program Is Approved by Paris Deputies
STIRLING HOMEX SHOWS INCREASE
description: The Stirling Homex Corpora tion, the nation's leader in modular housing, reported yes terday for the year ended July 31 net income of $2,035,189, or 24 cents a share, an increase of 88 per cent over the $1,082, 481, or 13 cents a share, earned in the previous fiscal year. Sales rose 117 per cent to $22,554,068 from the $10, 389,051 volume last year.

title: Gallagher's Backers Confident He Will Defeat G.O.P.
3 IN BRANDT'S BLOC JOIN THE OPPOSITION
description: BONN, Oct. 9 The yearold Social Democraticled Govern ment of West Germany ap peared to be heading for a crisis today as the opposition Christian Democrats accepted three defectors from the Free Democratic party, junior part ner in Chancellor Willy Brandt's coalition.

title: ADOLPH ZUBER
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Soon to Bow on Dec. 16
description: Soon, a new musical about four young rock musicians and how their intense drive for suc cess affects them, will be presented at the 499seat Ritz Theater on West 48th Street on Dec. 16 by Bruce W. Stark and Sagittarius Productions, Inc. The authors of the original story are Scott Fagan, Joe Kookoolis and Robert Green wald. Mr. Fagan also has pro vided the lyrics and Mr. Koo koolis the music.

title: Linda C. Rees, David Wallace Wed in Capital
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Voter Survey Uses Phone in Gathering Statewide Opinions
description: The New York Times/Yankel ovich Survey of voter atti tudes in the 1970 state elec tions for Governor and Senator is based on a continuing series of interviews conducted by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., one of the nation's largest social research concerns.

title: Governor Proposes Widespread Curbs On Excessive Noise
description: Governor Rockefeller said in a position paper yesterday that if reelected he would pro pose statewide zoning on per missible noise levels.

title: WILDLIFE REFUGE LIMITS VISITORS
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L.I. Oct. 10 The gates are open to only 50 visitors a day at the Target Rock National Wildlife Refuge, but still large crowds trY to gain entry to the quiet 80 acres on Long Island's North Shore.

title: Louise Dorsey Hemingway Is Wed
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., Oct. 10 Miss Louise Dorsey Hem ingway and Francis Harbert Statton were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Edwin Lincoln in the First Congregational Church. A reception was given at the home here of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Clayton Hemingway Jr.

title: MUSEUM ACQUIRES 18,000 BUTTERFLIES
description: The American Museum of Natural History has acquired what it describes as a magnif icent collection of more than 18,000 butterflies from East Africa for public exhibition.

title: The Rediscovery Of Elvis
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: Market Reflects Hopes for 1971
description: FINANCIAL markets continue to gaze rather opti mistically across the bleak valley of the economy to the verdant hills of 1971.

title: Nijinsky in the Arc: An IllPlanned Voyage
description: PARIS, Oct. 10Sassafras, the colt that defeated Ni jinsky in the Prix l'Arc de Triomphe last Sunday, must be one of the luckiest thor oughbreds in many years of racing.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe: The Patrician Stance As Esthetic Principle
description: WANDERING through the Georgia O'Keeffe retrospective at the Whitney Museum with your receptors wide open and your analytical channels blocked off, you would be likely to think that this artist, whoever she is (you would be blocked off in that channel also) was someone who had made some very neat adapta tions of various successful styles of the 1950's and 1960's in her own highly re fined and slightly removed manner. She would seem to have looked at Clyfford Still's outsize abstractions, apparently derived from sunset clouds stood on end and painted with maximum insensitivity, perceived that what they needed was a bit of discipline and reduction to rea sonable dimensions, and corrected their flaws. Feeling comparable exaggerations In Helen Frankenthaler's stained acre age, she would seem to have reduced these canvases also to a scale commen surate_with their content, turning them into watercolor sketches the size of a handkerchief.

title: American Notebook
description: James Baldwin is back in Paris after a 13year sojourn in the United States. A friend of ours ran into Mr. Baldwin in a Latin Quarter bistro the other day, and the reex patriated writer ticked off busy schedule of projects in the works or upcoming.

title: Trash: Just Like Ruby and Dick?
description: MOVIES, especially American m o v i e s (which receive no financial aid through government subsidies of one sort or another), are like an alysands. If you watch themand listen to theft long en ough, they inevitably tell you the way things are, with gestures, attitudes and moods that often have absolutely nothing to do with what they think is really on their minds. This is true of good movies (Catch22, Five Easy Piec es) and bad (Airport, R.P.M.), and sometimes, most spectacularly, with in between movies like Trash, Paul Morrissey's second fea ture (his first was Flesh in 1968) now at the Cinema II. Trash simply could not have been made in any time or place but Spiro Agnew's America, which, in effect, the movie celebrates.

title: ALABAMA DEFEATS VANDERBILT, 3511
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 10 (AP) Buddy Seay sprinted 93 yards with the secondhalf kickoff as Alabama defeated Vanderbilt, 3511, today in Southeastern Conference game.

title: United Nations Is 25 Years Old
description: THE United Nations, cel ebrating its 25th anni versary, is being hon ored postally by many nations. A number of issues are forthcoming, including single United States stamp and two from the world or ganization itself that will be released in New York on Nov. 20.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to OXford 53311 until 11 P.M. in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark. (201) MArket 33900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) IVanhoe 36660: Commack (516) 5435400; Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: 5,000 Children Evacuated From Biafra in Civil War Will Be Repatriated From Gabon and Ivory Coast
description: GENEVA, Oct. 10  The repatriation of 5,000 children, who were evacuated from the breakaway state of Biafra to refugee centers in Gabon and the Ivory Coast at the height of the Nigerian civil war, will begin by the end of October.

title: 3 Iranians Arrested After Hijacking Jet
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 10 (AP)Three Iranians forced an Iranian airliner to fly to Bagh dad today, shot and wounded a steward and then were ar rested by the Iraqi police. The plane later returned to Iran.

title: Letters
description: PAT, YES; JUDITH, NO

title: Red Cross Curtailing Relief
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Musicians Fund Lists Luncheon As First Benefit
description: The Musicians Emergency Fund, which provides music therapy for hospitalized vet erans and hospitalized chil dren, will open its fall benefit season Oct. 27 with a lunch eon and fashion show of the Madame Grs Collection in the Coronet Room at the Pierre.

title: BIG HEALTH GAINS FOR LATINS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 The Alliance for Progress has been a tremendous success in im proving health standards in Latin America and the Carib bean, according to a Pan Ameri can Health Organization leader.

title: Bloomfield Wins, 13 to 7, From Clifton
description: Bloomfield scored two first half touchdowns on passes and upset previously unbeaten and unscored upon Clifton, 137, yesterday for its first victory.

title: Scots Hold 6 Seamen In an Apparent Mutiny
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland, Oct. 10 (UPI) The police arrested six seamen from a Scottish trawler when it docked today after an apparent mutiny.

title: In the Middle of Everything
description: CAIROFrance's President Pompi dou is less grandiloquent, less re nowned, more pragmatic and more modest than his great predecessor, de Gaulle, but in a distinctly less flashy way he is continuing the latters diplo matic precepts. The principal among these is to keep simultaneously in the main ring of as many circuses as possible.

title: Marriages
description: FREEMANGRAZMess Barbara Ann Graz, daughter of Mrs. Michael Joseph Graz and the late Mr. Graz, was married to Dr. Paul Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Freeman, on October 2, 1970, at St. Pat rick's Church, Huntington, N.Y. The bride is a teacher in the New York City School System. She Is a graduate of St. John's University and received her master's de gree from Queens College. Dr. Freeman was graduated from Queens College and The Downstate Medical Center. He interned in Medicine at Kings County Hospital and was a resident in psychiatry at Creedmore State Hospital. He is a graduate of The New York School of Psychiatry and was Supervising Psychiatrist at Creedmore State Hospital. Dr. Freeman is currently in pri vate practice In Huntington, N.Y. A honey moon cruise to the Caribbean is planned for the winter.

title: Complex Maneuvers Behind The Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York told the House Small Business Com mittee last week that the Fed eral Governmenti.e., the Nixon Administrationapparently had no strategy for dealing either with the prospective fuel crisis this winter or the nation's long term needs.

title: Unbeaten Michigan Routs Purdue, 290, Tallying 23 Points in Last Period
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct 10 (AP)Seventhranked Michigan exploded for 23 points in the fourth quarter today to rout Purdue, 290, in the Big Ten opener for both teams.

title: BLACK LEADER HITS SHOOTING OF POLICE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The head of the Black Silent Majority Committee deplored today the shooting of police men by militants and called on Negroes to cooperate with au thorities to apprehend the as sailants.

title: The Ballet: Arpino's Topical Trinity
description: One of the most enjoyable works ever presented by the City Center Joffrey Ballet has arrived at the New York City Center. It is Gerald Arpino's Trinity, it is pure fun, and probably Mr. Arpino's most considerable work to date.

title: A Virus Helps Advance Genetic Control
description: WASHINGTON  Viruses are among man's worst enemies, yet within the last year, at least three efforts have been made to enlist them as tools to help cure the incurable.

title: Faces at the Races: At 5 Francs or at $2, the PariMutuel Windows Open Onto a Cross Section of Society
description: There was a splash of color and fashion at Longchamp race course in Paris last Sunday but beneath the bowlers and toppers and within the maxis and the midis there beat the hearts of true racetrackers. It could have been Belmont or Atlantic City or Happy Val ley in Hong Kong or Hobby Horse Hall in Nassaubut it was Paris on the day of the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe and the world was, especially for winners, young and gay.

title: Making a fortune was easier than giving it away
description: Carnegie was the most interesting of the great late19thcentury Ameri can industrialists because he was the most complex, and, while not quite an intellectual, surely the most re flective. If we cannot any longer acclaim him as a hero in the collo quial sense, neither can we dismiss him as a villain or a clownthough there were times when he was villainous or clownish. In him the virtues and vices of the American selfmade man of his time were so pronounced that he comes through as a symbolic, largerthanlife figure and therefore something of a hero in the classic sense.

title: Facts on World Series
description: Participants  Baltimore Orioles, American League, vs. Cincinnati Reds, National League.

title: Squatters Cast Doubt On Housing Plans
description: The squatters movement in New York City has failed to gain the mo mentum that some observers forecast when it began last spring, and appears to have leveled off at about 200 fami lies in buildings within Manhattan.

title: Miss Caroline Jones to Be a Bride
description: Miss Caroline Jones, a former correspondent for the Fidelity Research and Man agement Company in Boston, and Thomas Painter Cle phane, a former general partner in the Boston Equity Management Company there, plan to be married in December.

title: Gromyko to Visit Britain
description: LONDON Oct. 10 (AP)  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will make a threeday official visit to Britain starting Oct. 26 for talks with the Foreign Sec retary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, the Foreign Office announced today.

title: Police Tear Gas Explodes In an Arsenal at Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 10 (AP) A defective tear gas grenade exploded in the Police Depart ment arsenal early today caus ing a chain reaction among other stored grenades and the evacuation of the building by staff members and prisoners.

title: Gardens
description: IN THIS fast moving world with so many demands on one's time, people are looking for house plants that are easy to grow  tough plants that will stand neglect, plants for room dividers and other sunless places. Instead of the same old philodendrons and pothos, why not try something new?

title: Marijuana Survey Shows Average Age Of Smugglers Is 25
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 10A pro file of the average marijuana smuggler, drawn from United States files, has been presented to the general assembly of Interpol, the International Crim inal Police Organization, which devotes a third of its time now to drug cases.

title: Article 3  No Title

title: Groton's First Half Aids 308 Victory Over St. George's

Cornelius S. Thomas. He was assisted by the Rev. George Poffenbar ger 2d.

title: Postel Cites Filled Jails And Inactivity in Courts
description: City Councilman at Large Robert L Postel of Manhattan said today that the city's Criminal Courts were almost inactive this week because the Department of Correc tions failed to produce 80 per cent of the prisoners in its charge scheduled for trials.

title: Rangers Lose, 31, To Blues in Opener
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10The New York Rangers, apparently play ing for fun, beat the St. Louis Blues three times in preseason games. But here tonight, in the expanded arena when it count led, the Blues topped the New Ynrk club. 31.

title: A Word to the wise  From a Criminologist
description: FEW THINGS can sour a vacation faster than theft. The vacationer whose re laxed day ends with the discovery that his wallet is missing is likely to wonder if getting anywhere is half the fun.

title: VILLANOVA DEFEATS BUFFALO TEAM, 177
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 10 (UPI) Daryl Woodring threw touch down passes of 9 and 47 yards to Luke Soloman and Mika Si ani, and Duane Holland booted a 25yard field goal to give the Villanova Wildcats a 177 foot ball triumph over Buffalo to day.

title: Bulbs for Blossoms Indoors
description: SPRINGBLOOMING bulbs can be planted in dishes filled with pebbles and forced to bloom during the winter months. This is easy to do because bulbs con tain buds and the food needed to make them grow.

description: in these two short books. They de scribe in some detail the everyday, sometimes boring, often hectic, al ways real tempo of one of the most interesting aspects of hospital life, the emergency room.

description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. L, Oct. 10.Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Barone of Old Brookville and Point Lookout of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vivian Vincen zina Barone, to Ralph James Dewey of Locust Valley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Dewey of Newark, Del.

description: CONSTANCE, West Germany Although the United States and the Soviet Union still look at one another across a vast gulf of political, military and ideo logical differences, there are sit uations where failure to cooper ate is so patently absurd that the gulf can be bridged.

description: Saturday, Oct. 10. 36th day. Weather clear, track fast.

description: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Oct. 10  Miss MargaretLeigh (Mimi) Spencer and Brice Eldridge were married here this afternoon in Old St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, which has been attended by members of the bride's fam ily for 10 generations. Her maternal ancestors, Maskel Bacon and John Eno, were founding members of the parish.

description: Fiscal myopia by conservative members of the Senate Finance Committee and perfectionism by its liberal members have inflicted a damagingperhaps even fatal blow on President Nixon's imaginative proposal for reforming the present disastrous welfare system.

description: Campus unrest has blossomed as a major issue in political campaigns around the country, particularly in large.r states where there is a clear choice between a liberal and a con servative.

title: PARENTS WILL END BOYCOTT AT P.S. 11
description: Parents of Public School 11, the Bronx, have decided to end a boycott that was started on Sept. 14 and return their chil dren to school on Tuesday.

title: BOSTON U. RALLIES FOR 1310 TRIUMPH
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 10 A great effort by the defen sive platoon and two lastpe riod field goals by Fred Rapo port today enabled Boston Uni versity to defeat the Univer sity of Massachusettes, 1310.

title: Mich. State Harriers Win
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 10 (AP)Michigan State took 10 of the top 11 places today to defeat Ohio State, 1746, in a dual crosscountry meet. Randy Kilpatrick, a sophomore, took first place with a time of 26 minutes 6.6 seconds for the fivemile course. Greg Kilpan finished fourth for Ohio State.

title: TV: Big Bands Return on Channel 13
description: The era of the big band, once the dominant force in popular music before film houses dropped stage shows, hotels economized and rock took the youthful fancy, was appreciatively and winningly remembered On Friday in the debut of Homewood on Channel 13 of the public broadcasting network. The program originated at KCET, Los Angeles.

title: Discovering H. Lyman Saen
description: THE history of European and American avant garde in the early years of this century is so familiar to us in the rou tine chronologies of museum collections, art books and col lege courses that we tend, mistakenly, to believe there are no more discoveries to be made. And then, out of the blue, we are obliged to confront a new name, a new career and a new oeuvre of whose existence we had nev er had an inkling. Such ex periences are admittedly rare, but we are now being offered one in the exhibition of paintings by Henry Lyman Sayen at the National Col lection of Fine Arts in Wash ington. It is the kind of ex hibition that, on a certain modest scale, will require some revisions in the stand ard histories of modern American art.

title: Buffalo:
description: Nearly 30,000 visitors, some from as far away as India, Africa and South America have stopped by so far to inspect two model homes that have been erect ed in the Emslie Gardens section of this city.

title: CHAVEZ UNION SIGNS WITH TWO GROWERS
description: SALINAS, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI)Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Organizing Com mittee signed labor contracts with two major California growers this week.

description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 10 (UPI) Marty Januszkiewicz, a sophomore fullback, scored three touchdowns today to pace Syracuse to its first vic tory of the season, 237, over Maryland.

description: I don't care what your theory says, that's not the Way it works in real life, the student told the profes sor in no uncertain terms.
