From midnight on, and sometimes until dawn, the visitor knew he'd find everyone wide awake at Les Halles, located for his convenience (and to the traffic department's desperation) in the dead center of the French capital.

title: Royal Harmony Scores
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct 10 (AP) Royal Harmony, owned by T. F. Devereux, made a bold stretch move and won the $27, 425 Fayette Handicap today at Keeneland.

title: Suddenly, We're No Longer Looking at a Play
description: THE theater loves being served and hates be ing used. And when ever a playwright sets out to use it for his own purposes, however highmind ed, however moral, without first attending to its needs and comforts, the theater al most always plays a vengeful little trick on him. It leads him into using language that gives the show away.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 10 (AP)  Lionel Rose, the former world bantamweight champion, pounded his way to a unanimous 10round decision tonight over Ishimatsu Suzuki, a Japanese lightweight.

title: Manhattan Tops Seton Hall In Soccer on Late Goal, 10
description: Bob Schimpf, a junior who earned allMetropolitan honors as a sophomore, scored his seventh goal of the Fall season in the third period to lead Manhattan to a 10 Metropoli tan Conference soccer victory over Seton Hall yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

description: Special to The New York Times

title: PHILLIPS DIRECTS LONGHORN DRIVES
description: DALLAS, Oct. 10An alert Texas defense set up four touchdowns with three fumble recoveries and an interception today and Eddie Phillips guided the secondranked Longhorns to a 419 victory over Okla homa. It was Texas's 24th tri umph in a row.

title: Bolivian Marxist Students Oust Police Aides and Spread Terror
A Day's Racing Set by Monmouth Hunt
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Oct. 10 The Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association will stage its 40th steeplechase meeting here next Saturday at Woodland Farm, Mrs. Amory L. Haskell's estate. Gates will be open to the pub lic at 11 A.M., and post time for the first race will be 2:30 P.M.

title: Terence Toal Is Fiance of Jane O'Hara
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam J. O'Hara have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Mary O'Hara, to Terence Peter Toal, son of Mrs. Ter ence J. Toal of Yonkers and the late Mr. Toal. A March wedding is planned.

title: What's New At the Movies
description: THE BABY MAKER is written and directed by James Bridges, who seems much happier as a screenwriter than as director, accord ing to Roger Greenspun. More than comfortably welloff and in their 30's, Suzanne and Jay Wilcox (Collin WilcoxHorne and Sam Groom) decide to have the baby that Suzanne can't have by calling on hip, young Tish Gray (Bar bara Hershey), who so grooves on pregnancy that she will gladly bear Jay's child for a little cash, for nine months social securi ty and for the sheer joy of it all. That this seems not quite so silly in the unfolding owes a bit of some minor decencies in the screenplay and a bit more to some larger pleas ures among the perform ances. The Baby Maker is one of those too actively cinematic films in which miseenscene occasionally serves as an obstacle course for the camera. None of the actors are bad, but some have better chances than others. Miss Hershey's lifeforce ingenue seems a more reasonable and re warding role than her pre vious tyrannical in the Perrys Last Sum mer.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1970

title: Sanford: A Politician on the Campus
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 10In an age of campus unrest, the closest some politicians allow themselves to get to a univer sity today is a National Guard command post.

title: Romney Outruns 300 Presenting a Petition
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) George Romney's fre quent jogging in the park came in handy yesterday. It put the 63yearold Secretary of Housing and Urban Devel opment in shape to outrun 300 demonstrators down 10 flights of stairs and speed away in his limousine.

title: Colgate Eleven Stops Three Holy Cross Drives En Route to 2113 Victory
description: WORCESTER, Mass. Oct. 10 (UPI)  Steve Morgan, a full back, scored two touchdowns and Steve Goepel passed for a third today while the Colgate defense stopped three drives by Holy Cross inside the 20yard line en route to a 2113 victory.

description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Ted Heiskell scored three touchdowns today to lead Houston to a 3114 victory over Mississippi State.

description: Horace. Greeley of Chappaqua and John Jay of Cross River won crucial games yesterday to extend winning streaks and take major steps toward league championships.

title: Jersey Junior League Sale
description: Special to The New York Times

title: LEGAL MANEUVERS SLOW SONMY CASE
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 10 In a wellguarded wooden bung alow that serves as a court room at this Army post in the rolling hills of Central Texas, the courtmartial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell is slowly going forward through a thicket of legal maneuvers.

title: Candidate, 23, Seeks Vote of the Aged
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Oct. 10Barry Mayefsky, a 23 yearold law student, is trying to bridge the generation gap in his independent race for the Assembly seat in the three county 113th District. Among the 1,700 signatures he gath ered almost singlehandedly to qualify his Coalition party were those of 240 memberss nearly half the membership of the Monticello Golden Age Club.

title: Recordings
description: IT would be only slightly surprising to hear, any day now, that the best kept secret in music had leaked out: that the eminent German baritone Dietrich FischerDieskau is, in fact, not one artist, but a cartel, a team of inexhaustible sing ers that Deutsche Grammo phon Gesellschaft keeps hid den away in underground studios in West Berlin, turn ing out records as inexorably as the mill at the bottom of the sea grinds out salt. It has been apparent for years now that no other explanation for the FischerDieskau output will satisfy.

title: Caribbean poet of Elizabethan richness
description: Aficionados of Caribbean writing have been aware for some time that Derek Walcott is the first considerable Eng lishspeaking poet to emerge from the bonewhite Arcadia of the old slavocracies. Now, with the publication of his fourth book of verse, Walcott's stature in the front rank of all contem porary poets using English should be apparent. With hon ors divided these days between the easyriders of folk rock and the more heavily armored tra ditionalists in the wake of Lowell, Kunitz and Graves, Derek Walcott takes his place with authority among the lat ter. His language is often col loquial, and occasionally he uses the dialects of his native St. Lucia and Trinidad, but the closepacked lines within the strict forms he favors are al most Elizabethan in their rich ness.

title: Gail Dravneek Becomes Bride
description: Miss Gail Stephenson Drav neek, daughter of Mrs. Henry George Dravneek of Carmel, N. Y., and the late Mr. Drav neek, was married at the Harvard Club here yesterday to Edmund Huxley. Harvey Jr., son of Mr. Harvey of Pocopson, Pa., and Mrs. Mar garet Easton of Sandwich. Mass. The Methodist cere mony was performed by the Rev. William E. Barrick, as sistant professor of practical theology at the Union Theo logical Seminary.

title: U.S. STUDY ASSAILS AID EFFORT IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The General Accounting Office has concluded that some American relief commodities destined for refugees in Laos have been di verted or lost because of in adequate supervision by the Agency for International De velopment.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Outside the Englishspeaking world, the detective story sometimes seems a byproduct. There is, to be sure, Simenon; from Western Europe, at least, an occasional whodunit comes to these shores; on the basis of available evidence, it would seem that detective literature indigenous to the Orient (and, more specifically, to Japan) is nonexistent. I am pleased to report that this is not the case. Doubly so, since the first translated Japanese detective novel within my memory, POINTS AND LINES (Kodan sha International  USA, 577 Coller Ave., Palo Alto, Calif. 94306, $5.95) is a convoluted and revealing tale in the grand tradition of pure detection and unbreakable alibis.the place where heroin ship ments enter Tibet. Wainwright follows his quarry by truck, by donkey and on foot, over the top of a snowy and peri lous world. Eventually, he man ages to redeem himself, after a fashion.

title: Umpire Insists He Saw Carbo Tagged Out
Copters Aid 2 Hurt at Sea
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 (UPI)Two Norwegian sea mewwho were injured in an explosion aboard the freighter Tore Knudson 200 miles off the coast of Vietnamwere picked up by American helicopters today and taken to a United States hospital at Camranh Bay, American officials said.

title: Viewpoint
description: The question of Whether institutions should be allowed to join the New York Stock Exchange is rhetorical. By any definition, many Big Board member firms are in stitutions  whether the test is amount of assets con trolled, capitalization, finan cial and political power, di versity of products or con tinuity of existence.

description: STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 10 (AP)Oklahoma State, an op portunistic team today, turned four Texas Christian mistakes into touchdowns for a 3420 football victory.

title: Stranger Than Naked Or How to Write Dirty Books for Fun and Profit
description: Not quite a year ago the New York literary scene was shaken out of its summer torpor by the publication of a novel called Naked Came the Stranger. Author: one Penelope Ashe. Stranger was touted as the pornographic novel in extremis; it had been given a boost at the American Booksellers an nual convention when publisher Lyle Stuart offered a free tran sistor radio to any bookstore ordering 25 or more copies, the radio definitely being the better part of the deal. (You could al ways return the unsold books.)

title: Strike Closes Hawaii Hotel

At one hotel, they packed their bags and left. The Kona Inn on the island of Hawaii, one of eight hotels struck by the International Longshoremen's and Warehouse men's Union in a dispute over benefits and classification changes, closed its doors for the, first time in its 41year his tory.

title: The Bishop
description: Bruce Marshall, a novelist with a long history and a long er traditionthat of BeBoo and Chestertontakes a rueful look at some of the stresses within a Roman Catholic diocese in England. What accentuates ex isting conflicts is the latest Vatican encyclical on birth control, whose impact Mr, Mar shall explores with delicate hu mor. One priest becomes a martyr when he is assaulted by the husband (a nonCatho lic) of a parishioner he has been counseling. Another suf fers a loss of faith. There is also a hint of a love story be tween an apostate nun and a priest, an episode the author carries off beautifully.

title: The Runaway Generation
description: This book is based on first hand research (from the acid heads of Hashbury to the mal contents of exurbia), on inten sive interviews with both the author's subjects and their mentors. A 27yearold novelist. Bibi Wein divides her teen agers into three groups: the dopers, the streetdwellers, and the political radicals. What ties them together, inevitably, is their sense of being out of place and out of tune. They are strangers everywhere.

title: City Opera to Give 1st Full Production Of Janacek's Work
description: The New York City Opera will introduce its new produc tion of Leos Janacek's The Makropoulos Affair at the New York State Theater on Nov. 1. This will be the first time the work has been presented in a complete stage production in New York. It was given its American premiere by the San Francisco Opera in 1966 and was presented here in a concert version by the Little Orchestra Society in 1967.

title: DR. LEONARD ZWEIBEL
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10  Dr. Leonard Zweibel, obstetrician and gynecologist, died today at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 871 South 11th Street.

title: Seton Hall Club Eleven Wins
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Sports of the Times
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 10If those of meta physical bent and those who settle on reading tea leaves try to offer an infallible interpretation of the significance of Balti more's tensionpacked victory over the Cincinnati Reds in today's World Series opener, they are advised not to hurry. The Orioles did a far more convincing job in the opener azainst the New York Metz a year ago and you know how much good it did them. They failed to win another game.

title: Anne Hinshaw And Engineer Wed in Jersey
description: NEW VERNON, N.J., Oct. 10Miss Anne Stuart Hin shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McMillan Hin thaw Jr., was married here this afternoon to Raimund Gerhard Vanderweil Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderweil of Cohasset, Mass. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. William H. Felmeth at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: School Negotiators Freed in Illinois Following Protest
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Oct. 10, (UP1)State policemen formed a human wall today and es corted negotiators through chanting demonstrators who had locked them in the Board of Education office building last night.

title: Miss Nancy Moran Is Married To Iver E. Peterson, Newsman
description: TOWNSHEND, Vt., Oct. 10Miss Nancy Moran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana A. Moran of Roslyn Heights, L. I., was married in the Townshend Church this morning to Iver E. Peterson. The Protestant ceremony, performed by the Rev. Ruth Powell, was fol lowed by a small reception at the farm owned by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver A. Peterson, parents of the bridegroom.

title: Italian Beam Machine Pries Secrets From Matter
Better Rehabilitation Aid For Convicts Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Nixon Administration has called for increased em phasis on probation programs and facilities to rehabilitate convicts.

title: W. VIRGINIA UPSET BY DUKE, 21 TO 13
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 10 (AP) Duke's Blue Devils put a damper on West Vir ginia's powerful scoring ma chine here today and upset the 11thranked Mountaineers, 21 13, before a capacity Homecom ing crowd of 35,000.

title: Plastic Fights Pollutant Tag
description: Stung by criticism that they are major contributors to the pollution problem, makers of polyvinyl chloride, a plastic that has found its way onto every household shelf as a multitude of con tainers, have decided to fight back.

title: KELLY, TRUITT TAKE, GEORGIA CAR RACES
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 10 (UPI) The Group 44 racing team, the most successful in history with more than 100 victories, took two of the first four races today in the final Sports Car Club of America national championship at Road Atlanta.

title: Wrongful Death Claim Filed Against Los Angeles County
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (UPI) The MexicanAmerican fam ily of Ruben Salazar has filed a $1.15million wrongful death claim against Los An geles County.

title: Garibaldi Statue Found to Contain Jar of Documents
description: A glass jar containing docu ments and newspapers depict ing the death of Giuseppe Gari baldi, the Italian patriot, has been discovered underneath his statue in Washington Square Park.

title: The Future Is Not What It Used to Be
description: To the corpse of a robber shot by the police, Sunny Tid well says: When you lay gro tesquely on the street I want ed to cover your body, shield your body with my own, give you some of my life, lie on the street, wallow there beside you and scream. And wallow she does through every dismal page of The Future Is Not What It Used to Be. Patricia Griffith's account of the aches and pains of Sunny, the girl who is all heart.

title: Is Abbie Hoffman the Will Shakespeare of the 1970's?
description: THE mystic chant of Om filling the theater, the orgiastic writhings on the floor, the sensitivity acrobatics, the exchange of embraces and in sults between performers and audience, have subsided. The end of the 60's and the beginning of the new decade has seen the dispersal or eclipse of three leading groups involved in advanced theaterthe Living Theater, the Open Theater and the Performance Group.

title: Airlift to Start in Two Weeks
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 10 (AP)  Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan said today that the 5,000 children evacuated from Biafra in the civil war would begin returning to Nigeria in two weeks. The Prince arrived here from Gabon and said that the children there look healthy.

title: 6 FEDERAL JUDGES TO BE NAMED HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  A Republican State Senator, a woman member of the United States delegation to the United Nations and the former chair man of the New York State Narcotics Addiction Control Commission are among those in the running for six Federal district judgeships in the New York City area, Republican sources disclosed today.

title: Some in South Hope to Achieve BlackWhite Populist Coalition
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 10 When Maynard Jackson ran for the United States Senate in Georgia against Senator Her man Talmadge in 1968, he re ceived a call one evening from a white man in southern Geor gia who said he represented a group of small farmers.

title: Box Score of First Series Game
Cattle Rustler Strikes Out Westin Jersey
description: HAMPTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 10 (AP)State police In western New Jersey are looking for a cattle rus tler.

title: Chevalier sans peur et sans reproche
description: The of us whose happy lot it is to write about the men and women of show business know that actors are larger than Life. Many of them suffer from what Robert Sherwood once called elephantiasis of the ego.

title: NARRAGANSETT BAY LEADS IN YACHTING
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 10  Narragansett Bay, winning both races off Larchmont Yacht Club today, took a 45to72 point lead, under the lowpoint scoring system, over Western Long Island Sound in the start of their annual HerreshoffS Class interfleet team match. One race tomorrow completes the regatta which will be de cided on a totalpoints basis.

title: News of the Camera World
description: TWO new electronic flash units recently in troduced by Honeywell Photographic Products both have rechargeable nickel cadmium batteries that can be recharged to at least partial capacity in a matter of min utes, even when starting with a completely discharged bat tery. Called the Auto Strobo nar 332 and the Strobonar 312, respectively, each model comes with its own rapia re charging unit. Although each takes about three hours to ac cept a full chargewhich is good for 50 to 60 flashes each will deliver about ten flashes after only a 5minute charge; up to 30 flashes after a 20minute charge. Thus, in an emergency, if all power is used up, the photographer can give the flash enough of a charge to finish taking pic tures of most occasions while he changes, film or sets up his camera. And, unlike most other rapid charge units, it can be left on indefinitely without causing harm to the batteries.

title: Bonnor, Grey Lead Westfield in Rout
description: Westfield High continued to display a strong defense and an effective ground attack yester day as it rolled to a 490 victory over Berkeley Heights, its third triumph of the season.

title: Bavarian National Park Set Up Along Czechoslovak Boundary
description: NEUSCHONAU, West Ger many, Oct. 7 The Bavarian state government has opened West Germany's first national park under blue skies and cir rus clouds here in an outburst of home state pride with beer, bugle calls and boasts.

title: Trinity Downs R.P.I., 1 410, On Kiarsis's Two Long Runs
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 10 (UPI) Dave Kiarsis scored touch downs on runs of 83 and 31 yards as Trinity beat Rensselaer Poly, 1410, today. Kiarsis ran 177 yards in 18 carries for the game.

title: Plug In to Whisk the Dirt Away
description: ANY homeowner who is thinking about buying a good quality new vacuum cleaner may find It worth his (or her) while to investigate the possibility of installing one of the new and increasingly popular central vacuum systems.

title: School Lunch Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)A Senate hearing has been set for Tuesday to review implementation of the national school lunch act, Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, announced today.

title: FORD SUPPORTS F.T.C. ON CAR STICKER PLAN
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10 (UPI} The Ford Motor Company said yes terday it agreed with a Federal Trade Commission proposal that sticker prices on new cars should be closer to what the car buyers actually pay for their new automobiles.

title: Commuters Differ On Whether L.I.R. Has Improved]
description: A year ago today Governor Rockefeller announced to a group of Long Island business men: On this day we have become, officially, the finest commuter railroad in the coun try.

title: Games of survival through tantasy
description: This unique little book by a Polish novelist and screen writ er now living in the United States has extraordinary gam bits of literary style and poetic compulsions. Its 19 episodes are united by the visions of a child, or children, undergoing the Ger man occunation of Poland. It is a constant search for bread, shelter, parents, relatives  all the things the characters ex perienced during the war. There are bombs going off and Jews hiding from the Germans. There are arrests of patriots, black mail and death. There is con stant starvation, the begging handand a child's inner vision over all.

title: G.M. Plans a Device To Curb Car Fumes
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10  A little silverblue box may hold the solution to pollution caused by automobiles.

title: U.S. Aides in India Concerned Over Sale of Arms to Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 10United States Embassy officials here are concerned over a possible countermove by the Indian Government in retaliation for the United States decision to resume the sale of arms to Pakistan, India's hostile neigh bor.

title: The Parties Play the Mousetrap Game in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  The noises from Capitol Hill last week sounded as if the parties had got their roles reversed. There were the Republican leaders protesting that the 91st Congress should adjourn this month even if that meant a good portion of the Ad ministration's legislative program was left unenacted. Meanwhile the Democratic leaders were sug gesting that Congress should come back after the election so it could complete action on most of the Administration's bills.

title: Drake Is Upset, 1310
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa, Oct. 10 (AP)Northern Iowa's de fense put the lid on Drake after the first quarter today and the Panthers ground out a 1310 upset of their crossstate non conference football rival.

title: Treasury Aide Named
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy has announced the ap pointment of John E. Chapoton of Houston as his acting tax legislative counsel.

title: Quebec Extremists Escalate Separatist Campaign
description: MONTREAL  The French Canadian terrorists who kid napped James R. Cross, the sen ior British Trade Commissioner in Quebec and Pierre Laporte, Minister of Labor and Immigra tion in Quebec, last week acted in the name of French Canadian independence and social revolu tion. Ransom communiqus came from the Front for the Liberation of Quebec, which first popped up in 1953, and has claimed credit for bombings and armed robberies that have taken six lives.

title: Bridge
description: AN experienced player finds alarm bells ringing in his head in cer tain situations. Suppose you are play ing a suit contract, and the opening lead is a small card in a suit your side has bid. Why would an opponent choose such a lead? Probably because he has a singleton.

title: Ohio U. Tops Dayton. 1714
description: ATHENS, Ohio. Oct. 10 (UPI) Jim Kensinger kicked a 22 yard field goal with eight sec onds remaining to give Ohio Universitty a 1714 triumph over Dayton.

title: What Makes Susan Sontag Make Movies?
description: LONG SHOT: The eye tracks forward as the film company's bus pulls into the square and stops. The driver checks his watch (7:15 A.M.) and makes an impatient gesture in the direction of two figures hurry ing handinhand toward the bus.

title: St. John's Routs St. Francis In Club Football, 41 to 12
description: St. John's University trounced St. Francis, 4112, in a club football game at the winner's stadium in Jamaica, Queens, Yesterday. The game was tele vised over WNYCTV

title: GAINS REPORTED ON ENVIRONMENT
description: The use of state financial pressure has reversed a turn down on a sewage bond issue and caused a goahead, while a state enforcement order has started a test on cleaning up sludge in Lake Champlain.

title: Trenton State Tops Curry
description: TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Leo Kozlowski bulled his way for touchdowns in the third and fourth periods today to lead Trenton State College to a 2821 triumph over Curry College of Milton, Mass.

title: GIANTS EXPECTING EAGLE INNOVATION
description: Today is the big one for the Philadelphia Eagles and the New York Giants.

title: Canada Abandons Search For 3 Missing Balloonists
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 10 (AP) An air and sea search in the disappearance of three balloonists has been officially terminated by Canadian forces.

title: Penn State Pins Boston College With First Loss of Season, 283
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Oct. 10 Penn State, snapping a rare twogame losing streak, re turned to the East today and slapped down previously un beaten Boston College, 283, before 25,222 in Alumni Sta dium. The victory was the sec and in four games for the Nit tany Lions. Boston College had won three straight this season before today.

title: The Edwardians
description: In The Edwardians, J. B. Priestley is caught between his good sense and his nostalgia, at once denying and affirming that the Edwardians lived in the closed, safe world they are popularly supposed to have in habited, the sundrenched coun tryside John Osborne's Colonel Redfern recalls in Look Back in Anger. Priestley wants to make clear that the years be tween 1901 and 1914 (the period ends not with the death of Edward but with the begin ning of the war) are compli cated ones, full of contradic tion, richness, prophecy. It Might seem axiomatic that the Edwardians, in their art, their literature, their politics, their sociology, looked back to the Victorians and forward to the postwar moderns, but in em phasizing so selfevident a truth, Priestley ends in contra diction.

title: U.S. Balks At Paying Bill for I. L. O.
description: A year ago the International Labor Organization was savor ing the most universal acclaim since it was brought into being as a brainchild of Woodrow Wil son and Samuel Goanpers in the wake of World War I. This sole survivor of the instruments for global cooperation established under the Treaty of Versailles had just celebrated its 50th an niversary by winning the Nobel Peace Prize and having Pope Paul VI as a speaker at its an nual conference in Geneva.

title: Slowdown on Route 128
description: BURLINGTON, Mass.  Route 128 is a controlled access, divided highway that almost encircles Boston. It stretches about 68 miles from Braintree in the south to Gloucester on the North Shore.

title: STUDENT SUICIDES SEEN AS CONSTANT
description: The mental health of college students and their dropout and suicide rates have changed very little in recent decades, a Har vard University psychiatrist has reported.

title: MORAVIAN IS VICTOR OVER WAGNER, 1713
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 10 Moravian defeated Wagner to day for the first time since 1958, scorine a 1713 victory.

title: Rockefeller U. Head Cited
description: Dr. Frederick Seitz, president of Rockefeller University, re ceived the highest award of the American Institute of Physics last week for his distinguished statesmanship in science. The award, the Karl Taylor Comp ton Gold Medal, was given to Dr. Seitz at the annual meet ing at Rockefeller University here of the institute's seven memher organizations. Dr. Seitz was formerly president of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: DWYER OF RICE WINS CROSSCOUNTRY RACE
description: Vince Dwyer of Rice posted his second consecutive victory yesterday by capturing the Iona interscholastic crosscountry run at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: North Dakota Moves to Make Elementary Education Less Rigid
How Friends of Jack Martin Remember Him Still
A Political Smorgasbord
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (UPI)  Mayor Carl B. Stokes told a convention of the American Dietetics Association here Tuesday that the most popular menu in Washington these days is Applesauce Agnew, mutton chops Mitchell, fondue Ful bright and chicken Congress.

title: Joseph H. Louchheim, 62, Dies; Welfare Commissioner in 1965
description: Joseph H. Louchheim, a for mer welfare official here, died yesterday in Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, L. I., of in juries suffered in an automo bile accident on Monday. He was 62 years old and lived at 48 Morton Street in New York.

title: CATHOLICS URGE NEW CHURCH LAW
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8A growing number of Roman Catholic conon lawyers are con cluding that their church needs not only a new legal code but also a whole new philosophy of church law.

title: A Trolley Ride Through The Woods of Connecticut
description: WAREHOUSE POINT, Conn.This year more than 30,000 people will come to this village 10 miles northeast of Hart ford to tour a museum that some of the local citizens don't even know about. Yet on pleasant Sunday afternoons, spring through early winter, the parking lot of the Warehouse Point Trolley Mu seum fills with cars from all over the Northeast, and from as far away as Quebec, as families relive the past by riding through the woods on turnof thecentury trolleys.

title: 523 YARDS GAINED IN FOURTH VICTORY
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 10 (AP)Pat Sullivan scored the first two times Auburn had the football today, leading his team to a 440 rout of Clemson.

title: Brown Sparks Lawrenceville To 10th Victory in Row, 3313
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 10Al Brown paced Lawrence ville. School to its 10th straight football victory over a twosea son span today as the New Jer seyites routed Williamson Trade (Pa.). 3313.

title: General Dynamics Accused Of Overcharging the Army
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 10 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the General Dyna mics Corporation overcharged the Army up to $8.8million more than 100 per centfor assembling radio teletypewriter sets. General Dynamics denied the charge and said that the Government actually benefited by $3million because of the company's efficiency.

title: PITCHER ADMITS TO TIRING EARLY
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 (UPI) It was a very gutty perform ance by [Jim] Palmer, Balti more manager Earl Weaver said today after the Orioles beat the Cincinnati Reds, 43, in the first game of the World Series.

title: High School Game Canceled Over Fear of Racial Clash
description: SALEM, N. J., Oct. 10 (UPI) Fear of a racial clash at high school football game to day led to its cancellation.

title: A Black Critic for a Black Show?
description: THIS reviewer recently covered the seasonal debut of Black Jour nal. Tony Brown, the show's executive producer, voiced objections. In the voluntary spirit of the fair ness doctrine, I would like to print his letter here, along with my response.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: What Kind of Power Plant?

title: New Coop Due
description: Ground has been broken for a $10million cooperative apartment house on Park Avenue in which the least expensive unit (three bed rooms, four baths) is being offered at $270,000.

title: Little
description: Louis Zukofsky, a poet and the father of a violin virtuoso, draws on both connections in this spoof. He tucks into it a green roomful of concert gar goyles, and he indulges in an orgy of language: funny names, puns, malapropisms, verbal curlicues.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THE blonde bombshellonce known at Brooklyn's Thomas Jefferson High as Shelley Schrift, but now on stage, screen and television as Shelley Wintersis in the process of re claiming her brain. Miss Winters ex plains, I lost it in Hollywood, back in the bombshell days when I let the press boys put all those crazy things into my mouth.

title: Sons of Italy Luncheon
description: A luncheon and fashion show, under the auspices of the women's division of the Queens branch of the Order of the Sons of Italy in Amer ica, will be held Thursday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Tickets at $10 each may be obtained from Mrs. Edward Soyer of Malba, Queens, the chairman.

title: REGIME IN TAIWAN ACCUSED OF CURBS
Shattered Decade
description: Bombs sent through the mail to public figures. Youth in revolt: the older generation certainly ruined the world before passing it on to us. Girls flashing flesh above the knee. Credit skyrocketing  why pay cash? Men with sideburns. Women march ing for their rights. Prices zooming. National Guardsmen firing into mob, killing several protesters ...

title: Excerpts From the Mayor's Statement Calling for Court Reforms Here
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Lindsay's statement on court reform made to the Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference.

title: Fire Ant Quarantine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) North Carolina has been added to the list of states un der Federal quarantine for im ported fire ants.

title: Australian Students Split on War and Radicalism
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 10 Australian university students, normally eager to keep pace with their counterparts else where in styles and attitudes, are divided on the issues of radicalism and the Vietnam war.

title: Frankfort:
description: The Blue Grass State is enjoying a recordbreaking year in industrial develop ment. Paul W. Grubbs, com missioner of commerce, re ported that so far this year Kentucky has attracted 53 new industries.

title: BOWDOIN TOPPLES AMHERST BY 3421
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 10 Bowdoin College rolled up 27 points in the second half today to defeat Amherst, 3421, be for an Alumni Day crowd of 4,000. It was the Polar Bears first victory over Amherst in 10 years.

title: Alexander The Great
description: Let us now praise famous men, and the fathers that begot usnot a fashionable slogan today, when the hero is lucky if he escapes being pilloried and merely rests obscure. Yet the pride and boast of history is to reign above these temporary showers, and there are still figures that manage to stand, with time lapping round them in vain. Their immunity does not come from any mere cata logue of their achievements, but from some spring of the uni versal drama that their lives visibly illustrate and which in terests us all.

title: SWEEPING CHANGE IN JUSTICE SYSTEM URGED BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay issued a blunt statement yesterday blam ing the state judiciary for the current crisis in the City pris ons and calling for sweeping changes in the administration of criminal justice in New York.

title: Ens. Roy Flemister Coppedge Is Fiance of Susan Emerson
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Oct. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward Learnard Emerson of Chestnut Hill and Chatham have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Lyman Emerson, to Ens. Roy Flemister Cop pedge 3d, U.S.N.R., who is stationed in Athens, Ga. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Coppedge Jr. of Princeton, N. J.

title: Probable Batting Order For Second Series Game
description: Game time1 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time.

title: 2 White House Yachts Are Up for Sale Again
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 10 (AP)The White House has decided to try again to sell the Julie and the Patricia, two former Presidential yachts that didn't draw a single bid the first time on the sales block.

title: Gretchen Meyer Becomes Bride Of Stephan Salisbury, Student
description: Miss Gretchen Meyer and Stephan P. Salisbury were married here yesterday aft ernoon, about three years after they met at the Lions Den when she was a sopho more at Barnard and he a junior at Columbia.

title: APOLITICAL REVUE CLOSES IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Oct. 5Antonio, a tall, bearded young actor, spot ted an acquaintance passing outside the cafe, jumped from his seat and rushed out to talk to him.

title: COLLEGE GUARD SAYS HIS SHOT WOUNDED 3
description: MORRISTOWN, Tenn., Oct. 10 (UPI) A security officer employed by the school said to day, he apparently was respon sible for the wounding of three black students during a dem onstration at Morristown Junior College.

title: Saints Obtain Rams Pitts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 (AP) The New Orleans Saints trad ed an undisclosed draft choice today to the Los Angeles Rams for Elijah Pitts, a running back. The Saints also waived Dickie Lyons, a safety, injured and Vic Nyvall, a rookie running back, and activated Hugo Hol las, a safety.

title: Tennis Stars to Play At Fordham in Benefit
description: The first Fordham Univer sity tennis spectacular, with the proceeds going to the J. Franklin Ewing Institute, Americans Mutually Interest ed in Giving Others a Start (AMIGOS), and the Fordham University Ram Club, will be staged at Fordham's gymna sium in the Bronx Oct. 22.

title: The more arms we have
description: Last year, after the first major de bate on a defense issue in many years, the Senate approved, by the narrowest of margins, the deploy ment of the Safeguard antiballistic missile (ABM) system. This year's debate was something of an anti climactic replay but with different nuances. The Administration's re quest to begin initial work on a na tionwide antiChinese defense was rejected but otherwise its expanded ABM scraped by.

title: Joan T. Higgins Becomes Bride
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 10 The marriage of Miss Joan Therese Higgins to Alexander. John Chilko took place here this afternoon in St. Augustine's Roman Cath olic Church. The Rev. Ben jamin L. Masse performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. CURBING ENTRY OF EAST GERMANS
Armed Services, Faced With an Image Problem, Seek Public Sympathy and More Rapport With Youth
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The armed forces believe that their public image has become tarnished and that the older men at the top are having trou ble communicating with the young men who fill the ranks.

title: Dance: Martha Graham Speaks to the Young
description: WHETHER Martha Gra ham has retired from active danc ing or not  and the good and lovely lady seems a little uncertain her self from day to day  some thing different has happened to the Martha Graham Dance Company, which has just completed a week's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, starting off this sea son's dance series.

title: Mrs. Baker Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. William Lane Baker of New York on Oct. 1 at the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Baker is the former Miss Brigitte I. H. Jaenkel.

title: Adulteress Denied Alimony Despite Plea on New Era
description: TALLAHASSEE, Oct. 10 (AP) A state law passed 142 years ago forbidding alimony to an adulterous wife has been up held by the Florida Supreme Court despite the plea of a di vorcee that 1970's permissive ness outdates the rule.

title: Army Lightweights Topple Princeton as Colbert Stars
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 10 Mickey Colbert, a sophomore halfback, scored three touch downs today to lead Army's lightweight football team to its second straight victory, a 530 rout of Princeton.

title: Man in Motion
description: Michael Mewshaw's man in motion is a man not equal to his fantasies. At 26, Walker Hawley longs for a willowy blonde, San Francisco and the life of a sensitive writer, but he lives with his mother in Cottage City, hasn't written a line since college, ana makes love to a darkhaired girl who's 5foot2. Miraculously, his rich grandmother gives him $5,000 to visit his father who lives the creative life in San Francisco with a willowy blonde second wife. And when Walker advertises for a rider to share expenses, his ad is answered by (would you be live?) Lila Caine, willowy blonde. But the closest Walker comes to success is the front seat of his Triumph.

title: Coast Radicals Rally Behind 6 Latin Youths on Trial in Slaying of Policeman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10  In the early morning the long haired youths are there in the hallway, sitting on the floor and talking quietly while they wait for seats in the courtroom.

title: NEGRO CANDIDATE PRESSES WALLACE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 9 For the first time in the modern history of this state, a Negro is mining for Governor. And George C. Wallace, the white segregationist, is not taking it lightly.

title: KANSAS TURNS BACK KANSAS STATE, 2115
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 10 (AP) Underdog Kansas capi talized on mistakes today for a 2115 football victory over Kan sas State.

title: Surprise: A Profit on Wall St.
description: If Salomon Brothers, per haps Wall Street's leading institutional securities house, we're to offer itself for public ownership tomorrow, the firth's 31 general partners might become instant paper millionaires virtually over nightif they are not already.

title: PEOPLE FETE OPENS AN 8DAY RUN IN PARK
description: An outdoor festival called The People, Yes! designed to display the city's polyglot character, will open at noon to day in Central Park and will run through Oct. 8.

title: Headliners
description: Prisoners Friend

title: Challenge to Hanoi
description: In the past four days, the war in Indochina and the Vietnam negotiations in Paris have both been trans formed in the world's eyes by President Nixon's dramatic October 7 peace initiative and its nearuniversal ap proval at home and in nonCommunist countries abroad.

title: Miss Wyner To Be Bride
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 10  Mr. and Mrs. Leo Wyner have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Franclyn Joan Wyner, to Michael Stephen Hyman, son of Fred Hyman and the late Mrs. Geraldine Hyman of Miami Beach.

title: 200 Dogs Strut, Sniff and Point At a Show in Philadelphia Park
description: There were dogs that pointed game and dogs that leaped through fiery hoops and dogs that rolled over and played dead and obedience trained dogs and dogs that showed in competition and one dog that sniffed out a package of marijuana in a Philadelphia park last Wednesday. The occasion was the annual Ritten house Square dog axhibition, held in the heart of the city on a benign day of thin sunshine.

title: Anniversaries
description: GOLDRay & GeorgeVery best wishes for your Golden Anniversary & many more.

title: Alioto's 2d Trial Date Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP)  The second trial of Mayor Joseph Alioto's $12.5 million libel suit against Look Magazine has been set for next May 3. The first trial ended with a mistrial last May.

title: ISBRANDTSEN BOAT BEATS 63 RIVALS

The quality of Nell Blaine's paintings  now on view in a striking exhibition of 44 oils, watercolors, pas tels and drawings at the Poin dexter Gallery, 24 East 84th Street  depends as much upon the quality of her re sponses to the act of pure painting as to the quality of her reactions to the subject matter; whether committed directly to the canvas in front of the motif or translated from sketches made earlier.

The waterway has not been used for a halfcentury and is mostly dry. The bill, sent to the Senate, would authorize $20.4million for land acquisi tion and $17million for devel opment.

title: Two American travelers in the English springand how they survived
description: Deserting their American by ways, Edwin Way Teale and his wife crossed the Atlantic and, through a recent spring, made a meandering nature journey from Land's End to John o' Groats. He does not specify which spring and, as the weather of most in Britain is as bonechilling and capri ciously vile as the one they experienced, the year cannot be identified for sure. They endured blinding rain on Dart moor, freezing gales across the Severn, roadblocking blizzards in Somerset, and tomblike ho tels everywhere, and Mrs. Teaie was prevented from hear ing the nightingales at Selborne by being put to bed with in cipient pneumonia.

description: TOKYO, Oct. 10 (AP)Eight of the 18 tires on a jumbo jet airliner blew out as it landed, leaving it stranded in the middle of a runway and forcing Tokyo's international airport to shut down for more than two hours today. Airport officials said there were no injuries to the 266 passengers and 20 crew members aboard the Pan Ameri can World Airway Boeing 747, which flew into Tokyo from Honolulu.

title: Music
description: SO Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orches tra have introduced Krzystof Penderecki's Utrenja to New York, and it is a score very much in the tradition of the same compos er's St. Luke Passion. Pen derecki has been attracting a great deal of international at tention, and he has become one of the most popular of the avantgarde composers. It is easy to see why. As an eclectic who uses musical ele ments derived from Cage, Stockhausen, Schoenberg, Stravinsky, the medieval and renaissance composers, Bou lez, Xenakis and anything that serves his purpose, Pen deredd Is anything but doc trinaire. His work has none of the sterility that has so char acterized the serial move ment, and none of the anarchy that Cage and his followers represent. It is far from being traditional music, but it appears to be saying something in an emotional manner.

title: NEW URBAN RULES HELPING SAN JUAN
description: SAN JUAN, Oct. 10Mayor Carlos Romero Barcelo of San Juan is hoping to take advan tage of revised Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment regulations to expand the, the city's Model Cities program.

title: Doomed, damnedand unaware
description: The permanent errors of these bitter stories are suicide, the refusal to forgive and that violation of the heart's privacy whereby we know so much about a person's misery that we cannot know the person. All knowledge of others, Reynolds Price seem to say, is tragic. Then tension between human beings is a matter of distance, both real and psycho logical. All of these stories are about crossing the perimeters that may not be crossed without terrible re sponsibilities; love, compassion, con fession are wounds, and their scars are permanent.

title: Speaking of Books: Matthew Arnold's Times, Our Times
description: Culture and anarchyit is not too much to say that the words repre sent the poles on which is stretched the tightrope where we all teeter, crowded and jostling and anxious. Yet such is the power of relevance in the modem world that my eye kept sliding past the place on my shelf where the small, battered paper back bearing those potent words as a title rested. I had picked it up for 15 cents at a country  church book sale, the nature of its underlinings and its marginalia clearly indicating it had been the property of the resi dent divine.

title: Prelude to disaster
description: The agonizingly downward trajec tory of Judy Garland's later life and career ended with her death (from an overdose of barbiturates) in the early morning hours of June 22, 1969. She was 47 years old but many of her mourners still wept over the little girl who had first sung Over the Rainbow in The Wizard of Oz more than thirty years before. To others Miss Garland's voice had always been larger than life and louder than art. Like Helen Morgan and Edith Piaf, she had somehow institutionalized her sorrows in a singing style that was tremulous, emotionally demanding, sometimes rasping and scraping in its plea for sympathy and understanding, and yet as often intuitively precise in its grasp of a lyric or feeling. It is not the least of the virtues of Met Torm's book on the late star that it helps bridge the chasm between those who remember her as Judy and those who regard her as Miss Garland.

title: Attitude Toward Violence May Decide Key Races
description: WASHINGTON  In his primary campaign against Senator Ralph W. Yarborough in Texas earlier this year, Lloyd M. Bentsen used a television commercial that showed young people, mostly students, battling with the Chicago police during the 1968 Democratic Convention.

title: Dye Workers End Strike
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 10 (UPI)  Some 1,200 workers at the Allied Chemical Company's Buffalo dye works voted today to accept a new contract and end a 15week strike against the plant. The men were to return to work immediately. The contract provides a 54 cent an hour increase over three years, including 20 cents upon ratification. Other changes were to give premium pay for week end work, and set up a $25,000 trust fund for hospitalization costs of pensioners.

title: Mr. Chips, abandoned by social evolution
description: Twenty years ago it was easy to recognize them: Dirty white shoes, tweed sports coats, rep ties a little askew, coming down from Deerfield and Taft at Thanksgiving, or toting their bags and their prepschool pa raphernalia into the freshman dorms of the Ivy League. For those of us who had attended urban public schools and met them for the first time in col lege, they were a strange breed who seemed to talk a special language, had actually been to deb parties and cotillions, and wereas we imagined them, often correctlyloaded with money. In the first year of col ege they performed well, seemed in fact, to possess some secret weapon of preparation; then they began to fade in the golden haze of booze, fraterni ties and weekend trips.

title: Isle for an Empress, a Duke and the Durrells
description: CORFU, Greece  The morning we sailed into Corfu from Italy, the early heat haze was turning the mountains of Albania and the Greek mainland  a few miles across the channel  into a frieze of lilac and blue. Corfu's hills stood out in all their Vivid green.

title: COLUMBIA EVENS 12METER SERIES
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP)  The former America's Cup defender, Columbia, evened the California Cup series today with a victory over the Canadian yacht, Endless Summer.

description: THE Puerto Ricannot unlike other minority groups in America  has experienced every form of exploitation. The camera, however, is a rela tively new assault, which in the hands of a symbolmind ed photographer can be transformed into a cruel weapon.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Bigcity slums get the head lines but twothirds of the na tion's dilapidated housing is in small towns, the chairman of the National Rural Coalition said this week.

title: Bergen Burtis Rapalyea, A Pan Am Sales Aide, 61
description: O. Bergen Burtis Rapalyea, a Pan American World Airways executive, died on Friday at Center Harbor, N.H. He was 61 years old and lived at 101 Old Orchard Road, Chestnut Hill, Boston.

title: A glorious heritage whose future is cloudy
description: The fresco was a, public artform. in the great age of its development in Renaissance Italy, frescoes not only adorned the interior walls of church es, they decorated the facades of pub lic buildings as well. It was a sociable and spectacular art; larger than life, full of narrative action, peopledone might saywith casts of thousands. In certain respects, it was a popular artform like the modern movie. As a vehicle of artistic expression, it was at once so ambitious in scale and so personal in its possibilities that it accommodated all the great names of Italian art from Giotto in the 13th century to Raphael and Michelangelo in the 16th. That the age of fresco was a great age of painting, Millard Meiss makes clear in a hundred ways the hundred or more annotated examples, all of them in color, which he has selected for his book.

title: A Leftist General Rides the Bolivian Tiger
description: LA PAZ  Eighteen years ago, a polyglot mob of politi cians, leftist militants, tin min ers, students and Indians took up arms against the Bolivian army and ended by smashing it. In some respects history seemed to be repeating itself during the past week. Some kind of civ ilian revolution had taken place, and some of its leaders were the same as in 1952. The main question seemed to be whether or not the real winner this time would prove to be the late Che Guevara, the CubanArgentine revolutionary who died here three years ago.

title: Jailing of Catena, Genovese's Successor, Is Viewed as Weakening Mafia Family
description: The kind of absolute power that was exercised by the late Vito Genovese in ruling his Mafia family from a Federal prison tell during the last 10 years of his life has cracked in the seven months that his successor, Gerardo (Jerry) Catena, has been in jail for con tempt of the New Jersey Com mission of Investigation.

title: COMPANY DEFENDS AGNEW DART GAME

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONAlthough Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts is clearly one of that group of Repub lican Senators, which in cludes Charles E. Goodell of New York, that sometimes deserts the Nixon Adminis tration on key issues, he cer tainly has no record as a foe of business.

title: Bombay:
description: BOMBAY. THE monsoon arrived in Bombay the day after I did. Heavy, soundless and sad, like English butlers or Russian ambassadors, its clouds drifted up from the south, across a turbulent sea. They sus pended themselves above the city, obscuring a shrunken sun. The sum mer was over. The heat  shifted a little, delicately, and some five mil lion expectant people squinted up at the clouds. Dull thunder came from the distant hills. Then the rain started to fall, at first in slow blunt spears that dropped deliberately to the roofs and pavements, but thickening quick ly to a waterfall under which few people cared to walk.

title: Public Politics vs. Private Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10You can put it down as a fairly dependable rule that serious proposals between na tions, and particularly between the United States and the Communist coun tries, must be made in private. There are exceptions, of course, but Bohlen's Law is that privacy is the mark of diplomacy and publishing Is propa ganda.

title: Burning of Money Halted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Dorothy Kabis, the United States Treasurer, announced to day that, in the future, worn out moneyamounting to $9 billion a yearwould be pul verized instead of burned. The burning process is being aban doned because it contributed to air pollution. Used bills are de stroyed at Federal Reserve banks and branches in 35 cities.

title: Moscow Says Peace Offer By Nixon Is Great Fraud
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10The So viet Union today dismissed President Nixon's Indochina peace proposals as a great fraud and aligned its policy firmly behind the Vietnamese Communists.

title: CAPITAL'S PAPERS HIT BY SLOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Job slowdowns by printers and photoengravers at Washington's three daily newspapersThe Washington Post, The Evening Star and The Daily Newsare beginning to have serious ef fects.

title: Agnew Presses a Strong Assault Against the Republican Left
description: WASHINGTON  The edifice of the Republican party is some what smaller than the Demo cratic equivalent, has been for some 40 years now. As a re sult, when averagesize cracks appear in it, they may look a little bigger, a little more di visive and threatening to the party's relatively modest, oc casionally shaky foundation.

title: De Gaulle Says
description: PARISWorld events always assume an intimate look when recounted by a man who was a major actor in them. Last week, Charles de Gaulle told of events in France and the world from the time he returned to power in 1958 until the end of 1962. In recounting the eventsin the first volume of a new threevolume set of memoirs that appeared in Frence bookstoresGeneral de Gaulle had things to say about some of his fellow actors.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Stephen W. Brener's Point of View article [HotelMotel, Industry Must Stress Change, Sept. 20] is an out standing example of the mud dled, upsidedown thinking of the American travel in dustry. The woes of the motelhotel owners do not result from too high a qual ity in lodgings and facilities, but rather from the sterility and blandness of the environ ment and the ineptitude of management.

description: Third graders in the new white clapboard building at the New Canaan Country School sit at tables instead of desks. They also sit on pillows strewn about car peted floors. And sometimes they bring their dogs to class.

description: Hackensack High, bounced from the unbeaten ranks last week, turned around yesterday and did the same to Lyndhurst, pulling off a 2014 upset at Hackensack.

title: Coins

This first American standard, well preserved and carefully guarded, was honored recently by the Bedford Minuteman Company, which issued a medal to commemorate its place in history.

title: the traveler's world
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaThis is the first stop of an excursion into South America in anticipation of the observance of 1971 as Latin American Travel Year, so designated by the International Union of Official Travel Organizations. Through many media and with varying degrees of propagandizing skill, United States and Canadian tourists are about to be invited to travel southward as part of a continentdeep effort to bring tour ism alive down here.

title: Oriole Home Runs Subdue Reds, 43, In Series Opener
description: The Baltimore Orioles over came a threerun deficit with home runs by Boog Powell, Elrod. Hendricks and Brooks Robinson and defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 43, in the opening game of the. World Series at Cincinnati yester day.

title: Miss Jorgensen Asks Agnew for an Apology
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 10 (AP)  Christine Jorgensen, the former soldier whose sex was surgically changed in the early nineteenfifties, is asking Vice President Ag new to apologize for what she called his disparaging remark about her.

title: The New Plays
description: THE HAPPINESS CAGE, the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of a play by Dennis J. Reardon, was approved by four re viewers although with soze reservations, and was rejected by three. Clive Barnes: Mr. Reardon has written a play that is by turn gripping, entertaining and, oddly enough, not in frequently amusing. It is a pleasurably well  crafted work, although it is per haps too long, the ending is weak, and Mr. Reardon seems in two minds about precisely what he wants to tell us. The faults of the play, matter a great deal less than its virtues, which emerge very clearly. There is a lot of tension and mys tery to the play, and Toni Aldredge's staging kept up the suspense. The perform ances were at a high level, with Lewis J. Stadlen most impressive. There were faults, but I was never bored. For Walter Kerr, see. Page 1.

title: Puerto Rico's Floods Leave 10 Dead, 40 Missing and 1,600 Families Homeless After 7 Days of Rain
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 10. The toll of missing and dead in a week of disastrous floods climbed to 50 this morning as Puerto Rico went about the grim task of sheltering its homeless and clearing debris. The San Juan weather bureau lifted the flood alert late yes terday although periodic down pours pelted the island early this morning.

title: Music to Walk Through
description: THE object resting on the floor of the Guggenheim Museum might have been a part of the current Picabia exhibition gone astray. It was a Plexiglass box enclosing a metal construction, parts of it painted a pretty blue. Actually it was one element of a Moog synthesizer, the others being an enormous box resembling a switchboard and, at right angles to it, a double key board.

title: Texas FarmersTroubled By Land Loss to Mexico
description: PRESIDIO, Tex. Oct. 10 (UPI)  Alberto Armendariz bought land along the Rio Grande more than half a century ago. His sons later joined him in the fields.

title: Honest Story Sets Record In Taking Pace at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 10 The Wirtz Stables Honest Story established a New Jersey record of 1:58 25 in winning the onemile Coronet Pace at Freehold Raceway today. Eddie Cobb drove the son of Adios Butler to an easy eightlength victory.

title: Arms for Pakistan
description: As if it did not already have enough trouble trying to defuse perilous international conflicts in the Middle East and Southeast Asia, the United States Government isincrediblyadding fuel to another potentially ex plosive situation in South Asia. The State Department confirms the report that this country has decided to sell arms to Pakistan in what a spokesman describes as a limited exception to the prudent arms embargo that was imposed on both India and Pakistan after their 1965 war.

title: October Moon
description: This is the week of the Hunter's Full Moon, when a whole succession of autumn evenings will be brilliant with moonlight. The Hunter's Moon and the Harvest Moon of four weeks ago give autumn the most spec tacular moonlit nights of the year, when one has the feeling that the full moon persists night after night instead of coming to its fullness and then swiftly waning.

title: UTILITY IS FACING POLLUTION CURBS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 7 Power company officials esti mated this week that It might cost as much as $14million to bring a new desert generating plant into conformance with tightened air pollution regulations.

title: Where Time Stood Still
description: Spring covers the Southern Appala chian Mountains with wildflowers; autumn brings a blaze of fiery sumac and golden sassafras. But life there is bleak for the average family, who earns less than $3,000 a year, and the million people who have no work and little hope. Isolated by rugged terrain, the descendants of fiercely independent preRevolutionary set tlers see the land they love eroded by poor farming methods, devastated by stripmining. Clannish, fearful of outsidersa traveler may be asked, suspiciously, What business you got up on the mountain?the people of the 80,000 square mile area stretching southwest from western New York to northern Alabama have been bypassed by the 20th century.

title: Field Of Travel
description: IN A PROGRAM to encour age offseason travel to their country, the French tourist industry is offering a bonus to visitors between Nov. 1 and April 30, 1971. Entitled

title: Anna W. Dickinson Is Married In Illinois to Richard B. Platt
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Oct. 10Miss Anna Wilson Dick inson and Richard Booth Platt were married here this afternoon in a ceremony per formed at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Ander son of the First Presbyterian Church.

title: HANOI AIDES IN PARIS SPURN V.F.W. EFFORT
description: PARIS, Oct. 10 Herbert R. Rainwater, national commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said today that he had been unable to present North Vietnamese representa tives here with petitions bear ing some four million signatures asking the releas eof and better treatment for American prison ers of war.

title: Of time and the child
description: ON the evening of my birth day our 4yearold son an nounced: Daddy, you don't need any more birthdays, you are already all grown up. For Bobby, as for most preschool children, getting taller is the same as get ting older; thus when a person attains his final height he also at tains his final age (would that it were so!). The way children over come these early notions regard ing age and master other aspects of the complex concept of time is the subject of recently translated book, The Child's Conception of Time, by the Swiss psychologist, Jean Piaget.

title: Former Sioux City Manager Named to Top Newark Post
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10 (AP)  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson an nounced today that he has named Cornelius Bodine Jr., 54 years old, former city man ager of Sioux City, Iowa, to be Newark Business Administrator.

title: Sadat Must Choose Between Obvious Risks
How to Win a Million
description: New York State's public edu cation bill is a big one, $4bil lion a year, and one of the ways the state has contrived to finance this need is monthly lotteries. Ticketsthey cost $1 for a top prize of $100,000  have been selling at a rate of about 50 million a year. This has produced $25million to $29million annu ally for education, which is a lot of money but still far from what the state needs.

title: Nixon Seeks New Path to Indochina Peace
description: WASHINGTONThere is some thing about the autumn of Amer ican election years that enlivens the diplomacy surrounding the war in Vietnam. In 1964, 1966, 1968 and now again in 1970, Washington and Hanoi have re defined their positions, sent out new probes and, on one occa sion, even struck a bargain as they vied for the sympathies of the American electorate, whose tolerance of the war they recog nized as probably the most im portant variable in the negotia tions.

title: The Passion Of Robert Bronson
description: Mr. Alonso's springy novel of ideas calls to mind The Last Puritan, another philo sophical examination of an ex tinct habit of mind. Boston, Brahminism and an anachro nistic hero link the two books But Santayana's Oliver Alden really is a puritan. Alonzo's Robert Bronson, the last great New England transcendenta list, is a transcendentalist in reverse. His rarefied vision is diabolical, not celestial. At the novel's dark vortex are the in stability, the uncertainty, the flux and nothingness that char acterize the postmodern out look.

title: Oregon State Wins, 3121, Capitalizing on Utah Errors
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 10 (UPI)Oregon State, down by 15 points late in the third period, rallied behind its third string quarterback, Jim Kil martin, to whip Utah, 3121, in an international football game today.

title: Admirers in London Unveil Freud Statue Near Former Home
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  A statue of Sigmund Freud was unveiled here last week near where the psychoanalyst lived and worked after he came to England from Aus tria in 1938. He died the following year.

title: Beame Foresees No Need To Invoke Payless Paydays
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he did not believe that payless paydays for city employes would be necessary. He said that belttightening would be necessary, but that the city's fiscal condition was sound and that the city has never de faulted on its bond payments and this policy will and must be continued.

description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Oct. 10 (AP) The University of Wyoming broke a threegame losing streak today, racking up a 166 victory over Colorado State University.

description: THE DRIVER'S SEAT, by Muriel Spark. A teasing, enigmatic mystery story of a spinster on holiday who meets a series of men and choosesor does she?the agent of her destruction.

title: Peking Is Continuing to Regard Chen Yi as Its Foreign Minister
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 10 For eign envoys in Peking who in quired on Communist China's anniversary Oct. 1 about Chen Yi were told that he is still For eign Minister, although he has not acted as such for almost two years.

description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10 (AP)Prime Minister Heath pledged today to reassert Britain's world influence begin ning with active new roles in Southeast Asia, the Middle East, Africa and Europe.

description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 10Base ball's 67th World Series opened in rousing fashion today when the Baltimore Orioles hit three home runs and defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 43.

title: F.D. A. TO CURB USE OF CATTLE ADDITIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration and the nation's cattle men are initiating a joint program to curb residues of hormones and other growth stimulants in the human food supply.

title: Pistol Pete Now Is Up Against the Pros
description: AWHILE back, Pete Maravich the 22yearold basketball won der who will lay his $2million talents on the line next Saturday in his first regularseason professional gamerevealed that he had been of fered the lead in a Hollywood movie to be entitled Drive. It was going to be the story of a college star who hits the skids. He even rapes a girl. It would have been a real nice pic ture for my image.

title: Celeste Piderit Wed to Lawyer
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Child Jesus in Richmond Hill, Queens, was the setting yesterday noon for the marriage of Miss Celeste Mary Piderit, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Freder ick William Piderit Jr., to Lawrence Patrick Murphy Jr. son of Lawrence Patrick Murphy, Kings County As semblyman from the 42d District, and Mrs. Murphy of Brooklyn.

title: INVICTUS CAPTURES NORTHPORT REGATTA
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 10 Herman Willy's Invictus was first home and first on cor rected time today to capture Division I honors in the Last Chance Regatta for TriClubs Y.R.A. cruising yachts on Long Island Sound.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Bombing of Courthouse Here
description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation joined yesterday in an investigation of an earlymorn ing explosion that caused ex tensive damage to a courthouse in Long Island City, Queens, and the Federal Aviation Ad ministration tightened security at airports around the country after a series of bomb threats.

title: Notre Dame Scores Over Army, 51 to 10
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 10 Notre Dame's mighty legions ran up a record score on the outmanned Army team today, winning 5110 before a capacity crowd of 59,075 on a golden afternoon in northern Indiana.

title: Unveilings
description: FRIEDMANDr. Max and Ray. The unveil ing of the monument in loving memory of Dr. Max and Ray Friedman will take place Sunday, October 18, at 2 PM at Linden Hills Cemetery, Metropolitan Ave. Queens, Plot III. No postponement. All relatives and friends Invited.

title: Suicide of a Czech Poet Disturbs Prague Circles
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 10 Reuters) The suicide of a poetStanis lav K. Neumann, who took his life in a political protest Sept. 18has shocked cultural and political circles here as much as the protest suicide of a student Jan Palach, 21 months ago.

title: Sonmy In Court
description: It is nearly two and a half years now since that March morning in 1968 when American troops of the Americal Divi sion's Task Force Barker at tacked the village of Sonmy in South Vietnam, stayed a few hours and left behind burning houses and crops and, allegedly, about 500 dead men, women and children in one of the village's subhamlets. And it is nearly year since news of what has come to be called the Sonmy massacre broke with shocking impact.

title: Pennsylvania Show Opening on Friday Starts Ball Rolling
description: The Pennsylvania National, which gets under way Friday in Harrisburg, ushers in the annual fall indoor horse show circuitthe biggest on the continent. The Pennsyl vania National will run inrougn Mt. 24. the tollow ing week the Washington International will be held. After that the National Horse Show here is scheduled from Nov. 3 through 10. Then the car avan moves to Toronto for the Royal Winter Fair show, the last on the circuit.

title: Paul Schreier, 34, Executive Of A.B.C.TV, Dies in Crash
description: Paul R. Schreier, director of programing administration of the American Broadcasting Company television network, was killed in an automobile accident on Friday evening in Greenfield, Mass.

title: M.T.A. Seeking $1Billion Under a New Federal Act
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority will seek $1bil lion in Federal aid for city sub way and Long Island Railroad improvements under the $3.1 billion urban masstransit act passed by Congress last week.

title: REBUFF TO YOUTH SEEN IN TAX PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 John W. Gardner, the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the Government's planned re view of the taxexempt status of public interest firms could further discourage young peo ple from believing in peaceful change.

title: TALKS IMMINENT ON SPACE LINKUP
description: Soviet and American space engineers are expected to meet in late October or early No vember to discuss ways of standardizing space craft of the two nations so that their astronauts could join each other in earth orbital flights.

title: Kentucky Town Awaiting Growth Through $22Million Mountain Excavation
description: PIKEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9 This tiny Appalachian back woods town is about to dig up a mountain, dump 16million cubic yards of it into the steep valleys that have blocked the town from the outside world and hemmed in its growth, and construct a 10to12story gov ernment building on a drained riverbed.

title: Fifty years of rebellion
description: Tim Pat Coogan, editor of Ireland's most nationalist daily newspaper, the Irish Press of Dublin, has acquired something of a reputation for rushing in where wiser men fear to tread. Irishmen who wish to live in their own country and play some part in its public life traditionally fight shy of writ ing anything that smacks of the controversial. A few literary ar tists of distinction are excep tions to this rule, but they have long resigned themselves to the fate of being ignored or dis torted outside literary circles. One or two may go farther than this, but that is all.

title: BALDWIN  WALLACE TOPS HOFSTRA, 2416
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Oct. 10  The running of Bill Lund and the kicking of Mark Heaton sparked BaldwinWallace to a 246 victory over Hofstra to night.

title: 6 Manhattan Harriers Tie For First in Rout of lona
Joseph Shull 3d, Rosalind Lanier Marry in Jersey
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oct. 10Miss Rosalind Vereen Lanier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Huguley Lanier Jr., was married here this afternoon to Joseph Rush Shull 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shull Jr. of Charlotte, N. C. The ceremony was per formed in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Her bert Cooper, who was as sisted by the Rev. Robert Hayden of Charlotte.

title: ITALIAN DIVORCE BILL ASSAILED BY VATICAN
description: ROME, Oct. 10The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Ro mano said today that the di vorce bill approved by the Ital ian Senate last night was con trary to the law of God and to the real interests of the family.

title: Lindsay Reflects Disputes Between City and Courts
description: In criticizing the court sys tem, Mayor Lindsay has made public a feud that has long been raging between the city admin istration and the judicial ad ministration.

title: Unit Prices: Do They Work?
description: The Benner Tea Company in Burlington, Iowa, which last June became the first foodstore chain to install unitpricing, reported last week that it had set sales records under the system at a minimal cost.

title: Brenda Kopf Wed To Anthony Helies
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct., 10  Miss Brenda Christy Kopf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph C. Kopf of Great Neck and Mattituck, was married here this after noon to Anthony Meade Helies, son of Mrs. Elizabeth S. Dorsey of Brooklyn and the late Wallace F. Helies. The Rev. Gary Maier per formed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: German Book Fair Shows New Trend
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany Oct. 7  Peter Haertling, the 39yearold poet and editor in chief of the S. Fischer Verlag, sighed, raised his eyes to the ceiling of booklined office and said mournfully: This has been a fair of actresses, pop singers, famous fliers and obsolete comic strips. I suppose great novels are a thing of the past.

title: Armored Vehicle Crushes Jersey Car, Killing Driver
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 10 (UPI)One person, was killed injured when a 26ton National Guard armored vehicle collided with an automobile on Route 571 and rolled over its top.

title: A Free Clinic for Street People
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. A 20YEAROLD man comes to a clinic in Cambridge on a bum mera bad trip on LSD. Be cause he is frightened and agitated, unable to give a clear history, we ask him if he has a friend in the waiting room. Yes, his best friend is out there. His best friendsthere are two of themare then invited into the consultation room. They are given detailed instructions on how best to bring the patient down from his trip, including the need for at least one person to be with him at all times, to touch him, to reassure him, to ground him in reality. From their understanding and empathy with the patient, one would guess the task is not entirely new to them. As the three are leaving, however, one of the friends turns to me and asks if I know where the patient lives: You see, we have only been his friends since we met him in the waiting room tonight.

title: GOVERNOR SCORED ON AIRPORT PLAN

title: JOBLESS RATE RISES TO 6.5% IN SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 10 Unemployment in Suffolk Coun ty climbed to 6.5 per cent in August, a rate that County La bor Commissioner Lou V. Tem pera called the worst in six years and probably the highest of any county in the state.

title: The Urban Guerrilla Takes a Heavy Toll
description: There are not many of themat most probably no more than a few hundred. They are mobile, creating the illusion of an army by ap pearing on the East coast one day and the West coast the next; they are arrogant, nihilistic, disenchanted with American society and deter mined to destroy it, but with out clear ideas of what will replace it; they are violent, wedded to the gun and the bomb and the Molotov cock tail; they are young and, if white, usually middleclass college dropouts or gradu ates, or, if black, often with better education and greater potential than many fellow ghetto dwellers.

title: PITT'S FIELD GOAL SINKS NAVY, 108

description: New Canaan trounced Trum bull, 620, yesterday with five touchdown passes, a 517yard offense and seven interceptions. It was its 28th straight victory in its continued domination of Connecticut high school foot ball.

title: Designer's choice
description: David Laurence Roth, a designer who spent his early years creating the cos tumes and personal wardrobes of famous divas of the Metropolitan Opera, has in dulged all his pet preferences in his reno vated townhouse. Collecting and shopping for antiques, an avocation that coincides with his profession, has accounted for the quality of the furnishings and the variety of his collections. Red, his favorite color, is used generously in the living room; there, and throughout the house, lighting and color schemes have been planned to flatter Roth's guests, since partygiving is another of his great enjoyments.

title: Agnew Called Ineffective
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct 10 Vice President Agnew is nar rowing the base of support for the Republican party and prov ing to be an ineffective political weapon in the view of Senator Fred R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, former Democratic national chairman.

title: CAIRO MAY REJECT TRUCE EXTENSION
description: CAIRO, Oct. 10Foreign Min ister Mahmoud Riad declared today that the United Arab Re public would not renew the 90 day ceasefire with Israel, which expires Nov, 5, unless the Is raelis agreed to take part in the peace Mitsion of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations rap resentative, and announced their readiness to carry out the Se curity Council resolution of Nov. 22, 1967, on the Middle East conflict.
