description: David A. Haken, a lawyer and a former Long Island news paperman, died on Thursday in Queens General Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 8410 Main Street, Kew Gardens, Queens.

The Public Utility Commis sion chairman, George I. Bloom, said Thursday that the original route for the 500 kilovolt line had been opposed by residents and invironmental and historic groups.

title: O.E.O. Approves Grant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Office of Economic Op portunity has approved a $330,000 grant to the Opportu nities Industrialization Centers National Institute in Philadel phia. The institute will deliver training and technical assist ance to 25 centers throughout the country by training and placing unemployed and under employed persons in a variety of jobs. There are centers in Camden, N.J., and the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Kaser, ExS.C.C.A. Director, Dodges Specifics of New Job
description: Perhaps it's because the season is nearly over and there is little else to talk about. In any case, few events this year have evoked more needless fuss, rumor mongering and confusion than the resignation of Jim Kaser as director of professional racing in the Sports Car Club of America. Kas er, a charming man, is the most influential per sonage in Amer ican road racing. Judging by all the busy phone lines in the racing community, you'd think it was the Secretary of State retiring during some criti cal international negotiations rather than a guy changing jobs.

title: How Mother cast her shadow
description: There is a selfconsciousness in the novel these days, a preoccupation with style that calls attention to itself and is inevitably parodistic of other works of fiction. Yet in a Nabokov, a Barth, a Bellow, a Mailer, one does not feel that the reference to experience has become more re mote because we are being delib erately reminded of other books. Parody in these writers, on the con trary, strikes at the roots of style the human behavior and attitudes that underlie all verbal postures. Is Peter De Vries this sort of parodist? He is our most gifted takeoff man whose literary parodies are the hu miliation of anyone who merely criticizes. But there have been occa sions when his novels have seemed smothered or aborted by this faculty as in The Tents of Wickedness, which we read more for its series of mimetic exercises, comic imitations of Marquand, Faulkner, Fitzgerald and others, than for anything else.

title: RECALL ELECTION DIVIDES PASADENA
description: PASADENA. Oct. 10  Pasa dena's unified school district will hold the first recall elec tion in its 96year history Tues day, at a time when the com munity is polarized over the issue of busing for integration.

title: Janis Joplin I9431970
description: GOD, what a year this is turning out to be. As if the mass vio lence at Kent State weren't enough, we now seem to be caught in an al most hypnotic string of per sonal violence. Three weeksago, Jimi Hendrix, and now Janis Joplin. The king and the queen of the gloriously selfexpressive music that came surging out of the late sixties are dead, the victims, directly or indirectly, of the very real physical excesses that were part of the world that surrounded them.

title: Browne: TaxExempts Dean

As head of the investment securities division of the country's largest bank, he oversees holdings of some $2.24 billion of state and local government securities.

title: North China Beach Resort Gives Relief in Summer From the Heat of Peking

The wind blows, the waves curl over one another and, far out, the fishing boats with their gray sails move elusively on the edge of vision.

description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. S. Joseph Car ris on Sept. 27 at University Hospital. The child has been named Joanne Michele. Mr. Carris, a personnel consult ant, is president of Electron ics Personnel in Newark and New York.

title: China Refugees Still Enter Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Despite in tense land and water patrols by the Chinese Communists, thou sands of refugees continue to arrive every year in Hong Kong, most of them by swim ming.

title: The Abduction Of Virginia Lee
description: When a man has a sauna in his custombuilt airplane, and a private railroad car costing $1,835,912, be is apt to lose sight of the more pedestrian details of daily living. The Croesus to whom this pelt be longs is more attached to Vir ginia Lee (his Pullman) than to his paramour of many years standing. This male scorn up sets her quite a bit, and her fury is the driving force be hind some hellish machinery of revenge, which the author con structs with his customary in genuity. O'Rourke fans, me in cluded, may miss the rich trompe roeil atmosphere of his turn  of  the  century re creations. The Abduction of Virginia Lee, though a bit arid in climate, still carries a satis factory cargo of baroque mis behavior.

Then, Miss Sullivan sang and Mr. Hines played piano in a spacious second floor recep tion room of the Overseas Press Club, 54 West 40th Street.

description: UNION CITY, N. J., Oct. 11  Next Sunday Representa tive Dominick V. Daniels, the Democratic incumbent in New Jersey's 14th Congressional Dis trict, will be 62 years old. And I'm running scared for reelec tion, he says, despite the fact that he has won easily six times in the east.

title: Hippies Moving In on a Coastal Paradise in Hawaii
description: KEALAKEKUA, Hawaii  Randy and Diana, both 20 years old, both full of the joys of youth and the illu don of being without cares, had taken up station at the foot of a utility pole at the end of the fence that divides the property of the First Ha waiian Bank branch from the Buddist Temple. They chewed on a loaf of bread, nibbled at boiled potatoes, and sip ped from a half gallon of apple juice. She had long hair, a clear complexion, and white teeth in that even, perfect line that bespeaks the services of a skillful ortho dontist. He had long blond hair, a scraggily beard, a fuzzy mustache and a kind smile.

title: Loyalty Oath Suit Filed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  The American Civil Liberties Union said today that it had filed a Federal Court suit to halt the United States Passport Office from administering loyalty oath to passport appli cants. The A.C.L.U. said that all applicants were required to raise their right hands and swear to the contents of the oath, although, it said, there is no authorization for it.

Rockefeller's suc cessful and expensive 1966 re election campaign was one of the major subjects of a book that has been read and reread by political professionals in the last couple of years, The New Politics  the Expanding Tech nology of Political Manipula tion. by James M. Perry. title: More Is Less

Gal braith gave us the phrase private af fluence, public squalor a mere dozen years ago, that picture of our society struck a convincing note but did not really alarm many of the affluent. They might have been aware that pub lic transportation was a disgrace in the United States, that cities lacked parks and facilities of every kind, but none of that greatly disturbed the easy current of their lives.

title: 'Great White Hope' Brought to Screen
description: Howard Sackler's The Great White Hope," which won the Pulitzer Prize, the Drama Critics Prize and the Antoinette Perry Award as the best drama of the 1968-1969 Broadway season, never was much of a play.The movie that Martin Ritt has made from it, which opened yesterday at the Baronet, is necessarily limited by the nature of the original text. "The Great White Hope" is a polemical, black Passion Play about Jack Jefferson, a lightly fictionalized version of Jack Johnson who, in 1908, knocked out Tommy Burns of Canada to become the first black heavyweight champion of the world.The film, like the play, progresses in terms of highly stylized scenes that dramatize Jack Jefferson's initial triumph, his subsequent persecution and his humiliations as if they were the Stations of the Cross.Jack Jefferson, according to Mr. Sackler, is a victim not only of the bigotries of his time, but also of his own completely romantic notion that he is a private person. After he flaunts his white mistress, thus compounding the insult to white America represented by his championship, he is convicted on a trumped - up Mann Act charge, forced into exile in Europe, where he is reduced to playing Uncle Tom to his mistress's Little Eva in a Budapest beerhall, and finally to Mexico, where, in final frustration, he denies the love that originally sustained him.The style of the play, which the film faithfully retains, is most reminiscent of New York's old Group Theater productions. There are choruses of evil (the members of the boxing establishment as they conspire to get Jack to throw a championship bout) and choruses of good (Jack's friends and family, headed by Beah Richards who plays Jack's mother with hair of Scarsdale blue). There's even a mysterious soothsayer who confronts Jack, at the height of his early success, with predictions of doom.As the movie progresses, the tableaus become increasingly overwrought, leading to the climactic one in Juarez, in which the body of a lady, who has just committed suicide by jumping down a well, is hauled on screen like one of Medea's children. That Mr. Sackler's talents cannot support his tragic design is apparent from the fact that one's sympathies are not as much concerned with the poor lady as with the poor peons, who still must use the well into which the lady so thoughtlessly tossed herself."The Great White Hope" is one of those liberal, well-meaning, fervently uncontroversial works that pretend to tackle contemporary problems by finding analogies at a safe remove in history. In spite of Muhammad Ali, who was quoted two years ago as saying of the play, "You just change the time, date and the details and it's about me!", Mr. Sackler's play and screenplay are too smug, too full of stereotypes to be provocative as drama. Similarly, his method is too pretentious to create the kind of fundamentalist fervor that might prompt one to interrupt the production by shouting an occasional "Yes, Lord!" or "Amen!"However, having said all this, I'd like to add that the film contains a performance that makes the windy, otherwise empty movie seem inhabited, if not by life, at least by art. James Earl Jones, who re-creates the role of Jack Jefferson he played on Broadway, is marvelous to watch, combining heroic physical presence, technique and (to me) a completely mysterious way of projecting intelligence, so that the character commands attention even when the drama doesn't.There's also an initially charming performance by Jane Alexander as Jack's mistress (who is eventually defeated by the hysterics of the script) and good if conventional ones by Lou Gilbert, Hal Holbrook, Robert Webber and the late Chester Morris.Mr. Ritt has staged most of the film in the only way possible, as if all the events were locked inside a huge proscenium arch. The fight sequences are played like dumb shows to the accompaniment of dream - like cheers. The camera seldom looks beyond the sets to a real world, and then the real world is filmed as if it were in theatrical disguise.In this manner the director has served his star exceedingly well, avoiding the usual fate of the epic theatrical performance that becomes grotesque on screen, where, after all, man is always seen in the same dimensions as his settings.It may not be entirely fair to mention, but, throughout "The Great White Hope," I kept wondering how I might respond to a movie, made on a similar scale, that dared touch on some really controversial issues, including the war, the draft, the Black Muslims, black separatism, and all those other things that make Ali such a thorny public person today.

title: Bow and Arrow Mishap
description: BROOKFIELD, Vt., Oct. 11 (AP)Aldo Pedudzzi, 61 years old, of Barre, was injured yes terday while bow and arrow hunting on the first day of the season. He was shot in the face, chest and arms, the police said. He was reported to be in satis factory condition at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin.

description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (UPI) The recent brush fires in Southern California caused $8.8million damage in Los Angeles County, a survey showed today. The survey said that 295 homes were destroyed and 29 sustained some damage. The survey was made by the County Engineer's office and the Los Angeles Building De partment.

Dewey of New York called to say that the top Eisen hower advisers thought Mr. Nix on should resign as the Re publican candidate for Vice President.

title: Sharing the Blame
description: There has been an alarming rise in criminal arrests in New York City in the past several years, as Mayor Lind say notes in his statement to the administrative board of the Judicial Conference. Felony arrests have increased 50 per cent since 1964; misdemeanor arrests have jumped 75 per cent. The underlying causes for thispervasive poverty, inadequate employment opportunities, failures in education deserve redoubled attention. In addition, the old structures and handmedown criminal pro cedures require change.

title: FAVORED PARK TOP RUNS 3D IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 11  The Brit ish riding champion, Lester Pig gott, was roundly jeered at Longchamp today when his mount, Park Top, failed miser ably in what was to have been only a warmup race for the Laurel International in the United States next month.

title: Bazaar for Mentally III
description: To support its wide range of services for the mentally ill, the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will hold a benefit bazaar on Saturday at its headquarters, 30 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, from 2 to 5 P.M. Jewelry, clothing, books, records, sewing ma terials, handmade items and bricabrac will be sold. Mrs. William Renner is chairman of the bazaar, tickets for which may be obtained at the door.

The play is described as a comedy about a young girl with a Fidel Castro fixation. The cast con sists of Marian Hailey, Terry Kiser and Raul Julia. James Burrows, the son of Abe Bur rows, Broadway directorplay wright, has been engaged to di rect. Jeff Britton is the pro ducer.

description: Recommendations made Sat urday by Mayor Lindsay for sweeping changes in the admin istration of criminal justice in the city were praised yester day by Bernard Botein, presi dent of the Association of the Bar of New York City.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11 The Nixon Administration said today that the United States may have to embark on a tre mendous increase in defense spending unless accords are reached with the Soviet Union in negotiations on the limita tion of strategic arms and in other areas.

title: RAIDERS SET BACK BRONCOS BY 3523
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 11 (UPI)Daryle Lamonica threw four touchdown passes and set up a fifth score today as the Oakland Raiders scored their first victory and handed the Denver Broncos their first de feat, 3523.

title: FLASHES PUZZLE SPACE SCIENTISTS
description: CONSTANCE, West Germany, Oct, 10The International As tronautical Congress ended here this weekend with agreement on many problems, operational and scientific, but with widely differing views on one question: What were those flashes of light in the eyes of Apollo astronauts?

title: CZECH PIANIST GIVES FIRST RECITAL HERE
description: Antonin Kubalek, a Czech pianist who settled in Toronto two years ago, made his United States debut at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon playing Haydn's Sonata in E flat, Jana cek's In the Mist, Bach's Par tita in E minor and Hindemith's 1922 Suite for Piano.

title: CAPITAL WILL TEST AIR TRAFFIC PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) A revised form of a plan for controlling air traffic near air ports is to be tried again this month. The original plan failed in its first test in this area Aug. 20.

title: Red Sox Send Tony Conigliaro To Angels in 6Player Trade
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (UPI) Tony Conigliaro, the Boston Red Sox outfielder who made a dramatic comeback two sea sons ago, was traded tonight with Jerry Moses, a catcher, and Ray Jarvis, a pitcher, to the California Angels for Jarvis Tatum, an outfielder; Ken Ta tum, a pitcher, and Doug Grif fin, a minor league infielder.

title: Electronic War With Israel Called a Possibility by Sadat
description: CAIRO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Acting President Anwar Sadat said today that the United Arab Republic was facing the pos sibility of an electronic war with Israel and would be ready for it.

title: VIKINGS TRIUMPH OVER BEARS, 240
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) Alan Page, Minnesota's 255 pound defensive terror, lum bered 65 yards with a recovered fumble and Gary Cuozzo's pin point passing further stunned the Chicago Bears as the Vi kings recorded a 240 victory to day.

title: Daladier, Signer of Munich Pact, Dies at 86
description: PARIS, Oct. 11Edouard Daladier, one of the most prom inent leaders of the prewar Third Republic, died here yes terday, an almost forgotten man. He was 86 years old.

title: Makarova's Choice of U.S. Is Logical
description: Natalya Makarova's de cision to join the American Ballet Theater for a year is important both to Natalya Makarova and to the Ameri can Ballet Theater. Born in Leningrad 30 years ago, Miss Makarova was trained by Leningrad's Kirov Ballet School. Until her defection to the West in August, she was An one of the two or Appraisal three most ad mired ballerinas of the Kirov Bal let, and she is one of the leading dancers of her gen eration anywhere in the world. The interest caused by her arrival in Western ballet has been considerable, if only because very few Soviet dancers have previ ously joined Western ballet companies.

title: Cablegram From Solzhenitsyn
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11 (Reu ters)  A cablegram received here today from Mr. Solzhen itsyn said he intended to come to Stockholm to receive the Nobel Prize personally from King Gustav VI Adolf on Dec. 10.

title: European Companies Wary of Backing U.S. Ventures
description: PARIS, Oct. 11The Italian Olivetti Company came close to biting off more than it could chew in acquiring the Under wood Company, the American typewriter manufacturer, and had the full extent of Under wood's difficulties been appar ent beforehand, Olivetti would probably not have made the investment.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

title: CADILLAC JACK WINS AS REGULAR HUNTER
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 11  Cadillac Jack, owned and ridden by Torn Dembinski, scored in every class today to win the regular working hunter championship with 11 points at the Greenbrier Farms Horse Show.

title: Sepaiatists Earlier Weapons: Bombs, Dynamite and Robbery
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 11  The Front for the Liberation of Quebec, the organization re sponsible for two political kid nappings in Montreal this week, has been terrorizing this city intermittently for seven years.

description: The SCM Corporation intro duced today a new American made portable calculator.
