description: Market Averages

title: JAMES U. NORRIS, 87, HOSPITAL EXECUTIVE
description: James U. Norris, tormer superintendent of Woman's Hospital, which is now part of St. Luke's Hospital Center, died at the center Friday after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 412 West 110th street.

title: Advertising: How to Buy Space in Russia
description: It you want to run an ad is any of some 200 Soviet tech nical journals, see Saul Radin. As a matter of fact, if you want to run an ad in a So viet newspaper, or rent post er space, or run television or radio spots in Moscow, Len ingrad and Kiev, Saul Radin is the man to see.

title: The Price of Excellence
description: The director of one of the United Hospital Fund's member voluntary hospitals said recently, Teaching hos pitals, even more than any than any other, a r e tradition ally committed to excellence: excellence in patient care, in medical education and in re search. There is a price that must be paid for excellence. If great voluntary hospitals continue to excel they will continue to attract young doctors and old doctors of great skill and dedication, who will make their con tribution to medicine and the nation will benefit. We are now training young resi dents and interns who will be your doctors and your children's doctors. If we are forced to embark on a program of cutbacks and lowered medical standards, they will be learning what we choose to call bad medi cine, meaning anything less than the very best we know how to do for the patient. Help 56 excellent hospitals continue their excellent care of patientswith a gift to the United Hospital Fund, 3 East 54th Street, New York, N. Y. 1002.

title: Newsbov Slain as Prowler
description: ANNANDALE, Va., Oct. 12 (AP)A 14yearold boy deliv ering newspapers was shot to death early today by a young man who thought he heard prowler tampering with his car, the Fairfax County police reported. The authorities said William Psimas, 18 years old, was charged with homicide in the death of Todd McKinney, Washington Post delivery boy.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON SECRET ACCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) The House gave final ap proval today to a bill designed to stop the use of secret for eign bank accounts to evade taxes and to finance illegal ac tivities.

title: ARMY TO SPOTCHECK IN EUROPE FOR BIAS
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germa ny, Oct. 13  Gen. James H. Polk, commander in chief of the United States Army in Europe, disclosed today that flying squads of Army investigators would soon begin making un announced checks of, company and battalionsize units to insure that there is no dis crimination in this command.

title: Small Plus for Free Speech
description: The cause of civilized political discourse has gotten small push forward from Arthur J. Goldberg, the Demo craticLiberal candidate for Governor. His swift removal of two staff aides who heckled Governor Rockefeller on the Lower East Side was a welcome repudiation of tactics that prevent campaigners or anyone else from getting their message to the public.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: Syracuse 4, Nashville 1

title: Black Hawks Sign Stapleton
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP)Pat Stapleton, a defenseman, signed a threeyear contract with the Chicago Black Hawks today, ending what turned out to be a brief holdout. Stapleton, who missed the Hawk opener Sun day, had previously been side lined with a knee injury.

title: Starving Peasants Loot Food Supplies in Brazil
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  Hundreds of starving peasants looted food depots today in northeastern Ceara state, which has been hit by a severe drought since April.

title: Strange Illness Afflicts California Sea Lions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (UPI)Ten more California sea lions struggled onto beaches today apparently suffering from a mysterious malady that has killed at least 25 of them M a month.

title: Saigon Is Said to Plan New Offer to Vietcong
description: LONDON, Oct. 137 (AP) The South Vietnamese Gov ernment plans to offer the Vietcong a new basis for a Political settlement soon, United States sources report ed tonight.

title: Books of The Times
description: For a while there, I would have said that Peter S. Prescott's A World of Our Own is not an Indulgencethat 400 pages on a year in the life of a single Ivy League preparatory school is not too much. For like Prescott (Choate 53 and book reviewer for Look magazine), I, too, am singularly drawn to my acquiescent highschool past and intrigued by micro cosms. So I became completely involved with his journey up the Merritt Parkway to Wallingford, Conn, where Choate situated, and fascinated with his chronicle of an institution fighting to preserve the past and stave off the present.

title: REED'S 35 POINTS HELP BEAT BOSTON
description: In one notsoeasy lesson at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York Knicker bockers learned what the New York Jets and New York Mets learned before them: that de fending a championship can turn out to be harder than win ning it in the first place.

title: BRONX LANDLORDS AND UNION REACH ACCORD IN STRIKE
description: An agreement to end the strike of Bronx apartment house workers was announced last night by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board. The accord was reached on the strike's 29th day.

title: Ilana Vered, Israeli Pianist, Plays French Program
description: In a way, Ilana Vered, the young Israeli pianist, played a French program in Alice Tully Hall on Monday eve ning. The first half of the program was devoted to Ravel and Faure, beyond which Frenchness cannot go. On the last half of the pro gram she turned her atten tion to the Op. 72 of Moritz Moszkowskithe 15 Etudes de virtuosite. Moszkowski, Germanborn but of Polish parents, spent so many years in Paris, where he died in 1925, that many considered him French.

title: Fiji Becomes 127th U.N. State
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13Fiji became the 127th member state of the United Nations today by acclamation of the General Assembly. The Security Council unanimously recommended the membersthip on Saturday.

description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 13 Exhausted by two weeks of military and political upheav als, Bolivians reopened their schools and shops today, try ing to ignore widespread fears that, any fresh spark could ig nite civil war.

title: BUSING FOES CITE HIGH COURT RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Southern lawyers told the Su preme Court today that the Brown v. Board of Education school desegregation decision in 1954 was being violated by integration plans that assigned students to schools by race to achieve racial mixing.

description: The Paper Handlers Union reached tentative agreement yesterday with the city's four major daily newspapers on a new threeyear contract cover ing about 350 employes.

title: CONCERT MINGLES STYLES OF DANCE
description: An anthology of dance works is as rewarding and at the same time as mildly unsatisfying as any other anthology. One is pleased with the variety but longs for a thematic line. Last night at the New School, Chor eoconcerts was beligerently nonthematic in its selection of choreographers: Ethel Winter, this Solomons Jr., Charlotte Honda and Carol Conway.

title: The 747 Argument
description: Air travelers can hardly be blamed if they are puzzled and apprehensive about the issue involved in the current argument between the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Aviation Administration. The debate is fundamentally about whether the Boeing 747 is a safe airplane. It was touched off by a nasty scare that befell passengers and crew on a jumbo jet taking off from San Francisco last month, when a turbine wheel in one engine flew apart and caused extensive damage before the plane landed safely.

title: Article 1  No Title

title: Warm Day Forecast
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) Variable cloudiness with some sunshine in the afternoon and high temperatures near 80 are forecast for tomorrow's fourth game of the World Series. The Weather Bureau forecasts south erly winds 5 to 15 miles an hour, with a 20 per cent prob ability of rain.

A diverse ethnic pop ulation, with about 20 per cent ItalianAmerican, nearly 20 per cent Puerto Rican, more than 10 per cent Negro, nearly 10 per cent Polish American, about 5 per cent Jewish, plus pockets of Irish, Ukranians, Syrians and others.

They gave the Redlegs nothing on this occasion, including the right time.

title: Encouraging Murder
description: America is embarked on a rampage against life, potentially far more ex tensive, and already far sicker, than any of the great genocides of history. This genocide has many weapons: government lifeprevention campaigns, sterilization, proposals for genetic manipulation, euthanasia. But the most flagrant at the momentbecause the killing is direct and open and lawful is abortion.

Item, Swedish politician talking Vietnam was not an issue in the election campaign. No body would de fend United States policy. item: American banker based In Europe: I have never heard so much pessimism and unease ex pressed about the United States. Item: Sign in window of Swiss hairdressing shop: Our wigs made from Swiss hair.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 13 (Reuters)The United States Command reported to day that 10 Americans had been killed and 24 wounded in two days of fighting.

title: The Wrong Short Cut
description: Chalk up another victory for Vietnamization. The Saigon constabulary, in a grand swordsintoplowshares gesture, is using bayonets to cut local youths unpatri otically long hair. Such an extension of police activity will undoubtedly be the envy of those American disciples of law and order who have long believed that permis siveness is the last refuge of scoundrels.

At the airport, the President spoke kindly of James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for Senator.

title: The Canary Has Fallen Silent
description: In 1857 John Stuart Mill argued that a stationary state (by which he meant constant population size and a constant stock of physical wealth) was both necessary and desirable. Dur ing the century since Mill wrote most economists have argued that the sta tionary state was either unnecessary, undesirable, or both.

title: Bettor Not Alone in Losing on Trotters
description: YONKERS, Oct. 13It has been estimated that only about 10 per cent of the owners of standardbreds profit from their investments on trotters and pacers. Among those who belong in the 90 per cent, or losing category, are Sidney Roth of New York and associates.

title: In the 13th District, Podell Has Little Competition
description: An interviewer recently asked Representative Bertram L. Podell what he thought of his three opponents in the election for the 13th Congres sional District of Brooklyn Mr. Podell looked perplexed. Who are they? he asked.

title: Dr. Marguerite Richards Dies; Professor at Douglass College
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 13Dr. Marguerite Lentz Richards, professor of French emeritus at Douglass Cobeget, died at her sister's home in Lembach, France, on Friday after a long illness. She was 66 years old and had returned to France, where she was born, after retiring last June. She was the widow of Newton W. Richards, an architect. Before joining Douglass, she taught at Earlham College in Richmond, Ind., and at Penn sylvania State University.

Ottinger said he felt that he had the edge over his opponents in the race for the United States Senate. But, he added, Buckley wins if Agnew is successful and Goodell splits the Democratic vote.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Contrary to widespread public im pression the major problems besetting higher education in America today are not those associated with violence but the decline of academic standards: The general public is probably unaware that a growing proportion of college students are subject to fewer and fewer requirements and less and less evaluation than ever before.

title: Theater: Orton's Butler
description: Someone, somewhere, has surely done a doctoral thesis on maladjusted audiences. It is one of the pressing prob lems of today's theaters. Summed up, it means getting the wrong audience at the wrong time into the wrong theater to see the wrong play. Unfortunately  like unal loyed insanity of the very nastiest kindit can happen to the nicest people.

title: Author Sues for $3Million
description: Lois Goulds author of the novel Such Good friends, has filed a $3million malprac4 tice suit against St. Luke's Hos pital, contending that her 44 yearold husband died in April, 1966, as a result of the neg ligent, careless use of an anes thesia in surgery. Mrs. Gould alleged in her suit in State Su preme Court here that her late husband, Philip Benjamin, novelist and former reporter for The New York Times, died after being administered the anesthesia halothone. A pre liminary hearing on the suit by Mrs. Gould, who has remar ried, will be heard Tuesday.

title: New Orleans Fire Kills 2

title: Moose on Loose Upstate

description: The United States Weather Bureau has changed its name to the National Weather. Serv ice.

title: Link of Lloyds Bank Europe And BOLSA Effective Feb. 1
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP)The Bank of London and South America (BOLSA) and Lloyds Bank Europe announced today the details of a merger, which would allotw expended opera tions in Europe and Latin Amer ica. The new bank will begin operations next Feb. 1.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC HOUR OFFERS SAINTSAENSI
description: SaintSans died at the age of 86 in 1921, and in that year he produced three sonatas, one each for oboe, clarinet and bas soon, all with piano. They were written for friends of his who taught at the Paris Conserva toire. They turned up in Jens Nygaard's One Hour of Cham ber Music at Carnegie Recital Hall late Monday afternoon, and they show the composer's expert craftsmanship and occa sional inspiration to have per sisted to the end of his long life.

title: Northeast G. O.P. Nominees. Are Troubled Right and Left
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 13It is no easy thing this fall running for the Senate as a Republi can in a Northeastern state.

title: Foe in Cambodia, Set Back So Far, Keeps Government Guessing
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 13  Highly placed sources here believe that the Viet namese Communist forces, hav ing failed in their initial ob jective of toppling the Govern ment of Premier Lon Nol through widely diffused mili tary pressure on major popula tion centers; are regrouping and are keeping Cambodia guessing on where they will move next.

title: Money
description: Money

title: Prints by Picasso: Summing Up at 89
description: Within a year of his 90th birthday, Picasso no longer surprises, but he continues to amaze. Picasso: Master Printmaker, an exhibition opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, goes back to 1904, beginning with The Frugal Repast, an etching now almost as well known as Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper, and concludes with the set of 347 prints exe cuted by Picasso between March 16 and Oct. 5, 1968, some of which are already as notorious as Fanny Hill. The 347 set is a staggering performance, but the most amazing thing about the show is not Picasso's fe cundity in his old age but his inventive range over the entire stretch of 64 creative years.

title: Madness in Their Method
description: CAIRO  The United States and the Soviet Union are formally committed to end the continuing threat of local or possibly global war by pursuing political settlement of the Palestine question but the methods they employ to achieve this sensible end are mad.

title: SENATORS GIVEN RIGHTS TO FLOOD
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13The Philadelphia Phillies granted the Washington Senators bar gaining rights tonight to Curt Flood, the controversial out fielder who sued baseball for SImillion this year.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the.telephone com pany's time bureau.

title: C.B.S. Earnings Off in Quarter; Volume Hits Peak for 9 Months
description: Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, Inc., showed a decline in earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of this year, but the totals were ex ceeded only by the records es tablished in the late 1969 pe riods, according to a report yesterday by William S. Paley, chairman and Frank Stanton, president.

title: Haber Warns Municipal Unions City Can't Give BasePay Rises
description: The city's Director of Labor Relations said yesterday that the city would be able to give no more than costofliving in creases and fringe benefits to the more than 94,000 employes whose contracts expire Dec. 31. Among the employes are police men, firemen, sanitation work ers, correction officers and social service case workers.

title: SENATORS AMEND EQUAL RIGHTS BILL; IT MAY DIE FOR 70
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Senate added two provisions to the equal rights amendment to day and thus probably ended all chance for enactment of the amendment this year.

title: Panthers Denied Use of Hall
description: WASHISGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)The Black Panther party was turned down yesterday in an effort to obtain the District of Columbia National Guard Armory for its Planned Revo lutionary People's Convention in November.

title: Taping of Cavett's Show Disrupted by Jazz Group
description: A group protesting what they call the dearth of black jazz musicians on television inter rupted the taping of the Dick Cavett Show for more than an hour last night.

description: Belmont Entries

title: MSGR. WILLIAM LANNARY
description: DEAL, N. J., Oct. 13Msgr. William Joseph Lannary, pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here, died in the rectory of the church yesterday. His age was 83.

title: VAIN SEARCH ANGERS IT ALIAN CRIME BOARD
description: ROME, Oct. 13A special commission of the Italian Par liament investigating Mafia ac tivities met today in a mood of outrage over a fruitless far ranging search for a palermo newsman who is believed to be a victim of organized crime.

description: Prices dropped sharply and interest rates climbed yester day in the corporate bond mar ket.

title: Christmas Gift for Pessimists: $588,247 Noah's Ark
description: It's never too early to think about Christmas, according to any merchant worth his price tags and his overhead. And so the catalogues full of presents for everyone from the family's dog to the aunt whomayleavemoney are go ing into the mails with Nei manMarcus's dream book as usual in the lead.

title: CANADIANS SET UP TIE TO RED CHINA AND DROP TAIWAN
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 13Canada and Communist China, after 20 months of negotiations, estab lished diplomatic relations to day. At the same time, Canada broke relations with the Chi nese Nationalist Government on Taiwan.

title: Packaging Prices to Rise
description: The Crown Zellerbach Cor poration announced yesterday in San Francisco that it would increase prices, by amounts ranging up to 6 per cent, on various flexible packaging ma terials of the type used on items like cake mix, cereal, coffee and bread.

title: Marcello, Rackets Suspect, Loses Plea to High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) On a 7 to 2 vote the Su preme Court cleared the way today for a sixmonth jail term for Carlos Marcello, alleged New Orleans rackets figure.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Canada and Communist China established diplomatic relations yesterday after almost two years of negotiations. At the same time, Canada severed her diplomatic ties with the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan. The joint CanadianChinese announcement said that Ottawa noted Communist China's claim to Taiwan, but did not accept it. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Soviet Denial Reiterated
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13The So viet Union today issued its strongest denial to date that it was building a submarine base at Cienfuegos.

title: ORIOLES TOP REDS, LEAD SERIES, 30
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13  Dave McNally hit a grandslam homer and pitched the Baltimore Ori oles to a 93 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today, putting the Orioles within one game of winning the World Series.

title: McLicas Gets Year On Pleading Guilty In Escape Attempt
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13Lpn nie McLucas, the Black Pan ther convicted of conspiring to kill Alex Rackley, pleaded guilty ty today to charges stemming from an attempted jailbreak the day before his trial started here four months ago.

title: COMMANDOS SIGN PACT WITH JORDAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 13 King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, signed an agreement here to night that termed Jordan the main base for the liberation of Palestine and restored a large degree of freedom of action to the commando movement.

description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 13 The Chinese NationalistGovern ment announced today that it was immediately severing dip lomatic relations with. Canada in response to Ottawa's recog nition of Communist China.

title: Down With Escoffier!
description: Before it is too late I urgently pro pose a Diners Liberation Movement. At a time when joylessness has been established as an official life style by the rebel young and their emotional affiliates (e.g., existential philosophers exploring suicide as the most con structive solution to living), it be hooves decadents everywhere to hang on grimly to any experience smacking faintly of pleasure. Eating, for in stance.

title: BROOKLYN BANKS SET TO COMBINE
description: The Greater New York Sav ings Bank and the Flatbush Savings Bank were given au thorization to combine yester day by William T. Dentzer Jr., New York State's Superintend ent of Banks since last spring.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) The Senate voted overwhelm ingly today to denounce the re cent report of the Presidential Commission on Obscenity and Pornography and to reject its major findings.

title: HERO OF 3 GAMES PRAISES HIS CLUB
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (UPI) Brooks Robinson, a hero in all three Baltimore World. Series victories, says he realized last month, that this year's Series would be different from last year's for the Orioles.

title: U.S. Expects No Change In Policy Toward Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Administration officials said today that Canada's decision to extend diplomatic recognition to Communist China was unlikely to affect the basic united states policy toward Peking.

title: U.S. NOW DUBIOUS ON CUBA SUB BASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13LThee Defense Department said today, that new evidence from Cuba made it now appear less likely that the Soviet Union was plan ning to build a Submarine base there.

description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 13 (AP)  Northwest Airlines pilots canceled their threat ened walkout and were flying today.

description: DETROIT, Oct. 13The strike at the General Motors Corpora tion, now in its fifth week: is dampening newcar sales, and not just at G.M.

title: First of 30 World Leaders Land for U. N. Celebration
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13The first of 30 or more presidents and premiers arrived today to participate in the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the United Na tions.

title: Russian Spacemen May Forgo a Visit To Cape Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Sources at the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion said today that two Soviet astronauts due here Sunday for a 10day tour of space bases had not yet accepted an invita tion to visit Cape Kennedy, Fla., and probably would not do so.

title: Alleged Robber Shot in Park
description: An offduty patrolman shot one of two men he said had at tempted to rob him in Central Park yesterday. Patrolman Don ald DiGennaro, said he was walking through the west side of the park in civilian clothes at 10 A.M. near 100th Street when he was jumped by two men. The wounded man, identi fied as Michael Martinez, 19 years old, of 2070 Third Avenue, was taken to Knickerbocker Hospital for treatment of a hip wound and later charged with attempted robbery and posses sion of a dangerous weapon. The weapon turned out to be an imitation pistol. The second as sailant escaped.

title: MRS. HAROLD S. DIEHL
description: Mrs. Julia Mills Diehl died of a heart attack Monday at New York Hospital. She was the wife of Dr. Harold S. Diehl, recently retired senior vice president for research and medical affairs of the American Cancer Society and former dean of the Univer sity of Minnesota School of Medicine. Mrs. Diehl was 77 years old and lived at 11 River side Drive.

title: TV VETO REJECTION GIVEN EVEN CHANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Senate Republican lead er, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, Said today there was about an even chance that the Senate would sustain President Nixon's veto of a bill to limit campaign broadcast spending.

title: HEDY WEST ROAMS FOLK MUSIC WORLD
description: Hedy West comes out of the mountainmusic tradition of northern Georgia, but her con cert Monday night packed in an amazingly wide and deep span of folkmusic development.

description: James F. Tierney, a Federal Communications Commission hearing examiner, rejected yesterday a petition to alter the agenda of the WPIX license hearing.

description: Did you see this? Repre sentative John J. Rooney, Dem ocrat of Brooklyn, exclaimed the other day as he waved an advertisement that appeared that morning in a Washington newspaper.

title: Soviet and France sign Agreement To Deepen Political Consultations
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13President Pompidou and President Nikolai V. Podgorny today signed a FrenchSoviet agreement to extend and deepen political contacts and to hold consulta tions during periods of interna tional tension.

title: U.N. Defeat Seen Again For Peking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13Despite a diplomatic gain in achieving recognition by Canada, Communist China is likely to fall short of United Nations membership this year by just about the same vote as last year, according to opin ions expressed by diplomas here today.

title: A Discharged Aide Still Backs Goldberg
description: Arnold Segarra, whom Ar thur J. Goldberg discharged as a campaign aide on Monday for allegedly heckling Governor Rockefeller, said yesterday that he would continue to work for the election of the Democratic Liberal candidate forGovernor.

title: Cassidy Stops Burnside
description: FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 13 (AP) Bob Cassidy, 163 pounds, of Levittown, L. I., knocked out Johnny Burnside, 160, New York, in 2:02 of the fifth round of their scheduled 10round fight tonight.

title: Stevens Elected President Of Baseball Writers Group
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) Bob Stevens, a baseball writer for the San Francisco Chronicle, was elected president of the Baseball Writers Association of America at its annual meeting last night.

title: Esther Kleinfeld, 72, Dies; Founder of Music School
description: Esther Kleinfeld, founder and director of the Neighbor hood Music School in the Bronx, died Monday after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived at 16 East 169th Street, the Bronx.

title: RIDER WILL START SUSPENSION TODAY
description: Another Baltimore home run was soaring across the televi sion screen in the jockey room at Belmont Park yesterday, and Bobby Woodhouse was sympa thizing with the Cincinnati Reds.

title: 9% CUT PROPOSED INTOVERTY FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Nixon Administration has asked the Office of Economic Opportunity and the Depart ment of Labor to cut their anti poverty and manpower train ing budgets for 197172 by about $350Million, it was learned today.

title: Kretchmer Is Seekingl $1.2Billion
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration asked yesterday for a 1971 1972 capital budget of $1.2 billion, slightly above the $1.1billion sought last year.

title: Showdown on Protectionism
description: After only one hour's deliberation, the Senate Finance Committee has voted 93 to attach the House trade bill to the Social Security bill, and the nation stands in immi nent danger of a return to protectionism.

title: 4 BENDER BROTHERS PLAY STEEL DRUMS
description: Four trim and casual young brothers put on an amazing demonstration, of virtuosity and coordination on the steel drums Sunday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: CAIRO DENIES REPORT ON NASSER'S CHOICE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13 (AP)Reliable diplomatic in formants here reported today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had named Zakariya Mohieddin as his successor shortly before his death, but that Mr. Mohieddin was under house arrest because he was unacceptable to the Soviet Union.

title: MAYOR FINDS PERIL TO ARTS PROGRAM
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city's ability to support cultural programs was in trou ble, and urged cautious decen tralization to bring the arts to more people at less cost.

title: New Star in Butterflies
description: Rosemary Murphy has taken over the starring role of Mrs. Baker in the comedy, Butter flies Are Free, playing at the Booth Theater. She replaces Eileen Heckart who left for London to star in the British version of the Leonard Gershe play:

title: Doctors Evaluating Data in Study of Malnutrition Here
description: The first results of a Fed eral study of malnutrition in New York City show that nearly half of a, sample of low income children under 7 years old here suffer from low lev els of vitamin A.

title: Shallowbrook, Salem View Advance to Polo Semifinals
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 13  Shallowbrook of Somers, Conn.; and Salem View of North Sa lem, N. Y., scored upset victor ies tonight and advanced to the semifinal round of the George Sherman Memorial indoor five goal polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: FourPlayer Trade Made By White Sox and Royals
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) The Chicago White Sox traded a first baseman, Gail Hopkins, and an outfielder, John Matias to the Kansas City Royals to night for Pat Kelly, an outfield er and Don O'Rilev a Ditcher.

title: Bench Refuses to Put on Film His Expressions About Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (UPI) Johnny'Bench wasn't in any mood today for pictures whether they were rated GP, R, X or anything else.

title: Driver Tries to Enliven Auto Racing With Humor
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 13 If you should hear of CanAm mechanics racing in a Creep er Grand Prix in the pad dock; if you see Riverside's corner workers racing on their brooms in a Halloween Sprint; if you see an air foil mounted on a racing helmet; it you discover the United States Grand Prix being run as an adjunct to Pulaski Day, chances are you have stum bled into the orbit of Oscar Koveleski, founder of the Polish Race Drivers of America and a lighthearted competitor in the Canadian American Challenge Cup series. Kovelski's broom race is timed for the closing Can Aln of the season on the weekend of Oct. 31. It is in tended to provide an antidote, as all, of Kovleski's capers do to the serious goingson of the CanAm race itself.

title: New Director of Mines
description: Dr. Elburt Franklin Osborn is getting two distinguished appointments at the same time.

title: Fordham Harriers Defeat Yale for Fourth Victory
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13  Fordham's crosscountry team defeated Yale, 1837, today, for its fourth victory against three defeats.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO FALI
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to retreat yesterday as the list declined for the fourth consecutive ses sion In quiet trading.

title: Aide Hints Quebec Front May Ease Its Demands
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 13  An official representative of the Front for the Liberation of Quebec hinted today that the leftwing terrorist organization might modify its terms for the release of James R. Cross and Pierre Laporte, who were kid napped last week.

title: PROFITS RAISED BY BANK AMERICA
description: The Bank America Corpora tion, parent of San Francisco's Bank of America, reported yesterday that operating prof its rose by 6.5 per cent in the third quarter to $43.88million, or $1.28 a common share. This compares with $41.18million, or $1.20 in the comparable 1969 period.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Conill Corporation
description: The Conill Corporation, a onebank holding company for Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, yes terday reported net income for the third quarter of $13,357, 000, or 79 cents a share, com pared with $11,440,000, or 67 cents a share, in the corre sponding quarter last year.

title: RIGHTS COUNCIL GETS CASE AGAINST BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Oct. 13  The Council of Europe has cleared the way for a judicial hearing of a complaint that Britain's treatment of East African Asians violates the European Convention of Human Rights.

title: 2 Union Chiefs Trade Charges On Goldberg's Service to Labor
description: The battle between Rocke feller and Goldberg supporters in organized labor brought sharp exchange yesterday be tween two labor leaders on op posite sides in the guberna torial contest.

title: MARSHAL LOGINOV, LED SOVIET AVIATION
description: Air Marshal Yevgeny F. Logi nov, head of Soviet civil avia tion from 1959 until last May died in Moscow last Wednes day. He was 63 years old.

title: French Navy Captain Recalls Two Talented Uncles
description: Standing before a photo graph of two famous men and pulling thoughtfully on a Gaul oise cigarette, Capt. Jean Jacques Schweitzer remarked yesterday:

title: Chamber Music Society Will Give Sonata Series
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will offer a special Sonata Series of four Saturday night events this sea son. The series will present in dividual members of the soci ety in programs of sonatas for their respective instruments.

title: EXPLOSION GOES OFF ON HARVARD CAMPUS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Wednes day, Oct. 14An explosion be lieved caused by a bomb went off at Harvard University's Cen ter for International Affairs early this morning.

title: PAPERS IN CAPITAL SUE THE PRINTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The Washington Newspaper Publishers Association filed a claim today for $250,000 in damages against Columbia Typographical. Union Local 101. The claim, filed under the grievance clause in the con tract between the union and the publishers, charged the printers with interruption of normal production of Washington's three daily newspapers  The Post, The Daily News and The Evening Star.

title: Rankings in Football Of ten Ignore Caliber Of Opposing Teams
description: Although winning is the prime factor in getting a team rated high nationally, the type of opposition encount tered in perhas more impor tant. The rub is that this second factor is not always taken into consideration by those who vote in the wekely ratings. With the season nearly nair coin pleted, only two of the teams in the top 10 of the United Press I n t e r n a tional ballot this week have competed against opponents whose total record is a win ning one. These are Texas, No. 2 this week, and Stan ford, No. 9. Michigan's op ponents have a .500 standing and the Wolverines are rated No. 7.

title: Nixon Aides, Deborah Murray And H. W. Sloan Jr., to Marry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Although it had not been an nounced officially by her parents, the engagement of Miss Deborah Louise Murray to Hugh W. Sloan Jr., a staff assistant to President Nixon, was the small talk of the White House last week. The news even reached Mrs. Nixon in Key Biscayne, who telephoned the prospective bride on Friday. Miss Mur ray, assistant to Mrs. Lucy Winchester, the First Lady's social secretary, was sur prised and pleased by Mrs. Nixon's good wishes. It just brightened my day, Mrs. Nixon said.

title: Nicholas. J. Vasilieff, 82, Dead; Artist an Emigre From Moscow
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. Oct. 13Nicholas J, Vasilieff, an artist, died today at a nursing hoine here after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived on Quarry Road in Lanesboro, near here.

title: Lickerish Quartet, a Vivid but Barren Film. Owens
description: Radley Metzger is a com paratively young man (40) who lives in New York and makes movies in Europe, but everything he does (Car men, Baby, Therese and Isabelle, Camille 2000) is designed to evoke memo ries of a kind of Hollywood moviemaking you probably thought died with World War II.

title: TV: Ban Political Ads
description: Courage on television does exist. Frank Reynolds, co anchorman with Howard K. Smith of the American Broad casting Company's evening news program, last night urged the total elimination of campaign spot announce ments as Injurious to the na tion's political health.

title: TwoThirds of Increase Attributed to Growth in Stocks of Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 13 (Reu ters)Total manufacturing and trade inventories grew by $640 million in August, to $169.27 billion, a drop from the $1.26 billion increase in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Miss Constance Girard to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Girard have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Constance Eaton Girard, to Jack Wayne Boron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Boron of Canton. Ohio.

description: Three ostensibly unrelated acts yesterday served to gether to point up both a major reason for the inadequacy of the United Nations as a world security organization and the hollowness of one aspect of United States for eign policy.

description: 11:05Noon, WNCN: Adventures in Good Music.

title: WILLIAM THOMPSON JR.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) William B. Thompson Jr., an assistant vice president in the legislative department of the As sociation of American Rail roads, died yesterday of cancer at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 53 years old.

title: U.S. Continues Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The State Department announced today that the United States would continue to recognize the Government of Bolivia de spite the coup last Wednesday that brought Gen. Juan Jose Torres to power.

title: Gains by Republicans Indicate Close Senate Contest in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 9  On the surface, things seem normal in the United States Senate campaign in New Mexico.

title: Mr. Nixon's TwoLevel Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13All govern ments operate on two levelsthe mor al and the politicalbut seldom in recent history has any Administration matched the Nixon Adm'nistration's spectacular combination of priggish moralizing and political expediency.

title: Farmers in Midwest Wary of Crime Rise
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa, Oct. 12 The long lines of trucks and tractor  drawn wagons moved steadily through the unloading chute at the Farmer's Coop today, pouring a stream of corn and soybeans into the enormous elevator.

title: BANK AIDE INDICTED IN EMBEZZLEMENT
description: A former trust officer of the American Bank and Trust Com pany at 70 Wall Street was indicted yesterday on charges of having embezzled more than half a million dollars over a 15month period that ended in December.

title: Garbage Burned in Street In East Harlem Protest
description: Garbage was thrown into the streets and set afire at several places in East Harlem last night to protest what resident of the area said was the Sanitation Department's failure to collect the garbage for a number of days.

title: Braves Recall 2 Farmhands
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Atlanta Braves called up Hal Breeden, the leading home run hitter in the International League this season, from their Richmond farm club. Breeden, a first basemanoutfielder was added to the Braves, roster, along with Curtis Moore, a 19 yearold outfielder. To make room for two players, Steve Barber and Julio Navarro, pitchers, were assigned to Richmond.

description: Deaths

title: TB VACCINE USED IN LEUKEMIA STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13A threeyear study has shown that children under 15 in the Province of Quebec who were vaccinated against tuberculosis appeared to have only half the death rate from leukemia as children who were not vacci nated.

title: London Gold Price Hits 11Month High
description: LONDON, Oct. 13A reviv ing interest in gold pushed the freemarket price of the metal to $37.425 an ounce in Lon don today, its highest level in 11 months. The price yester day was $37.19.

title: SHIPMENTS OF P. & G. SET RECORD LEVELS
description: Shareholders of the Procter & Gamble Company attending the annual meeting in Cincin nati yesterday were told that shipments in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 set rec ord levels.

title: Screen: Winners of Student Festival
description: The fifth National Student Film Festival, which played last night in two slightly different programs in Phil harmonic Hall, presented short films by recent gradu ates and undergraduates of schools, mostly on the East and West coasts, together with one film by a 32yeer old professional stills photog rapher. I'm not sure what Frank Dandridge's Pas de Deux is doing among the student movies, but since liked it as well as anything I saw in the programs, I can't complain.

title: Criticism of French Role in Chad Increases in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 13Maj. Gen. Edouard Cortadellas, French commander in Chad, cut short a visit here today and rushed back to the embattled central African country as criticism mounted in press and political circles over France's military commitment there.

title: A U.S. JUDGE DELAYS LIST OF RADICALS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13A Federal District Court judge here ordered the House Inter nal Security. Committee today temporarily not to publish a report listing 69 radical revo lutionaries who spoke on col lege campuses in the last two years.

title: Allied Off in Quarter
description: Sharply lower earnings on slight sales gains for the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 were reported yester day by the Monsanto Company.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had a morning meeting With George Meany and other Union leaders. He also met with representatives of the Polish American Congress. Later in the afternoon he saw Treasury Secretary Davrid M. Kennedy, Paul McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers: and George P. Shultz, director, of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: CITY BANK TO CUT EURODOLLAR DEBT
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 13  The First National City Bank, New York's largest bank, has decided to reduce substantial ly its $1.4billion debt in the Eurodollar market, the market for dollars on deposit in banks abroad.

title: It's Showtime, and Cardin Takes the Spotlight
description: Anyone who thinks she can close her eyes for a while and all the long skirts will go away is simply deluding her self. Knees were scarcer than bare midriffs on Seventh Ave nue as spring showings got under way this week, if you don't count the knees that show when the skirt slits go up to there.

title: Nancy B. Young Is Betrothed To McGhee Tyson Gilpin Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Robert B. Young of Washing ton and Boyce, Va., has an nounced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Nancy Baxter Young, to McGhee Ty son Gilpin Jr. He is the son of Mr. Gilpin of Lakeville, Boyce, and the late Mrs. Gil pin, the former Catherine Ginna Mellick of Far Hills, N. J.

description: CAMBRIDGE, England, Oct. 13 (AP)Cambridge Univer sity undergraduates de manded tonight the imme diate abolition of the proctor's office, which has kept order on the campus for the past 700 years.

description: POPULATION  Almost 500,000, about 70 per cent Jewish, 20 per cent Italian and the remainder Irish, white Protestants and some Negroes.

title: KIN SEE U.S. YOUTH IN BERLIN RED JAIL
description: BERLIN, Oct. 13The parents of Mark Huessy, an American student sentenced to seven years imprisonment in East Germany last month, visited their son in an East Berlin prison today and found him skinnybut said he had retained a fine sense of humor.

description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 13 Lieut. Col. William O. Dickerson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Dickerson of River side have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Valerie LaVerne Dickerson, to Ronald Dean Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. R. Coleman of San Fran cisco.

title: War Protests to Be Held Despite Fears of Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Antiwar demonstrations are being planned for 31 cities three days before the Nov. 3 general elections, much to the dismay of some dovish candi dates who fear adverse reac tions at the polls.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP)  Stan Mikita of the Chicago Black Hawks, following three days of hospital treatment for Ian ailing back and stiff neck, was back skating today.

title: City Opposes Proposal For Rail Rate Increase
description: The city joined shipping interests, maritime unions and business associations yes terday in a fight against pro posed increases in railway freight rates for shipping through Northeastern ports. The proposal is now pending before the Interstate Com merce Commission.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Curb extile and Shoe Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Senate Finance Committee approved today foreign trade legislation that would establish import quotas for textiles, footwear and, potentially, a wide range of other products.

description: The owners of the National Football League assemble here today for an unusual midsea son meeting. Pressing business includes the completion of ar rangements for the AllStar game Jan. 24 in Los Angeles, next year's preseason schedule and the possibility of a change in ownership for the New Or leans Saints.

title: GRAIN FUTURES. REGISTER A DROP
description: Grains and soybeans futures declined sharply in the early trading yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade but re covered somewhat near the close. They had risen quite high the day before.

title: CONSULTANT TIED TO CITY ELECTION
description: An economist with McKinsey & Co., a management consultant concern with $1.7Million in contracts with the city, testified yesterday that he canvassed his colleagues in the New York office last fall to recruit poll watchers for Mayor Lindsay's reelection campaign.

title: Marine Midland Bank Realignment
description: The Marine Midland Bank, formerly the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, announced yesterday realignment in its senior man agement, a move viewed as providing more depth at the highest levels of the $3.39 billion institution.

description: Business Records

title: Engelhard Named Top Owner
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP)  Charles W. Engelhard, Far Hills, N.J., owner of Nijinsky, won the owner of the year award today given by the British Horseracing Writers and Re porters Association. Other awards went to Vincent O'Brien, who trains Engelhard's horses in Ireland, and Lester Piggott, who rides for Engelhard.

description: City Controller Abraham D. Beanie issued a detailed report yesterday charging mismanagement and misuse of funds by the city's Addic tion Service Agency in its $4.3million Phoenix House narcotics program.

description: WARSAW, Oct. 13 (AP) Thousands of Poles, along with the Communist party leader, Wladyslaw Gomulka, paid hom age today to former Foreign Minister Adam Rapacki whose body was lying in state at War saw's Prymasowski Palace.

description: Yonkers Drivers

description: Negotiators for the News paper Guild conferred among themselves yesterday on issues in their strike against The New York Post.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MENEMSHA, Mass.Along the boulder  strewn beaches of Martha's Vineyard's north shore, just beyond the wreck of an old barge that went ashore many years before, our SonaGraf depth finder indicated that we had passed over a good fish, and a few minutes later Al Ristori had a solid strike on one of the multiple tube rigs we were trolling about 20 feet down on wire line.

title: Incumbent Favored In 11th District Race
description: For half a century, the 11th Congressional District, which covers southeastern Brook lyn and an adjacent piece of Queens, has sent Democrats to the House of Representatives.

title: U.S. Pollution Control Panel Bars Environmental and Consumer Observers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  The Department of Commerce refused today the request of 10 environmental and consumer organizations to have repre sentatives present at a meet ing of the National Industrial Pollution Control Council.

title: End of Fare on London Transit Urged
description: LONDON, Oct. 14 A free travel plan for the millions of subway and bus riders in Lon don was outlined today in an official report seeking to ease the congestion and financial problems of the city's transport system.

title: SILVER FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Silver Futures rose on the Commodity Exchange here yes terday in line with the rise in prices at the Government's re ular weekly silver auction in Washington on Tuesday.

title: President to Visit 9 States In a Swift Campaign Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Between Saturday morning and Tuesday night, President Nixon will visit nine states to try to bolster the electoral fortunes of Republican candidates.

title: ExBear Player Dies
description: GREENWOOD, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP)Michael Rabold, 33 years old, a former Chicago Bears linebacker, died last night when his car spun on a wee highway and collided headon with another auto, the state police reported. Mr. Rabold was captain of the Indiatia Uni versity football team in 1958. Following his graduation in 1959, be became a professional football player.

title: Film Maker's Sales and Earnings Rise by 2%
description: The Eastman Kodak Cornpany set records in sales and earn ings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 6, but the gains in all instances were lim ited to 2 per cent, according to yesterday's report from its Rochester, N.Y., headquarters.

title: Hussein Says. He Is, Sure Of Guerrilla Cooperation
description: UMM AL HIRAN, Jordan, Oct. 14 King Hussein said today that he was now confi dent of cooperation from our brethren in the commando movement and that Arab re sistance in Israelioccupied areas was justified, but he in dicated that he would nonethe less still accept a peaceful set tlement with Israel.

title: Manufacturers Joining Forces Against a Change in Golf Ball
description: The Golf Ball Manufactur ers Association preented yes terday a solid front of opposi tion to a change in the size of the officialball recently pro posed by a joint committee of the United States Golf Asso ciation and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. An drews, Scotland. The two groups govern the game and cooperate in setting the rules for equipment and play.

title: Show Offers Joy of Hotel Architecture
description: I had a much better time at the Morris Lapidus show that has just opened at the Architectural League than I've ever had at a Lapidus hotel. The Architecture of Joy, a tribute of sorts to the High Priest of High Kitsch who virtually invented the Florida hotel (somebody had to), is an absolutely dandy little exhibition, compactly and impeccably installed in the league's tiny exhibition space at 41 East 65th Street, where it will run through Nov. 7.

title: Petare Dies at Age of 19
description: OCALA, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP) Petare, an outstanding race horse in Argentina, Venezuela and the United States, died to day at the age of 19. Petare's offspring included Sadair, Rec ordDash, Subpet, GinRob and Iron Card.

title: The Proceedings In the. U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Carbide Pollution Assailedby Nader
description: ALLOY, W. Va., Oct. 14 A Union Carbide Corporation metallurgical plant that each year spews into the narrow Kanawha River Valley here 28,000 tons of black smoke and dust particlesa fallout of grit, according to Federal air pollution data, that is one third the total particulate pol lution of the entire city of New Yorkcame under strong attack today from Ralph Nader.

title: Screen:A Fauna Legend:Saga Traces Life of the 'King of the Grizzlies'
description: Having already penned practically all fauna from aardvark to zebra on color film, Walt Disney's fearless hunters, with an ample assist from a willing Canadian contingent, now have trapped a generally benign "King of the Grizzlies" for legend lovers, if not zoologists. This adaptation of Ernest Thompson Seton's saga of a storied bear from cub to sovereign, which opened together with Disney's 1959 cartoon legend, "Sleeping Beauty," at local theaters yesterday, should be a delight for cub scouts of all ages.For scouts above the age of 12, say, this adventure is more cute than arresting and has all the tension of "Sleeping Beauty," as it meshes the life cycle of Wahb, the grizzly, and the simple stories of Moki, the Cree Indian ranch foreman, who rescued Wahb as a cub and still reveres him, and his boss, Colonel Pierson, who wants to destroy the grizzly as a threat to his livestock.There is vivid, picturesque beauty in the Alberta Rockies where it was all shot. And, the forests, meadows, waterfalls, snowy peaks and clear streams are striking too, as are cubs cavorting or bears battling each other or other carnivores.But despite Winston. Hibler's off-screen comment that "grizzlies are unpredictable," this 1,200-pound Wahb, "played" by a grizzly named Big Ted, is entirely predictable as the ultimate winner over his puny, human adversaries, who after all, have to grapple with an entirely predictable story.

title: Womah Applies for Seat In the French Academy
description: PARIS, Oct. 14 (Reuters)A French women's liberation worker, Frangoise Parturier, ap plied today for membership in the Academie Frangaise. She is the first woman to do so since 1893.

title: Bucher Plans to Retire From Navy Next Year
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)  Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, 43 years old, who was captain of the Pueblo when she was captured by North Korea, will retire from the Navy next year.

title: Chess:
description: Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York City is primarily a positional player of great depth. His forte is to fabri cate a victory from a drawish looking setting. His way is to fix a weakness in the foe's pawn phalanx and destroy it by the basic principle divide and conquer.

description: DELMONTFlorence (Flo), cherished memo ries fondly remembered; sadly missed. DELMONT & MARKEL FAMILY.

title: Anderson May Get His Wish
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) Manager Sparky Anderson sur veyed his depleted Cincinnati pitching corps today and said he hoped tomorrow's fifth World Series games would be rained out. The weatherman may have been listening. He is predicting likely showers, with a cooling of temperatures to the mid70's.

title: DR. ANTHONY PAYNE, W.H.O. DIRECTOR, 59
description: Dr. Anthony Payne, assistant directorgeneral of the World Health Organization and for merly professor of epidemiology and chairman of the depart ment of epidemiology and pub lic health at Yale University, died yesterday in Geneva fol lowing a short illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Before plunging into a synopsis of Garry Wills's astonishing book, one must give some account of Mr. Wills. To say that he is a contributing editor at Esquire, a syndi cated newspaper columnist and the author of The Second Civil War is inadequate. The Second Civil War was about Ameri ca's racial agony. In his newspaper column.

title: Bonn Party Defections Believed to Peril Brandt
description: BONN, Oct. 14Less than year after it took power, the Government coalition of Chan cellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel is facing a serious challenge.

title: Social Role Urged on Business
description: A group of New York ex ecutives was told yesterday that, because there was a lot of tinder lying around capable of ignition, the so cial responsibility of business was greater than ever before.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: During this 25th anniversary of the United Nations, it is fitting that the organization set a new goal for the future. The goal could well be for the nations of the world to abandon war as a means for settling disputes.

title: Irish Hail Apollo 13 Crew
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 14 (Reuters) The Apollo 13 astronauts, Capt. James L. Lovell Jr., John L. Swigert Jr. and Fred W. Haise Jr., were given an enthusiastic reception today when they arrived in Ireland during a Euro pean tour. The three men, whose moon mission in April almost ended in disaster when an explosion damaged part of their craft, were received by President Eamon de Valera, who is 88 today.

title: $163,800 Paid for Yearling
description: NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 14 (UPI)Vincent O'Brien, a trainer, paid a European record sum of $163,800 for a yearling today when he purchased the Frenchbred Cabrienne for an unnamed American owner. Cab rienne is a brown filly by Si cambre out of Torbella III.

title: Defense CostsHine but Vital
description: For some years the budget for na tional defense has been the favorite target for most people urging reduc tions in Federal expenditures or seek ing funds to be diverted to different projects. Simply because of sheer size defense has necessarily attracted, the attention of both groups.

description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for Governor, said yesterday that unemployment in the state had increased by nearly 40 per cent over the last year, and demanded that Governor Rockefeller call a special session of the Legis lature to extend state unem ployment insurance benefits from 26 to 39 weeks.

Fireman Henry Yaeger of Engine Co. 69 suffered smoke inhalation.

description: AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP)Howard L. Shuttleworth, former president of Mohawk Carpet Mills and later board chairman of Mohasco Industries, died today at Amsterdam Me morial. He was 74 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Raymond J. Crowley, who worked 39 years for The As sociated Press, died here today of cancer. He was 68 years old.

description: Wednesday, Oct. 14. 39th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Marsalis Helps Bump and Run to join Pro Football Lexicon
description: It began a decade ago with blitz. This season it is bump and run. Pro football contin ues to evoke catchy phrases embraced by fans to describe vogues of play. There has been the stacked I, the mov ing pocket, the bomb, the run to daylight, the audibles and many more, all of them even tually talked to death and forgot ten. Bump and run is not new. But with these trends there is a lag before the public picks up the phrase. One reason for a focu; on bump and run is Jim Marsalis, the spectacular cor nerback of the Kansas City Chiefs and a leading prac titioner.

title: The President's Silence
description: The President's silence on the report of his own Com mission on Campus Unrest invites the suspicion that Mr. Nixon prefers to let his party get maximum political mileage out of distortions of the student issue.

title: U.S. Court in Hartford Bars Aid to Nonpublic Schools
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 14 (AP) A threejudge Federal Court ruled here today that state aid to nonpublic schools was un constitutional and issued an in junction immediately affecting some $6million earmarked for 263 schools in Connecticut.

description: Reapportionment and an at mosphere of voter malaise and discontent have increased con servative political sentiment in the Eight Congressional Dis trict in central Queens. But the DemocratLiberal Represen tative, Benjamin S. Rosenthal, is still the acknowledged front runner for reelection this fall.

title: New Juice in Old Oats
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  All the boys were whooping it up down at the Lead Dollar Saloon when the message arrived. It was wrapped around a piece of sagebrush which some galoot tossed through the saloon window. There is a bomb in this saloon, the message said. It will explode in three minutes.

title: TAPE IS EVIDENCE AT POLICE TRIAL
description: A taperecorded conversation in which a suspended New York patrolman said he had told a Brooklyn grocery store owner not to pay him money in front of neighborhood chil dren was accepted in evidence yesterday in the patrolman's Police Department trial.

title: SOVIET HARD LINE ON BERLIN IS SEEN
description: BONN, Oct. 14 An au thoritative Western source said today that the Soviet Govern ment showed signs of wanting to negotiate a Berlin settlement with the three Western allies early last week, only to revert to a stance of obstinacy at the fourpower ambassadorial meet ing last Friday.

title: NOBEL PRIZE JUDGES ACCUSED BY MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14The So viet Union, while continuing to avoid personal criticism of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn for winning the Nobel Prize for Literature, accused the award judges again today of antiSo viet motives in honoring a novelist whose latest works are banned in his homeland.

title: U.N.Marks Anniversary; Security Keeps Public Out
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 The United Nations opened its 25thanniversary celebration today with abotit dozen of the 127 delegations absent and with many others represented by only a single delegate.

title: NEW YORK TAKES COMMAND EARLY
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14Pitted for the second straight night against a young, inexperienced but energetic opponent, the New York Knickerbockers responded with a wellrounded attack to night to drub the Cincinnati Royals, 128404, at Cincinnati Gardens.

title: Charge Barred in Riot Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) District Attorney Evelle J. Younger said today that his of fice would not file charges in the death of Ruben Salazar, killed in the East Los Angeles riots Aug. 29. Mr. Salazar, 42 years old, was news director of a Spanish language television station, KMEX, and was: a col umnist for the Los Angeles Times. He was killed when struck in the head by a tear gas projectile while in a bar at the time of the riot.

title: Mayor Walks Out On Angry Council

description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 14 (UPI)Eleven American soldiers were arrested early today and charged with assault ing passersby In Frankfurt's nightclub district, the German police and military authorities said.

title: LAIRD AIDE HOPES TO BEAT DEADLINE

Laird. Roger T. Kelley, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Man power, told reporters that with the active cooperation of the armed services, Congress and the country at large, we may indeed beat this goal by a sig nificant margin.

title: Miss Grania Mary Hoskins Fiancee of John W. Ackley 3d
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., Oct. 14 Miss Grania Mary Hoskins, a stage manager at the Amer ican Place Theater in New York, and John Westervelt Ackley 3d, who does free lance work in sound and electronics there, plan to be married.

title: 147 Flee Hospital Fire
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct, 14 (UPI)Doctors and nurses led 147 patients, many still in their beds, to safety today when a storage room fire sent smoke through the fourstory east wing of the Allentown General Hospital. The patients were moved to two other wings and returned to their own rooms and wards four hours later. No one was injured.

title: Daniel Haller's Pieces of Dreams
description: It was probably inevitable that someone would finally get around to making a film about the progressively con cerned young priest at odds with the church who finds happiness in the arms of a pretty young thing. The theme is inherently dramatic but fraught with dangers for the unsophisticated.

title: Personal Finance
description: The Administration has cast its acquisitive eye on the field of Federal estate taxation. It hopes to speed up the process by which the dead help finance the living.

description: Would you think that blue velvet Louis XV arm chair could live comfortably in a room hung with stain less steel paneling? Or that Chinese Chippendale chairs would be at home with op art carpeting?

description: ALLBANY, Oct. 14The Pub lic Service Commission barred the Consolidated Edison Com pany today from increasing gas rates in parts of New York City and Westchester next Thursday pending hearings to determine if the $12.4million in additional anual revenue sought by Con Ed was justified.

Cuellar will pitch if his sore hip and sore elbow are not bothersome and Merritt if his aching elbow is fit.

title: DAVIS CASE GOES TO CITY'S COURTS

But late last evening, United States Commissioner Earle N. Bishopp quashed the $250,000 bail he had set for her eight hours earlier and turned the 26yearold former philosophy teacher over to the custody of New York detectives.

For one thing its old apprentice programgetting promising dancers into the school by giving them modest but essential scholarships  is now really beginning to pay off. On Monday night, for example, Gary Chryst danced the title role in Pet rushka for only the second time in New York, and he was quite remarkable.

Guests are carrying their own bags and making their own, beds at six hotels on three of Hawaii's islands because of a strike by the International Longshoremen's and Ware housemen's Union, which repre sents all hotel employes. Two other hotels were forced to close. The union is seeking a 9 per cent increase in wages, which range from $1.67 to more than $3 an hour.

description: Raymond Bigar, president of Lederer, calls them abso lutely nonconforming and the phrase may be the un derstatement of the week. The first collection of hand bags by Lanvin of Paris bears out designers theories that inspiration can be found anywhere, if one knows where to look. The Lanvin de signers obviously looked every where, eschewing anything as mun dane as a single theme. Three of the most unusual designs of the small group, to be unveiled tomorrow it Led erer (711 Fifth Avenue at 55th Street), are called the Dog Collar, the Slave and the Touareg. Each is $59.

Roth, chairman and chief executive officer, told share holders yesterday at the an nual meeting.

title: Film: Joe Namath Rides a Motorcycle:Football Player Seems Her Perfect Match Ann-Margret Co-Stars in 'C.C. and Co.'
description: "C.C. and Company," which has been described, rather too hyperbolically for my taste, as "the 'Ben-Hur' of the motorcycle pictures," is actually a work of such opportunism, such vulgarity and such old-fashioned, romantic nuttiness that it's impossible not to be charmed by it, at least much of the time.Here, at last, is the picture to name when someone asks you to recommend "a good bad movie." It's not very long; it pays attention to every hallowed idiocy of its genre, and its characters talk a marvelously unreal type of movie repartee Truck-driver: "You a student?" She (cheerfully): "No. I'm a teen-age prostitute. Give you any ideas?"). What's more, its images are crammed with advertisements (for, among other things, Hamm's Beer, Hondas and Kraft Cheese) that are its own kind of relevant symbology.Even if that weren't enough (and it almost is), the movie stars Joe Namath and Ann-Margret, probably the only two people in the United States who have no identity problems, as, respectively, a nice, clean-cut, long-haired Hell's Angel sort, and a high-fashion writer forif I remember correctlyHarper's Bazaar.Although Joe belongs to a rogue bike gang, the sort that demands the kind of fascist discipline so much of young America seems to find appealing, you suspect he's still essentially a fresh, high-spirited, decent kid from Beaver Falls when he saves Ann-Margret from a gang-rape.You are positive by the time he and Ann-Margret are enjoying a tryst at "the fabulous Flamingo Hotel in Las Vegas" (a direct quote from the movie's credits) and she asks him if his friends wouldn't be jealous if they could see how he was living. "Not how," he answers, "with whom."Any man who shows that much respect for the objective pronoun simply has to love his mother.The film is the first to be directed by Seymour Robbie, whose earlier experience has been in television. Compared to the gaudy theatrical films of other TV-trained directors, "C.C. and Company" is simplicity itself, even though the screenplay threads its way through all sorts of obligatory things like cycle duels, dirt races and one love scene in which Joe and Ann-Margret seem to be under the impression that they're in "Hiroshima, Mon Amour.""C.C. and Company" is actually Mr. Namath's second film (his first, "Norwood," hasn't been released in New York yet). He has almost as many changes of wardrobe as his co-star, an easy wit, and the unruffled manner of a guy who'll try anything twice, which means that he's a perfect match for Ann-Margret, who already has, in all sorts of pop movies.The movie opened yesterday at theaters throughout the city, including the DeMille, on Seventh Avenue, where the sound was sometimes faulty and whose projectionist, at the second show, was apparently so taken by the third (or was it the fourth?) reel that he started to show it twice.

title: Harvard Bomb Blast Damages Center for International Affairs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 An explosion ripped through Harvard's Center for Interna tional Affairs early this morn ing, damaging several offices and a library. There were no injuries.

As Villanova won four games and lost only to Bos ton College, Siani reached the No. 4 position among the nation's re ceivers with an average of 7.2 catches a game. The junior has picked up 567 yards with 36, receptions, and only two other receiverd, Ernie Jen nings of Air, Force and Bob Newland of yards have gained more yards catching.

title: An Evil Country for Youth
description: Vietnam is itself many crises. It is the crisis of the draft, and what that has done to students and colleges. It is one of the chief causes of the crisis over political activity on the campus, for it is one of the main occasions for political activity on the campus. It raises the question of the proper function of the university, for university sponsored advice and research plays a role, and no minor one, in Viet nam. It has contributed to the stripping of respect and awe from authority, for it is the greatest failure of government, perhaps, in Amer ican history. It is in this last sense that the impact of Vietnam on the campus crisis is most serious.
