description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 14Authoritative Cambodian sources attached reservations today to the Government's en dorsement of President Nixon's peace proposal for Indochina.

title: Concrete Company Faces 100 Charges Of River Pollution
description: A New York concrete com pany was indicted by a Fed eral grand jury yesterday on charges of polluting the East River by washing out its concretemixing trucks and pouring the wash into the river.

title: BAYH SUBSTITUTES EQUAL RIGHTS BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Sen ator Birch Bayh, in an effort to revive the nearly dead equal rights amendment, proposed a new version of it today and won agreement that it should be the pending business when the Senate returns from its campaign recess on Nov. 16.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: RICHARD M'AVOY, 60, CORPORATE COUNSEL
description: Richard McAvoy, vice presi dent and general counsel of the Great Lakes Carbon Corpora tion, a diversified manufactur ing and processing concern, died yesterday at. New York Hospi tal. He was 60 years old and lived at 14 East 75th Street.

title: Hijacker Charges Guards Murdered Arab Companion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 The Palestinian resistance movement produced with con siderable flourish today its most famous and probably most ex perienced air hijacker: Miss Leila Khaled.

title: Braves Down Cavaliers
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 14 (UPI) Don May scored a career high of 24 points tonight to lead the Buffalo Braves to a 10792 victory over the Cleveland Cav aliers in the season opener for the two National Basketball As sociation expansion teams.

title: Legislating by Rider
description: In a dismal mixture of demagoguery, selfindulgence and expediency, the Senate has contrived to ensnarl several major proposals in two legislative tangles. The constitutional amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women has probably been killed because the Senate added a second amendment permitting recitation of non denominational prayers in public schools. The case for the Equal Rights Amendment has not been proved but it is a serious issueone that deserves to be decided on its own merits, not sunk without a trace by weighing it down with the wholly unrelated school prayer con troversy.

title: Test for G.O.P. in Jersey.
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14  With the election just three weeks away, many Republican and Democratic leaders through out New Jersey have concluded that Nelson G. Gross, the Republican candidate for United States Senator, is trailing the Democratic incumbent, Har rison A. Williams Jr. The assessment was made today fol lowing expressions of jubilation by Gross campaign officials that Presi dent Nixon would visit the state on Saturday in behalf of Mr. Gross.

title: Ehrlichman Says Crime In Capital Has Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Crime in the nation's capital during September may have dropped 25 per cent below the levels of the same month a year ago, according to John D. Ehrlichman, Presidential assis tant.

title: First Pennsylvania Opening
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (UPI) The First Pennsylavnia Banking and Trust Company, the oldest bank in the United States, has opened an office in Mexico City, it was announced today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Communist China, the Soviet Union and the United States apparently detonated nu clear devices yesterday. The Chinese and Soviet devices apparently were hydrogen, and the Chinese testthe only one in the atmospheremarked a resumption after a lapse of more than a year. An Atomic Energy Commission spokesman said it was the first time that three nuclear explosions had been detonated on the same day. He called it pure coincidence. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: FRESH N FOOLISH VICTOR AT $77.20
description: It's beginning to look as if Jorge Velasquez has provided New York horseplayers with sure system for picking win ners in stakes races.

title: Promotion Announced At Campbell Soup Co.
description: Lorraine C. Reid moved from the agency to the client side and has found happiness in Camden, N. J. How many of you can make that state ment?

title: Systematic Thefts Laid To 18 Seized at Kennedy
description: A breakthrough in an inves tigation of largescale, syste matic cargo thefts at Kennedy International Airport was re ported yesterday with the ar rest of 18 people, including six present and former employes at the Pan American Cargo Ter minal.

title: NIXON PEACE PLAN FORMALLY BARRED BY NORTH VIETNAM
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 14  North Vietnam to night officially rejected Presi dent Nixon's weekold propo sals for peace in Indochina.

title: I. R. S. to the Rescue
description: A remarkably encouraging development in recent years has been the emergence of publicinterest law firms and of new citizens groups which appear before regulatory agencies and the courts in behalf of consumers and the environment. Instead of demonstrating in the streets, holding rallies and picketing, these lawyers and concerned citizens have been making use of the orderly processes of Government to make their protests against companies with a reckless buyer beware attitude toward their customers and toward the physical environment. Against this background, it is astonishing that the Internal Rev enue Service has now come to the rescue not of the publicspirited lawyers and voluntary organizations but of corporate marauders who can well take care of them selves.

title: 45 KOREANS KILLED IN BUSTRAIN CRASH
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 14 Fortyfour junior high school boys and a bus driver were killed today when a bus carry ing them home after a school excursion collided with a train at an unmanned railroad cross ing near Onyang, 55 miles south of here.

title: Radio
description: 11:05Noon, WNCN: Adventures in Good Music. Karl Haas: Composer's Views on Others Music.

title: Business Records
description: JOSEPH F. GAFFNEY, doing business as Gaffney's candy store, checker, 4227 White Plains Road, Bronx. Liabilities, $11,045; assets, 51,405.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: COURT COMPLETES SCHOOL HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Justice Department's chief advocate cautioned the Su preme Court today that white students might flee the public schools if school integration were Dressed too vigorously.

title: Bridge:
description: Several varieties of trans fer bids, designed to place the trump length in the dummy so that the opening lead will come up to tenace positions in the closed hand, are in use in tournament play in this country.

title: Weeden & Co. Goes Fully Public In Rare Brokerage House, Offer
description: Weeden & Co., a major thirdmarket brokerage con cern, went fully public yesterday in one of the rare broker agehouse stock offerings in Wall Street history It was also the first public offering in securities concern since Don aldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., went public last April and could provide an indica tion of the public appetite for brokeragehouse equities in the wake of the crippling bear market.

title: House Panel Lists Radical Speakers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Representative Richard H. Ichord, chairman of the House Internal Security Committee, released today a committee re port listing 65 radical campus speakers, although a Federal court order had pro hibited official Government publication of the list.

title: Asian Officials React Mildly To Canada's Action on Peking
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14 (Reuters) Asian governments reacted quietly today to the establish ment of diplomatic rela tions between Canada and Communist China, hints of dis appointment in some countries being matched by hints of ap proval in others.

title: Conservative Group Warns Of a Liberal Swing to Right
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Americans for Constitutional Action, a conservative group, said today that some Senators with long records as radical liberals were trying to ride trend toward conservatism by switching positions to get re elected.

title: MORRIS, A GUITARIST, PLAYS RECITAL HERE
description: Harold Morris, a guitarist who teaches at the Horace Mann School and the Mount Kisco School of Music, came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tues day night to play music by Tor roba, Ponce, VillaLobos and Antonio Lauro.

title: N.Y U. HELD LIABLE IN 19DAY CLOSING
description: A student's father has suc cessfully sued New York Uni versity for a tuition refund of $277.40 because the school canceled classes for 19 days during student demonstrations last May.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Hijacking. The President took two actions to combat international air hijacking. He sent a letter to Walter Binaghi, president of the International Civil Aviation Organization in Montreal, endorsing recent council ac tion to deter hijacking. He also ratified a supplemental convention to the extradition agreement between the Unit ed States and France that would add aircraft hijacking to the list of extraditable offenses.

title: Parking Rules Suspended
description: Alternateside  of  the  street parking rules will be suspended today and tomorrowthe first two days of SuccothTraffic Commissioner Theodore Karag heuzoff announced yesterday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: CHARTER NEW YORK PICKS TOP OFFICERS
description: Gordon T. Wallis, who last month was elected chairman designate and chief executive officer of the Irving Trust Company, was named yester day as future president and chief executive officer of the bank's parent, the Charter New York Corporation, a $6billion registered bank holding com pany.

title: Husband and Wile Team To Film Caper Novel
description: The husbandandwife team of Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon, Jan Mitchell, the res taurateur, and Robert Carson, the novelist, have joined to produce an independent film version of Mr. Carson's latest novel, The Golden Years Caper, recently published by Little Brown.

title: A NixonAgnew Medal For G.O.P. Contributors
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)People who contribute at least $10 to the Republi can Campaign Committee, may, for the asking, receive a commemorative Nixon Agnew medal, the Republican National Committee an nounced today.

title: Box Score of Fourth Series Game
description: CINCINNATI (N.L.)

title: Talks on Quebec Hostages Bog Down
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 14 Ne gotiations for the release of Quebec's two kidnapping vic tims bogged down today, less than 48 hours after they began.

title: E. Jay Rousuck Is Dead; Art Dealer and Author, 69
description: E. Jay Rousuck, vice presi dent of Wildenstein & Co, art dealers, died in his home art 525 Park Avenue yesterday, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 69 Years old.

title: AMER. BASKETBALL ASS'N
description: AMER. BASKETBALL ASS'N

title: Israelis Release Two Algerian Officials Removed From an Airliner
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 14  Is rael released two Algerian of ficials today after two months detention. They had been re moved from an internation al airliner, on which they were passengers, when it made an unscheduled stop in Israel.

title: POLICE SEIZE THREE IN MOSCOW PROTEST
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (Reuters)  Two men and a woman, ap parently foreigners, were ar rested here tonight after they showered about 50 leaflets among Moscow shoppers, ac cording to witnesses.

title: There Was a Time She Couldn't Cook.
description: When I came to this country, Mar cella Hazan said, one of my first acquaintances told me that the Amer ican bride's wedding vow was, I will take you for better or for worse but not for lunch. Mrs. Hazanwho was pre paring a meal of artichokes Romanstyle, an eminently delidious dish of tortelloni filled with chopped Swiss chard, and rollatine of veal for her husband one recent noonlaughed.

title: BLACK CHURCHMEN OBTAIN A HEARING
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 14The Un ion of Black Clergy and Laity of the Episcopal Church won hearing here today at the de nomination's triennial general convention after threatening to withdraw from the 12day meeting.

title: 2 KILLINGS REPORTED By CHADIAN LEADER
description: FORT LAMY, Chad, Oct. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)  Two men were murdered and five others, including a local thief, were kidnapped at Largeau less than 24 hours before rebels ambushed French troops last Sunday northwest of Largeau in north central Chad, Presi dent Francois Tombalbaye said last night in a nationwide radio broadcast.

title: PACIFIC LIGHT PROFIT IS DOWN IN 9 MONTHS
description: The Pacific Lighting Corpora tion and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in net in come for the nine and 12 months ended Sept. 30 despite higher total revenues and other in come in both periods.

title: What Conservative Tide?
description: If it is true, as often alleged, that California already is what the nation is about to become, then a brief survey of the politics of that harbinger state does not support the proposition that a great conservative tide is sweeping America.

title: Text of Secretary General's Statement
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14Following is the text of a statement issued by Secretary General Thant to day on the opening of the General Assembly's 25than niversary session: A quartercentury has passed since the leaders of a tired and bleeding world put their signatures to a docu ment born of the agony and anguish of war. The Charter of the United Nations, which came to life in one of his tory's most momentous cere monies, held out the promise of a world with peace, pros perity and freedom to be attained through equal rights for men and women and for nations, large and small, old and new.

title: Eased Tensions in Cuba
description: In a period of growing anxiety about RussianAmerican relations, Moscow's denial that the Soviet Union building a naval base in Cuba contains an unexpected extra dividend. The Tass statement affirms the continued validity of the KennedyKhrushchev understanding that ended the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Of parallel impor tance, it implicitly recognizes that a Soviet nuclear submarine base on that islandthe possibility raised by White House and Pentagon statements last Sept. 25 would violate that pact The departure of a Soviet sub marine tender from Cienfuegosthe Cuban port at which Washington thought a base might be under construc tionhas further helped to clear the air.

title: U.S.Soviet Ties: An Uncertain Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  For about a month the Nixon Administration has been sound ing the alarm that the Rus sians are coming  coming from all sides, that is, in dan gerous and deceiving ways that threaten not major war but certainly whatever chance ex ists for making a better neacPWell, now the Russians have ar rived, in the per son of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, for what may prove to be the most in teresting psychological encount er between the superpowers in quite a while.

title: Bankers Cautioned on Stolen Securities
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 14 Attorney General John N. Mitchell warned the nation's bankers here today that an es timated total of $40million in stolen stocks and $25million in stolen or lost Government bonds were in circulation.

title: N.F. L. Individual Leaders
description: N.F. L. Individual Leaders

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: The stock market, like the Cincinnati Reds in the World Series, finally produced a vic tory yesterday.

title: Parley Studies DrugResistant Germs
description: Drugresistant bacteria those that have developed a sort of immunity against com mon antibiotics  are on the increase throughout the world in human and animal popula tions. Such bacteria are poten tially dangerous to man be cause modern drugs might lose their ability to treat many diseases.

title: Dr. Judith M. Cooper Of Duke to Be Bride
description: SPRINGFIELD, Pa., Oct. 14 Dr, Judith Marion Cooper, a resident in internal medi cine at the Duke University Medical Center, and Dana Kimball Andersen, an alum nus of Duke who is attend ing its medical school will be married on Dec. 27 in Philadelphia.

title: Composite Score of Series Games
description: Composite Score of Series Games

title: Rites for Fuleihan Today
description: A funeral service for Anis Fuleihan, the composer and pianist, who died Sunday at the age of 70 in Palo Alto, Calif., will be held today at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Red Cross Opens Harlem Unit
description: The New York chapter of the American Red Cross in Greater New York dedicated its Harlem Service Center yes terday. The ceremony took place on a dais erected in front of the Kenwood Building, 144 West 125th Street where the center is situated.

title: Diebold Computer Ends Suit
description: Diebold Computer Leasing, Inc., said yesterday that it had settled its September, 1969, suit against two subsidiaries of the Commercial Credit Corpora tion, a unit of the Control Data Corporation, over terms of loan agreement. According to the company, the settlement provides that Diebold will be free to create a holding com pany and engage in other busi nesses through new subsid iaries.

title: Rockefeller Plans Rise Of 400,000 Jobs instate
description: ALBANY, Oct. 14Gov ernor Rockefeller announced today plans to increase em ployment in New York State by 400,000 jobs during the next four years, citing the unprecedented growth in jobs during his previous ad ministrations.

title: Esposito Sparks Bruins
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (UPI) Phil Esposito scored three goals tonight and the Boston Bruins exploded for five goals in the second period to rout the Los Angeles Kings, 85.

title: 6 Cadets Face Drug Charge At the Air Force Academy
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 14Courtmartial charges have been filed against six Air Force Academy cadets after a preliminary investigation of alleged drug abuse at the school, academy spokesmen said today. The six were among 14 third classmen (sophomores) investi gated for alleged possession of marijuana and LSD.

title: Series Standing, Figures
description: FOURTHGAME STATISTICS

title: Technamation Is Arranging To Continue in Operation
description: Louis Zink, newly elected chairman and chief executive officer of Technamation, Inc., said yesterday that the company was continuing in business and would not terminate its oper ations as previously reported.

title: Details on 8th District at a Glance
description: Population  According to the 1960 census, the District has a population of 409,330. This is largely middle and upper class communities of residents of Jewish, Italian and German descent, with a substantial black section cen tered around portions of Co rona and Elmhurst.

title: TALKS OFFER TEST OF PEKING POLICY
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14Ca nadian negotiations for further) wheat sales to Communist China, now under way, will provide an early test of whether Ottawa's diplomatic recognition of Peking will make any difference in Chi neseCanadian trade relations.

title: 3dQuarter Net Off 70% as Volume Dips 4.9%
description: The RCA Corporation re ported late yesterday a disap pointing third quarter in which net income toppled by 70.3 per cent on a decline of 4.9 per cent in sales. Net income for the first nine months of the year fell 50.8 per cent under the 1969 level as sales slipped by 3.8 per cent.

title: STUART E. PLANTE
description: Stuart E. Plante, manager of regional business operations, domestic consumer products di vision, PhilcoFord Corporation, Philadelphia, died Sunday in Johnsville, Pa. He was 61 years old.

title: Reports on Income Mixed for Chemical Makers
description: Earnings of three of the five chemical and drug companies that reported yesterday for the third quarter and nine months were higher than last year. An other company cut its loss in half for the quarter, while the leader of the industry, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., will show lower earnings when its statement is released early next week.

title: Results of Series
description: Results of Series

title: Market Place
description: It's been a long time since Wall Street was willing to give a stock a high price earnings multiple without nervously watching the tape for signs of shortseller per fidy.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. BACKS ROCKEFELLER ANEW
description: The New York State A.P.L. C.I.O. endorsement of Governor Rockefeller, made in a disputed vote last month, was overwhel mingly reaffirmed yesterday as delegates reconvened at Kia mesha Lake.

title: NUCLEAR BLASTS ET OFF BY CHINA, SOVIET AND U.S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Communist China resumed its nuclear testing program today after a lapse of more than a yearwith an explosion in the atmosphere.

title: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS
description: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: New York (Sunnyside Garden) Bob Cassidy, 163 pounds, Levittown, L.I., knocked out Johnny Burnside, 160, New York, 5 rounds.

title: Nixon Gets Personal View of Detection of Marijuana by Trained Dog
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 14Al bert and Kishi gave a splendid performance on the South Lawn of the White House to day. But, like many accom plished performers, they paid the price of their artistry. They made the act look so easy the President left in the middle.

title: Poll Shows Political Views Unaffected by Union Membership
description: Despite the attention politi cians give to winning union en dorsements and despite talk of a labor vote in New York, a statewide survey indicates that there is virtually no difference between the political attitudes of union members and their families and the attitudes of the Clectorate at large.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment Events

title: U.N. Command in Korea Asks a Meeting Tomorrow
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 15 The United Nations Com mand proposed to North Korea today that the meeting of the armistice commission that was called off on Monday after a scuffle between North Korean and American guards now be held on Saturday at Panmun jom.

title: Gulf & Western Net Off; Alcoa's Earnings Decline
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., reported yesterday profit declines of 64.8 per cent for the fourth fiscal quarter and 37.8 per cent for the year ended July 31, but annual sales reached a record. All eleven groups operated at a profit, only four with somewhat lower earnings.

title: Mets Reported Ready to Trade Pitcher for McCarver of Phils
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15The New York Mets may have been the forgotten men of the 1970 World Series, but they were busy behind the scenes today trying to fortify themselves for 1971. They were reported close to a trade with the Philadelphia Phillies for Tim McCarver, the Phillies frontline catcher.

title: Pacers Down Colonels
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 (AP) The defending American Bas ketball Association champion Indiana Pacers began the 1970 season with a 12795 victory over the Kentucky Colonels to night.

title: Fowler Joins Tiger Staff
description: DENVER, Oct. 15 (UPI)Arts Fowler, 48yearold former ma jor leaguer who was a pitcher and coach for the Denver Bears of the American Association last season, was named pitching coach of the Detroit Tigers to day. He won nine games, los five and saved 15 for Denver in 45 relief appearances last sea son.

title: In Memoriam
description: GLEESONWilliam F. October 16, 1961. An niversary Mass of Requiem in Latin of fered.

title: 2 City Employes Accused of Extortion
description: Two city employes have been arrested on charges of extorting $1,500 from a major shipping company that is building $100million freight distribution center on Staten Island.

title: Moynihan Predicts Senate Will Adopt Welfare Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  Daniel Patrick Moynihan, coun selor to the President, main tained today that the Nixon Administration's welfare re form program had enough sup port in both the Senate Finance Committee and the Senate it self to insure its adoption.

title: Timing Interests Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15  Israeli officials declined imme diate comment on the Soviet plan.

title: SALE OF GOETZ ART BRINGS $2,658,000
description: LONDON, Oct. 15Sixteen major pictures from one of the outstanding collections of im pressionist and modern art in the United States were sold here last night. The paintings, from the collection of the late William Goetz, the Hollywood movie producer, were sold by Sotheby's for $2,658,000 in an auction that lasted only 34 min utes.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Binary Devine, by Jon Hartridge (Doubleday, $4.95). Science fic tion.

title: Commonwealth Festival
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 15The Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New Jersey have planned a Commonwealth Festival to be held at the Woman's Club of Morristown next Thurs day from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mrs. William R. Whitaker is general chairman for the an nual event. Proceeds will go toward the maintenance of the Victoria Home in Ossin ing, N. Y., for aged men and women of Commonwealth heritage.

title: Press Group Gets Member
description: Allen H. Neuharth, presi dent of the Gannett Company, the Rochesterbased newspaper chain, has been appointed to the advisory board of the American Press Institute at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

title: WUSTENCHEFNEXT IN 2MILE TEST
description: Rain that roared down like a waterfall cut attendance at Belmont Park to a season low of 15,749 yesterday, but it didn't keep the steeplechasers from their appointed rounds.

title: CADWELL SHOWS BANJO ARTISTRY
description: Paul Cadwell, a tall, white haired, 81yearold retired law yer and very active banjo buff, conducted a delightful excur sion through banjo lore and banjo styles on Wednesday evening at the Washington Square Church, 135 West. Fourth Street.

title: The SoCalled Great Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15On the opening day of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations world peace organi zation in New York, the United States, the Soviet Union and Communist China resumed testing of nuclear weapons.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hawks Sink Wings, 21
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (UPI) Bobby Hull and Pit Martin scored 6 minutes 15 seconds apart in the second period tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks posted a 21 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Politics Stirs Vermont Autumn
description: BRISTOL, Vt., Oct. 15 Former Gov. Philip H. Hoff of Vermont has spent his life breaking precedents. Now he is trying to become the first Democratic Senator in Ver mont's history, something that once seemed as likely as Protestant Pope.

title: 244Day TaxAnticipation Bills Yield 6.26% at Treasury Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Government reported late this afternoon the results of $2,500,000,000 sale of 244day taxanticipation Treasury bills. The bills were dated Oct. 21, 1970, and mature June 22, 1971.

title: The Angela Davis Tragedy
description: Beautiful, brilliant and committed, Angela Davis rocketed tonational attention as an effective and elo quent spokesman for radical causes. At the University of California at Los Angeles, efforts by the Regents remove her from the faculty surrounded her with an aura of martyrdom and won her wide sympathy even from many who did not agree with her politics. Then last August the bloody shootout at the courthouse in San Rafael was followed by charges that she had been an accomplice of those who invaded the judicial cham bers with guns. Miss Davis dropped from sight and national and international hunt for her began.

title: Child for Dustin Hoffmans
description: A daughter was born yester day to Mr. and Mrs. Dustin Hoffman in the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital. Mrs. Hoffman is the former Anne Byrne, a dancer with the New York City Center Ballet Company.

title: Goodell Wins Backing Of 62 Student Leaders
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell received the endorsement of more than 60 student leaders yesterday, as well as promises to have up to 5,000 student volunteers working for him by Election Day.

title: Repairs to 4 Jails Estimated by Mayor To Cost $1.5Million
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that it would cost between $1.5million and $2million to repair four city jails damaged during recent prison riots. The estimate includes replenishing of supplies destroyed.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15In the beginning today, it was the rains that tried to delay the Orioles from their date with destiny. Then the Cincinnati Reds took an apolo getic whack at it in in first inning. Both failed. Resplendent in the murky half light of a miserable day, the Baltimores com pleted their dismantlement of the Big Red Machine and became champions of the world.

title: Hunter Recital Postponed
description: Ivan Davis, the pianist sched uled to give a recital at Hunter College Playhouse on Saturday night, is ill and has had to postpone his appearance. The recital has been rescheduled for Jan. 23. Tickets sold for and dated Oct. 17 will be hon ored for the postponed event.

title: Brooks Robinson's Bat Had a Good Series, Too
description: Brooks Robinson, whose glove snared the spotlight in this year's World Series, swung a rather lethal bat, too, accord ing to final statistics released by the The Associated Press.

title: The Miseducation of Doctors
description: A 17yearold who wants to be a doctor faces eleven to fifteen years of training, at a total expense of more than $50,000, before he is ready to begin practice. This extraordinary in vestment of time and money is one of the most remarkable facts about American medicine. In America, doc tors are literally the most educated people we have. The accepted myth ology, with its glorification of this extended, expensive training, is that nobody who has the dedication to em bark upon such a lengthy program of study could possibly emerge unequipped for the Job he had to do.

title: U.S. and Agency Bonds
description: Thursday, October 15, 1970

title: U.S. Discounts Publicity
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The United States today discounted Moscow's publicity on Soviet proposals for a Middle East settlement as a partial disclo sure of exchanges that are four months old.

title: REGGIO BARRICADES SMASHED BY POLICE
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Oct.15 (AP)Policemen broke through barricades north of this rebellious city today ana restored road and rail contact with the rest of Italy.

title: Harold W. Haight, Headed Standard Oil Subsidiaries
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 15 (AP) Harold W. Haight, retired ex ecutive vice president of the Humble Oil & Refining Com pany, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: Belmont Jockeys

title: Tammy Books Author Slain; Massachusetts Youth Charged
description: DUXBURY, Mass., Oct. 15 Mrs. Cid Ricketts Sumner, the Mississippiborn author of score of books, including the Tammy series adapted for movies and television, was found bludgeoned to death at her home here early today.

title: Nixon to Speak in Dallas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The White House said today that President Nixon would make a political appearance and would speak at the Memorial Auditorium in Dallas Oct. 2S.

title: Threat Is Disclosed
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 15 (AP)The Episcopal Church's presiding Bishop, the Right Rev. John E. Hines, was under special police guard today because of a threat on his life.

title: Hebert Explains Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Representative Hebert said to day that he would not release the testimony unless he was ordered to do so by Congress.

title: REDS TAKE DEFEAT WITH STOIC PRIDE
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15There was disappointment but no em barrassment or shame today in the Cincinnati clubhouse after the Reds had lost the World Series.

description: 7:00 (2)News Reports (4)Today: News (7)LIsten and Learn

title: FOOTBALL TONIGHT
description: Home teams listed first. HofstraWest Chester St. Miami (Fla.)Tampa.

title: HALFBACK PLANS BASEBALL CAREER
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) The Kansas City Chiefs traded Mike Garrett, one of pro foot ball's outstanding running backs, to the San Diego Charg ers today for a secondround National Football League draft choice in 1971.

title: Money
description: Thursday, Oct. 15, 1970

title: A List of Major Party Candidates in the Senate and Governor Races
description: A List of Major Party Candidates in the Senate and Governor Races

title: Wedding Dec. 5. For Mix Paine, Debutante of 65
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Miss Alix Ellis Paine plans to be married here Dec. 5 to James Williams Seymore Jr., a research assistant to the director of the National Mu seum of History and Tech nology of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Dance: Joffrey Ballet's Time Cycle
description: There is a special solem nity to theatrical pretentious ness; its attitudinizing has that very specific air of empty seriousness. Todd Bol ender's Time Cycle, which was given for the first time at the New York City Center on Wednesday night and re peated with an alternate cast last night, not only has empty seriousness but is seriously empty.

title: Europe Tightening Code To Guard Own Investors
description: PARIS, Oct. 15The myth of American financial wiz ardry is being destroyed in Europe and with this process the trend toward liberaliza tion of money flows is being reversed.

title: Wood Field and Stream

title: Rain Dodgers Show Many Styles
description: Meteorological roulette was a city pastime yesterday. Winners remained dry and losers were drenched as the weather switched frequently from threatening skies to downpours that dumped 0.77inch of rain between morning and evening sub way rushes.

title: Lebanon Ends Censorship
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 (AP)The new Government of Premier Saeb Salaam today ended the censorship of news dispatches and photographs from Lebanon. Information Min ister Ghassan Tueni said that foreign newsmen should bear the Arab  Israeli conflict in mind when reporting on mili tary matters.

title: A Lot of Yesteryear and a Bit of Tomorrow in Spring Fashions
description: There were plenty of tipoffs. The wedgies at Donald Brooks Boutique, the anklestrap shoes at Chester Wein berg, the rouged cheeks and red lips at Geoffrey Beene. You didn't even have to look at the clothes to see that Seventh Avenue's leading designers were so busy remem bering the past they gave short shrift to the main business at hand: making clothes for today. Maybe women aren't nostalgic; designers are. Not all of them, of course. Jacques Tiffeau, who set the pace for the nineteen sixties (along with Gern reich, Courreges, Cardin and nobody else), is still looking ahead.

title: New Picasso Drawings On View for First Time
description: Keeping abreast of Picas so's latest mode offers increasingly specialized pleas ure depending more and more upon your acquaintance with his nexttolatest, which, in turn, depends on the one be hind that, and back through the years since he settled down to juggling the various styles he invented between 1905 and, say, 1945 or 1950. The latest episodes of Picas so's amazing nonstop per formance have reached New York in a group of 37 draw ings executed between 1967 and 1970, none of them ex hibited anywhere before, at the Saidenberg Gallery, 1035 Madison Avenue at 79th Street.

title: Rumanian President Greets Animals at Disneyland

title: Corinthians Turn to Campus; Collegians to Sail Tomorrow
description: The Corinthians, a paper organization of yachtsmen devoted to amateur sailing whether or not they own a boat, are turning to the campus in order to invigor ate their activities and infuse their breed with youth. For its first step in that direc tion, the group, which was formed in 1934, will hold its first intercollegi ate contest to morrow off the Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club.

title: Senator Hollings Divorced

Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, was granted a divorce in Juarez last Thurs day, civil court records showed today. Mrs. Hollings charged incompatability. The Hollingses were married in 1946.

title: WEAVER SAYS DAY IS HIS BIGGEST
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15Omar Aparicio stood near the middle of the bedlamfilled Baltimore clubhouse, sipping champagne from a plastic cup. All round him, however, jubilant players were doing everything with the champagne but drinking it. They were spraying it, spilling it and using it any way that would create even more bed lam and jubilation.

title: 4 Die in New Mexico Crash

He was 83 years old.In his professional career, Mr. Murphy served as general counsel of the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies and as Iowa's Insurance Com missioner, but most of his pub lic life after World War I was devoted to his work in the na tional organization of the Amer ican Legion.

Win throp Rockefeller and Dr. Eugene Moony, University of Kentucky law professor who is counsel for a 17state en vironmental compact. The President also met with sev eral career. Women leaders. title: Film: Insight Into World of Revolution:Robert Kramer Puts It on Personal Level
description: The American revolutionary movie, commercial style, with its now values, its now hairdos and its now stars, has generally proved nothing but the survival of ancient nonsense no matter how new the vehicle. Hollywood's response to the present, in which, say, Eliot Gould gets radicalized and also gets his girl over the gassed-out bodies of his pals in the student union iswellHollywood's response, not without an old-fashioned charm but quite without the relevance it so disingenuously means to capitalize upon.But the movie career of Robert Kramerthe Newsreel, the picketing of the New York Film Festival in 1968 (protesting its perpetuation of "litist art"), last year's much-publicized field trip to Hanoi, even his current withdrawal from film-makingcontains relevance enough to compensate for an entire misdirected industry. And in his two feature films, "The Edge" (1968) and "Ice," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, Kramer's association with the movement pays off not in the power of his polemics, which are not all that powerful, but in his real, if humorless, insight that revolution, like everything else we do, lives in our awareness as a succession of personal relationships.Running for well over two hours, "Ice" is of course too longnot only for endurance but also for its own proper form. Nevertheless, that form demands a certain spaciousness, for it is concerned with understanding a revolutionary action in its totality as a complex network, a communications network, if you will, that needs time if only for the dispersal of information, the transmission of its all-important messages.Set in the future (i.e., today), when the United States is committing aggression in Mexico and suppressing freedom at home (the film is very vague about this and Kramer seems congenitally incapable of offering even a reasonable parody-view of the other side), "Ice follows a group of urban guerrillas as they plot sabotage, proselytize before the unconvinced middle, make love with or make allowances for one another, and live through one night of violent terror.There are assignations at the New Yorker Book Shop, as assassination in the courtyard of the Belnord, an occupation of Washington Square Village. The look and feel of New York City, its airports, its facades, its monuments, its side streets and its avenues are in a sense the documentary evidence the film offers to certify its action. For "Ice" seems ultimately to be its own most important communiqu as if it were a film on tape, to be reproduced and delivered to yet other cells in other cities as part of the pattern of propaganda, the technology of which is almost its chief subject.Because it is secretive and yet full of disclosures, because it accepts the melodramatics of its themes, even because it is so prophetically timely, "Ice" is much of the time a very exciting film to watch. But it is also a rather moving film.Passing beyond the takeout coffee-carton stage of revolutionary planning (which endeared "The Edge" to a good many critics, including me), "Ice" nevertheless remains true to its characters alone and with one another. The cast is amateur (and wholly anonymous, though you may recognize a few friends and familiar faces), but it is adequate to the moods, frustrations, accommodations and intolerances of the movie  which always, sometimes awkwardly, sometimes more wisely than it probably intends, patterns its fiction upon the rhythms of life.

title: Union Opposes Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The International Union of Electrical Workers announced, today that it was distributing more than a million leaflets throughout the nation express ing opposition to foreign im ports.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rose From 108.3 to 108.4
description: The wholesale commodity price index rose to 108.4 yes terday from 108.3 last week.

title: Iraq Ousts Vice President Considered Leading Hawk
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15  Air Marshal Hardan Takriti, one of Iraq's top leaders, has been stripped of all power and appointed to the ceremonial post of Ambassador to the Foreign Ministry.

title: FORD GETS PLEA TO RECALL CARS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15Dr. Col ston E. Warne, president of Consumers Union, urged the Ford Motor Company today to recall four million cars and re pair what he called a safety defect on the front wheel sys tem.

title: Howell and Devlin, at 68, Lead in Australian Golf
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 15. (UPI)Ron Howell, a native of New Jersey who moved to Aus tralia six months ago, shot a fourunderpar 68 today to tie Bruce Devlin of Australia for the firstround lead of the Wills Masters golf tournament.

title: 9th District Details at a Glance
description: POPULATION  409,339, based on the 1960 Federal census, many of them skilled bluecollar workers who own their own homes or are ten ants in twofamily homes. The number of apartment houses has skyrocketed in the last decade. The area has a large Roman Catholic pop ulation consisting of persons of Italian, Polish and Irish descent. In addition, there are sizable numbers of blacks, Jews, Greeks, Germans and a growing Puerto Rican com munity.

title: Rogers and Egyptian Official Confer Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Mah moud Riad, Foreign Minister of the United Arab Republic, net today to explore each other's views on the conditions under which Middle East peace talks could be revived.

title: RUSSIANS REVIVE THEIR PEACE PLAN FOR MIDDLE EAST
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15Pravda, the Communist party newspa per, revived today a Soviet plan for a Middle East settle ment that calls for a formal state of peace even before Is rael completes her pullout from all occupied Arab lands.

title: Fire Calls Increase Here
description: The number of fire alarms transmitted in the first nine months of this year exceeds the record  breaking number sent in the same period last year, Lieut. John E. Kelly, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, said yes terday. From Jan. 1 through Sept. 30, Lieutenant Kelly said, 200,600 alarms were sent, com pared with 184.012 during the first nine months of 1969.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: Protest Has Value To New Yale Hero
description: NEW HAVENCharles A. Reich, a 42yearold professor at the Yale Law School, beams his way across the lawn.

title: HARPISCHORD WORKS PLAYED BY PUYANA
description: French baroque suites for harpsichord monopolized Rafael Puyana's attention on Wednes day night at Hunter College Playhouse. By basing his pro gram on three very different examples of the genre, Mr. Puyana provided a delightful evening of varied musical fare designed to instruct as well as entertain.

title: Drawings Done in Analysis
description: In 1939, the American painter Jackson Pollock, al ready at the age of 27 a vic tim of acute alcoholism and severe mental illness, sub mitted himself to psychiatric treatment by Dr. Joseph Hen derson, a Jungian psychoan alyst then in his first year of practice. The treatment was terminated in 1940 when Dr. Henderson left New York to take up residence in San Francisco. In the course of his 18month treatment, Pol lock created for Dr. Hender son a voluminous series of drawings in which the still fledgling artist attempted to probe the unconscious sources of his malaise.

title: Rail Route Plan Due in 30 Days For National Passenger Service
description: The Department of Transpor tation plans to designate within 30 days the tentative routes for a national passenger train net work that will be taken over May 1 by a quasipublic corpo ration whose creation was au thorized Wednesday by Con gress.

title: Mrs. Doubilet Wins by Stroke In Senior Golf With 81 for 165
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 15 Mrs. Henry Doubilet of Holly wood won the 20th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf As sociation senior championship today at the Fenway Golf Club.

title: Cairo, III., Gets New Chief
description: CAIRO, Ill., Oct. 15 (AP)  A veteran of the East St. Louis, Ill., police department today was appointed chief of police of racially troubled Cairo, where three former chiefs have re signed in less than two years. The Cairo City Council ap proved the appointment of Fred Theriac, 59.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: ORIOLES DISCLOSE CATCHER'S INJURY
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (UPI) There's usually one closely guarded secret in a World Se ries. This year the secret con cerned Andy Etchebarren, the Orioles catcher.

title: Italian Here to See Rogers 1
description: Foreign Ministor Aldo Morn; of Italy arrivrd in New York from Rome today to meet with Secretary of State William P. Rogers before leaving for a fiveday visit to Mexico.

title: Bostonians Open Here In 2 Works
description: There were only two works on the program that opened the Boston Symphony Or chestra's season here in Phil harmonic Hall on. Wednes day night: Reger's Variations and Fugue on a Theme by. Mozart and Bruckner's Sev enth Symphony. Although 31 years separate themthe former was completed in 1914, the latter in 1883 they both belong within the German romantic tradition. Yet they had enough differ ences to make them nicely complementary.

title: QUEBEC PROPOSES DEAL ON HOSTAGES
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 15The government of Quebec offered tonight to release five of the 23 political prisoners whose freedom was demanded by separatist kidnappers as, ran som for two officials held hos tage.

title: President Is Meeting. Delay on Proposed Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Last Jan. 6, the Nixon Administra tion announced a pilot project of storefront postal academies that would use the employee and resources of the post of fices to give high school drop outs remedial education, coun seling and parttime jobs.

title: The Three Recipients of the Nobel Prize
description: Dr. Julius Axelrod left his house in Rockville, Md., early yesterday morning to report to the dentist. When he ar rived, the dentist, who is a friend, greeted him, Julie, you've won the Nobel Prize! Dr. Axelrod said of course he did not believe a word of it because his friend was a great kidder. But the dentist kept insisting he had won something.

title: Appellate Court Overrules City On Adjusted Pay for Patrolmen
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday upheld by a 3to2 vote a low ercourt decision that the city had contended could cost it millions of dollars in pay ad justments for policemen, fire men and other municipal em ployes.

title: Royal Gardener's Book Is Withheld in Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 15The Queen's advisers have pre vented publication of the me moirs of her former gardner, it was disclosed today.

title: Roy Rather to Wed Miss Johnson
description: HOUSTON, Oct 15  Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Johnson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Lippincott Johnson, to Roy Randolph Rather, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Lamar Rather. A January wedding is planned.

title: Sato Is Doubtful on Accord on Textile Sales to U.S.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15  Premier Eisaku Sato voiced deep con cern today over his country's bitter textile dispute with the United States and said he lacked confidence in the possi bility of a solution during his forthcoming talks in Washing ton with President Nixon.

title: Book on Verrazzano Is Published by Yale
description: The Voyages of Giovanni da Verrazzano, 15241528, by Lawrence C. Wroth, was published yesterday by the Yale University Press for the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: Amer. Basketball Ass'n

title: C.N.P. RISES BY 6%; NIXON AIDES CITE GAINS IN PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.The nation's total output of goods and services rose significantly during the third quarter of 1970 despite the automobile work ers strike, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: Dining Out on Home Cooking
description: **Elizabeth White, 987 First Avenue (near 54th Street), 7597850. Elizabeth White has long been a citadel of lowcost Americanstyle dining in New York. It has recently moved to a new location, and although the prices are considerably ele vated above what they were, say, 20 years ago, they compare favorably with those of many another restaurant in town.

title: Books of The Times
description: Boys and girls, come out to play,/The moon doth shine as bright as day. A sinister rhyme, as the author of Bleak November points out, since boys and girls do not come out to play by moonlight unless something is very much the matter. Or unless they enjoy gothic thrillers, which ought to be read under the most sinister conditions imaginable. Despite the lack of bright moonlight, I got myself Into a frame of mind recently where the silence of the night sounded like hair turning white, the drip in the kitchen sink was blood from wound, and I was sure that just outside of my field of vision they were disemboweling mastiffs or something just as awfuland read four novels that gave some promise of gooseflesh.

title: ROBERT W. SCHOFIELD
description: Robert W. Schofield, president of Robert W. Schofield Associ ates, documentary film produc ers, died in his home at 9323 Shore Road, Brooklyn, Wednes day, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 69 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Soviet Union yesterday published a Middle East peace plan, first proposed pri vately last June, that would entail a state of peace before Israel completes a total withdrawal from the territory she occupied in 1967. The previous Soviet demand was complete withdrawal before the state cif war could be legally ended. [Page I, Column 8.]

title: Tulsa Rehires Spahn
description: TULSA, Olka., Oct. 15 (AP) Warren Spahn, a former Na tional League pitching star, was rehired today to manage the American Association Tulsa Oil ers, a farm club of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Smelter Cost and British Strike CitedIncome of American Can Is Up
description: Lower earnings for the third quarter and first nine months despite improved sales were reported yesterday by the Alu minum Company of America.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: SOVIET BIDS TURKS RETURNHIJACKERS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15The So viet Union asked Turkey today to extradite the hijackers of Soviet passenger plane.

title: Delaney Is Confident With 3Party Help in Ninth District
description: Kepresentative James J. De laney, Democrat of Queens, padded in hiss stocking feet about his Washington office the other day with the trium phant air of Sabu after he had put the skids on a stampeding elephant.

title: 2 GROUPS DECRY SCRIBNER STAND
description: The Board of Examiners of the city school system and the Council of Supervisory Associa tions yesterday denounced Chancellor Harvey B. Scrib ner's proposal to abolish local licensing tests for prospective teachers and supervisors.

title: Halpern Is Opposing Young Conservative in Sixth District
description: On paper, Representa tive Seymour Halpern, the only Republican House member from New York City, looks like shooIn for reelection to a seventh term from the Sixth Congressional District in Queens.

title: Sargent to Continue Drive
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent, a Republi can, said today that he would continue his campaign for re election despite the illness of his Democratic opponent, Mayor Kevin H. White of Bos ton. Mr. White underwent surgery at Massachusetts Gen eral Hospital last night for an ulcer. Earlier, Mr. Sargent had said he would suspend cam paigning during Mr. White's convalescence.

title: Weaver Develops Managerial DecisionMaking Into a Fine Art
description: Atop the baseball world today sits a small, lively, 40 yearold man with a roly poly face and a hoarse but nonstop voice, named Earl Sidney Weaver. He never played in a major league baseball game, and never even reached the TripleA level, which is one step be low the majors; but before lie was 26 he was already managing in the minors and yesterday, on his second try, he completed the job of pilot ing the Baltimore Orioles to victory in a World Series.

title: Britain Gets New Panel on Environrndnt
description: LONDON, Oct. 15Prime Minister Heath created a broad new government department today to preserve and defend the environment of the British isles.

title: At Paris Talks, Nixon Plan Meets a Total Rejection
description: PARIS, Oct. 15 The Com munist delegations at the Viet nam peace talks declared to day that their rejection of Pres ident Nixon's peace proposals was firm, total and categori cal, but the. United States re fused to accept this as a final answer.

title: Floridians Down Cougars
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 15 (AP) The Floridians opened their American Basketball Associa tion season with a 10597 victory over the Carolina Cougars at the Miami Beach Convention Hall tonieht.

title: Senator Calls Inquiry Into Shift On TaxExempt Litigant Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Senator Gaylord Nelson an nounced today that hearings would be held early in Novem ber on the challenge by the Internal Revenue Service to the taxexempt status of or ganizations that file suits on behalf of consumers or envir onmental protection.

title: SCHOOL SOCCER
description: SCHOOL SOCCER

title: Mayor Studies Role in Governor Race
description: Mayor Lindsay is receiving conflicting counsel from his official family and his oldest, most trusted advisers over what role he should assume in the gubernatorial campaign.

title: Sexism in a Child's Books?
description: A boy wonders what he's going to be as a man; a girl wonders not what she will be, but who the man will be.

title: 3 PROTEST LISTING IN RADICAL GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Three persons who were listed by the House Internal Security Committee, in a report released yesterday, as being members of or as having participated in the activities of radical organ izations protested today the in clusion or their names on the list.

title: Paduano Outpoints Fraser
description: TORONTO, Oct. 15 (UPI) Donato Paduano, 152 pounds, Montreal, scored his 21st con secutive victory tonight by pounding out a unanimous ten round decision over Colin Fra ser, 147, Toronto.

title: Finch on Agnew's Action
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 15Rob ert H. Finch, Counselor to President Nixon, said to day that Vice President Agnew was not representing the White House when he attended a luncheon for James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for Senate, and denounced Mr. Goodell.

title: I.O.S. Chief to Meet With S.E.C.
description: Robert E. Slater, the newly named president and chief ex ecutive officer of Investors Overseas Services, disclosed in a news conference here yester day that he would meet soon with the Securities and Ex change Commission to pave the way for the giant mutual fund complex to begin operations in the United States.

title: Permissiveness in Baltimore
description: Playing in Vice President Agnew's Baltimore, the Orioles showed no signs of being nabobs of negativism at the plate or of pusillanimous pussyfooting afield as they won the World Series. By standing up to the Red aggressors from Cincinnati, silencing the majority their sluggers, and denying the radiclibs from middle America a chance to do their thing, the Orioles proved that clean living and thinking plus Brooks Robinson third base can bring victory with honor.

title: Court Backs State Ban on Pelts Of Animals Nearing Extinction
description: ALBANY, Oct. 15The State Court of Appeals today upheld a new state law prohibiting im portation or sale of skins of animals deemed near extinction.

title: Bell, Jets Rookie, Imitates the Stars
description: Ed Bell is a 5foot10inch 160pound New York Jets rookie who has always tried to be like somebody bigger than himself.

title: Nixon Signs Transit Bill, Terming It a Landmark
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  President Nixon signed today legislation he proposed last year to commit $10billion for new and improved bus and sub way systems in urban areas over the next 12 years.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Treasury Statement

title: Corporate Bond Prices Steady, But Some Municipals Ease Off
description: Corporate bond prices firmed in early trading yesterday but faded somewhat in latter ac tivity to close, as one broker put it, just about on dead center.

title: Flyers Top Canucks, 54
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (UPI)Serge Bernier scored two goals, the first of his Na tional Hockey League career, to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5.4 victory tonight over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Conservative Campaigners Demonstrate a Polished Expertise
description: Just for a moment, F. tlif ton White, the tweedy; bow tied politician who is master minding the campaign, to elect James L. Buckley as United States Senator from New York; lost bis profes sorial air.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: New Jersey New Jersey New Jersey

title: Egypt Votes in Presidential Plebiscite
description: NAZLET EL SAMMAN, United Arab Republic, Oct. 15 Camel drivers, guides and souvenir venders in this vil lage at the foot of the Pyra mids of Giza paused briefly to day from waylaying foreign tourists to mark ballots in the plebiscite to elect Anwar Sadat as President of the United Arab Republic.

title: Correspondent for WPIX Denies He or Station Falsified Report
description: A freelance correspondent whose name was introduced un expectedly into the WPIX li cense hearing has written to Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, denying that he or WPIX had falsified a news re port from Caracas, Venezuela, in November of 1968.

title: Two Hijack Soviet Plane To Turkey, Kill Hostess
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 15 A Soviet airliner, on a do mestic run between two Black Sea cities with 51 persons aboard, was hijacked today by two passengers who killed the stewardess and seriously wounded the pilot and copilot, forcing them to fly to the Turk ish Dort of Trebizond.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15 [UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Posters, Including Own, Pain Court Candidate
description: Joseph Modugno, Republi can Conservative candidate for the State Supreme Court in Queens, yesterday put his money where his protests had been.

title: Stage: Woes of a D.A.
description: Shortly before My House Is Your House opened at the Players Theater, the ac tor playing the lead part withdrew from the cast, announcing a suddenly dis covered prior commitment. A wise actor. Last night, at the first of what is bound to be a drastically reduced num ber of performances, there was a mass exit during the course of the play. The exit ers included most of the re viewers in attendance. While they were there, they saw nothingand after they left, they missed nothing.

title: Buzin Offers Rationale for Giant Woes
description: The New York Giants seem to be at a loss to explain and thus correct their second half jitters this season. Lead ing in all of their four games at halftime, the Giants lost three and almost dissipated their advantage over the Phil adelphia Eagles last Sunday before Ron Johnson's run won the game.

title: interne Group to Report Deaths Laid to City Hospital Shortages
description: An organization of more than 2,000 city hospital internes and resident physicians announced plans yesterday to start an abuse registry documenting evidence of patient deaths, caused by a lack of nurses, equipment or facilities in the city hospitals.

title: Lindsay Installs 3 Judges To Terms in City Courts
description: Mayor Lindsay appointed and swore in two judges to the Criminal Court yesterday to terms that will expire Dec. 31, 1978, and a Civil Court judge whose interim term will expire next Dec. 31.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: AMEX PRICES DIP ON LATE SELLING
description: Declines outpaced advances yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the eighth consecutive session as some late selling erased most of the earlier gains in Quiet trading.

title: Nasserism Without Nasser
description: CAIROThis week's national refer endum overwhelmingly approved the uncontested selection of Anwar Sadat as President of the United Arab Re public or, as it is better known, Egypt, but it will be up to Sadat himself to consolidate his position as unchal lenged boss. For there can be no true successor to Nasser and there is bound to be a behindthescenes struggle for the apparent succession in terms of real power.

title: RAIL FREIGHT DOWN; TRUCK TONNAGE OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Saturday were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

title: Dr. Scribner's Heresy
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner is following the rare course of a public official who puts professional integrity above the exigencies of school system tradition. He has told the Board of Education that he does not intend defend in court the examination procedures for principals now under challenge by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund. His reason is simply that he believes those procedures are no longer valid.

title: 2 BARGES IN CUBA NOW WORRY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 United States officials said to day that the continuing pres ence of two Soviet barges in the Cuban harbor of Cienfue gos was causing concern to the Nixon Administration.

title: Mr. Impossible Wins Car and Fans Cheers
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (AP) If you don't think Balti more fans expect the impos sible from Brooks Robinson, the Orioles premier third baseman, listen to this:

title: Advertising: ExBaker Lets Sunshine In
description: Recently, it seems, almost every time a new and differ ent advertising medium ap pears on the scene Sunshine Biscuits is among the first to try it.

title: Motorcycle Record Set
description: BONNEVILE SALT FLATS, Utah, Oct. 15 (UPI)After midweek accident that caused his vehicle to roll 20 times, Cal Rayborn of San Diego returned today and set a land speed record for motorcycles. Ray born had a twoway average speed of 255.373 miles an hour through the measured mile, sur passing the previous record by, about four miles an hour he drove a 1480 CC Hanley David son.

title: No Comment in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15There was no immediate official comment here on the Soviet proposals.

title: TRADE GROUP DUE TO REVIEW SETUP
description: A restructuring or a split in the ranks of the Association of Buying Offices, the 37yearold trade association of resident buying offices here, is expected to emerge today from a meeting of a number of its member of fices.

title: SYLVIA MARLOWE LEADS A CONCERT
description: The concert that Sylvia Mar lowe led on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, first in a series of four sailing un der the name Contrasts, al most lived up to its port manteau description. The pro gram promised music newold, solo  ensemble, frivolous  seri ous, simpledifficult, gaysad, shortlong, naivesophisticated, well knownobscure, major minor, nowthen  If it stretched a point to find any thing really new, let alone now, or genuinely naive, the results were nonetheless totally palat able and predominantly de licious.

title: $1.2Million Fund Drive Opened by the Lighthouse
description: The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, held its annual award luncheon at the Plaza Hotel yesterday to open a fund drive for $1,293, 600.

title: LANDLORDS, UNION APPROVE CONTRACT
description: Landlords and striking build ing service workers in the Bronx voted in separate meet ings yesterday to accept a settlement reached last Tues day night. The walkout had affected service for up to 500, ono tenants.

title: Ashe Defeated by McKay In Phoenix, 76, 36, 64
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 15 (AP) Barry McKay, a former Unit ed States Davis Cup player, pulled a stunning upset today in the $25,000 Phoenix Thun derbird tennis open, downing topseeded Arthur Ashe, 76, 36, 64.

title: A Hard Look at Vietnam Peace
description: When Mme. Nguyen Thi Binh, rep resenting the Provisional Revolution ary Government (PRG) of South Viet nam, put forward an 8point program to end the war a few weeks ago, it was shrugged off here as nothing new.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The six changes proposed by Mayor Lindsay to the Judicial Conference with reference to court reform almost implies, ipso facto, that the unpre cedented crime rise this past half decade in New York CityWe expect 250,000 arrests this year, says Mayor Lindsayare wholly ascribable to an obsolete judicial system rendered only worse by an obsolescent prison system.

title: EUROPEAN BANKS ARRANGE A PACT
description: PARIS, Oct. 15  France's second and Germany's third largest banks announced today a program of financial, tech nical and managerial coopera tion, setting them up as the fifth strongest banking force in the world.

title: Louis to Be Released From Hospital Today
description: DENVER, Oct. 15 (UPI) Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight boxing cham pion, hospitalized since last May because of an emotional disorder, will be released to morrow from the Veterans Administration Hospital.

title: Fashion Show Set For Brick Church
description: Members of the Brick Pres byterian Church and their children will serve as models for the fashion show to be presented Tuesday afternoon at the 27th annual fair ar ranged by the church in be half of national and interna tional social services.

title: College Results
description: College Results

title: Jewelry That Has Sense of Movement
description: Jewelry designers seem to come and go from one estab lishment to another with only a little less frequency than advertising men move from one Madison Avenue agency to another. Thus, Cartier's new designer, Aldo Cipullo, the only one the store now has under contract, started Shop Talk out with David Webb and then spent six years at Tiffany Co. Only 32 years old Mr. Cipullo (pro nounced CheePOOLo) has just finished his first collec tion for Cartier and the store likes to think that he may be on his way to becoming to it what Schlumberger has been to Tiffany's.

title: MORRIS RYBAK
description: Morris Rybak, a textile im porter and exporter of 70 Franklin Street, died Thursday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 575 West End Avenue.

title: Holly Ewing Bride on L.I.
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Oct. 16Miss Cath erine Halsted Ewing, grand daughter of Dr. James Ewing, the cancer patholo gist for whom the James Ewing Hospital in New York was named, was married here this evening to Giorgio Andrea Tattanelli of Flor ence, Italy.

title: Universities at the Crossroads
description: Maybe our problems relate more deeply than we suspect to the parlous state of the world around usto its basic malaise, to its anomie, to its frustration and rootlessness. I suspect that we are, in the Western world and even beyond its boundaries, passing through an historical watershed which we little understand and which may be ultimately of more importance than the Renaissance, the Reformation; or the industrial revolution.

title: Kendall Ahead in Aussie Golf
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 16 (AP)Terry Kendall of New Zealand led by a stroke after the second round today in the Wills Masters open golf tourna ment with a fourunderpar 140. Tommy Aaron of the United States had a 145 and Dave Marr, also of the United States, was at 147.

title: Egypt, at U.N., Says U.S. Misled Nasser on Truce
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16Foreign Minister Mah moud Riad of the United Arab Republic accused the United States today of having misled President Gamal Abdel Nasser into accepting a Middle East ceasefire.

title: Knicks Oppose Bulls Tonight, With Bradley Unlikely to Play
description: The Knicks have started well in the defense of their National Basketball Association cham pionship with victories in their opening two games, but a couple of the New Yorkers may be limping tonight when Coach Red Holzman's squad opposes the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Gaidem.

title: Buried System Makes Communication With Vehicles Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Theodore Hafner of New York, holder of a number of patents on the GLine, which transmits microwaves through an invisible tube of air sur rounding a pole strung wire, has invented an un derground ver sion. Because it allows communi cation with vehicles but needs no overhead wires, he hopes the buried GLine will be adopted for the country's highways and railroads. Pat ent 3,534,303, granted to Dr. Hafner this week, provides for an insulated wire to be mounted in an aluminum trough, covered by a strong plastic shield flush with the ground.

title: Irish, Fighting Inflation Order WagePrice Curbs
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 16  The Irish Government announced sweep ing controls over wages and prices today including a one year ceiling of 6 per cent on pay increases and a total freeze on rents, company dividends and prices of houses.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Transport News: Pilots Course at Planetarium
description: The American MuseumHay den Planetarium, which is ac credited by the Federal Avia tion Administration as an in strument pilot ground school, is offering a sevenweek cram course starting Nov. 3 for pi lots preparing for the F.A.A.'s written examination to qualify as instrument pilots.

title: Drug. Use Worries Service Schools
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 13 The nation's service academies have become in creasingly concerned over the potential threat to military discipline and effectiveness posed by the ready availa bility of marijuana and LSD to future officers.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS PLAN FOR COURTS
description: Governor Rockefeller pro posed yesterday a program to improve the state's court sys tem through judicial and execu tive action, including more judgeships for the city, more state aid for the system and a special narcotics court.

title: L. I. Gives Buckley Exuberant Greeting
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 16  This Is Buckley Country, a sign on Sunrise Highway in Nassau County reads, and the Conservative party candidate received tumultuous receptions during a threeday swing through Long Island this week.

title: Pacers Down Rockets
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16 (AP) 6The Indiana Pacers surged to their second straight victory tonight, a 115105 triumph over the Denver Rockets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh's statement in his Op. Ed. page Pro posal for Mideast Peace  (Oct. 1) that the Israelis have not shown more compassion than the politically motivated Arab nations toward the problem of the Palestinian refugees is grossly in error, and a libel on the Jewish State.

title: Bringing the Boys Home
description: President Nixon's announcement that another 40,000 troops will be brought home from Vietnam by Christmas is clearly a curtainraiser for the campaign swing he begins this morning. Politics also is undoubtedly a factor in Secretary of Defense Laird's announced plan to do away with draft calls by July 1, 1973. Unfortunately, the fine print does not quite meet the expectations both announcements have created.
