description: Obituary 4  No Title

title: Goodell for Senator
description: In these restless times, when old institutions increas ingly seem unable to cope with new problems, it is es pecially important for voters to select candidates vision and independence to shape public policies. Division and despair undermine confidence in government. Educational institutions do not educate. Transportation sys tems do not transport. A long abused environment de teriorates in almost every way. Cities, awash in wastes, choke on foul air and grope through blackouts enforced by power failures. And a frustrating war drains off re sources needed to mount an effective attack on these staggering problems.

title: L.S.U. WINS, 147, FROM KENTUCKY
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 17 (UPI)Art Cantrelle and Del Walker scored one touchdown apiece tonight, leading Louisi ana State to a 147 South eastern Conference victory over Kentucky.

title: NONCOMBAT TOLL TOPS WAR DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) American casualties in South Vietnam have dropped to the level where nearly as many men die from accidents, illness or disease as are killed in combat.

title: A PACIFIST REVOLT IS URGED BY DOW
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Danilo Dobai, whose words are of peace and whose acts are edged with boldness, stopped here last week on a tour of American campuses.

title: NEBRASKA BEATS KANSAS BY 4120,
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 17 (UPI)  Fourthranked Ne braska, stung by a three touchdown explosion by Kan sas in the first half, rallied behind the passing and running of Dan Brownson today for a 4120 Big Eight Conferenc football victory.

title: King of Carnivals: Feria in Seville Is Europe's Zaniest
description: SEVILLE, SpainThis city has survived invasion and occupation by Phoenicians, Greeks, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals and Moors, but how it manages to sur vive its yearly fair is a mystery.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: ST. LOUISBen Fixrnan is the kind of man about whom Horatio Alger wrote those success stories. He started working at the age of 6, dropped out of school to help his widowed mother, and now at 45 is chairman of one of the largest corpora tions in America. He would not seem to have many things to regret.

title: Subway Service Delayed For Hour by Fire on 1RT
description: A smoky fire in a train at the BIT station at Broadway and 72d Street disrupted service on Ste downtown express line for almost an hour yesterday morn ing.

title: What's Opened in the Theater?
description: CONDUCT UNBECOMING, a play by Barry England, excited eight of the ten critics who reviewed it. Clive Barnes: Conduct Unbecoming is quite a wonderful example of its genrea whodunit, a why hedidit and a wnereit wasdone of quite unusual interest and quality. Mr. England has set his play in the late part of the last century in the anteroom to the Officers Mess of an In dian Army regiment. The pattern is familiar. It was the subject of all those Hollywood movies with C. Aubrey Smith, Victor Mc Laglen and occasionally Sabu on an elephant. This is where Mr. England is very clever. He prepares us for the full North East Frontier saga, but then turns the story completely inside out. Val May's stag ing, like the author's writ ing, makes the most of the play's two most attractive qualities; its suspense and its exceptional atmosphere and style. Paul Jones, Jere my Clyde, Donald Picker ing and Michael Barrington are superb in their roles. It is a rattling good play, and I trust the sun doesn't it for some time.

title: College of Surgeons Picks Philadelphian as President
description: Mr. Rhoads was elected on Thursday at the group's 56th annual clinical congress, being attended by 14,000 surgeons from throughout the world.

title: Dr. Quincy Wright, 79, Is Dead; Authority on International Law
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 17Dr. Quincy Wright, profes sor emeritus of international law at the University of Chica go and the University of Vir ginia, died today. His age was 79.

title: Art
description: LET'S not put up any money here, since who knows who might be reading this, but you would be safe in most art conscious circles in betting that nobody present could name half a dozen German painters working at any time during the three and a half centuries that elapses be tween the deaths of Holbein and Cranach around 1550 (Cranach's sons don't count) and the emergence of Ger man expressionism in 1905 with the formation of The Bridge.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Under the Nixon Adminis tration's economic policies we have the worst of all worlds. We have high un employment and a low growth rate. In the mean time prices have continued to rise and interest rates are close to the highest levels in modern United States his tory. We thus have inflation and stagnation. Recently this combination has been dubbed stagflation.

title: Miss Martha Louise Farnsworth Is Wed
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 17Miss Martha Louise Farnsworth, a senior at George Washington Universi ty, was married here this morning to Joseph Richard Gallagher Jr., a senior at Georgetown University. The Rev. John Fitzgerald per formed the ceremony and cel ebrated the Nuptial Mass in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Kent State Routed, 440
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Oct. 17 (UPI)Julius Lives scored four touchdowns and gained 107 yards, more yards than he had gained in the five previous games combined, to lead Bowl ing Green to a 440 victory over Kent State today in a Mid American Conference game.

title: At Last, an Imaginative Mind
description: THERE are all kinds of sounds in the dark between the chopped off scenes, some on earth, some in heaven, that are cavalierly, merrily, wantonly stitched together to make Kurt Vonnegut's first play. Happy Birthday, Wanda June. Aviary sounds, jungle sounds, carousel sounds and one I thought I identified but still can't swear to. Every so often I think I heard a quick crack! with a slapstick followed by the harsh, high squawk that has always signified that Punch, of Punch and Judy, is being swatted again.

title: Son to Mrs. Meyer
description: A son was born on Sept. 24 in the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Rob ert Meyer.

title: Springfield Takes No. 5; Downs Northeastern, 147
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 17Unbeaten Springfield Col lege jumped off to a 14point lead, after three quarters, and held on to beat Northeastern University, 147, for the Chief's fifth victory.

title: When sound overcame sense
description: The C.B.S. radio 89 P.M. Sunday timeslot in 1938 was given over to Orson Welles and his Mercury Theater, one of the best programs of this pretelevision period. For Sun day, Oct. 30, the famous Orson, then on his way up and out of radio into the films and such triumphs as Citizen Kane, chose to dramatize H. G. Wells's short sciencefiction novel, The War of the Worlds, in which a Martian invasion of earth is stirringly described. Howard Koch, who presents this account, was the man who wrote the play itself, and thus knows whereof he speaks.

title: Oil Produced Off Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 17  The independent In donesian American Petro leum Company appears to have won the race for In donesia's first offshore oil production, having completed a production platform on a discovery well it announced only six weeks ago.

title: A Builder of Canada
description: DONALD Alexander Smith, born 150 years ago (Aug, 6, 1820) at Forres, Morgy, Scot land, will be the subject of a commemorative stamp from Canada on Nov. 4. Smith rose from humble beginnings to become a prime leader in Canada's development and in the building of the Canadian Pacific Railway which linked eastern Canada with its West ern provinces. For his many services in Canada he was knighted by Queen Victoria in 1884 and raised to the peerage in 1897.

title: PEKING AWAITING CANADIAN ENVOY
description: CANTON, ChinaIt was at the breakfast table in the din ing room of the Tung Fang Ho tel here that I first got the news that China and Canada had established diplomatic re lations.

title: Middleburg Eleven Victor Over Hamilton, 21 to 20
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Oct. 17 Middlebury, trailing by 20.0 at halftime, defeated Hamilton in football, 2120, today when Bill Pope ran 75 yards for a touch down in the third period and scored a lastperiod touchdown on a pass from the quarter back, Pete Makay, whose con version kick provided the win ning margin.

title: GOLDBERG SCORES DRUG CENTER USE
description: Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that gross under utilization by the Rockefeller administration of narcotics treatment facilities was partly responsible for the continuing high level of crime attributed to addicts.

title: Rogers, Gromyko Fail to End impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Secretary of State William P. Rogers flew home today with a report for President Nixon that he had rejected Soviet pres sures for a quick start of Arab Israeli talks without rectifica tion of violations of the Middle East ceasefire.

title: BULLETS SET BACK LAKERS BY 118116
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (UPI) Kevin Loughery sank a pair of free throws with 9 seconds re maining in overtime tonight to give the Baltimore Bullets 118116 National Basketball As sociation victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Rally Erases Leafs Lead
description: TORONTO, Oct. 17A hockey player named Syl Apps ap peared on Maple. Leaf. Gardens ice for the first time in 22 years tonight, but it was the presence of Walt Tkaczuk and Brad Park that wrecked To ronto.

title: Foreigners Hail Open Door Idea In Florida
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.Citizens of this growing city a few miles north of Mi ami are giving foreign visitors an un usual opportunity to meet Americans and see how they live. It is done through a Greater Hollywood Chamber of Com merce program called Hollywood at Home, under which residents here meet cruise ships from overseas arriving at nearby Port Everglades and take pas sengers on a tour of the area and into their own homes.

title: Mayor of Vancouver Urges Use of War Power on Crime
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Oct. 17 (UPI)The mayor of Vancouver, Tom Campbell, who has been under police guard since Thursday because of telephoned threats of kid napping said yesterday he would like to use the War Measures Act against all types of criminals, not just persons advocating anarchy.

title: Soviet Passengers and Crew Describe Hijacking
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17Nadya rushed into the pilots com partment, screamed hijack ing, and began to close the door. A shot rang out. Nad3ra fell and a man of about 50 burst into the cabin. He held a sawedoff shotgun in his hands and shouted, Turkey, Turkey?

title: For Young Readers
description: Aschenputtel, Cinderella, now Vasilisa the Beautifulso familiar, and still so deeply stirringwhy? Maybe because of the momentous question implicit in every version of the story: Mather, what will happen to me when you die? The story is the answer: Child, my love and care

title: BECKNER CAPTURES FLYING SCOT SERIES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 17 Ralph Manee of Shore Acres, N. J., won the 7.8mile final race of the fall invitation regatta of the Flying Scot Class off Riverside Yacht Club to day but Richard Beckner of Candlewood Lake, Conn., the only skipper to officially com plete all three races, took the series title.

title: When the Republicans were, the liberals
description: Until recently historians have not been kind to the founders of the Republican party. Charles A. Beard dismissed Republi cans professed concern over slavery as windowdressing, designed to conceal their real purpose of promoting Northern business. Other scholars have

title: Warning On Cars
description: The Federal Government last week warned the owners of four million 196569 big Ford cars that there might be a defect in their vehicles that could cause a wheel to fail.

title: Light Snow Marks Winter's Preview In Suburban Areas
description: The first signs of winter crept into the metropolitan area yesterday as the tempera ture plunged to 36 degrees in the city and light snow fell in parts of Westchester County and Long Island.

title: Back at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) President Nixon arrived by helicopter at the White House at 11:45 P.M. tonight from Andrews Air Force Base, Md., where his plane landed.

title: Study Finds Impact of Migrants On the Cities Is Not Significant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Urban Institute has completed a study that discredits the widely held belief that poor and uneducated migrants from the South and rural areas elsewhere are contributing greatly to the problems of the cities.

title: Television This Week
description: TODAYSUNDAY, OCTOBER 18

title: Ylvisaker Is Elected Chairman Of United States Polo Group
description: William T. Ylvisaker of Bar irington, III., was elected chair man of the United States Polo Association at the recent annual meeting at headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill. Northrup Knox of Buffalo was named vicechair man and Heath Manning of Columbia, S. C., was named secretarytreasurer.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Some cable television prophets foresee television and radio transmitters rust ing in the fields while the Doyle Danes and the Carl Allys anxiously master the new vernacular of CATV. Wires alone, however, do not an advertising medium make.

title: Banks Aid Puerto Rico Drive
description: Several Puerto Rican banks here will be open today from noon to 6 P.M. to receive dona tions for Puerto Rican flood re lief victims. They are Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, with branches at 90 Delancey Street and 3540 Broadway in Manhat tan and 432 Westchester Ave nue, the Bronx; Banco de Ponce, at 162 East 116th Street, Man hattan and at 1030 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx and Banco Credito at 1 Union Square West, Manhattan.

title: DR. NORMAN STEWART
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 Dr. Norman H. Stewart, pro fessor emeritus of zoology at Bucknell University, died yes terday at the age of 85.

title: Tattersalls Yearling Sales Set Record of $4.6Million
description: NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Records were es tablished today at the conclu sion of the Tattersalls yearling sales.

title: The War Of the Cops
description: PHILADELPHIA. IT was a Sunday night and there was tension in Philadelphia. The previous night, Aug. 29, a group of black militants had attacked lonely guardhouse in Cobbs Creek Park, on the border of West Philadel phia and Delaware County. Frank Von Colin, a 42yearold park guard, was killed and another guard, James Harrington, wounded.

title: Beatrice Ward Of Navy Is Wed To S. S. Gauvain
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. Oct. 17Lieut. (jg.) Beatrice Lynn Ward, U.S.N., was mar ried here today to Steven Sands Gauvain. The Rev. Dr. Joseph T. Bishop performed the ceremony at the East Hampton Presbyterian Church.

title: That Man On the Stump Is President Nixon
description: WASHINGTONBetween Mr. Nasser (who died) and Mr. Agnew (who remains very much alive), Richard Nixon hasn't been getting many headlines recently.

title: Reader's Report
description: Manila during the dark days of World War II is the incu bator for this unusual ferment of fantasy and reality. It is a stagnant time, high in mal nutrition and low in hope. (The word was WAIT. Wait for the Locidieeds with the twin bodies. Wait for the midnight submarine from Australia. Wait for dawn, for doughnuts, for retribution. Ultimately, the magic word ceased to be a word; it became their world.) Torture, mutilation and murder in a Japanese internment camp, love in a scrofulous boarding house, the comings and goings of occupation troops and re sistance harbingerssuch stim uli as these provoke a fever of imagery that gives this book its surrealist aura.

title: ROBERT DOLMAN, MR. TENNIS, DIES
description: Robert (Rip) Dolman, who was known as Mr. Tennis for almost four decades in New York, died on Monday at Rock land County Hospital at the age of 77.

title: The Diary of Samuel Pepys
description: From 1660 to 1669 Samuel Pepys, the ambitious young Secretary to Navy Board, described his daily activities in one and a quarter million words of prose. That he should compile such a monstrous liferecord, in an age that placed a relatively low value on private experience, is extraordinary; still more so that he should be able to conceal the monster's existence from his family, his friends, and even his wife.

title: An old man's erotic revels pulsing with the juices of life
description: Here are all 347 of the series of gravures (etchings, dry points, aqua tints, etc.), already famous, that Picasso began on March 16 and con cluded on Oct. 5, 1968, just three weeks before his 87th birthday. To scan the two volumes page by page is like watching an old, old acrobat go through his paces with undi minished alacrity. Such handsprings, backflips, somersaults and cart wheels, you never saw.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A few days ago I met a fellow townsman on Martha's Vineyard Island who remarked that he hadn't seen me for quite a while. He then asked how things were at the Oceanographic.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Those of you who share my fondness for British mystery comedy films will remember Make Mine Mink, in which TerryThomas played a retired military officer who led a mot ley but inspired crew of re ugees from the geriatrics ward on a mad crime spree. You may also recall Robert L. Fish's novel The Murder League, in which a band of mystery writers whiled away their twilight years by setting up shop in the killforhire line. Now comes Robert Carson's THE GOLDEN YEARS CAPER (Little, Brown, $5.95), another joyous variation on the theme.

title: 2 BET MARKS SET AS YONKERS SHUTS
description: YONKERS, Oct. 17The 41 degree temperature kept the crowd down to 22,912 as Yon kers Raceway wound up its 1970 harness racing year to night with a couple of money records and one dead horse on the track.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Permits a State SelfRule
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 17 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi under severe criticism for having suspended the govern mant of Uttar Pradesh 15 days agotoday allowed an oppo sition coalition to form a new government in that pivotal northern state.

title: Executives Retire to Work
description: A growing number of top corporate executives are tak ing early retirement to help cure social ills, to enter gov ernment work and to assist in raising the nation's edu cational level.

title: Army Leads N.Y.U. in Run
description: The Army cross  country team defeated New York Uni versity 2530, in a dual meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The West Pointers offset N.Y.U.'s Jim Schindler's firstplace finish with their depth, placing five men in the top eight positions.

title: New York Tech Wins
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 17 (AP) Steve Szewzuk gained 98 yards in nine carries, including a touchdown to Dace unbeaten New York Tech to a 2914 vic tory over the University of Con necticut, Stamford branch. It was Tech's fourth victory.

title: Lafayette Erases 12Point Deficit and Conquers Jefferson, 2112, in. P.S.A.L.
description: Thomas Jefferson moved to an early 120 lead over Lafay ette yesterday in the battle of undefeated Public Schools Ath letic League teams. But then John Perretti, a halfback, and Joe Cioffi, the quarterback, swung into action for the home team, and at the game's end Lafayette had its third victory, 2112.

title: Tax Protection Is Proposed For Spouse of Embezzler
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reu ters)A bill to protect the in nocent wife or husband of an embezzler from tax liability has been introduced in the House by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Arksansas Democrat, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

title: Owners in City Start to Feel Fuel Squeeze
description: A longforeseen fuel crisis that appears certain to make the coming winter a cold one for thousands of New York ers has begun to bear down upon apartment house own ers in the city.

title: Sullivan Leads 317 Rout
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 17 (UPI) Pat Sullivan passed for two touchdowns and scored third today as eighthranked Auburn trounced 15th ranked Georgia Tech, 517.

title: Strike Over Fish Cook Delays Sailing of QE2
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 17 (AP)  The British liner Queen Elizabeth 2 was prevented from sailing for 4 hours today by a strike of crewmen, but she finally left for New York when the Cunard Line agreed to rein state a fish cook who had been dismissed.

title: Miss Anne Dolores Davis Is Bride
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 17 ailiss Anne Dolores Davis, daughter of Mrs. Armand M. Morell of Rye and Joseph G. Davis of San Francisco, was married here this after noon to Richard Alden Rav Pinkham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pinkham of Rye. Msgr. John P. Kelly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Res urrection. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Wendell Philips, an Episcopal priest.

title: ELIS WIN, 32 TO 15
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17Yale, ranked No. 1 on defense be fore the game, showed it had offensive power too today in subduing Columbia, 3215, to remain undefeated.

title: Field Goal by Goncalves Keeps East Hampton Undefeated, 30
description: Perferio Goncalves kicked a 27yard field goal midway in the second period yesterday and a strong East Hampton de fense made it stand up for a 30 triumph over Southampton. The victory was the fourth straight iwithout a loss for the Smackers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Howard Stein (Viewpoint, Oct. 4, is quite correct when he states that the question of institutional ownership of stock exchange seats may be settled without adequate discussion and debate. Un fortunately, however, Mr. Stein's own comments, con taining serious errors of fact and logic, shed little light on the issues involved.

title: Negro Student Aid Of $500,000 Given By Ford Foundation
description: The National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students has been granted $500,000 by the Ford Founda tion to extend its computerized counseling and placement serv ices to virtually all young blacks seeking to enter college.

title: Governor Opposes Plan For Jamaica Runways
description: Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that he was com pletely opposed to the pro posed extension of Kennedy In ternational Airport runways into Jamaica Bay.

title: Ukrainian Said to Be Tried For AntiSoviet Writings
description: A Ukrainian student group here said this week that a his tory teacher was being tried in the Soviet Ukraine on charges of propaganda and agitation against the state.

title: La dies Auxiliary Of the Chaminade Society, Arise !
description: Some time ago a high offi cial of the American Govern ment made a speech castigat ing the deleterious impact of popular music on American youth. Recently hi:; attention has been drawn to contempo rary music. Following is part of a speech he delivered to the Ladies Auxiliary Group of the Chaminade Society of Independence, Idaho, on Feb. 29, 1971.

title: Manhole Fire on East Side
description: Firemen battled a manhole blaze on Third Avenue between 65th and 66th Streets for more than half an hour last night, the Fire Department reported. The fire was believed to have been caused by a gas explosion and the subsequent effects on electrical wiring running under the street, but the exact cause was not immediately deter mined. There were no injuries reported.

title: 50 of 100 New Jersey Bus Drivers Are Suspended
description: TRENTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Nearly 50 of 100 operators of school and chartered bitses who have appeared before a hear ing examiner of the New Jer sey Division of Motor Vehicles have had all driving privileges suspended.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Economic Indicators

title: Elliott Gould Will Ride a Tiger
description: BRITISH director Anthony Harvey teems to have contracted jungle fever. First The Lion in Win ter, and now A Glimpse of Tiger. Although the latter specimen still something of a dark mystery, Harvey did say the other day that it an original black comedy by Herman Raucher about two farout New York ers and their battles with the establish ment. They are in love, and yet they never really touch. The young man cannot cope with reality and the girl cannot operate continuously in a world of fantasy. Starring as the fantastic young man will be the fantastically popular Elliott Gould, who will copro duce the movie with Jack Brodsky for Warner Bros. But first Gould must com fate his Swedish stint for Ingmar Bergman in The Touch, which is also shrouded in its fair share of mystery. And Harvey still faces the task of get ting They Might Be Giants, his comedydrama with Joanne Woodward and George C. Scott, ready for its Dec. 21 bow at the Plaza.

title: Owned by Earl and Trudy Grier
description: Owned by Earl and Trudy Grier of Pottstown, Pa., gaited to first place in the non sporting divi sion from the classes.

title: First Puerto Rican Here Named Superintendent of Local Board
description: Alfredo Mathew Jr. has been appointed a community school board superintendent making him the first person of Puerto Rican background to attain that position.

title: Susanne Jackson Wed To Jeffrey C. Miller
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 17St. John's Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Susanne Jackson to Jeffrey C. Miller.

title: CANADIAN HOSTAGE SLAIN; BODY OF LAPORTE FOUND IN AUTO NEAR MONTREAL
description: MONTREAL, Sunday, Oct 18 The body of Pierre Laporte, one of two men kidnapped by extremist Quebec separat ists, was found about midnight in the trunk of a car at St. Hubert Airport, outside Mont real.

title: KANSAS CITY HURT BY 196DAY STRIKE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 17  The strike that shut down construction in this city for 196 days is over. But civic leaders are predicting that it will take years to recover from the eco nomic loss.of construtcion that prevailed when the stoppage began April 1. They hope to get back into full stride before severe winter weather again shuts down some of the projects.

title: A 29TH TRIUMPH FOR NEW CANAAN
description: New. Canaan is one victory from tying the Connecticut school record for consecutive victories after notching its 29th yesterday, an impressive 406 triumph over Stamford Catholic at New Canaan.

title: Costa Rica Inaugurates Highway to Atlantic Coast
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 17 (UPI)San Jose has been linked to Puerto Linin on the Atlantic side of Costa Rica.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The body of Pierre Laporte, one of Que bec's two kidnapping victims, was found early this morning near Montreal, only hours after the government offered the kid nappers, members of the militant terrorist Front for the Liberation of Quebec, safe passage to Cuba in return for the hostages. Earlier the House of Commons voted confi dence in the government, which had as sumed emergency wartime powers. [Page 1, Column 68.]

title: 2 WOMEN ARE NAMED TO LIST OF FUGITIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of In vestigation placed on its 10 Most Wanted List today the names of Susan Edith Saxe and Katherine Ann Power, charged in connection with the killing of a Boston policeman after bank robbery last Sept. 23.

title: REGULAR GAS FOUND ALL ALIKE IN SURVEY
description: DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP)Ad vertising claims to the contrary, the various brands of regular gasoline are as alike as aspirin tablets, Senator Philip A. Hart said today.

title: Angela Davis: Flight but Not Fight Is Over
description: LOS ANGELESWhen she was a teenager in Birming ham, Ala., Angela Davis worked in voter registration drives and picketed segre gated department stores. She was a friend of the four black girls who were killed in 1963 when a bomb exploded in a Birmingham church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: In describing Rockefeller Center nearing its goal, Glenn Fowler quotes some high praise that I have given the center, as coming from a thoughtful critic and his torian, and his quotation is accurate, in context, and cor rect as far as it goes.

title: MINERS PROTEST IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 17White mine workers in South Africa are threatening to strike in protest against Government plans to train black workers for skilled jobs on mines in the homelands set aside for blacks.

title: On Being an Unfashionable Professor*
description: THE hell of being a historian who has spent a good deal of time over the past quarter century rummaging around in politi cal theory is that one is never really surprised at contemporary follies. Thus the events on American cam puses last spring gave me an acute sense of Mkt vuall one has to do is turn to the late Ronald Knox's brilliant study of enthusiasm as a re curring religious phenomenon.

title: Nixon and Agnew Faulted on Unity By Ripon Society
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) The Ripon Society said today that the failure of President Nixon and Vice President Ag new to endorse Republican Sen ate nominees in New York and Virginia would jeopardize Re publican unity in the 1972 Pres idential election.

title: LIFE STILL HARD IN NORTH KOREA,
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 17When North Korea inau gurated its seven  year eco nomic plan in 1961, Premier Kim II Sung promised that the people would eat meals of rice and meat soup, wear clothes of silk and live in tileroofed houses within five years.

title: Court Weighs Nudity Case
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17, (AP)Superior Court has taken under advisement a motion by two Cambridge residents to dis miss charges of lewdness for walking nude on the porch and roof of their house. Dr. Seth E. Many, 28 years old, a psychia trist, and Carolyn R. Peck, 27, a lawyer, were convicted on the charges lest April in District Court and sentenced to 30 days in jail.

title: Son to Mrs. Estabrook
description: A son was born to Mr.and Mrs. J. Reed Estabrook Jr. of Somerset, N. J., on Oct. at the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Estabrook, a lawyer in Som erset, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Labate of Easton, Pa. Mr. Estabrook is a management service con sultant with the Union Car bide Corporation in New York. The child has been named Matthew Reed.

title: usiness Group Asks U.S. To Discourage Pay Rises
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 17 A group of the nation's lead ing corporation executives pro posed today that the Federal Government embark on some new policies aimed at holding down wage increases and im proving the productiveness of certain groups of workers.

title: SUBURB VOTE KEY TO GOVERNOR RACE
description: Arthur J. Goldberg or any future Democratic candidate for Governor will have to win more support in suburban and nonurban areas than past Dem ocrats to be elected, according to a study issued by the New School's Center for New York City Affairs.

title: Laird Gets 4 Touchdowns
description: LEWISTON, Me., Oct. 17 (AP) Bruce Laird &cored four touchdowns for American In ternational College today, in a 6112 rout of Bates.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS HONORED UPSTATE
description: PINE BUSH, N.Y., Oct. 17 (AP)A colorful parade drew nearly 4,000 persons to this Catskill Mountains community today to honor veterans of the war in Vietnam who, the parade's organizers say, often face psychological defeat at home.

title: WISCONSIN BEATEN BY NORTHWESTERN
description: I MADISON, Wis., Oct. 17(AP) I Northwestern's surprising Wildcats, led by Maurice Daig neau and Mike Adamle, ex ploded for two touchdowns late in the game today to score a 2414 Big Ten victory over Wisconsin.

title: State University Sailors Win 16School Competition
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 Winds of 30 miles an hour and waves of four feet greeted the first intercollegiate sailing championships sponsored by the Corintthians today.

title: Nixon's Peace Plan May Bring International Control Commission Attention From More Than Creditors
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 17  President Nixon's peace proposals for Indochina have succeeded at least in fo cusing the attention of people other than creditors on the In ternational Control Com mission.

title: BOWDOIN'S LATE PASS TOPS WILLIAMS, 2013
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 17 A 48yard touchdown pass from John Benson to Paul Wiley with 18 seconds to play gave Bow doin College a 2013 victory over Williams today before a Parents Day crowd of 3.500.

title: Mood at The U.N.'s 25th Not Exactly Festive
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.The peace organization's 25th birth day anniversarybegan last week with brave words: The world will be listening to what we say and watching what we do, solemnly promised Edvard Ham bro, the Norwegian president of the General Assembly in open ing the 10day commemorative of the United Nations founding.

title: Findings on Obscenity and Pornography
description: To the Editor: The excerpts from the majority re port of the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography reveal a number of dubious premises, allegations and con clusions. For example, the commission states that there is no empirical evi dence that exposure to pornography leads to sexually harmful or deviant practices. While this may be true, a more accurate statement would have been: The causes of sexual aggression and deviancy are currently uncertain. Any number of responsible scientists would support this assertion.

title: Combat Force Reduced
description: SAIGON, Oct. 17 (AP)The United States withdrawal from Vietnam entered another phase today. Three units consisting of nearly 2,000 men were pulled out of combat as the first step to deactivation in the near fu ture.

title: 3 U.S. Judges Rule Texas Illiterates Can Get Voting Aid
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 17 (UPI)  A threejudge Federal panel ruled unconstitutional yesterday those parts of the Texas election code that pro hibit an illiterate person from receiving assistance in the vot ing booth.

title: Sign Backing Extremists Draws Winnipeg Police
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 17, (AP)Winnipeg police men yesterday ordered a bookstore employe to remove a handlettered sign that said Freedom for the F.L.Q. from the store window.

title: Bomb Victim's Children Will Get Scholarships
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 17 (UPI)Regents of the Uni versity of Wisconsin have voted unanimously to guaran tee the undergraduate educa tion of the three children of a researcher killed in a bomb blast at a campus building on Aug. 24.

title: Desolation shading into terror
description: These books invoke by their subtitles the false distinction between prose and poetry: the real distinction is between prose and verse, since both are books of poems, with distinct resemblances and a few differ ences. There are more allego

title: Greece Will Choose 56Man Committee To Advise Cabinet,
description: ATHENS, Oct. 17Greece's military  backed Government, which abolished parliamentary democracy 42 months ago, to day proclaimed elections to be, held Nov. 29 for what was termed a miniParliament.

title: Army in Front, 20
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 17 Army scored two thirdperiod goals to defeat New York Uni versity, 20, at Clinton Field, for the cadets sixth straight soccer triumph. Rich Walters and Lou Sosler accounted for the goals.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Obituary 6  No Title

title: Adoption Group In Jersey Holds Party Saturday
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 17Ronald M. Heymann, di rector of the New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles, and his wife, who adopted their 4yearold daughter Carol Ann when she was 3 months old, are cochair men of the third annual dinner dance in behalf of the Children's Aid and Adoption Society.

title: How to Discourage Suits by Concerned Citizens
description: WASHINGTONJoe Brow der, a young man who works for the Friends of the Earth, was bitter last Wednesday.

title: Sadat Takes Oath of Office as President of Egypt
description: CAIRO, Oct. 17Anwar Sadat was sworn in today as the Pres ident of the United Arab Re ublic, succeeding the late Gamal Abdel Nasser, his revolutionary colleague and friend for more than 30 years.

title: Ottinger Flummoxed Public On Vietnam, Goodell Charges
description: Standing In the entry to a Brooklyn shoe store, huddled against the chill gusts that blustered along Fulton Street, Senator Charles E. Goodell charged p yesterday that his Democratic opponent, Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger, had flummoxed the public about Vietnam.

title: At Tennis Club, Members Take Sides On Its $100,000 Redecoration of Court
description: Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Danzig describes it as very glamorous, and George T. Delacourt says it looks like, a bordello, which only goes to show that you can't please everyone. Especially when it comes to tennis.

title: Musie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: JANIS JOPLIN dead, the radio broadcast said. For all the expression in the announcer's voice, he might as well have been reporting the tempera turehumidity index. I felt frozen. The announcer dropped in a grisly detail buring the autopsy, 20 needle marks were found inside her left arm. Oh God, I thought, She did it. She went on the Hard stuff. I never believed she would.

title: LeafFall
description: The brilliant leaves of October begin to fall and for a little while their gold and crimson, their bronze and pink and scarlet, will belong neither to sky nor earth. Those leaves will be free as the autumn air, showering, swirling, gusting, chattering crisply, restless as the wind. Stand in a hillside maple grove and you will be caught in a shower of gold as a breeze sighs past. Walk through the woods on a cloudy day and you will walk in a scuf fling cloud of leafy sunlight. Go down through the valley and you will be surrounded by ruby and garnet and carm an and carnelian from red maples, sumacs, dog woods.

title: Miss Seymour Wed To Craig Whitaker
description: Miss Jennifer Seymour, an assistant editor of Foreign Affairs magazine, and Craig Wescott Whitaker an urban designer with the City of New York Housing Development Administration, were married here yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior.

title: Sharing Bends Life Styles
description: High rents, the scarcity of housing and sometimes just plain loneliness are mak ing yesterday's friend or stranger today's roommate in many apartments in the city.Television audiences may laugh at the weekly antics of mismatched roommates, but the real odd couples are not amused. A social crusader may he lodged with a social butterfly; a lover of classical music may be trapped in a den of rock. Such possibilities make many people wary of roommate seeking. On the other hand, it became clear from interviews with opera tors of roommate agencies, there are success stories, too.

title: A Ghost Waterfall South of Grand Coulee That Dwarfs Niagara
description: COULEE CITY, Wash.To most people, Grand Coulee stands for one of the world's, largest irrigation and power dams. Straddling the Columbia River 30 miles north of here (this city is 90 miles west of Spokane), the dam is a major tourist attraction, along with its two big reservoirs, Roosevelt Lake and Banks Lake. But in many ways, the canyon to the south known as the lower Grand Coulee makes the dam seem al most puny by comparison. The area's lakes offer a variety of recreational activity, and there are two state parks side by sideDry Falls, named for a ghost waterfall that was once equal to scores of Niagaras, and Sun Lakes.

title: Music: Chamber Society Opens Series
description: The pure sounds of cham ber music, administered by the most professional of hands, filled Tully Hall on Friday evening. It was the first concert of the second season of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and it is good to report that the hall was sold out. Last season it was apparent that the series was filling a need, and the renewal rate this year ran very high. It would ap pear that the concerts will be playing to full houses.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH the extensive development and use of comparatively inex pensive portable power tools has made work a lot easier for many thousands of homeowners and home handymen in recent decades, this trend has also been re sponsible for an increasing number of injuries to these same people. According to testimony given before the National Commission on Prod uct Safety in Los Angeles, portable power tools of all kinds (this includes lawn mowers, hedge clippers, etc., as well as drills, saws and sanders) are responsible for injuring more than 125,000 doityourselfers every year.

title: Patrolenen Chasing Robber FindLarge Drug Factory
description: Two Tactical Patrol Force Policemen accidentally uncover ed what was described as large drug factory at 165 Christopher Street last night while pursuing two burglars through the apartment building.

title: Canal Zone Lawyer Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  Lester Engler, 56 years old, was nominated by President Nixon Tuesday to be United States Attorney for the Canal Zone. Mr. Engler, a Phoenix, Ariz., lawyer, would succeed Rowland K. Hazard of Rhode Island, who resigned.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONSoviet American relations, always an uneasy combination of rivalry and accommodation, have long fluctuated between moods of detente and confrontation, and lately the mood has been sour.

title: East Meadow Routs Massapequa, 278
description: Massapequa and Freeport, which only three weeks ago possessed two of the longest unbeaten streaks in Nassau County, continued their down ward slide in South Shore Di vision I yesterday. East Meadow disposed of Massapequa, 278, and Lawrence edged Freeport, 98

title: Island Troupe Will Enliven April in Paris
description: The theme of the 19th an nual April in Paris Ball at the WaldorfAstoria on Oct. 30 will be Les Antilles Fran gaises. Details of the decor, which is usually quite elabo rate, are supposed to be kept secret until the night of the ball. But it is known that a troupe of 25 singers and danc ers from Martinique will be on hand to give a touch of authenticity to the scene, and that the dinner menu will in dude Creole dishes.

title: Editorial Comment From Canadian Newspapers on the War Measures Act
description: The invoking of the special War Measures Act by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau early today is an unprecedented move by a government in peacetime. It was obviously.

title: Israel Enjoying Slackening Of Arab Pressure
description: JERUSALEMNot since the immediate aftermath of the six day war more than three years ago have Israelis allowed them selves such a glow of well being. The calendar and the cir cumstances have coincided these October days to produce a welcome respite from the tu mult of the last few months.

title: Recognition For Communist China
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17It was time to teach the children about the democratic way. Sniveling and sneer ing, they were herded into the cellar where the television is kept. When Dennyhe is 7saw the electronic salesman being activated, he sniveled and sneered twice as hard.

title: Let the Buyer Beware
description: Ever since President Nixon vetoed the bill to limit the amount of money candidates can spend on television advertising, the public prints have been full of gloomy predictions that the fat cats were about to take over the television screens, brainwash the voters and buy up all the seats of power in the Great Republic.

title: ATOM PLANTS GET ALBANY SUPPORT
description: Atomicpowered electric gen erating plants, which some environmentalists have strong ly opposed because of possible radiation dangers, drew sup port last week from the Com missioner of the State Depart ment of Environmental Con servation.

title: Whatever the. Crises, the Politics Gives Way to Music
description: THE United Nations will get a lot of atten tion this week be cause it celebrates its 25th birthday next Saturday. There will be many special events, but one of them will be both soecial and regular.

title: Deborah L. Bittner Is Fiancee Of Davenport Wested, Student
description: BOONTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 17Mr. and Mrs. George Russell Bittner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deb orah Lou Bittner, to Daven port West 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps West of Bernardsville and Harwich Port. Mass.

title: Broker Weds Christine Curto
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oct. 17Miss Christine Ann Cur to was married here this afternoon to Bruce Noel Tul lo. The Rev. Dr. Herbert H. Cooper performed the cere mony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ohio State Downs Minnesota by 288
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 John Brockington and Rex Kern scored two touchdowns each in the first 21 minutes today as topranked Ohio State scored a 288 football victory over Min nesota before a crowd of 86, 667, a record for the Ohio State stadium.

title: KOREAN REDS REBUFF U.S. AT PANMUNJOM
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 17  The United Nations Com mand proposed today that both American and North Korean guards at this truce site be disarmed during meetings of the Korea Military Armistice Commission to lessen the like lihood of clashes between them. North Korea immediately re jected the proposal as foolish and sneaky.

title: Mepham Safety Returns Interception 103 Yards
description: BELLMORE, LI., Oct. 17 Neil Weingart, who was not a student at Mepham three years ago when the Pirates were a doormat in the South Shore returned an inter cepted pass 103 yards for touchdown today to cap 206 victory over Calhoun.

title: 3 Series of Sports Car Club Not as Healthy as They Seem
description: As Jim Kaser prepares to vacate his position as direc tor of professional racing in the Sports Car Club of Amer ica on Nov. 15, the question is naturally raised about the club's pro racing: What shape is it in? Kasersays the pro fessional series for 1971 is quite healthy, I feel pretty

title: Griffith Victor Over Perez
description: ST. THOMAS, V. I., Oct. 17 (UPI)Emile Griffith, the for mer middleweight and welter weight champion, gained a unanimous decision over Danny Perez of California last night.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Obituary 5  No Title

title: Snowmobile Title Races Slated in Boonville, N.Y.
description: Boonville, N. Y., will again be host for one of the largest snowmobile races in the country, the New York State championship on Feb. 13 and 14.

title: Ship Sinks at S.I. Pier
description: The Sea Witch, a 610foot container cargo ship owned by the American Export Company, sank early yesterday morning in about 30 feet of water while moored at Pier 13 in Stapleton, S. I. According to the police, the vessel had docked to unload large containers when the boiler room began flooding, appar antly from an open valve.

title: Civilizations
description: H.I.C. wonders if anyone can tell her the source of the following passage: There is a certain sequence that civiliza tions follow and they usually last about 200 years. This is the sequence: From bondage to spiritual faith; from spiritual faith to great courage; from courage to liberty; from liberty to abundance; from abundance to selfishness; from selfish ness to complacency; from complacency to apathy; from apathy to dependency; from dependency back to bondage.

title: POLICE SEEK TO ADD TO COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Police Department has asked the city to provide $5 million for an array of com munications equipment ranging from closedcircuit television to experimental teleprinters in 50 squad cars.

title: Peronists Rally in Cordoba Despite Ban in Other Cities
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 (keuters)Strong police rein forcements were deployed throughout Buenos Aires today to enforce a Government ban do rallies and demonstrations by supporters of Juan Peron, the former dictator.

title: A Shade Or Two of Politics In That TV Bill Veto
description: WASHINGTONThis is likely to be looked back upon as the year when television was accept ed as the strongest tool in Ameri can politics.

title: Duke Beats N.C. State by 226; Auburn Trounces Georgia Tech
description: Duke Beats N.C. State by 226; Auburn Trounces Georgia Tech.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: High Priest of Minimal
description: MINIMAL ART, one of the most portant critical terms of the 1960's, also remains one of the vaguest and most con troversial. It has been used, alternately, to describe prac tically any contemporary painting or sculpture that is neat and geometric, and to categorize one or another charmed circle of artists pre sumed to share one or an other esthetic ideology. The very word minimal, lend ing itself at once to insult (implying paucity and in significance) and to arcane philosophizing (evoking some metaphysical essence), has been bandied about in so many ways to so many po lemical ends that its mean ing in relation to art is by now approximately nil. For this reason, among others, one welcomes the formidable retrospective of works by Carl Andre now at the Guggenheim Museum. In spirit as in practice, Andre is a Minimalist if anybody is.

title: The Court Grapples With the Integration Nettle
description: WASHINGTON If  back in 1954someone had tried to de vise a means by which applica tion of the Supreme Court's de cision against school segrega tion would create the maximum confusion, division and delay, he might well have prescribed precisely what has happened.

title: Art Notes
description: IT would be terrible if got a double chin, mused Georgia O'Keeffe the other day at the Whitney Museum, as yet another camera closed in on her chiseled profile. But the famous O'Keeffe features, still hardedged after 83 years and thousands of lens ings, were obviously of mi nor concern. Her eye was on the major O'Keeffe retrospec tive  121 oils, watercolors and drawihgs covering a 55 year span that currently in habits the Whitney's fourth floor. The works range from early fantasy drawings, done in 1915 when she broke with the academic art of her teachers, to a 1970 portrait of a shiny black rock, so ripe that it might be en ceinte with a litter of peb bles.

title: Xavier Drops 6th Straight As Temple Triumphs, 2815
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 17 (UPI) Temple scored three touch downs in the first half today and Nick Mike  Mayer booted two field goals in the third period as the Owls defeated Xavier, 2815.

title: TARKENTON, KAPP READY FOR DUEL
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17  The New York Giants are going to be delighted tomorrow afternoon when they hear the cheers of the crowd. The play ers may not know it yet, but the Giants have been the pro fessional football heroes of New England for a generation.

title: Dr. Westrum's search for identity
description: The trouble with Mark Harris is that he can't shake Mark Harris. In other guises, notably the three splendid 1950's Henry Wiggen baseball novels (of which Bang the Drum Slow ly is the best known), he is a funny, perceptive, moving writer. But when an autobiographical or selfanalytical im pulse strikes him, he descends into a curious blend of whin ing selfflagellation and intel lectual chestthumping. He has been that way for a decade, especially in a ghastly stab at personal journalism, Mark the Glove Boy, and in the long introduction to his autobio graphical play, Friedman & Son. The Goy suggests that the cloud of selfindulgence is beginning to lift, but it still hovers.

title: HULICK CAPTURES HORSE SHOW TITLE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 James Hulick of Sterling, Mass., achieved a longsought goal tonight at the Pennsyl vania National Horse Show when Richard E. McDevitt, sec retary of the American Horse Show Association, presented him with the Adrian Van Sinderden Trophy for winning the A.H.S.A. hunter seat medal final.

title: Teitlebaum's Window
description: Teitlebaum's Window is an eth nic musical comedyit hasn't opened yet, but it willabout Brighton Beach Jews in the 1930's. It has a large cast, all of whom are indistinguisha bly Brooklyn Jewish, and all of whom do comic turns that are based on Wallace Markfield's marvelous ear for a pretension. But these comic bits are usually artificial, implausi ble, repeated without mercy, and al ways identify the characters as Brighton Beach Jews in the 1930's. This was a very hilarious thing to be.

title: Field Goals Aid Louisville
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 17 (UPI)Scott Marcus kicked three field goals and Louisville scored a fourthquarter touch down following Paul Matting ly's interception to defeat Mar shall, 1614, today. Marcus booted two field goals in the first half, from 25 and 26 yards, and kicked one of 19 yards in the second half.

title: McGrath Was Out of City When Prison Riots Started
description: Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath was out of the city advising Philadelphia on how to avoid jail riots on Oct. 1 the first day of New York's recent jail riots.

title: SOVIET ADDS SHIPS IN INDIAN OCEAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Soviet Union is expanding its naval forces in the Indian Ocean as Britain progressively withdraws from her positions east of the Suez Canal.

title: TENNESSEE ROUTS ALABAMA BY 240
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17 (AP)  Tennessee's alert sec ondary stole eight Alabama passes today and the Volunteers turned the thefts into three touchdowns and a field goal for a 240 victory in a Southeast ern Conference game.

title: HUMPHREY CONCEDES ERROR ON JOHNSON
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 17 Hubert H. Humphrey has stated that he erred in saying that President Johnson was para noid about the war in 1968.

title: Jersey Karate Tournament To Be Held Next Saturday
description: Trenton State College will be the host for the first New Jersey State karate champion ship on Saturday.

title: Helpful Hints to Make Cut Flowers Last Longer
description: CUT flowers will last longer if they are gath ered properly, and conditioned in deep warm water before they are arranged. The best time to cut them is in the evening. If this is not convenient, cut them in the early morning when the dew is gone but before the sun has robbed them of some of their mois ture.

title: Sicilian Government Quits
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 17 (Reuters)The regional govern ment of Sicily resigned tonight) following a Government an nouncement that a new steel works, formerly destined for Sicily, will be built in Calabria.

title: WAGNER SUBDUES ALBRIGHT, 22 TO 14
description: Wagner College's football team scored twice in the fourth quarter to record a 2214 vic tory over Albright at Fischer Field, Staten Island, yesterday. Wagner had entered the period trailing, 147.

title: Couve Visits the Caves Mao Inhabited in 30's
description: YENAN, CHINA, Oct. 17 (Agence France  Presse) Maurice Couve de Murville, a former Premier of France, today visited the caves where Mao Tsetung and other leaders of the Chinese Com munist party lived for 10 years after the famous Long March in 1934 and 1935.

title: Engagements
description: BEGELMANGORDONMr. and Mrs. Lionel Gordon of Hewlett, L.I. proudly announce the engagement of their daughter Stefanie Kay to Robert Begelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Begelman of Patchogue, L.I.

title: CURBS MODIFIED ON KENT REPORT
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 17 A Por tage County judge today per mitted Kent State University's president, Robert I. White, to comment on the findings of special state jury, but ordered him not to criticize it.

title: Recordings
description: THE human voice is the most personal, univer sal, versatile and, at its best, the most satisfying of all musical instruments. Arguments about technique and style and golden ages of singing come and go, but there seems always to be a healthy supply of singers around whose performances touch the sensibilities of most of the listeners who hear them.

title: 20 SITES LISTED FOR ALI FIGHT TV
description: The closedcircuit telecast of the Muhammed AliJerry Quar ry bout in Atlanta on Oct. 26 will have close to 100,000 seats available in greater New York.

title: Resistant Bacteria Pose A New Danger
description: Bacteria  those tiny bugs that invade bodies and some times raise havoc  are begin ning to fight back against man's attempt to control them with modern drugs. Moreover, the bac teria are waging such a good fight that many scientists from around the world have become seriously concerned that the bugs might come out on top, rendering human populations vul nerable to diseases now under control.

title: Dr. Albert Chang Weds Miss Huang
description: Miss Yvonne Huang, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Huang of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday after noon to Dr. Albert Chang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Chang of Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Ivan L. Sterner per formed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Hollis.

title: Nixon Signs T.V.A. Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  President Nixon has signed a bill that increases the bonding authority for the Tennessee Val ley Authority from $1.75billion to $5billion to finance addi tions to the T.V.A. power system.

title: Women's Rights: Es It Not Yet Time?
description: WASHINGTONA con stitutional amendment gua ranteeing equal rights, re gardless of sex, appears to ba an idea whose time has not yet come.

title: NIXON, IN JERSEY, BIDS VOTERS HELP SILENCE RADICALS
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 17 President Nixon encountered vocal hecklers in Teterboro, N. J., today as he went on a fourstate barnstorming tour to urge the silent majority to answer dissidents and radicals with their votes in November.

title: She'll never go there any more
description: Irene Kampen is one of those people born to tribulationat least, as soon as she puts pen to paper. When she goes ski ing, she informs us, she breaks an ankle; when she marries, divorce follows inevitably. And

title: The Anachronism That Is Ecuador
description: QUITO, EcuadorThe 90minute leap upward from the 8,700foot altitude of Bogota to the 9,300foothigh bowl wherein Quito lies encircled by Andean peaks reverses time by 100 years or so You leave a driving metropolis whose colonial facade has been overlaid with the glass and neon of modern commer cial architecture and arrive in a capital that is still predominantly Spanish colo nial in its architecture, its steep and crooked streets, its people and its gen erally warm and pleasant way of life at least for the tourist.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: IMPORT QUOTAS on shoes, textiles and a wide range of other goods neared reality as the Senate Finance Com mittee attached a changed version of the House trade bill to pending Social Security legislation. The protective trade measure will reach the Senate floor in the postelection session and, if it survives there, go to the President as part of a virtually vetoproof package.

title: Dinah H. Day And Bank Aide Married on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 17Miss Dinah Hawkins Day and John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr. were married here this afternoon 'n St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church by the Rev. Melville Harcourt, canon of St. Anne of the Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn. A reception was held at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Baldus Day, here.

title: Ceylon's Leftist Government Finds Its Promises. Have Added to Economic Problems
description: COLOMBO, CeylonShortly after the leftist Government was swept into power on an ariticapitalistic platform in the election last May, some over enthusiastic workers began taking over factories, issuing checks and otherwise reveling in the fruits of production until the checks bounced.

title: CHILE ACTS TO CUT DOLLAR OUTFLOW
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 17 The flight of dollars from Chile, where a Marxist is expected to become President Nov. 4, forced the central bank today to cut back sharply on the sale of dollars to Chileans traveling abroad.

title: Reports in Beirut Say Syrian Leader Resigned
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 (AP)Reports reaching here from Damascus today said that Dr. Nurreddin alAttassi had resigned as President and Premier of Syria.

title: Brewers Buy Kopacz
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates sold a first basemanoutfielder, George Kopacz, to the Milwau kee Brewers today.

title: See the Pig Judge Set Bail
description: EVERYONE seems to agree that Sesame Street is doing won ders for preschooleis, but to those who think big it's only first step. Plans are afoot to extend television's educational arm to xeach children during the vital gradeschool years. After months of study, a blueribbon panel of educators has conclud ed that the best way to meet the needs of older children is not with farout cartoons and puppets but with the tradi tional, direct classroom approach. A se ries for secondgraders is already in production.

title: CONNECTICUT ROUTS MAINE BEARS, 4613
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 17I All opportunistic University of Connecticut football team took advantage of Maine misplays to roll today to an easy 4513 vic tory, the Huskies third straight in Yankee Conference Play.

title: Turks Radio Says Courts Act to Free 2 Soviet Hijackers
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17 The Ankara radio reported tonight that Turkish courts had ordered the release of two Soviet Lithuanians who hi jacked, a Soviet airliner Thurs day and killed the stewardess.

title: The Heart Of the Conflict Is the Two Solitudes
description: MONTREALHugh MacLen nan, one of Canada's bestknown writers, called his 1945 novel about the English and the French in Quebec Two Solitudes. Twentyfive years later, Mr. Mc Lennan's portrait of two separate cultural communities coexisting uneasily remains essentially true.

title: Radio
description: TODAY'S LEADING EVENTS

title: Drunken Birds Pose Threat
description: PUYALLUP, Wash., Oct. 17 (UPI)  Rural residents have been advised to close the blinds of their picture windows to guard against injury because wild birds, drunk on fermenting mountain ash berries, have been crashing into the panes.

title: Katharine Bacon, W. S. Patten, Descendants of the Jays, to Wed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 Miss Katharine Bacon andWilliam S. Patten, whose grandfathers, the late De Lancey Kane Jay and the late Peter A. Jay, were broth ers, plan to be married here in December. Through their grandfathers the couple are descended from John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States.

title: Cambodians Draft Plan to Save Rice From Red Seizure
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 17 (Agence FrancePresse) The Cambodian authorities have drawn up an emergency plan to save the bulk of Cambodia's rice harvest from being cap tured by Vietcong and North Vietnamese troons.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: AIR FOUND DIRTIER IN NORTH ATLANTIC
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Scientists reported today that the air over the North Atlantic Ocean was twice as dirty as it was in the early nineteenhundreds.

title: FLORIDA STRUGGLES TO A 200 TRIUMPH
description: GAINESVILLE. Fla., Oct. 17 (AP)Florida, troubled by a tough defense and a 25mile gusting wind, struggled to a 200 football victory over Rich mond today. All the touch downs were scored by a hard running sophomore, Duane Doel.

title: YOUNG LORDS CHARGE SUICIDE WAS BEATEN
description: The Young Lords said yes terday that a pathologist re tained by them had found marks of beating and other suspicious signs on the body of a party member who allegedly hanged himself in the Tombs on Friday morning.night said Mr. Roldan's body showed no signs of beating and listed his death as a suicide by hanging.

title: The Approach To Kings
description: Disraeli and Trollope, the old pros of the political novel, would not find their calm, academic approach to af fairs of state duplicated in this lusty, soupedup and largely incredible tale of derringdo in and about the White House during the Barney Newfield Administration. The action is seen through the eyes of Dave Hyer, a 31 yearold Presidential Assistant, whose

title: Russia Now Joins The List Of Hijack Victims
description: MOSCOWThe announcer on the 11:30 P.M. Moscow televi sion newscast Thursday smiled occasionally as he told of good wheat crops, soccer standings and cloudy weather. Thus, millions of Soviet citizens who do not listen for news from abroad on short wave radio went to bed ignorant that an Aeroflot plane had been hijacked that day to Turkey, that a stewardess had been killed and two pilots wounded.

title: The U.S. May Be Punching Railroad Tickets
description: Between 1850 and 1871, in return for promised discounts on Government passage of mail, passengers and freight, Washington presented the nation's railroads 131 million acres of American land. Con gress authorized the grants which some critics later as sailed as a scandalous give away worth billionsto in duce railroads to push across the nation and bring rail transportation to the coun try's awakening frontiers.

title: A Highly Critical View of Progress On Rights
description: ATLANTAThe Commis sion has examined the Federal civil rights enforcement effort and found it wanting.

title: Manhattan Harriers Down Providence for 13th in Row
description: Manhattan College's cross country team extended its un beaten streak to 13 meets over a threeyear period while top pling Providence from the un beaten ranks, 1940, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

title: The Jefferson Airplane Is An Unscheduled Trip
description: IN the dim past when San Fran cisco's HaightAshbury district was a quiet, happy place; when people of all colors and origins smiled and spoke to each other on the streeta time of love and flow ersbefore the quarter became a vile horror of filth and murder and Mafia; a young man from Ohio named Marty Balin, a resident or the dis trict, a veteran of little theater, a musician, a singer and dancer in roadshow companies of West Side Story, My Fair Lady, etc. ap proached another young man, a na tive San Franciscan, Paul Kantner, whom he had seen in a solo and vocal act in a local club, with the vague purpose of the two of them performing together.

title: WAKE FOREST TOPS CLEMSON, 36 TO 20
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Oct. 17 (UPI)Larry Hopkins, junior fullback, scored two touchdowns en route to an At lantic Coast Conference single game rushing record of 230 yards today as Wake Forest beat Clemson, 3620.

title: Pop
description: Lonon WHEN British rock guitarist Eric Clap ton arrives in America this week, it will almost certainly be his last visit as a touring mu sician. I feel I'm almost con tinually on trial, he told me. Every time I step on stage now, I know I am expected to give more than I possibly can. The strain is terrifying.

title: Mehta's Mystique: Baton In Hand, Foot in Mouth?
description: HE is supposed to have hot eyes. brutal charm, and a cat nip gaze. Not to mention the sex appeal of an Italian beachboy. The Zu bin Mehta Mystique. It has evolved in the last few years largely because of his vast personal publicity (New York er profile, Time cover, among other things) that resulted from music critics and cog noscenti branding him the foremost of the new breed of young conductors  pos sibly The Hottest Thing to Wield a Baton Since Leonard Bernstein.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Few will disapprove of President Nixon's new peace efforts in South east Asia, even though little hope is seen for their success, and those closest to the Administration admit this. Yet why, one may now ask, if these efforts appear so reasonable and wellintentioned, do they bear so little chance to succeed?

title: Baking Continues Rise
description: Americans consume annu ally about 18 billion pounds of bread and related prod ucts, or about 93 pounds per capita, turned out by only about 400,000 bakery work ers.
