title: DA CAPO PRESENTS 7 MODERN WORKS
description: Based on the premise that worthwhile new musical works deserve a second hearing, the appropriately named Da Capo Players did not include any premieres on their Carnegie Recital Hall concert Friday night. Instead, the program consisted of seven previously per formed contemporary works. Just to make sure the audience understood the point, three of the pieces were performed twice.

title: Barbara Weil Married in Rye
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 17Miss Barbara Gail Weil and John Lippincott Gummere were married here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Linton. The Rev. Dr. Peter Samson of the White Plains Community Church performed the cere mony.

title: PESTICIDE CAVEAT CALLED TOO LONG
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 17An 18word warning proposed by the Federal Trade Commission for use in advertising pesticides and insecticides has been at tacked by the National Associa tion of Broadcasters as very cumbersome.A fourword substitute has been suggested by John B. Sum mers, general counsel of the association; in a letter to the commission.

title: RENEWED FIGHTING IN JORDAN REPORTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 (AP)Fighting broke out today between the Jordanian Army and Palestinian guerrillas four days after the two sides signed a final peace agree ment according to guerrilla broadcasts monitored here.

title: Alfred Takes Fifth in Row, Vanquishing Hobart, 3122
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Oct. 17 Alfred's unbeaten football team spotted Hobart a 143 lead, then fought back to win, 3122, before a homecoming crowd of 6,000 today. It was the fifth successive victory for the Sax ons.

title: Citizen Power
description: The Council on Environmental Quality has a rare chance to open a new era in the protection of the country's water, air and natural beauty. Its openly declared support of the HartMcGovern bill would go far to rescue from quiet death this measure to give citizens the right to sue violators of the common environment, whether private polluters or Government agencies that permit the pollution.

title: New Life for Old Depots As Museums, Homes, Bistros
description: SOME OF THE most nostalgic sights the motorist is apt to see on his trips around the country are those little railroad de pots that once bustled with travelers and are now bypassed disdainfully by whistling streamliners of stainless steel and aluminum.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1 JAY GOOD FOR RCA RECORDS 2627LAWRENCE SACKMAN

title: Article 4  No Title
description: 1 cups chicken broth

title: MIGRANTS TRAINED BY OREGON GROUP
description: WOODBURN, Ore., Oct. 17 For almost a quarter of a cen tury, Cruz Garcia followed the sun. Born in Texas, he joined the migrant labor stream at the age of 10 and was caught up in a cycle of poverty from which there was no apparent escape.

title: Laotian Premier in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier of Laos, visited the State Department today for lunch and private meeting with John Irwin, acting Secretary of State. The Premier is in the United States for the current session of the United Nations.

title: West Virginia's Pollution Chief Scores Muskie's Air Quality Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The chief air pollution control officer of West Virginia has voiced a highly critical view of a tough air quality bill now pending in Congress. His criticism closely parallels the op position to the bill expressed by the Union Carbide Corpora tion, which is acknowledged to be among the state's biggest polluters.

title: A portrait of the Caribbean
description: By James V Elmore

title: A Few Misconceptions On Composting Uncovered
description: COMPOST makes good house plant soil. This is especially true if the plant collection is large, for commercial soils and soilless mixtures are ex cellent but expensive in quan tities.

title: COLONELS DEFEAT ROCKETS, 109103
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP)Louie Dampier's basket and free throw in the last min utes tonight helped the Ken tucky Colonels post a 109103 American Basketball Associa tion victory over the Denver Rockets.

title: Author's Query
description: For a study of the New York City draft riots of 1863, I would appreciate any informa tion about private papers or journals.

title: United Hospital Benefit
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 17The First Twig of Harrison will sponsor a benefit brunch bridge at noon on Oct. 29 at the Westchester Country Club here, under the chair manship of Mrs. George J. Munck. The United Hospital in Port Chester is the bene ficiary.

title: Sonny Says. Quick, $45.40, Takes Final Feature of Atlantic. City Meeting
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 (AP)Peter Fuller's Sonny Says Quick took command at the head of the stretch and went on to score an upset vic tory in the $29,600 Mermaid Stakes for 2yearold fillies to day at Atlantic City.

title: DAYAN'S STATURE GROWS IN CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8The ta ble talk at a Jerusalem home had veered on to politics, when the host sought to summarize a widely held view:

title: Curry Defense Red Hot
description: MILTON, Mass., Oct. 17 (AP) Curry College defeated Bridge water State's football team to day, 180, allowing Bridgewater only 41 yards on the ground.

title: Japanese Delay a Cut For the Discount Rate
description: Although there are signs that the tempo of Japan's economic expansion Is slack ening, the head of that coun try's largest commercial bank does not think that the time is ripe for a lowering of her discount rate.

title: India Urges U.S.Withdrawal
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 18 (Reu ters)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called today for the, complete withdrawal of United States forces from Vietnam. She termed American with drawal the key to a settlement in Southeast Asia.

title: CORPORATE REPORTS
description: CORPORATE REPORTS

title: Murder in Quebec
description: The coldblooded murder of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Labor Minister, has shocked and unified in deep sorrow the vast majority of Canadians. In the aftermath of this atrocity, Prime Minister Trudeau probably enjoys much greater supportas he shouldfor the vigorous and nec essary military security measures he has taken in Quebec. More than ever now, however, his immediate political problem is to avoid excessive use of force that would give substance to charges of repression.

title: Amex Weighs Assistance For Robinson Customers
description: Officials of the American Stock Exchange have met quietly with the courtappointed receiver for Robinson & Co., brokerage house in bankruptcy proceedings, to determine how the Amex might assist in pro tecting Robinson's 8,000 cus tomers, whose accounts are frozen.

title: BRABHAM, CEVERT TAKE PARIS RACE
description: PARIS, Oct. 18Jack Brab ham of Australia and Francois Cevert of France drove a Ma traSimca to victory today in the 1,000 Kilometers of Paris snorts car race.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Two months ago, while Joe Namath was holding out for a longer summer vacation, a comedian asked a latenight television audience: Well, who would you rather take a shower with, AnnMargret or Emerson Boozer? It was a much shrewder question than it seemed at the time. Namath, of course, returned to football, ap peared in half of the exhibition games and led the Jets to one victory in their first four games.

title: College Conference Standings
description: College Conference Standings

title: 2 Unknowns Facing Vocal Incumbent in Brooklyn
description: Two years ago at this time, Mrs. Shirley Chisholm was stumping every night in the streets of BedfordStuyvesant, attending meetings of neighbor hood groups, fundraising parties and election forums.

title: 4 Saved as Houseboat Sinks
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP)A Coast Guard helicopter escued a man and three chil dren today from the waters of Nantucket Sound off Chappa quiddick Island after their houseboat sank in high wind and choppy water. The four were Christopher Recklitis of Boxford, his children, Alison, 13 years old, and Christopher, 8, and Daniel Massina; 7, of Mal den.

title: Big Budget Deficit
description: Representative Wilbur Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has shocked the public and the financial community particularlyby forecasting a Federal budget deficit for the current fiscal year of $12 billion to $20 billion. The original estimate of the Nixon Administration was for a $1.3billion deficit. The difference is mainly due to the shortfall of tax revenues resulting from the economic slump.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Margaret Scattergood Bacon Bride of Christopher Woerner
description: ITHAN, Pa., Oct. 18Miss Margaret Scattergood Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Allen Bacon of Philadelphia, was married here today to Christopher Robert Woerner, son of Mrs. Kurt Woerner of Doe Run and the late Dr. Woerner. The ceremony in the Radnor Friends Meeting House was after the manner of the Society of Friends.

title: U.S. POLICE WATCH FOR 3 QUEBEC GARS
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 18 The Royal Canadian Mounted Police today asked the United States Border Patrol to issue an alert for three auto mobiles with Quebec license plates sought in connection with the kidnappings by the Front for the Liberation of Quebec.

title: Racing Meets Open Today at Aqueduct, Westbury Tracks
description: The locales for thoroughbred and standardbred racing change today for the last time this year. The flatracing scene shifts to Aqueduct for a meet ing that ends on Dec. 7, while the harness horses move to Roosevelt Raceway in West bury, L. I, for a 50night ses sion that concludes Dec. 15.

title: Bruckner Interchange Is Monumentally Complex
description: In a setting reminiscent of Stonehenge, the riddle in stone spires left by an ancient people in Britain, the first year of con struction ended last week on the $67.8million CrossBronx Bruckner interchange.

title: Horne Economics, Fiji Islands Style
description: SAMABULA, Fiji IslandsBurn a 3foot length of banana stem, mix the ashes with six cups of water, let stand over night, strain and presto, you have a substitute for caustic soda or lye, the only ingredient in homemade soap that not available free on any South Sea Island.

title: English Cocker Spaniel Best Among 1,015 Dogs at Troy
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 18Joyce ScottPine's 5yearold English cocker spaniel, Ch. Ancram's Simon, was best of an, entry list of 1,015 at the Troy Kennel Club show today at the Troy Armory. The winner was han dled by Ted Young.

title: West Side Campaign Will Be Intensified During the Week
description: Representative William F. Ryan will cut loose this week with his usual nervous energy and impassioned talks as he makes the rounds of community rallies, kaffeklatsches, street corner gatherings and walking tours.

title: Vacancies Stir a Debate Over Office of Education
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The organization chart of the Office of Education looks like last year's Christmas tree, with all the top branches missing and many of the lower ones also gone.

title: The New Jersey Senate. Race
description: New Jersey is a high priority target in the Nixon Administration's drive for control of the Senate. The President himself on Saturday provided proof of this by helicoptering across the state to spark three rallies for Republican candidate Nelson Gross.

title: TV:Mozart, Nicely Done
description: Given the right singers, The Abduction from the Seraglio an opera, made to order for almost any oc casion.

title: Testing Mr. Heath
description: LONDON, Oct. 18The British peo ple are beginning to learn something important about their new Conserva tive Prime Minister, and the world will know it soon enough. There is a firm ness of resolution in Edward Heath; a toughness that evidently has deep emotional roots. Once he arrives at what to deems a principle, he will stick to it with almost religious fervor. If he feels that he is being pushed around for his principles, he will bris tle with resentment and renewed commitment.

title: H. DUNCAN OLIPHANT
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 18H. Duncan Oliphant, editor emeritus of The Portland Press Herald, died today in the Maine Medical Center. Mr. Oliphant, who retired as chief editorial writer in 1949, was 88 years old.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Mrs. Harrison Roth, Victor Over Polio Twice, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Hazel Gery Roth, who in her youth twice recovered from polio, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital from a respiratory ailment. She was 35 years old and lived at 45 West 132d Street.

title: Egypt Spurns Suggestion Of Token Missile Pullback
description: Mahmoud Riad, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, yesterday spurned any suggestion that the United Arab Republic pull back a token number of missiles from along the Suez Canal as a gesture to get Arab Israeli peace negotiations un der way.

title: 124 MILLION PEOPLE OLD ENOUGH TO VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) The Census Bureau estimated today that there would be 124 million persons old enough to vote in the Nov. 3 elections, an increase of four million from the 1968 Presidential election.

title: McGee Is Leading G.O.P. Rival in a Replay of Their 1964 Race in Wyoming
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 17 The other night Senator Gale W. McGee was campaigning his way through the dining room of the Chef Cafe on Third Street here and when he moved to the bar, a solitary drinker responded to the out stretched senatorial hand with this snarl:

title: G. A. Reigeluth Plans to Marry Susan L. Butler
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 18  The engagement of Miss Susan Lord Butler of Boston to George Applegate Reige luth, a senior at Williams Col lege, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Comdr. John Lord Butler Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. But ler. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Seeley Reigeluth of New Haven.

title: SCIENTISTS DIFFER ON HUMAN VALUES
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18A group of socially concerned scientists, engineers, doctors and scholars gathered in Boston this week end to ponder a hardy peren nialthe problem of instilling human values in a technologi cal society.

title: FARRELL TROUNCES CURTIS TEAM, 506
description: Monsignor Farrell romped to its sixth straight football vic tory, its third this season and 17th game without a defeat in overwhelming Curtis, 506, on the winners field at Staten Island. The defending Catholic Conference champions have now scored 154 points in three games.

title: Sanford Installed at Duke
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 18 (UPI) Former Gov. Terry Sanford was inaugurated today as the sixth president of Duke Univer sity.

title: GEORGIA POLICEMAN SLAIN WITH OWN GUN
description: CORDELE, Ga., Oct 18 (UPI) policeman was shot and fatally wounded with his own pistol this morning after he arrested a Negro for selling a Black Muslim newsphper with out a license.

title: 1352'S SAID TO RAID TRAILS IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 (AP)  United States B52 bombers extended their raids on North Vietnamese sup ply routes from Laos into Cam bodia for the first time in more than a week, the United States command announced today.

title: Last Political Slaying In Canada Was in 1868
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (UPI)  The slaying of Pierre La porte was the first political assassination in Canada in 102 years.

title: CLOSE MARCOS AIDE SLAIN IN PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA, Oct. 18  Floro Crisologo, a member of the Philippine Congress and close associate of President Ferdi nand E. Marcos, was shot dead this afternoon while attending church services in Vigan, his home town, about 180 miles north of hete.

title: Republican Gain in House Likely as Census Result
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The effect of the 1970 census, in depriving 10 states of a dozen House seats and reas signing them to six other faster growing states appears almost certain to benefit the Republi can party.

title: Michael F. Haggerty Dies at 91; Long a Reporter for The Times
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., Oct. 18 Michael F. Haggerty, a former police and court reporter for The New York Times, died in Holmdel Convalescent Center this evening. He was 91 years old and live at 401 Little Clove Road, Sunnyside, S. I.

title: Franciosi, With 1348 Total, Leads P.B.A. ProAm Event
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct 18The nation's top profes sional bowlers were at Garden City Bowl for the 11th Profes sional Bowlers Association $75,000 national championship, and 500 area amateurs rolled with them today in the proam event. The top prize for the leading amateur was $500.

title: Cates's Film, 'I Never Sang for My Father,' Begins Run
description: "I Never Sang for My Father" is, by definition, a wonderful motion picture if you're prepared to respond with feelings of mingled surprise and curiosity, excited by something extraordinary, to the adolescent misery of Gene Garrison, a 40-year-old widower. Gene cannot bring himself to love his father, Tom, a boring, self-centered, 80-year-old tyrant who was once mayor of the prosperous Long Island suburb in which he lives, the pillar of its Rotary Club and the president of its board of education.

title: THOUSANDS HONOR LAPORTE IN DEATH
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 18Thou sands of residents of Quebec stood in long lines tonight to pay homage to Pierre Laporte, the provincial Minister of La bor and Immigration who was found murdered by radical ter rorists early today.

title: Political Peace Concert Sett
description: Music for Peace concert will be held tomorrow at noon at the City University Grad uate Center at 42d Street be tween Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The concert, which will feature the Cannibis, a rock group, is being held to support political peace candidates.

title: Prince Zeid el Hussein, 72, Jordanian Diplomat, Dead
description: PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP)The Jordanian Embassy announced today the death of Prince Zeid el Hussein, greatuncle of King Hussein. He was 72 years old.

title: Radio
description: 11:05Noon, WNCN: Adventures in Good Music.

title: POLICE SEIZE TWO IN NARCOTICS RAID
description: A man was arrested early yesterday on charges of pos session of more than 17 pounds of heroin In his Bronx apartment worth more than $3 million, the Bronx District At torney's office reported.

title: JOB GAINS FORECAST BY LABOR SECRETARY
description: RACINE, Wis., Oct. 18 (UPI) James D. Hodgson, the Secre tary of Labor, said today that employment in the United States would undergo a notable increase in the first quarter of next year.

title: Symphonic Elegy by Partos Bows Here
description: The Boston Symphony gave the first New York perform ance of Oedoen Partos's Paths, a symphonic elegy, at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Partos, born and ed ucated in Hungary, is now known as an Israeli com poser, having settled in Pal estine in 1938. He composed this work for the 1970 Ein Gev Festival, have it is the first piece to have been com missioned by the Lotti Stein berg Memorial Foundation set up by William Steinberg after the death of his wife. Mr. Steinberg, who is music director Of the Boston Sym phony, conducted it here.

title: Princeton Unit Elects Chief
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 R. Manning Brown, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, has been elected chairman of the executive com mittee of Princeton University's board of trustees, the univer sity's president, Robert F. Go heen; announced today. Mr. Brown, a 1936 graduate, suc ceeds John N. Irwin, 2d, who was recently appointed Under Secretary of State.

title: Cantor, Fitzgerald Plans Corporate Economics Deal
description: Cantor, Fitzgerald & Co., Inc., an investment banking firm, announced over the week end that it had acquired Cor porate Economics, Inc., a con cern specializing in presenting seminars for professionals and corporate executives within the financial and business com munity. Terins of the agree ment were not disclosed.

title: Aemiko Iinurna Offers Variety In Song Recital
description: Charm and simplicity were the keynotes of Aemiko Iinu ma's recital at Tully Hall yes terday afternoon. The Tokyo born soprano sang art songs and arias with effortless grace, and while her interpre tations rarely probed deeply, they were never less than tasteful and refined.

title: Rodger H. Hess And Mrs. Seago Are Wed Here
description: The marriage of Mrs. Betty. Levy Seago to Rodger H. Hess, son of Mrs. Harold B. Hess of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Mr. Hess, took place here yesterday. Rabbi Ronald Sobol performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave L. Levy, parents of the bride. Mr. Levy is a partner of Gold man, Sachs & Co. and for mer chairman of the board of the New York Stock Ex change.

title: Kings Point Finishes First In Intercollegiate Regatta
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 18 The Nevins Trophy in Long Is land Sound was won today by the Merchant Marine Academy.

title: and Congressional Choices
description: In this newspaper's appraisals of Congressional candi dates, our concentration is on past records, on programs and on personal effectiveness. No judgment is based on party label or the chances for success. Only those dis tricts are included in which endorsements are made.

title: Celtics, Paced by Havlicek, Vanquish Blazers, 133115
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 18 (UPI)John Havlicek poured in 38 points, grabbed 14 re bounds and handed out 13 as sists tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 133115 triumph over the new Portland Trail Blazers. It was Boston's first victory of the National Basketball Association season.

title: The Double Wounds of War
description: In another autumn of war without fanfare in Vietnam, the chances of an American soldier getting wounded, and surviving with a broken body, still remain very high. Despite an encour aging drop in battlefield deaths, Viet nam by its very nature continues to be a dangerous, bloody war. The dimensions of America's own body count cannot be buried by Vietnami zation or optimistic rhetoric.In the week in which the Presi dent made his latest peace proposals, 666 Americans were wounded in ac tion. The usual listing of American deaths stresses that the killedinaction ratio is dropping. That, fortunately, is true; but, it still leaves about fifty deaths reported in an average good week. And that does not include about 200 South Vietnamese and 1,200 North Vietnamese and Vietcong who die weekly, much less the civilians who are maimed without statistics.

title: PRESIDENT HEARS PLEA BY BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18A grou.p of the nation's leading business executives brought di rectly td President Nixon today their complaint that the Gov ernment needs to do more about ending inflation.

title: F. C. C. ember Member Decries Managethent of A.T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Federal Communications Com missioner Nicholas Johnson, who has often charged the bell telephone system with neglect ing the public interest, accused the phone monopoly today of blindness toward even its, private interest.

title: NETS ARE BEATEN BY SQUIRES, 10388
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 18 Making his regularseason debut here as a pro, Charlie Scott, a local product, scored 29 points to lead the Virginia Squires to a 10388 victory over the New York Nets before 2,468 fans at Island Garden to night.

title: Steinberg Leads Opening Concert By New World
description: There was a certain amount of energetic and unfrilly mu sicmaking at the opening Symphony of the New World concert of the season yester day afternoon at Philharmon ic Hall.

title: Obert. Upset by Quintero In National Handball Event
description: Thirdseeded Rudy Obert of the New York Athletic Club was upset yesterday in the sec ond round of the United States Handball Association national championships at hte Browns ville Boys Club in Brooklyn. Tony Quintero of the West Side Y.M.C.A. defeated Obert. 2514.

title: Conservationists See Gains in U.S Courts
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18The courtroom door that was once closed to citizen protests about the immense range of Federal actions or positions affecting the environment has now swung threequarters open, in the opinion of some of the nation's leading conserva tion lawyers.

title: Mellon Grant to Buy Island
description: A grant of $5million to help purchase much of Cumberland Island, in Georgia, was made yesterday by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to the Na tional Park Foundation, the As sociated Press reported.

title: Mrs. Borah Observes Her 100th Birthday
description: BEAVERTON, Ore., Oct. 18 (UPI)  Mrs. William E. Borah observed her 100th birthday with 100 red roses, 100 guests and thousands of memories.

title: Votes of the Week in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ending yester day.

title: Columbia Report Assails JudgeSelection Method
description: The appointment of unquali fied men to be judges in New York's Criminal Court is having a pervasive and devastating impact on the city's ability to cope with crime, a Columbia Law School professor has charged.

title: GIFTED TEACHERS RECEIVE AWARDS
description: The Danforth Foundation an nounced last night the 10 win ners of the 1970 E. Harris Harbison Award for Gifted Teaching in American colleges and universities.

title: Rebel Says French Troops Saved Government in Chad
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 18 (UPI)Dr. Abba Siddick, leader of the in surgents who killed 11 French soldiers in a clash one week ago in the north of Chad, said today that his movement would have brought down the Govern ment of President Francois Tombalbaye but for French intervention.

description: Soccer Results

title: ToughMinded Canadian
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 18A few weeks after the Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, Pierre Elliott Tru deau, the new Prime Min ister was asked to de fend his decision to phase Canada militarily out of the North Atlantic alliance. I am less worried about what might happen In Man Berlin than in Chicago or New in the York, he replied. News If in the next halfdozen years or so, there were to be great riots and the beginnings of civil war in the United States, there is no doubt that they would overflow the bor ders and link up with under privileged Mexicans and Canadians.

title: BENJAMIN BOSS, 90, ASTROVOMER, DIES
description: ALBANY, Oct. 18Dr. Ben jamin Boss, an internationally renowned astronomer, who di rected the Dudley Observatory here from 1912 until his retire ment in 1956, died last night at his home. He was 90 years old.

title: Bridgeport Lack of Beauty More Than Skin Deep
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct 18Smokestacks, dirty red brick factory buildings, the sooty tar paper tops of tired frame houses.

title: Brookville's Overtime Goal Tops Bethpage in Polo, 87
description: BETHPAGE, L. I. Oct. 18 Allen Jerkens scored a goal with a minute gone in sudden death overtime today as Brookville beat Bethpage, 87, at Bethpage State Park to win the Long Island Recreation As sociation Trophy polo match.

title: Freak Power Candidate May Be the Next Sheriff in Placid Aspen, Colo.
description: ASPEN, Colo., Oct. 13  It wasn't really supposed to be a political campaign, at least not in the ordinary sense, when Hunter S. Thompson author, satirist, master of the puton, connoisseur of the ab surdannounced that he was running for the office of county sheriff with the sup port of freak power. It was a joke, a diversion ary tactic. It was a wild, raucous noise raised from the underground of this pres tigious tourist city famous for its skiing, its classical music festivals and its Insti tute for Humanistic Studies.

title: The 20th District
description: POPULATION: About 450, 000 people live in this West Side area of Manhattan that extends from 83d Street to the Bronx. It is estimated that about 40 per cent are Jewish, 30 per cent Irish, less than 20 per cent Negro, and the other 10 per cent are of Span ish and other ethnic back grounds.

title: Stage: AllM ale Hamlet
description: The idea of using male ac tors in female roles is at least as old as Shakespeare, which Gene Feist, the director, to call his allmale Hamlet an Elizabethan production. But he needs more than prece dence as justification.

title: T. W. A. Threatened by a Strike Of Its Hostesses and Pursers
description: The 5,428 hostesses and pur sers of Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that they would go on strike at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: War, Though Near Pnompenh, Seems Far, and Life Is Serene

Like some of the dancers they had on fatigue uniforms, which noncombatant Cambo dians wear to indicate combat readiness.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 18 (UPI)Brian Barnes of Britain won the Wills Masters golf tournament by a single stroke today in a close finish at the Australian Golf Club.

title: CounterCultures vs. Straights
description: These excerpts are from the report of the Santa Barbara Citi zens Commission on Civil Disorders, a private group exploring the reasons behind tensions in this area of California.

title: Ballet: Filipov, Soviet Defector, Makes U.S. Debut
description: When Rudolf Nureyev and Natalya Makarova defected from Russia to join the free forall enterprise of Western ballet, they were already established dance stars. The 23yearold Aleksandr Fili pov, who was born in Mos cow, trained in Leningrad and, until his rapid exit last month in Mexico, danced with the Moiseyev Youth Company, is not yet that. He is, however, a bright, attrac tive and talented dancer who should do well in the West.

title: M.T.A. Takes Over Airport
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 18 (AP)The Metropolitan Transit Authority has taken over own ership of Stewart Airport from the Federal Government. The deed to the 1.590acre property, formerly Stewart Air Force Base, was presented to Dr. Wil liam J. Ronan, M.T.A. chairman, by a representative of the Gen eral. Services Administration on Friday.

title: Mobil Plant Superintendent Seized on Pollution Charge
description: BUFFALO, Oct 18 (AP)The night superintendent at the Mobil Oil Corporation's Buffalo refinery was arrested early to day as an agent of the com pany on charges of creating public nuisance by polluting the air.

title: Goldberg Urges Major P.S.C. Revision
description: Arthur J. Goldberg proposes an extensive overhaul of the Public Service Commission yesterday to separate the agen cy's regulatory and quasiju dicial functions and, at the same time, set up a consumer advocate within the agency to Protect the public interest.

title: QUEBEC GETS NOTE FROM 2D HOSTAGE, RENEWS ITS OFFER
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 18  A letter in the handwriting of James R. Cross, the kidnapped British diplomat, was received today about 12 hours after dis covery of the body of Pierre Laporte, the Quebec Labor Minister, who was also kid napped by the extremist Front for the Liberation of Quebec.

title: SAMUEL M. SHOR
description: Samuel M. Shor, an electrical manufacturer, collapsed and died Saturday afternoon in the lobby of the Park East Syna gogue, 163 East 67th Street. He was 70 years old and lived at 880 Park Avenue.

title: Philadelphia Teachers Talk
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (UPI) Negotiators sat down to gether today for the first time since about twothirds of the city's 11,500 public school teachers went on strike. No progress was reported after the threehour session and a spokes man for the school board said the two sides did not agree on the date of their next meeting.

title: In Memoriam
description: CULLIGANCharles R. Happy second anniver sary in heaven Cully. Rest in God's care. You are with me always.

title: Floridians Down Condors As Calvin Excels, 125115
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (UPI) Mack Calvin, a 5foot8inch guard, scored 41 points and the Floridians stopped a late rally by the Pittsburgh Condors to day for a 125115 American Baslcetball Association victory.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER CANUCKS, 53
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Oct. 18 (UPI)John Mc IKenzie scored his first twa goals of the season and as sisted on two others today as the Boston Bruins won their fourth game in a row, 53, from the Vancouver Canucks.The Bruins, ahead, 21, in the second period, scored three goals in the last six minutes two of them by McKenzieto pull away.

title: PACERS WIN, 134113, FROM CHAPARRALS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18 (AP) The undefeated Indiana Pac ers rolled to their third Ameri can Basketball. Association vic tory, beating the Texas Chapar rals, 134413, today.

title: Hambro Finds Red China Less Hostile to a U.N. Role
description: Edvard Hambro, President of the United Nations General As sembly, said yesterday he had the definite impression that Communist China was less hos tile than hitherto to joining the international organizations.

title: Prince Andrew of Sherline Is Judged Best in Jersey
description: VINELAND, N. J., Oct. 18 Ch. Prince Andrew of Sherline, a 5yearold Old English sheep dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sherline of Detroit and handled by Robert Forsyth, de feated 1,244 rivals today in winning the bestinshow title at the 19th annual South Jersey Kennel Club event.

title: 3 Field Goals Help Giants Top Patriots, 160, for First Shutout Since 1961
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 The Giants made their first regularseason expedition to New England today, to the banks of the Charles River, to the fringes of Harvard Univer sity itself, and wished they had come here years sooner.

title: Rise in Mortgage Lending Is Reported for Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that net mortgage lending on oneto fourfamily homes in the na tion rose sharply in April, May and June compared with the first quarter of 1970.

title: Report Hails Oregon High School's Experiment in Free Study
description: PORTLAND, Ore.The clean lined, futuristic colonnades, courtyards and skylights of Portland's John Adams High School symbolize a fresh view of how teenagers should be educated.

title: sparkman's Lulu Is First Among Soling Class Fleet
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18 Palmer D. Sparkman's Lulu won a 7.3mile Soling Class race off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today in the 10th regatta of the fall series for Yacht Rac ing Association fleets based east of Ryer. Lulu triumphed by 2 minutes 58 seconds.

title: News Backs Buckley, Levitt and Lefkowitz
description: James L. Buckley has been endorsed by The Daily News for United States Senator, along with Arthur Levitt for, reelection as state Control ler and Louis J. Lefkowitz for reelection as Attorney General.

title: Pope Comments on Slaying
description: ROME, Oct. 18 (UPI)Vati can sources said today that the Pope had expressed profound consternation at the slaying of Pierre Laporte, Minister of Labor.

title: Altar of 550 B.C. Is Unearthed at Sardis
description: A 2,500yearold altar to the Greek goddess Artemis and an ancient synagogue poor box that had apparently been robbed were two important discover ies reported yesterday by Amer ican archeologists who have been excavating parts of King Croesus capital city of Sardis.

title: Personal Finance
description: Telephone companies throughout the country are reporting a sharp upsurge in the number of annoying phone calls being received by their customers.

title: HAVENOT NATIONS FIND HOPE IN PACT
description: GENEVA, Oct. 18A pact Just reached by the havenot countries With the affluent in dustrialized nations is being heralded as the start of a new era in international trade rela tions although no government has committed its signature to a binding document of any kind.

title: Vikings Crush Cowboys, 5413
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 18The Dallas Cowboys, a team of uneasy riders this sea son, fell all the way off their mounts today when they lost to the Minnesota Vikings by a record score of 5413. The rec ords came from both sides. It was the worst defeat in the Dal las team's history and the most points the Vikings had ever scored.

title: 500,000 at Festival in Park Savor Exotic Food and Music
description: Armenian dancers stamped on the Mall, Mr. Deussing played his alpine bells and venders sold exotic food to voracious public as The Peo ple, Yes! festival closed yes terday in Central Park.

title: BOOMING MARKET IN STEEL IS SEEN
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18Steel users were warned last week to prepare for a boom market.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO. CHOOSES CHAIRMAN
description: The Adams Express Company said yesterday that David G. McCornack, president, had been elected to the additional office of chairman of the board, effec tive Nov. 1. He succeeds George E. Clark, who is retiring as Chairman upon reaching retire ment ate.

title: Whittaker Corp. President Shifts to New Subsidiary
description: William Meng Duke has relinquished his post of presi dent of the Whittaker Corpora tion to become chairman and, president of the Sciences Man agement Corporation, a new subsidiary that will offer plan ning and management services for any company, it was an nounced yesterday. He remains on the board and executive committee of the parent com pany.

title: Advertising: BreathTaking Investigation
description: Among the activities cur rently under way in the hal lowed halls of the Federal Trade Commission, there is one that is sure to confound, delight, amaze and enrage the advertising community: an investigation into the ad vertising of mouthwash.

title: Mayor Reactivating Jail Watchdog Unit
description: Mayor Lindsay moved yes terday to reactivate the city's Board of Correction, a citizens watchdog agency that was de nounced by Correction Com missioner George F. McGrath three years ago for allegedly having interfered with his department's operations.

title: Night at Races to Aid Mental Health Unit
description: WESTBURY, LI., Oct. 18 The building fund of the Men tal Health Association of Nassau County will benefit from a Night at the Races at the Cloud Casino, Roosevelt Raceway, on Wednesday eve ning. Sponsored by the wom en's division of the Associa tion, the event is under the chairmanship of Mrs. John R. Dunne of Garden City.

title: Wendy P. Wild and M. J. Pugsley Start a New Day
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 18Miss Wendy Patricia Wild and Michael James Pugsley were married here promptly at 7:15 A.M., three minutes after the sun rose to start a new day in our lives, as the bridegroom explained.

title: Chess:
description: The 17th World Student Chess Championship in Haifa, Israel, was won by the United States with 28 points of a possible 40. Eleven four board teams played. The event, however, was boy cotted by Communist coun tries, presumably since Israel was the host country.

title: Pretre Leads American Symphony in Sibelius 2d
description: Contrary to popular con ception, a conductor's po dium manner usually does bear a traceable connection to the musical performance, and in some instances mir rors it precisely. The excep tions, and they are numerous, come when the conductor's musical gift is so slight that the orchestra pays no atten tion to what he does.

title: Boston & Maine Renewing Bid to Join N.&W. System
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18The trus tees of the Boston & Maine Corporation have asked the Federal District Court here to allow them to petition the In terstate Commerce Commis sion to include the B. & M. in the Norfolk & Western Rail way system. Judge Francis J. W. Ford will hold a hearing on the request on Oct. 26.

title: Gloria A. Czerniuk Wed to Captain
description: Miss Gloria. Ann Czerniuk, daughter of Brig. Gen. Ed ward J. Czerniuk, U. S. A., retired, end Mrs. Czemiuk of Flushing, Queens, and Capt. Richard Hubert Clarke, U. S. A., were married yes terday in the new St. Nicho las Russian Orthodox Church in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Rangers Snap Canadiens Streak at 4 With 10 Triumph

description: VALPARAISO, Chile, Oct 18 Salvador Allende, the Marx ist who is expected to become Chile's President, assured a large audience of businessmen today that 98 per cent of Chil eans would have nothing to fear from his government.

description: PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 18 (AP) Theodore J. Richmond, who headed a financial empire that once included the InterCity Transportation Company and twoscore other concerns be fore he went bankrupt in 1967, collapsed and died yesterday.

description: POPULATIONAccord ing to the 1960 Census; the 12th Congressional District has a population of 409,383. The population is overwhelm ingly black and Puerto Rican, some estimates ranging as high as 90 per cent. Most of the population is lowincome.

title: Paris: A Modern Twist to Moliere
description: PARISHow many revered classics would by now have lapsed into oblivion hadn't the class struggle come to the rescue? This farce about the misfor tunes of a cuck old of the type popular since the Middle Ages, was given a modem twist by Molten: who mismatched the rich farmer with a girl of im poverished nobility.

description: Few New Yorkers know that the Republican candidate for Governor is named River Foun dation Spend Control and his Democratic opponent is High Morality Pine Tree. The Con servative for the office has not yet acquired a name. That's the way politics is in the news papers of Chinatown.

Teachers, however, have been asked to report to the Wash ington Heights school for a series of conferences.

title: SENATE DISCLOSES U.S.ETIMPIA PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The United States entered into an unpublicized agreement in 1960 to support a 40,000man Ethio pian army and to oppose any threats to the territorial integ rity of Ethiopia.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is nearly impossible for a nonRussian speaking audience to understand the true artistic stature of the poet Osip Mandel stam (18911938?). Certainly, his creden tials are excellent: He and Anna Althma tova were the leading practitioners of the socalled Acmeist school, those admirable members of the Poets Guild (founded in 1912, at the height of the Silver Age of Russian literature), who devoted them selves to the purification and clarification of poetic language. His fame had spread throughout Russia by the time he reached his 20's. Today his small body of work is as vital as ever, even without the benefit of publication. Perhaps most impressive of all is that he was arrested during the Stalinist terrorostensibly for writing verse uncomplimentary to the leader (His cockroach whiskers leer/ And his boot tops gleam.  /And every killing is a treat/ For the broadchested Ossete.), but actual ly because Mandelstam was too completely a poettoo helplessly his own manto be pressed into the forms of the New Era and made to sing the songs of the Union of Soviet Writers. Still, it remains hard for us to apprehend his work truly, just because (one must guess) of the purity of his lan guage and the impossibility of rendering it in English. We are left with shadows.

title: Nonlethal Weapons Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (Reu ters)The defense department is developing special gases, sprays and other nonlethal weapon for use in civil disor ders, a Pentagon spokesman said today. The weapons could he used by National Guardsmen to prevent such incidents as the shooting of four students at Kent State University last May 4.

title: News Summary and Index

Cross the first new evidence that the kidnapped British diplomat is still alivereiterated the demands of his kidnappers, a Quebec sepa ratist group, that 23 prisoners be freed as the ransom for his release. title: The City: Fear and Hope
description: All around me there were giant unseeing crowds, Frank Lloyd Wright recalled when he first came to Chicago in 1890; I felt engulfed and terribly afraid. The great architect's fear of the city was not unique to him, nor to his time. The feeling has appeared in every generation from his day to the present, and this long dislike of city men for cities is in fact a major cause of our present urban woes.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) President. Nixon goes on the campaign trail again tomorrow on behalf of Republican candi dates.

title: The Cities: Fear and Hope
description: America has been called a violent society so often that people have stopped thinking about what this cliche means. Statistics, of course, tell the story in one way: there are more rapes and murders in this country than in any other Western nation, more political demonstrations that re sult in violence, and so on. But many historians believe this Violence is nothing new we have always been a violent nation, it, appears, only now physical brutality is out in the open, fit to print, dramatize, or spark a political reputation.

Hiram Watson, a 47yearold policeman. Sergeant Watson was shot four times yesterday after he had arrested a man for selling a Black Muslim newspaper without a license.

title: Bridge

There were no postmortems during the play, and no tournament di rectors laying down the law because someone had led out of turn. Even the usual sounds of players bidding, of boards being moved about, and of cards being shuffled and dealt were absent.

description: CAPETOWN  Every day they line Up in, the privately run welfare centerblack wo men, young brides, Mothers of large families, widows andthe aged, all With the saine prob lem: They have been ordered to leave their homes and families.

description: A group of black poets, ar tists and writers has urged the black community not to deny Angela Davis money, time and involvement because of her Communist party affiliations.

description: Its a place where men pay hundreds of dollars for one understated, straightgrained briar, or a flamboyant lion topped pipe that requires the jaws of a lion to hold it in place. A place where the Ianguage is of oom pauls and dublins and lumbermen and bulldogs and 101. other names signifying different pipe shapes. A masculine world redolent of tobacco, custom mixed from the great book of favorite blends.

The debate will also cover the value of priestly celibacy, a controversial issue in the church.

description: ED GARTOWN Mass There are four ripe tomatoes on the kitchen windowsill, the final harvest from a gar den that is now rank with weeds.

title: Finnish 'Time of Roses' Looks at Politics in 2012
description: "Time of Roses," Risto Jarva's Finnish movie that opened yesterday at the 72d Street Playhouse, is set in 2012, 11 years after Stanley Kubrick's spaceship Discovery set off for Jupiter and 28 years after George Orwell's Big Brother consolidated his grip on Britain. The setting is a Finland in which people communicate by view-phone, laze around on not-so-Finnish-modern, inflatable plastic furniture and take their meals from machines that, in friendly, gravelly voices, announce the calorie content of the items ordered.Politics, not gadgets, however, is Mr. Jarva's principal concern, and his future Finland is one of those brave new worlds that can only be accepted as a projection of the cowardly old one. Class distinctions have disappeared. Everyone contributes according to his capacity and pure, unbiased science has become a repressive political dogma.The symbol of this repression is Raimo, a young man who makes biased, unscientific, immensely popular TV films that reshape history in support of current ideology. When Raimo decides to make a movie about what it was like to be alive in the 1970's, by reconstructing the life of a rather ordinary girl who died in 1976, some of his revolutionary associates plan to expose his methods. At the same time, these associates are also involved in the organization of a strike in an atomic power planta loose plot thread of which absolutely nothing is made.I suspect that "Time of Roses" might seem a lot more relevant in Finland, a country that has lived on political edge for some time, than in New York, where Mr. Jarva's view of the future seems not very dark, just dim and rather polite. Although I know it's wrong, I can't help but feel wistful about a state in which love is free and strikes are so rare that the very planning of one becomes an act of heroic affirmation."Time of Roses" doesn't occupy the mind, but it does offer some amusing fringe benefits. I liked a futuristic, basketless basketball game, in which hugging and kissing between the boy players and the girl players is encouraged, and the somewhat cautionary final image: the opportunistic filmmaker, having passed out with booze celebrating the success of his new movie, turns on his inflatable couch in such a way that he punctures it. When last seen, he is slowly, mindlessly, sinking to the floor in a heap of clear plastic.

title: Sato's Mission in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 20 Premier Eisaku Sato is in the United States today to perform two tasks: to proclaim publicly before the United Nations Ja pan's determination never to be come a great military power and to plead privately to President Nixon for the kind of Japanese American relationship that would make it possible to fulfill News this determination. Analysis The public task is relatively simple. Japan has achieved the thirdlargest economy in the world, and some analysts, including Herman Kahn, have been predicting that in thenext century Japan may overtake the United States to become the world's foremost economic power.

description: AMENIA, N. Y.The an cient oracle at Delphi, Greece, was a disembodied voice offering cloudy predic tions, which simplified the job of prophecy. Today Amer ica has a small number of honored oracles who have studied the past, who speak clearly and who are there in flesh and soul.

title: Books of The Times
description: In last Thursday's New York Times, E.W. Kenworthy reported from Washing ton that representatives of 10 environ mental and consumer organizations were refused permission by the Department of Commerce to attend a meeting of the National Industrial Pollution Control Coun cil. The Council was established in April by President Nixon to advise the Gov ernment on en vironmental pro grams affecting industry and on industry's propos als for dealing with the pollution it causes. The members of the Council are top executives of ma jor companies and industry associa tions. Not only were representa tives of the con servation groups kept out, but they were also told that no transcript of the meeting would be pro vided and that no press conference would be held afterward. If you want to know why the President and the Department of Commerce prefer to be advised on pollu tion, in secret, by the people who do the polluting instead of the people who protest it, read James Ridgeway's The Politics of Ecology.

title: New Law on Voting Rights at Age 18 Is Denounced Before Supreme Court by Lawyers for Four States

The con cern, a subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, the major copper producer, said it would trim operations by about 10 per cent at its Columbia Falls, Mont., plant.

title: Miller, in 20thCentury Works, Displays Pianistic Expertise
description: Robert Miller is one of a blessed few pianists who play the most difficult contempo rary music both expertly and often (William Masselos, Bald Jacobs, David Burge, Easley Blackwood and a few others might be cited, too). And all of Mr. Miller's technical ex pertise and intellectual powers were called upon at the Kauf mann Concert Hall on Sun day evening, where the pianist offered an intensely serious program of 20thcen tury works. Only an un relenting sternness could be charged against the pianist in a remarkable night's work.

title: Hanoi's Nyet
description: Hanoi's formal rejection of President Nixon's peace initiative is a cause for disappointment, not despair. Am bassador Bruce's refusal to take no for an answer, was the proper response. Both sides have now publicly be littled the other's new public proposals. But both have also upgraded their negotiating teams; they give evidence of having more important aims than simply taking advan tage of propaganda opportunities in Paris. Intensive probing in private is now in order to discover whether progress toward a settlement can be made.

title: L.I.U. Soccer Victor

The association is an or ganization of regional daily newspaper associations, with 519 member newspapers in 25 states and Canada.

The firemen said they had not yet decided whether to obey the order. Judge Gallagher said the strike by 425 union firemen seeking wage increases is irreparably damaging the inhabitants of this city and their continued conduct may well cause a tragic loss of life and property.

Groups of young men with sunken cheeks and vacarnt eyes hang just beyond the corners. Shoppers and school children move furtively on the littered sidewalks.

title: Multicar Homes Increase

A decade ago the figure was 16.4 per cent. The survey also showed that 38 per cent of all house holds had a color television set.

The new play costars James Earl Jones and Cameron Mitchell.

Ohio, Tuesaay, Oct. 20Portage County deputy sheriffs arrested the student president of Kent State Univer sity and a sociology professor yesterday in the beginning a roundup of 25 persons in dicted by a state grand jury in connection with the di? orders here, last May, in which four students were killed by National Guardsmen. By early this morning four arrests had been made.

Daniel Taradash, academy president, said that grants would be awarded on recommendations made by a newly appointed committee that includes Gordon E. Sawyer, William W. Hornbeck, Hal Mohr, Wilton R. Holm and Sidney Solow.

title: U.S. VIETNAM FORCE DROPS TO 4YEAR LOW

title: 'Goin' Down the Road' Winds Its Way From Canada
description: Donald Shebib's "Goin' Down the Road," which opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema and 34th Street East Theater, has already won best Canadian picture award at the Toronto Film Festival and has received considerable praise in at least one of its pre-reviews. It is, however, a very dull movie, and because it pretends to a kind of flat realism to certify its fiction, it lacks most of the saving graces that attend ordinary bad movies and sometimes make them fun to watch."Goin' Down the Road" concerns two young Nova Scotians (Doug McGrath and Paul Bradley) who, because they are without prospects at home, take off for Toronto, where, in everything they attempt  jobs, seduction, marriage, installment buying, theftthey fail. They are stupid young men, each in his own way elaborately self-deceived. But the film persists in taking them seriously, or, more accurately, in taking their plight seriously. Finally, as the presskit plot synopsis faithfully (alas) sums it up: "Victims of urban life and institutions, with shattered dreams of quick affluence held out by the media to the uneducated and untrained, leaving behind bad jobs, bad debts, bad apartments and the pressures which turned them eventually to petty crime, they again take to the road."In spite of its earnestness, and, to a degree, because of its earnestness, the film inevitably condescends toward its charactersplacing them, understanding their motives and reactions, settling their destinies with deterministic rigor. A mostly depressed view of a depressing world, it eschews the clichs of conventional fiction only to be trapped by the banalities of its own social-studies conventions. When somebody in "Goin' Down the Road" moves into an expensive apartment, you know exactly what humiliation will follow  even though the attending deities are the Angels of Economics rather than the Avenging Fates.The performances are mostly first-rate, and the scenes that do come to life (I remember especially a pathetically moving wedding banquet) owe a good deal to the skill and sensitive interplay of Doug McGrath and Paul Bradley. In a minor role, voluptuous Nicole Morin plays a kind of walking, talking Playboy centerfold who adds nothing much to the plot but who, for the time she is on screen, indicates at least one of the seven dimensions otherwise lacking in "Goin' Down the Road."

Or he can play softly, with full control, heard to best advantage in the Mozart Sonata in F (K.332).

title: Ban on U.S.I.F. Fund Extended By Gramco for 30 More Days
description: Gramco Management, Ltd., announced yesterday that the temporary halt of sales and redemptions of its U.S.I.F. Real Estate Fund  first suspended by directors less than two weeks ago  had been ex tended for an additional 30 days.

title: Lee Marvin Marries
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 19 (Reuters) Lee Marvin, the actor, mar ried Pamela Feeley, a divorcee from his hometown of Wood stock, N.Y., here yesterday. It was the second marriage for Mr. Marvin, who won an Academy Award for best actor in 1965 for his performance in Cat Balou He met his wife following World War II when he was recuperating at his family's New York home. It was her third marriage.

title: 2 High in Administration See Economy on Upbeat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Two high economic officials of the Nixon Administration asserted, today that the national, econ lomy was resuming expansion.

title: Truck Mechanics Strike Four Chicago Newspapers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) Truck mechanics serving Chi cago's four major newspapers went on strike early today, but spokesmen for the papers said publication would not be in terrupted.

title: SISTER BRIGID ROWSOME
description: Sister Brigid Rowsome, ex ecutive director of auxiliary services at Marymount Man hattan College, 221 East 71st Street, since 1961, died yester day in Doctors Hospital. She was 65 years old.

title: President Ceausescu's Visit
description: A few years ago a formal visit to and tour of this country by the head of a Communist countrya man who is also chief of his nation's Communist party would have produced strong controversy. It is a sign of the new maturity of American public opinion that Rumanian President Nicolae Ceausescu has been received with great cordiality everywhere he has gone in the United States. Unquestionably, one factor in this recep tion is America's memory of the extremely cordial wel come President Ceausescu and his people extended to President Nixon when he visited Rumania in August 1969. And during his stay here, Mr. Ceausescu must have learned also that there is widespread admiration in this country for the policy of genuine national inde pendence which the Rumanians and their leaders have implemented so capably in the last decade.

title: Prices Close Easier on London Board
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed generally eas ier in quiet trading yesterday.

title: PAUL R. WAGNER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 Paul R. Wagner, curator of special collections at the Princeton University Library, was found dead today in his apartment at 65 College Road. He was 32 years old. The police ascribed the death to natural causes.

title: Nat'1 Hockey League
description: Nat'1 Hockey League

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: YANKEE MANAGER VERY SURPRISED
description: Ralph Houk, who led the New York Yankees out of five years, of baseball oblivion this season, was named American League Manager of the year by The Associated Press yes terday, beating Earl Weaver of the world champion Baltimore Orioles.

title: Knit Shirts Are Hit of Men's Wear Show
description: The talk this week at the semiannual trade show of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers is about the goods that are moving out of the stores and those that aren't.

title: U.S. Expresses Sympathy to Canadians
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The United States announced today that it had expressed its sym pathy to the Canadian Govem ment, to the Quebec provincial government and to the widow of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Minister of Labor and Immigra Alan, who was kidnapped by members of the Front for the Liberation Of Quebec and found mtrdered Saturday.

title: Theater: Modest Revue
description: To Be or Not to BeWhat Kind of a Question Is That? is the title of a modest little revue that opened at the Bar bizon Plaza Theater last night. It is a sort of love let ter to Israel, devoted to quips and songs about the young state. But; though the title suggests something of a frol ic, the show is unable to live up to its promise.

title: Midtown Bank Held Up
description: A man held up the Franklin National Bank on Eighth Ave nue between 41st and 42d Streets about 10 A.M. yester day and made off with $2,270, the police reported.

title: Quebec Police Find House Where Laporte Was Held
description: ST. HUBERT, Quebec, Oct 19The house in which Pierre Laporte was held hostage for a week before he was slain last Saturday was discovered today on an unpaved street in this quiet suburb of Montreal.

title: Gabriel Suffers Contusion
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (UPI) Roman Gabriel, the National Football League's most valuable player last season, suffered a contusion, not a shoulder separation, in the Los Angeles Rams 3121 victory at Green Bay yesterday as feared, the team announced today. Xrays of Gabriel's left shoulder proved negative. He is expected to start at Minnesota next Mon day night, the Rams said.

title: First Lady Helps Mrs Romney
description: DETROIT Oct. 19 (AR)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that wonnen have a ink influence in politics and that the country needs more of them in political office.

title: Teleprompter in Accord for Muzak
description: The Teleprompter Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to ac quire Muzak, Inc., suppliers of background music to offices, factories and restaurants, from the Wrather Corporation.

title: TWO DUOS CARD 67'S TO SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oc. 19The opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association propro championship found two teams tied for the lead at 67 today over the 6,601yard, pax, 36, 3672! Cedar Brook County Club layout.

title: E.W. DEFAULT ON INTEGRATION CHARGED IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Civil rights forces filed a law suit today charging the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare with general and calculated default in its en forcement of a law that for bids racial discrimination in the use of Federal education funds.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M.

title: Joel Pocock To Be a Bride
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Pocock have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Kathryn Joel Pocock, to Paul Alexander Mitchell, son of John M. Mitchell and Mrs. Barbara J. Mitchell of Stamford, Conn.

title: LINDSAYENDORSES GOLDBERG, CITING URBAN PROGRESS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday en dorsed Arthur J. Goldberg and Basil A. Paterson, the Demo cratic Liberal candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Gov ernor, because they have ex pressed the strongest commit ment to the battle for urban progress.

title: Market Summary
description: Market Summary

title: Market Place:
description: Are the combatants in proxy fights and writers of proxy statements in general really interested in telling it like it is to Aunt Jane? Judging from the prolixity of proxy material Aunt Jane and other shareholders re ceive one wonders.

title: Change at Jamaica Is Only a Memory For 12,000 Riders
description: For some 12,000 Long Island Railroad commuters, it was the end of an era yesterdayno more changing at Jamaica.

title: WANAQUE TAKE5 WESTBURY PACE
description: WESTBURY, L.L, Oct. 19 (UPI)Wanaque scored an up set victory tonight in the $49, 312 New York Sires Stakes No. 3 for 2yearold pacing colts and geldings as Roosevelt Raceway began the final 50day meeting of the season.

title: Chilean Coal Miners Await Allende's Rule Hopefully
description: CORONEL, Chile, Oct. 14 The mist off the nearby Pacific Ocean was cold and clung to coal dust on the miners faces and the thin wool of their wives sweaters as they lined up outside a pit elevator to be paid.

title: Conqueror of Nijinsky Sought for International
description: LONDON, Oct. 19 (UPI) Lorenzaccio, surprise winner of the Champion Stakes at Newmarket last Saturday, and Hotfoot, who finished third in the race, behind Ni jinsky, were invited today to run in the Nov. 11 Washing ton D.C. International on the grass at Laurel.

title: Service to Blind Wins Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The Post Office Department ruled today that currentevents recordings for the blind would get the same favorable postal rates as newspapers and maga zines. The decision came on an appeal by the American Print ing House for the Blind of Louisville, Ky., which produces Newsweek Talking Magazine.

title: AMEX PRICES SINK IN SLOW TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change sustained its sharpest daily loss in almost four months yesterday as the list retreated in slow trading.

title: Sheila H. Wood, 1964 Debutante, Betrothed to Richard Schwartz
description: Mrs. J. Bogert Tailer of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Sheila Hunter Wood, to Richard Jay Schwartz, pres ident and chief, executive of ficer of Jonathan Logan, Inc., manufacturers of apparel for women.

title: Susan Eisenhower to Be Wed in April
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 19Miss Susan Elaine Eisenhower, granddaughter of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, plans to be married in April to Alexander Hugh Bradshaw, a British barristeratlaw.

title: PRESIDENT SCORES TIDE OF TERRORISM
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 19 President Nixon swung through the Middle West today and said that a rising tide of terrorism) and crime could only be stemmed by Republicin votes in November.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Pay Rise Ends 22Week Irish Bank Strike
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 19 (UPI)Em ployes of Ireland's banks ac cepted a new pay offer today, ending a 22week strike. Bank ing officials said that it would take weeks to clear up the re public's tangled financial af fairs.

title: ExG 1. Says He Saw Galley And Mitchell Kill Civilians
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 19  A former member of the infan try company that swept through the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in 1968 testified today that screaming women, children and old men had been pushed into a.ditch and shot by S. Sgt. David Mitchell and Sec ond Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. Another former member said that he had observed both men standing at the edge of the ditch but had seen only the lieutenant fire.

title: Mrs. H. C. Phipps, Leader in Horse Racing, Dies
description: Mrs. Gladys Mills Phipps, widow of Henry Carnegie Phipps and celebrated for many years as the First Lady of the Turf, died yesterday after a short illness at Spring Hill, her West bury, L. I., estate. The New York and Palm Beach society leader and owner of Wheatley Stable was 87 years old.

title: Soviet and Turkey to Sign a Road Pact
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 A highway agreement that will permit Soviet trucks to cross eastern Turkey on a 500mile land route into Syria and Iraq is to be signed here tomorrow, a. Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10 A.M., and 3:10 P.M.

title: The Prince of the Island
description: CAIROWhen Anwar elSadat, as a young officer, was imprisoned for conspiring agaimst the British and the corrupt King Farouk he wrote a politi cal novel discussing the relative values of revolution and evolutionary re form. His book was called The Prince of the Island and was never published.

title: Congress: Manhattan
description: Manhattan this year offers an unusually bright array of Congressional contenders, but such is the voting com plexion of the five districts involved that the contests present a minimum of suspense. As it happens, the five candidates endorsed by this newspaper are overwhelm ing favorites to win, although that fact has played no part in our decisions.

title: TORTURE IN BRAZIL DENIED BY PRESIDENT
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Oct. 20 (AP)Presdient Emilio G. Medici said today that peo ple who accused Brazilian au thorities of torturing prisoners were bad Brazilians, Commu nists and subversives. The public statement was his first on the issue.

title: Facts Invented for a General's Medal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20The United States Army has awarded a Silver Star for valor to a general in Vietnam based on a descrip tion of acts of heroism in Cambodia that were invented by enlisted men under orders.

title: Feld Troupe to Present 4 New Works in 4 Days
description: Eliot Feld, as everyone in dance will tell you by now, is a young choreographer who knows what he wants and has itnamely, his own ballet company, the Ameri can Ballet Company. Tonight, a year from the day it made its debut here, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's resident ballet troupe opens a two week season with four new works in four days.

title: Du Pont Scion, in Court Petition, Lists Liabilities of $63Million
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 20 Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., a greatgreatgreat grand son of the founder of E. I. du Pont de Nemours, the world's largest chemical company, asked the United States Dis trict Court here today to super vise his payments to 121 creditors.

title: Cards Trade Campisi
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals traded Sal Campisi, a pitcher, and Jim Kennedy, an infielder, to the Minnesota Twins today in ex change for Herman Hill and Chuck Wissler, outfielders.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Premier Golda Meir of Israel told Secre tary of State Rogers yesterday that her Government was ready to resume talks with the United Arab Republic as soon as Egypt rectified her violations of the ceasefire. Mrs. Meir's comments stifled speculation that Israel might have softened her terms for a resumption. [Page 1, Columns 23.]

title: U.S. FINANCIER FACES A TRIAL IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, Oct. 20Thomas A. Pappas, a Greek born Bos ton financier with, a $200mil lion industrial empire in Greece, was charged today with breach of trust and vio lation of Greek corporate laws.

title: President Stumps For Gore's Rival
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Oct. 20President Nixon launched today a political attack against Senator Albert Gore in the Tennessee Democrat's home ter ritory.

title: NETS TURN BACK MEMPHIS, 108103
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 20The New York Nets opened a two game road tour by defeating the Memphis Pros, 108103, at MidSouth Coliseum tonight.

title: TV: Free Time Runs Into Difficulty
description: Channel 13 courted trouble in the Monday night premiere of its program entitled Free Time. David Peel and the Lower East Side, a group that, with good reason, does not want to be compared with accomplished rock ensembles, used the live microphone in a way that by any reasonable interpretation constituted en couragement of the use of marijuana.

title: Tito Arrives in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Oct. 20 (UPI)President Tito of Yugoslavia bezan a threeday state visit to the Netherlands today amid intense security.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS ADVANCE BRISKLY
description: Glamour issues bounded up ward yesterday to star in stock market that otherwise registered a small advance.

description: Morning

description: Garden State Results

title: 2 Pieces of Moon Rock Are Missing in the Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Two tiny pieces of moon rock have apparently been lost in the mail.

title: U.S. to Sponsor Hijacking Parley in November
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 20  The United States has invited other nations to a conference on pre vention of aircraft hijacking, to be held in Washington at the end of November.

title: The 3d District
description: POPULATIONAbout 409, 000, including Great Neck and Port Washington areas, the city of Glen Cove and the Douglaston section of Queens County. Predominantly upper middle class, one of most af fluent Congressional districts in the United States.

title: Denver Museum Aide Accused Of Attempt to Sell Stolen Art
description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation charged yesterday that the vice president of the board of trustees of the Denver Art Museum, wearing a wig and a false mustache, sneaked into New York City to sell paintings stolen not from his museum but from the art collection of a friend.

title: Late McLaren's Conservatism In Building Cars Is Dramatized
description: Sunday's CanAm race at Monterey, Calif., dramatized the late Bruce McLaren's, faith in building cars cau tiously, conservatively and with a great deal of atten tion paid to fundamentals. Denis Hulme won the McLaren team's fourth con secutive. CanAm championship in a su perbly prepared al McLaren M8D Chevrolet that weathered t h e challenges, actual and poten tial, of three. Buck Rogers types: Jim Hall's vacuum cleaner Chaparral 2J; the superlight Ti22 Made mostly of titanium, and Mac's Sper cial, a weirdo with four. en gines.

title: Our Cadet, After a Losses in Row, Triumphs on Grass at Aqueduct
description: After eight straight defeats in a string that began last June at Belmont Park, Calumet's Our Cadet finally was returned to the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Amex Prices Keep on Even Keel; But Declines Outpace Advances
description: Declines continued to out pace advances yesterday on the American Stock Exchangr for the 11th consecutive session in quiet trading although the losses were considerably less than on Monday.

title: NAVY CONSIDERING PLAN TO MOTHBALL 6 OF 18 CARRIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The United States Navy, facing the prospect of shrinking budgets and increasing costs, has a plan to mothball up to six of its 18 aircraft carriers, according to authoritative sources.

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: Tuesday, Oct. 20. Second day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: RATIO OF AWARDS TO GENERALS HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Al most half of the Army generals who served in Vietnam last year brought back medals for bravery in combat. Few more than 1 in 10 average service men not similar awards.

title: Brother Principal
description: Brother Melvin Taylor, principal, proclaimed a bul letin board inside East Har lem's Benjamin Franklin High School yesterday, He is the students, the parents the teachers and the peo ple's choice.

title: U.S. ASSERTS PRAGUE HOLDS A CHICAGOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  The State Department said today that Czechoslovakia had been holding a naturalized American citizen in a jail near Prague since Sept. 4 on charges of making allegedly derogatory remarks about President Lud vik Svoboda.

title: New England Papers Elect
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Carter H. White, executive vice president and publisher of The Meriden (Conn.) Record Journal, was elected president of the New England Daily Newspaper Association today at the group's annual meeting.

title: UNITED THE CARDS GAIN FIRST PLACE
description: The St. Louis Cardinals will come to tow on Sunday as a firstplace football team. The last time they came to town they were a divided team.
