Juno van de Oranje Ma nege, which she coowns with Karen Amistead of Brooklyn, competed at the Puerto Rico Club fixture. She is a Dutch, and inter national champion. Miss van der Vlis hopes to show her at the Afghan specialty in New York next February.

title: Pope Paul Assails Torture by Police, Alluding to Brazil
description: ROME, Oct. 21Pope Paul VI, clearly alluding to Brazil, condemned police torture today as barbaric. In an address to thousands of pilgrims from many countries who attended his weekly general audience in St. Peter's Basilica, the Pontiff also voiced outrage over other forms of political violence, ter rorism and crime throughout the world. Particularly, the Pope de plored aircraft hijackings, kid nappings, armed robbery and trafficking in drugs.

title: SOVIET AND ISRAEL UNDERSCORE SPLIT ON MIDEAST IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21Premier Golda Meir of Is rael and Foreign Minister An drei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union underlined the deadlock in the Middle East today by de livering diametrically opposed statements to the General As sembly on the terms for re opening ArabIsraeli peace talks.

title: U.S Agronomist Gets Nobel Peace Prize
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 21.An Iowaborn crop expert who has sought to, ease the world's hunger with research into im proved strains of wheat and rice was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1970 today.

title: CONSUMER PRICES RISE AGAIN HERE
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that consumer prices here last month continued to rise faster than the rate for the entire country.

title: World Religious Leaders At Parley Urge CeaseFire
description: KYOTO, Japan, Oct. 21 (AP) About 300 religious leaders ended a sixday international conference for world peace here today and unanimously adopted resolutions calling for an immediate ceasefire in Viet nam and a prompt halt to South Africa's racial policy. The resolution on Vietnam also demanded that all foreign governments immediately with draw military assistance to both North and South Vietnam.

title: Lee Konitz Brings Saxophone And Cool Jazz to Half Note
description: Lee Konitz, one of the hardy survivors of those turbulent days after World War II when jazz burst its traditional bound aries to explore what became known as bebop and cool jazz, has turned up at the Half Note, Hudson and Spring Streets, where he will be play ing through Saturday:

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS BILL TO ENLARGE MERCHANT FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  President Nixon signed into law today a new maritime program that will build 300 merchant ships over the next 10 years and extend operating subsidies to almost the entire fleet.

title: TowTruck Operators Seek a Rate Rise
description: Private towtruck operators demonstrated for higher rates Yesterday at City Hall.

title: Television
description: 7:00 (2)News Reports (4)Today: Senator George Murphy of California, Republican (7)Listen and Learn

title: PUBLISHER GROUP TO LEAVE THE CITY
description: The American Newspaper Publishers Association, which was founded in New York City 84 years ago and has been here ever since, announced plans yesterday to move its head quarters to Reston, Va., pri marily because of unaccept able rent increases.

title: Canaveral Concern's Head Cites Copeland's Security
description: Daniel S. Dubbin, president of Canaveral International, Inc., said yesterday that hi believed that the real estate security for $1.1million owed to the com pany by Lammot, du. Pont Cope land Jr. was adequate proteg tion to Canaveral.

title: SPORT IS PRAISED BY UNION LEADER
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21 George Meany, one of the world's top labor leaders, recommended golf today as healthy exercise for all as he took part in a proamateur preliminary to the $150,000 Kaiser international open.

title: MILLS CRITICIZES REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways, and Means Committee, publicly, criticized for the first time to day President Nixon's proposal to share revenues with state and local governments.

title: Vending Machine Gives Cigarettes and a Spiel
description: The only audible cigarette message available in Amer ica after Jan. 1, 1971, says Audio Vend, Inc., which has patented a system that can be installed into existing cig arette vending machines.

title: Labor Group Backs White
description: DEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP) The state A.F.L.C.I.O. Labor Council's Committee on Politi cal Education, endorsed Kevin H. White,  the Democratic nominee for Governor, at a meeting here today. Mr. White is Mayor of Boston.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: 2 COMPANIES FACE POLLUTION CHARGE
description: A special Federal grand jury indicted two major manufac turing companies yesterday on charges of polluting the Hudson and Harlem Rivers.

title: POST WILL RESUME PUBLICATION TODAY
description: The New York Post prepared yesterday to resume publica tion today for the first time since the Newspaper Guild went on strike Oct. 6. Guild members ratified a new con tract Tuesday night.

title: PROGRAM ON GUITAR FOR FREDERIC HAND
description: Frederic Hand's guitar pro gram on Tuesday night at Car negie Recital Hall made several welcome excursions outside the wellthumbed repertory too often heard in such recitals. There was not, in fact, one Spanish or South American piece, revolutionary as that may seem. Mr. Hand further de lied guitarrecital practice by including several sizable pieces, two of them of his own compo sition.

title: JOHN JAMES MURPHY, EXSTOCKBROKER, 71
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., Oct. 21John James Murphy, re tired stockbroker who was sen ior partner in the recently dissolved New York Stock Ex change specialist firm of Mur phy & Co., died tonight at his home on Baldwin Avenue. He was 71 years old.

title: Yahya Asserts IndianPakistani Enmity Is Tragic
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21President. Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan of Pak listen declared here today that Pakistan and India had became the laughingstock of the world because of their per sisting enmity. The two countries should have been the closest friends, but are instead the worst of enemies, he observed, and added: It is tragic for both of us.

title: at Penn Central Ordered To Testify About Trading
description: Three insiders who alleg edly sold 32,000 shares of Penn Central Company stock from January, 1969, until the eve of last June's bankruptcy filing by its railroadoperating subsidi ary, the Penn Central Transpor tation Company, were ordered yesterday to testify in New York State Supreme Court.

title: QUEBEC MAY HOLD SOME FOR 21 DAYS
description: MONTREAL,. Oct. 21The Quebec Government announced today that some of the 369 per sons arrested in raids since last Friday would be held without arraignment for the maximum period of 21 days permitted un der wartime emergency powers invoked by the Federal Govern ment following two political kidnappings and the slaying of one of the victims. Jerome Choquette, Quebec's Minister of Justice, sought to reply today to criticism of the way the Government's emer gency powers have been exer cised.

title: Key Factors in the 16th District
description: POPULATIONAbout 400,000. The largest ethnic groups are Italians and Irish, with pockets of Scandinavian, German and East European residents.

title: Arizona's Code of Student Conduct
description: These excerpts are from a code of conduct covering all universities governed by Arizona's board of regents. Tomorrow, a public hearing will be held at which the code is being challenged as a model of campus repression.

title: Peril to Coalition From Opposition Denied by Brandt
description: BONN, Oct. 21Chancellor Willy Brandt, marking his first 12 months in office today, dis missed predictions by the Par liamentary opposition that his Government would soon top ple. He vowed to serve out his term ending in 1973.

title: The Chief Awards
description: Model Green Conformation HunterMrs. A. C. Randolph's Lord Sutler.

title: Capote Jailed on Coast
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI)Truman Capote entered Orange County Jail tonight to serve a threeday sentence for failing to appear as a witness at a murder trial. The author was found in contempt of court Monday in Superior Court.

title: Congress: Brooklyn,
description: This newspaper's endorsements for Congressional contenders in the tristate area continue with the seven districts comprising Brooklyn and Staten Island, all but one of which are about as safe for a Democratic candi date as the South was in the days when it was really solid. In the Tenth District alone we, refrain from making an endorsement, 47 years in the House seeming exces sive even for so durable a fixture on Capitol Hill as Representative Emanuel Celler (Dem.Lib.). Endorsements for the other districts follow:

title: U.S Seeking Rise In Its Latin Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The United States has of fered, provided Congress ap proves, to increase its im ports from Latin America by more than $350million an nually in agricultural and fisheries products and raw materials.

title: Germans Get 5th Victory in Row At Horse Show in Pennsylvqnia
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21 The Canadian Equestrian Team did its utmost tonight to break the West Germans tight rein on the international events at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, but couldn't do it.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: Kinney National Service Bids To Acquire Simon & Schuster
description: Simon & Schuster, the 46 yearold book publisher, and Kinney National Service, Inc., a multimillion  dollar conglom erate that owns among other thingi Wainer Brothers, the mo tion picture company, and the Riverside Funeral Chapels in New York and Florida, an nounced yesterday that the two companies are engaged in nego tiations looking toward Kin ney's acquisition of the publish ing house.

title: General Dynamics Picks a New Chief
description: David S. Lewis, the 53year old president and chief operat ing officer of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation; has been elected chairman and chief ex ecutive officer of the General. Dynamics Corporation.

title: CASO is ENDORSED 131 TEAMSTER GROUP
description: GARDEN, CITY, Oct. 21 (UPI)  member Inter national Brotherhood of Team sters Joint Council 16 an nounced today that it was back ing Ralph G. Caso, a Republican, in the race for Nassau County Executive.

title: KERTESZ CHOOSES MUSIC CONTRASTS
description: Schubert's classically formed Symphony No. 5 in B flat and Bruckner's Symphony No. 4 in E flat, which is Romantic both in style and subtitle, were programed by Istvan Kertesz in his appearance with the Phila delphia Orchestra in Philhar monic Hall Tuesday night.

title: Decline for Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Commerce Department said today new orders for dura ble goods in September de clined by $900million over the preceding month.

title: STOCKS ARE MIXED AFTER FAST START
description: The stock market, propelled by one of its favorite rumors, got of to a Funning start yes terday morning. Then it spent the rest of the session slowing down, and finished with mixed results.

title: Delayed Alarm Cited In Ironworks Blaze Fatal to  Fireman
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery reported yesterday that an ironworker whose acetylene torch started the fire last Sat urday in which a fireman died tried to fight the fine for 20 minutes by hauling buckets of, water seven stories to the roof before the Fire Department was called.

title: Amex Prices Drop as Volume Eases
description: Prices on the American Stock. Exchange again moved down yesterday in the lightest trading in two months.

title: Comment on Insurance Deal
description: C. Eugene Farnum, Insurance Commissioner of Massachusetts, said yesterday he had reason tc believe a tender offer by Massa chusetts Indemnity and Life In surance Company for stock of the Loyal Protective Life Insur ance Company was in contra vention of state law under the Holding Company Regulatory Act of 1970. A hearing is set for Oct. 29 to decide whether a temporary restraining order granted Oct. 20 will be dis solved. The tender called for purchases of Loyal at $42 share.

title: Roundup in Kent State Indictments Moves Slowly
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 21The roundup of 25 persons indict ed in connection with the Kent State University disorders con tinued to move slowly today. One young woman turned her self in and a Yippie was told by a clerk to come back to morrow to find out if he had been indicted by the special state grand jury.

title: Radio
description: 15:30 P.M, WRVII: Just Music: Carl Nielsen. Symphony No. 2 (The Four Temperaments); String Quartet No. 3 in E flat (Op. 14); Prel udes for Organ (from OP. 51); Symphony No. 4The Inextin guishable; Woodwind Quintet; Symphony No. 5 (Op. 50); Con certo for Flute and Orch.; Sym phony No. 6 (Sinfonia Semplice) Nielsen

title: Bruce Is Believed Discouraged by Continuing Impasse in Vietnam Peace Talks
description: PARIS, Oct. 21After two months of talking to the Viet nam Communists, David H. E. Bruce, the chief American ne gotiator at the peace talks here, has found himself in much the same deadlock as his pred ecessor, Henry Cabot Lodge, and there are indications that he is feeling the same dis couragement. In the American view, the Communists continue to insist that Washington solve their political problem for them by getting rid of the present Sai gon Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu and allow ing the establishment of a coali tion on Communist terms. Thus the Americans hear, week in and week out, the demand that they abandon the puppet re gime they., have imposed on the Vietnamese people.

title: Naata Koutisen Companes Styles in Violin Recital
description: Nadia Koutzen's violin recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night divided itself neatly into two sections in terms of the listening pleasure it provided. And the distinctions between the two were so pronounced that they might have been played by different violinists.

title: N.Y.U. 20 Victor in Soccer
description: New York University's soccer team defeated Kings Point, 20, yesterday on Ohio Field in the Bronx on fourthquarter goals by Abdula Jama and Roger Gestal.

title: Witter Has Profit
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest broker age houses, reported yesterday that it earned $1,011,000 in the year ended Aug. 31, down sharply from $3,068,000 in the previous fiscal year.

title: Bunche, Brewster To Receive Awards Of Church Council
description: Dr. Ralph J: Bunche, Under Secretary of the United Na tions, and Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, will receive the eighth annual Family of Man Awards for ex cellence from the Council of Churches of the City of New York.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A young magazine writer named Phil Berger, whose tippytoe habit earned him from Dick Barnett the nick name Sly, has written an extraordinary book that contains this paragraph:

title: France Bans Arms Sales
description: PARIS, Oct. 21  President Pompidou has decided to for bid the export of French arms that could be used to suppress uprisings in, South Africa or other countries, it was official ly announced today.

title: Tenneco Files for Offering
description: Tenneco, Inc., filed a regis tration statement with the Se curities and Exchange Com mission covering an offering of 5.5 million shares of stock with warrants to buy an equal num ber of shares. Stone & Web ster; White, Weld, and Paine, Webber will handle the public offering, scheduled Nov. 24.

title: Light on Lindsay and All That
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The New York political situation is now so con fused that many people want to export the whole thing to California where it would feel more at home. Unfortunate ly, this is impossible because Gov ernor Rockefeller has never acted in movies and Mayor Lindsay's smog type (Manhattan positive) creates such dis turbing symptoms as Sam Yorty when subjected to Los Angeles auto exhaust.

description: The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System

title: A.T.&T. Planning to Sell $500MiIlion Debt Issue
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday (to sell $500 million of debt securities early in November.

title: ASHER ROSEN
description: Asher Rosen, a former cloth ing manufacturer here, died Tuesday in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 92 years old.

title: MRS. DENNIS J. CAREY SR.
description: Mrs. Margaret Collins Carey, wife of Dennis J. Carey Sr., who with her husband found ed the Peerless Oil Company (now the Petrochemicals Com pany), died Tuesday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 87, years old and lived at 195 Adams Street. Brooklyn.

title: Soviet and Canada Agree On Pacific Coast Fisheries
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 21 (AP) The Soviet fishing fleet will stay clear of an area of the fleet will stay clear of an area of the continental shelf off Van couver Island, scene of past in cidents, under an agreement an nounced today.

title: NORTH STARS BEAT CANADIENS, 3 TO 1
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (UPI) Bill Goldsworthy scored late in the third period and Minnesota's rookie goaltender, Gilles Gil bert, was outstanding tonight as the North Stars defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 31.

description: SmallCollege Ratings

title: The U.N. at 25: Birthday Is Far From Happy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21The United Nations is 25 years old, and the chances are that no birthday child has ever had to listen to so many unkind remarks. Like so many disappointed parents, statesmen from all over the world have pointed out its shortcomings during the celebrations here. Secretary General Thant has said that time is run ning out for the member govern ments to throw their full sup port behind it.

description: Nat'l Hockey League

description: Open Interett

title: Tarkenton Has Yet to Miss a Game
description: The fact that Joe Namath had played 77 consecutive pro football games before be ing forced out by his broken wrist this week brought at tention to the subject of quarterback durability, and that, in turn, brought up the subject of Fran Tarkenton.

title: 2 Marines Have Meningitis
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Oot. 21 (AP)Two marines were listed in serious condition today with meningitis. They were identified at Pvt. William R. Kelly Jr., 19 years old, of Shreveport, La., and Pvt. John H. Salis, 20, of Milwaukee.

title: LAKERS TROUNCE 76ERS BY 141117
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) Jerry West scored 37 points, 16 in the third period, in lead ing the Los Angeles Lakers to a 141117 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a National Basketball Associa tion game.

title: PeepShow Producer Is Called Evader of Federal Income Tax
description: The chief accountant for the State Commission of Investiga tion testified yesterday that a company headed by a reputed underworld figure failed to ac count for at least $250,000 and probably twice that amount in 1969 Income earned by supplying peepshow machines and films to bookstores in the Times Square area and else where.

description: The Program

title: Episcopal Church Planning a New Ministry for Youth
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 21The Episcopal Church authorized today the establishment of a youth program designed to de velop new patterns of min istry to youth and young adults focused on issues and institutions important to their lives.

title: Pirates Martaugh Voted National's Top Manager
description: Danny Murtaugh of the Pittsburgh Pirates was named National League manager of the year by The Associated Press yesterday.

title: Scientist of the Fields
description: Early yesterday, a slender, vigorous, deeply tanned man was busily at work oversee ing a special harvest of wheat in a Mexican field.

title: DAVIS TO BE USED AS A BACKUP MAN
description: Coach Weeb Ewbank again discounted reports yesterday that the Jets would make a trade to replace the injured Joe Namath at quarterback.

title: Nixon on Stump: 5Part Theme
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 20It is delivered without text, streamofconsciousness style; but there is nothing unconscious or accidental in the design of the message that President Nixon brought here last night and plans to carry into every close Sen ate race across the country.

description: Entertainment Events

title: ENGINE MISFIRED, CRASH PANEL TOLD
description: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 21 (AP) A witness testified today that at least one engine of the Wichita State University foot ball plane was misfiring just before the aircraft crashed Oct. 2. But the surviving copilot testified that everything on the plane worked.

title: BRIBERY ATTEMPT LAID TO POLICEMAN
description: A Brooklyn policeman was arrested yesterday on an indict ment that accused him of trying to bribe another policeman to change his testimony in a marijuana case.

title: Revolutionary for Peace
description: Timely recognition has been given to the vital role of food in the world's search for peace by the award of the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize to American agriculturist, Dr. Norman Ernest Borlaug. Dr. Borlaug's pioneering work in developing better grains has been a key element in the green revolution. It has brought new hope the majority of the world's people, whose chronic hunger has posed a continuing threat to national and interna tional stability.

title: Market Place
description: Is the Era of Great Pros perity over for this nation? From a stock market point of view must we seek out very special situations in the future?

title: Canada Picks China Aide
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 21The Canadian Government today named John M. Fraser, a Foreign Service officer, to head its mission to establish an embassy in Peking. Mr. Fraser took in the talks in Stock holm that led to establishment of diplomatic relations.

title: Corsaro Opera: The Full Treatment
description: She's like a dope addict looking for a fix, desperately trying to break into the house and get the document. The image of the fix domr nates the whole opera. Frank Corsaro, waving his arms and sending off rays of hyperthyroid enthusiasm, was explaining the first scene of his production of The Makropoulos. Affair, whose East Coast premiere will be given Nov. 1 by the New York City Opera.

title: Berthold Waldorf, Officer Of Management Company
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 21 Berthold H. Waldorf, execu tive vice president of Waldorf Equity Research, a New York investment management com pany, died yesterday in Green wich Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 30 years old and lived at 12 Lindsay Drive.

title: U.S. Air Attache Missing in Crash in North Laos
description: VIENTIANE. Laos, Oct. 21 (AP)An American air attach who had been in Laos only a, few days crashed in northern Laos on Oct. 13 and is presumed dead, the United States Embas sy announced today. A spokesman said the at tach6,. Maj. Joseph L. Chestnut, 36 years old, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., was 18 miles east of Luang Prabang when his pro pellerdriven T28. either was shot down or had a mechanical failure. The spokesman de scribed the flight as orienta tion. but the T28 was armed with bombs.

title: Prize to Aid Research
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21Dr. Borlaug said here today he would use the $78,000 prize to further his research in richer strains of Wheat to alleviate world hunger and perhaps win another Nobel Prize.

title: Study Suspended on Use Of North Slope Tankers
description: The Humble Oil and Refining) Company announced yesterday that it was suspending its stua ies of icebreaking tankers to concentrate efforts on pipeline methods to bring oil from Alaska's North Slope to markets in the lower 48 states.

description: Article 3  No Title

title: ITALIAN SHOOTER SETS WORLD MARK
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 21 (AP) Giovanni Liverzani of Italy set a world record of 598 in the rapidfire pistol match today in the 40th world shooting chain pionships.

title: U.S COMPANIES CITED. IN GOLDFIELD SUIT
description: The Goldfield Corporation of Delaware filed a suit yesterday in the Court of Queen's Bench in Winnipeg, Canada, as a counterclaim against three prominent United States com panies and their directors and officers.

title: Blount May Make Trip To Hanoi on G.I.'s Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)President Nixon told Postmaster General Winton M. Blount today to go to Hanoi, if that is necessary and possible, to deliver Christmas Mail to American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: NIXON CAMPAIGNS ON WELFARE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 President Nixon is campaign ing more strenuously for his welfare refofm progearn now than he did when it stood a chance of Congressional ap proval before the election.

title: FAWZITAKES OATH AS U.A.R. PREMIER
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21The new Premier of the United Arab Re public, Dr. Mahmound Fawzi, and 32 Cabinet ministers took oaths of office today in a cere mony in Kubbeh Palace, open ing a new period in Egyptian political history. Dr. Fawzi, a 70yearold dip lomat, is the first Egyptian Premier of nonmilitary back ground since Sept. 7, 1952, six weeks after Gamal Abdel Nasser and fellow officers de posed King Farouk.

title: Bridge:
description: Enthusiasts from the New York metropolitan area had a wide choice open to them last weekend. Some stayed in Manhattan and competed in the International Bidding contest, and others partici pated in a sectional tourna ment at Westwood. N.J.

title: Seale Motion Denied
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21Su perior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey today denied a defense motion to dismiss charges against Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins because of pre trial publicity.

title: Foes of Allende Plan Their Countermoves
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 The panicky reaction., of Chil ean conservatives.to. Dr. Salva dor Allende's impending presi dential victory has receded and potential opposition forces sense some confusion now within Dr. Allende's leftwing coalition.

title: The Courts: Need for Change
description: Nothing, at least nothing that is secular, changes more slowly than the ways of courts. Judges are tradition alists, and they ought to be. After all, the continuity of the society's com mitments is substantially in their keep ing.

title: Drawbridge in Queens Shut Monday Collapses
description: A wooden drawbridge across Shellbank Creek near Howard Beach, Queens, col lapeed last night after some children were reportedly seen playing near the structure.

title: DAVIS KEEPS LEAD IN TITLE BOWLING
description: GARDEN CITY, L. L, Oct. 21 Dave Davis, bidding to win this title for the third time in a sevenyear professional bowl ing career, leads 23 others into tomorrow's semifinal round of the $75,000 National champion ship at Garden City Bowl.

title: Profit Squeeze for Airlines and Metals
description: The financial distress of the nation's airlines was pointed up yesterday in earnings state ments for the September quar ter issued by four of the 11 big trunklines.

title: PRICES CLIMB Oh% AFTER 3 MONTHS OF MODEST RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The rise in prices accelerated in September, the Department of Labor reported today, as the Consumer Price Index rose one half of 1 per cent to 136.6, after adjustment for seasonal factors.

title: Committee for Gala Feted by Cheathams
description: The countdown for the 1971 Red Cross International Gala, one of the main events of the Palm Beach season, was begun here yesterday when Mr. and Mrs. Owen R. Cheatham gave their annual committee reception at their River House apartment.

title: MAYOR STIRS BOOS AT SMITH DINNER
description: Mayor Lindsay was greetea with a mixture, of boos and cheers when he got up to speak last night at the 25th annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial din ner.

title: Blass Makes the Forties Look Good
description: In its race for revivals, fashion has already nosed out of the nineteenthirties and into the forties. At this rate, it can't be long before it reaches the sixties and dis covers Rudi Gernreich.

title: Textile Recession Cited
description: The FMC Cdrporation re ported yesterday that third quarter earnings declined by per cent to $13,051,000, or 38 cents a share, from $14,273, 000, or 43 cents a share in the 1969 period,

description: Aqueduct Entries

title: Varig Buys Boeing Jets
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 21 (AP) yarig Airlines of Brazil has pur chased four 727100 trijets to be used in internal and inter national flights, Boeing officials said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Lindsay Favors Widening OpenEnrollment System
description: Mayor Lindsay suggested yes terday that the state's private colleges and universities the students admitted to the City University under the openen rollment program, with the city paying their tuition.

title: The City Comes First
description: It was entirely proper, in our view, for Mayor Lindsay to make known his preference for Arthur J. Goldberg in the gubernatorial contest. But it is far from proper for the Mayor's declaration to become a cue for key city officials to absent themselves from their duties campaign for Mr. Goldberg.

title: Executive Changes
description: Marine Midland Banks, Inc. announced that George R. Williams had resigned yesterday as presi dent and director for personal reasons. Charles A. Winding, chairman and chief executive of the $7billion bank holding company that operates statewide in New York, was given the additional title of president. Following the suicide almost a year ago of J. Fred Schoellkopf 4th, the company's then chairman, the 63yearold Mr. Windingwho at that time was chairman of one of Marine Mid land's smaller subsidiary bankswas named chair man of the parent holding company, even though Mr. Williams was already president.

title: Socialists Here tack Goldberg and Ottinger
description: The Socialist party of New York endorsed the gate Democratic ticket bf Arthur J. Goldberg and Basil N. Pat erson yesterday as well as the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, Richard L. Ottinger.

title: ARMY TO CONDUCT INQUIRY ON MEDAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21The Army today announced an official investigation into the award bf a silver Star for valor to a general in Vietnam on the basis of a citation written from the imagination of an enlisted man. Brig. Gen, Eugene P. For rester, who learned on Monday that his medal was a source of dispute, wasstill not available for comment today.

title: Lowell Thomas Honored at Fete After 40 Years as a Newscaster
description: Lowell Thomas, a voice out of eyeryone's past, was hon ored at a luncheon yesterday for his unparalleled endurance as a radio newscaster.

title: F.D.A. CITES DOUBT ON DIABETES PILI,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Food and Drug Administration said today that it, the Ameri can Medical Association and the American Diabetes Associa tion concurred with findings of a study that cast serious doubt on the value of a diabetes pill used by about 800,000 Ameri cans.

title: COPPER PRICES CUT BY PHELPS DODGE
description: The Phelps Dodge Corpora tion, the second largest pro ducer of American primary copper, announced yesterday an immediate price cut for the metal to 56 cents a pound from 60 cents a pound.

title: JORDAN REPORTS MINT BY IRAQ
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 21 Informed Jordanian sources said today that the 12,000 Iraqi troops stationed in Jordan since the ArabIsraeli war of June, 1967, were being pulled out and that their withdrawal would be completed tomorrow night.

title: Ton Pasquale Returns to the Met With New Faces
description: It has been five years that Donizetti's Don Pasquale has been, away from the Met ropolitan Opera, and that is too long a time. Thus the revival Tuesday night was cause for general rejoicing and merriment. Of all buffo operas, only Rossini's Bar blare di Siviglia has this combination of good clean fun end tune after happy tune.

title: The Rebirth of a Future: II
description: All around us today we see new ways of thinking and living: long hair, student protest, rock music, rejection of old careers. Many people find all of this shocking, frightening, sense less. But against the background of what has gone wrong with America, it all makes sense. There is a logic to it that explains each large and small experiment. Taken as a whole, it represents the only largescale search for common sense and selfpreserva tion that can be found in America today, the only major effort to come to grips with reality and thereby re assert man's control of his own fate. This is the beginning of a new con sciousness, Consciousness III.

title: The Screen: Marlon Brando and Black Revolution
description: "Burn!," Gillo Pontecorvo's first film since "The Battle of Algiers," aspires to be a prole epic but winds up as the sort of prole pageant in which characters always seem to be conceptualizing great issues, mostly freedom, as they pass in front of history, as if it were a scenic view, instead of moving in and out of it.The time is the mid-19th century and the setting is the fictitious island of Queimada, a Portuguese sugar colony in the Caribbean. To further their own trade, the British send to Queimada a secret agent, Sir William Walker (Marlon Brando), to preach independence (and greed) to the plantation owners and to teach revolution (and freedom) to the slaves.Largely with the help of Jos Dolores (Evaristo Marquez), a black Bolivar whom he first meets as a dock porter, Sir William is triumphantly successful. The Portuguese are removed and the independent nation of Queimada is established with the support of the British Antilles Sugar Company.At the height of the victory, the now-General Jos Dolores is persuaded to disband his black army and to leave the running of the country to the white commercial interests. Ten years later, Sir William returns to the island to put down a new black rebellion led by the disciple who is of no further interest to the crown.Although it is fiction, "Burn!" can never quite bring itself to take advantage of this in order to create a drama of conflict and confrontation. Its scope is so broad, so grand, really, that it can't be dominated by either the British agent, whom Mr. Brando plays with a marvelously complex, rueful intelligence, or by Jos Dolores, a role that is not so much played by Mr. Marquez as represented by him. Mr. Marquez, a nonprofessional Colombian, looks fine, like a mahogany saint, but his speeches are often unintelligible.In the course of its production, "Burn!" (originally titled "Queimada") turned into a kind of mini "Cleopatra." There were stories of illnesses, reports of feuds and rumors of romances. The location of sites near Cartagena, Colombia, became so rugged that shooting was shifted to North Africa. The film went over its schedule and over its budget, but this can only explain some minor technical failings.Mr. Pontecorvo seems to have conceived "Burn!" as a kind of super-"Battle of Algiers," an attempt to dramatize not only the meaning of freedom but also the black Caribbean heritage, which is a large order. There is a tremendous difference between reconstructing fact, which he did in "Algiers" and has its own shape, and creating so-called significant fiction on which a shape has to be imposed.I'm not sure, but it does seem to me that he may actually have made his own compromises with contemporary commercial needs by making Queimada a Portuguese colony. Portugal, which was about the only European power not to colonize in the Caribbean, is not as big a market for imported films as, say, Spain, which takes a dim view of foreigners dipping into its history and rewriting it.Having said all this, I must add that I wasn't bored by the film for a minute. It is lovely to look at, and although it never delivers an ultimate payoff, it keeps promising one. Furthermore, Mr. Brando is worth watching under almost any circumstances, and you should enjoy seeing him here, using that Fletcher Christian accent and, towards the end of the film, looking very much like the late Ernest Hemingway, a tired and tragic hero whom life has somehow double-crossed. The movie opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie.There are points of interest in "Little Fauss and Big Halsy," which opened yesterday at Cinema I, but most have to do with issues beside, behind, and, I guess, beneath the film. It is not so much a bike movie, or a movie about contemporary life styles, as you might believe from the ads, as another in a continuing series of betrayed male relationships that seems central to the screen career ("The Leather Boys," "The Ipcress File," "The Lawyer," etc.) of Sidney J. Furie.Little Fauss (Michael J. Pollard) and Halsy Knox (Robert Redford) do ride bikes, and, without much success, they race in various meets throughout the Southwest. Little is the earnest ugly good guy, and Halsy, the handsome womanizing lying louse, and between them grows up an affection more real and more nearly equal than their world or their own ideas might ordinarily allow. But it is a relationship so poorly defined, so genuinely inexpressive in its devious reserve, that when at the climax Little lets down his pal, it feels as if nothing has happened. And, on the whole, nothing has.Between Little and Halsy falls a shadow, a girl (Lauren Hutton as "Rita Nebraska," and you can see where names get to be a problem in this movie) whom Little loves and Halsy has. But the theme of sexual jealousy must be taken almost on faith. Although the film-keeps acting as if it knew what girls were for with many breast shots and an occasional thigh or two, the actual sense of attraction is lacking utterly. What draws Little to Ritaas opposed even to what draws Little to Halsyremains more of a mystery than this movie can bear.If you compare "Little Fauss and Big Halsy" with a real movie about speed racing say, Hawks's "Red Line 7000"you will understand the disadvantage of having, instead of a subject, a series of (mostly negative) attitudes. I'm not sure what the bikes mean to Furie, but he seems to appreciate them for their nuisance value, like a crowd of swarming flies. He is careful also to include a crowd of swarming flies. Everyone drives as if in a mad rageacross a landscape that is good only for the dust that can be raised on it.In this context it is difficult to understand character or admire characterization. Of the two leads, Redford does better at resisting the understated hamming that the camera seems to beg of him. Miss Hutton might be good, and she would be beautiful, in most movies. I suspect that Linda Gaye Scott, a symbolic sex object here, has more to offer than the misuse of her body. But Lucille Benson and Noah Beery, as Little's mom and dad, eagerly push American postgothic into theater of the absurd, and Miss Benson must be credited with one of the creepiest performances in recent movies.

title: Lightning Test Fails
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 21 (UPI)The space agency fired a fivefoot rocket into a thunderhead today to try to trigger lightning, but the elec trical charge in the cloud was too low. It was the first at tempt in a project called Mighty Mouse to touch off lightning by firing small rockets into thunderheads. The idea is to see if a cloud's electrical potential can be drained enough so that manned rockets can be safely launched through it.

title: 7 AIRPORTS ASKED TO CURB SST NOISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The Environmental Defense Fund asked seven major air port authorities today to pro mulgate a rule now to bar fu ture use of their runways by supersonic transports exceeding Federal noise levels for subsonic, jets.

title: Goldberg Promises Equal Treatment for All Cities
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 22Arthur J. Goldberg promised today that if he became Governor he would establish a genuine partnership between the state and its cities, in which all are equal and none superior.

title: PISTONS SET BACK HAWKS BY 120101
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI)The backcourt combination of Jim Walker and Dave Bing sparked the unbeaten Detroit Pistons to their sixth victory of the Na tional Basketball Association sceason tonight, a 120101 de cision, over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Montgomery's 65 Leads By Stroke in Coast Gold
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 22  Jack Montgomery of Fort Worth, Tex, who is down at 115th place on the current money list, looked over his shoulder today at 155 other contestants as he led the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tourney with a sevenunderoar 65.

title: 2d Wounded Student Seized On Kent State Indictment
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 22 (UPI) A second student who was wounded last spring on the Kent State University campus when National Guardsmen fired into a group of demonstrating students was arrested today on an indictment of a special state grand jury.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: DetroitAlvin (Blue) Lewis, 214 pounds, Detroit, knocked out Cleve land (Big Cat) Williams, 205, Hou ston, 4 rounds.

title: Soviet Shows Illustrations of Luna 16, Moon Material Retriever
description: Detailed illustrations of Luna 16, the craft involved in the first unmanned retrieval of ma terial from the moon, have been released by the Soviet Union.

title: Cost of Food Is Becoming A Political Issue in India
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 22The Indian housewife's trip to the market is becoming more and more costly these daysand more of a political issue.

title: MONITOR AGENCY ON DRUGS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22A national agency should be set up to monitor patients adverse reactions to medicinal drugs, an expert in drug surveillance said today. At present, doctors are en couraged to report drugs ad verse effects to the Food and Drug Administration, but there is no national program for in tensive surveillance of drug re actions. The same lack exists in most nations.

title: Administration Aiming Its Big Guns at Tydings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The Nixon Administration went gunning with its biggest artil lery this week for Senator Jo seph D. Tydings of Maryland, but even some Republican poli ticians, agreed that it missed a good opportunity to unseat a vulnerable Democratic Senator.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

description: ROME, Oct. 23The Vatican announced today that it had held talks here with Hungarian Government officials on ways to improve churchstate rela tions.

description: Federal Reserve System Statistics

description: Unveilings

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A week ago I met a man on a wild dawn on the New England seacoast casting for striped bass into the teeth of a screeching southwest gale.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 22 (UPI)  The Yomiuri Giants captured their sixth straight Central Baseball League pen nant today as Hidetake Watan abe hurled a fivehit 41 victory over the fifthplace Chunichi Dragons.

title: Flyers Beat Sabres, 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (UPI)Thirdperiod goals by Bobby Clarke, Jean Guy Gend ron and Garry Peters gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 42 vic tory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight. Buffalo gained a 20 lead early in the first period on goals by Chriss Schmautz and Gil Perreault. Simon Nolet scored the Flyers first goal at 11:35 of the first period.

title: Nixon, Confident of Gains in 70, Planning Same Tactics for 72
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 President Nixon and Vice President Agnew, apparently confident that their 1970 elec tion strategy is clicking smooth ly, are already looking toward employing the same basic ap proach in the 1972 elections.

title: Paris Reserve Holdings Up
description: PARIS, Oct. 22 (UPI)  France's foreigncurrency hold ings grew by $18.7million in the week from Oct. 8 to Oct. 15, the Bank of France an nounced today.

title: TV The Serpent, a Ceremony Based on Genesis
description: The Serpent, which was presented last night on the N.E.T, Playhouse over Channel 13 as the main body of a 90 minute program Open Thea ter: The Serpent, is the sem inal work of The Open Thea ter, America's most important ensemble theatrical workshop.

title: Irish Rider Breaks W. Germany's Hold With Jumping Score
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 Capt. E. V. Campion of the Irish team and Neal Shapiro of the United States played an equally adroit game of cards on horse back tonight in the interna tional jumping of the Pennsyl vania National Horse Show.

description: Market Summary

title: Launching Postponed Again
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Oct. 22 (AP)Adverse weather con ditions forced postponement to day for the fourth time this week of the launching of the orbiting frog otolith satellite, designed to place two bullfrogs in orbit for a fiveday mission.

title: Patti Hogan Loses Temper, But Wins in British Tennis
description: STALYBRIDGE, England, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., lost her tem per and was threatened with disqualification today before she defeated Winnie Shaw of Scotland, 810, 75, 64, in a quarterfinal match of the De war Cup indoor tennis tourna ment.

title: Lockheed to Get $20Million In Settlement With Boeing
description: BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 22 (AP) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which last March said it was suffering a financial crisis because of contract prob lems with four major programs, said today that it had reached a $20million settlement on one, the short range attack mis sile.

title: Market Place
description: Years ago, it was regarded as a signal honor to be elected to the board of a corporation.

title: Football Injury Proves Grave
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) Jim Pitts, sophomore quarter back on the Johns Hopkins University football team who was injured in the game with Haveiford last Saturday, under went surgery for removal of his spleen, one kidney and part of his diaphragm, according to a Union Memorial Hospital spokesman. One of his kidneys was ruptured after he was hit from the rear while attempting to throw a pass.

title: Westchester, Upstate
description: We conclude bur consideration of Congressional con tenders in the tristate region with districts from West chester Ceiunty north to the Albany area.

title: Fellowship to Honor Danny Kaye
description: The Institute of Rehabilita tion Medicine of the New York University Medical Cen ter will recognize Danny Kaye's worldwide efforts on behalf of UNICEF and under privileged children by estab lishing a fellowship in his name.

title: Continental Oil Co. Seeks Own Shares With Tender Offer
description: The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday it would invite tenders of shares of its common stock in exchange for up to two million shares of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Com pany, Ltd. Conti nental now owns 12,039,06,7 corn mon of Hudscon's Bay, or 65.8 per cent of those outstanding., Assuming the tender offer is fully sub scribed, Continental's owner ship in Hudson's Bay would be reduced to 54.9 per cent.

title: Stage: 40 Informative Vignettes of Street Sounds
description: Street Sounds, a new play by Ed Bullins, which is being performed this week at La Mama Etc, sprawls with the sounds, sights, guts and humor of the urban ghetto.

title: Study Group Is Formed By Financial Community
description: A committee of prominent members of the financial com munity has been organized to examine major Issues confront ing the securities industry and has agreed to advise the New York Stock Exchange on its deliberations and conclusions.

title: O'Brien Scores Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Dem ocratic National Chairman, ac cused the Nixon Administration today of converting the 1970 election into a national trag edy by using the politics of fear to divide the country.

title: Dropping the Mask
description: The White House has now dropped the mask of noninterference in this state's Republican party. When Vice President Agnew first began firing his radiclib torpedoes at Senator Charles E. Goodell, the White House press spokesman said that President Nixon was staying out of the New York campaign at the request of the state's Republican leaders.

description: Open Interest

title: DEBT REFINANCING SET BY TREASURY
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it would offer a 7 per cent 42month note and a 7 per cent fiveyear ninemonth note to refinance $7.67billion of notes that ma ture in midNovember.

description: Roosevelt Entries

title: ABRAHAM NEIMAN OF DALLAS STORE
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Oct. 22 (AP)Abraham Lincoln Neiman, cofounder of the NeimanMar cus Company, died here yester day. He was 95 years old.

title: Struck York, Pa., Paper Sold To a Law Firm in that City
description: YORK, Pa., Oct. 22J. W. Gitt sold The Gazette and Daily today to the York law firm of Morris, Vedder & Fitzkee. Har old W. Fitzkee Jr., District At torney of York County, is the new publisher.

title: Laver and Gisbert Advance
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 22 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia and Juan Gisbert of Spain, won their quarterfinal matches today in the Count of Godo open ten nis tournament. Laver defeated Manuel Arantes of Spain, 36, 60, 64, 61, and Gisbert beat Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 26, 75, 57, 108, 75.

description: NEW YORK CLEARING HOUSE STATEMENT

title: Abacus President Answers Charge by Royal Bank Chief
description: The bitter proxy fight over the proposed merger of the Security National Bank, Hunt ington, L. I., and the Royal National Bank, based in Man hattan, heated up yesterday.

title: ARMY COMMANDER IN CHILE IS SHOT; ALERT IS DECREED
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 An unidentified gunman today shot and critically wounded the Conimander in Chief of the Chilean Army,. I Gen. Rend Schneider Chereau. The Govern ment later decreed a state of emergency.

title: WARRANT ISSUED IN COAST KILLINGS
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 22 The Santa Cruz County Dis trict Attorney said tonight that a murder warrant had been is sued and a nationwide search was under way for a suspect in the slaying last Monday of a wealthy eye surgeon and, four other persons at his moun taintop estate five miles south of here:

title: 13TH LOSS IN ROW LISTED BY AMEX
description: The American Stock Ex change yesterday sustained its 13th consecutive loss as the list retreated on the lightest vol ume in more than two months.

title: DR. JOHAN KOPP, 95, OF ESTONIAN CHURCH
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 22, (Reu ters)Prof. Emeritus Johan Kopp, former bead of the Es tonian Evangelical Lutheran Church tioth in Estoniaand in exile, died here in his sleep yesterday a spokesman for the church confirmed today. He was 95 years old.

title: Rachel M. Davies Of Duke to Marry
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 22 The Rev. Dr. William David Davies, George Washington Ivey Professor of Advanced Studies and Research in Christian Origins at Duke University, and Mrs. Davies have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Rachel Mary Davies, to John Ogden Manter, son of Mrs. Florence Ogden Manter of Augusta, Ga., and the late Dr. John Tinkham Manter.

title: Sports of at gimes
description: The obituary notice was brief and that's probably all it rated  a mere statement of the fact that Lou Novikoff, onetime outfielder with the Chicago Cubs, had died at the age of 54. After all, he couldn't even make it as a wartime ballplayer in the early nineteenforties. But he did sup ply a vivid splash of color when it was so sorely needed and he was a genuine gate attraction when most of the real stars were off to war. He was afloat in a wave of publicity from the moment he arrived in the big leagues until the moment he left.

title: PAPPAS CUTS LEAD OF DAVIS IN BOWLING
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 22 George Pappas, the only righthanded bowler among the top five, continued tonight to hound Dave Davis of Miami, for the lead in the $75,000 na tional championship of the Pro fessional Bowlers Association, at Garden City Bowl.

title: Jordan, at U.N., Accuses U.S. of Encouraging Israeli Occupation of Her Territory
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22The Jordanian repre sentative at the 25th anniver sary session of the United Na tions accused the United States today of helping and encourag ing Israeli occupation of Jor danian territory.

title: HERMAN J. HORNSTEIN
description: Herman J. Hornstein, a certi fied public accountant with of fices at 280 Madison Avenue, died Wednesday of a heart at tack in his home. He was 67 years old and lived at 1521 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx.

title: The Situation In 5th District
description: POPULATION: About 409, 000, largely middle and high income. It is estimated thilt half the population is Roman Catholic, with the rest split equally between Jews and Protestants.

title: NONCOMMERCIAL TV IS GIVEN $1MILLION
description: Mobil Oil Corporation granted more than $1million to non commercial television, it has been announced by John W. Macy Jr., president of the Corporation for Public Broad casting.

title: Anne N. Young And a Teacher Plan Wedding
description: BERWYN, Pa., Oct. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Neale Young have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Anne Neale Young, to Robert Model, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jean Model of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Rail and Truck Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonage in the week ended Oct. 17 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

title: JOHNSON J. HAYES, RETIRED JUDGE, 84
description: WILKESBORO, N. C., Oct. 22 (AP)  Retired United States District Judge Johnson J. Hayes died today, apparently from heart attack, while tending cat tle on land he leased in Dough ton Park. He was 84 years old.

title: Nixon Peace Plan Rejected Again, Definitively, at Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Oct. 22The Vietna mese Communists said today that they totally, globally, ca tegorically and definitively re jected President Nixon's so called peace initiative of Oct. 7, terming it a swindle aimed at helping the Republicans in the coming American elections.

title: ROMEO MEETS NIXON TWO HOURS IN HELPFUL TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 President Nixon met for more than two hours today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, for talks that both sides described in positive terms. But no specific progress was disclosed on the wide range of issues discussed.

title: WERNER KNOP DIES; WROTE ON GERMANY
description: CHANTILLY, Va., Oct. 22 (UPI)Werner Knop, an au thor and economic writer, was killed in an auto accident today near Middleburg. He was 58 years old. Mr. Knop, a native of Ger many, was educated at the University of Freiburg, Oxford University and the London School of Economics.

title: U.S. Combat Deaths Decreased to 40 Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22 (AP)The United States command announced to day that 40 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, six fewer than the week before and the second lowest weekly toll in four and a half years.

title: ANTIWAR OFFICERS SEE RETALIATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Three weeks after their spokes men denounced the Vietnam war, members of an officers organization are facing armed forces retaliation, according to the dissenters.

description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 22Now you can put the name of B. Devereux Barker on the list with Brooks Rob inson, Willis Reed and Bobby Orr as soughtafter after dinner speakers. Barker, the chairman of the New York Yacht Club Race Committee, was neither a skipper nor a crewman during.

description: Charts of Races at Aqueduct

title: Scopes of Monkey Trial Is Dead at 70
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 22 John T. Scopes, whose teaching of evolution led to the monkey trial of 1925, died of cancer yesterday at the age of 7Q.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We reject it totally, globally, definitively and categorically.Nguyen Thank Le, the North Vietnam ese press spokesman, commenting at the Paris peace talks on President Nixon's peace plan. [10:5.]

title: CHRYSLER, A.M.C. STEP UP SALES
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22  The Chrysler and American Motors Corporations reported today that their midmonth car sales topped levels for a corre sponding period last year. But the continuation of the strike at the General Motors Corpo ration means that the industry sales totals will trail the Oct. 1120, 1969, total.

title: MUSIC FROM SPAIN HEARD IN PROGRAM
description: Thruston Johnson, violinist, chose a program of rarely heard Spanish music for his recital with David Garvey, pianist, at the New York Cultural Center Wednesday night.

title: New Knudsen Concern Will Make Motor Home
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) Semon E. (Bunkie) Knudsen, dismissed as Ford Motor Company president in 1969, has formed a new company that will market recreational vehicles.

title: Additional State Troopers Authorized for Cairo, Ill.
description: CAIRO, III., Oct. 22 (UPI) Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie au thorized today additional state troopers to keep the peace in racially troubled Cairo where Mayor A. B. Thomas said a revolution was going on. Mayor Thomas said several hundred shots were exchanged by snipers and city police last night in a 2hour battle. No injuries, were reported.

title: Italy Honors Art Dealer
description: LONDON, Oct. 22  Eric Estorick, New Yorkborn direc tor of the Grosvenor Galleries here, was decorated by the Italian Government today for his services to Italian Art. The decoration, making Mr. Esto rick a Commendatore al Merito della Republica Italiana, was presented to Mr. Estorick by Raimondo Manzini, Italian Am bassador to Britain, at the cultural department of the embassy.

title: American Reporter Is Ousted by Soviet; Linked to a Protest
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22  John Dornberg, correspondent for the magazine Newsweek, was ordered today to leave the So viet Union.

title: BIG BOARD LOWER IN SLOW TRADING
description: Wall Street analysts kept de scribing the action of the stock market yesterday as drifting. It turned out to be a slow drift downstream for many issues.

title: Knicks Erase 11Point Deficit in Second Half and Defeat Warriors, 9592
description: Happy days were here again last night for Knick fans in the crowd of 16,244 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Utility Plans Expansion
description: Middle South Utilities, Inc., plans to spend $1.3billion on new construction in the five years ending 1974, Gerald L. Andrus, chairman, told a meet ing of security, analysts in At lanta. Operating companies the system plan to double their generating capability over the next seven years through the addition of 6,825,000 kilowatts. Three of the new units will be nuclearfueled. Middle South Utilities is a holding company with operating subsidiaries in parts of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Dorm Ownership Clarified
description: Barnard College said yester day that two residence halls re cently criticized by students were owned by Teachers Col lege rather than Barnard. The dormitories, at 503 West 121st Street and 501 West 121st Street, both partially occupied by Barnard students, were called unlivable in a Colum bia Sepectator article quoted in The New York Times yesterday. The Times article suggested the two dormitories had been re furbished, but a Barnard spokesman said that the refur bished Barnard dormitories are at 3001 Broadway.

title: WAGEPRICE GUIDES ANNOUNCED BY BONN
description: BONN, Oct. 22The West German Government announced adoption today of a package of price and wage guidelines designed to stabilize further this country's economy in 1971.

title: Casualty Figure In Error
description: Because of a transmission error, an Associated Press dis patch from Washington pub lished in The New York Times last Sunday said that eight Americans had been killed in action in South Vietnam during the week ended Oct. 3. The cor rect figure is 38.

title: RUSSIA PLANNING NEW SPACE TESTS
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 22Soviet space experts are sufficiently concerned about the effects that long periods of weightless ness may have upon the human body that they are planning more endurance flights in Soyuz spacecraft before they launch their longheralded earthorbiting mace station.

title: Sandler and Dikman Gain In National Handball Event
description: Steve Sandler, seeded No. 1 in the United States Handball Association onewall singles championship, won his semi final match at the Brownsville Handball Court, yesterday. Howie Eisenberg, the No. 2 seeded player, was upset by Mike Dikman, seeded sixth.

title: Piatigorsky Don Quixote Marks Debut Anniversary
description: The New York Philhar monic is having a sentimen tal season, celebrating birth days (Aaron Copland's 70th) and anniversaries. On Wednesday evening Gregor Piatigorsky was the cello so loist in Richard Strauss Don Quixote, and the per formance was given in com memoration of the 40th an niversary of Mr. Piatigorsky's American debut.

title: The NixonGromyko Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The most that can be hoped for tram the Nixon Gromyko talks is that both sides will now agree to cut down on the propa ganda and buckle down to serious negotiations on the control of strategic weapons.

description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: CAMBODIAN FORCE TRAINING IN LAOS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct 22Reliable sources have re ported that three Cambodian battalionsabout 1,500 men are at an American Special Forces, camp in southern Laos for commando training and possible use in the Laotian Cambodian border region.

title: Secret Places By Arpino Returns To the City Center
description: Gerald Arpino's Secret Places, which looks, mislead ingly like a for fewer than all seasons, has endured surprisingly well since its El vira Madigan days. Two years ago, the use of the same Mozart cqncerto in the Swedish film and the new for the City Center Jeffrey Ballet as well as their common yeunglove theme associated the two perhaps too closely with each other.

title: Candidates on Democratic Slate In a Turmoil Over Split Support
description: The statewide Democratic ticket has been thrown into turmoil  with Richard L. Ottinger and Adam Walinsky challenging Arthur J. Gold bergbecause the Liberal party and Mayor Lindsay's personal political organization have be gun working for Mr. Goldberg but against Mr. Ottinger and Mr. Walinskv. Mr. Walinsky, the Demo cratic candidate for Attorney General, canceled all his other appointments last night to fly to Buffalo for a meeting with Mr. Goldberg. They reportedly discussed the OttingerWalin sky objections to joint cam paign efforts for Mr. Goldberg and the two RepublicanLiber als, Charles E. Goodell for Senator and Louis J. Lefko witz for Attorney General.

title: INDIA IRKED BY U.S. OVER VISIT PROTOCOL
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 22 (UPI) A Foreign Ministry spokesman expressed displeasure today over the treatment accorded Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on her current trip to the United States.

title: Horses Killed as Fire Destroys Stable at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Oct. 22 At least 35 thoroughbred race horses were killed last night when a 250footlong wooden stable was leveled by fire at Garden State Park.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Miss Morris Sets Bridal Next Month
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 22Miss Laurie Morris, graduate student at New York University, will be mar ried Nov. 21 to Lewis Novod, a senior at the N.Y.U. School of Law.

title: Harvard's Coach In Last Bid to Even Dartmouth Series
description: It is not only Harvard vs. Dartmouth tomorrow in the Harvard Stadium. It is John Yovicsin vs. Bob Blackman for the final time. Yovicsin is scheduled to retire as Harvard's football coach after, this season.

title: Iraqi Troop Units In Jordan Continue To Man Positions
description: MAFRAQ, Jordan, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Iraqi troop units to taling 12,000 men continued to man positions around Mafraq today and showed no sign of pulling out despite reports they would do so.

title: Guerrilla Movements Reported
description: MAGHAYER, Jordan, Oct. 22 (AP)  The Jordanian Army said today that about 1,800 Palestinian guerrillas had crossed into Jordan from Syria and had taken up positions near this frontier village.

title: Bomb Explodes at Church as Mourners Await Funeral of Policeman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (UPI)A nailfilled time bomb exploded outside a church to day, as mourners gathered for the funeral of a policeman who had been killed in a bank holdup.

title: Manson Takes Seat. In Courtroom Again As Order Prevails
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22  Judge afarles H. Older today permitted the defendants in the murder trial of Charles M. Man son to return to the courtroom although they gave no promises of good behavior. Such a pledge had previously been required by the judge.

title: Should Women's Lib Succeed, Would Men Be Free at Last?
description: It almost had to happen and it has. Women's liberation has given birth to a small but healthy ancillary movement: men's liberation.

title: Two Benefits Planned for Little Orchestra Society
description: The concert performance of Weber's opera Euryanthe. at Philharmonic Hall next Tuesday will be a benefit for the Little Orchestra So ciety, of which Thomas K. Scherman is director. A sec ond benefit will be a dinner dance Nov. 17 at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Witness on Smut Changes His Mind About Testifying
description: A witness who declined to testify Wednesday at the State Commission of Investigation hearings on sexoriented busi ness denied that he was con tected with the underworld. He also denied allegations yes terday that he had failed to report all of his 1969 income earned from supplying peep show machines and films to bookstores in theTimes Square area and elsewhere.

description: C. Peter McColough, presi dent, and Joseph C. Wilson, chairman, reported the results yesterday from the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters:

title: Advertising: FullService Shop a Fossil?
description: The fractionalism of the fullservice agency, a gen uine concern among some executives wondering about the future of the business, was the final topic as the Eastern Region of the Ameri can Association of Advertis ing Agencies ended its three day meeting at the Biltmore.

title: Air Quality Designations Are in Dispute in the City
description: The city's Commissioner of Air Resources said yesterday that he had been under pres sure to modify his oneword daily description of air qual itywhich frequently is the word unhealthy because it is frightening people and is giving the city a bad image.

title: Jersey Standard Rises Along With Texaco
description: Oil industry reports received yesterday for the thirdquarter and ninemonth periods con tinued to be evenly balanced between profit advances and declines.

title: Profit Squeeze Seen Loosening In City Bank Corporate Survey
description: The First National City Bank, releasing preliminary findings of a corporate profit survey, reported yesterday that, al though the General Motors strike was clouding the earn ings picture, the squeeze on profits appeared to be easing for a treat many companies.

description: Both majorparty candidates for Lieutenant Governor are bringing strength to their run ning mates for Governor, while statewide contests for Attorney General and Controller have brought up differing concepts about those offices.

description: Film TODAY

title: Peruvian Leaders Both Pleased and Apprehensive Over Leftist Tend in Chile
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 22  There is satisfaction as well as appre hension in the revolutionary military Government of Peru as her southern neighbor and traditional rival, Chile, pre pares to certify a Marxist as President on Saturday.

description: Money

title: GIANTS REVERSING FANS PENDULUM?
description: For every football coach in the world, the most important game ever played is the one coming up. For players, the same is true to a lesser degree, human beings being as imper fect as they are. Club manage ments, families, season ticket holders and other committed fans of any particular team tend to absorb, to some degree, the coachlv attitude.

title: Bloomingdale's Stamford Branch Expands
description: In 1954, Bloomingdale's, the New Yorkbased store division of Federated Depart ment Stores, Inc. opened a large branch store 40 miles from the city in downtown Stamford, Conn. It was then the concern's largest branch and one of the area's largest.

title: Council for Nationalities Names Executive Director
description: Harry W. Morgan has been appointed executive director of the American Council for Na tionalities Service, David Cogan, the national nonprofit group's chairman announced yesterday. Mr. Morgan, who is 36 years old, is a graduate of Rutgers University and served in the United States Air Force. He has been active in the development of international programs, in cluding the Ambassadors for Friendship program. He was special assistant to the presi dent of Macalester College in St. Paul for five years:

title: Pope Appoints Latin to Direct Missions
description: ROME, Oct. 22  Pope Paul today named Agnelo Cardinal Rossi, Archbishop of Sao Paulo and chairman of the Brazilian bishops conference, as chief of the Roman Catholic Church's missions throughout the world.

title: 2 U.S. Generals in Soviet After Their Plane Strays
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22The Soviet Union announced tonight that a United States Air Force plane, missing on a flight over Turkey with two American generals aboard, had violated. Soviet airspace and landed in Soviet Armenia near the Turkish border.

title: Mutilated Books
description: The school authorities of the Mepham Central High School District on Long Island who cut fortY pages on human sexuality out of four hundred copies of a text book on health had in mind the protection of seventh graders morals. A little pedagogical sophistication might have told them that every pupil whose normal sense of curiosity has not yet been dulled by pedantry will rush to the nearest library to read the missing chapters. This is probably more than ordinary teaching could have accomplished. But such unintended increases in reader ship cannot offset the consequences of the barbaric ex ample of book mutilation. A school that puts scissors books slashes civilization and leaves it bleeding.

title: MACHINISTS ACCEPT PACT WITH 4 PAPERS
description: Newspaper machinists indi rectly accepted a new contract with the city's newspapers yes terday when they did not mus ter suffiicent votes for a strike authorization.

title: BRUINS TIE HAWKS TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP)The Boston Bruins remained the National Hockey League's only unbeaten team by rallying to tie the Chicago Black Hawks, 33, on Johnny Bucyk's fourth goal of the season in the third period tonight.
