title: Helmut Hertz, 65, Head Of Superba Cravats, Dies
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 22 (AP) Helmut Hertz, board chairman and chief executive officer of Superba Cravats, a neckwear manufacturer, died yesterday in Strong Memorial Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in suburban Brighton. Mr. Hertz returned Sunday from a business and pleasure trip to Europe, and entered the hospital Tuesday.

title: Ogilvy Makes Changes On International Scene
description: Ogilvy & Mather. Interna tional has named James Ben son, former chairman of Ogil vy & Mather, London, as vice chairman and has put him in charge of all agency oper ations outside North Amer ica. That means 29 offices in 15 countries that are respon sible for some 35 per cent of the agency's $229.8mil lion in billings. Mr. Benson will be replaced by Angus Ross.

title: Farber Sees Mrs. Abzug But Only as a Newsman
description: The rival candidates for the House from Manhattan's 19th Congressional District had a confrontation in the. City Hall Rotunda yesterday.

title: U. S. Shooters Win 3 Events
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 22 (UPI) American shooters doubled their gold medal total today by taking three standard rifle events in the 40th world shoot ing championships. John Writer of La Grange, Ill., triumphed in the three position standard rifle. Margaret Murdock, of Topeka, Kan., retained the ladies standard rifle title. The United States team took the gold medal in the ladies com petition.

title: I.B.M. Gets U.S. Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 22 (AP) The General Services Admin istration has awarded the In ternational Business Machines Corporation a contract that could total as much as $380 million, it was announced to day. The contract is for Gov ernment purchase, rental, and maintenance of automatic data processing equipment.

title: East River. Analyzed for Twine
description: Aboard the auxiliary sur vey vessel Ferrel, tied up un derneath the Queensboro Bridge at East 59th Street, Government scientists are taking the pulse of the East River.

title: Leader of Student Riots In Paris Gets 18 Months
description: PARIS, Oct. 22Alain Geis mar, leader of an outlawed Maoist group, the Proletarian Left, was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment here to day at the Palace of Justice.

title: D.A.R. Unit Sets Dance
description: The Colonielles, a commit tee of the National Society of the Daughters of the Amer ican Revolution, will give their 11th annual tea dance from 4 to 7 P.M. Sunday at the Plaza to benefit D.A.R.approved schools for Indians. Mrs. Charles Ardo vino, state chairman of the American Indians Committee, will be guest of honor. Tick ets are $7 each and may be obtained from the dinner chairman, Miss Jessie E. Ad amson, 34 Gramercy Park.

title: Moscow Audience Hails Ailey Dancers
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22A vibrant American modern dance com pany tonight won the unre strained approval of a theater full of Russians unaccustomed to the style of swinging innova tion they saw on the stage of Moscow's Variety Theater.

title: Capote Gets Early Release From Jail on Doctor's Plea
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 22 (AP)  Truman Capote, the author, stubblebearded and looking tired, was released to day from jail a day after his doctor said he was worried about Mr. Caoote's health.

title: Robyn Smith Gets First Victory at New York Track
description: Sure; she's pretty, a confused horseplayer said yesterday as Robyn Smith rode Hill Cloud to the post for the fourth race at rain soaked Aqueduct. But how can you bet her?

title: No Votes in Jail
description: Government responds not to problems but to pressures, says David Rothenberg, execu tive secretary of the Fortune Society, an organization of for mer convicts and others seek ing to create a greater public awareness of the problems of penal inmates. Mr. Rothenberg was speaking of the political impotence of in mates, and of their friends and relatives, as a key factor in the fail ure of prison re form, even though virtually all public officials regard prison conditions as scandalous.

title: In Memoriam
description: In Memoriam

title: A.C.L.U. PLANS SUIT TO HELP MAGAZINE
description: The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would file a suit in Califor nia in an attempt to get the November issue of Scanlan's Monthly, it friagazine, printed and distributed.

title: Statistics on Volume and Net Earnings for the Latest Periods Covering a Wide Variety of Corporations
description: Statistics on Volume and Net Earnings for the Latest Periods Covering a Wide Variety of Corporations

title: Treasury Statement
description: Treasury Statement

title: LOWER NET POSTED BY CHICAGO UTILITY
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday that operating revenues for the first nine months rose to $660,236,000, compared with $600,028,000 last year, However, net income slipped to $95,387,000, or $2.12 a share, from $99,072,000, or $2.25 a share, in 1969.

title: EMPLOYES PROTEST AT JACOBI HOSPITAL
description: Laboratory technicians at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx held union meetings during working hours yesterday and Wednesday to protest what they claim are violations of the contract between the hospital and their union, Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes.

title: Extended Civil Rights
description: In 1955, with two other Fed eral judges, Judge Hayes ruled in Greensboro that the Univer sity of North Carolina must re ceive and process the applica tions of three Negro youths.

title: ExLatin Aide Held As Drug Smuggler
description: A former Colombian vice consul ip this city was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges that he had smuggled $5mil lion worth of pure cocaine into this, country.

title: Suit Charges Neglect of Abandoned Children by City
description: The Legal Aid Society filed suit here yesterday charging the city with widespread failure to provide psychiatric care for hundreds of abandoned children in three city institutions.

title: TRANSPORT UNITS ASK $590MILLION
description: A shopping list of trans portation improvements that would cost the city more than $590million including heliports, subway lines and even bullet proof change booths, was out lined to city budget makers yes terday.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: Baseball Transactions

title: Jazz Attracting Some Younger Fans
description: Max Gordon, the gray haired gnome who created the Village Vanguard in 1934 and, in the ensuing 36 years, has paraded poets, folk sing ers, comedians, pop singers, blues bands, satirists and, currently, jazz musicians across its tiny stage, is smiling these nights for the first time in several years.

title: Woodall Faces Task of Coordinating Jets Offensive After Limited Drills
description: By this timefive days A.N.I. (after Namath's injury) one must wonder whether Al Woodall feels more pres sure from the task facing him Sunday or from the endless questions everyone is asking him about how he'll face the task.

title: IOWAN IS ELECTED BY LUTHERAN UNIT
description: SON ANTONIA, Tex., Oct. 22 (AP)  A 45yearold Iowa, theologian, the Rev. Dr. Kent S. Knutson, was elected presi dent of the American Lutheran Church tonight on the fourth ballot.

title: Where Is Youth's Individualism?
description: Those with open minds and hearts would want to share Professor Reich's faith that the new Consciousness of the young is our best hope for bringing America back to its senses and its roots. This is the core of their revolu tion against the inhumanity of the Corporate State we have become; revolution of which the first stage, he writes, must, be personal and culturalthe reassertion of values in each individual's life.

title: CLEANUP DATES SET FOR MIAMI WATERS
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22federal and state officials established dead lines today for a broad cleanup of pollution in Biscayne Bay, the Atlantic Ocean and other waters in and near Dade County.

title: Austrian Delegate to Run
description: VIENNA, Oct. 22Austria's delegate at the United Nations, Kurt Waldheim, was nominated today as the Presidential candi date of the opposition People's party. He will run against Presi dent Franz Jonas, a Socialist.

title: Positive Identification Made Of Murdered Algerian Exile
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 22 (UPI)West German authorities said today that the body of a man found strangled Tuesday in a Frankfurt hotel had been positively identified as that of the exiled Algerian revoluntionary Belkacem Krim.

title: SONG PROGRAM GIVEN BY MICHAEL COONEY
description: Few singers can convey the sheer fun of singing and still underline his singing with a strong sense of conviction as skillfully as Michael Cooney, who delighted an enthusiastic audience that crowded into the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas, on Wednesday night.

title: jurors Here Read Seized Issue Of a Panther Article on Bombs
description: The jury in the trial of 13 Black Panthers spent yesterday afternoon reading an article in the party newspaper on how to make bombs and hand gre nades.

title: Lowenstein Is Fighting Hard To Hold Off Lent in Nassau
description: LYNBROOK, L. I., Oct. 22 Representative Allard K. Low enstein stood in the center of a living room here recently, seeking votes'from a small part of the silent majority.

title: NEUBERGER FIRM SET FOR CONSOLIDATION
description: Neuberger & Berman and Ralph E. Samuel & Co., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed yes terday that they plan to con7 solidate, with Neuberger & Ber man as the surviving firm. Donald C. Samuel and Bernard Stein, principal partners of the Samuel firm, will become Neu berger partners on or about Dec. 1.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Italian Spectacle Is Set For Bryant Park Nov. 4
description: OrlandO Furioso, the Italian spectacle originally scheduled to open on Pier 86 as part of Mayor Lindsay's culture at the piers program, will be performed for a lim ited run starting Nov. 4 in specially constructed bubble theater in Bryant Park.

title: Los Angeles Suit Seeks a Ban on the Dumping of DDT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22The Environmental Defense Fund filed suit in United States Dis trict Court here today to stop the nation's largest maker of DDT from allegedly dumping large quantities of the pesticide into the ocean near the Los Angeles County sewerage sys tem.

title: Musica Aeterria Series Starts Well
description: Frederic Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra have for many years offered a distinguished and lengthy series of concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Occasionally they have made the trip downtown to Car negie Hall, where they could reach a much larger audi ence. This fall they have startea a threeConeert series at Alice Tully Hall, making the conductor and his en semble accessible to more people, but still sticking to an intimate auditorium. On Wednesday night, the new series got off to a fascinat ing start with a program featuring the pianist Yvonne Loriod.

title: PROFITS DECLINE AT UNION CARBIDE
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter of this year dropped to $37, 033,000, or 61 cents a share, from $43,751,000, or 72 cents share in the 1969 period. Sales totaled $763,141,000, against $757,475,000 a year earlier.

title: 200 M.P.'s Get Jetliner Wings
description: FORT DIX, N, J., Oct. 22 More than 200 men were sworn in today as special deputy United States mar shals to ride aboard passen ger airliners in an attempt to thwart hijackers.

title: T. W. A. and Burroughs Suing Each Other on Computer Pact
description: The Burroughs Corporation suffered a setback yesterday in its quest for a larger place in the multibillion dollar com puter industry sun as Trans World Airlines announced that it was discontinuing all efforts to use Burroughs computers in its automated passenger reser vation and management infor mation system.

title: Children Become an Issue for Worried Mothers in the Midwest
description: NEW PALESTINE, Ind. It used to be, Mrs. Treva Fortner said the other day, that Mom and Dad were up on a pedestal and the kids were down here saying, what can I do for you? Now the kids are on a pedestal and the parents are down here. Mrs. Fortner is a cook in the King Arthur Restaurant in New Palestine, a farming community or 900 persons about 20 miles southeast of Indianapolis.

title: HARPSICHORD PAIR HEARD AT SERIES
description: The harpsichord fraternity, than which there is no musical ingroup more fanatical, not even excepting opera standees, found itself twiceblessed in the final event of Hunter College's Virtuoso Harpsichord Series, so called. (How a harpsichord can be a virtuoso is a point not to examine too closely, of course).

title: A 10Hour General Strike Halts Argentine Economy
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22. Argentina's commerce and in dustry were halted by a general strike today but, contrary to expectations, there was little violence.

title: ROCKEFELLER TELLS OF DEE BY RIVAL
description: Governor Rockefeller said last night that Arthur J. Gold berg, his DemocraticLiberal op ponent, had offered a $70,000 ayear state job in return for an endorsernent.

title: Rockets Down Cavaliers
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 22 (UPI) The San Diego Rockets, led by Elvin Hayes with 40 points and John Block with 29, scored a 190110 victory over the Cleve land Cavaliers tonight. It was the fifth loss in five games for the new National Basketball Association club.

title: Market Averages
description: Market Averages

title: The SatoNixon Talks
description: Prime Minister Sato of Japan will meet President Nixon in the White House tomorrow in a final effort to re solve the dispute over Japanese textile shipments to this country.

title: Radio
description: Music.

title: United Church of Christ Urged To Use Funds for Social Impact
description: The exeeutive council of the twomillionmember linited Church of Christ recommended yesterday that not less than 10 per cent of its unrestricted funds, or about $1.3million, be placed in highrisk, lowreturn investments with maximum social impact.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rises From 108.4 to 108.9
description: The wholesale commodity price index rose to 108.9 yester day from 108.4 last week.

title: Emergency Substitute Wins Cheers in Seinele
description: LONDON, Oct. 22A new Sadler's Wells production of Handel's opera Semele was dramatically interrupted last night when the leading so prano was taken ill.

title: Dance: Feld's Powerful New Ballet
description: What do you remember, about childhood? Where were you when your dreams were born, your trauma inflicted, your pattern set? This, I pre sume, is the theme of Eliot Feld's new ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Called A Poem Forgotten and danced, of course, by Mr. Feld's American Ballet Com pany, this makes a most powerful and enduring im pression.

title: 2 Pipe Bombs in Harlem Cause Slight Damage
description: Two pipe bombs exploded early this morning in Harlem. They caused no injuries and only light damage, the police said.

title: Egypt's Patient Premier
description: The new Premier of the United Arab Republic is a nimbleminded, patient man, steeped in the nuances of in ternational diplomacy and a familiar figure to its practi tioners.

title: Robert Walsh, a Reporter For The Daily News, Is Dead
description: Robert Walsh, Brooklyn Federal Court reporter for The Daily News, died of cancer last night in his home at 152 Collins Avenue, Williston Park, L. I. He was 52 years old. Mr. Walsh began his career with the old Standard News Association in Brooklyn in the late 1930's and after being one of the first to be drafted for World War II, returned to the City News Association as a re porter in 1945. Shortly after, he joined The News.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, conferred for more than two hours at the White House yesterday in what both sides later described as positive talks. But no specific progress was disclosed on any of the topics discussed, which included the Middle East, Indochina and Berlin. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: The Tragic Case of Washington High
description: When it was opened in 1924 and for many years afterward, George Washing ton High School, a sprawling redbrick building with white columns in front was known as the countryclub among city schools.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the matter of Vietnam, Charles Brace len Flood, the novelist, is a hawk, troubled hawk, but one who believes that if the Vietcong take over in South Viet nam, the situation for the Vietnamese will be worse than It is now and that a blood bath would be inevitable. But his long, THE WAR OF THE INNOCENTS. By Charles Bracelen Flood. 480 pages. McGrawHill. $7.95. factual account of a year's stay with American fighting men in that country, airmen, advisers, infantry, is really a first person record of what sort of war it and how it is being fought, or at least was fought in 1967, the year he was there.

title: Lagging Harlem Political Activity Begins to Pick Up
description: Despite the fact that a black man from Harlem is running for the secondhighest political office in the state, political ac tivity in the area is at one of its lowest points in years.

title: Rembrandt Portrait Fails to Sell In $ 1Million Art Auction Here
description: Old Master paintings had their peaks and low points last night at auction, hitting bottom when a Rembrandt portrait fail ed to sell and soaring with the sale of a Venetian scene by Francesco Guardi at about twice its appraisal.

title: Selassie Says U.N. Must Be Bolstered
description: Emperor Haile Selassie warned yesterday that the United Nations must be strengthened if it is to avoid the fate of the League of Na tions.

title: Mexico City Is Hit By Power Failure During Rush Hour
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 (Reuters)The Mexican capital was plunged into darkness to night by a power failure that left the metropolis of S million without light for an hour just as the evening rush was be ginning.

title: Clemente, in Debut as Pilot, Draws Cheers and Jeers
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 23 (AP)Roberto Clemente of the Pittsburgh Pirates was cheered last night when he made his managerial debut in the Puerto Rican winter league, but eight Innings later, after he made his first strategic move, the boos were louder than the cheers.

title: House Report on Speakers On Campus Called Blacklist
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) A Federal district judge called a House committee report on al leged radical campus speakers a blacklist today and sched uled a final decision for next week on whether to forbid its public distribution.

title: Woman,28, Is Fighting for Wydler's L.I. House Seat
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23  A diminutive, 28yearold newcomer to politics has been campaigning 20 hours a day for the last few months to convince residents of the Fourth Con gressional District that she should replace the Republican incumbent.

title: Water Monitor an Early Pollution Patent
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 An inventor of aerospace de vices has turned to pollution abatement and patented a waterquality monitor. The Colorimeter produced by Harold H. Sew and of Arlington Mass., indicates the organicmate irial content of water in munici pal supplies, rivers and treat ment plants. Patent 3,535, 044, granted this week, is one of the first to be issued under the Patent Office's program of expediting action on antipollution inventions. The application was pending a year instead 6f the aver age 29 months.

title: Film: Continuing Tale of 'I, A Woman':Interracial Sex Theme Also Gets Workout 'The Daughter' Makes It a Family Affair
description: After "Tamburlaine the Great Part I" and "Henry IV Part II" comes "I, A Woman Part III," also called "The Daughter." Whatever the relation of part to part (I never saw Part II, and I can't really remember Part I), it is impossible not to admire the tenacity of titles in this series and to look forward hopefully to the time when "She, a Woman (Part VIII)," in a last fillip of unreconstructed lust, seduces her confessor on her deathbed and thereby so traumatizes her eavesdropping great-granddaughter (a frustrated virgin of 12) that it will take a whole movie full of pot parties, Lesbian encounters and willing young men to work out her problems.I'm afraid I've given away half the surprise in Part III, except that the daughter (Inger Sundh) is 17, while "I, A Woman" (Gun Falck), is only in her mid-30's and has a wonderful healthy thing for men that only her daughter fails to appreciate. But the pot parties are there, and a lot of five-years-out-of-date go-go dancing, and the Lesbian (Ellen Faison), and the young men, the best of whom (Tom Scott) happens to be the Lesbian's brother.By one of those sleights of character in which Part III specializes, the brother falls in love with the daughter rather before first sight. All he really wants to do is marry her. But since he is black and she is frigid and this is pornography (not much) certain rituals must be recognized before brother can marry daughter and sister, who has all the best in the movie, can cast her first speculative glances at "I, A Woman."On the interracial sex question the movie clearly means to have it all four ways  finding it normal, finding it quickly, loving it, and firmly disapproving, by means of a chorus of old biddies who are never shut up. There are also contributions by the Copenhagan chapter of Hell's Angels, who hate the brother because he is black, and by Danish pacifists, who hate him because he happens to be an American.Actually, Tom Scott, who plays the brother, is the film's cutest performerlooking rather like a regenerate dark Tony Curtis. Ellen Faison is the sexiest. But neither Miss Sundh nor Miss Falck are likely to cloud your fantasy life, and Miss Sundh especially keeps pasting on her face a stupid smile that characterizes the kind of girl you may go to dirty movies to forget. Mac Ahlberg's fancy color photography, of which there is a great deal, seems mostly a way of filling time. But it does produce an opening title sequence, perhaps the longest opening title sequence in history, of exceptional decorative nuttiness. In it a naked girl voluptuously slithers and slithers, while all around her fall acres of liquid-suspended snowand for that moment (more like a half hour) "I, A Woman, Part III" looks as if Rosebud had met and mated "Cherry, Harry & Raquel.""The Daughter (I, A Woman Part III)" opened yesterday at the New Embassy and Trans-Lux 85th Street theaters.

title: Banks Activated by Giants For Game Here Tomorrow
description: Willie Banks, an offensive guard, was officially activated by the Giants yesterday for re serve duty against the St. Louis Cardinals at Yankee Sta dium tomorrow. He replaces Len Johnson, released by the Giants on Monday. Because of Pete Case's ankle Injury, Banks will be the only available re serve behind Charlie Harper (re placing Case) and Doug Van Horn.

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: Charts of Races at Aqueduct

title: Atlantic Richfield Net Off; Sales by Chain Stores Up
description: Net income of the Atlantic Richfield, Company fell 19 per cent to $43,591,000, or 77 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept: 30 from $54,112,000, or 97 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago, the company an nounced yesterday.

title: EARLY CALL URGED ON HEART ATTACK
description: The reluctance of many heart attack victims to call for help in time to save their lives has prompted a medical jour nal to urge physicians to edu cate the public to avoid delays in appeals for this type of medical assistance.

title: Coast Double Pays $1,576
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 23 (AP)  Bold and Saucy cap tured the first race for a $144.40 payoff and Getting Even paid $45.20 in the second today at the Oak Tree meeting at Santa Anita for a daily dou ble payoff of $1,576.20.

title: W. GERMAN TEAM WINS NATIONS CUP
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 The West German Equestrian Team, specialists in winning Nation's Cups in international jumping in Europe during the recent summer, brought their slick machinelike riding in doors to the Pennsylvania Na tional Horse Show tonight and got another.

title: Rendel of The Times Honored at Horse Show
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 John Rendel of The New York Times was honored to night at the Pennsylvania Na tional Horse Show, for his outstanding contributions to the sport for more than 25 years. He has covered the fixture here for two decades.

title: WorldLeaders Assess U.N. Role on 25th Anniversary
description: WorldLeaders Assess U.N. Role on 25th Anniversary

title: Hourly Flight Quota At 2 Airports Here Extended by Volpe
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)  Transportation Secre tary John A. Volpe extended today hourly landing and take off quotas for another year at four major airports, including Kennedy and LaGuardia. He said that on the average the quotas had cut traffic delays by 30 per cent.

title: TRADE UNIT OPPOSES E.E.C. TEXTILE MOVE
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 23Dele gates of the European textile industry told the European Economic Community's Execu tive Commission today that the industry was in danger of be ing squeezed out by massive, lowprice imports from Asia.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Planner Lawyer and Target
description: On the day in 1965 that John V. Lindsay announced his decision to run for Mayor of New York City, a young lawyer active in Reform Democratic politics sent him a note asking if he would like to talk with the loyal op position. The following day, as the young lawyer was helping his wife and three sons prepare for a weekend trip to their Dutchess County retreat, the telephone rang. The weekend trip was never taken. The author of the note, Donald Harrison Elliott, had been enlisted in the Lindsay campaign.

title: A Correction
description: In the obituary of Joseph Brownstone in yesterday's New York Times, he was incorrectly described as a stage manager. In recent years, Mr. Brownstone was a company managerfor, S. Hurok and other producers. He died Wednesday in Univer sity Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 50 years old.

title: Maritime Boondoggle
description: President Nixon has signed the Merchant Marine Act of 1970 with the declaration that it would have been easy for him to have simply continued the 1936 sub sidy program, but that he was determined to keep his campaign pledge to replace it with something better.

title: Rockefeller Gives Identity
description: SOLVEY N. Y., Oct. 23 Governor Rockefeller confirmed tonight that Mr. Procaccino was indeed the Unnamed per son he had referred to in his remarks yesterdayin New York City. After an appearance at a Republican, rally in this small townt near. Syracuse the Gov ernor was asked if Mr. Pro caccino was the unnamed man.

title: Cortez in International
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26Cor tez, winner of the Preis von Europa at Cologne ldst week end, will represent West Ger many in the $150,000 Washing ton. D.C. International race at Laurel Nov. 11.

title: Allende Backers Cancel Plan for Victory Celebration
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23 Followers of Dr. Salvador Allende today canceled plans to hold victory celebrations tomor row following his expected election as President of Chile.

title: NEW INFLUX HERE BY PUERTO RICANS
description: Puerto Rican families, beset by widespread unemployment on their home island, are mi grating to the mainland in rec ord numbers this year. Most have settled in New York.

title: Japanese joining Hawaii's Elite
description: HONOLULUThe April, 1889, issue of The Planters Monthly advised Hawaii's plantation owners that the Japanese readily learn the English language and habits, and snake good house, farm and plantation servants and they are provident and thrifty.

title: Art: Calder Provides a Lift as Always
description: According to a reliable in formant, they were serving the last bottles of Pommery and Greno 1962 available in New York at the Alexander Calder opening last Tuesday. This was at the Perls Galler ies, 1016 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street. Free dispensation of the princely bub bly to all corners was no doubt justified by the occa sion, but on the other hand it was unnecessary. The show Is champagne enough in itself.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SHARING ITS URANIUM SECRET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The United States is consid ering the possibility of sharing with other nations its secret technology for producing fis sionable uranium 235, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced today. It is a potential fuel for atomic reactors and an ingredient of atomic bombs.

title: For Many L.I.R. Commuters, No Trains Meant Back to Bed
description: Into the breech yesterday Morning, after the Long. Island Railroad strike, came the car pools and the rushes to the city bound buses and, since it was Friday, the decision by many to take a long weekend.

title: Sabres Beat Wings On Anderson's Goal In Third Period, 43
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 23 (AP) Ron Anderson's unassisted goal with just over six minutes left gave the Buffalo Sabres a 43 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: AMP SUES DETROIT ON SMOG DEVICES
description: A manufacturer of technical equipment filed a suit in Fed eral Court here yesterday charging the nation's major automobile companies with a conspiracy to delay and monop olize airpollutioncontrol de vices for motor vehicles.

title: IRISH COURT ACQUITS FOUR IN ARMS CASE
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 23Four de fendants, including former Fi nance Minister Charles Haughey, were acquitted today of charges that they had conspired to im port arms and ammunition ille gaily into Ireland.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: COMMENT Lions need victory to salvage slow start; cadets have played determinedly in defeat. This Lion is flexing a muscle on offense and has sights on best season since 63.

title: Cool Way Is Found to Cut Nois
description: Tons of wet earth along Riverside Drive in upper Manhattan have been frozen in an unusual engineering feat intended to spare resi dehts the noise of construc tion more than 50 feet be low the ground.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One of the most significant cate gories of jail cases pending in the Su preme Court is that of those found guilty (by plea of guilty or after trial) and awaiting sentence. On Oct. 1the day the prison riots began183 de fendants were confined to the Queens House of Detention in Kew Gardens whose cases had been pending in Queens Supreme Court for more than ninety days. Of these, 76or 36.1 per centwere awaiting sentence, many for more than six months.

title: Unveilings
description: SHANERuth. Unveiling of monument Sun day, October 25, at 2 P.M., Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N. J., Block 3, Sec tion 14.22, Blumenstock Plot. No post ponement.

title: The Boutique Business: Fun on Seventh Avenue
description: I don't know why put ting this collection together is always so much more fun than doing my regular line, Mollie Parnis told an admirer after her boutique showing this week.

title: Philip Zach, 73, ExPresident Of Capper Publications, Dead
description: Philip Zach, former presi dent of Capper Publications, Inc., and retired advertising consultant to Life magazine, died Thursday in his home at 40 Fifth Avenue. He was 73 years old.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Treasury Statement

title: BIG FOUR TO URGE MIDEAST PARLEYS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23Secretary General Thant announced tonight that the Big Four foreign ministers had agreed to exert their utmost efforts to get indirect Arab Israeli talks under way. at the earliest possible date and to work toward agreement on ex tending the Middle East cease fire.

title: Amex Stocks Post Modest Gain After 13 Lower Sessions in Row
description: After 13 straight days of de clines, the American Stock Ex change managed to register an advance yesterday. It was modest one, achieved in con tinued light volume.

description: The Cast

title: Haywood Suspended By Rockets of A.B.A. Af ter 5Day Absence
description: DENVER, Oct. 23 (AP)  Spencer Haywood, the Ameri can Basketball Association's most valuable player and rookie of the year last season, has been suspended indefinitely by the Denver Rockets, without pay, and has been fined $500 per game and $100 per practice missed, the club announced today.

title: Albatross Faces Test Tonight; Juvenile to Race Older Pacers
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 23 The $50,000 National Pac ing Derby and a $60,000 New York Sire Stakes Pace are billed as the cofeatures of tomorrow night's program at Roosevelt Raceway. These will be the fourth and sixth races on the card and each is certain to attract wide atten tion.

title: Sports of eht einto
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 23Champ, a man asked today, have you ever been scared?

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CALIFORNIASigned Billy Muffelt as minor league pitching coach. Purchased Winston Lienas, third baseman, from Hawaii of the Pacific Coast League, Randy Niles, catcher, from El Paso of the Texas League. Sent Randy Brawn, catcher; Ray Oyler, Infielder, and Harvey Shank, pitcher, to Hawaii.

title: U.S. Doubts Soviet Ouster Of Newsman Was Justified
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) The State Depart ment said today that the Soviet. Union's expulsion of John Dornberg, a correspondent of Newsweek magazine, appeared to be unjustified.

title: 2 Carriers Among 19 U.S. Ships Being Recalled From Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23Nineteen ships of the, United States Seventh Fleet, ranging from aircraft carriers to tugs, are going home from Vietnam to be retired from ac tive service, the Navy said to day.

title: One of Quadruplets Dies
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Oct. 23 (AP) The lastborn of the Hugo quadruplets, Diane, died last night, but her surviving sisters were reported holding their own. The three girls Amy, Barbara and Colleen received their first food through tubes today, two days after they were born to Mr and Mrs. Charles Hugo of Stoneham.

title: Minnesota Twins Official Is Killed in Auto Accident
description: HOUGHTON, S. D., Oct. 23 (AP)Sherry Robertson, direc tor of the Minnesota Twins farm team system, was killed today in a single car accident near here while traveling from Aberdeen, S. D., to Ashby, Minn on a hunting trio.

title: Goodell Says Comments By White House Aid Him
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 23Sen ator Charles E. Goodell fol lowed up his attack on Presi dent Nixon today, contending that White House opposition would not hurt his candidacy and might even help.

title: Agents Forced to Quit a College After Teacher Criticizes F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation has forced a group of its agents to drop out of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice because a professor there criticized the F.B.I.

title: NORTHWEST SEEKS SCOTCH IMPORTER
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., disclosed yesterday in Chicago that it was investigating the possibility that it might acquire the Buckingham Corporation, the exclusive United States im porter and selling agent for the Cutty Sark brand of Scotch whisky.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES REPORTS PROFIT DROP
description: Northeast Utilities and its operating subsidiaries reported yesterday a 7.3 per cent earn ings decline for this year's first nine months despite a gain of 8.2 per cent in operating rev enues.

title: The Third District
description: POPULATIONAbout 450, 000, predominately Italian American but with a large number of Jews and Irish. There are about 30,000 blacks, mostly in New Haven.

description: The way the brand new Arnold R. Krakower Elema tology Foundation's very first benefit, scheduled for the WaldorfAstoria Nov. 1, is shaping up, it may be hard to tell the guests from the en tertainers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meetings have been closed to the public during the anni versary session. Tours will resume tomorrow and are given 9:15 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: AMEX DISCIPLINES FIRM ON TRADING
description: The American Stock Exchange revealed yesterday that its board of governors had voted to discipline F. L. Salomon & Co. and two of its partners, Burton W. Blank and Ben jamin Marks, for violations of exchange rules in handling block transaction.

title: Quarry's Fight Plan Calls for Outslugging All
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 23Just as Muhammad Ali's effectiveness after 31/2 years of inactivity is an unknown quantity for Mon day night's heavyweight bout here, Jerry Quarry's style is equally unpredictable.

As in his novels and short stories, Petrakis combines down

description: Morning

title: 2 Challenges Received For 73 America's Cup
description: The Royal Vancouver Yacht Club of Canada and Club d'Hyeres of France have presented challenges for the America's Cup in 1973, it was announced yesterday by the New York Yacht Club.

title: COPPER PRICE CUT SPREADS RAPIDLY
description: Price reductions for copper bearing fabricated products and for the primary metal continued to spread rapidly through the industry yesterday, following cut in the basic quotation that was initiated Wednesday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: The Artist as the Enemy
description: NOW SAD, YugoslaviaTo pose the question of why a man who creates novels, songs, poems, music or paint ings is considered the potential enemy of the social system under which he lives seems strange to me. No one who lives in a totalitarian society such as, say, the Chinese or the Soviet, would ask the question. It is clear without any explanation.

title: Chapman Is 7th Driver To Gain 2,500 Victories
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 23 John Chapman, by win ning with Milan Hanover ($6.40) and Raphael ($5.20) in the second and seventh events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, became the seventh harness driver to post 2,500 victories.

title: Text of President Nixon's Address at the 25thAnniversary Session of the U.N.
description: Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General, distinguished chiefs of state and heads of government, your excellencies the foreign ministers and delegates here as sembled:

title: WILLIAM S. LADD
description: William S. Ladd Jr., a hotel and airline representative, died yesterday in Peninsula General Hospital, Edgemere, Queens, after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived at 136 Beach 138th Street, Belle Har bor, Queens.

title: Economy at Issue in Wisconsin
description: RACINE, Wisc., Oct. 22If economic problems are going to elect Democrats anywhere next month, they should certainly do so in Wisconsin's volatile First Congressional District.

title: BIG BOARD BACKS ACCOUNTING RULE
description: The senior rulemaking body of theaccounting profession, which Came under heavy at tack from the corporate com munity in connection with its overhaul of the rules governing accounting for mergers, has re ceived some powerful support for its position.

title: Saigon's Leaders, Led by Thieu, Confer on Strategy
description: VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (AP)  President Nguyen Van Thieu and South Vietnam's top military and political leaders mapped strategy today for a cease fire or a prolonged Indochina war. Gathered for an extraor dinary conference in this cpastal resort city about 40 miles southeast of Saigon, the South Vietnamese leaders discussed what actions they would take if the Viet Cong accepted President Nixon's Oct. 7 peace proposal.

title: Racial Theme Dominates South Carolina Campaign
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S. C., Oct. 21In a political year that has seen other Southern states move away from the race is sue as the central theme in election campaigns, South Car olina has remained faithful to tradition.

title: L. I. Flower Show Set
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 23 The North Shore Horticul tural Society will hold its 66th autumn flower show for five days starting Friday at the Glen Cove Neighborhood House Young Men's Chris tian Association. Proceeds will go to the House. Fred G. Luckham heads the show committee. Admission $1.

title: Vandals Damage L.I. School
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., Oct. 23 Damage estimated at $150,000 was caused early today by fires and vandalism in the West Islip Junior High School.

title: Chrysler Recalls 6,366 Cars
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation re called today 6,366 Dodge Darts and Plymouth Valiants, all 1970 models, for inspection and re placement, if necessary, of the front primary brake linings. A company spokesman told the National Highway Safety Bu reau that only a few vehicles would need the linings replaced.

title: STOCKS UP A BIT ON LIGHT VOLUME
description: Strength in glamour Issues provided the chief feature yes terday to a generally firm stock market.

title: Songs by Raphael at His Debut Display Concentrated Precision
description: Raphael Martos Sanchez is a slight, roundfaced, 24year old singer from Spain who is known professionally as Ra phael. As he steps out on the stage at Royal Box at the Americana Hotel, where he is making his New York night club debut, he seems an ami able, winsome boy.

title: Women Who Can Hypnotize
description: People kept asking me, are you one or those? Mrs. Lillian Warren, a psychiatric nurse from Napa, Calif., said yesterday, holding her hands in front of her face stiffly and wiggling her fingers.

title: After Nasser: Increased Turmoil
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 23 Toothy and confident, the face of Gamal Abdel Nassel still grins down from thousands of posters here and in other Arab capitals.

title: Miss Anderson, J. P. Meyer Wed
description: Miss Joanna Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Anderson of Corn wall, England, and John Paul Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Meyer of New York and Bedford Village, N. Y., were married yester day in, a civil ceremony at the registrar's office at Pad dington in London.

title: Another Round With Agnew
description: The Vice President, Mr. Agnew, pro poses that network commentators, like this one and brothers Smith and Reynolds down the street at ABC people of that type, he saysbe pub licly examined by government person nel. The public has a right to know, he says, our opinions and prejudices.

title: Antiques: Sideboard for and by Phyfe
description: The sideboard Duncan Phyfe made for his own homein the Empire, not the socalled Duncan Phyfe stylehas just been put on exhibition in the entrance of the Museum of the City of New York.

title: FANNY MAY PLANS ISSUE NEXT WEEK
description: The Federal National Mort gage Association announced yesterday that it would offer $750million of debentures next Wednesday.

title: CELTICS CONQUER ROYALS BY 131126
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Don Nelson capped a comeback With a 3point play that broke a tie with 14 seconds left to nigh as the Boston Celtics posted a 131126 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

title: Nixon Moves to Open Data on Consumer Products
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon plans to order next week new steps to make public information the Govern ment collects on a wide variety of consumer products.

description: Roosevelt Entries

title: Women of Federation to Hold A Donor Luncheon at Pierre
description: Guests who contribute a minimum of $700 will attend the 50th anniversary lunch eon for advance gifts donors of the women's organization of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York at the Pierre Tuesday.

title: Union Leaders Divided On Issues Behind Strike
description: Yesterday's 4 A.M. shut down of, the Long Island Rail road appeared to be rooted in a long record of success by unions in winning concessions from the L.I.R. through well timed job actions, the 1966de cision that brought the line under the same political um brella as the New York Transit Authority and a farreaching agreement last June 27 that was aimed at bringing labor peace to the line.

description: The CastThe CastThe CastThe Cast

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York and Ameri can Stock Exchanges have issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of their listed com panies. The lists include the following:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY ISRAELIS WILL GET 180 MODERN TANKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The United States has agreed to provide Israel with about 180 modern tanks as part of almost $500million in assistance de signed to maintain the balance of power in the Middle East, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Marcia Munro And Clergyman To Be Married
description: Miss Marcia Munro and the Rev. Ronald. Bruce MacLen nan, pastor of St. Mark's Lutheran Church in Atchison, Kan., plan to be married here next June.

title: Goldberg Kennedy Men Give State Party Rare Unity
description: Although he is not general ly identified as a Kennedy brand politician, Arthur J. Goldberg's gubernatorial cam paign organization is essen tially a Kennedy operation.

title: Campaign Gets Rougher
description: Arthur J. Goldberg was try ing to make a point about changing state labor laws last Wednesday during a guheina torial debate at The New York Times when Gdvernor Rockefeller suddenly cut him off with a curt What would you do? Cancel all laws?

title: Firecrackers Stir Fears A.s Nixon Enters the U.N.
description: A string of firecrackers thrown from a window in the United Nations Plaza apart ments resounded like a volley of small arms fire yesterday as President Nixon stepped from his car to enter the General Assembly Building.

title: The Esthetic Realms of Redon's Art
description: Odilon Redon (18401916) is one of the most mysteri ous figures in the history of the postimpressionist paint ing in France. His art seems to occupy two very distinct esthetic realmsthe fantas tic and the naturalisticand to dwell in each of them with equal conviction and in tensity. As a graphic artist especially, he looks inward, to the world of dreams and the macabre, yet as a painter and particularly in the medium of the pastelhe turned late in life to a series of enchanting, lyrical flower pictures that bring to the direct observation of nature a beguiling poetry and charm.

title: A Suburb of Detroit Sues to Block Census Figures
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23 (UPI)  Suburban Woodhaven has be come the first city in Michigan, and one of the first in the na tion, to sue the Census Bureau to stop publication of 1970 census figures.

title: Cyclone Strikes Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 23  An 80mileanhour cyclone lashed Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan, and areas of Chittagong, Barisal and Khulna on the Bay of Bengal today. There was no immediate esti mate of injuries or damage.

title: Montreal Election Opposed
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Parti Quebecois, a separat ist party, demanded today that the Quebec provincial govern ment cancel the Montreal city election scheduled for. Sunday because of the climate of pan ic provoked by the events of the past two weeks.The party, which seeks inde pendence for Quebec through peaceful means, said the politi cal atmosphere of the province had been made so tense by separatist terror and the accu sations of politicians that the election would be a farce.

title: A SURPRISE STRIKE SHUTS DOWN L.I.R. FOR MOST OF DAY
description: A strike by three unions shut down the Long Island Railroad for 10 hours yesterday.

title: PRISONER KILLED IN CELL IN TOMBS
description: An inmate of the Tombs was found dead in his cell yester day morning, and his cellmate, until recently a patient in the Matteawan State Hospital, for the Criminal Insane, said that he had killed him.

title: Suspect Is Seized Near Scene of Coast Slayings
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 23  Two deputy sheriffs cap tured early today the 24year old man sought since yesterday in the killing of five persons at a mountaintop mansion five miles south of here.

title: ASTRONOMERS GET SPACE DUST DATA
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 23An American astronomical satellite has returned data in dicating that interstellar dust seems to have a high carbon content and that comets are enveloped in clouds of hy drogen larger than the sun.

title: CHILD'S BODY FOUND IN VERMONT VILLAGE
description: DORSET, Vt., Oct. 23The body of a child was found in this small westcentral Ver mont hamlet this afternoon and there was immediate spec ulation that it might be that of 5yearold Leah Sarachik, who had been the object of a search in Vermont since she was re ported missing from her New York City home Sept. 10.

title: PENN CENTRAL ROLE IN AIR TAXI CITED
description: New light will be shed on the manner in which the Penn Central Transportation Com pany's management spent the railroad's time and money be fore it went into bankruptcy reorganization on June 21.

title: Action. Not Atmospherics
description: President Nixon's challenge to the Soviet Union to build detente by a series of actions, not just a super ficial change in atmosphere, voices publicly the deep concern stirred in the West by Moscow's recent power moves. The central question raised by Russia's baffling behavior, which Mr. Nixon and Secretary Rogers evidently have put to Foreign Minister Gromyko, now has been laid before the forum of world opinion at the United Nations.

title: RECORD PRODUCER REJECTED MANSON
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23A young record producer testi fied today that he once au ditioned Charles M. Manson as a singerguitarist and that he wasn't impressed enough to want to make a record.

title: FRANK GAMINO
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 23 (AP)Frank A. Gamtnino, pres ident of the M. A. Gammino Construction Company and chairman of the board of. Co lumbus National, Bank, died, at the Jane Brown Hospital here today. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. Gold Stock Fell Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The United States gold stock declined by $323 million last month to $11.49 billion, the Treasury reported today. The drop in September follows a net decline of $117million in August.

title: Gas Import Is Authorized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Federal Power Commis sion has authorized the Ten nessee Gas Pipeline Company to import 30 billion cubic feet of Canadian natural gas, pay ing TransCanada Pipelines, Ltd., 42 cents per thousand feet.

title: WLIB, Off the Air Because of Strike, Goes to Court
description: Thirtysix staff members or radio station WLIB, who walk ed out last week in support of a discharged employe, have been ordered to appear in court on Tuesday to answer charges that their action violated union contracts.

title: NEW HAVEN PANTHER FREE ON PROBATION
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23 George Edwards, one of the 14 Black Panthers charged in the death of Alex Rackley, was given two suspended prison sentences today and released on probation.

title: NIXON, AT THE U.N., BIDS MOSCOW KEEP RIVALRY PEACEFUL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23President Nixon ap pealed to the Soviet leaders today to join with the United States in keeping the competi tion between their countries peaceful despite very profound and fundamental differences.

title: BOARD PROPOSES SCHOOL BUDGET
description: The Board of Education yes terday proposed a $765million school construction program, but the city budget makers re sponded by calling for better utilization of some unfilled schools.

title: 2YEAROLD COLT TRIUMPHS BY NECK
description: Moments after Epic Journey made a $46.80for$2 splash in his racing debut at Aqueduct yesterday, a chalkplayer saw the light.

title: Bridge:
description: A world record that is un likely to be broken soon will be set today at the New York Hilton Hotel in the Open Pair Championship at the Greater New York Bridge Associa tion's Metropolitan Tourna ment.

title: Ford Deliveries Up 7% for Oct. 1120; Industry Fell 23%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23  The Ford Motor Company said to day its dealers delivered 71, 466 Americantype cars Oct. 11. 20, up 7 per cent from 66,609 sold a year ago.

title: HOSPITAL AGENCY GETS RATE RELIEF
description: The New York Telephone Company has canceled a pro posed rate increase for the Health and Hospitals Corpora tion that eventually would have cost the city an addition al $600,000 a year, according to a spokesman for the corpo ration.

title: Grain Futures Rise On Short Covering In Spirited Trading
description: A strong demand, supple mented by short covering, sent soybean, corn and wheat futures higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: NETS TOP COUGARS IN BARRY'S DEBUT
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 23Rick Barry made his debut in a New York uniform before 2,228 fans at Island Garden tonight and helped the Nets down the Carolina Cou gars, 11797.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Japan and U.S. to Reopen Talks on Textile Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23A top Japanese business leader disclosed today that Japan and the United States had agreed to reopen negotiations on the intensely controversial question of Japanese textile exports to the United States.

title: SAMSON FRANCOIS, CONCERT PIANIST
description: PARIS, Oct. 23Samson Francois, the French pianist, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 46 years old.

title: Shoestrings of the 50's Still Timeless in Revival
description: The Equity Library Thea ter occasionally revives a big musical by cutting it down to size. For its first production this seasonrun ning through Nov. 1the E.L.T. has revived a small musical; or rather a com pilation from a series of small musicals, Ben Bagley's Shoestring Revues, on the stage at the Master Theater.

title: L. R. Petta Weds Mrs. Rasmussen
description: Mrs. Fontaine Rasmussen, daughter of Robert V. Ras mussen of Palm Beach, Fla., and Antioch, Ill., retired chairman of the board of the National Tea Company of Chicago, was married Mon day in Elkton, Md., to Lewis R. Petta, a specialist on the American Stock Exchange here. The civil ceremony was performed in the Elkton Courthouse.

title: Lutherans and Catholics Called Closer
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 23 Roman Catholic and Lutheran theology are on a con vergence course, the new president of the 2.6million member American Lutheran Church said here today.

title: ITALIAN GOVERNMENT OUTFLANKS ITS FOES
description: ROME, Oct. 23Premier Emilio Colombo's Government today circumvented a parlia mentary filibuster that threat ened its antiinflation policy and its very future.

title: L.I. MAN IS GUILTY OF KILLING HIS WIFE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 23 A Long Island clothing execu tive, Jay T. Pobliner, was found guilty late tonight of first degree murder in the slaying of his wife, Brenda, in their Men; rick home In 1968.

title: WPIX Concedes Some Distortions
description: Leavitt Pope, vice president for operations at WPIX and, by his own statement, the sta tion's officer primarily con cerned with this matter, said yesterday that an investigation of allegations of news distor tion had turned up five in stances of misuse of news film or reports during 1968 and 1969.

title: Quebec Issues 3 New Warrants in Kidnapping
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (Reu ters)The Quebec police to night issued three more war rants for men wanted for the kidnapping of the Quebec Min ister of Labor and Immigration, Pierre Laporte, murdered a week ago by members of the extremist Front for the Libera tion of Quebec.

title: School Concerts to Resume
description: The 15th season of New School Concerts at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, will begin tomorrow with per formances at 2 P.M and 8 P.M. by a chamber orchestra con ducted by Alexander Schneider.

title: DEMOCRAT FEARS SURE LOSS IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Democratic party is in such critical financial straits that it may virtually forfeit the 1972 Presidential election before the campaign begins, Joseph A. Califano Jr., general counsel to the Democratic Na tional Committee, said today.

title: HANOI PREDICTS U.S. WILL EXTEND WAR
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)A North Vietnamese commentator predicted today that President Nixon would intensify and ex tend the Vietnam war once next month's congressional elections in the United States were out of the way.

title: Troops Collect Rubbish Piled in London Strike
description: LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 24 (Reuters)The Govern ment moved troops into Lon don's East End early today to remove rubbish that has piled up during a garbage collectors strike.

title: Korean Reds Accused
description: PANMUNJON, Koreo, Oct. 23 (AP)The United Nations Command accused North Korea today of 24 infiltrations and unprovoked shootings across Korea's demilitarized zone since Sept. 8 and said that 19 armed North Korean agents had been in the grave incidents. Maj. Gen. Felix M. Rogers, of the United States, the senior United Nations Command representa tive in the Korean Armistice Commission, charged that through the deliberate and unprovoked violations of the armistice agreement, the North Korean. Government was in reality attacking South Korea.

description: Aqueduct Entries

title: GEORGE A. WELSH, FEDERAL JUDGES 92
description: MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 23Judge George A. Welsh of the Federal Court of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania and a former Rep resentative, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 92.

title: Buckley Is Optimistic
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 24Mr. Buckley said today that he was confident of win ning the election on Nov. 3.

title: Other College Games on Today's Card
description: Horn, teams are listed first.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Administrative. The Presi dent announced the appoint ment of three members of the Council of the Adminis trative Conference of the United States. The appoint ees, for terms of three years, are Charles David Albard, of Alexandria, Va., who re places Rosel H. Hyde; Wil liam H. Rehnquist of Phoenix, Ariz., who replaces Leonard Marks; Harold Louis Russell of Atlanta, who is being re appointed. The purpose of the conference is to develop improvements in the legal procedures by which Federal agencies fix the rights and obligations of private per sons and businesses through agency adjudication, rule making and investigating proceedings.

title: TYPHOON DEATH TOLL 1,109 IN PHILIPPINES
description: DAVAO, the Philippines, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  The Philippine Red Cross said today that 1,109 people were killed by two ty phoons that struck the country in the last 10 days and that 522,000 had been made home less.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: Washington High to Stay Closed to Pupils Monday
description: George Washington High School will be closed to stu dents again on Monday, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

title: NEW ARM PLAY IS STAGED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 23Jean Anouilh's latest drama, Ne Reveillez pas Madame, which, opened at the Comedie des ChampsElysees last night, has a Maughamish trait themati cally. It is a sardonic study of human bondage, and, though its scene is the theater, it is only on the surface a theater play.

title: Agnew Calls Lindsay Conglomerate
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23Vice President Agnew called Mayor Lindsay of New York our po litical conglomerate here to night. He also criticized the Mayor and others who have defended draft resisters.

title: Quicken Tree, Star Racer, Dies After Surgery on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI)Quicken Tree, one of the nation's leading distance racing horses, died last night at Santa Anita from complica tions that followed surgery for removal of a bone chip.

title: Saks Outlet Set for Houston
description: Gimbel' Brothers, Inc., said yesterday It had acquired a 10 acre site in Houston for the construction of a Saks Fifth Avenue store. Bruce A. Gimbel, president, said the store; to be built near the intersection of South Post Oak Road and San Felipe Drive, mould be the first Saks Fifth Avenue store in the Southwest.

title: Quick Test of Penicillin Allergy Reported to Be Highly Reliable
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Years of research into the na ture of penicillin allergy has led to a promising quick test to predict severe bad reactions to that widely used drug. Presently available tests are not considered very depend able.

title: DAVIS LEADS WAY INTO PINS FINALS
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23 Sixty games after play began last Monday, the stage finally has been set for tomorrow's televised finals of the $75,000 National championship of the Professional Bowlers Associa tion.

description: Entertainment Events

title: Tankers Collide Off England
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Saturday, Oct. 24 (Reuters) At least one seaman was re ported dead and 12 others were missing early today after a col lision between two oil tankers off the Isle of Wight on Eng land's south coast.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: In Canada's West, Crisis Measures Are Questioned
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Oct. 23 A week after the imposition of war time emergency powers, seri ous questions are being raised here about the long term implications of the Government's decision on political life in Canada.

title: BunkerRamo Terminal
description: The BunkerRamo Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had developed a new low cost cathoderay tube data ter minal that would rent for $39 a month. The machine is said to be compatible with all exist ing data processing systems.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRENOWITZSonl. Darlino, 1.year today we miss you so. The shock was sudden and severe to part with Son we loved so dear. Rest In peace. Mom, Norman, Lorraine, Alan. Randy, Stacy and Rena.

title: 4,000 Students at Kent State Assemble in Quiet Protest Rally
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 23  Some 4,000 students at Kent State University gathered on the Commons today for a quiet noon rally to protest the find ings of a special state grand jury a week ago. All regular) classes were held today.

title: Gary Player's 136 Leads By 4 Strokes in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 23 (UPI)Gary Player carded five birdies and an eagle today for a sevenunderpar 65 to gain a fourstroke lead at 136 over Dave Marr, a former Pro fessional Golfers Association champion, midway in the $16, 000 Australian open golf cham pionship.

title: Walinsky Aide Gets An Eyeful of His Boss
description: Adam Walinsky, the Demo cratic candidate for Attorney General, was late for his first scheduled campaign appear ance in Syracuse yesterday because the candidate's con tact lenses were swallowed by his campaign manager.

title: Strike at Arsenal Ends
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Ravenna Arsenal, one of the largest ammunition manufacturing operations in the nation, reopened today after settlement of a three week strike. Members of United Steelworkers of America Local 4581 began returning to work last night. The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company operates the facility under a Defense De partment contract.

title: 2 Birth Pills Discontinued After Tests Made on Dogs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Two brands of birth control pills are being discontinued be cause certain of their chemi cal constituents appear to be linked with breast changes in dogs.

title: Money
description: Money

title: North Vietnam Will Receive More Soviet Arms and Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP) The Soviet Union has agreed to provide North Vietnam with additional military and eco nomic assistance. Tass, the So viet press agency, reported to day.

title: Joffrey Puts Off Premiere
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet will not present a fourth new production during its current season at the City Center. The premiere, which has been post poned until next season, was to have taken place on Wednes day.

title: N.C.A.A. Football
description: N.C.A.A. Football

title: Wichita State Starts Long Road Back
description: Marvin Kellum has never played an organized game of 11man football. Eight man, yes. Ragtag, sure. But round his hometown of Lecompton, Kan. (pop. 600), it was difficult enough finding 11 players for two teams.

title: LOUGHERY'S SHOT BREAKS LATE TIE
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 23  An almost complete lack of scoring by the New York backcourt in the second half, coupled with a tenaciously effective defen sive effort by Baltimore, gave the Bullets a 9892 victory over the Knicks tonight in a typi cally hardfought contest be tween the teams at Civic Center.

title: Prudence on the Mideast
description: In his address to the United Nations, President Nixon was prudently sparing in his references to the inflamed Middle East situation. Warning of the disastrous con sequences of any new conflict there, he appealed to the Russians to conduct themselves so as to strengthen the forces of peace rather than to strengthen the forces of war.

title: SAMMARTINO WINS WRESTLING FEATURE
description: Bruno Sammartino, weighing in at 265 pounds, rallied after being thrown from the ring three times to defeat Bepo Mongol, 315, after 14 minutes 30 seconds in a Texasstyle wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night. Six weeks ago in the same ring, Mongol won on a technicality from Sammartino.

title: MRS. BASCOM TIMMONS

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 United States officials said to day that they were studying Jordan's economic needs, but that no decisions had been reached pending receipt of pre cise estimates from the Amman authorities.

title: Scores on WQXR

title: A Call for U.N. Reform
description: Nothing could mere perfectly state the attitude of the United Nations to any criticism of its operations, or lack of them. In a world whose every signi ficant institution has been challenged by public protest, this body has as sumed a position of immunity. General.

title: How Tough Is S.E.C.?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Does the Securities and Exchange Commission really intend to draw a line, rigidly, right here? That is the first, but only the very first, question that is raised by the S.E.C.'s an nouncement yes ter da.y approving in part but disap proving in more significant part the commissionrate increases on stock transactions that were proposed by the New York Stock Exchange last July. If the commission chooses to take its stand and negotiate no fur ther, there is little doubt that it has the power to force its wishes on the brokerage busi ness. It could almost certainly win in any legal proceeding the exchange forced it into, for the courts rarely overturn the decisions of regulators unless they are plainly arbitrary or out of conformity with the law. Of more immediate conse quence is the fact that the S.E.C. has a club to force com pliance with its wishes. If the exchange refuses to ratify the new commissionrate structure, the S.E.C. can simply revoke the special surcharge on or ders of 1,000 shares or less that has been in effect since May and is permitted on a till revoked basis.

title: Daylight Time to End At 2 A.M. Tomorrow
description: Daylight saving time comes to an official end for this year at 2 A.M. tomorrow, when standard time returns for six months.

title: Market Place:
description: You've heard the sad story of the disillusioned customer and the one about the hard pressed customer's man. But you may not have heard the lament of the small broker age house, struggling to make a profit against the combined forces of bear markets, backoffice mixups and customer perfidy.

title: Houston's KPFT, Two Bombs Later, Tries to Rebuild

title: The New Shows
description: THE ROTHSCHILDS, a musical by Jerry Bock, Sheldon Har nick and Sherman Yellen, got favorable reviews from five critics, mixed from three, and unfavorable from three. Clive Barnes: I think The Roths childs will give a lot of pleas ure to a lot of people. It has geniality rather than incan descence, there are showstop ping performances rather than showstopping numbers, and the structure of the show lacks that simple sweep of action more often than not a pre requisite of a hit musical. Yet it is interesting, in parts very witty, has a certain moral force and best of all, it has style. The story is based on Frederic Morton's biography The Rothschilds, and it is one of the musical's clearest successes that you are really made to care for the outcome of a story that is never for a moment in doubt. Mr. Bock's music makes a neat nod in the direction of the 18th century, but blends period pastiche with a gentler, more cultivated version of those Jewish folk melodies that were so success ful in Fiddler on the Roof. The lyrics also have style and a lot of gusto. The cast is a delight. Hal Linden's Mayer Rothschild is one of the best musical performances now on Broadway. The Rothschilds is a good and solid start to the musical season.

title: In Brief
description: A book for ardent Laurentians only. The years 19201929 marked a happy congruence of interests on the part of Law rence and Scofield Thayer, the editor most responsible for the revitalization of The Dial during the twenties. Lawrence, hound ed as he was by a brutal critical reception in England, the cen sors and his own stunning inner torments, was ready for Amer ica in every sense. Thayer, on the other hand, with his limit less financial resources, utter contempt for censors and dis tinctive empathy for Lawrence's artistic principles, was more than anxious to bring Lawrence into what was to be the most distinguished American literary review of the period. Lawrence was no small part of that achievementsome 30 pieces of his were published by Thay er and successive editors in the review. Messrs. Joost and Sulli van have drawn a full portrait of Lawrence's tempestuous re lations with such figures as Ma bel Dodge Luhan, Compton Mackenzie, T. S. Eliot, Conrad Aiken and Marianne Moore among others, and have disen tangled, as the scrupulous de tectives of literature that they are, the labyrinthian complexi ties (both contractual and per sonal) of the world of the avant garde magazine in the twenties.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Stanley Cohen's Oct. 4 review of The Supermarket Trap be moans author Jennifer Cross's admitted bias on behalf of the consumer. Your reviewer may well have chosen to present the other side of the mixupbut surely he should confess his bias for big business. Or, at least, a lack of understanding of governmental procedures, when he assumes that a busi nessgovernment cartel was behind the Penn Central failure. I'll admit that Government as a business makes horrendous mistakes. But is business so far behind?

title: Agnew Divides Missouri City's Voters
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo.Mr. and Mrs. William Cannon were out for a Sunday stroll when a re porter asked them what they thought of Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Five turbulent years as mistress of the White House
description: With the notable exceptions of Eleanor Roosevelt and Jacqueline Kennedy, the wives of American Presidents in living memory have not been excep tional women. In turn gracious, homey, amiable, spunky, hollow or diffident, their public images have shared the kind of blandness that insures public approval and inclusion in the Most Admired List of American Women. As hostesses and home makers for husbands of immense power, what glow they have had derived more from their position than their personality. To be the wife of an Amer ican President is surely glory enough.

title: Pitt Vanquishes Miami, 2817, Capitalizing on Foe's Mistakes

title: U.S. Adopts the Bumps, Jumps, Grinds and Twists of Europe's MotoCross Races

title: Capital Hill: Staffs at Work
description: WASHINGTONThe capi tol is quiet. The Senators and Representatives have moved their rhetoric from the halls of Congress to cam paign platforms and banquet halls across the country, and most will not return to Wash ington until after next month's national election.

title: Women Are Thwarted At Harvard Lampoon
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP)Any women's lib eration changes have been balked, until 1972 at least, at the doors of the allmale Harvard Lampoon, the uni versity's oldest and largest humor magazine.

title: Alerrill: His Silver Bowl Runneth Over
description: IN Robert Merrill's autobiography, written five years ago after 20 years as an outstanding baritone with the Metropolitan Opera, he said, Most firms give you a gold watch and your walking papers after 20 years. I'm just beginning to warm up. Next Saturday nighton stage at the Met between the third and fourth actr of a gala performance of La Tra viatt. Merrill will get a 25year award from 's firm. Rudolf Bing and Lowell Wadrnoh chairman of the board of the'Metrop'Mtan Opera Association, will present him with a silver bowl.

title: Michigan State Aide Named
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 24 (AP)A former University of Kansas basketball star, No len M. Ellison, 29 years old, has been named special assistant to the president of Michigan State University, Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr. Mr. Ellison has been on the Michigan State staff since 1968 and was asso ciate director of its center for urban affairs.

title: Colonels Down Condors
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP)  The Kentucky Colonels, with Dan Issel scoring 31 points, beat Pittsburgh, 138120, in an American Basketball As sociation game tonight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: About nothing and everything, which is nothing
description: Alfred Andersch's Efraim's Book is a novel about nothing. But unlike the many novels published every day purporting to be about something while actually being about nothing, Andersch's challenging novel intends to be about nothing: the great spirit ual lassitude that descends on the protagonist, the nothingness on which his and the world's intentions seem to debouch. It is like everything human, imperfect an imperfect noth ingness, shot through with little striv ings, fledgling hopes, aborted possi bilities. There is, in short, life in it, but a life governed by chance: with out any design other than accidental, and thus unsatisfactory to the dis criminating spiritas good as noth ing.

title: Harvard Study Calls Emotional Illness Major Cause of Dropouts
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 A 10year followup study of 1,454 undergraduates who had dropped out of Harvard has found that emotional illness was the major cause of dropping out and that nearly a third of these intellectually gifted youths never went on to obtain college degrees anvwhere.

title: Acquittal of Dublin ExMinister May Bring Government Crisis
description: WEXFORD, Ireland, Oct. 24 The tormenting issue of the di vision between the Irish Repub lic and Northern Ireland is back in the center of Dublin politics, with all its potential for violence, both north and south.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS $225BILLION LIMIT FOR 72 SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 24The Nixon Administration has set a spending ceiling of $225billion for the budget now in prepara tion for the fiscal year 1972. But it already looks as though the ceiling is going to be breached.

title: Late Surge Helps White Plains Overwhelm New Rochelle, 240
description: After being held to a first quarter field goal of 23 yards by Rick Rooke, White Plains scored three touchdowns in the fourth period to defeat New Rochelle, 240, and win ithe Westchester Interscholas tic Athletic Conference Big Three championship.

title: American Airlines Set For 4Abreast Seating
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)  American Airlines said yesterday it was re luctantly entering the seat war and would offer its passengers fourabreast seat ing on coach flights, unless the Civil Aeronautics Board made a decision.

title: Ann Dodds Is Wed To R. N. Costello
description: Miss Ann Margaret Dodds, a public relations adviser for the Health Services Admin istration of New York City, was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard Neu mann Costello, an account supervisor for the Ogilvy & Mather Advertising Agency.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: TOLEDO, SpainWe are sitting in the shade on Zocodover Square, midway through our day in Toledo, taking a break from its churches and its art, and now we want to look at the people. My companion remarks that they seem at peace with themselves and the world. They don't, in other words, show tell tale signs of living under relentless totalitarian rule.

title: VIRGINIA DEFEATS W. AND M. BY 336
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Zill Troup, a quarterback, threw a 75yard touchdown pass to Joe Smith, an end on Virgina's first play of the game today and the Cav valiers romped to a 336 victory over William and Mary. It was Virginia's third victory in a row.

title: E. S. WITKOWSKI, OF TRAVEL FIRM
description: Edward S. Witkowski, a lead er in PolishAmerican activities and former president of the E. S. Witkowski & Co., a travel bureau at 130 East Seventh Street, died yesterday in Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx. He was 85 years old and lived at 1215 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: The disasters of love, sexual and otherwise
description: There are as we know, other writers in America besides Joyce Carol Oates, but it sometimes seems as if they're all fighting a losing battle for attention in the face of her terrifying ubiquity and boundless clat. At 32 Miss Oates has published four long novels, three long volumes of stories and two of poetry, has had a play produced and another on the way, and is at work on a new novel. She has won dozens of literary prizes, including the National Book Award for her last novel, Them, and is talked about increasingly in language ordinarily reserved for the assured and unmistakable heroes of our cul ture. To express any doubts about her work would seem to be so rash and ungracious as to amount to an act of Iese majeste.

title: In Japan's Holy of Holies
description: KOYA, JapanAs I stood before the temple of Shojoshinnin on Mount Koya, 3,000 feet above the sea, a young monk bowed low in welcome. A black robe covered his white gown and a golden emblem on the official stole proclaimed his priestly office. Although he spoke no English, he managed to convey the fact that I was expected and my room was ready.

title: Ellen Rosenbaum Is Prospective Bride
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 24The engagement of Miss Ellen Terry Rosenbaum to James Nathan Ellowitch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon H. Ellowitch of Springfield and Hallandale, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosenbaum.

title: Glen Cove Trounced, 308, as Winners Approach Title
description: Levittown Division and Carle Place, owners of Nassau Coun ty's two longest winning streaks, continued to head for a playoff showdown with smashing victories yesterday.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP)M. Stanton Evans, editor of the Indianapolis News, was named Tuesday as the National Man agement Association's free en terprise writer of the year. Mr. Evans is a contributing editor and regular colunist for the.

title: Wool and Whisky Warm the Hebrides
description: STORNOWAY, Scotland Och, you don't want to take a taxi, said the girl at the front desk of my hotel here in the capital of the Isle of Lewis in Scotland's Outer Hebrides. They charge 40 shillings [$4.80] each way.
