description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 24 Lieut. Robert Iverson, chief of the identification bureau of the state police here, said today that he was certain that the body of the child found yester day in the town of Dorset was that of Leah Sarachik, the 5 yearold girl reported missing from her Manhattan home since Sept. 10.

J., Oct. 24The engagement of Miss JeanneNicole Ledoux, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Pierre Ledoux of Cornwall onHudson, N.Y., and Engle wood, to Kenneth Huntington Chase was announced today at a cocktail party and buf fet given by her parents at their home here. title: Stamps
description: THE proliferation of post age stamp issuesap proximately 5,000 a year in recent years has swelled catalogues to nearbursting, making them cumbersome, weighty vol umes. This weightiness, and the recognition that stamp collectors are growing in numbers, has forced cata logue publishers to new think on their difficulties, and has created a break through in some recent ef forts. Among these have been: 1] A colorful abridged United States catalogue every stamp is in colorfrom Scott Publishing Company, which was recently acquired by Duane Hillman, head of a printing firm in Omaha, Neb., in association with Har mer, Rooke & Company, New York.

title: Winds of Change at Harvard BSchool
description: BOSTONOne of the new er species of Harvard M.B.A. candidates, a smallboned brunette who's trying to sensitize the management of Consolidated Edison in New York to the problems of women and blacks, looked across the Charles River to ward the Harvard Yard and its undergraduate rebels. If we had their spirit and our organization, she sighed.

title: McGrath Beats Davis, 226222, With 3 Closing Strikes to Win Pro Bowling
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I. Oct. 24 Mike McGrath, whose record for consistency is unmatched by any other professional bowl er, went to the paymaster's window once again today, this time as the repeat winner of the $75,000 National Champion ship of the Professional Bowl ers Association.

title: Letters: Pricing A Stateside Safari
description: To THE EDITOR: The cost of A LongHaired Safari (Travel Section, Oct. 4) for two people out for six weeks, driving 11,400 miles, was stated by authors Stock and Gordon to be about $650. They sound like couple of spendthrifts to me. Three of us (father, girl of 16, boy of 14) were out on a similar trip this summer for nine weeks, went 10,800 miles, and managed on $750. And we really didnt scrimp.

description: Tony Regalbuto scored three goals in leading New York State Maritime College to a 53 soccer victory over Man hattan on the Maritime field at Fort ??? in the Bronx.

But as Mayor of Hartford, by far the district's largest city, Ann Uccello, his Republican opponent, is better known, and most observers see the contest as a close one.

title: Sinkhole Engulfs Man
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Oct. 24 (Reuters)A man sitting on the veranda of a goldmine company's tennis club disappeared down a sink hole that suddenly opened be neath him today.

title: Explorations In Freedom
description: One of the more unsettling effects of the Cold War has been the dispersion of whole cultures by exile and the silenc ing of those who stay by cen sorship and simple political pressures. Kultura, a literary review founded in 1947 in Paris by the Polish publisher and edi tor Jerzy Giedroyc along with the publishing house Institut Litteraire, has effectively rem edied this loss of center by es tablishing an underground on both sides of the Iron Curtain for the publication of what otherwise would be unpublish ablepostwar Polish writing, works by Andrey Sinyaysky, Yuri Daniel, losif Brodsky among otherseverything that the socialist literary establish ment would not touch.

title: Foe Says Turkey's Premier. Is Heading for a Disaster
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 24 Premier Suleyman Demirel, who has ruled Turkey for the last five years, is floating on a wave of selfconfidence that, his en emies say, is about to crash him onto the political reefs.

title: CLASSES OFFERED TO V. A. HOSPITALS
description: The city Board of Education has offered to set up special educational programs for hos pitalized veterans of the war in Vietnam.

title: TRADE TALKS SET BY NIXON AND SATO
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 President Nixon and Premier Eisaku Sato formally agreed today to resume negotiations on voluntary restraints on tex tile exports to this country by Japanese industry.

title: Louisiana State Upsets Auburn, 179, Handing Tigers First Loss of Season
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 24 (AP)  A fumble, a pass interference penalty and a tough defense gave Louisiana State two touch downs and a 179 upset vic tory over Auburn's previously unbeanten football team today.

title: Dr. Gladys Hodges, Teacher Of the Mentally Retarded
description: Dr. Gladys Couth Hodges, a pioneer in the use of music in teaching the mentally retarded, did in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. She was 79 years old and lived at 144 West 80th Street.

title: He outraged people while convincing them
description: This is the second volume of a soft of autobiography of George Bernard Shaw made up entirely of Shaw's own words welded together by an ingen ious editor. I say sort of be cause what results is not really Shaw's story of his own life, but G.B.S. talking about his ideas, picking up and playing with particular episodes from his experiences in the theater, in politics, during World War I, on a visit to the U.S.S.R., and prophesying, propagandiz ing, jesting, boasting, in the way we all know so well. It is a little disconcerting some times to recognize a substan tial passage from a preface to one of the plays and see it merging into something writ ten, say, 20 years later. Stanley Weintraub is aware of the prob lem: Since some parts of the memoir were written as late as Shaw's last years, the gen eral perspective must be that of G.B.S. looking at history from his nineties,  an angle of vi sion maintained in places with some strain since his references to contemporaries long passed from the scene by the fifth decade of the 20th century were in some cases written as early as 1898.

title: Rustin Assails Nixon Policies
description: President Nixon's economic policies may have caused morn harm to black Americans than the Administration's reaction ary racial policies, Bayard Rustin said yesterday, according co United Press International. Mr. Rustin a civil rights strate gist who mobilized the 1963 march on Washington, said in his weekly column for Negro newspapers that the two over riding issues for black voters this year were the racial andl economic policies of the Nixon Administration.

title: Dr. Toll Weds Miss Taintor
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Oct. 24The marriage of Miss Deborah Taintor, a free lance writer and editor, to Dr. John Simpson Toll, presi dent of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, took place here this afternoon.

title: OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: SENSATIONS Tonight, Theater Four, 7:15. A musi cal. Music by Wally Harper; book and lyrics by Paul Zakrzewski.

title: Lawlessness and Order
description: WASHINGTONNo.matter whether those responsible are ordinary, crimi nals or persons with criminal political motives, the rising incidence of attacks on policemen must be condemned and stopped. This is doubly true if such incidents as the bomb explosions at the funeral of a San Francisco police man, killed by bank robbers, are part of a general or national plan.

title: OLD HITS RECALLED BY FIFTH DIMENSION
description: The Fifth Dimension is a razzledazzle group of singers two women, three menwho are such a polished vocal en semble that one never becomes overly conscious of the choreo graphic sleight of handor is it sleight of foot?with which they dress up their songs. The quintet put on a fastpaced, precisiontooled performance for an enthusiastic audience that filled Philharmonic Hall at the first of two shows there on Friday night.

title: LEARY OFF ON A VISIT TO ARAB GUERRILLAS
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Timothy Leary, the advocate of the use of LSD, left Algiers to day to visit Palestine guerrilla bases in the Middle East.

title: Filipino Stewards Still Used by Navy, But Number Drops
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Navy, steeped in tra dition in an age of missiles, jets and nuclearpowered ships, still recruits hundreds of Filipinos to serve only as cooks, waiters and cabin boys.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 24  The way the election campaign in New Jersey was going, it was bound to happen eventually, and it finally did this week: Nelson G. Gross, the Republican candi date for United States Senator, ended up debating himself.

title: Oregon Topples Southern. California, 107 With Touchdown in Last Quarter
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 24 (AP) Bobby Moore smashed over from the 1yard line early in the fourth quarter today as the University of Oregon upset Southern California, 107, in a Pacific8 game.

description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Ivory Coast has made inocula tion against cholera mandatory following an outbreak this week, it was announced yester day.

description: LONDRINA, Brazil, Oct. 24 (AP)The United States won one title yesterday in the Pan American judo championships as Patrick Burris of Los Angeles won in the lightweight class.

title: Births
description: ZUCKERMANSteven and Shetlie (neo Feiner man), of Great Neck, N. Y., are ecstatic M announce the arrival of their first child, Glenn Adam on Oct. 16, 1970. Proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Feinerman of Great Neck, N. Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zuckerman of New York City.

title: Have sociologists been failed politicians?
description: It isn't every day that a pub lisher's blurb underestimates the importance of the book it intends to promote. But Alvin Gouldner's publisher does ex actly this in describing his new book as possibly the most in fluential book in American sociology since C. Wright Mills'The Sociological Imagina tion. The reference to Mills is apt because Gouldner is clearly in the running (indeed, with this book he goes to the head of the pack) to inherit Mills's leadership of the so ciological left. But Mills's book, good as it is, was primarily a polemic against Grand Theory and Abstracted Empiricism (the dominant modes of con temporary sociological think ing and research); Gouldner's book is nothing less than a full blown sociological analysis of sociological theory, from Au guste Comte to the present, and if only for this reason is a far more important achievement than Mills's in the history of sociology.

description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP)The Grenadier Guards, a spitand polish regiment normally as signed to ceremonial duties at Buckingham Palace, got a new job today: hauling piles of gar bage off the streets of London.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: What's right with Nixon economics is basically a mat ter of character and responsi bility. We did what had to be done. In the common phrases, we faced the facts, grasped the nettle, bit the bullet. We did not pretend that there was no problem, or that it could be solved without cost, or that we had any trick up our sleeve that would avoid the cost.

title: 21,741 choices for a career
description: THE surprising results of a new study on career choice should change the prevalent view that parents have little or no influence on their children. Dr. Raymona C. Doane of the University of Connecticut asked 2,000 high school students who had been most influential in help ing them reach whatever career decisions they had made. About half of the youngsters reported that their parents had carried the most weight.

title: David Eisenhower to Be Navy Officer
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 24 (UPI)David Eisenhower, son of a West Point graduate and grandson of one of the nation's most distinguished Army lead ers, entered Naval Officers Can didate School here today for an 18week training course lead ing tto a Navy commission as an Ensign. An officer here said his training would be as nor mal and rcutine as it could be for a President's soninlaw.The 22yearold soninlaw of President Nixon reported to O.C.S. at the Newport Naval Base shortly before noon for threeyear hitch.

title: Honest Story Wins Pace At Freehold in 1:59
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 24  Honest Story, owned by the Wirtz Stables of Chicago, cracked the 2minute mile for the second time at Freehold Raceway in today's $10,000 Morris Pace when he won by 3 lengths in 1:59 2/5: Two weeks ago today he set a track record of 1:58 2/5.

title: North Vietnam to Punish Misuse of Public Office
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)A decree for the protection of government property has been promulgated by President Ton Duc Thang, the newspaper Nhan Dan reported today.

title: Sharon Donnelly to Wed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Col. Leonard Francis Don nelly, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Don nelly have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Butler Donnelly, to Dr. Alan Ros Taylor. He is the son of Mrs. Herbert P. Taylor of New York and the late Mr. Taylor. The future bride is social secretary to Ambassador Olavi Munkkl of Finland in Washington. Her fianc is a professor of in ternational relations at the School of International Serv ice of American University. The couple will be married here Nov. 28.

title: American Notebook
description: I've always been a sap for esoteric statistics. I love curling up with the almanac; I'm not even above flipping through an atrocious recent book in order to find out how much Jackie and Ari spent last year for en tertaining at home and eating out ($190,860).

title: Huskers Roll, 6531
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 24 (UPI) Nebraska, the defending co champion, put it all together today as it combined a light ning offense and rock hard de fense to pile up a 30point first half bulge and go on to humble Oklahoma State, 6531, in Big Eight action.

title: Vault Gains Measured in Years, Inches
description: It took 30 years after Cor nelius Warmerdam cleared the magic 15foot mark for Christos Papanicolaou to go three feet higher.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TIED BY UCONNS, 21 TO 21
description: AMHERST, Mass. Oct. 24 Juan Madry made two big plays for the University of Connecti cut in the second half today as the Huskies rallied to tie the University of Massachu setts, 2121, before 14,600 homecoming fans in Alumni Stadium.

title: North Stars Defeated
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 24  Rod Seiling's firstperiod tiebreaker and powerplay goals by Rod Gilbert and Vic Had field sparked the New York Rangers to a 41 victory over the Minnesota North Stars to night and a tie for first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Vision of Man's Adaptability
description: AS director Michael Lang ham has pointed out in his program note for the world premiere of A Play by Aleksandr Sol zhenitsyn at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneap olis, the Nobel Prizewin ner's threehour tour of a Stalinist correctional labor camp in 1945 is not really an antiCommunist play. A number of the prisoners who see their suitcases kicked open, their books strewn about the ground, their truly sick companions treated mer cilessly as malingerers, are and plan to remaindevoted Communists. The fact that they at present inhabit nightmare does not matter; the nightmare is a personal thing, an accident of time and place, an oversight; the great dream goes on.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: Nat'l Football League

title: Murder Trial Nearing End
description: ALFRED, Me., Oct. 24De fense and state attorneys rested their cases today in the murder trial of Joseph Crowder, 24 years old, of Delray Beach, Fla., charged with the stabbing death of Samuel M. Shipp Jr., 39, a bellhop at Kennebunk port's Colony Hotel last Aug. 29. Mr. Crowder, former head chef at the resort hotel, tes tified Friday that he had stabbed Mr. Shipp in selfde fense.

title: Gard of Thanks
description: DICHTERDavid. The family of the late David Dichter wishes to express sincere thanks to their relatives and friends for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: NONPOLLUTING CAR IS MEETING TOPIC
description: KYOTO, Japan, Oct. 24 (Reu ters)Representatives of major automobile manufacturers and petroleum companies from the United States, Japan, West Germany and Italy meet here Monday to continue their quest for a pollutionfree car.

title: Long Beach, West Hempstead Triumph
description: Long Beach, Wantagh and West Hempstead managed to end the fifth week of South Shore Division I competition in a three way tie for first place yesterday and all three con tinued to look impressive in the process of increasing their rec ords to 41.

title: The ferocious strains in our national past
description: The present not seldom re quires us to take a fresh look at the past; and the turbulence of American society over the last several years has unques tionably forced historians to confront points about the Amer ican experience long neglected in our written history and rare ly acknowledged in our national selfimage. The problem of conflict, indeed, was studiously minimized during the consen sus history enthusiasm of the nineteenfifties; and violence hardly existed as an academic subject at all until H. R. Gra ham and T. R. Gurr put to gether their report on Histori cal and Comparative Perspec tives for the National Com mission on the Causes and Pre vention of Violence in 1969. Now Richard Hofstadter, pro fessor of American history at Columbia, in collaboration with one of his students, Michael Wallace, has collected an in valuable series of documents illustrating varieties of Ameri can violence.

title: Sophia Loren: I Shall Return
description: MAMA MIA! That Sophia Loren sure is made of sturdy stuff. One minute she's being subjected to a mass interview at the Music Hall and the next minute she's being robbed of her Sunday best jewels. Still, the sunny star of Sunflower swears that she really digs Fun City so much so, in fact, that she will return here in Jan uary to make Mortadella, film based on a screenplay by Leonard Melfi. Mario Monicelli will direct for Warner Bros.

title: Bates Loses 5th in Row
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Oct. 24 (AP)Bates held Norwich Uni versity scoreless in the first quarter, but a sophomore, Mark Conroy, kicked a 43yard field goal in the second quarter and the cadets went on to score a 100 football victory today, handing Bates its fifth straight 10Sr.

title: Joan Meyer Fiance of C. A. Dana 3d
description: Lady Weidenfeld of Lon don and William Blair Meyer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Whitney Meyer, to Charles Anderson Dana 3d, son of Mr. Dana Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and New York and the late Mrs. Marion Terrell Francis of Morristown. N.J.

title: Clocks Set Back To Standard Time
description: Daylight saving time ended at 2 A.M. today as most of the nation turned back clocks and watches to regain the hour lost when the system went into effect on April 25.

title: GROMYKO MEETS KISSINGER QUIETLY
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have been en gaged in behindthescenes di plomacy on urgent issues in addition to the publicized meet ings that the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, has held this last week with President Nixon and Secretary of State William P. Rogers.

title: GORTON HANOVER IS PACING VICTOR
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 24 Canadianowned Horton Han over, bred for and tried as a trotter but found wanting on that gait, won the $50,000 Na tional Pacing Derby tonight be fore 28,941 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: 2 Students Sentenced In AntiNixon Protest
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP)  Two University of Tennessee student have been sentenced to the Knox County Workkhouse on disorderly con duct charges stemming from President Nixon's visit to the Billy Graham Crusade on the campus last May 28.

title: Books:
description: Peter Bernstein is an in vestment adviser with the title of chairman of an in vestment management sub sidiary of a New York Stock Exchange member firm. From this vantage point, he has collected his thoughts, issued in the form of bulletins to in vestors over a period of years. The result is a gather ing of chapters that might be outdated except the author has at the end of each added his 19691970 thoughts.

title: 700 HEAR DEBATE ON SOCIAL ISSUES
description: Leading family therapists, meeting at a conference here on Thursday and Friday, argued whether calling society today sick was justified in view of the changes taking place and what now seems normal.

title: TULANE 206 LOSER TO GEORGIA TECH
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 24 (UPI)  Rick Lewis broke open a score less game early in the fourth period today when he scored twice on defensive plays in 27second span to lead Georgia Tech to a 206 victory over Tulane in the rain.

title: OHIO STATE TESTS ELECTION COURSES
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 24 The office used to belong to a pediatrician, and the pink lambs on the wallpaper were not com pletely concealed by campaign posters. At a table in the cen ter, five young persons earn estly discussed ways to recruit voluteer workers.

title: POSTER DESIGNER HIT BY BOTH SIDES
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24A Viet nam veteran who makes peace posters as well as some that glorify warriors like Attila the Hun has received praise and criticismboth based on mis understandingafter paying a $2,500 fee to the city of Hous ton so the American Legion can have its Veterans Day parade.

description: LJUBLAJANA, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 (AP)Japan won the compulsory exercises for men at the 17th world gymnastic championships today.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)  President Nixon has officially written Army horse and mule auctions into the history books.

description: In a double dual meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday, Fordham triumphed twice, defeating New York Uni versity, 2234, and Connecticut, 1741. N.Y.U. defeated Connec ticut, 2036.

title: Miss Wendy Vanderbilt Is Married to Orin Lehman
description: Miss Wendy Vanderbilt, daughter of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the noted sports man, was married yesterday morning to Orin Lehman, the civic leader, theatrical producer and broadcasting executive.

title: Race Relations Is Their Business
description: WASHINGTON. THE seventhfloor suite of Sam Harris Associates, Ltd., once part of the Ling  Temco Vought conglomerate, looks like any other office in the section of down town Washington where a special breed of lawyers, lobbyists and shad ow bureaucrats work. The decor is Connecticut Avenue contemporary plastic, glass and veneerbut on the neutral white walls of Sam Harris's office, instead of meaningless mod abstracts, there are photographs of black ghetto youngsters with wide eyes and black revolutionaries with raised fists. The trim receptionist is black, with colorful minidress, steel rimmed spectacles and an imposing Afro hairdo. And on her desk, which adjoins the room where the clacking and humming Xerox 3600 is constant ly being fed, there is a sign: Weusi WampandeziSwahili for Black Is Beautiful.

title: Governments Are Barred from I.L.O.'s Maritime Unit
description: GENEVA, Oct. 24  The United States Government, the shipping industry and seafarers unions were united in opposing a move this week that could have diluted the collective bar gaining role of seamen and their employers in the Interna tional Labor Organization.

title: Education
description: Last January, a special Presi dential task force submitted rec ommendations on the needs of higher education to the White House. The document  and covering letter by Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University and chairman of the group  remained under wraps until recently, when it was made public without comment or ex planation.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: I NEVER SANG FOR MY FA THER, directed by Gilbert Cates from Robert Anderson's screen adaptation of his play, does the human spirit a dis service, writes Vincent Canby, in the way it pleads for sym pathy for people who are small and flat, like comic strip characters, without sweetness, without imagination, without any suspected reserves of emo tion. Indeed, it almost be comes ridiculous when you realize that it is without any honest problem, either psycho logical or economic. Melvyn Douglas and Dorothy Stickney perform with the kind of pro fessional sufficiency one ex pects of them, but Gene Hackman and Estelle Parsons left me cheerless, which is the nature of the entire enterprise. I Never Sang for My Father is, by definition, a wretched motion picture.

title: Unbeaten Air Force Rallies Twice to Down Boston College, 35 to 10, for No.7
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Oct. 24 (AP)The undefeated Air Force twice fought from behind to defeat Boston Col lege, 3510, today for the Fal cons seventh football victory.

description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1970

title: Ensclish Win at Lacrosse
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (UPI) England came back from a 16 deficit to beat the United States, 1210, today in a wom en's lacrosse match at the Hurlingham Club.

title: Wall Street
description: One of the darkest clouds now hovering over Wall Street came all the way from Detroit. That cloud was formed by the strike against General Motors, a work stop page that will start its sev enth week Tuesday.

title: Eileen V. Grady Officer's Bride
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 24 Miss Eileen Virginia Grady and Lieut. Edward H. Soder strom 2d, U.S.A., were mar ried here today in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Francis Pegnam per formed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Charles E. Wilcox of Tulsa, Okla.

description: SANTA FE, N. M.  In the continuing war against the mos quito, New Mexico health of ficials believe they have come up with a new weapon: instant fish.

title: FRENCH POLYNESIA SEEKS AUTONOMY
description: SUVA, Fiji, Oct. 14 Dis affection over tight control of local affairs by distant France has intensified the movement for selfgovernment in Tahiti and other islands of French Polynesia, according to a high elected official of the strategic southern Pacific territory.

title: The In Game, the New Obsession
description: Subject of debate, harbinger of hope, object of affection, creator of Hectors and Croes uses and (as we all know) Penelopes, professional foot ball sweeps all Sundays and Mondays before it. It is the in game, the new obsession. As author Paul Zimmerman says, the fan is being lifted to new levels of awareness. Professional football has be come, among other things, a prime source of American lit erature. Here are the year's best books, touching all bases (if one may borrow a phrase from the nation's runnerup sport)history, statistics, bal letic photos, reminiscence, in side dope, booboos, techniques, feuds, the great games, the great plays and the unforget table personalities.

title: JEWISIH UNIT SEES DRAFT BOARD BIAS
description: The Synagogue Council of America is protesting alleged denial of conscientious objector status to members of the Jew ish faith by elements of the Selective Service System that the council says hold that Judaism cannot embrace con scientious objection.

description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 24The engagement of Miss Susan Gail Spevack to Robert Howard Carlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Carlson of Upper Montclair, N. J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Spe vack.

title: 3 New Boston U. Trustees
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Three trustees were elected yesterday at a meeting of Boston Uni versity's board of trustees. They are Mrs. Ernest Hender son of Boston, a securities ana lyst Warren Alpert of New York, president of Warren Equities, Inc., and Christopher A. Barreca of Prospect, Ky., a labor relations lawyer.

title: Nets Send Hunter to Colonels
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, LI., Oct. 24 (AP)The New York Nets sent Les Hunter to the Kentucky Colonels today for cash and a future high draft choice. The 6foot7inch Hun ter was No. 2 scorer for the Nets last season with a 16 point average.

title: 3 Reported Killed in Shellings
description: SAIGON, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Three civilians were killed and 15 injured when Vietcong guer rillas shelled two small towns near Danang, the South Viet namese command said today.

description: CHAMPAIGN, In Oct. 24 (UPI)  Ohio State rolled to five touchdowns in the second half today and scored a 4829 victory over Illinois.

description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24 Ben B. Seligman, professor of economics and director of the Labor Center at the University of Massachusetts since 1965, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: Ulbricht Ends Prague Visit
description: BERLIN, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Walter Ulhricht, the East Ger man leader, returned home to day after an official fourday visit to Czechoslovakia.

description: The New York City Opera Twill end its fall season at the New York State Theater on Nov. 15 with a matinee of Jana cek's The Makropoulos Af fair and an evening perform ance of Verdi's Rieoletto.

title: After 18 Hours, Just Tears
description: I VE been accused by directors and producers being a pain in the rear, said Elaine Stritch, lean ing across a table in Sardi's to emphasize her point. This documentary will prove that I'm actually trying to get the damned material right.

title: Name Franchising
description: Ever since celebrities in the entertainment and sports fields first associated their names publicly decades ago with commercial ventures, businessmen have pondered the answer to that Shake spearean question. But in the last few yearswhen it seemed that almost everyone who could throw a ball or sing a note was lending his or her name to a business the value of such an associa tion has become a subject of interest and debate among nameless citizens.

title: NIXON REPUDIATES OBSCENITY REPORT AS MORALLY VOID
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 24Pres ident Nixon rejected totally today the monthold report of the National Commission on Obscenity and Pornography. He called its conclusions morally bankrupt and charged that the group had performed a dis service.

title: Sally Tryon and Howard Lepow Marry
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 24 Miss Sally Victoria Tryon and Howard Gerald Lepow were married here today in the home of the bride's par ents in a dual ceremony. Rabbi Jonas Javna of Temple Israel in New York per formed the first ceremony and the Rev. Robert Cotter of the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church officiated at the second.

title: Homfeld, Newest Team Rider, Will Start for U.S. in National
description: Conrad Homfeld is the youngest (18 years old) least experienced (riding jumpers four years) and skin niest (6 feet 1 inch and 135 pounds) member of the Unit ed States Equestrian Team.

title: Wichita State Trounced
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Ninthranked Arkansas scored the first four times it had the ball tonight and crushed Wichita State, 620.

description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Oct. 24 Kill Referendum 20, not me, says a billboard in the state of Washington.

title: Coins
description: ASCHEDULE for the sixth annual Grand Central Coin Convention, to be held on Nov 6, 7 and 8, was announced last week by Patrick James, president of the Long Island Coin Club, sponsor of the event. The show will be held at the Mc Alpin Hotel, 34th Street and Broadway and it will be open to the public with no admis sion charge.

title: REV. DOUGLAS REID OF TRINITY PARISH
description: The Rev. Douglas Reid, a member of the staff of the Chapel of the Intercession of Trinity Parish, Broadway at 155th Street, died on Friday of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 800 Riverside Drive.

title: BlowUp Threatened in Quebec If 4 Front Leaders Aren't Freed
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 24A mes sage reportedly from the Front for the Liberation of Quebec warned tonight that there would be a blowup in Montreal and that our program of execu tions will continue unless four front leaders were released from jail by noon tomorrow.

title: Japanese ABomb Study Sees Steady Leukemia Rate
description: TOKYO, Oct. 24 (AP)Chil dren and parents exposed to the two atomic attacks on Japan do not have a leukemia mortal ity rate particularly higher than that for other children, Japanese scientists have re ported.

title: Antipollution Block
description: ARNOLD COPELAND of New York and Walter DuBois Richards of New Canaan, Conn., designed the block of four antipollution stamps that will be issued at San Clemente, Calif., on Wednesday, reported briefly here last week.

title: Nineteenthcentury England will never be the same
description: In the first sentence of his book Kellow Chesney suggests that much of the fascination of the Victorian age derives from its strange familiar ity. That may be so, but, as his book hammers home, our sense of familiarity with the Victorian age is in some respects a complete illusion. Indeed, reading The AntiSociety, I felt that the London of a century ago was scarcely less strange to us than, say, the St. Petersburg of Crime and Punishment, and for not very different reasons.

title: Miss Pamela Morton Is Bride Of Bruce Coleman in Bay State
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Oct. 24The First Congrega tional Church of Wellesley Hills was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Morton, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. James Augustus Morton, to Bruce Taylor Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Amiable Cole man of Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John Elmo Wal lace performed the ceremony.

title: MICH. STATE AERIALS CONQUER IOWA, 370
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Mike Rasmussen tossed two touchdown passes today as Michigan State regis tered a 370 Big Ten triumph over Iowa.

title: MOST IN A SURVEY NOT AFRAID TO DIE
description: TORONTO, Oct. 24 (AP) Almost 63 per cent of 183 mid dleaged to elderly persons surveyed by the University of Southern California were not afraid to die, one of the re searchers said yesterday.

title: TEXAS MAKES RICE 25TH VICTIM, 4521
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) Eddie Phillips, the quarterback, scored three touchdowns and Steve Worster scored a fourth tonight to lead secondranked Texas to a 4521 vittory over Rice. It was the Longhorns 25th triumph in a row.

title: Engagements
description: BADERPARIS. Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Paris of Rockville Centre, N. Y., are pleased to announce the engagement of their daughter, Rosanne Ellen, to Mr. Laurence Bader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bader of Augusta, Maine. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Quickly, with quality
description: Great cooking doesn't necessarily imply long or complicated hours in the kitchen. For instance, a roast rack of lamb should indeed, mustbe done with a certain celer ity. Of course, the lamb must be tender, of first quality, to begin with. When you have lamb of such quality, it can be prepared excellently, and quickly, using the recipe below. Note well that this lamb is best cooked rare. Serve it with the accompanying dishes, and finish with the chilledorange dessert on the facing page.

title: Habitat, All Rented, Erases Stigma Of White Elephant
description: MONTREALHabitat, the experimental housing system built on the banks of the St. Lawrence River for the Expo 67 world's fair, is fully occu pied now and expanding.

description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 24  Aircraft began scattering three million pounds of grass seed this weekend over nearly 600 square miles of forest and brush land left scarred and charred by the worst fires in Southern California's history.

title: Squires Obtain Maley
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 24 (UPI) The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Associa tion announced today the ac quisition of Mike Malay from the Pittsburgh Condors for an undisclosed amount of cash. Malay, who starred at Bryant High, Queens, and Davidson College, was the firstround draft choice of the Condors.

description: One of the city's top environ mental officials says the sani tation problem cannot be solved here until some new technology is found to change the anti quated collection system.

description: Although it sent television crews scurrying, it was not much of a surprise as sur prises go in the city. The Young Lords party, New York's most visible radical group outside of a courtroom, had taken uo arms.

description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) Twentysix policemen were killed and there were 141 bombings in the United States from July to September, a lead ing police official has said.

description: DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 24 (AP)A hurricane with winds of 90 miles an hour battered nine East Pakistan districts to day, and sketchy information indicated at least 100 persons had been killed.

title: Dance
description: w HAT is the differ ence between good dancing and bad dancing, between good ballet and bad ballet? The questions are not merely rhetorical. They are virtually insoluble. The strange thing is that when dance happens, when all the right com ponents slip into place, it is as unmistakable as musical harmony. And precisely as undescribable.

title: Mrs. Naimo Has Son
description: A son was born Oct. 2 to Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Naimo of Brooklyn in Caledonia Hospital. Mrs. Nahrio is the former Miss Susan Ascher.

title: Son for the W. A. Rosses
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Austin Ross of New York on Oct. 6 in Doc tors Hospital. Mrs. Ross is the former Miss Jill Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Williams of Palm Beach, Fla. The child, the couple's second, is named Harold Franklin. His father is managing director of the American TV and Radio Com mercials Festival.

title: Bucks Overtime Victors
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) Bobby Dandridge's 3 points and a basket by Bob Boozer helped the Milwaukee Bucks post a 122120 victory in double over time over the Baltimore Bullets tonight.

title: Religion
description: Five years ago, the late Bishop James A. Pike of California at tempted to ordain Phyllis A. Ed wards, a 48yearold widow, as a deacon of the Episcopal Church. He was soundly re buffed by the church fathers on the grounds that the ancient or der of the ministry was a male preserve. Last week the church's high est policymaking body, the Gen eral Convention, handed Bishop Pike a posthumous victory.

title: Pop
description: INCREDIBLE, romantic haze  in the desert! Of course: it's photographer Laszlo Kovacs patented longshot, with the focus re duced to make background a kind of moving abstraction. And now the two baddest mothers of the New Age, our Batman and Robin, come up the hill and into focus, the aura of their cycles golden in the sun. And that's Step penwolf hitting Born to be Wild on the soundtrack. And out there is an audience of millions loosening up and grooving a bit with the Walter Mittyness of it all, for this is Easy Rider, starring Pe ter Fonda and Dennis Hopper and costarring, if you will, the the Band. Jimi Hendrix, the Electric Flag, the Electric Prunes, and Bob Dy lan via Roger McGuinn. Somewhere in the bleachers, critics and competitors are busting their skulls trying to figure out why this dheapie grosses so much, and the best anyone comes up with is that Easy Rider is  revolu tionary.

title: Rockefeller Funds Key Factor in Race
description: In a campaign that is shaping up as the most ex pensive ever waged for the executive mansion in Albany, the Democratic and Conser vative party candidates feel that the power of the purse of Governor Rockefeller, the Republican incumbent, puts them at an acute disadvan tage.

title: Best Turn, $13, Is Victor In Vosburgh at Aqueduct
description: Best Turn didn't have to be a Dr. Fager or a Ta Wee to win the $59,300 Vosburgh Handicap yesterday at Aque duct.

title: Roger S. Hewlett Marries Mrs. Grew
description: Mrs. Selina Wood Grew and Roger Sanderson Hew lett, who got to know each other about 25 years ago when their children went to school together on Long Is land, were married yesterday noon in St. John's Episcopal Church in Far Rockaway, Queens. The Rev. Charles R. Supin performed the cere mony.

title: AmherstWesleyan: Big Game in a Low Key
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24Two hours before kickoff, Dick Lyman, Amherst Class of 1947; Ralph Bemis, Wesleyan 50 and their wives spread out a blanket on scenic Foss Hill, a stone's throw from Andrus Field, the site of the Wesleyan Amherst football game.

title: SouthWest Africa Saves Antelopes From Drought
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Af rica, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Con servation officials have flown the last of 75 roan antelopes and two tsessebea type of antelope400 miles from droughtstricken eastern areas to the safety of a game park.

title: Ottinger: Study of a Quiet Candidate
description: TRADITIONALLY it has been the Republicans rather than the roistering Democrats who have made political virtues of silence, seriousness and long hours of grind ing toil. Representative Richard Law rence Ottinger, although the Demo cratic candidate for the United States Senate, descends from a line so pro foundly Republican that the very mention of the name of Franklin Del ano Roosevelt was forbidden in the Scarsdale mansion in which he grew up, and he shows it.

title: Florida State on Top

title: News of the Rialto

The idea has a special pertinence this morning because the winner of three Pulitzer prizes (one for his play J.B.) is returning to the theater. Hes working on a twoact play, Scratch, which alert lovers of Stephen Vincent Benet should recognize as being right out of the late poet's celebrated short story, The Devil and Daniel Webster, which was the basis for much admired movie in 1941, All That Money Can Buy. Scratch is the evil one.

It is an interesting, imaginative and generally ingenious work.

title: A noble failure by a corrupted mystic
description: Malcolm Lowry struggled with this novel the last 10 years of his life, until his death in 1957. He never fin ished it. What that means for Lowry is something different from what it means for most novelists. What it meansin addition to an impossible unevenness (in which banality stands juxtaposed with the profound)  is that the work lacks the final ex purgatory look which was as important for Lowry's writing as the initial inspiration. Lowry had the habit of turning every scrap of expe rience into a novella, the novella into a huge and sad novel, and that in turn into a continuum of novels. October Ferry to Gabriola was once a novella; it is the novella length experience within this maze of prose that the reader should look for. What awaits him is worth the effort: a species of ecstatic, lyrical prose that has all but gone out of existence.

title: Penn State Romps Over Army, 3814; 6th Loss for Cadets
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 24Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State revised his offense; put a new quarterback, John Hufnagel, at the contruls, and ordered his Nittany Lions to take the game right to the middle of the Army defenses today.

title: A believer of old virtues and old ways
description: This is a book of unabashed, sentimental nostalgia, a son's tribute to his father. It is so elaborately written in places, and it has such a turnofthe century air, that it might be a takeoff on books about the Good Old Days and Wonderful Family chronicles. But it is a remembrance written by a man still in his forties while re covering from a heart attack suffered just six years after his father died in his early sixties.

title: The Militants Who Play With Dynamite
description: BEHIND locked sliding doors, suspended in antiseptic array on white pegboard are bulbous black bottles, cylinders, wires, timing mechanisms  among them a watch with its face impaled by makeshift terminals. Infernal devices, the bombs. They decorate one wall of the corridor leading into the New York City Police Department's bomb squad headquarters in the Police Academy building on East 20th Street. They look like antique gad getry out of a sunless corner of the Victoria and Albert Museum. They conjure up dim images of anarchists, extortionists, madmen.

title: HalfPast Autumn
description: You hear, you feel, you see what time it is on the big clock of the year. It isn't quite halfpast autumn, but will be soon. Back on standard time today, the sun sets before five on the clock for the first time since January. Now the shortening days will seem even shorter and the lengthening nights will start early.

title: the traveler's world
description: LIMA, PeruThe twohour flight from Quito, Ecuador, over the snowy, jagged Andean peaks down to sealevel Lima on the shore of the Pacific puts the traveler back in step at once with the current calendar, for Lima's airport is the slick, glass and shiny metal terminal of a modern city. Lima is a big capital city of more than two million, pulsing and driving, although its modern build ings stand next to colonial buildings whose balconies and carved outside beams recall Spanish days. There is even talk of a national program to re store wooden balconies to the many modernized old structures to recapture and preserve the colonial flavor now fading slowly before the glare of neon.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: HILTON KRAMER touched the sensitive nerve of the press preview in his review of the Information show at the Museum of Modern Art, which technically closed Sept. 20 but will actually continue indefinitely, though not nec essarily at MOMA. It is ger mane to mention it now since one of the critical elements in Information is the em phatic recognition by the mu seum that art is a process which has no beginning or end at all. The preview or membership opening is there fore an institutional device which accedes to the trap of press deadlines, newspaper publicity, patronage fanfare, and some celebrity relief for everyone involved.

title: Cozy Objects Gone Berserk
description: CHAIRS: lethallooking chairs, bristling with sharp pins; dainty bou doir chairs looped with pretty patterns of colored yarn; chairs that look as if they were collapsing in fright at the thought of their human burdens, their legs melting away; proud chairs boasting additional services, their slightlyopened drawers of fering bits of bright silk, heaps of woodchips, mounds of glittering dimestore jewelry; chairs that seem to have had sudden changes of mind about their material status, their Formica halves yielding to columns of soft cotton yarn; mirrored chairs that dissolve on the spot into nothing more than glassy re flections; chairs that have stacked themselves up to be come unlikely staircases; chairs that have blossomed into bright chintzy gardens of synthetic flowers; chairs that made themselves over into instruments of torture; chairs, in fact, that subscribe to all sorts of improbable fan tasies but which never settle down to their one indisput able function. None of the chairs in Lucas Samaras's Chair Transformations, a striking exhibition of sculp ture and drawing now on view at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, has ac cepted its ostensible purpose in lifeseating.

title: Headliners
description: To gather material for his book In Cold Blood, a study of two Kansas killers, Truman Capote spent many hours inside prison an interviewer. Last week he returned to jail as a prisoner. Mr. Capote was sentenced in Santa Ana, Calif., to three days and a $500 fine for failing to appear in court to testify in a murder trial. The 46yearold writer told the judge he had not understood the seri ousness of the subpoena. Obviously I should have been here. He subsequently was released a day early because his doctor said he was worried about Mr. Capote's health.

title: Ithaca Downs Bridgeport For Third Straight, 156
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 24 (UPI) Ithaca turned a blocked punt and a fumable recovery into two touchdowns and made them stand up for a 166 vic tory over Bridgeport today. Ithaca has won three straight and is 33; Bridgeport is 24 after losing four straight.

title: Bruised Psyche of A Timid Big Tipper
description: WHEN IT comes to tipping, I run scared. I ran scared when everybody else was tipping 10 per cent, and I'm still running that way now that the figure is up to 15 or 20 per cent. Even when I get Inferior service, my impulse is to overtip; I just keep feeding the hand that bites me.

description: Manhattan College hobbled by injuries to several of it I regulars, was beaten by the Georgetown Hoyas yesterday 350, in a club football game.

title: Color and Field and Ancestors Presumptive
description: ONE of the most engaging frailties of the artists and critics who carry aloft the banners of new movements in American painting is that they enter the lists one after another as revolutionaries, or at least as avowed originators; and then within a few years are busily supplying them selves with ancestors. Success breeds a yearning for conventional respectabil ity, and like nouveaux riches who are not quite certain who grandma and grandpa were, but who are revealed by imaginative genealogists to be the de scendants of aristocratic houses, so does eacn new movement in turn grow rest less with commercial success in the galleries and a show at the Jewish Museum, and yearn for identification with the past.

title: Fondue Bruxelloise, one of many dishes

description: Call them movers, corners, young turks, overachievers, or longknives  whatever label you hang on them, it is clear that they are the scarce generation of United States business executives, with a golden ladder of promotion ahead of them.

title: Random Impressions of a Changing Land
description: BUCHARESTThe Athenee Palace Ho tel provides accommodations, food and services in the grand old European man ner: curved carpeted staircases, page boys in pillbox hats, gilt and glass, gypsy violins with dinner. At $12 a double room, it is a bargain in any body's languageand you are liable to hear them all in the busy lobby.

title: Politics, Rochester's Favorite Game, Appears to Be in an Apathetic Slump
description: ROCHESTERMost cities have something that fires them upa baseball team, a football team, something, a young woman at a lunch eon counter said here the other day. Traditionally, it's politics in Rochester. The game here is politics.

title: Speaking of Books
description: Francophilia, in America, is an unaccountable virus, striking even those who have no trace of France in their background. In my case the malady has taken a long course, determining several decades of work. The resulting biographies of French literary men have quite by chance, or so it seemed, occurred in chronologi cal order: Gustave Flaubert and his Madame Bovary; Flaubert's dis ciple Guy de Maupassant and his stories; (here an interruption for the 17thcentury Grande Mademoiselle); the poet Guillaume Apollinaire (who died on the eve of the 1918 Armis tice); and most lately Apollinaire's lieutenant in the arts, Jean Coc teau, who lived until 1963 and was poet, novelist, dramatist, cineast, por traitist, sculptor and more besides. While Flaubert is the giant of those four, utterly absorbing in his art and in his incomparable letters, Cocteau has been the most pervasive.

title: Trescher Gets New Museum Post
description: George Trescher has been elected to fill the new post of vice director of public affairs at the Metro politan Museum of Art, it was announced yesterday by C. Douglas Dillon, museum president, and Thomas P. F. Roving, director.

title: Charles H. Kerrigan Dies at 57; A LongTime Official of U.A.W
description: Charles H. Kerrigan Eastern regional director of the United Automobile Workers Union for 29 years until last September, when he became special assist ant to the union's president, Leonard Woodcock, died yes terday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at Millard Avenue, Miller Place. L. I.

title: Wedding Held For Jean Gantt
description: GLOUCESTER, Va., Oct. 24 Miss Jean DuVal Gantt, daughter of Col. He is the son of Mrs. Christine Thomas Nuzum and Russell Owen Nuzum, both of Lexington.

title: Author's Query
description: At the request of the late Sir John Baribirolli (18991970), famed orchestra conductor, and with the approval of Lady Bar birolli I am writing Sir John's official biography. I would ap preciate receiving any letters that were written by him or reminiscences about him that might be of assistance to me.

title: Candidates Vary on Solutions to the Drug Problem
description: The candidates for major of fice in New York State have talked much about drug addic tion, which they all agree is one of the principal issues of the campaign. But as election day draws near, it remains un clear to many familiar with the drug problems as to precisely what the candidates are pro posing as solutions, how these suggestions differ from ap proaches that have already failed and what basis they have for saying one thing will work, and another not.

title: An early act of memory and imagination
description: I read Mary many years ago in the Russian original. It appeared in Berlin in 1926 as the first novel of Sirinthe pen name of young Vladi mir Nabokov (born in 1899). At that time he was a beginner, an obscure poet and the author of a few short stories. Is it possible today to ap praise Mary on its own merit, to overcome the almost irresistible temptation to examine it as a piece of literary history or biography, as a first step in a long and brilliant career, and abandon the search for elements brought to maturity and fulfillment in later creations of famous writer?

title: Kalashnikov Rifle: A Grim Arab Symbol
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 16 The Arab commando movement has found a suitably grim sym bol in the Sovietdesigned as sault rifle known here as the Kalashnikov.

title: A Mandarin Pretending To Be A Stumblebum
description: SPEAKING of his new paintings and the startling change of style they represent, Philip Guston is reported in the current issue of Art News to have declared recently: I got sick and tired of all that Purity! I wanted to tell Stories! Well, the paintingsall 33 of them, most of them hugehave now come to the Marlborough Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, and they certainly tell us a story all right, though not perhaps the story the artist had in mind.

title: The great director as a young man
description: D. W. Griffith still eludes definition. We know little of the motives that drove this ex traordinary pioneer of the mo tion picture, the greatest of American directors before Ford and Welles, from a minor ca reer as an actor to the tri umphs of The Birth of a Na tion, Intolerance and Hearts of the World in the teens of the century, to disaster in the talkies, and then to an obscure death.

title: CHINESE RELEASE ANOTHER BRITON
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 24Com munist China has released a British ship's officer after de taining him for two and a half years. His release, the second of a Briton in three months, was seen here as reflecting a further easing of relations between Britain and China.

title: Maybe Next Year? Don't Bet on It
description: THE criticism of Presi dent Nixon for vetoing a bill limiting expendi tures in political cam paigns was chiefly note worthy for its display of naivet6. No realist in the TV medium thought for one mo ment that the White House would throw away its eco nomic advantage in drowning the opposition in spot com mercials or staged discus sions, either in the current campaign or in 1972. Former President Lyndon B. Johnson was no less a master in bend ing the medium to his will, and in 1964 it was Senator Barry S. Goldwater who suf fered the economic disadvan tage in his Presidential cam paign.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Historical mystery fiction comes in several guises. The most abundant, accorded the status of a separate genre be cause of its peculiar frontier aura, is the Western. The most exacting is the novelization of an actual unsolved crimeas in John Dickson Carr's The Murder of Sir Edmund God frey and Lillian de la Torre's Elizabeth Is Missing in which each jot and tittle and scrap of dialogue (except for the author's proposed solution) is documented. Another varia tion blends fictional people and crimes into events and backgrounds of high historici ty. Sometimes, I wonder why we don't see more of this. The obvious answer, I suppose, is that it requires far more re search than the contemporary crime novel. But the rewards, especially when the result is as good as Peter Lovesey's WOB BLE TO DEATH (Dodd, Mead, $4.50), are eminently worth the effort.

title: Consumers Union Awarded Federal Education Project
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24A $250,000 grant for the develop ment of consumer education materials has been awarded to the Consumers Union by the United States Office of Educa tion.

title: Trash: One of the Cleanest Dirty Movies?
description: TRASH  the latest and glossiest product of the sevenyearold Andy Warhol shoe string cinema dynastyis a witty, poignant situation com edy about some utter degen erates. Like the recent Flesh, it was directed by Warhol's longtime assistant Paul Morrissey and stars the winsome, voluptuously mus cular Joe Dallesandro. And like most of the Warhol can on, it features casual camera work and a haphazard sound track and relies on the skill and presenceofmind with which very selfconscious ac tors (superstars, for whom selfdonsciousness is an ele ment of style) improvise char acter and dialogue within gamelike, usually erotic sit uations. It may be seen as, alternately, a fiction per formed by real people or a sort of documentary about people whose reality is not among their more preposses sing attributes. In either case, it is provocative, affecting and a lot of good, thorny fun.

title: A collector's item about collections
description: Let's put it this way: I have friend who would love this book. My friend is a rich collector, and his collection obsesses him, consumes him. It takes the place, I suspect, of sex for him. My friend collects, think, rare booksfirst editions, that sort of thing. Or perhaps it is porce lains. Come to think of it, I am cer tain it is books and porcelains. If appear to be less than sure what my friend collects, it is because whenever my friend is discussing his collection with his customary intensity, my own thoughts have had a tendency to wander off in other directions. Yes, my friend would love this book. It goes on my Christmas list for him today.

title: Point of View
description: It used to be that moving to the suburbs enabled families as well as corporations to escape the ills of the big city. Beyond the city line, the tax picture looked rosy. Corporate ownership of suburban facilities was relatively inexpensive. So was housing for em ployes. There was little crime and violence. Narcotics was a word one related strictly to the urban ghetto. Welfare costs were minimal. Travel on suburban park ways was comfortable and even the rail commute into Manhattan was preferable to the crowded city subways.

title: Evil, muted but omnipresent
description: This collection of five stories introduces the work of A. B. Yehoshua, a gifted young Is raeli writer. Unfortunately, the American edition has been miserably translated from the Hebrew by Miriam Arad, who has no ear for the common usage of English. Her sentences are often needlessly inverted, adjectives are misplacedand Yehoshua's style, which, I'm told, is spare and incisive, comes across as stiff and awk ward. Nevertheless, his talent is immediately apparent. He has been influenced by Kafka andslike him, has managed to con vey, by the specifics of objec tive reality, a unique inner world. He is a fabulist; his characters inhabit a familiar but mysterious universe in which meaning and emotion are expressed by many esthetic elements: leitmotif, counter point, and, when he is in full control, overall structure.

title: Male Dominance? Yes, Alas A Sexist Plot? No.
description: THE feminists angry rebuke to us males could not be more correct and more justified. Women everywhere earn less money than men, possess Iess power over their communi ties than men, have more difficulty becoming eminent than men, and do so far less often; as group they have lower status than men and less public prestige. Surely no one, myself included, would want to argue that such a situation is good or even tolerable: this must be the moral given or baseline from which all discussion of the feminist movement proceeds. However, if you want to change a system you have got to understand it.

title: MADISON AVE.

title: Abel of Steelworkers
description: WASHINGTON  Neither labor nor management has abandoned hopeit is much too earlybut several dis couraging and ominous signs suggest that nearly a dozen years of labor peace in the steel industry could end with a strike next summer.

title: What Do Understudies Do All Night?
description: UNDERSTUDIES are among the unsung people in the theater, and there are a few misunderstandings I would like to clear up for anyone contemplating becoming one. First of all, be very sure about what role it is you are standing by for. Play It Again, Sam is a play about a lovable neurotic's fasci nation with movies and how his fantasies of Humphrey Bogart help him through an affair with his best friend's wife. I am understudying not only the role of the neurotic, but the best friend and Bogart as well. I am sure that if I read the small print understudy to Red Buttons in the road company of Play It Again, Sam in my contract, I am also understudying the friend's wife. I hope this is not the case as I don't mind working nude, but I draw the line at having to work in threeinch heels.

title: CANADIAN GROUP GOES TO PEKING
description: OTTAWA. Oct. 24Six Ca nadian officials left for Peking today to arrange for an em bassy that Prime Minister Pi erre Elliott Trudeau hopes will develop the broadest range of exchanges between Canada and Communist China.

title: Electoral Shadow
description: It is no occasion for regret in most state elections that voters cannot cast a direct and separate ballot for Lieutenant Governor. Usually the nominees for that office on all tickets are a lackluster lot, picked in the hope that they will have special appeal to some groups that might not otherwise vote for their party's gubernatorial candi date.

title: Boston Mayor to Resume Campaign After Surgery
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White, the Democratic nominee for Gov ernor, was released from Mas sachusetts General Hospital today aand aides said he would resume campaigning shortly.

title: Insurance Executive Named Dartmouth Trustees Head
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 24 Charles J. Zimmerman, chair man of the board of the Con necticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of Dartmouth College yesterday at the board's fall meeting.

title: FOR THIS WEEK
description: Root leaves of lanky African violets and discard the old plants. Store tender bulbs in cool, dry places and be sure to label varieties. Keep up with the leaf fallout and compost the rakings.  Bulb planting can continue well into November. Gradually ease off on lawn mowing as grass growth wanes.  Bareroot trees and shrubs will be ready at nurseries next month and can be planted well into late fall. Be sure a good supply of quality feed is in store for wintertime bird visitors.

title: Ice: Finally Getting The Revolution Straight
description: OF ALL the films we've seen recently having to do with the New Ameri can Revolution, from William Klein's terrible, dilettantish Mister Freedom to Richard Rush's madly rack focussed cooption of revolution called Getting Straight, the only one to make any sense is Robert Kramer's Ice, the current attraction at the New Yorker Theater on the upper West Side where, as a matter of fact, it all seems to hannen.

title: Fire Risk Pool For Slum Aid Now Citywide
description: Fire insurance for apartment buildings in all but few areas of New York City has become difficult not impossible to buy outside a recently established fire risk pool.

title: LONDON VS. NEW YORK
description: Readers respond to Clive Barnes's suggestion to S. J. Perelman that instead of moving to London, he come to New York. Page 13.

title: Perfect for the Belle Epoque
description: The evolution of the poster is one of the characteristics of urban civil ization at the end of the 19th cen tury, and we can readily imagine Paris at that period as a city covered with multicolored placards vaunting the merits of a soap or a brand of aperitif; recalling the pleasure of the nocturnal life or the ambiguous charms of a cabaret singer.

title: BEAME ASKS RETURN OF SOME ADDICT AID
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame recommended yesterday that the Phoenix House Foundation, a private group that adminis ters the Phoenix House nar cotics program, return some of the $344,539 he said it had wrongly received from the city.

title: Light Action in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 24 (AP)A spokesman for the Cambodian command said bat tlegrounds were quiet except for light harassing forays by Communist forces.

title: Ronald Reagan Is Giving Em Heck
description: LABOR DAY, 1970. Ronald Wilson Reagan, former sports announcer and movie star, former bleeding heart Democrat, now Governor of California, was going campaigning. The press had been waiting for sev eral minutes when he bounced onto the bus, waved out the window to a pair of whitehaired young ladies, handed his notesneatly printed on white cardsto an aide and settled into a front seat. Then the bus pulled slowly away, headed for the Orange County Fairgrounds and the annual picnic of Local 324 of the Re tail Clerks International Association, A.F.L.C.I.O. It passed little stucco bungalows with aging Fords in the driveways, women in Bermuda shorts raking the grass and kids in Tshirts riding bicycles, American flags flap ping in a soft breeze and freeways carpeting the suncharred landscape with walltowall concrete. It passed something called Movieland of the Air and the General Steam Corpo ration, Dover Shores Veterinary Hos pital and the Happy Land PreSchool. As it approached the fairgrounds one of the Governor's companions re marked that working people did not like to go to Labor Day picnics any more. Reagan flicked at the subject like a frog at a fly. You youngsters probably don't remember, he said to the middleaged labor leaders sitting around him, but when I was young, golf was a sissy, rich man's game. So was boating and skiing and horse back riding. Today they're weekend sports for the working man; he doesn't have to go to Labor Day picnics.

title: Enueilings
description: ANCOWITZA monument to the loving memory of David Anrowitz, will be un veiled on Sunday, November 1, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N. Y., 11:45 A.M.

title: SOUZAY PRESENTS SCHUMANN CYCLE
description: Viewed as an interpretation, Gerard Souzay's performance of Schumann's Dichterliebe Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium was a mag nificent piece of work. Mr. Souzay and his excellent ac companist, Dalton Baldwin, pre sented the cycle as a unified entity rather than a mere col lection of pretty tunes, and the two artists made a compelling case for this rarely encountered approach.

title: Looking for Atlantis? Try Thera
description: THERA, GreeceAtlantis! Ever since Plato described the wonders of the Lost Continent 2,300 years ago, it has been name to dream about. And now, with the exercise of some faith and imagina tion, it lies within the reach of every traveler to the Mediterranean. If, that is, the traveler will accept the theory that Thera is the Lost Paradise, the Garden of Eden, which Plato said was swallowed up by the sea and vanished.

title: BRIDGEPORT ELEVEN BEATS BULLS, 1913
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 24 In a game featured by an incredible number of fumbles, dropped passes, and mistakes, the Bridgeport Jets defeated the Long Island Bulls, 1913, to night in an Atlantic Coast foot ball league contest.

title: Chess
description: THE master's lot is not an easy one and he is happiest when he is harried. Always immersed in the fantastic art of chess play, he hopes for survival against his anta gonist, but, when mortally wounded, the point is irretrievably lost.

description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24  The St. John's University football club downed Duquesne, 416, here today.

title: Was It a Long Trip Home to This Valley?
description: WHAT was I doing in a rundown cemetery on a late summer's afternoon? Is it enough to say I was bored by sun and water, by kids and crowds, by end less stretches of green wilderness? Per haps. When I think about it now, it seems a morbid, melancholy thing to have done. You see, I talked to them, in my mindmaybe even aloud. I don't know.

title: Heron Island A Natural Showcase of Living Coral
description: HERON ISLAND, Great Barrier Reef, AustraliaUnlike most of the Great Bar rier Reef resorts, this 42acre islet in the Capricorn Group, off the Queensland coast near the port of Gladstone, is itself part of the massive complex of giant coral formations that makes up the reef.

title: To Curb the Monster
description: All mass murders, whatever their motives, share common base of irrationality, even if the perpetrators of the atrocities may legally and medically be adjudged responsible for their actions. Such antisocial pathology appears to link the terrible blood baths of the Sharon Tate killings and the more recent massacre of Dr. Victor Ohta's family in Santa Cruz.

title: Haute boutique
description: Some of fashion's biggest guns, the haute couture designers, are deciding that the future couture lies in thinking small. Small as in small shops, that isboutiques loaded with all couturiers own designs, from clothes to jewels to shoes. And small, as in prices, which, while they are not inconsiderable, are considerably less than couture. Yves Saint Laurent's Rive Gauche was one of the first couturier boutiques to open in New York. Givenchy's new boutique collection is installed at Bergdorf Goodman, and now Valentino has opened a shiny new Madison Avenue shop. Perhaps this trend means a new future for boutiques as well.

title: Bay State Jobless Welfare U
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)  The state Department of Employ ment Security said this week that 74,176 persons drew unemployment compensation checks last month in Massa chusetts, compared to 38,396 a year ago, an increase of 93 per cent.

title: Lindsay Presents Cake For 25th U.N. Birthday
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24The reception mark ing the 25th birthday of the United Nations included a fivetiered birthday cake pre sented by Mayor Lindsay with 26 candlesone to grow on, it was explained.

title: Recordimis
description: ONE flight below the main lobby of the Metropolitan Opera is what is called Found ers Hall. In it are portraits of many of the great singers who have appeared with the company. One of the most striking pictures is of a hand some woman wearing a laurel wreath in her hair, clothed in flowing robes and carry ing a lyre. It is a painting of Louise Homer as Orfeo in Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice. The nobility of the figure, softened by a kind of human ity in the singer's profile, conditions the viewer as to what the singer sounded like. And Miss Homer sounds ex actly as you would expect her to on a new release from RCA called Louise Homer Profile of a Golden Age Con tralto (mono, Victrola VIC 1519).

title: Did the Nazis Win the War?
description: To THE EDITOR: THE other day some stu dents and I were dis cussing the influence of television on Amer ican culture when, rather in passing, one student asked me what program I regarded as most offensive or obscene among the many likely can didates. Somewhat to my sur prise I blurted out, without thinking, Hogan's Heroes Upon more careful refelction, I would stick to that nomi nation; but the somewhat less than conscious way I had suddenly struck upon that program continued to fasci nate me for some days, and tried to reconstruct how I had come to that swift, if visceral, choice.

title: In all his fallibility and also his greatness
description: James Thomas Flexner's bi ography of Washington has grown from the original design of three volumes to four, of which this is the third. Volume I, subtitled The Forge of Ex perience (17321775), appeared in 1965 and covered the rela tively placid period of Wash ington's life, during a small part of which he learned a little about the art of war (though much less than was implied by his military reputation in 1775). Volume II, George Washing ton in the American Revolution (17751783), showed how the unprepared Commander in Chief learned generalship by trial and error assisted by luck, and statesmanship by native ability, emerging at the end of the war as the central figure in the country.

title: Aeroflot Home Service Has Long Way to Go
description: MOSCOW  Aeroflot, the Soviet state airline, has been upgrading its services on in ternational runs. Its sleek IL62 jets, for example, ferry intercontinental passengers in physical luxury compar able to the Americanbuilt Boeing 707's that are used so widely by Western airlines.

title: At home in a national landmark
description: Many people visit national landmarks; few live in them. Yet the private occupancy and preservation of historical buildings is, in James Biddle's view, almost important as transforming them into public museums Mr. Biddle, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, learned this lesson at homenow national landmark. He was raised at Andalusia, his family's Bucks County estate, where he was surrounded by four generations of Biddle possessions. Andalusia, the house from which the estate got its name, is an 18thcentury farmhouse which James's famous ancestor, Nicholas Biddle, added a Greek Revival portico overlooking the Delaware River. This innovation helped establish the temple form in residential architecture in mid19thcentury America. Today, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Biddle, James's parents, live on in Andalusia; it is a place as warm its heirloomfurnished rooms as it is historic. Nearby on the estate James and his wife Louisa are proceeding with the restoration of the Cottage, their gabled Gothic Revival vacation house, shown on page 87.

But Mr. Barber was born during the depression years of the nineteenthirties and is a member of the scarce generation of execu tives. So his road is likely to be both faster and more hectic than that of his pred ecessors, and he looks at his present job as simply a way station.

title: A Cross and a Privilege
description: SOONER or later a conversation with Lili Kraus will take a theological turn. It is perfectly natural for her to speak of the soul versus God, the soul versus oneself, the soul versus the cosmos. Religious terms extend to her discussion of music. If you have truly moved an audience it has been touched by grace Listening to Bee thoven's music is sometimes to under stand redemption A performer must expose himself to shame, and it is both a cross and a privilege.

description: The Long Island Railroad said yesterday that it would provide refunds on weekly or monthly tickets for loss of serv ice during Friday's 10hour strike by three unions.

Y., Oct. 24Mrs. Frances Wells Bernhard, a descendant of Nathaniel Wells, who came here from England in 1629 and pur chased land from the Narra gansett Indians in what is now Rhode Island, and David B. title: News of the Camera World
description: CLAMED by the manu facturer to the world's smallest and lightest rangefinder 35mm cam era, new measures about 2 by 3 x4 inches and has an electrically programmed combination shutter and diaphragm that automatically sets the correct exposure required (a dual set of leaves acts as both shut ter and diaphragm). The cam era comes equipped with a fourelement, 38mm f/2.8 lens, and exposures vary in a con tinuous range from 1/30th to 1/650th of a second.

title: Kerr on 'Trelawny of the Wells
description: PAULINE KAEL was say ing in The New York er a few weeks ago that when, in the old bad but booming days, Metro GoldwynMayer made an Andy Hardy film it may have been conning the public with its tribute to homespun vir tue and ripe domestic senti ment but it at least gave that avid public the sentiment it had bargained for. The cyni cal filmmakers may have been deceivers ever; but they did deliver.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The report in the Oct. 18 Times about Walter N. Roth schild Jr., Jack J. Dreyfus and other top corporate execu tives who are taking up posi tions in the notforprofit service sector only toudhed the very top of the iceberg of discontent in American busi ness. As former director of the nowdefunct FordFoun dationsponsored New Careers program at Columbia Uni versity, I received communi cations from thousands of middle and highlevel execu tives who sought career changes into education, social welfare, library and hospital administration and related fields.

title: The Japanese Challenge
description: Japan's remarkable recovery from World War II, her Phoenixlike rise to third place among the nations of the earth in the size of her economy is no longer a new story. The fatherly indulgence with which this socioeconomic miracle was original ly received in the West, the paton the back congratulations that a star pupil of Western democracy and free enterprise had proved the superiority of this system, even when transplanted to a nonWestern con text, over the rigidly planned econo mies of the Communist nations, are giving way to expressions of concern, articulated with varying degrees of politeness or of alarm, that a Frank enstein has burst or is about to burst on the cozy EuropeandAmericacen tered world scene, a Frankenstein who has learned the techniques of the West without really imbibing its spirit.

title: The Maharana of Amarpur as hotel keeper
description: Oriental and ancient, modern and Jungian, a mandala is a cosmic and also an individual symbolas would, of course, be expected in a Pearl Buck novel. It is in effect an agree able augury. If not a guarantee of happy endings, it is at least a promise of moral and ethical enhancement. In fact, practical ly everyone in this story laid in Northwest India in 1962 winds up finer, nobler, a bit less mundane, an infinitesimal bit more godlike.

description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 24Bob Mantefusco and Greg Smith scored touchdowns on 1yard plunges as Newark State defeated Fairleigh Dick inson in football here today, 137.

title: For Young Readers
description: What's a Something? Ha! Better first you should ask what's a Mylo. He's the one worried that a Some thing will come in through the cave window. As warmly sketched in black and white by Natalie Babbitt, Mylo is, well, a sort of primordial child: a shaggy  haired, pear  shaped body with skinny arms and legs, three square, protruding teeth and a wart on the end of his nose. Just the same he's lovable, almost human. His mother tries to reassure him against ghosts and robbers at tuckin time but that's not what he's afraid of it's a Something. With modeling clay, after working his way through thumbprints, lumps and rolling the stuff into snakes, Mylo gives general shape to exactly what a Something is and in a dreampresented here in six gray pagesmeets a Something which isn't so fearsome after all.

title: LAFAYETTE BEATEN BY BUCKNELL, 3028
