title: To Vonnegut, the Hero Is the Man Who Refuses to Kill
description: WHEN I first saw Kurt Vonnegut Jr., the celebrated author was dreaming his way through the openingnight party for his first play in New York, Happy Birthday, Wanda June, which had its premiere two weeks ago at the Theatre de Lys. Every so often somebody would come over to him and say that the show's peculiar loony pessimism was reminis cent of his most famous book, Slaugh terhouseFive, and Vonnegut would smile with his eyes closed. Laterjust before he sneaked away to watch the TV critics give their verdicts  I caught him leaning far forward in a futile at tempt to sniff at the little pink rose in his buttonhole.

title: Taxi Fleet Owners Warn of a Strike Unless the City Grants Rate Increase
description: Taxi fleet owners expresse.I concern last week that there would be a strike by drivers in a month unless their com panies were given some form of financial relief by the city which controls fare rates.

title: Cousteau's Philosophy of the Sea Helps Get Him Another Medal
description: From birth, man carries the weight of gravity on his shoul ders. But man has only to sink beneath the surface, and he is free. Buoyed by water, he can fly in any directionup, down, sideway  by merely flipping his hand. Underwater, man be comes an archangel.

title: Arlington Auto Ban Lifted
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 24 (AP) The Army has temporarily postponed an order barring cars, and buses from Arlington Na tional Cemetery after Nov. I. A spokesman said tourists would be able to continue driv ing through the cemetery until the Army has had time to study alternatives.

title: Baltimore Seeks To Extradite Man Wanted in Killing,
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 24Offi cials have started extradition proceedings against Arthur F. Turco, a New York lawyer, who was arrested Thursday in Mon treal. He is wanted in connec tion with an alleged torture murder by Black Panthers in Baltimore.

title: MISS. STATE DRUBS SOUTH. MISS. BY 5115
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Oct. 24 (UPI)Joe Reed scored twice and Lewis Grubbs three times today as Mississippi State ran up a 5115 victory over South ern Mississippi, the upstart team that a week ago knocked off powerful Mississippi.

title: FRUGAL WORKER A MODEL IN CHINA
description: PEKING, Oct. 24Should a Chinese inventor come up with the throwaway bottle, it is un likely the Orient would beat a path to his door. He would more probably receive a visit from his local revolutionary committee telling him to forget it.

title: Schoolboy Soccer Star Victim of Cancer at 17
description: Rudy Lamonica, a 17year old soccer player at Ocean side (L. I.) High School, died in South Nassau Communi ties Hospital Wednesday, six months after his right leg had been amputated because of bone cancer.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Oct. 31Jamaica Plains Sports Car Club drivers school and time trials at Lime Rock, Conn. Regis tration: 7 A.M. School in morn ing; acceleration runs and time trials in afternoon. Information: Lars Giers, 470 Glenbrook Road, Stamford, Conn., 06906; phone (203)3488483.

title: Uncollected Prose by W. B. Yeats
description: Yeats hated criticism. For him, it was but a postponement of the creative act; and he rarely forgave himself for hav ing to do it, even for money. As a critic and fledgling au thor trying to make his way in London, he chose only those authors who might conceivably advance his own maturing Celtic aesthetic, but even with These he seems to us now to be most uncomfortable in the critic's mask. Such incom patibilities are evident all through this first volume (of a projected two volumes) of reviews and articles, most of which give full vent to a truculent and shrill brand of poetic nationalism that later was to become so repugnant to him. One has to give some thing of one's self to the devil that one may live. I have given my criticism.

title: EXHIBITIONS
description: MUSEUM OF MODERN ART41 West 53d Street. East 100th Street. Photos by Bruce Davidson of a block of East Harlem. Through Nov. 29.

title: Best Seller List
description: Thisanalysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right haand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearance.

title: In the Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To the Editor: Re J. Samuel Perlman's let ter [Oct. 18 Mailbox], I dis agree with the distinguished observer of the horse race scene in his thesis that Hoist The Flag, Champagne Stakes winner, should not have been disqualified because the horse interfered with at the five eighths pole finished 11th and that, as Perlman states, the four horses who benefited from this decision (stewards dis qualification of Hoist The Flag) were not interfered with.

title: The Nation
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  In nine days, America will vote again. Everywhere, or almost every where, the wandering question er finds a lack of commitment, of enthusiasm, of fervor. Per haps the voters have never seen their Senators and Senatorial candidates as tall men who could articulate and respond to their concerns. Perhaps the con stituents of Borah, Norris, Huey Long, Taft, Lehman and the rest viewed them as lackluster sorts, but it is hard to believe. What is plain this autumn is that most of the Senatorial candidates of 1970 evoke such emotions in a substantial segment of the elec torate.

title: Montclair State's Runners Beat C.C.N.Y., Jersey City
description: WEST PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 24  Montclair State College scored two dualmeet victories in crosscountry at the Garrett Mountain Reservation course today, defeating City College of New York, 2134, and Jersey City State, 2140. C.C.N.Y. beat Jersey City State, 2332.

title: Quince for the Late, Late Harvest
description: AQUINCE TREE adds an extra something to a small home orchard. Fruits look like char treuse apples  sometimes like pearsand ripen after the first frosts to goldenyel low. Quinces are too hard and puckery to be eaten raw, bit their flavor is unique.

title: Dr. Raymond Walters, 85, Dies; Led U. of Cincinnati 23 Years
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 25  Dr. Raymond G. Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati from 1932 to 1955, died today at Drake Memorial Hospital. Dr. Walters, who lived in sub urban Clifton, was 85 years old.

title: Saturday Football
description: Saturday Football

title: Pro Football: Browns, Colts, Lions Win
description: Bill Nelsen, the quarterback who came to the Cleveland Browns from the Pittsburgh Steelers at the end of 1967 with two painworn knees and a rep utation of erratic play, was at his best yesterday. Benched last week while his team lost to Detroit, Nelsen bounced back and picked apart the Dolphins to win, 280, in a National Foot ball League American confer ence same at Miami.

title: Morale Sag Afflicts Career Servicemen
description: The morale of the profes sional American fighting man has been shaken by the frustra tions of Vietnam, a wave of antimilitarism in the United States, race troubles, drugs and reverses and scandals in indi vidual services like the Sonmy affair.

title: VALEK REINSTATED AS ILLINOIS COACH
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 25 After the University of Illinois football team had repeated its threat to boycott practice to morrow, the Athletic Board to clay backed down and rein stated Jim Valek as coach for the four remaining games of the season.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Mr. Nixon's Smutscreen
description: President Nixon has now added a smutscreen to the fog of campaign rhetoric about crime and student vio lence with which he has obscured the nation's real domes tic and foreign problems. No candidate of either party favors crime, violence or obscenity, and the American people clearly want to live in an orderly society where the laws are fairly enforced and justice prevails. But Mr. Nixon's campaign has made no effort to chart solutions to the real and hard problems.

title: Head of Panel on Prisons to Seek End of Crowding
description: The new chairman of the city's watchdog Board of Cor rection said yesterday he would seek to reduce the prison population quicklyin telligently, not indiscriminate ly.

title: DUFFEY OFFERS NORTHERN PLAN
description: A Northern strategy against the Nixon Administra tion was outlined yesterday by the Rev. Joseph D. Duffey, the Democratic candidate for the seat now held by Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut.

title: Wounded Crewmen Returned
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Two wounded crewmen who stayed behind in a Trebizond hospital after their Soviet air liner was hijacked to Turkey returned here yesterday, Soviet newspapers reported today.

title: Campaigning Failsto Stir Much of Middle America
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Oct. 24  The bumpers in Middle America are bare this elec tion year. They're not loving the country, or leaving it. Except in the packing lots around an occasional cam paign headquarters, the cars are not proclaiming any poli tical preference or interest.

title: A New Idea in Discipline: Spanking
description: The title is a bit of a tip off: How to Parent. Un grammatical but catchy, and you get the feeling that the person who wrote it is prob ably dispensing what he feels is some iconoclastic ad vice on child raising.

title: Miss Barbara Bonner Is Bride Of Jonathan M. Marks, Lawyer
description: CANAL WINCHESTER, Ohio, Oct. 25Miss Barbara Bonner, who is studying ror a master's degree in art history at Queens College, was married at her parents home here today to Jonathan Michael Marks, a lawyer with the New York firm of Town ley, Updike, Carter and Rogers. The ceremony was performed by Lancaster Mu nicipal Court Judge S. Farrell Jackson.

title: INCREASE SHOWN IN STEEL ORDERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25Order rates of steel mills have shown a slight improvement recently.

title: GROSS VOWS TO SEEK U.S. AID FOR JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Republican candidate for the United States Senate vowed yesterday, if elected, to try to see that his state received a fair share of Federal funds.

title: Entries for Today's Races at Aqueduct
description: Entries for Today's Races at Aqueduct

title: CHINA SIMPLIFIES MINISTRY LINEUP
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 25  A somewhat smaller Government structure that includes new as well as old faces is taking shape in Peking.

title: State Educational TV Stations May Get More Aid
description: Governor Rockefeller has told the state's eight education television stations that he plans to seek legislation by which the state would pay onethird of their annual operating costs.

title: The Cast
description: The Cast

title: Retailers Dubious On Holiday Trade
description: Christmas business? A better question is will there be a Christmas season this year, snapped a top execu tive of one of the country's bestknown department store chains. With a painful larigh he said, Business is so different right now that it's hard to visualize that we will have a holiday season. He rang off with an admoni tion to hope for the best.

title: 11 Die in Netherlands
description: WAGENBORGEN, Nether lands, Oct. 25 (AP)  Eleven women inmates died in a fire that raged through a mental hospital in this northern Dutch village Saturday night, police reported today.

title: Story Theater Is Here With Version of Grimm
description: I don't think there is such a thing as Story Theater, just theater, says Paul Sills. Then he adds, I don't want to own it. His disclaimer is a little like Lee Strasberg denying the existence of the Method. Mr. Sills invented Story Theater. He is its fore most practitioner, and his original version, based on Grimm's Fairy Tales, opens tonight on Broadway.

title: EGYPT PREPARED TO EXTEND TRUCE, CAIRO PAPER SAYS
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25The United Arab Republic was reported today to be ready to extend for two months the 90day ceasefire along the Suez Ca nal.

title: Three Newsmen to Get Cabot Prizes
description: The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for interAmerican journalism will be awarded Thursday at Columbia Uni versity to John M. Goshko of The Washington Post, John D. Harbron of The l'oronto Telegram and Alberto Dines of The Jornal do Brazil of Rio de Janeiro.

title: Ken Still Wins Kaiser Playoff After Tie With Trevino, Yancey
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 25Ken Still won a playoff for the $30,000 first prize in the $150, 000 Kaiser Open golf tourney today by beating Lee Trevino and Bert Yancey with a birdie on the first extra hole.

title: SANTANA TOPS LAVER IN SPAIN OPEN FINAL
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 25 (Reuters)Manuel Santana of Spain scored today one of his finest triumphs since winning the 1966 Wimbledon title when he beat Rod Laver, the world's topranked player, and took Spain's first open tennis cham pionship.

title: The Cast
description: THE CONSORT (world premiere) chore ography, Eliot Feld; music, Dowland, Neusidler. Morels and Anonymous Composers; orchestrated and conducted by Christopher Keene; costumes, Stan ley Simmons; lightning, Jules Fisher. Presented by the American Ballet Com pany at the Brooklyn Academy of Mu sic.

title: Thieu Ends Parley, but Saigon Gives No Details
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25President Nguyen Van Thieu has ended a two day meeting with all of South Vietnam's major appointed of ficials, but there is no Indica tion that any major decisions were made at the gathering, the most comprehensive in re cent memory there.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: PORTER L. WILLETT
description: Porter Lawrence Willett, a descendant of Thomas Willett, the first Mayor of New York City, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 70 East 77th Street.

title: 2 Queens Men Held as Heads of Boy Burglary Gang
description: Two menone an auxiliary policemanwere arrested early yesterday by detectives in Queens and charged with being the masterminds of a gang of juveniles who looted a school and homes in Bayside.

title: Gary Player's 280 Takes Aussie Open by 3 Shots
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 25 (AP)Gary Player of South Africa held off a lastround challenge by Australia's Bruce Devlin today to win his sixth Australian open golf champion ship.

title: BONDS CALLED FOR REDEMPTION
description: Major Issues Reported in the Week Ended Oct. 17, 1970

title: Reported Deal Aims To Return Britain To Airbus Project
description: PARIS, Oct. 25 (UPI) France, West Germany and the Netherlands have pledged to drop United Statesmade Gen eral Electric jet engines in favor of RollsRoyce of England if the British rejoin the $500million European airbus project, the weekly news magazine Express said today.

title: Vixon's Remark a Courtesy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) A White House spokesman said today that President Nixon's statement of endorse ment for the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, Demo crat of Montana, in New York last Friday was an expression of courtesy. The President's press secretary, Ronald L. Zieg ler, said Nixon's remarks should not be construed as non support for Mansfield's Republi can challenger, Harold E. Wal lace.

title: Migrant Workers Children Leave Fields for Groves of Academe
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Nineteen yearold Jimnay Long looked like a typi cal college student as he wandered around the campus of the State Univer sity Center here in his bleachspattered pants and shirt.

title: TULANE SOUL BOWL HELD TO AID BLACKS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25 Over 25,000 young people, most of them black, crowded Tulane University's Sugar Bowl Stadium yesterday to hear six hours of soul music provided by top soul singers and groups from around the nation.

title: Lucerne Votes to Grant Women Political Rights
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 (AP)The male vot ers of the Swiss canton of Lucerne today voted 25,170 to 14,781 to grant women the right to vote and be elected to public office.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Mrs. Gandhi Avoids Telling Why She Didn't Go to Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)  Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Prime Minister of India, said today that her nation's strong objec tions to resumption of United States military aid to Pakistan had had nothing to do with her absence from a White House dinner last night.

title: Sandler Defeats Dikman To Keep Handball Title
description: Steve Sandler retained his United States onewall hand ball title yesterday by topping Mike Dikman of the Elks Club of Queens, 219, 219, at the Brownsville Recreation Center in Brooklyn.

title: 15 Black Militants Surrender After a 9Hour Confrontation With Detroit Police
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25A nine hour confrontation between a group of black militants and 100 policemen, touched off by the shooting death of a black patrolman and the wounding of another, ended without further bloodshed early this mornning.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: A Game for Eagles, by Oakly Hall (Morrow. $5.95). A trouble shooter gets involved with big business and Fascism.

title: BRITAIN FIGHTING U. S. TRADE BILL
description: LONDON, Oct. 25The Brit ish Government has openly en tered the battle to prevent the United States Congress from passing the protectionist trade bill before it.

title: RALLY BY BRUINS TOPS FLYERS, 43
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) John McKenzie's thirdperiod goal gave the Boston BruinE a 43 uphill victory, over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight. The. Bruins, continued unbeaten through their sixth game.

title: Miss Lannik Wed To Mark Gorstein
description: MERRICK, L.I., Oct. 25 Miss Susana Lannik, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. William M. Lannick, was married here this noon to Mark Gor stein, son of Mrs. Vladimir Gorstein of New York and the late Mr. Gorstein.

title: Chess:
description: Often during the recent chess Olympiad in Siegen, West Germany, Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York scored brilliantly by an un expected sacrifice in the mid dle game. In the Reti Open ing, against Higashi of Japan, the American's winning ma neuver was a twopart ven ture.

title: Goodell's I Will Stand Recalls the Reformation
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell, during his 30minute telecast last night, used words and phrases derived from several sources, including one that might have been suggested to the Senator, the only one of the three candidates who is a Protestant, by the fact that yesterday was Reforma tion Sunday. It was the 453d anniversary of the Protestant Reformation and a date that is observed in most Protes tant churches.

title: Couve Ends Tour of China
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 25 (AP) Maurice Couve de Murville, for mer Premier of France, crossed the border into Hong Kong to day, ending a threeweek tour of Communist China.

title: TINES PICKS EDITOR OF TRAVEL SECTION
description: The appointment of William H. Honan as editor of The New York Times travel section, a part of its Sunday edition, was announced yesterday by Daniel Schwarz, Sunday editor of The Times.

title: Newcomer: Learning on Job Not Easy
description: The reaction to Al Wood all's first start at quarterback for the Jets yesterday was optimistic, perhaps an at tempt at confidence building.

description: The appointment of seven vice presidents of the Ciba Geigy Corporation, the newly merged chemical company, was announced over the weekend by Otto Strurzenegger, presi dent and chief executive officer.

title: Carolyn Pries Has Wedding
description: WYNNEWOOD, Pa., Oct. 25 Miss Carolyn Diane Pries, a psychologist at the Haverford State Hospital, and Dr. Donald Lawrence Nathanson, a psychiatrist practicing in Philadelphia, were married here this after noon at the Main Line Re form Temple, Beth Elohim. Rabbi Theodore H. Gordon performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Samuel Kligfield.

title: Who Minds the Store?
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandCharles Reich has written an enormously in teresting book. I am favorably dis posed for he draws substantially on The New Industrial State (as he is generous in saying) but vanity is not all. His social evidence and interpre tation are wideranging; his conclu sions are well beyond my imagination or courage. It will have a big audi ence and his concept of Conscious nesses I, II and III will affect political thinking and behavior.

title: Old Pro: Making a Pitch for Success
description: Backed into a cornerhis own lockerfor the first time all day, Fran Tarkenton told a bevy of blitzing re porters yesterday his formula of success for a pro passer.

title: Anaconda Turns to Ore in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24The Anaconda Company, whose ma jor mining operations are in leftistmoving Chile, is striving to activate its unworked prop erties in Peru by sharing its holdings with the military Gov ernment here and Japanese in terests.

title: Palme Critical on War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden said today that the Vietnam war was a civil war, not aggression by the north against the south, and the sooner the United States recog nized this, the sooner peace would come.

title: Dance: Feld's Consort
description: The consort in Eliot Feld's ballet The Consort, given its world premiere Saturday night at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music, is no ordinary consort. But then it is no ordinary ballet. Anyone ex pecting a ballet about, say, Queen Victoria's Prince Albert, or even more simply a domestic but still dramatic battle between man and wife is scheduled for disappoint ment.

description: Jerry Quarry vs. Muhammad Ali, 15round heavyweight fight, at Atlanta, 10:40 P.M.

title: American 500 Postponed
description: ROCKINGHAM, N. C., Oct. 25 (UPI)A driving overnight rain caused officials to postpone the sixth annual American 500 NASCAR race at the North Carolina Motor speedway for one week.

title: RACE ISSUE SPLITS A BAPTIST CHURCH
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 25 An allwhite Baptist congre gation, divided for months in a controversy over the member ship application of a black woman and her daughter, split apart here today with a deci sion by the applicants support ers to resign and form a new conuregation.

title: In Cambodia, Soviet Doctors Quandary
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 25The Khmer Soviet Friend ship Hospital, not far from Pre mier Lon Nol's house, has be come a principal center for the people wounded in the Cam bodian war.

title: Contestants Facing Each Other Third Time Since 1958
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 Running for Congress from Connecticut's Fifth District is familiar stuff to the Democratic incumbent John S. Monagan, and James T. Patterson, his re publican challenger.

title: Public Frustrated, Governor Asserts
description: Frustration with the prob lems of modernday living, rather than a sharp swing to the right, was seen by Governor Rockefeller yesterday as the motivation for demands that government get going and meet these problems.

title: CITY URGES THE AGED TO FILE ON RENT RISE
description: The city is urging elderly people who are eligible to file applications for exemption from the rent increases that went into effct last Aug. 1.

title: GEORGE V. MOHN, OF AUTOMATION FIRM
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 25George V. Mohn, president of Advanced Automation Sys tems, Norwalk, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home on Sherwood Lane. He was 48 years old.

title: PLUNKETT STREAK IN PASSING BROKEN
description: If football is a microcosm of, life, as some philosophers sug gest, the country must be over shifting its defenses to the right, or blitzing administra tors from the blind side. How else can one assess these un usual events in last week's col lege football program.

title: Goldberg Says Governor Resorts to MudSlinging
description: Arthur J. Goldberg accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of resorting to demagoguery and mudslinging in the guber natorial election campaign.

title: U.S. AIDES MAY SEE 3 HELD BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25  The Soviet Foreign Ministry in formed the United States Em bassy today that American con sular officials could expect to, meet tomorrow with the three United States Army officers whose light plane landed in Soviet Armenia Wednesday.

title: City Prison Chaplains Load Is Heavy
description: TwentySeven years ago a German lawyer named Fred erick Proelss was arrested by the Gestapo as a political risk and marked for transport to the concentration camp at Buchenwald. At the last min ute he was saved through the intervention of an influential friand.

description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: CHINA LAUDS KAUNDA ON NIXON INCIDENT
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 25  Deputy Premier Li Hsiennien of Communist China praised yesterday the refusal of Presi dent Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to meet with President Nixon in Washington last Monday, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, said today.

title: The Theater: Sensations
description: Sensations, the new rock musical that opened last night at Theater Four (and which I saw at a critics pre view), is suggested by Romeo and Juliet. What suggestion! This is no mere rock updating, but a com plete overhaul.

title: POLICE FRISKED BY YOUNG LORDS
description: Two police officers and patrolman submitted to what they said was a mock frisk ing by members of the Young Lords yesterday when they en tered a church in East Harlem to search for illegal weapons.

title: Bankers Acceptances Fall For First Time in 7 Months
description: Outstanding bankers accept ances fell in September for the first time in seven months, re flecting a large drop in bills created to finance thirdcountry trade, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the weekend.

title: Struggle for the Senate
description: President Nixon and his fellow Republicans are making a major effort to capture control of the Senate. If the Republicans make a net gain of seven seats, they will organize the Senate with Vice President Agnew casting the tiebreaking vote. Because of the accidents of politi cal history, liberal Democrats in the North and West are defending an unusually large number of seats this year. Their success or failure could determine the balance of Senate power for the next several years.

description: Chihuahuas (Long Coat)Martha and William Hooks Jr.'s Kitty's C. and Davis. Chihuahuas (Smooth Coat)M. Patrick Slada's Ch. Weevill's Tricia Too.

description: Nat'l Football League

title: FOREIGN LEADERS MEET WITH NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 President Nixon conferred at the White House today with six foreign heads of state and gov ernment then flew to his Camp David retreat in Maryland to rest overnight and prepare for another round of personal diplomacy here tomorrow.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: POPE CANONIZES BRITISH MARTYRS
description: ROME, Oct. 25Pope Paul VI today proclaimed the saint hood of 40 Roman Catholics in England and Wales who were martyred in the 16th and 17th centuries.

title: 8 Paintings Stolen From 78th St. Home; Valued at $300,000
description: An East Side duplex was robbed of uninsured paintings worth more than $300,000 early yesterday by thieves who left behind paintings worth more than $700,000.

title: TYPHOID CARRIER TIED TO EPIDEMIC
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 25At least one typhoid carrier and poor sanitation caused an epidemic of 56 cases of typhoid fever, in cluding one death, among pas sengers and crew of the cruise ship Oronsay earlier this year, a Canadian health official re norted here today.

title: Soccer Results
description: Soccer Results

title: GHANA WANTS CUT IN DEBT PAYMENTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 Dr. Kofi A. Busia, the Prime Minister of Ghana, has disclosed that his nation will seek a rescheduling of its massive foreign debts  now totaling more than $800mil lionat an international meet ing of its creditors next year.

title: President Nixon's Big Drive
description: The 1970 midterm election has be come a characteristic Nixon effort.

title: GILELS PRESENTS MOZART PROGRAM
description: In the 15 years since he made his American debut, Emil Gilels, the Soviet pianist, has covered a sizable crosssection of the repertory for his instrument, but at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday night he played his first allMozart recital here. The occasion was the opening of the 197071 Hurok Interna tional Series, and he made it special one indeed.

title: NEW ORDERS RISE IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: New orders for American machine tools rose 43.5 per cent in September from the August level, but there was little cheer ing among tool builders. As one industry spokesman remarked, The August orders were at a disaster level. We rebounded in September to the recession level.

title: Seniors in Westchester Schools to Develop Antidrug Programs for Younger Students
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 24 An experimental program on drug abuse based on the theory that students are the best teachers of their peers is being undertaken in several West chester County school systems.

title: Cars Join Camels on Desert of Mauritania
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania Oct. 16Copper and iron an beginning to change this dusty wilderness, but the change as slow as the camel caravan: that roam its desert.

title: Facts on 4th District
description: POPULATION About 540, 000 largely middle and high income, but some also in the lower ranges; primarily white AngloSaxon families with some of Italian and Eastern European heritage.

title: Penny Creator Retires
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) Harry Haenigsen, creator of Penny, the cartoon strip, is retiring after more than half a century of drawing. Mr. Haenig sen is 70 years old.

title: CONDORS BEATEN BY NETS, 11598
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25Rick Barry was back on the sidelines tonight, but the New York Nets continued win ning as they beat the Pitts burgh Cairdors 11598, in an American Basketball Associa tion name at Island Garden.

title: Background on the 5th District
description: POPULATIONPreliminary 1970 census figures indicate the district now has 492,461 inhabitants, a gain of more than 40,000 in the last dec ade. Ethnically, it includes descendants of Yankee set tlers along with large num bers of families of Irish, Italian, French Canadian, Polish, Portuguese, Lebanese and Greek ancestry.

title: TARKENTON PEGS 5 SCORING PASSES
description: A razorsharp Fran Tarken ton and a fine performance by the defensive team brought the New York Giants a 3517 vic tory over the favored St. Louis Cardinals at Yankee Stadium yesterday, and projected them into the Eastern Division race by leaving them only one game out of the lead with eight to play.

title: Rehabilitation Is Rare for Vietnam's Many Wounded Civilians
description: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam One of the most wretched problems facing the Saigon Government is civilian war cas ualtiesrehabilitation for the, hundreds of thousands who are maimed.

title: Top Strike Loss in a Decade Reported by Labor Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) About 2.5 million workers en gaged in 5,035 strikes for a loss of 41.5 million mandays of pro duction time so far in 1970, the Government said today. It was the highest work loss of any corresponding period in the last 10 years.

title: ICKX'S FERRARI WINS MEXICAN GRAND PRIX
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) Jacky Ickx of Belgium won the Mexican Grand Prix today and clinched second place in the world Formula One driving championship. Jochen Rindt of Austria earned enough points to take the title before his re cent fatal crash.

title: Bridge:
description: Play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's metropolitan tournament at the New York Hilton over the weekend was marked by an unusual double victory. Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J., won both the mixed pair and open pair championships. An even more unusual circumstance, per haps unique, was that an other pair, Ronald Anderson of Madison, Wis., and Sue Picus of Milwaukee finished second behind the New York experts in both events.

title: School Names Headmistress
description: The appointment of Mrs. Ed ward B. McMenamin as head mistress of the Nightingale Bamford School has been an nounced by the board of trus tees. Mrs. McMenamin, who has been with the girls school at 20 East 92d Street since 1958 and assistant headmistress since 1965, will succeed Mrs. Fred erick J. Woodbridge on Mrs. Woodbridge's retirement in June.

title: Fire Bombs Damage Glen Cove City Hall In Early Morning
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 25 Fire bombs were thrown through the windows of each end of the twostory City Hall here today, setting off a fire that caused considerable dam age.

title: Credit Markets Entering A Week of Heavy Volume
description: The credit markets face an other historymaking week of financing activity as Federal and local governments and cor porations continue to seek rec ord amounts of funds.

title: The Return
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 25Jerry Quarry's mother was intro duced to Muhammad Ali several days ago, and as the middleaged, hennahaired woman smiled tentatively up through the ropes of the training ring, All boomed: You can't be Jerry's mama,'you too young to be a grandmother. I don't believe it. She was led away, quivering slightly, a brand new Ali fan as surely as her daughterinlaw, who was told several weeks ago: Jerry's wife? Myoh my. You are pretty. Don't know how Jerry's gonna train and stay away from you. The Quarrys, a large California clan of pretty women with sturdy, goodlooking men with leather short coats and greased pomadors, tend to regard Ali's charm as flat tering and his celebrity as a pool of bright light they had been fortunate enough to share, however briefly. The Quarrys, who dress up to attend Ali's workouts in a shabby arena, seem to realize that Jerry is merely a character inserted for con flict and plot development in a story with only one possible hero, and only one possible ending.

title: Random House Aide Named
description: Selma Shapiro has been ap pointed director of publicity and public relations for Ran dom House, Bennett Cerf, chairman of the board of the book publishing company, an nounced over the weekend. Miss Shapiro, who has been with Random House for five years, succeeds Jean Ennis, who died last week.

title: Frankfurt: Of the Pen and the Sword
description: FKANKFURT, West Ger manyThe new center of interest in German culture has the name sachbuch, or thing book. This means not just nonfiction, but more specifically, works on his tory, on science, any sort of useful knowledge.

title: Casualties Reported, U. S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Defense Department denied to day that United States Special Forces troops had suffered cas ualties in Laos in recent months that had not been reported. All casualties for all of Southeast Asia have been re ported on a regular basis, a Pentagon spokesman declared.

title: Big Maine Victory Crucial for Muskie
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 24 As a token of appreciation from the LewistonAuburn Rotary Club, 82yearold Harry W. Rowe the other day presented Senator Edmund S. Muskie with a pine bough to carry as the Senator set forth on his task of making the nation smell better.

title: LEGISLATOR NAMES EDUCATION PANEL
description: A 17member committee of public and private college and university officials was ap pointed yesterday to advise the Legislature on policy affecting higher education.

title: Cleveland Bank Profit Up
description: The Society Corporation, Clevelandbased bank holding company, reported over the weekend a 12.2 per cent in crease in ninemonth operating results to $4.95million, or $2.82 a share. In the first nine months of last year the com pany earned $4.41million, or $2.51 a share. Net income after securities transactions rose tl $5.02million, or $2.86 a share, from $4.98million, or 2.84 a share.

title: MILITARY LEADER DIES IN SANTIAGO
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 25 Gen. Rene Schneider Chereau, commander in chief of the Chil ean Army, died today, almost 72 hours after an unidentified assailant shot him three times in a terrorist attack on his au tomobile.

description: 7:00 (2)News Reports (4)Today: News (7)Listen and Learn

title: NORTHEASTERN WINS CHARLES RACE AGAIN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP) Northeastern University's No. 37 boat successfully defended its championship in the senior eights classification today in the sixth annual Head of the Charles Regatta.

title: FORMER CHAMPION BOASTS OF POWER
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 25After an exile of 3 years, Muhammad Ali, sport's most controversial showman, will return to boxing tomorrow night against Jerry Quarry for the world's invisible heavyweight title.

title: TANKER FIRE OUT AFTER 41 HOURS
description: VENTNOR, Isle of Wight, Oct. 25 (AP)Fire fighters to day extinguished the flames that for 41 hours had ravaged the grounded tanker, Pacific Glory, but oil seepage raised new fears of pollution of beaches.

title: Murphy Plans to Expand Police Anticorruption Unit
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy indicated yesterday that he would increase the size of the police unit that deals with departmental discipline and investigates charges of cor ruption.

title: 250 From West Side Area Protest Delays on Renewal Program
description: More than 250 West Side residents demonstrated near Gracie Mansion yesterday to protest what they regard as Mayor Lindsay's failure to hasten further construction on the West Side Urban Renewal Program.

title: The Only Course for Chile
description: There was never a defensible way to deny Salvador Allende the Presidency of Chile once he had won a nar row plurality in the popular election last month. Demo cratic forces in the National Congress have now formally recognized this by joining Dr. Allende's Popular Unity coalition in a decisive confirmation of this dedicated MarxistSocialist for a sixyear term.

title: Art Tour to Aid Brandeis Libraries
description: The women's committee of Brandeis University has ar ranged a tour of private art collections for Wednesday. The homes to be visited are those of Mrs. Abraham L. Chanin, Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Furman, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Solomon, Mr. and Mrs. I. Donald Grossman, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. M. Stern, Mr. and Mrs. Eli Bennett Levy and Mr. and Mrs. John F. Fleming.

title: School Grants Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The Office of Economic Op portunity announced today grants totaling more than $89, 000 to two more school dis tricts under the agency's inno vativeperfo rmance contracting program under which both teachers and students who do well are paid for performance in mathematics and reading im provement. The money will go to the Stockton, Calif., Unified School District and public schools in Mesa, Ariz.

title: 29,000 Pupils Face Delay as Bus Union Calls Strike Today
description: Bus service for more than 29,000 school children, includ ing 3,000 physically handi capped pupils, was to be inter rupted this morning by strike against the City Wide Transportation Company.

title: COWBOYS TOPPLE CHIEFS, 27 TO 16
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 25The Dallas Cowboys, all but interred by their fans after losing, 5413, to Minnesota last Sunday, came back to life today and teat the champions, the Kansas City Chiefs. 2716

title: Hoekman Sings Schubert Well In Debut Here
description: It took only a few measures for Guus Hoekman to proclaim his uncommonly expressive vocal gifts. The silverhaired Dutch bass was making his New York recital debut at Tully Hall on Saturday night, and the glowing initial impres sion was reinforced throughout his intriguingly unhackneyed program.

title: Brokers See Big Changes With Negotiation of Fees
description: Major structural changes in the securities industry are likely to occur as a result of the proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission to abolish fixed commission rates on all transactions of $100,000 or more.

title: DORATI IMPRESSES IN NEW COMMAND
description: Despite its status as musical standard bearer for our nation's capital, the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington has never been first in the hearts of orchestral music lovers, or near there: Now, with Antal Dorati in his first season as music director, the National Symphony is making serious efforts to rise in the world. That will take time, work and infusions of money, not to men tion talent.

title: CONSUMER BUYING CALLED CAUTIOUS
description: Caution in consumer spend ing, more than any other single factor, is keeping the pace of general economic activity rela tively subdued, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

title: Jack Reigot Weds Mrs. Schwartz
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 25 Mrs. Betty Polisar Schwartz and Jack Reigot were mar ried here this evening at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Joshua Emmer. The cer emony was performed by Arthur Dobrin, leader of the Ethical Humanist Society in Garden City.

title: Desperate but Not Serious
description: WEXFORD, Ireland, Oct. 25Imag ine, summoning up all your resources of fantasy, that President Nixon has uncovered a plot by members of his own Adzbinistration to smuggle guns to Frenchspeaking elements in Can ada. Criminal charges are brought against Secretary of the Treasury Ken nedy and three others. After a long trial all the defendants are acquitted. Crowds carry Secretary Kennedy through the streets, demanding that he take over leadership of the Repub lican nartv.

description: As the 1970 tax year draws to a close, investors have some doubletrouble planning. Is this the year to take cap ital gains or losses?

title: Chile's Middle Class a Willing Force in Move to Left
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 25 The theory that a growing middle class guarantees capitalist stability in Latin America has been under mined by the democratic election of a Marxist Presi dent in Chile.

title: Donohue, in a Lola, Takes Formula A Race at Sebring
description: SEBRING, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP)  Mark Donahue of Media, Pa., started on the pole, held the lead for 99 miles today and won the L. and M. Grand Prix Formula A continental cham pionship sports car race. His average speed was 122.255 miles an hour.

description: TOKYOWhenever one thinks of the People's Republic of China, one at once associates her with the name of Mao Tsetung. And Mao Tsetung is often connected with the idea of dic ta Mr or personality cult.

Scribner's refusal to testify in court on behalf of the existing examination procedures for school principals does little service to the cause of better school leadership selection that it hopes to promote.

title: Voice of Courage
description: A nation starved for political leadership heard last night the moving voice of a public official determined to keep freedom from being assassinated by the ruthless night riders of the political right. The voice was that of Senator Charles E. Goodell explainingextemporane ously and eloquentlywhy he does not intend to submit to the ax with which Vice President Agnew and other Administration hatchet men are attempting to cut short not only his own political career but all independence and progressivism in the Republican party.

title: The Commitment to Ethiopia
description: Many Americans, in and out of Congress, will be shocked to learn that the United States for the last ten years has been committed to oppose any threat to the territorial integrity of Ethiopia. This 1960 pledge by the Eisenhower Administration has been brought to light by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee investigating American overseas commitments.

He is the Rev. Dr. Kent Sig vart Knutson, the 46yearold president of the Wartburg Theo logical Seminary in Dubuque, Iowa. Dr. Knutson won the presidency last Thursday over nine other candidates in an election that was notable for its wide open politicking, something new in American Protestant ism.

The Ford Motor Company di vision said the increases in volved all 18 and 25inch color sets, most 23inch color sets, a 20inch color set and all black and white sets except the 16 inch model. The increases average $5 on black and white and $20 on most color sets, the company said.

Townsend Jr. as acting associate administrator of N.O.A.A. Mr. Townsend has been deputy administrator of the Environmental Science Services Administration since 1968.

title: Not So Contradictory
description: It is easy for the city's restive taxpayers to boil the disclosure that nearly $500,000 in annual wage in creases is being given to 300 professional employes municipal agencies just when Mayor Lindsay has been warning that payless paydays may be needed to keep the city from bankruptcy. In truth, however, the two positions are much less contradictory than they seem.

title: Court Denies Bid by Leone
description: State Supreme Court Justice Simon J. Liebowitz denied yes terday a bid by Brooklyn Borough President Sebastian Leone, to have his name listed on the Conservation party line, as well as the Democratic party line, on the ballot. Mr. Leone, named to the Borough President on the retirement of Abe Stark, is seeking election to a full term. Justice Liebowitz said he agreed with the recent Court of Appeals ruling that the addi tional line was Invalid because the party name could be con fused with the Conservative party.

title: Walsh Resigns Police Post; H.U. D. Official Successor
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy accepted the resignation of First Deputy Commissioner John F. Walsh yesterday and immediately appointed William H. T. Smith to the powerful job, whose prime responsibility is com bating police corruption.

title: Ceausescu Visits Nixon at the White House for Talks on World Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 President Nixon discussed Indochina, Communist China, the Middle East and Euro pean security for two hours today with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, who maintains cordial relations with all the sides in the con flicts. Mr. Ceausescu arrived by helicopter from Williams burg, Va., to a colorful recep tion on the White House lawn. The talks ran 30 min utes overtime, forcing a de lay in a luncheon for the Ru manian leader at the State Department. Mr. Nixon went out of his way to publicize President Ceausescu's two day stay in Washington even though he had already been entertained at the White House on Saturday at a din ner for 31 chiefs of state and government who were in the United States for the 25th anniversary of the United Nations. Mr. Ceausescu was the only Communist head of state to attend the celebra tions, and the Nixon Admin istration, pleased with Ruma nia's independent foreign pol icies in the Communist world, displayed warm friendship for him. This afternoon Mr. Ceausescu met with Secretary of State William P. Rogers, George F. Shultz, director of the White House Office of Man agement and Budget, and Sec retary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin. Then President Ceausescu and his wife attend ed a White House dinner.

title: HARRY J. SEELIO
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 26 Harry J. Seelig of 728 West South Avenue, who retired in 1954 as payroll supervisor for the Home Insurance Company in New York, died today at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. His age was 81.

title: Teacher and a Prosecutor Cited For Contempt in Kent Comments
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 26 (UPI) A special county prosecutor and a professor were cited for contempt of court today for publicly discussing a grand jury report on violence last May at Kent State University. At the same time, four more persons we.a arrested on indictments handed down by the grand jury.

title: Screen: Oliver Cromwell's Rise to Power in England:Richard Harris Plays Him Without Warts
description: Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658), country gentleman, Puritan, passionate reformer, reluctant revolutionist, regicide, a man who fought for freedom but who wound up a military dictator, is the subject of Ken Hughes's big, sober, iron-sided British movie that opened last night at the Rivoli and Fine Arts Theaters. Somewhere between one of its scenes of high council and some earnest debate in Parliament (was it the Rump?), it occurred to me that although fashions in pop historical movies have changed over the years, they haven't changed nearly enough.If Warners had made a movie about Cromwell 30 years ago, it would have starred Errol Flynn in the title role, Olivia DeHavilland as Mrs. Cromwell, George Sanders as poor old Charles I, and Bette Davis, with a French accent, as Queen Henrietta Maria, all under the wonderfully foolish direction of Michael Curtiz. It might have been historically inaccurate, especially when the Queen made a play for Oliver, but it probably would have been fun.In the early 1950's, Fox would have shot it in Cinema-Scope with Richard Burton, George Sanders and maybe Bella Darvi (as the Queen), all under the doggedly faithful direction of Henry King. It would have been as silly as the Curtiz movie, but inching towards the piety of present-day producers.Mr. Hughes's film, which arrives with its credentials for accuracy certified by Will and Ariel Durant, stars Richard Harris as Comwell, Sir Alec Guinness as Charles and Dorothy Tutin as the Queen. Its supporting cast includes some well-trained character actors and dozens of those British extras who apparently devote their lives to playing soldiers, farmers, footmen, nobles, clerks and governesses, always with an abject facelessness that is a reminder of British caste in movies as well as history."Cromwell" is not a silly movie in the sublime Hollywood sense. In fact, the film, taken in conjunction with a handsome program prepared by the producers, gives a rather nice, serious, eighth grade introduction to a place and time that produced Prince Rupert and his pet poodle named Boy, the Grand Remonstrance, and the quote: "Keep your powder dry."Curiously, however, just because it presents its history with such unimaginative respect for factswhich are necessarily truncated and ellipsized, the effect is more historiographically neutral than was Mr. Curtiz's romantic "The Private Lives of Elizabeth and Essex." Mr. Hughes, who wrote the screenplay he has directed, has kept the form of the old Hollywood historical film but eliminated its meaning.There are those obligatory early scenes showing commoners being maltreated by the King's men, Oliver refusing to think ill of the crown, finally making his grave decision to fight for freedom, big battle scenes that can only be shot in Spain, lonely vigils, throne room confrontations, and the like. At the same time, however, Mr. Hughes has abandoned the sort of romantic speculation that might have made Cromwell and Charles at least dramatically interesting, without substituting historical speculation that might have given them significance.

He was a total whirlwind as he smothered Jerry Quarry with the speed he still preserved from three and a half years ago and he crushed him with the extra strength of his new maturity. It was a dazzling exhibition in the ancient Municipal Auditorium here by one of the premier dazzlers of pugilistic his tory. Cassius was simply magnificent in the three short rounds that were.required to demolish the rugged Californian. He was breathtaking with his speed in the first round and devastating with his hitting in the third.

title: Samuelson's Economics

title: Alec Guinness Is King in Sober Film
description: Mr. Harris's Cromwell is a generally spruced up, hand some, wartless, historical personage who speaks his lines with such theatrical in tensity that, towards the end of the film, he sounds as hoarse as an actor at the end of King Lear. description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  George Meany, presi dent of the American Federa tion of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said that he and the acting presi dent of the International Broth erhood of Teamsters, Prank Fitzsimmons, had agreed at a meeting today to stop the jur isdictional fight over Califor nia farm workers.

title: Army Is Developing Battlefield Computers and Detection Devices
description: An electronic battlefield, where sensors and people sniffers pick up hostile move ment, infrared beams guide in fantry to the enemy and com puters evaluate combat infor mation, is the goal of an exten sive research program under way in the United States Army.

title: Court Star Breaks Foot
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  Howard Mathews, George Washington University's star sophomore basketball center, has broken his right foot in practice and will be out of action four to six weeks.

title: Goodell Program Outpolls Lassie in Some TV Ratings
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell, who preempted Lassie on WCBSTV Sunday night and got a higher rating than the series in at least one of the polls, had previously been turned down when the sought to buy time on WNBCTV.

title: 26 Bow Friday At Cotillion Set By Church Unit
description: Some 2,500 people are ex pected at the Grand Ball room of the Commodore Hotel on Friday when 26 young women are presented at the Candlelight Cotillion sponsored by the Women of the Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church.

title: Goldberg Assails Albany Project
description: ALBANY, Oct. 26Arthur J. Goldberg opened the final week Of his campaign for Governor today by charging that the South Mall state office building complex here was a billion dollar blunder.

title: Red Tape Fouls 1969 Snow Removers
description: The 15.4nch snowstorm of February 1969 that virtually paralyzed the city and led to charges that the Lindsay ad ministration had bungled the handling of the emergency especially in Queensis still Dimling the administration.

description: The team standing, with points figured on a 20181614 1210987654321 basis for first through 20th places (first place votes in parentheses) and

title: Teacher Purges Are Seen on Increase
description: Noting a resurgence of the kinds of complaints we haven't been getting in years, the in coming executive director of the New York chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union expressed alarm yesterday at a growing trend of political purges of teachers.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: Man of the association and senior vice president of Hon eywell, Inc., commented. No other industry in the last quarter of a century has had a greater impact on our way of life than the business equipment industry.

description: Article 7  No Title

title: El Paso GasSonatrach Deal
description: HOUSTON, Oct 26 (UPI) The El Paso Natural Gas Corn pany said today that it had agreed to purchase an addi tional 500 million cubic feet per day of liquefied natural gas over a 25year period from, Sonatrach, raising its purchases) from the Algerianrun concern to 1.5 billion cubic feet per day. The company recently filed with the Federal Power Com mission to import the initial one billion cubic feet daily to the Eastern Seaboard. Deliv eries are expeoted to start in late 1974.

title: President of National Distillers Named Chief Executive Officer
description: A change in the top job at the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation was an nounced yesterday.

title: FEDERAL CARS GET LEADED GAS CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 President Nixon ordered today that all Federal vehicles must be operated on lowlead or un leaded gasoline wherever prac tical, and he asked the Gov ernors of all the states to use the same restriction with state owned vehicles.

title: Levitt for Controller
description: As I see my responsibility, says State Controller Arthur Levitt, it is to make sure a full dollar's worth goods and services is received by the state for every single dollar spent.

title: Lisa Judith Schnitzer to Be a Bride
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 26  Miss Lisa Judith Schnitzer and Richard Jeffrey Plavin, teachers at the B'nai Emunah Religious School here, plan to be married next fall.

title: Close Race Expected in Connecticut 6th
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 26  In the last few months, voters in the Sixth District have become familiar with two sights  a metal shopping bas ket carried under the arm of a buoyant brunette, and a 20 foot Dodge camper careening along the backcountry roads.

title: Strike Halts Parcel Deliveries
description: The United Parcel Service said yesterday that an illegal strike by a small group of driv ers in Secaucus, N. J., had in terrupted delivery operations in northern New Jersey and sec tions of Brooklyn and Queens. The cause of the walkout was not explained, but a spokesman for Local 804 of the Teamsters Union said that members had been instructed to return to their work.

title: GIANTSJETS GAME REWRITES SCRIPT
description: A funny thing happened to the Giants on their way to that climactic intracity clash with the Jets.

title: Unbeaten Pistons Crush Sonics, 142111, for Eighth Victory, a Club Record
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP)The Detroit Pistons established a club record for consecutive vic tories tonight when they trounced the Seattle Superson ics, 142111, for their eighth victory without a loss in the National Basketball Association season.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: YOUTHS CAN END THEIR DEFERMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, the director of Selective Service, ordered local draft boards today to withdraw deferments immedi ately from all men who request, that their deferments be can celed.

title: Republicans Are in Trouble in Florida
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Oct. 26  President Nixon will come to Florida tomorrow in an attempt to rescue two Republicans who are in trouble.

title: Lefkowitz Bids Court Close Polluting Refinery
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 26 (AP)  State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had asked the courts to close the Mobil Oil refinery in Buf falo for polluting the Buffalo River.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: Ali Says Frazier Will Be Easier
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 26By the end of an unusually fastpaced first round that wiped out any vague doubts he might have held about his return to the ring tonight, Muhammad Ali wondered only if he could keep dancing around Jerry Quarry and jabbing him in the face without getting hit himself.

title: Schneider Concert Charms Audience
description: Alexander Schneider is, by ordinary standards, no con ductor at all. He sat at a music stand facing a chamber orchestra in the New School Auditorium on Sunday night, occasionally lending a hand with his fiddle, leaping to his feet momentarily to punctu ate a phrase by a sweep of his bow or otherwise indicat ing, in unorthodox ways that would get him thrown out of many a conducting class, how the music should go.

title: L'Aiglon to Close Two Units
description: L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it planned to close its Kramer Company blouse division and its Gayle Kirkpatrick couturier operations, which have been its two loss divisions. The com pany said that it would concen trate in the immediate future on its profitable dressmanu facturing business and its retail operations.

title: JOHN F. SCHMIDT
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Oct. 26 John F. Schmidt of 427 Boule vard, formerly chief engineer of the Federal Shipyard in Kearny for 30 years, died yesterday at his home. His age, was 87.

title: Foreign Accounts Curb Is Signed by President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)President Nixon signed into law today legislation to crack down on illegal use of secret foreign bank accounts, to ban unsolicited mailing of credit cards and to protect consumers against mistakes in credit agency reports.

title: OCEAN AIRLANES TO ADD CAPACITY
description: The traffic capacity of the overcrowded North Atlantic airlanes will go up by 50 per cent in about a year, John H. Shaffer, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administra tion, said here yesterday.

title: 5 Winners for Gambardella
description: LINCOLN, R. I. Oct. 25 (AP) Carl Gambardella, the meet's leading rider, brought home five winners today, including four trained by Dick Barnett, at Lincoln Downs.

title: GOLD PRICES SOAR TO PEAK FOR YEAR
description: LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Gold prices hit new peaks for this year in the gold mar kets of London, Zurich and Beirut today with gains vary ing between 35 and 95 cents an ounce. There was a fairly heavy demand in all the mar kets although not all from the same buying source.

title: Federation of Scientists Says Ads Alleging Soviet Nuclear Lead Are in Error and Use Scare Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  A scientists organization labeled today as scare tactics an ex tensive advertising campaign by the American Security Council asserting that the So viet Union had taken the lead in strategic nuclear weaponry from the United States. The United States is ahead, not behind, the Soviet Union by any important measure of strategic force effectiveness, the Federation of American Scientists insisted in a state ment.

title: Aircraft Maker Reports
description: The Boeing Company made a substantially better showing in the third quarter of this year over the results for the corresponding 1969 period, but declined from midyear, with fourthquarter earnings forecast at a low level. Nine month earnings lagged behind those of the previous year.

title: GRAIN PRICES CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Favorable harvesting weath er, coupled with profit taking, sent prices of corn and soy bean futures lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Steel Output Off 0.2%
description: Steel production fell last week by 0.2 per cent, com pared to output the week be fore, marking the fifth drop in Succession. However, the cumu lative decline since the middle of September was a surprisingly small 5.4 per cent, in view of the General Motors strike and otherfactors tending to weaken, steel markets.

title: Fortunes Declining
description: Miami's basketball fortunes have declined since the gradu ation of Rick Barry, its all American, after the 1964 sea son. While Barry played for the Hurricanes and his fatherin law, Bruce Hale, was coach, Miami had 233, 207 and 224 wonlost seasons.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: SCHOOLBUS STRIKES AFFECT 29,000 HERE
description: As the strike of schoolbus drivers went into its second day today, the Board of Educa tion began distribution of emer gency public transportation tickets, good for the duration of the strike, to all affected school districts. The tickets are to be given to any student deprived of transportation.

title: B. & M. MERGER MOVE ADVANCES IN COURT
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  A move to include the Boston & Maine Railroad in the 1964 merger of the Norfalk & West ern Railway system with the New York, Chicago & St. Louis Railroad Company cleared a legal hurdle today in Federal Court.

title: Radios in Salmon Track Spawning Runs
description: RICHLAND, Wash., Oct. 24 This is the land of the broad casting fish.

title: P.B.A. TO REQUEST $16.000 PAY BASE
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yester day that it would seek a salary of at least $16,000 a year for patrolmen and the right to re tire after 25 years at full pay.

title: College Conference Standings
description: College Conference Standings

title: 3 Negro Freshman Players Reinstated at Idaho State
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Oct. 26 (AP)The Idaho State football coach, Ed Cavanaugh, reinstat ed today three Negro freshman football players who had been suspended last week for boy cotting a practice.

title: Judge Refuses to Block PowellRangel Contest
description: A Federal judge refused yes terday to block the elections next Tuesday in the 18th Con gressional District, where Rep resentative Adam Clayton Pow ell is contesting his narrow de feat by Charles B. Rangel in last June's Democratic primary.

title: Bout With Ali Looms In Frazier's Dreams
description: Yank Durham, manager of Joe Frazier, the heavyweight champion, said last night that Frazier would like to fight Muhammad Ali as soon as possible.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: James Reston's Oct. 18 column en titled Let the Buyer Beware might more appropriately be entitled Let the Reader Beware. While I recognize the tongueincheek tone of the arti cle, it nonetheless reflects a considera ble misunderstanding of the political broadcasting bill which the President vetoed.

title: Foster Wins Rifle Match; Soviet Takes Team Title
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 (AP) Maj. John Foster won a gold medal for the United States to day with a 566x600 in the Army rifle match at the 40th world shooting championships.

title: Business Machines Go on Display Here
description: The 12th annual exposition of the Business Equipment Manufacturers Association opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum with less frills and fewer exhibitors than last year but still with an abundance of optimism.

title: LEWIS BABCOCK, 63, WAS AMEX MEMBER
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 26 Lewis D. Babcock, a retired member of the American Stock Exchange and a founder of L. D. Babcock & Co., died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 63 years old and had lived in Christiansted, St. Croix, Virgin Islands, since retiring from the Amex in 1960.

title: Agnew Pledges the South A Seat on Supreme Court
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 26Vice President Agnew, cam ipaigning in the Carolinas, pledged today that the Nixon Administration would put a Southerner on the Supreme Court, stand with the South behind neighborhood schools and protect the region's tex tile industry.

title: Dr. John F. Weston Dies; Was Surgeon in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 26 Dr. John F. Weston, e retired surgeon, died yesterday in Har lem Valley State Hospital after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 280 Bronxville Road. He retired in 1966.

title: RCA Is Studying Methods Of Consolidating Facilitie
description: The RCA Corporation indi cated yesterday that it was studying ways to consolidate certain of its consumerproduc tion facilities in an effort to help meet rising costs of mate rials and manufacturing.

title: CAMBODIA DRIVE OPENED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 (AP)Led by two armored columns and supported by American artillery, 6,000 South Vietnamese troops were report ed to have pushed into the war ravaged Cambodian town of Snoul today in a new offensive.

title: MRS. CROSS APPEALS TO FRONT IN QUEBEC
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (Reu ters)Mrs. James R. Cross, wife of the senior British Trade Commissioner in Quebec, to night appealed to the Front for the Liberation of Quebec to free without delay her hus band, who was kidnapped Oct. 5.

title: Cigarette Makers Offer Data: on Tar and Nicotine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Eight cigarette manufacturers have submitted a formal pro posal to the Federal Trade Com mission for voluntary listing tar and nicotine rating in their ad vertisements.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: GARDEN PRODDED IN TICKET PROTEST
description: In response to more than 100 letters of complaint received; by his office, Attorney Gen eral Louis J. Lefkowitz urged Madison Square Garden yester day to make available to the general public and casual visi tor more tickets for the Knick and Ranger games.

title: SQUIBB TO ACQUIRE LANVINCHARLES
description: Squibb BeechNut, Inc., ha agreed in principle to acquire LanvinCharles of the Ritz, Inc. a leading company in the cos metic and perfumes industry through an exchange of stock Based on the closing price of Squibb on the New York Stoct Exchange yesterday at 65 the transaction is valued at $197,500,000. Un der the agreement, shareholders of Lanvin  Charles would receive 0.6253 of a share of Squibb common for each common share held on the ef fective date of the merger and 0.8129 of a share of Squibb common for each Lanvin Charles preferred share.

title: WASHINGTON HIGH TO RESUME TODAY
description: George Washington High School, which has been closed for more than a week because of student disorders, will be reopened this morning but only for seniors.

title: BONTE II NOTCHES JUMPING VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Conrad Homfeld, tall, thin, 18 years old and new to interna tional competition, rode Bonte II, also relatively new in inter national company, to victory in the jumping competition of the Washington International Horse Show tonight.

title: Ashe No Longer Interested In Playing in South Africa
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  Arthur Ashe, who was barred by South Africa earlier this year, said tonight he now had no interest in play ing tennis there.

title: Decisions Due Soon by Britain On Airbus and RollsRoyce Aid
description: LONDON, Oct. 26The finan cial future for British commer cial aircraft and aircraft en gines will be decisively influ enced by Government decisions in the next few days.

title: FACULTY OF CITY U. GIVEN GUIDELINES
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion yesterday adopted guide lines to discourage fulltime faculty members of the City University from accepting ex cessive outside.work.

title: Charisma Is as Charisma Does
description: DENVERIt rankles Senator George McGovern that the widely accepted knock on him as a political leader is that he does not charge up the voters to shrieks of enthusiasm. No charisma, political buffs are apt to say, when discussing the man who evoked the biggest popular response of the 1968 Democratic convention, for his rousing performance in the candi dates debate before the California delegation.

title: MRS. WILLIAM CRADDOCK
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 26 Mrs. Mabel Foster Craddock, former executive assistant to Arthur J. Morris of the Morris Plan Bank in New York, now the Bank of Commerce, died yesterday at her home. She was the widow of William A. Craddock and lived at 44 Ledge wood Drive. Her age was 86.

title: Canadian Plans to Open China Embassy by January
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 26 (Reu ters)  Canada's newly ap pointed provisional envoy to Peking, John Fraser, said here today that he hoped to have an embassy set up in the Chinese capital by January.

title: TRIAL OF BLACK G.I. OPENS IN GERMANY
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 26Sgt. James Earl Hob son, who was arrested 43 times as a youth in Chicago's black ghetto and who was later dec orated for heroism in Vietnam, went on trial before a general courtmartial today on charges of attempted murder and con spiracy.

title: Ringside Crowd Forms Dazzling Backdrop
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (AP) They came in sleek limousines, mink and flamboyant hats to night to cheer their hero, Mu hammad Ali, in his comeback. It was a page out of the Roaring Twenties.

title: THOMAS M. DAVIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) Thomas McParlin Davis, asso ciate chief counsel of the Inter nal Revenue Service, died yes terday in Georgetown Univer sity Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 62 years old and lived in Bethesda Md.

title: Asia Expert Says Peace Talks Must Be Widened
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26A former Government specialist on Asia said today that allied intervention in Cambodia had made it almost impossible to negotiate a Vietnam settlement in Paris without enlarging the talks to deal with Cambodia and Laos as well. Chester L. Cooper, former aide to W. Averell Harriman and for two decades a Govern ment official said at a news conference that he believed that President Nixon's latest proposal for an Indochina con ference and an Indochina cease fire reflected recognition that the Paris talks were unlikely to make much progress as pres ently constituted.

title: Leary, or a Lookalike, Appears Briefly in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 A thin graying man identified as Timothy Leary burst out of a luxury hotel here tonight and sped off in a taxi into the fragrant Mediterranean night.

title: Egypt Recasting Strategy
description: CAIRO, Oct. 26  Egyptian military planning for action if the ceasefire with Israel col lapses was reported today to be based on a developing strategy for a war of liberation, not a return to the earlier limited tactics of hitandrun attrition against the Israeli forces.

title: ARTHUR WOLLENHAUPT
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 26 (AP)  Arthur F. Wollen haupt, former president and treasurer of the Poughkeepsie Newspapers, Inc., died yester day at Vassar Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: D'Arcy Executive Panel Chief Out
description: Daniel H. Lewis, chairman of the executive committee, vice chairman and corporate creative director of D'Arcy Advertising Company, is out.

description: Senator Jacob K. Javits warned here yesterday that the world was on the brink of catastrophic trade war.

title: Leader of Economic Mainstream
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26The father of four very athletic sons, Paul Anthony Samuelson finds himself.rush ing one of them with a con cussion or lacerations to a hospital emergency room about three Saturdays a year.

title: L.I.R. Freight Halted in Dispute on Explosives
description: Movement of freight on the Long Island Railroad was halted yesterday after the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers re fused to move cars until its members were given instruc tions about the hauling of ex plosives or other hazardous materials.

title: EXCONVICT JAILED IN SHOOTING HERE
description: A 26yearold Brooklyn ex convict was held without bail yesterday on charges of at tempted murder in the shoot ing of two policemen who were seeking to question him about a boldun.

title: ROBERT M. EWING
description: CARMEL, Calif., Oct. 26 Robert M. Ewing, an associate professor of English emeritus at Bucknell University, who re tired to Carmel Valley Village, died today after a short ill ness. He was 71 years old.

title: The Cultural Contradiction
description: The ultimate support for any social system is the acceptance by the popu lation of a moral justification of au thority. The older justifications of bourgeois society lay in the defense of private property. But the new capital ism of the twentieth century has lacked such moral grounding.

title: InjuryTroubled Jets Get Guard From Bengals for 71 Draft Pick
description: The New York Jets, over barrel with eight games to go, made a trade yesterday in an effort to reinforce their rid dled ranks before tackling the revived Giants Sunday in Shea Stadium.

title: French Toughen Stand on Market Entry
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 26  The French position toughened today on a key British demand for entry into the European Common Market, pointing the way to the first skirmish since negotiations opened nearly four months ago.

title: English Women Shut Out U.S. in Field Hockey by 20
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Oct. 26The touring English wom en's field hockey team defeated the United States national team, 20, today in an exhibi tion game at Port Jefferson High School field. Jane Barrell, the right inner, scored both goals.

title: American Lutheran Church Is Debating Use of the Title Bishop
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 26  The fifth general convention of the American Lutheran Church began debate today on proposed major structural changes within the denomina tion, including use of the title Bishop.

title: Oldham Tied in Rugby,1515
description: LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Oldham drew with Wakefield Trinity, 1515, in the only Eng lish Rugby League match played tonight.

title: The Goodell Program
description: I don't know whether Good ell really thought about quit ting, an important New York Republican said yesterday, but I do know he had to do some thing desperate and dramatic and he did it rather well.

title: Chile Buries General as Martyr
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 26 Tens of thousands of Chile ans gave a marty's funeral today to Gen. Rene Schneider Chereau, Commander in Chief of the army, whose name the public barely knew a year ago.
