title: The Judicial Candidates
description: In a time of trial for the courts and the judicial system, once again New York voters go through the ridiculous charade of selecting judges by rubber  stamping party designees. Presumably, impartial judges do not run on issues; for them to be identified as Democrats, Repub licans, Conservatives or Liberals is at once contradictory and meaningless. The familiar system of double and tri ple endorsements underscores the tradeoff method now prevailing among parties. The voter goes through the ritual of choosing among unknowns on a long ballot.

At the Village Vanguard, where he is ap pearing through tonight with a supporting trio called The Choir, he is exhibiting only the last three of his talents, although he said it was his study of the martial arts that opened him up so he could be a jazz violinist and singer.

Jews, Italians and Irish account for about half of the population, and blacks and Puerto Ricans make up the other half. The last two groups live in the southern end of the district in the Hunts Point section, one of the city's worst slums.

He might be accused of lack of sophis tication.

description: Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel, ad dressing the United Nations General Assem bly yesterday, stressed Israel's insistence that Egypt pull back missiles from the cease fire zone along the Suez Canal before. Israel rejoins peace negotiations. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: TINY BRITISH FORCE TO REMAIN IN ASIA
description: LONDON, Oct. 28The Gov ernment formally decided to day to keep British forces in Southeast Asiabut at a level so low that it was promptly dismissed by critics as insig nificant.

title: French Bill May Retire Executives at 65
description: PARIS, Oct. 28The French Government has decided to legislate age limits for business executives, a step unprece dented in a capitalist society.

title: G.O.P.Conservative Opponent Running Hard in Bronx
description: For the last six years Rep resentative James H. Scheuer divided his time among his apartment in the Bronx, an of fice in Washington and his headquarters in the 21st Con gressional District, in the west central section of the Bronx.

title: QuickWitted Variety Show Returns to Soviet TV
description: MOSCOWThe Club of the Jolly QuickWitted, the Sov iet Union's most popular tele vision show, reached a new highor an old lowin its fall premiere last week.

title: Better Now Than Never
description: President Nixon's lastsecond signing of the bill to help states and cities build systems for solidwaste disposal and recovery is gratifying, whether or not his apparent change of heart was stimulated by the imminence Election Day. Certainly the bill, as passed unanimously by both houses of Congress earlier this month, calls for a great deal more money than the President had contem plated spending; even now there is a grudging note the White House announcement that the President would withhold some of the funds if, in his opinion, they were not being spent wisely.

title: 'House of Dark Shadows' Stresses the Sinister
description: The vampire movie is such an agreeable type, with so many good and even great examples  remember "Vampyr" and "Nosferatu"that it would seem to have taken an act of unusual perversity to have made anything as dreadful as "House of Dark Shadows," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.The cast, the director, the characters, the locales and the situations derive of course from the "Dark Shadows" television series, but despite the identity of credits, the film looks like desperate imitationand by an inferior team of plagiarists at that.The film emphasizes the sinister rather than the benign aspect of much-tormented Barnabas Collins (Jonathan Frid). Although he wants Dr. Julia Hoffman (Grayson Hall) to cure him, his reasons ("Do you think anyone could enjoy an existence like mine? I haven't seen the light of day for almost 200 years!") do not seem the most exalted. As for lovely Maggie Evans (Kathryn Leigh Scott), he wants her any way he can get her. And although he, not she, insists on a wedding ceremonytwo coffins, a stone altar, stage smoke and miles of phony cobwebshis intentions won't bear inspection.Not that they are ever inspected. "House of Dark Shadows" really has no subject except its special effects (which aren't very good) and its various shock sequences. Characters are picked up and dropped with an indifference unacceptable even for soap opera. And by the end of the movie everybody is either dead or discarded or a vampire (or all three) except for Miss Scott and her fianc (Roger Davis) and Joan Bennett, who has the good fortune to settle into a catatonic state rather early on.Lest all this sound like good clean fun, prospective audiences should understand that it is neither fun nor even especially clean. Indeed, "House of Dark Shadows" overflows with blood  though it is pretty pallid in its sex, which is what I had thought vampirism was all about.

title: Penn Central Rate Increase Is Opposed by Lefkowitz
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday asserted his vigorous opposition to a Penn Central request to in crease passenger fares by 10 per cent from New York to Albany.

title: EUROPEANS LEARN THERE'S U.S. VOTE
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) Thanks largely to Vice Presi dent Agnew, Europeans are gradually becoming aware that the United States is to hold midterm elections Tuesday.

title: Aide Asserts Pathet Lao Expects Victories but Is Hopeful on Talks

description: When Richard Derecktor Schwartz was appointed to a teaching post at North western University in 1961, a colleague named Harry V. Ball described him as the best sociologist of law in the country.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI) President Nixon's plane landed at O'Hare International Airport here tonight.

title: U.S. Expects Soviet to Take the Initiative When Arms Talks Resume in Helsinki
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The United States looks to the Soviet Union to take the major initiative at what is expected to be a fairly brief round of the talks on limiting strategic arms starting Monday at Hel sinki. Finland.

title: Southwest Cooking: Not All That Authentic, but It's Fun Food

It is admirably varied, based largely on corn and beans and chilies that range from the mild to the piercingly hot, and it is derivedrather loosely, Mexican purists sayfrom the food of Mexico.

But labor leaders, while pleased with this trend, fear that it has come late and that widespread apathy among union members may sharply undercut the union vote.

title: J. F. Trouts Have Child

Mrs. Trout is the former Miss Patricia Daley, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Daley of Greenwich. Mr. Daley is sports columnist for The New York Times. Mr. Trout is vice president of Ries, Capiello & Colwell, a New York advertising agency. The child, the sixth for the Trouts, will be named Peter.

title: Premier Returns to Tunisia

The Court will hear ap peals by Dennis C. McGautha of Los Angeles and James Crampton of Toledo, both un der death sentence.

description: A fishing port scene by Andr Derain made a world auction record last night at $225,000 in a sale of impressionist and mod ern paintings at the Parke Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. A work of 1905, in bril liant color and composition, Port de Peche, Colliours was purchased by Col. C. Michael Paul, a collector who has made numerous important art dona tions to the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art. Another version of the scene is in the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad.

title: State to Change Truck Fuel
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller directed the Office of General Services today to equip two messenger trucks to use natural gas as fuel in a move to reduce the output of carbon monoxide.

title: 2d Daily News Poll Shows Rockefeller And Buckley Lead
description: Governor Rockefeller and James L. Buckley, the Conserv ative party candidate for United States Senator, were ahead of their opponents in the second survey of The Daily News's straw vote, which was published today.

title: Mayor Appoints Policeman
description: A 42yearold police sergeant, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as his assistant in the Office of Special Com munity Problems. The sergeant, Carleton Irish, who joined the Police Department in 1954, will work with Barry H. Gottehrer, the Mayor's executive assistant for special community prob lems as well as the Mayor's Education Task Force on School and Community Problems.

title: U.S. Ready to Expand Program To Curb Airport Cargo Thefts
description: The Treasury Department is, ready to apply on a nationwidel basis special Customs cargo security measures that have been in effect at Kennedy In ternational Airport since May.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: ManHour Rate Up
description: Output per manhour in the private economy increased sub stantially during the third quar ter, President Nixon's chief economic adviser said here yes terday evening.

title: New Books
description: American Empire: The Political Ethics of TwentiethCentury Conquest, by John M. Swomley Jr. (Macmillan. $6.95; paper hound, $1.95). A critique of as sumptions about foreign policy and recent history.

title: EBAN TELLS U. N. U. A. R. PULLBACK IS KEY TO TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28  Israel stressed be fore the United Nations today that ArabIsraeli peace talks could be resumed only if the conditions existing in the Suez Canal area at the start of the present 90day ceasefire were restored.

title: Excerpts From a Speech Given by Murphy on Police Corruption
description: Except for your paycheck there is no such thing as clean buck. It Is Just as cor rupt to tolerate the book maker as it is to ignore the drug pusher. It is just as dis honest to accept the favor of the traffic violator as it is to exact a gratuity from the liquor licensee.

title: Giovacchino Forzano, 86, Dies; Wrote Puccini Opera Librettos
description: ROME, Oct 28Giovacchino Forzano, a versatile man of letters who wrote librettos for Puccini operas and was co author of plays with Benito Mussolini, died here today after a short illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Fans Give Baeza a Riding
description: Jockeys started getting an extra $10 at Aqueduct yes terday for riding losers, and some of them earned extra jeers for doing it.

title: Janis Joplin's Death Is Laid To an Overdose of Heroin
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP) Janis Joplin, the blues singer, died from an accidental over dose of heroin, the Los Angeles County coroner's office said today.

title: CoPilot of Air Taxi Dies From a Fall During Flight
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 28 (UPI)The copilot of a Carib bean Island Airways air taxi fell to his death today while apparently trying to close a door that had opened in flight, the Federal Aviation Adminis tration reported.

title: FIRST SPACE TALKS ON DOCKING OVER
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28  Soviet and American officials agreed today to continue efforts lead ing to the development of docking system that would en able their spacecraft to link up in space.

title: WILLIAM KAY
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 28William Kay, president of the Phillips Manufacturing Com pany of Newark, a maker of advertising and campaign but tons and badges, died today in St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 69 years old and lived at 320 South Har rison Street.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS LEAD LATE RALLY
description: A brisk rally in the final minutes of trading yesterday led the popular averages out of minus territory into the land of small gains.

title: Clay Loses Nothing in the Translation
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) Muhammad All was ac claimed in many parts of the world today for his victory over Jerry Quarry and many experts predicted he would regain the heavyweight championship.

title: Baby Food Labels To Tell Consumer Of Nutrition Value
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 , The Food and Drug Adminis tration acted today to provide mothers with a better idea of what they are feeding their) babies by ordering the makers of specialty baby foods to label the nutritional value of their products.

title: Homeowners Deny Role In PostFight Robbery
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (UPI) The owners of a house used by a gang of thieves in the holdup of about 100 boxing fans Monday night denied to day that they were involved in the robbery.

title: Chad Reports 13 Rebels Slain
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, Oct. 28 (Agence FrancePressc)French and Chadian forces have killed 13 rebel Toubou tribesmen and captured 4, a military source reported here today.

title: UNBEATEN STRING REACHES 7 GAMES
description: The Rangers continued to be faster, stronger and better than the opposition last night, and they wore down the Detroit Red Wings, 41, with three final Period goals.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
description: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY

description: Treasury Statement

title: Governor's Backers Active on the Phone
description: A battalion of Rockefeller workers is on the telephone six hours a day  and has been for weeks  reaching Demo crats and independents to identify the Governor's sup porters outside Republican ranks, put them to work and make sure they vote on Nov. 3.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Tucker of Giants Expects He'll Get Foe's Attention
description: Bob Tucker, the Giants rookie tight end, had a busy afternoon against the St. Louis Cardinals, but whether he'll be able to produce as well against the Jets on Sun day remains to be seen.

title: EMIL TALAMINI
description: Emil Talamini, of 70 East 10th Street, a real estate broker and investor long active in the Greenwich Village area, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Five Agencies to Seek Interbank Card Account
description: The Interbank Card Asso ciation is understood to be reviewing its advertising.

title: Delay in Mitchell Trial
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 28 A military spokesman said to day that the courtmartial of Staff Sgt. David Mitchell on charge arising from the alleged massacre at Mylai 4 would probably not resume for an other two weeks.

title: Aqueduct Entries for Today
description: Aqueduct Entries for Today

title: Hayward to Present Egg
description: Leland Hayward, whose Broadway projects have col lected two Pulitzer Prizes (State of the Union and South Pacific), one Drama Critics award (South Pa cific) and three Tonys (Sound of Music, South Pacific and Mister Roberts), is planning his first Off Broadway venture.

title: U.S. Will Create a Sky Marshal Force on Hijackings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Treasury Department's Bureau of Customs will or ganize and train a perma nent sky marshal force of at least 2,000 security officers to prevent hijacking of air liners, it was announced to day.

title: Judge Asks Nine to Behave
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Nine Earth Day demonstrators were placed on their good be havior today in Suffolk Su perior Court. Judge A. Frank Foster told the defendants, who were appealing District Court convictions, that he would dis miss their cases if they did not get into any trouble during the next 90 days. The nine were convicted of disrupting passen ger travel at Logan Interna tional Airport last April 22.

title: Pilot Dies on a Flight; Plane With 54 Is Safe
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2S (AP)The pilot of a Trans World Airlines plane died in flight of an apparent heart attack today, but the Chi cagotoSan Francisco flight landed safely in Cedar Rap ids, Iowa, with 54 persons aboard, an airline spokesman here said.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Obituary 3  No Title

title: Football Transactions
description: IETSEmerson Boozer, running back, placed on move list.

title: Hope for Investment In Chile and in Peru Is Seen by Banker
description: Sir Maurice Parsons, chair man of the Bank of London and South America, said yes terday that he saw new signs of hopefulness for private in vestment, particularly interna tional banking, in Chile and Peru. The bank is a major trad ing bank in Latin America.

title: BOEING IS ACCUSED ON COST ESTIMATES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Congress's watchdog inves tigating agency contends that the builder of the Apollo Saturn 5 rocket booster increased po tential earnings at least $695, 000 by overstating costs by $2.7million.

title: ELMER F. BETH
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 28 (UPI)Elmer F. Beth, professor or journalism at the University of Kansas for 30 years, died today at the age of 67.

title: EAST GERMAN GROUP, IN PARIS, URGES TIES;
description: PARIS, Oct. 28A high ranking delegation from East Germany appealed here today for the establishment of full diplomatic relations between its country and France.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Obituary 2  No Title

title: Trenton Emergency Called After Rocks Are Thrown
description: TRENTON, Thursday, Oct. 29 Sporadic rockthrowing and windowbreaking erupted in the predominantly black western area of this city last night onthe third day of busing of black and Puerto Rican stu dents to largely white schools.

title: UNBEATEN PISTONS SET BACK BULLETS
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UPI) The undefeated Detroit Pistons streaked to their ninth victory tonight, putting down a Balti more Bullet rally in the final two minutes and earning a 1109103 National Basketball Association triumph.

title: SENATORS EXPECT FLOOD WILL SIGN
description: Robert Short, the owner of the Washington Senators, said yesterday that Curt Flood will be playing for us in 1971. But he denied reports that he al ready had signed the contro versial 32yearold outfielder, who sued baseball this year for $1million.

title: 30,000 Youths Sign Plea To U.N. for a Peace Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28Two teenage girls who wrote prizewinning essays about the United Nations met today with Secretary General Thant. A petition circulated by World Federalist Youth, signed by 30,000 young people in 36 countries, was presented to Mr. Thant at the meeting. The peti tion urged the United Nations to set up a permanent peace keeping force.

title: A. A. BODINE DIES; PHOTOGRAPHER, 64
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UPI) A. Aubrey Bodine, photo di rector of The Baltimore Sunday Sun magazine, died at Johns Hopkins Hospital today at the aee of 64.

title: The Impossible Show
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  The Vice President, of course, was only having more sport with the news industry when he proposed that panels of poli ticians examine news commentators on television so that the public might discover the philosophical convictions of those wordy wretches.

title: Rockefeller and Buckley Supported by Group Made Up of Principals and Others in City Schools
description: A group of principals and other educators in the city school system, among them Walter J. Degnan, the head of the Council of Supervisory As sociations, has called for the reelection of Governor Rocke feller and the election of James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for the Senate.

title: ExBorough Leader Is Facing a Strong Conservative Bloc
description: The character of the newly created 21st Congressional Dis trict has attracted as much at tention as the race for that seat. Both Herman Badillo, the DemocraticLiberal nominee, and George B. Smaragdas, the Conservative candidate, agree that no matter which of them wins, the job of representing this district will be difficult.

title: Mr. Nixon on the Stump
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 28The Rev. Jess Moody was in fine oratorical fettle when he gave the invocation last night at the Nixon rally in West Palm Beach, Fla. What roiled the nation, he cried, was not death throes but birth pangs and thank God our nation can still give birth. Help our President to be a good midwife!

title: Implant of Human Embryo Appears Near
description: CAMBRIDGE, England, Oct. 27The day appears to be rapidly approaching when it will be possible to remove egg cells from women un able to bear children, fer tilize them in a laboratory with sperm from their hus bands, culture them into manycelled embryos and reintroduce them into the womb. In recent weeks this process has been carried through here almost to the stage at which the embryo could be reimplanted in a prospective mother. A re search team at Cambridge University reported earlier that it had grown such em bryos to the eightcell and 16cell stages before they died.

title: $8Million Is Sought By Nassau to Aid Antidrug Programs
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28 The Nassau County Drug Abpse and Addiction Commission an nounced today that it was ap plying for nearly $8million in state funds to expand 53 com munity drug programs to reach every schoolchild in the county.

title: 2 Bookstore Clerks Found Guilty in Obscenity Case
description: The clerks of two Manhattan bookstores were found guilty yesterday of selling obscene materialan issue of Zap com ics. A third clerk was acquitted.

title: Chess:
description: If enthusiasm were the prime factor in winning chess, Jude Acers of San Francisco, our faithful West Coast correspondent, would be champion of the world. Overtheboard, Acers is an adventurous tactician playing to win all the time. As an analyst, he is breezy, in formative, objective and pos sessed of a pungent wit that he can turn on himself, and he is not afraid to comment on his losses as well as his victories.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Entries
description: Roosevelt Raceway Entries

title: BIG OIL CONCERN RAISES EARNINGS
description: The Standard Oil Company of California attained record sales and earnings in the third quar ter but profits for the first nine months receded despite an eight per cent gain to a new peak in sales and revenues.

title: Mrs. Johnson Recalls Forecast by Husband
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28(AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson re called today her husband's prediction in the fall of 1968 that there might be a great swing back toward authori tarianism and conservatism in America in response to the permissiveness, the law lessness of the day. But, she said, he believed such a reaction would set us back many decades, in the fight against ignorance, poverty and disease.

title: Off to the Golden West
description: You'll be there five hours or so after takeoff; with the time difference, two hoursstill lunchtime on the Coast, if it's a fairly early flight. Just 80 years ago this trip began in a handsome cab heading for a little twostory, redbrick Grand Central Station on 42d, Street. An Englishman named W. G. Marshall made the trip, and left some notes.

title: High Jobless Rate Confronts Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28 Unemployment and underem ployment affecting almost one third of Chile's labor force will constitute one of the main prob lems facing Dr. Salvador Al lende's leftist Government, ac cording to a study made by Dr. Allende's economic planning team.

title: Move to Admit Women Rejected by Press Club
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)A move to admit women as members of the National Press Club failed to day even though more than twothirds of the members voting in a mail referendum favored it.

title: Leafs Rout Canadiens, 6 to 2; Penguins Win, 53, From Kings
description: TORONTO, Oct. 28 (UPI) Ron Ellis, Guy Trottier, Dave Keon and Norm Ullman scored thirdperiod goals as the To ronto Maple Leafs snapped fourgame losing streak by de feating the Montreal Canadiens, 62, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: 4 Gunmen Gowned as Doctors Slay Palermo Hospital Patient
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 28 Four gunmen wearing white medical dress and gauze masks raided the city hospital here early this morning, ordered nurses to lie on the floor face down and killed a patient who was recovering from wounds suffered in a knifing last week.

title: NEW HAVEN LINE GETS MORE U.S. AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Secretary of Transporta tion John A. Volpe granted New York and Connecticut an additional $11.6million today to improve commuter opera tions of the Penn Central's New Haven Division.

title: $77Million Deficit in 3d Quarter Is Record For 3Month Period
description: DETROIT, Oct. 28  The General Motors Corporation, closed by a strike since Sept. 14, showed a net loss of about $77million. or 28 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1970.

title: Ojukwu's Appeal for Asylum Is Rejected by Switzerland
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28Switzer land has refused to grant asylum to Odumegwu Ojukwu, who commanded Biafran forces in the Nigerian civil war, it was announced in Berne today.

title: Police in Montreal Seek Clues in Note On Missing Envoy
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (Reu ters)Two messages purport ing to be from the Front for the liberation of Quebec were found last night, but one moved a hoax.

title: Unishops, Inc., Is Set to Acquire Gold fine's, Inc.
description: Unishops, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in prin ciple to acquire Goldfine's, Inc., operator of discount depart ment stores in the Duluth, Minn, area. The acquisition calls for Unishops to exchange its common stock in an initial amount to be determined by Goldfine's net worth on Dec. 31, 1970, and additional amounts of stock based on future earn ings.

title: PRICES OF BONDS ARE UP SHARPLY
description: Bond prices rose fairly sharp ly yesterday and new corpo rate and taxexempt issues carrying this week's higher yields  attracted investors.

description: College, School Results

title: Elizabeth Mae Dell Prospective Bride
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 28 Mr. and Mrs. George J. Dell have, announced the en gagement of Mr. Dell's daugh ter, Miss Elizabeth Mae Dell, to Arthur Rovins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Rovins of Westport.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE

title: Person, Goldman Beaten In NorthSouth Senior Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 28 (AP)Curtis Person of Mem phis, Tenn., the defending chain pion, and David (Spec) Gold man of Dallas, medalist, were beaten today in the first round of match play in the North and South senior golf championship.

title: Nixon to See Mexican Chief
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 28 (Reuters)President Nixon will hold daylong talks with Mex ico's Presidentelect, Luis Eche verria Alvarez at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla., on Nov. 12, it was announced today by the White House press Secretary Ronald L. Ziegler, who is ac companying Mr. Nixon on a campaign trip.

title: CAPTAIN CLEARED IN FAMILY DEATHS
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., Oct. 28 (UPI)Capt. Jeffrey R. Mac Donald was cleared today in the murders of his pregnant wife and two daughters.

title: Meat Standards Met
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Meat inspection programs in Washington and Tennessee have been approved as at least equal to Federal standards, the Agriculture Department announced today. Seven states now have met provisions of the Wholesome Meat Act of 1967 requiring each to have inspec tion programs approved by Dec. 15. The others are California, Florida. Maryland. New Mexico land Idaho.

title: Murphy Warns His Officials That They Face Demotion in the Event of Failure
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told New York's top police officials yesterday to rid their commands of corruption or face demotion.

title: Burlington Aide Retiring
description: Henry E. Rauch, former chair man and more recently a senior executive and a director of Burlington Industries, Inc., is retiring from these posts, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Rauch, who is 63 years old, joined Burlington in 1952 as controller, was named chairman in 1962 and became finance committee chairman in 1968.

title: Nicklaus Is Seeking To Win Fifth Time In Sahara Tourney
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 28 Jack Nicklaus will be able to take the lead in tour earnings if he does as well as he usually does in the $100,000 Sahara in vitation golf tournament, which begins tomorrow.

title: EGYPT LETS LEARY VISIT CAIRO BRIEFLY
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28 (AP)Egyp tian authorities eased their re strictions today on Dr. Timothy Leary, allowing him and his three traveling companions to visit Cairo briefly. But they said he would have to leave the county tomorrow.

title: Basel for Surrogate
description: The Surrogate's Court is a center of keen political interest because it dispenses most of the judicial patron age. The two Surrogates in Manhattan supervise the probate work in connection with nearly a billion dollars worth of estates each year. They appoint guardians and administrators who often reap lucrative fees.

description: VIENNA, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP)  Charges of footdragging, pussyfooting and artful dodg ing were lodged today against the Union Carbide Corporation by Representative Ken Hechler, Democrat of West Virgina.

title: L. I. Water Corp. Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28The Pub lic Service Commission today told the Long Island Water Corporation it may file tempo rary rates, calling for an aver age increase of 12.2 per cent. The P.S.C. said the rates would provide $685,500 additional an nual revenue to the company until the state makes a final de termination on the company's request for rate increases that would produce $1.7million ad ditional annual revenue.

description: Money

title: Bench and Gibson Cited
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (UPI) John Bench, Cincinnati catcher, was named National League player of the year and Bob Gibson of St. Louis the league's No. 1 pitcher today in a poll conducted by The Sporting News. Cleveland's Sam Mc Dowell, pitcher, and Minne sota's third baseman, Harmon Killebrew, took American League honors.

title: Phiis Promote Seminick
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (UPI) The Philadelphia Phillies pro moted Andy Seminick today as manager of their No. 1 farm team, Eugene, in the Pacific Coast League. Seminick was the catcher on the Phils last pen nant winner in 1950.

title: Stanford and Oregon Vie for Bowl Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28  Rose Bowl fever moved north this week to Stanford and Ore gon as both Southern Califor nia and the University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, for the first time in a decade, have been virtually eliminated from the Pacific Eight Conference football title race.

title: Museum Trustees Elected
description: The American Museum of Natural History announced yes terday the election of Sylvan C. Coleman, former chairman of E. R. Hutton & Co., Inc., to the board of trustees. Two former trustees, Dr. Henry Clay Frick 2d, and Thomas J. Watson Jr. also were elected.

title: Government Shows Deficit Of $7.7Billion in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The Federal Government in curred a $7.7billion deficit for the first three months of the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Sarmi President Resigns
description: Ferdinando Sarmi, well known designer of women's evening clothes, announced yes terday his resignation as presi dent of Sarmi, Inc., and the severance of all connections with NandoSarmi, Ltd.

title: IranianSoviet Gas Pipeline Opened
description: THERAN. Iran, Oct. 28 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran and President Nikolai V. Pod gorny of the Soviet Union to day opened a 630mile pipe line that will carry natural gas from the Iranian fields at Qum to the Soviet Union.

title: At Chorale Concert, the Children Join In
description: The National Chorale and a group of about 300 school children gave a special con cert for each other on a recent morning at Hunter College Assembly Hall.

title: Premature Quadruplets Are in Critical Condition
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP)Quadruplet girls born eight weeks premature were re ported in critical condition to day at Memorial Hospital here.

title: Bermuda Population 53,0001
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 28 (AP)  Census figures re leased today showed that Ber muda now had a population of 53.000, up 8,000 from 10 years ago.

description: A celebrity motherand daughter combination, which had an unpleasant, stunn and drang relationship when the daughter was a teenager, have teamed up to write a book designed to take the worries out of being a house wife.

description: Entertainment Events

title: Hussein Names His Third Cabinet in Six Weeks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 28 King Hussein of Jordan tonight appointed a new Cabinet under Premier Wasfi elTal With in structions to carry out recent agreements with Palestinian commandos and to seek closer relations with Jordan's Arab neighbors in order to strengthen the Arab eastern front against Israel. The Cabinet, the third in six weeks, replaces the Government of Premier Ah med Toukan.

title: WLIB RETURNS TO AIR AFTER STAFF DISPUTE
description: Radio station WLIB, whose FM outlet has been off the air since Oct. 13 and whose AM operation went off the air on Oct. 17 because of a commu nitylabor dispute, will return to the air this morning.

description: Charts of Races at Aqueduct

title: Thomas Lask Named Head Of Newspaper Guild Here
description: The representative assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York last night elected Thomas Lask, a book reviewer on the staff of The New York Times, as its president for 1970.

title: Laver Defeats Taylor
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 28 (UPI) Rod Laver defeated Roger Tay lor, his Wimbledon conqueror by 46, 76, 63, last night in the first round of a professional tennis tour through Italy. Andres Gimeno beat Cliff Drys dale, 63, 57, 76. The four will also play in Turin, Rome and Bergamo.

description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: WPIX NEWS WRITER TESTIFIES ON FILMS
description: Mrs. Nancy McCarthy, a former WPIX news writer, tes tified at a Federal Communica tions Commission hearing yes terday that she and other writers at the station repeated ly complained about what they considered unethical news prac tices by WPIX during the latter part of 1968.

title: North Carolina Reduces Auto Deaths for 2d Year
description: HOUSTON. Oct. 28  A medical evaluation program for automobile driver license applicants, combined with a more vigorous campaign to detect and penalize drunken drivers has reversed the steady rise of highway deaths in North Carolina, an epidemiologist in that state's health department reported here today.

title: CALLEY IN SAIGON SEES ARMY AIDES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering at least) 102 South Vietnamese civilians, conferred with Army officials here today amid the secrecy of a crucial military operation.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Kansas State, Tulsa on Probation 3 Years for Athlete Aid Violation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 (AP) The National Collegiate gov erning council placed two uni versities on probation today, barring Kansas State and Tulsa from postseason football for three years. It also reprimanded Jacksonville.

title: U.S. BODY DISCUSSES YIELDS ON DEPOSITS
description: The President's Commission on Financial Structure and Reg ulation held its third meeting here yesterday at the offices of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation and discussed the broad issue of the regulation of interest rates paid on deposits by banks and saving associations.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: Amer. Basketball Ass'n

title: It's Mush! Mush! as Siberians Warm Up for DogSled Racing
description: Metropolitan fanciers will have a chance to see dog sled racing. Starting on Jan. 3. six programs will be run on Sundays by the Garden State Siberian Husky Club over courses in Turkey Swamp Park near Freehold, N. J. Teams are expected from New Jersey, New York and Pennsyl vania. Contrary to many of our neighbors. said Jay Weigman, the club's presi dent, we are always hoping for snow.

title: ECONOMIC GAUGES SHOW NO UPSURGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Economic indicators for Sep tember and October continued the recent string of relatively unfavorable news, Government reports showed today.

title: Lebanon Pressing Guerrillas to Curb Attacks on Israelis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27 The new Lebanese Govern ment has pressed Palestinian commandos not to fire rock ets into Israel from Lebanese soil, highly placed Lebanese informants said today.

title: Papillon Author Pardoned
description: PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP)Henri Charriere, author of the best seller Papillon, has been pardoned for the murder that sent him to Devil's Island and the imprisonment and escapes he recounts in his book. Justice Minister Rene Pleven signed the decree Oct. 17, informed sources said.

title: TORRID SHOOTING INSURES VICTORY
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28The New York Knicks put on their finest shooting and defensive effort of the season tonight in over whelming the Boston Celtics, 12689, for their third straight victory and second over the Celtics this season.

title: Books of The Times
description: Why include Shirley Maclaine's auto biography in a roundup review of the latest texts on radical feminism? Because Miss MacLaineand it is the style of this newspaper to use Miss and Mr. deals with herself as a person, not a victim, not an abstraction. Her accommodations to stardom, marriage, motherhood and the mysterious East don't add up to an argu ment or a slogan; they add up to something like a poem, in which, moreover, the figure of a child assumes reality. Miss MacLaine's Caughter, Sachiko, is not perceived to be a piece of property, an inconvenience re sulting from our primitive and obsolescent reproductive processes. She is perceived instead to be a source of wonder and in sight, a reality to be remembered during the next exchange of inanities that passes for conversation between men and women these days over the dinnertable trough. Her: Marriage is a prison! Him: What makes you think that work is freedom? Her: Sexist pig! Him: You want a knuckle sandwich?

title: Film: 'McKenzie Break':P.O.W. Camp Is Scene of Escape Attempt
description: Lamont Johnson's "The McKenzie Break," which opened yesterday at several New York theaters, is so greatly superior to most recent war movies, adventure movies, escape movies and action movies generally that it seems almost unfair to raise the objection that it is not quite as good as it sets out to beor, given the talents involved, as it ought to be. But it is nevertheless modest enough in pretensions and strong enough in achievements to repay the time of anybody not hell-bent on major subjects or total cinema.The film takes its title from a Camp McKenzie, a prisoner-of-war camp in Scotland from which, near the end of World War II, a group of German U-boat men attempt an escape in order to rejoin the failing forces of Admiral Dnitz. The German leader (Helmut Griem) disguises his escapevia the usual painfully dug tunnelwith all manner of nasty prisoner hijinks, thus upsetting the authority of the camp commander (Ian Hendry) and moving British Intelligence to send to McKenzie a troubleshooter (Brian Keith), a free-wheeling, insubordinate, hard-nosed, clever type too rarely seen in modern movies.Between Keith and Griem a certain equivalence by opposition is set up, which, until the mechanics of the escape itself take over, seems to be the main interest of "The McKenzie Break." With this relationship the film is by no means subtle, even going so far as to superimpose images of the two men in a final stop shot, but it is also always interesting and valid. Where it fails is in the penultimate identification of Griem as nasty Nazi, which doesn't quite jibe with a central action that has less to do with ideological conflict than with competiing styles of anarchic behavior.But for the most part "The McKenzie Break" sticks to a level of intelligent competence that it would be pointless to fault. As usual, the prisoner-of-war camp is run more as an escape factory than a prisoner-of-war camphowever, the film always takes reasonable pains to subordinate machines to men. Near the beginning, there are just enough young Nazi faces by firelight so you might think you were watching second-unit footage for a sequel to "The Damned," but this is one of the very few stylistic excesses in an otherwise gratifyingly economical movie.I liked all the cast. But as the charming and astutely bullish Capt. Jack Connor, Brian Keith is especially goodand sufficiently in control of things to serve for anybody's authoritarian fun father figures.

title: Gromyko, in Britain, Bars Wide Vietnam Parley Now
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (UPI) Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko told British leaders today that the time is not ripe for an international peace conference on Viet nam, Government officials said.

title: Theater: Chelsea Center
description: The least you can say of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is that it is adventur ous. Last night the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn (New York's solitary profes sional dramatic theater out side of Manhattan) opened its sixth season with the New York premiere of Edward Bond's play Saved.

title: Joffrey Performs Ballet by Arpino At the City Center
description: Gerald Arpino's Sea Shad ow, one of those short, mys terious and often earnest ballets by Mr. Arpino that played around with fantasy and reality in the Jaffrey Ballet's first few years, came back into the reper tory last night at the City Center after a year's absence.

title: A JUDGE BARS U.S. FROM PUBLISHING LIST OF RADICALS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28A Federal judge issued a perma nent injunction today barring official Government publica tion or distribution of a report by the House Internal Security Committee listing 65 persons as radical campus speakers. In a landmark decision limit ing Congressional power, Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of United States District Court here said the committee report is with out any proper legislative pur pose and infringes on the rights of the individuals named therein. He said it would be illegal to publish the report at public expense.

title: Dare to Struggle Dare to Win
description: LONDONWading through a mass of impressions formed in prison, not because it was prison but because for the first time in my life I had 117 con secutive days in which, against a clock work background, all I had to do was survive and think, the single most im portant fact that I established in my mind can be best summed up in the battle cry, Dare to StruggleDare to Win.

title: Son to Mrs. A. M. Brown
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 28 A son was born Oct. 25 in the Mary Immaculate Hos pital here to Lieut. Archibald Manning Brown Jr., U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Brown, the former Miss Laura Havemeyer Webb of Shelburne, Vt. The child's parents are both descended from Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. The baby has been named Brewster Jen nings for his late greatgrand father, Benjamin Brewster Jennings, who was chairman of the board of the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I share the concern expressed by Prof. K. Laurence Chang in his letter (Oct. 20) over the low volume of aid to developing countries. But it seems to me that the stand which he takes on linking Special Drawing Rights (S.D.R.'s) to development assistance is inconsistent with his advocacy of a larger flow of aid.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HAVE MIXED DAY
description: Despite reports of wide spread rain in the central Mid west, soybean futures dropped sharply from seasonal highs under substantial profit taking yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. They rallied mildly near the end of trading and closed with prices irregular.

title: TV Newsman Fined $200
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 28  Dell Wade, a television news reporter for WABCTV in New York City was found guilty today of interfering with the police while covering news story here and fined $200. The charge stems from the civil disturbance in the Negro sec tion here last July, when the state police were called in. A charge against Mr. Wade for assault and battery against a state trooper was dismissed by Acting Magistrate James Wilson after a sevenhour hearing.

title: DON RODRIGO SUITS MARIANNA CIRAULO
description: The role in which Marianna Ciraulo made her debut with the New York City Opera, that of Florinda in Ginastera's Don Rodrigo, is not easy. As in most contemporary opera, the vocal line is disjunct, declama tory rather than lyrical, over ridden at times by heavy or chestration.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Moore, G. E. Summers
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Oct. 28  Miss Elizabeth Moore and George Ellis Sum mers of Locust Valley, L. I., plan to be married next spring.

title: Yearling Nets $40,000, Record at Yonkers Sale
description: YONKERS, Oct. 28Harry Minbar, a full brother to Meadow Elva, who at 4 was the world champion pacing mare, brought $40,000 today, a record price for a yearling at the Old Glory Sale at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Councilmen Ask Changes In Hiring of Consultants
description: The City Council ended its public hearings on consult ants contracts yesterday with a demand for major revi sions in the way the contracts with the city are awarded and supervised. It is obvi ous to me that the present system cannot be permitted to continue, said Edward L. Sadowsky, Queens Democrat who is chairman of the Coun cil's Committee on Charter and Governmental Operations. He was chairman of the seven member subcommittee that conducted the often tumultu ous sessions.

description: Sharply lower profits despite higher revenues for the third quarter and first nine months were reported yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: Widow Stabbed in Church On East Side by 3 Youths
description: A 63yearold widow who at tends mass every morning was stabbed yesterday on a stair case in St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street.

title: $1MILLION TO AID CLEANUP IN CITY
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the state would give New York City $1million for an emergency cleanup of its dirtiest areas. However, Henry L. Diamond, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said the money would not be released until the city supplied a list of the blocks it intended to clean up.

title: One Recent Afternoon
description: On a bedsheet nailed to the livingroom wall, Jack Johnson struts in a vanilla suit. Jack was sharp, wasn't he? says Muhammad Ali, lounging on a sofa watching unreleased documentary movie about the first black cham pion and his times. The filmmaker, Jim Jacobs, supervises the humming projector and shoots over Ali and the eight others in the darkened room of this suburban Atlanta cot tage. This is something, this is really something, Jim. I got to get a print of this movie. Take a man in his sixties come visit me, I can tell him to sit back and entertain him with this movie  How old was Jack when he won the title? 31, hmmmmm.  My case revives his story.

title: JAPAN'S PREMIER WINS A 4TH TERM
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 29 Premier Eisaku Sato was re elected today to an unprece dented fourth term as president of the governing LiberalDemo cratic party in a vote that as sures his continuance as head of Japan's Government. If he serves out the twoyear term, he will have been Premier for eight consecutive years, longer than any other occupant of the Office.

title: Screen: Mel Broods on Prowl in Soviet:'12 Chairs,' a Comedy, at Tower East
description: One of these days someone is going to put together a smash-hit television special called "The Greedy, Fraudulent World as Seen by Mel Brooks." It will celebrate the comic genius of the writer-director-occasional performer whose longer works tend to outrun their initial inspiration.If I were in charge of the show, it would include a 60-second visit with the generally quarrelsome, 2,500-year-old brewmaster ("My tongue just threw a party for my mouth") whom Mr. Brooks created for Ballantine Beer; the opening number from "Springtime for Hitler" (the musical within his first film, "The Producers") in which myopic Nazi chorines sing "Here Comes the Master Race!"; "The Critic," the Ernie Pintoff cartoon that Mr. Brooks wrote and narrated, and the parody of "Death of a Salesman" (from "New Faces of 1952") in which Willy Loman's son absolutely refuses to pay attention to his father, the crook.It might also include the scene from "The Twelve Chairs," Mr. Brooks's newest film, a comedy set in 1927 Russia, in which Ostap Bender (Frank Langella), the con man, asks Tikon (Mr. Brooks), the caretaker at a home for the aged, what goes on there. "The old ladies," says Tikon blandly, "they tippy-toe in. They have a bowl of porridge, and then they. . . ." Tikon gives an abrupt, nasty Bronx cheer that, in Mr. Brooks's elastic vocabulary, may be either an insult or a euphemismfor death and lesser failures."The Twelve Chairs," which opened yesterday at the Loew's Tower East Theater, is otherwise a comedy for Brooks-watchers somewhat more indulgent than I. The screenplay is an adaptation of the Soviet comic novel by Ilf and Petrov, who continued the adventures of Ostap Bender in a second novel, "The Little Golden Calf."The film is essentially one long chase across the Soviet Union, to Moscow, Siberia and the Crimea, undertaken by three energetic, irritable and inept treasure huntersOstap Bender, the youngest of the trio, Vorobyaninov (Ron Moody), a fallen aristocrat, and Father Fyodor (Dom DeLuise), a fallen priest. Their prize is a dining room chair, one of a set of 12, in which Vorobyaninov's unpleasant mother-in-law hid 50,000 rubles worth of jewels during the Revolution.As able as the three leading actors are, it is Mr. Brooks, who, though he appears only briefly in the film, dominates it from the beginning, which is a death scene, to the end, in which the movie, quite literally, winds up flat on its back, jerking with the spasms of a simulated epileptic fit.Most of the things that happen in between are almost as joyless, and as joyless as the Soviet Union the film purposefully depicts. This is, I think, because Mr. Brooks's sense of humor is expressed almost entirely in varying degrees of rudeness and cruelty, unrelieved by any comic vision of mankind, of the Soviet Union, or even of his characters.There is an innocence about "The Twelve Chairs," but it is the kind of innocence in which one character will say to another "You aren't worth spitting on." To which the second replies: "Well you are!" and then spits on the first. For some reason, this sort of comedy of physical insult seemed much funnier to me in the Broadway world of "The Producers," which really is aggressive and nasty and cheap, than in a Russia that is not too far removed from the world of Sholem Aleichem.In "The Twelve Chairs" Mr. Brooks wants to be lovable, and to stomp on your foot at the same time. I, for one, object.

Trumanwill serve as honorary chairmen for the 75th anniversary observance of the Volunteers of America. The din ner will be held next March 8 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 28  Albatross, harness racing's best bargainbuy in recent years, is not expected to encounter dif ficulty in Saturday night's 11th annual Roosevelt Futurity for 2yearold pacers at Roosevelt, Raceway.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the giant of the computer industry, made two nimble moves yesterday that it hopes will give it a dominant position in the low power, lowprice spectrum of the data processing market.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 28 (UPI)The National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion delayed next month's launching of a $75milliion star gazing satellite when engineers discovered today that a neces sary wiring change had not been made in the craft's main com puter. The space agency said the launching would be re scheduled from Nov. 17 to the following week.

description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 28Unit ed States officials, seeking to strengthen their Government's shaky relations with Sweden, are convinced that the outpour ing of antiAmericanism in recent years among students, radicals and politicians has steadily declined in the last few months.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Personal Finance: New Law to Help the Bankrupt
description: One of the cruel injustices of the American legal system has long been the fact that many people who go through bankruptcy  often at con siderable personal sacrifice walk out of Federal courts with the exhilarating feeling that they now are free of past debts.

title: 4 MISSING AS BOAT SINKS IN THE GULF
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 28 (AP) A 100foot work boat sank in choppy seas 20 miles out in the Gulf of Mexico be fore dawn today, going down so quickly that the eight men on board were unable to scramble to the oil drilling platform where the boat was moored, the Coast Guard said.

title: LINDSAY STUMPS WITH GOLDBERG
description: Mayor Lindsay backed up his endorsement of Arthur J. Goldberg with shoe leather yes terday as he campaigned with the DemocraticLiberal candi date for Governor in the City Hall area and the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Senator Hughes Quietly Pushes 1972 Presidential Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 Senator Harold E. Hughes flew to the California southland to day on one of the lowestkey campaigns of the 1970 elec tionfor his darkhorse can didacy for President in 1972.

title: A.T. & T. ACCUSES F.C.C.'S JOHNSON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today asked Nicholas Johnson of the Federal Communications Com mission to disqualify himself from all regulatory proceedings involving the Bell system be cause of what it called the deepseated bias and prej udice it said he revealed in a speech in Chicago 10 days ago.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: FRANKIsadore Reverend. Beloved, In ten der memory, you never left your loving wife, children and grandchildren.

title: Nixon Lauds Agnew
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 28 (UPI)President Nixon, answer ing speculation that he might seek a new running mate in 1972, said today that Vice Pres ident Agnew is doing a won derful job.

title: Unser Sets Driver Mark With $448,145 for Season
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP) Al Unser of Albuquerque, N. M., became the highest moneywinner for one season in autoracing history, the United States Auto Club said today.

title: City Doctors Sue to Block Hospital Check of Students
description: A taxpayer's suit was begun in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the bus ing of schoolchildren to a pri vate hospital for routine medi cal examinations that will al legedly cost more than 10 times as much as examinations con ducted in school.

title: Bay State Justice Sworn
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Judge Walter H. McLaughlin of Belmont became Chief Jus tice of the Massachusetts Su perior Court system today in a State House ceremony. He succeeds Judge G. Joseph Tauro, who recently became chief justice of the state Su preme Court.

title: Hague Bill Would Tax Royalty
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 28 (Reu ters)The lower house of Par liament today approved a Gov ernment bill under which the royal family becomes liable to pay income and property tax. The bill now goes to the upper house.

title: TECHNIQUE SHINES IN URIBE CONCERT
description: Some musicians seem to thrive when the thickets of notes they have to negotiate become densest, and Blanca Uribe, the Colombianborn pi anist, is apparently one of those. At the end of the recital she gave at Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night, the opening event in a Latin American Series being pre sented there this season, Miss Uribe plunged through Villa Lobos's Rudepoema with a heartiness that was truly im pressive.

title: Unpolitical Economy
description: The latest statistics about the economy are scarcely reassuring. Los Angeles and four other major industrial centers have just been added to the list of labor markets with substantial unemployment. The Government's official list now puts just under onequarter of all the country's principal labor markets in this category38 out of a total of 150. Two years ago only six areas were in that plight.

title: 'Trog' and 'Taste Blood of Dracula'
description: Three hours of British-made pseudo science fiction and horror, such as "Trog" and "Taste the Blood of Dracula" that drenched the screens of the DeMille and other houses yesterday in ersatz plots and gore, could conceivably encourage potential movie buffs to turn, say, to the charms of plumbing. This might not be a disservice since neither entry shocks entertainingly nor enlivens the ailing cause of the B-type thriller on the lower half of double bills.There is, however, a rudimentary virtue in "Trog," a sort of second cousin, 15 years removed from "Creature From the Black Lagoon," in that it proves that Joan Crawford is grimly working at her craft. Unfortunately, the determined lady, who is fetching in a variety of chic pants suits and dresses, has little else going for her.As the anthropologist chief of a research center that has unearthed a living, hairy, half-caveman half-ape, Ice Age "missing link," a troglodyte she cutely nicknames 'Trog' and attempts to rear as you would a backward child, she poses no threat either to Dr. Margaret Mead or Dr. Spock. Of course, there"s the villainous Michael Gough who goads the gentled 'Trog' 'into murdering several villagers, a rampage that leads to "Trog's' climactic destruction."I never expected this," one of Trog's discoverers exclaims. But thanks to a script that makes everything vapidly obvious from the start, 'Trog' is no more exciting or scientific than the antics of a rambunctious kid in a progressive school.If anything, "Taste the Blood of Dracula" is as "scientific" and humorless as "Trog." Christopher Lee, as Dracula and an old hand in the horror trade ("The Hands of Orlac," "The Gorgon," "Dr. Fu Manchu," "Dracula," "Dracula Has Risen From the Grave") now is involved in dispatching three improper Victorians, who not only are averse to drinking his blood but also have killed one of his disciples.As the vampirish Count, complete with crimson eyes and king-sized incisors, Mr. Lee, his victims, Geoffrey Keen, John Carson and Peter Sallis, and their amorous sons and daughters, Linda Hayden, Martin Jarvis, Isla Blair and Anthony Corlan, succeed in making blood-letting an anemic show.Early in the creepy proceedings in a ruined church, one of the timorous trio whispers, "My God, I don't like this." He proves to be absolutely right.

title: ROBERT P. GARDENER
description: Robert P. Gardener, financial officer of the Dommerich divifi sion of the Chemical Bank, died Tuesday of a heart ail ment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: Morris High School in Bronx Forced to Close by Disorders
description: Morris High School in the Bronx was closed early after, students ran through the cor ridors and cafeteria overturn ing chairs and tables yesterday. Later, after classes, they clashed with the police outside they building.

title: 8 Indicted in a Fraud Case Here Allegedly Sold Worthless Stock
description: Federal and local authorities yesterday began rounding up eight men who allegedly en gineered a stock swindle that victimized brokerage houses and individuals across the country.

title: Brian O'Doherty Named To Edit Art in America
description: Brian O'Doherty, writer, art ist and a former art critic for The New York Times, has been appointed editor of Art in America, a himonthly maga zine devoted to the visual arts. Mr. O'Doherty, who has served sine 1969 as director of visual arts programs for the National Council on the Arts, will add the editorship to his present duties with the issue of March and April, 1971.

title: Sale of Church to Militants Rejected
description: Officials of the First Spanish Methodist Church denied yes terday that they had been ne gotiating to sell the church building to the Young Lords, is militant group that has oc Icupied the church for 11 days. The administrative board of the church said the property, at 111th Street and Lexington Avenue, is not for sale.

title: STAR RUSHER OUT WITH RIB DAMAGE
description: Emerson Boozer has joined Joe Namath and Matt Snell on the Jets list of noncombatants for Sunday's game with the Giants at Shea Stadium.

title: Facts at a Glance on District 21
description: POPULATION: Almost every racial and ethnic group in the city can be found among the 425,000 persons in the 21st Congressional Dis trict, which was put together from the South Bronx, a por tion of East Harlem, and the Astoria and East Elmhurst sections of Queens. The larg est groups are Puerto Rican, Italian, Greek, black and Jewish.

title: Dr. Nicholas Sees a Ray of Light for InjuryPlagued Jets
description: The Jets may be limping and they may be 10point under dogs for their game against the healthy Giants on Sunday. But they received a longrange vote of confidence yesterday from the man who probably knows them better than anyone  Dr. James A. Nicholas.

title: Dividend Omitted
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday losses for the third quarter and first nine months and an mounced it was again passing up the quarterly dividend.

title: DECLINE CONTINUES IN HELPWANTED ADS
description: The helpwanted index, measure of the volume of help wanted advertising in 52 major newspapers across the country, dropped last month to its low est point since August of 1965, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Dispute Engulfs Scribner After Only 2 Months in Job
description: A scant two months after he took over as the city's first School Chancellor, Dr. Harvey B. Scribner the for mer Vermont Education Com missioner, is embroiled in a major conflict with the or ganizations that represent the school system's 60,000 teach ers and nearly 4,000 super visors.

title: Hystron Prepares Its Own Copy
description: If any of you have been wondering what happened to Adrian M. Butash of Hystron Fibers since he announced last July that he was giving up his agency, here is a report: Mr. Butash is alive and well and working with Bert Stern, the photographer.

title: McDonnell Results Off
description: Reduction in DC8 and DC9 deliveries and some delays in acceptance of these aircraft by airlines pending completion of financing arrangements have continued to depress sales and earnings of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: American and Soviet space officials have signed an agreement to develop mutually compatible rendezvous and docking systems for space vehicles of the two countries, the Federal space agency announced yesterday in Washington. The compact was signed in Moscow on Wednesday, the agency said. [Page 1. Column 8.]

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON LONDON BOARD
description: Apprehension as to what the British Government's statement on money policy, expected next week, would mean to in vestors  perhaps stricter con trols on credit and bank lend ing  depressed prices on the London Stock Exchange ves terday, and traders cut their commitments.

title: Public or Private, Polls Breed Dispute
description: Two days after The Daily New's straw vote indicated that James L. Buckley was leading in the threeway race for United States Senator. Oliver Quayle & Co. released a poll showing Representative Richard L. Ottinger ahead of Mr. Buckley. At the same time, pollsters working for other newspapers, other candidates, politi cians and televi sion stations were making telephone calls and knocking on doors in every part of the state. At least a halfdozen public opinion surveys are under way or just completed as part of the state campaigns for Governor and Senator. Some are private polls for the use of candidates and some are for publication or broadcast, but all are controversial in one way or another.

title: Knicks Halt Late Surge by Rockets and Win, 114107, for 4th Victory in Row
description: Most of those in the crowd of 16,934 at Madison Square Garden last night, almost in credibly, sidetracked their emo tional involvement with the Knickerbockers to cheer for Cal Murphy, the 5foot9inch rookie backcourt man of the San Diego Rockets.

description: ESELCIRADEWhen I visited Great Britain and the United States in 1968, the most frequent question directed at me was: What will happen after Tito?

description: Twelve Federal Reserve Banks Combined

title: Marketplace Can the Layman Get Full Data?
description: If Harry Nagler is right, the layman can get the whole story on his investments. Mr. Nagler, a reaaer, taxes issue with Prof. Homer Krip ke, a New York University expert on securities law, who thinks it is impossible to in form the ordinary investor because business is just too complex.

title: Auto Output Estimated
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP)New car production in United States plants continued at a 90,000a week pace this week was the United Automobile Workers strike kept the General Motors Corporation's plants closed.

title: SWEDEN IS LEADER IN PRISON REFORM
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29  At the Nacka Prison near Stock holm, inmates travel each morning to civilian jobs and return to their quarters at night. In the university town of Uppsala, convicts live be side students, who offer them tutoring help for academic de grees. Around Sweden, nearly 4,800 convicts received two day and threeday furloughs through the year to help ease the difficulties of adjustment after release.

title: BRENDAN SCORES IN JUMPER EVENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A highjumping contest on horse back was won tonight by Bren dan, an open jumper owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill of Collegeville, Pa., for the high light of the Washington inter national horse show. Roderick Jenkins, a 26yearold profes sional, was the rider as he had been when another Gill leaper, Idle Dice, won the event a year ago.

title: Bonavena Stops Brazilian
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 (UPI) Oscar Bonavena scored fourthround knockout of Luis Faustino Fires, a Brazilian heavyweight, tonight. Bona vena weighed 210 and Fires 207.

title: Michelson and Miss Wald Elected to the Hall of Fame
description: Albert Abraham Michelson, the physicist, and Lillian B. Wald, social worker, have been elected to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans at New York University, Dr. Russell D. Niles, director of the shrine, has an nounced.

title: U.S. Aide Asks BlueCollar Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Nixon Administration car ried its concern over the blue collar blues to the doorstep of private industry today, urging job reforms to improve the safety, satisfaction and se curity of millions of lowerpaid workers.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF 4TH STRAIGHT DAY
description: The American Stock Ex change sustained its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as the list declined in slow trad ing.

title: 31 ORIOLES VOTED SHARES OF $18,216
description: 31 ORIOLES VOTED SHARES OF $18,216

title: Eaton Visits Warsaw for Honor and Son for Hotel Deal
description: WARSAW, Oct. 29Two Cy rus S. Eatons were in Warsaw todayone to receive an hon orary degree and the other to negotiate construction of an $00room hotel.

title: KUROSAWA MOVIE IN TOKYO DEBUT
description: TOKYO., Oct. 29DoclesKa Den, Akira Kurosawa's first film in five years, had its pre miere at the Yurakuza Theatre here Tuesday night.

title: Oh, for the Old Dinty Moore's
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: 14 Killed in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Friday, Oct. 30 (UPI)A barrage of mortar shells struck a Cambodian troopship convoy on the Me kong River last night, killing 13 soldiers, a crewman, and wounding 50 others, a Govern ment military spokesman said today.

title: Job for the Legislature
description: The Legislature to be elected Tuesday will have the consequential responsibility of reapportioning Congres sional and state legislative districts under the 1970 census. The best assurance of equity in the carrying out of that assignment lies in the establishment of a non partisan reapportionment commission, a project to which the Democratic leadership in Albany is committed but the normally dominant Republicans are not.

title: Four Missing as Boat Sinks
description: MORGAN CITY, La., Oct. 29 (AP)  The Coast Guard, searched today for four crew men missing and feared dead after a 100foot work boat sank in rough waters about 20 miles off the Louisiana coast. Four others were rescued. The miss ing men were identified as Joseph Steward of New Orleans, Bill Driver of Lake Providence, Douglas McMillan of Tillatoba, Miss., and Andrew J. Haan Jr. of Altus, Okla.

title: SHOP THIS GREAT COAT EVENT TODAY. AND TOMORROW OPEN LATE FRIDAY NIGHTS
description: Both our Au Courant and Better Coat Departments join in this preElection Day Value event. The collaboration brings you a greater choice of superfashion looks in contemporary and midilength coats of fine worsteds and softplushy wool meltons coats, and even a hooded cape, boasting the uncommon designer details and superlative tailoring that denotes upperbracket quality. All the great fall colors. Sizes 6 to 16.

title: PLEDGES ARE MADE FOR U.N. AID AGENCY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29  Rich and poor nations joined today in pledging con tributions to the United Na tions Development Program that should give the aid agency $249million in resources for 1971.

title: Gromyko in East Berlin
description: BERLIN, Oct. 29Foreign Minister Gromyko arrived in East Berlin today for talks with East German leaders.

title: Buckley Is Seeking Liaison With Blacks
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 29  Con ceding that he had very little support in the black communi ty, James L. Buckley, the Con servative candidate for Sena tor, said today that if elected he would appoint a Negro as a staff liaison officer.

title: Nodouble Out of Gold Cup; 5YearOld Racer Retired
description: Candidates for tomorrow's Jockey Club Gold Cup at the Big A won't have to contend with Nodouble.

title: Leary Back in Algeria; Hints He'll Settle There
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 29 (UPI) Dr. Timothy Leary, the LSD advocate who escaped last month from prison in the United States, returned to Algiers today with three American companions after an unsuccessful attempt to make contact with Palestinian guerrilla leaders in Lebanon and Egypt.

title: BELLEVUE FORCE ACTS ON NARCOTICS
description: An undercover force of hos pital security guards and city detectives, some posing as pa tients and staff members, has been at work in Bellevue Hos pital for the last IS months to ferret out pushers and buyers of narcotics.

title: Race Violence Brings Trenton Curfew
description: TRENTON. Oct. 29Mayor Arthur J. Holland ordered a curfew here tonight after a day of sporadic racial disturbances in which bands of black youths invaded the downtown area, smashing windows, breaking into stores and pelting police men with stones and bottles.

title: They're Shorter Than Minis But Perhaps More Ladylike
description: The invasion is on. Paris couture houses, not content with exporting their scarves and perfume, are concentrat ing on sending their ready towear to the United States, too.

title: Eastern Planning to Test 2 Antihijacking Weapons
description: Eastern Airlines plans to test two unorthodox weapons for possible use by its pilots against hijackers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Episcopal Bishops Stand

title: Wolstenholme Gains Stroke Lead With 67 In Dunlop Tourney;
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 29 (UPI)Guy Wolstenholme of England shot a fiveunderpar 67 today and took the first round lead over some of the world's top golfers in the $28,000 Dunlop international golf tournament.

title: Galley Returns to Area of the Alleged Massacre
description: SONMY, South Vietnam, Oct 29The Vietnamese of Sonmy say that 570 civilians were massacred here on March 16 1968, when an American infan try company entered the area, but none of them know the name of Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr., nor what he looks like, nor do they understand why he was in Quangngai Province to day.

title: 3 BIG LABOR GROUPS SEEK UNITY IN ITALY
description: PLURENCL, Italy, Oct. 29 Me leadership of Italy's three major tradeunion organiza tions, including Communists and nonCommunists, agreed today to step up efforts to build a united labor front that would strive for drastic social reforms.

title: Excerpts From the Carnegie Commission's Report on Medical Education in U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 Following are excerpts from a report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Edu cation on medical education in the United States:

title: Bridge
description: Enthusiasts who like to watch displays of topclass bridge will have a rare op portunity at the New York Hilton this weekend.

title: Contract Is Signed for 144 Cars on New Haven
description: A $59.4million contract for 144 new electric cars for the New Haven rail commuter line was signed here and in Hart ford yesterday by the respec tive state agencies that plan to take over the service on Jan. 1. The formal takeover agree ment was signed last Tuesday.

title: Soon Signs Cast
description: Joe Butler and Boni Enten have been engaged for major roles in Soon, the new musi cal by Scott Fagan and Joe Kookoolis, which opens Dec. 16 at the Ritz Theater. Bruce W. Stark and Sagittarius Produc tions are the producers of the show dealing with the life of a rock music group.

title: Show for Bella Abzug
description: Broadway for Bella, a musical program with Barbra Streisand, George Segal, Joel Grey, Alan Alda, Jack Guilford, Tony Roberts, Scott Jarvis and Buck Henry, will be presented at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden at 7:45 P.M. Sunday, as a fundraising event, for Bella Abzug, candidate for the House of Representatives from the 19th Congressional District.

title: Similarities Mark Texas Rivals
description: WACO, Tex., Oct. 29 George Bush is 6 feet 2 inches tall, handsome, conservative, a multimillionaire, 46 years old and a Republican. In World War II, he was a combat pilot.

title: Job for the Governor
description: The tyranny of the polls and the timidity of Governor Rockefeller are combining to thwart a true expression of the will of New York voters in next Tuesday's election for United States Senator.

title: LIMITATION IS SET IN FLOOD PACT BID
description: Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday he would not approve a contract between Curt Flood and the Washington Senators if it in cluded any modification of the reserve clause.

title: LILI KRAUS DISPLAYS BOLDNESS IN RECITAL
description: Tradition is slovenliness, according to Mahler, as quoted by Lili Kraus during opening remarks before her piano re cital at Hunter College Assem bly Hall Wednesday night.

title: FUR COATS ONLY $275
description: Your favored length, midis or knee length. Natural muskrat, Australian opossum, badger trimmed, Sheared Borrego lamb. An Mini Coats reduced to $199. We'll lengthen your present coat reasonably.

title: Roorback the Smear Artist
description: WASHINGTON, Oat. 29The last few days of a political campaign are always the most dangerous, for then candidates are vulnerable to damaging and misleading attacks which they have no time to answer. The last minute smear is one of the oldest and ugliest tactics of American politics, and lately it has been used against Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, among others.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week rose to an estimated $739million, 2 per cent above the $721 million sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales last week advanced to an estimated $6.917billion, 2 per cent above last year.

title: 2 Happy Towns on Delaware: One Awake, One Dozing
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N. J. Distant tinklings of bells across the Delaware River from this residential New Jersey town break the au tumn stillness.

title: Chippewas Adopt Miss Nixor
description: BELCOURT, N. D., Oct. 29 (AP)Tricia Nixon was adoptH led today as a member of the Chippewa Indian Tribe on the Turtle Mountain Reservation in North Dakota. The elderly medicine man presiding at the eremony to the accompaniment of beating tomtoms gave her the Indian name of Beautiful Bird. Miss Nixon, 24 years old, the elder daughter of the Presi dent, received a warm welcome from the 1.500 elementary and high school youngsters and several hundred adults at the reservation school.

title: YOST CALLS ON U.N. TO ASK EXTENSION OF MIDEAST TRUCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29The United States called on the United Nations General Assembly today to rec ommend a threemonth exten sion of the Middle East cease fire and to urge the parties in the conflict to restore condi tions of confidence necessary for the resumption of peace talks. The 90day truce in the Suez Canal area is scheduled to expire next Thursday.

title: Head Start Cutback Protested in Capital By Buffalo Parents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A group of parents of children en rolled in Project Head Start in Buffalo today protested the Nixon Administration's cut in funds for the preschool pro gram.

title: SADAT, ON A TOUR, SEES MISSILE SITE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29President Anwar elSadat toured the Suez Canal front yesterday, a week before the expiration of the 90 day ceasefire, and watched Egyptians at an antiaircraft mis sile base prepare within seconds for battle.

title: Assets and Liabilities in Reserve Cities
description: Assets and Liabilities in Reserve Cities

title: Construction Contracts Declined in September
description: Continuing an upanddown pattern that has prevailed for much of this year, contracts for future construction placed in September throughout the coun try slipped downward on seasonally adjusted basis.

title: Gene Tunney and Son Denounced by Murphy
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (UPI)Senator George Mur phy called Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight champ ion, a liar today and accused Mr. Tunney's son of basing his election campaign on a deliberate political smear about Technicolor.

title: Ground Is Broken for Mall
description: The formal groundbreaking for the Staten Island Mall, the first regional shopping center slated for the Borough of Rich mond, was held yesterday. Large units of both Macy's and Sears are scheduled to be the dominant stores at the 133acre site, which is located southeast of the intersection of Richmond Avenue and Richmond Hill Road, near the center of the island.

title: Yomiuri Giants Win Again
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Yomiuri Giants beat the Lotte Orions, 63, on 12 hits today and took a 20 lead in the Japan baseball world series.

title: Mrs. Crimmins to Face Trial In Deaths of Two Children
description: Supreme Court Justice George J. Balbach ruled yesterday in Queens that Alice Crimmins must stand trial on charges of manslaughter and murder in the deaths of her two children in July, 1965.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Harry Markson is the director of boxing at Madison Square Garden and the absolute antithesis of the prototype. He is no cigar chomping semiliterate, but a man of cul ture with a taste for fine music and the higher arts. He doesn't normally go search ing for analogies to drop into a strange context, but when one pops into his mind he doesn't hesitate to offer it.
