description: Business Records

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: Charts of Races at Aqueduct

title: 2 IN A CHICAGO GANG ARE ARRESTED HERE
description: Two Chicago street gang leaders were arrested here yes terday as fugitives sought on charges including murder, kid napping and fraud.

title: Net Tops $17Million
description: Pan American World Air ways, Inc., reported yesterday a $17.2million profit for the September quarter, up from $3.872,000 in the same quarter last year. Losses incurred earlier this year resulted in the company reporting a loss of $1,270,000 for the first nine months. This compared with a loss of $6,956,000, in the same period last year.

title: NEW YORK CLEARING HOUSE STATEMENT
description: NEW YORK CLEARING HOUSE STATEMENT

title: WEEK'S TRAFFIC OFF ON RAILS AND TRUCKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the cor responding week of last year.

title: Voters in State Sampling Stress Moral Positions of Candidates
description: Most elections are decided by issues, candidate person ality and party loyalty. The findings of The New York Times / Yankelovich survey, conducted among a sample of 1.912 registered voters from all over the state, suggests this may be less applicable in the election for Governor and Senator.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: MERRILL LYNCH TO RESCUE FIRM
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., and the New York Stock Exchange an nounced plans yesterday to rescue Goodbody & Co., major brokerage house threat ened with insolvency.

title: New Jersey Bell Telephone
description: Net income of the New Jer sey Bell Telephone Company dipped to $21,305,231, or 40 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30 from $23,085, 689, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues during the period totaled $174,562, 141, against $163,821,367 a year ago.

title: WINGS WIN, 63, END BRUIN STRING
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP)Alex Delvecchio scored his 400th and 401st National Hockey League career goals and Gordie Howe registered his 1,000th regular season assist to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 53 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

title: Schells Join for Play
description: Maria Schell, film and stage actress, has signed to play the principal female role next month in At the Order of the Empress, written by her father, Hermann Ferdinand Schell. The comedy, to be staged by the actress's brother, Maximilian Schell, will be pre sented at the Salzburg State Theater in Austria.

title: The Kalashnikov Kid
description: AMMAN  During the recent civil war in which they received a bloody nose from Jordan's army the greatest accomplishment of the Palestine guer rillas was a decision to unite their bickering factions under the command of a single man, Yasir Arafat.

title: MARKET DECLINES AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: The stock market's brisk ral ly on Wednesday ran aground yesterday after the opening hour. Then, stock averages settled lower in desultory trad ing.

title: Eartha Kitt Starring on London Stage
description: LONDONEartha Kitt, the singer who has sought to play Cleopatra, Medea and a Henry James heroine, has finally re solved one of her professional yearnings.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: State Voter Rolls Drop From Totals in 1966
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) The Secretary of State's of fice reported today that 7,930,798 New Yorkers were registered to vote in the elec tions next Tuesday for Gov ernor, United States Senator and other offices.

title: City Refuses Lease to a Local Group
description: Overriding the Mayor's recommendation, the Board of Estimate voted 14 to 8 yester day against allowing a broadly based community group to lease a 16story cityowned building on the Lower East Side for 35 years.

title: Lawyer to Marry Miss Van Cise
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 29Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Gordon Van Cise have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Woodruff Van Cise, to Wil liam O'Connor Harnisch, a lawyer with the New York firm of Cahill, Gordon, Son nett, Reindel & Ohl, where his future fatherinlaw is a senior partner.

title: MISS MEIER SINGS FIRST FAUST ROLE
description: Two new faces graced the New York City Opera's per formance of Faust Wednes day night. Johanna Meier, who sang her initial Marguerite with the company, at first seemed a bit too pallid and retiring even for this sweet girl next door, but her performance gained in profile as the evening wore on and in the final prison scene her acting was most af fecting.

title: Panel Bids Blood Banks Test for Hepatitis Virus
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  A panel of the National Research Council urged today that blood banks increase their testing for the presence of hepatitis virus to reduce the risk of infections that can be transmited through blood transfusions.

title: In Memoriam
description: DEUTSCHBertha. In loving memory of our sister. October 30, 1969.

title: CORPORATE SPENDING. ON POLITICS WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Justice Department is broadening its drive on ques tionable campaign spending i in investigate the executive poli tical funds set up by some corporation officials to funnel money to favorite candidates.

title: A Favorite New York Tradition
description: 12 NOON TO 3 P.M.

title: Books of The Times
description: Don't go away bored yet. The subject isn't quite dead. Chicago may have fallen on us last winter like a hail of cuckoo clocks and struck us dizzy; but the hour is past now and we may yet figure out what happened. Judging from this first trickle of serious books on the subject, there is still much to be said about the conspiracy trial of the Chicago Eight SevenNine (subtract Bobby Seale and add the defense lawyers William M. Kunstler and Leonard Weinglass). And I'm not in cluding Tom, Hayden's Trial (Holt, Rine hart & Winston, $4.95), which ought to be read, or Joseph Okpaku's Verdict!: The Exclusive Picture Story of the Trial of the Chicago 8, with drawings by Verna Sa dock (The Third Press, $7.95; paperbound, $3.95), which is so much poorly written scattershot. These two are partisan books and not what I have in mind at the mo ment.

title: City Hall Charges Beame Hired Consultants Without Board Vote
description: The Lindsay administration has charged in an affidavit made public yesterday that Controller Abraham D. Beame awarded two consultant con tracts totaling more than $100,000 without submitting them to the Board of Estimate.

title: Vorster's Party Suffers a New Setback in South African Provincial Elections
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Oct. 29South Africa's governing National party re ceived its second electoral set back of the year today as re sults of provincial council elec tions showed a shift toward the United party, the main op position.

title: Poor Marks for the F.B.I.
description: An institution that places itself above criticism cuts its bridges to vital realities, including those that dictate reforms in attitudes and procedures. It is with precisely such selfdestructive insularity that the Federal Bureau of Investigation ordered fifteen of its agents to drop their studies at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, in protest against a professor's criticism of some of the bureau's opinions. Among the offending comments by Dr. Abraham S. Blumberg, an expert in law and sociology, was that Edgar Hoover has been director of the F.B.I. too long, with the result that a cult of his personality has tended to develop.

title: Consultant Set for Bonwit
description: Harry Hinson, vice president and director of store planning and design for Bonwit Teller for the last five years, will form his own design and planning concern, effective Jan. 1, 1971. Mr. Hinson has been retained by Bonwit's as a design con sultant.

title: Beret Captain's Murder Conviction Is Overturned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The 1968 murder conviction and sentence of a Green Beret cap tain involved in clandestine missions into Cambodia were set aside today by three judges of the Army Court of Military Review.

title: 8th St. Mural Stirs Landmark Dispute
description: Thomas Kyan, an impetu ous young artist, is at war with the city's cautious Land marks Preservation Commis sion. And small wonder. Zealously watching over the Greenwich Village Historic District, it has ordered him to remove a mural he has painted on an outdoor wall at the fourthandfifthstory levels of a building at 52 West Eighth Street.

title: How to Settle Vietnam
description: As one professionally interested in negotiation, I went to Paris to see if it looked like a negotiated settlement in Vietnam is possible.

title: Peking Delegation on Way
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 29  A delegation left Peking today to attend the inauguration of Dr. Allende, Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, re ported.

title: O'Brien Asks Inquiry On Smear Tactic Ads
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chair man, lashed out today at a series of advertisements that have appeared in more than 60 newspapers in at least six states accusing Democratic candidates of being easy on crime, trying to tear down America and encouraging student violence.

title: Wilder's Sherlock Holmes Opens at the Music Hall
description: In 1899, William Gillette, the American actor, sought the permission of Arthur Co nan Doyle to present Sherlock Holmes in a play in which the world's first and un doubtedly most famous con sulting detective would get married. Mr. Doyle, who six years earlier had tried to re move Holmes from the lit erary scene by letting him disappear into the falls at Reichenbach, replied that Mr. Gillette could do what he wished. The author couldn't have cared less. To the man who was later to be knighted as Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Sherlock Holmes had become a profitable but bloody bore.

title: Reagan Orders Troops To Guard Candidates
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 29 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Rea gan said today that some National Guardsmen had been called up to protect California candidates on election night. His reelection opponent branded the action political grandstanding.

title: Baeza Ends 25Race Riding Slump by Registering Triple
description: While Braulio Baeza broke a 25race riding slump, Aque duct's apprentice jockeys kept looking yesterday for the breakthrough that could re store the bug to fashion here.

title: ROBERT MEYERS, 51, ILLUSTRATOR, SHOT
description: CODY, Wyo., Oct. 29Roberi Meyers, a magazine illustrator who in recent years alternated his work as an artist with the operation of a dude ranch south west of here, was shot fatally in the head shortly after noon yesterday as he and his wife were digging post holes for fence. He was 51 years old.

title: Doctor Testing AirIllness Link Finds More Rural Emphysema
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29A public health physician reported find ings here today that challenge widely held theories that urban air pollution is a direct cause of respiaratory disease.

title: A Business That Thrives in Area of Despair
description: Joseph Coles's wages are about half what they were year ago when he drove laundry truck. He works longer hours and collects no overtime. Yet, when the fab rics printed with leopard masks, elephanttusk carv ings and African bronzes come rolling off the produc tion line under his direction, there is a proud look in his eyes that his purple sun glasses cannot congaal.

title: CAR IS ONLY CLUE IN ILLINOIS SLAYING
description: PALATINE. Ill., Oct. 29 (UPI) A latemodel Oldsmobile, de scribed by the police as either black or red with a black top, was the only clue today in the murder of the millionaire horse man George W. Jayne.

title: CONNECTICUT TOUR MADE BY KENNEDY
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 29Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy took a day off from his own Mas sachusetts campaign today for a sixcity swing through Con necticut to bolster the un certain Democratic forces here.

title: CHURCH ASKS EASING OF CURBS ON CUBA
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 29 Senator Frank Church, Demo crat of Idaho, called here today for a relaxation of the rigid and inflexible United States policy toward Cuba.

title: DEADLINE IS SET FOR PAPER STRIKE
description: The Newspaper Guild an nounced last night that it had set a deadline of 6 A.M. Mon day for a strike against either The New York Times or The Daily News if new agreements had not been reached by that time.

title: Nixon's Campaign Tactics Turn Heckling to His Own Advantage
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 28  When the doors to Bayfront Center in St. Petersburg were opened this morning, among the first in line were 20 longhaired students who had come to heckle President Nixon.

title: HEARINGS ARE URGED ON WASHINGTON HIGH
description: A group of parents called on Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton yesterday for public hearings into conditions that they said had turned George Washington High School into a cauldron of racial ha tred and community warfare.

title: Defending the Defenders
description: This letter to Secretary of the Treasury Kennedy by the dean of the University of Pennsylvania's law school concerns the decision of the Internal Revenue Service to suspend tax exemptions for organizations specializing in litigation (such as on defective products or against polluters) in the public interest. My dear Secretary: I write this letter primarily from the perspective of an educator, secondarily from that of a tax law professor.

title: Lindsay in Buffalo
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Oct. 29  Mayor Lindsay came here today to praise Arthur J. Gold berg but talked as if he came to bury the Nixon Administration.

title: Agnew Concedes Remarks Vary as Audience Changes
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29 Vice President Agnew con ceded today that, as some poli ticians do but do not admit, he sometimes tailors his differ ent campaign statements to dif ferent campaign audiences.

title: An OttingerGoodell Debate Fizzles
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican incumbent, and Representative Richard L. Ot tinger, his Democratic opponent in the race for the United States Senate, went to Harlem last night for a scheduled debate. But they failed to con front each other.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS SIGN AGREEMENT ON SPACE DOCKING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed today that the United States and the Soviet Union had taken a ma jor step toward space cooper ation by agreeing to develop mutually compatible rendezvous and docking systems for space craft.

title: JAPANESE ACCUSED ON DUMPING CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The United States Treasury has ruled that Japan has dumped on the United States market ferrite cores used in electronic products, with a value of more than $650,000.

title: 25 Are Nominated for N.B.A. Career AllStar Team
description: Twentyfive pro basketball players who carved a legend of greatness in the National Basketball Association were nominated yesterday for the career AllStar team to be named next January in San Diego.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: ILIA A. TOLSTOY, 68, AN ICHTHYOLOGIST
description: Ilia A. Tolstoy, noted ichthy ologist and grandson of Leo Tolstoy, the Russian author, died Wednesday in New York Hospital of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 300 East 57th Street.

title: CREDIT EXPANDING AT A STEADY PACE
description: Money and bank credit ex panded at a moderate pace dur ing the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday show ed, but the demand for business loans at the major money center banks was notably weak.

title: Eggs and Rocks Thrown at Nixon After Coast Talk
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 29 Demonstrators threw eggs, rocks, and placards at Presi dent Nixon's limousine tonight as he left the San Jose Muni cipal Auditorium following a political speech.

title: Defunct Magazine Upheld on Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) A Federal Trade Commis sion hearing examiner today ordered dismissal of deceptive trade practice charges against publishers of the now defunct Saturday Evening Post.

title: FOOTBALL TONIGHT
description: Horne teams listed first Miami (Fla.)Florida St. U.C.L.A.Washington St.

title: Northeast Utility Sells an Offering Of $35.58Million
description: Northeast Utilities raised $35.58million with the com petitive sale yesterday of 3 mil lion common shares to an un derwriting group managed by the First Boston Corporation.

title: $9Million for Liner Terminal Shifted to a Container Project
description: Nine million dollars origin ally allocated to a future pas senger terminal for luxury lin: ers on the Hudson River were formally transferred to a Brook lyn container port project yes terday.

title: Books of The Times
description: Nadine Gordimer's last novel, The Late Bourgeois World, was published four years ago, and we know now what she has been doing all this time. She has been writing this one. A Guest of Honor is a long, spacious, comprehensive work of fiction. It has all the lineaments of traditional story. It is leisurely and detailed in narrative, melodramatic in its ending, exhaus tive and superbly successful in its evocation of land scape and back ground. It lacks the restless energy and offbeat psy chological probing of much current fiction. In fact, there is something Olympian, some thing magifi cently confident in the way in which this South African writer goes about her work. Her

description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Sports Today
description: Long Island Bulls vs. Hartford Knights at Hofstra field, Hemp stead, L. 1., 8 P.M. (Radio WGBB, 8 P.M.)

title: U.S. War Dead Below 50 For the 4th Week in Row
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (AP)  The United States command reported today that 43 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, three more than the week be fore.

title: Unlimited Racers Move To Stifle Yawns of Fans
description: Unlimited hydroplane rac ing, once the glamour spoit of the future, has suddenly realized it is in danger of be coming extinct. It took some tans in Seattle to shake up the sport's commissioner, George (Buddy) Byers Jr. They re acted to a poll by saying: We'd rather sit at home and watch on televi sion than sit on the shore for long periods waiting for something to happen. Too often bored by too few boats and too little competition hydro fans lately have found them selves watching meaningless qualifying heats with three boats, one of them jumping off to a halfalap lead and the other two hundreds of yards apart.

title: Walinsky Sues or Uaoter Of State's industrial Chief
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29  Adam Walinsky, the Democratic can didate for Attorney General, is seeking the dismissal of Stati. Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood.

title: Dun G Bradstreet: City Future Good
description: Despite Mayor Lindsay's re cent gloomy forecast of possi ble payless pay days for city employes, Dun & Bradstreet has informed its clients that the city's longrange financial future has extraordinary eco nomic strength.

title: NIXON PLAN BURIED, REDS SAY IN PARIS

title: 4 Major Banks Forming Joint Venture in Europe
description: PARIS, Oct. 29Four of the world's largest banks an nounced today a $50million cooperative venture. It was the second agreement for a multinational banking linkup to be announced this month.

title: A Correction
description: John Leonard mentioned only one price in his review of Sis terhood Is Powerful, published in hardcover by Random House. It is also published by Vintage Paperbacks in a $2.45 edition.

description: An agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testi fied yesterday at the trial of 13 Black Panthers here that a defendant had threatened him the previous day.

title: General and 2 Others Die in Crash
description: KENOVA, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP)Maj. Gen. Edwin H. Burba, on his way to More head, Ky., to present the Army's highest civilian award to a friend, was killed with two chief warrant officers to day when their crippled twin engine military plane crashed at TriState Airport.

title: Powers to Head Smith, Barney
description: Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., announced yesterday the election of Robert A. Powers as chairman and chief ex ecutive officer to succeed Hugh Knowlton Jr., who is retiring at the age of 47 to pursue personal interests.

title: Some Facts on Survey Of Voters in the State
description: The New York Times/ Yankelovich survey, which began Sept. 15, is based on a daily series of 40 to 60 inter views conducted by tele phone with persons whose names were selected from state voter registration lists.

title: Advertising: Grey Sells DirectMail Unit
description: Grey Advertising has sold its sixyearold directmail subsidiary, Grey & Chapman, to Wunderman, Ricotta & Klein. The amount of the cash deal was not disclosed.

title: Susanna McKemie Wed to C. H. Drexel
description: Miss Susanna Louisa Mc Kemie and Clinton Howard Drexel were married Satur day. The civil ceremony took place on the lawn of Foot point Plantation which is owned by the bridegroom's uncle, Henry Sargent Cram, in Bluffton S.C.

title: Marsden J. Perry Is Dead at 68; A Commander in Naval Reserve
description: Marsden J. Perry, a retired cothmander in the Naval Re serve and a collector of hooks on war and on naval and mili tary strategy, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 322 East 57th Street.

title: Margaret Waldinger Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Cohen of New York and Koneonga Lake, N. Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Cohen's daughter, Miss Margaret Waldinger, to Les lie Seff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Seff of Queens Vil lage, Queens.

title: COLORADO MERGER OF BANKS APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board disagreed today with the Jus tice Department and approved the application of Colorado's largest bank holding company to acquire control of a bank at Colorado Springs.

title: LATVIAN JEWS SEEK AID OF REDS IN WEST
description: LONDON, Oct. 29Some So viet Jews living in Latvia have appealed to 23 Communist par ties in the West to intercede with Moscow to allow them to join relatives in Israel.

title: Music: Spirited Elijah
description: The truth of St. Paul's ad monition that the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life was confirmed in the performance of Mendels sohn's Elijah in Philhar monic Hall Wednesday night. In conducting the oratorio for the American Bible So ciety's fifth annual benefit concert, Lukas Foss disre garded probably half the rhythmic and dynamic mark ings in the score, but he gave it so much dramatic fervor and musical sweep that he realized its potential power. For this listener it was a most persuasive read ing of a work that is usually smothered in a pious observ ance of every metronomic indication and every decre scendo.

title: Flyers Subdue Kings
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UPI)Thirdperiod goals by Wayne Hillman, Earl Heiskala and Serge Bernier gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 31 vic tory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

title: Pathet Lao's Formula for Talks Is Accepted by the Government

title: The Air New York Breathes
description: The city's Commissioner of Air Resources, Dr. Robert N. Rickles, says he has been under pressure to drop the designation unhealthy which his department has applied to the air New Yorkers breathe more than seventy times so far this year. The Commissioner's stand ards are too tough, critics say, and his labels too alarm inn.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOLS URGED TO EXPAND AND ALTER GOALS
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29A basic overhaul in medical training was recommended today by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education in a re port that called for a 30 per cent increase in medical stu dents, a 20 per cent increase in dental students and more allied health personnel to meet American health needs in the nineteenseventies.

title: Nastase Is Upset by Lloyd In Tennis by 63, 36, 63
description: PORT TALBOT, Wales, Oct. 29, (Reuters)David Lloyd of Britain scored an upset victory today over Ilie Nastase of Ru mania, the topseeded player, in the quarterfinal round of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tour nament. Nastase lost, 63, 36, 63.

title: PLATINUM OPTIONS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Platinum futures continued their downward path yesterday in fairly heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Five of the options hit new lows for the life of the contract, com pared with four the day before.

description: Sandra Lloyd Lesser, vice president and director of edi torial services for Reportes Medicos, a publication for phy sicians in Latin America, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, after a long illness. She was 45 years old and lived at 412 East 55th Street.

title: Parsons Resigns a Post

Mr. Stewart is president of the Federally licensed venturecapital small business investment company. The company's stockholders in clude more than 15 banks in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Cultural Gala: Diamonds and Pickets
description: The New York City Cul tural Council had its first benefit Wednesday, and it was one of those now in frequent events everybody thinks of as a gala. Most of the ladies were iced up with masses of diamonds and such. Ballgowns far outnumbered the new, more casual, eve ning attire. And the men, who have been turning up recently in almost anything after dark, were in plain old black tie.

title: Yale vs. Dartmouth: They're This Close
description: The irresistible force will collide with the immovable objector is it the other way round?  when Dartmouth faces Yale in a clash of un defeated Ivy League teams at the Bowl tomorrow. The Bulldogs nave been fashioned into a finely tuned offensive defensive unit by Carmen Cozza. The Han over Indians, un der Bob Black man, are just as well balanced. Statistically, the teams are about as close as possible. Yale, in defense against scoring, stands third nationally with a 5.8 mark. Dartmouth ranks sixth with an average of 8.4 points. But in overall defense, the Indians stand third, having allowed 179.6 yards a game, while the Bulldogs stand fifth with a yield of 193.8 a game.

title: Candidate Unhurt in Crash
description: FORSYTH, Ga., Oct. 29 (AP) A car carrying the Repub lican governorship candidate, Hal Suit, overturned down an embankment on a rainslick highway today, but the candi date was not injured. He did not see a doctor but complained of a stiffness in his neck.

title: CORRUPTION UNIT PLANS SUBPOENAS

title: Flexner's Attack Closed Quack Schools Quickly

title: Propaganda or Peace?
description: The Egyptians and their supporters have had a chance to let off steam in the United Nations General Assembly this week; that is certainly preferable to their shooting off the new weapons they have packed into the Suez front in violation of the standstill ceasefire. But, feared, the Assembly debate so far has produced more propaganda than progress toward peace.

title: The 19th District
description: POPULATION  There are about 445,000 people in this economically and racially mixed district. Jews make up the largest ethnic bloc; there are also large concen trations of Puerto Ricans, Italians, Chinese and blacks, as well as pockets of Poles and Ukrainians. The area includes thriving middleclass enclaves in the West Village, Chelsea and the Upper West Side as well as the slums and housing projects of the Lower East Side.

He was tied for 137th.

description: Fredell Lack, a violinist who for many years ornamented the New York musical scene and now is artistinresidence at the University of Houston, returned here on Wednesday night in recital at Alice Tully Hall with a Houston colleague, the pian ist Albert Hirsch. Academics residency has done nothing, ap parently, to diminish the skills, of either musician, and they collaborated in a program marked by excellent musician ship and highly polished team work.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The State Department spokes man, Robert McCloskey, said today that the department was seriously distressed by the deaths of Mr. Frosch and Mr. Sawada.

description: Until recent years, we have looked upon the oceans of the world as inexhaustible. That they could be overfished seemed impossible; their vast expanse alone made such a thought ludicrous.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The United States is pre pared to return to Russia frag ments of a Soviet space satel lite that rained down on parts of the Middle West last month, State Department officials said tonight.

title: Screen: A Loner vs. a Modern Mafia:'Machine Gun McCain' Stars Cassavetes
description: "Machine Gun McCain" and "Land Raiders" opened Wednesday at neighborhood theaters. There were five other openings on Wednesday, and for reasons of space, and the sanity of the staff, a review was delayed until today. For reasons of space, not sanity, the present review won't be long enough to do justice to a pair of mostly awful movies that are nevertheless not without interest and the honor of their genres. By any standards I can recognize, there is more to be said for this failed double bill than, say, for all the schlock earnestness of "Goin' Down the Road" or the nasty knowingness of "Little Fauss and Big Halsy."Nathan Juran's "Land Raiders" is a fairly ambitious blood-feud Western in which Telly Savalas plays an evil older brother, George Maharis plays a good younger brother with a part-time Spanish accent and Janet Landgard plays the love interest in a voice and manner that seem modeled on the style of Tricia Nixon. There are Indians, Apaches, and in the manner of recent Westerns, they winovercoming almost everything except Maharis, Miss Landgard and, presumably, the tide of history. Nothing about "Land Raiders" really works, but it is impossible wholly to dismiss a film so full of fancy flashbacks, super-emphatic characterizations and well-loved stereotypes."Machine Gun McCain", a modern Mafia movie made by Italians at home and in the United States with a rather illustrious international cast, actually has more to say about family relations than "Land Raiders." McCain (John Cassavetes), pardoned after 20 years in prison, confronts his son (Pierluigi Apra), whom he immediately identifies and disowns as a two-bit punk. He picks up a bar girl (Britt Ekland), who becomes his loyal accomplice in a highly improbable raid on a Las Vegas casino owned by the Mafia, whose revenge constitutes the fatal climax of the movie.Between the Mafia with its familial network of courtly captains and deferential lieutenants, and the unyielding loner McCain, whose personal morality will exclude an only son if necessary, a rather interesting contrast develops. At best the contrast is never sufficiently dramatized, and it finally falls in the inexpressiveness of Cassavetes's performance, the vagaries of the screenplay, and the superfluous introduction of an old flame (Gena Rowlands), who adds nothing but conventional confusion to the plot. But it is there to think about; to admire in passing, to lament its loss  as so frequently falls to those of us who love C movies.

title: Stage: Not Now, Darling

We pretend that all plays are of equal intrinsic interest to usbut dear friends, they are not. We each know the plays that we would, individually, be prepared to pay good green money to see, sight unseen.

description: SANTA CRUZ, Oct. 29 (UPI)  John Linley Frazier was ar raigned today on indictments charging him with killing fivepersons at Dr. Victor Ohta mountain mansion. Judg Charles Franich warned al parties to the case not to tall about it.

title: Economic Policy Is an Art
description: Item. The Prime Minister of Singa pore, Lee Kuan Yew, when passing through Cambridge recently, asked me why an advanced technology like America's should insist on producing lowproductivity textiles and common shoes. I touched a nerve of a New England radio audience when I quoted my answer. We should move our resources to more efficient uses and turn over to the developing countries primitive activities that any emerging economy can do with lowwage labor. Item. The single question I am most asked when lecturing abroad is this: Professor Samuelson, doesn't Amer ica's prosperity depend upon Cold War expenditures and imperialistic ven tures like that in Vietnam?
