description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reu ters)  The Federal Reserve Board unanimously approved today the application of Shaw mut Association, Inc., Boston, to acquire all voting shares of the Framingham National Bank, Framingham, Mass.

title: 18 Members of U.S. Team Honored at Ski Ball Here
description: Eighteen members of the United States team were honored last night at the an nual Ski Ball, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. Proceeds of the affair, attended by about 1,000 people, went to the United States Ski Team Fund.

title: BEATY HELPS STARS DEFEAT NETS,114105
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 29 (AP)The Utah Stars started slowly, but picked up momen tum in the third period tonight and went on to defeat the New York Nets, 114105, in an Amer ican Basketball Association game.

title: Blood Bank Head Named
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 (AP)Dr. William G. Battaile of Washington, D. C., has been named presidentelect of the American Association of Blood Banks to take office in Chicago at the group's 1971 convention. Dr. Bernard Henry of Syracuse, N. Y., is the incumbent presi dent.

title: Calls to Violence Scored by Buckley
description: The rhetoric of violence should be curbed, James L. Buckley said yesterday, but he added that this did not mean that he favored new laws to limit freedom of speech.

title: Data on Silk Stocking District
description: POPULATION: There are about 500,000 residents in Manhattan's 17th Congres sional District, which extends from 97th Street on the north to Houston Street on the South, from Ninth Avenue on the west, to the East River. The area is largely middle and upper class, but there are pockets of poverty on the Lower East Side, in the Nineties and East Thirties.

title: Witness Against WPIX Admits Exaggeration in 1968 Complaint
description: Mrs. Nancy McCarthy, a for mer news writer for WPIX, con ceded yesterday that she had exaggerated in one instance when she listed allegations of news distortions and impropri eties to Fred M. Thrower, presi dent of the television station.

title: Music: Copland Salute
description: Aaron Copland is going to be 70 years old in two weeks on Nov. 14, to be exact and orchestras all over the world are taking note. The New York Philharmonic did, on Thursday night, with Mr. Copland conducting a con cert of his own music. There was an added honor. At intermission, Amyas Ames, chairman of the Philhar monic, made a short speech and presented the composer with an honorary member ship in the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York.

title: WHITE HOUSE DOUBTS IT CAN WIN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  Republican control of the Senate in the election is be yond what you ought to ex pect, Herbert G. Klein, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Dartmouth Will Shuttle Kicker by Ail
description: Men cannot move mountains, but Wayne Pirmann has helped change the starting time for the DartmouthYale soccer game, and he may become the deciding factor in the crucial football showdown between the two unbeaten Ivy League schools today at the Yale Bowl.

title: RIDERS CONSIDER PACE KEY FACTOR
description: When Angel Cordero Jr. takes Twogundan out for the $109,900 Jockey Club Gold Cup today at Aqueduct, he'll be steering him as gingerly as firsttimer at a riding academy.

title: Excerpts From Summary of F.B.I. Report on Kent State U. Disorders Last May
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Following are excerpts from a summary by the Justice Department of a Federal Bu reau of Investigation report on the Kent State University disorders of May 4:

title: Mexicans Coming Nov. 11
description: The Mexicans Are Coming, a variety show from Mexico City, including 68 dancers, singers, musicians and comedi ans, will open at the Mark Hel linger Theater on Nov. 11 in stead of Wednesday. Produced by Umberto Cecchi, the enter tainment features Luis Gascon, Ema Pulido, Luis Elliot, Miguel Alberto, the Tex Mex Trio and Daniel Armas.

title: On Jordan's West Bank, Frustration Amid Plenty
description: RAMALLAH, Israeli  Occu pied Jordan, Oct. 29  Mine were the best olives on the whole west bank  I worked hard for this, said Abed Ka rim Fayad, a farmer from the Tulkarm area, displaying the first prize he had won at the Ramallah agricultural fair, a shiny insecticidespraying sys tem.

title: Peru Laws Forcing Out Foreign Concerns
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 30Ford, General Motors, British Leyland Motors and Fiat plan to close their assembly plants here by the end of the year, while the Royal Bank of Canada is con sidering either a merger or the shutting of its doors in Peru.

title: Two Leaving Disabled Train Are on Tracks
description: Thousands of Penn Central commuters were delayed as much as three hours yesterday morning by an accident in the Bronx in which two passengers alighting from a disabled train were struck by a train on an adjacent track.

title: Peter Doelger, President Of Old Brewing Company
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Oct. 30Peter Doelger, president of the former Peter Doelger Brew ing Company in New York from 1933 to 1945, died Wednesday in Point Pleasant Hospital, after a short illness. He was 65 years old and lived in the Beacon Manor Apartments and at Boyn ton Beach Fla.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DIP IN QUIET DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mostly lower yesterday in quiet trading.

title: 2 CHURCH GROUPS CONCLUDE TALKS
description: Some topranking Roman Catholic theologians called on the church yesterday to rec ognize the validity of the Lu theran ministry and the real presence of Christ in the Lu theran administration of holy communion.

title: Proposition One: Yes
description: Because additional lowcost public housing is desper ately needed and present levels of state subsidy have been exhausted, voters are urged to approve Proposition One on the state ballot Nov. 3. Approval of this proposi tion is essential under the State Constitution which requires direct voter acceptance of levels of state hous ing subsidies.

title: MORTGAGES GAIN AT THRIFT UNITE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Savings and loan associations closed $2.1billion for mort gages in September, up about 25 per cent from the same month a year ago, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board an nounced today.

title: C. M. Spofford Weds Mrs. Luddy
description: Mrs. Brewster Luddy and Charles M. Spofford, a part ner of the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell here were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Church Methodist by the Rev. Harold Bosley.

title: Bomb Blasts San Juan Base
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 30 (UPI) A bomb exploded early today outside the message cen ter of the United States Naval Base in Miramar. There were no casualties. Damage was slight.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Stage: The Tokyo Kid Brothers Again
description: The Tokyo Kid Brothers the delightful people who gave us, and indeed are still giving us, The Golden Bat at the Sheridan Square Play househave extended their operations. They have been offering in a series of mid night performances (the last so far scheduled are tonight and tomorrow night) at Cafe La Mama a brand new show, Coney Island Play.

title: 2 Cosmos Satellites Placed In Earth Orbits by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (UPI) Soviet space scientists launched two unmanned Cosmos satel lites today, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: SOVIET TAKES STEPS TO CURB HIJACKINGS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (AP) The Soviet airline Aeroflot is taking serious precautionary measures against hijackers and other persons who might board planes with criminal in tent, the Civil Aviation Min istry reported today.

title: BULLS DOWN KNIGHTS ON LATE PASS, 2420
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 30 The Long Island Bulls, after six defeats, posted their first victory of the season tonight by turning back the Hartford Knights, 2420, in an Atlantic Coast Football League game.

title: April in Paris Ball, Age 19, Goes On Dancing
description: It was 19 years old last night and, as these things go, it is an age bordering on senility. Over the years, its demise has been forecast with monotonous regularity, but the April in Paris Ball goes on and on, confounding the prophets of doom, sur mounting economic reces sions and ignoring the long sighs of boredom.

title: GUSTAV FORSTENZER
description: Gustav Forstenzer, who re tired two years ago as a distrib utor of personal leather goods here and earlier had been co owner of a department store in Braunschweig, Germany, died yesterday in Kew Gardens Gen eral Hospital, Queens. He was 82 years old and lived in Kew Gardens.

title: Story to Have 7:30 Curtain
description: Paul Sills Story Theater wiil inaugurate a 7:30 P.M. cur tain time for all evening per formances at the Ambassador Theater starting Nov. 10.

title: KENT STATE STUDY BY F.B.I. DIFFERS FROM OHIO FINDING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30A Justice Department summary of the inquiry by the Federal Bu reau of Investigation into the shootings at Kent State Univer sity last May 4 differs sharp ly from the conclusion reach ed later by an Ohio grand jury that exonerated National Guardsmen on the ground that they believed they were physi cally threatened.

title: VIETNAM PENALIZES AMERICAN REPORTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct, 30The South Vietnamese national press center has with drawn the press accreditation of the American journalist and former social worker who first publicized the tigercage pris on cells on Con Son, an island 60 miles off South Vietnam.

title: Chief Awards at Horse Show
description: Chief Awards at Horse Show

title: Hawks Caldwell Jumps to A.B.A. Team
description: CHARLOTTES, N.C., Oct. 30 (AP)Joe Caldwell, a star for ward with the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball As sociation, jumped tonight to the Carolina Cougars of the rival American Basketball Associa tion.

title: Goodell Booed by Hard Hats at World Trade Center
description: Senator Charles Goodell visited the site of the World Trade Center yesterday and was booed and heckled by a lunchhour crowd of 200 con struction workers when he tried to tell them why they should not support James L. Buckley, his Conservative party opponent.

title: Watson Is Held Insane In Tate Murder Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (UPI)Charles (Tex) Watson, 24 years old, was adjudged today as insane and unable to stand trial in the Tate LaBianca murders by a judge who said the young man was turning into a vegetable and was in imminent danger of death.

title: Four Seized in San Jose
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 30 Four men were arrested last night on various charges in connection with the eggthrow ing incident. They were iden tified by the San Jose police as Gayle M. Justice, 31 years old, of San Jose; Doyle Dean Hart line, 21, of San Jose; Ronald John Cosetti, 29, of Santa Clara, and Randy Lewis Proda novich, 20, of San Jose.

title: President to Get Program To Curb Terror Bombings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Attorney General John Mitchell and 13 representatives of the nation's police chiefs agreed today on recommendations that will be submitted President Nixon for coopera tion between Federal, state and local officials to combat terrorist bombings and at tacks on policemen.

title: $5.3Million More Is Asked to Erect Minischools Here
description: Mayor Lindsay recommended additional capital spending yes terday to finance a total of 30 prefabricated socalled mini schools, most of them in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

title: Hnueilings
description: BLACKMANDavid. The unveiling of the monument, in loving memory of David Blackman will take place on Sunday, November 1st, at 11 A.M., at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Amityville, New York. Plot C6 Section 90.

title: NICKLAUS AT 145 IN SAHARA EVENT
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 30Tom my Aaron, who traveled 12 miles into the desert to score a leading 64 yesterday, played a course within the city limits today and set the pace again with a 36hole aggregate of 135 in the $100,000 Sahara invita tion golf tourney.

title: L. I. Lighting Profit Falls
description: I Net income of the Long Is land Lighting Company fell to $8,882,000, or 38 cents a share, in the third quarter from $9, 127,000 or 44 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues of the utility rose to $71,713, 000, from $66,390,000 a year ago.

title: Florida State Trounces Miami, 273
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP)Tom Bailey rolled up 108 yards in the third quarter tonight to be come Florida State's top career rusher and paced the Seminoles to a 273 victory over Miami.

title: Trustees File Result
description: The trustees of the Penn Len trai Transportation Company filed a report with the Federal District court in Philadelphia yesterday showing that the rail road had operated at a net loss in the first eight months this year of $208,930,467. This com pared with a $50,917,939 net loss reported by the railroad in the corresponding period last year, when it still was operating under private ownership.

title: 4 Arrested as Crowd Gathers In Clashes Near Times Square
description: A series of melees between the police and bystanders broke our in the Times Square area last night after the police tried to question the occupant of suspicious car.

title: Foreplay to Bow Dec.
description: Foreplay, a new play by Robert M. Lane, will be pre sented at the Bijou Theater on Dec. 1 by Sweet Alice Ltd. The cast will consist of Robert Jun delin, Donn Whyte, Amy Burk and Peter Spar. The scenery is by Leo B. Meyer.

title: Mary H. Wylde Becomes Bride Of Stuart Swiny
description: DOVER, Mass., Oct. 30 In the orangery of Three Brooks, her father's country home here, Miss Mary Helena Wylde, an archeologist, was married today to Stuart Swiny, a fellow of the British Institute of Persian Studies in Teheran. The Rev. Gary Rundle, an Episcopal priest, performed a ceremony writ ten by the couple.

title: Paris Hotel for Dogs Only
description: PARISThe Rue Paul Bert is a quiet residential street in suburban Puteaux. It is lined with middleclass hous es occupied by quiet middle class people, but the one at Number 17, has, to all in tents and purposes, gone to the dogs.

title: John C. Rogan, 85, Dies; An ExReporter for Mirror
description: John Christopher Rogan, a former reporter who covered police headquarters for The New York Mirror from its in ception in 1925, died of stroke Thursday in Coney Island Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

title: With Polish and Jaunty Touch, Garner Plays at Persian Room
description: In the last 25 years, Erroll Garner, the jazz pianist, has gone from 52d Street, where he sometimes worked in three clubs at the same time, to Carnegie Hall, where jazz is frequently heard, and now to the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, where jazz has never been heard before. He will play in the Persian Room twice each night.

title: Koch Faces Novel Challenge in Silk Stocking District
description: Voters in the 17th Congres sional District, Manhattan's so called Silk Stocking District, have a choice on Tuesday be tween two major candidates  Edward I. Koch, the Democrat Liberal incumbent, and Peter J. Sprague, a political neophyte who says he would have voted exactly as Mr. Koch did had he been in Washington instead.

title: BATON OF MEHTA EVOKES 2 MOODS
description: Zubin Mehta led the Los An geles Philharmonic in a pro gram that had only two works on it Thursday night at Carne gie Hall. For one of them, Mr. Mehta conducted as though he had a slide rule for a baton, and for the other, a club. One was Penderecki's Cosmog ony, commissioned for the 25th anniversary of the United Nations and given its first per formance at United Nations headquarters last Saturday. The other was Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

title: DR. PAUL H. CURTS
description: Dr. Paul H. Curts, emeritus professor of German at Wes leyan University, Middletown, Conn., died Thursday in Dur ham, N. C., to which ha re cently moved. He was 86 years old.

title: DR. AARON BORTIN, L.I. PSYCHIATRIST
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 30Dr. Aaron W. Bortin, direc tor of psychiatry since 1964 at Brunswick Hospital Center, Amityville, L. I., died in United Hospital here yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived at 18 Juneau Road, Woodbury, L. I.

title: Photoengravers Agree on Pact With 3 Daily Newspapers Here
description: Photoengravers Union 1P reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new threeyear contract with The New York Times, The Daily News and The Long Island Press.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge

title: Is Black Beautiful to Africans?
description: WASHINGTONThe African intelli gentsia has more than a passing inter est in the future of the American of African extraction. To begin with, there is between Black Africa and Black America a synthesis of blood and culture. We have both suffered in slavery and in colonialism at the hands of the white man.

title: Pope Travels Far, but Sees Little of His 108Acre Realm
description: ROME, Oct. 30Pope Paul VI, about to set out for East Asia and Australia, will stay away from the Vatican longer than any Pontiff has done in the last 120 years, but everyciay life in the world's smallest state will hardly change.

title: Executive Changes
description: Allen M. Shinn, a retired vice admiral in the United States Navy, has been elected president, chief executive officer and a director of Harvard Industries, Inc.

title: Leon Thompson to Direct Philharmonic Education Unit
description: Leon Thompson has been appointed director of the New York Philharmonic's new de partment of educational ac tivities. The purpose of the department will be to establish a closer relationship between the orchestra and the educa tional forces of the city and to increase the orchestra's educa tional activities.

title: Rockefeller Says Voters Are Not Shiftinp to Right
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 30Gover nor Rockefeller today chal lenged the that voters in this state were moving to the right.

title: Of Means and Ends
description: LONDON, Oct. 30For those in Europe who care about the United States, this has been a painful elec tion campaign. It has projected an American politics of fear and personal abuse, corrupted by money, with ra tional argument overwhelmed by pos turing. And now it has produced the outrage of violence against the Presi dent of the United States.

title: Royals Beat Cavaliers, 125110
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) Norm Van Lier scored 17 of his 23 points in the final quar ter to lead the Cincinnati Royals to a 125110 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: Photos Indicate Ohio Patrolmen Had a Role in Student Disorders
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 Photographs introduced into evidence at an Ohio State Uni versity disciplinary hearing have indicated that undercover State Highway Patrolmen played a role in the incident that touched off several days of dis orders here last Spring.

title: Books of The Times
description: Louise Bogan's critical pieces come to us almost as from another age. Not that her subjects are dated. The list of poets reviewed could not be more contemporary. But her tone of civilized inquiry, her judg ment that was both detached and involved, the complete absence of trivia and small talk and her desire only to engage the work

title: French Liner Out of Service As Talks With Waiters Fail
description: LE HAVRE, France, Oct. 30 (UPI)  The French Line took the liner France out of service today when strike negotiations with touristclass waiters broke down.

title: Rockefeller Says Voters Are Not Shiftingto Riat
description: Rockefeller Says Voters Are Not Shiftingto Riat

title: DR. HENRY SPENCER, RETIRED PROFESSOR
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 Dr. Henry Russell Spencer, pro fessor of political science at Ohio State University from 1909 until his retirement in 1949, the year he was president of the American Political Science As sociation, died here yesterday. He was 91 years old.

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: Charts of Races at Aqueduct

title: ManHour Output Rises; Factory Orders Post Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Output per manhour, the most common measure of productiv ity, rose substantially in the third quarter for the second quarter in a row, the Labor Department announced today. The rise amounted to 4.6 per cent on an annual basis.

title: Police Pressing a Search for Slayer of Teacher on West Side
description: Extra police patrols searched the tense Upper West Side yes terday for the slayer of a 22 yearold assistant teacher at the Brearley School who was found dead Thursday afternoon in her apartment at 310 West 73d Street.

title: RUSSIAN, AT U.N., ASKS RESUMPTION OF MIDEAST TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30The Soviet Union called today for the immediate and unconditional resumption of the ArabIsraeli peace talks.

title: Irene Andersson Bride Of H. A. Goodman
description: Miss Irene G. Andersson of Stockholm and Howard A. Goodman, a partner in the Joseph L. Shapiro Company, Inc., consultants and insur ance brokers, were married here yesterday afternoon by State Supreme Court Justice George Postel in his chambers.

title: CARNEGIE EXHIBITION OPENS IN PITTSBURGH
description: The Pittsburgh International Exhibition of Contemporary Art, established as an annual event in 1896 by Andrew Car negie, and the oldest surviving exhibition of its kind in Amer ica, opened its 45th version yes terday.

title: CITY OPERA TROUPE OFFERS TIGOLETTO
description: The New York City Opera gave its first performance of the season of Rigoletto on Thursday night. It might have been the fifth or sixth. There was energy to spare onstage and in the orchestra pit, but little of it seemed disciplined.

title: Hepatitis at NASA Center
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (UPI) Infectious hepatitis passed by communal coffee stirring spoon has broken out at The Lewis Research Center operated by the National. Aeronautics and Space Administration; it was reported today. Five aerospace engineers have contracted the disease. Doctors innoculated other workers at the center.

title: Antiques: A Ming Must
description: The exhibition of Ming Porcelains at the China Insti tute, 125 East 65th Street, is a must for ceramics collectors and a fascinating display of fine craftsmanship that is worth anyone's time.

title: CHARLES DELEUW, ENGINEER, WAS 79
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30Charles. E. DeLeuw, a prominent con sulting engineer in the field of transportation planning and construction, particularly sub ways and highways, died Wednesday in a nursing home here. He was 79 years old.

title: McDonnell Douglas Chief To Add Post of President
description: The McDonnell Douglas Cor poration announced yesterday that James S. McDonnell, chair man and chief executive offi cer, will assume the additional duties of president.

title: SPINSTER STAKES TO TAKEN ABACK
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 (AP)Taken Aback of Jack Dreyfus's Hobeau Farm soared to victory by 234 lengths in the $62,150 Spinster Stakes at Keeneland race track today.

title: Democrats Given Chance to Win State Assembly, but Not Senate
description: New York State Democrats, winding up their bestrun and bestfinanced legislative cam paign in years, are optimistic; about their chances of making substantial gains in both the State Senate and Assembly.

title: Aqueduct Entries
description: Aqueduct Entries

title: U.S. AIDE IS HOPEFUL ON HELSINKI TALKS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 30 Gerard C. Smith, the head of the United States delegation, said tonight that progress could be achieved in the Soviet American talks on limiting strategic arms despite current strains in relations between the two countries.

title: BEAMES'S 137 LEADS BY SHOT IN DUNLOP
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 30 (AP)Peter Beames, a 23 yearold British golfer, took the lead today at the halfway mark of the Dunlop international tournament by firing a second round 68 for a 137 total over the 7,116yard, par72 Royal Canberra course.

title: Raymond C. Hoiles, 91, Is Dead; Freedom Newspapers President
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 30 Raymond Cyrus Hoiles, pres ident of the Freedom News papers, Inc., a chain that pub lishes 20 daily newspapers, died today at the age of 91. He had been under treatment for kid ney disease in Santa Ana Hos pital.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Soybean futures, which had been declining for a couple of sessions, rebounded yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices ran up as much as cents a bushel at the top end of the list, but a wave of profit taking chopped away much of the gains.

title: White People Scared
description: The following are excerpts from a tape recording of a conversation which I had with a young blaclz girl from New Orleans whom I have known for a decadeever since she helped initiate school desegregation in that city:

title: List of Recently Published Books
description: A Game of Patience, by Lorna Pegram (Gambit, Boston, $4.95). A woman caught between the demands of integrity and need.

title: Heath's Socialist Chief Adviser
description: LONDON, Oct. 30  The newest recruit to Prime Min ister Heath's Conservative Government, and a highly significant one, is something of an anomaly in the halls of power.

title: U.S. Judge Sworn in Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 30 (AP) John J. Kitchen of Bridgeport was sworn in today as New Jer sey's 11th United States Districts Court judge at ceremonices at the Federal Building here. Mr. Kitchen, 59 years old, had been a Gloucester County judge since 1962.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices Oct. 20, 1970, to Oct. 27, 1970.

title: WEBSTER WEIGHS NEED FOR PUNTING
description: The interesting thing about what Coach Alex Webster of the Giants did yesterday was that he didn't do it.

title: 9Month Level Dips
description: Higher quarterly earnings but lower ninemonth results were reported yesterday by the Anaconda Company.

title: 3 Communists Given Key Economic Posts In Chilean Cabinet
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30 Presidentelect Salvador Al lende named a 15man Cabi net today that includes three members of the Communist party's Central Committee.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Two exciting players, Don Jackson and Ed Marinaro, should keep Baker Field buzzing. Has Scarlet forgotten how to win? Coach John Bateman is asking that question.

title: 28 Indicted Here For Role in Rioting At Detention Houses
description: The Brooklyn and Queens District Attorneys announced grand jury indictments yester day of 28 inmates accused of initiating jail riots earlier this month.

title: Market Place
description: Early this year American Metal Climax, Inc., let it be known that it planned to buy up the 57.7 per cent interest in Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., that it did not already own.

title: Lakers Repel Braves, 10490
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif Oct. 30 (UPI)Wilt Chamberlain tallied 20 points tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 10490 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: 2 WIDE RECEIVERS SHED LEG INJURIES
description: For the first time since the Jets season opener, George Sauer and Don Maynard appear to be available for fulltime duty against the Giants tomor row at Shea Stadium.

title: American Airlines, the 2d Biggest Domestic Line, Talks With Western
description: American Airlines, the na tion's second largest domestic air carrier, and Western Air Lines, the sixth largest, an nounced yesterday that they were holding merger discus sions.

title: A WideRanging Career
description: Lord Wakehurst, the former John De Vere Loder, was born in London on Feb. 5, 1895, had a wideranging career in the military, the Foreign Service and in the arts.

title: Key West Fears Crisis if Navy Pulls Out
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 29  An aging Cuban, Theadore Betancourt, sat at his work bench and used a caveta, a widebladed cigar knife, to cut a leaf of tobacco into the shape of a racing sail. He worked silently at the front of a small cigar shop near the Key West water front, and tourists paused on the sidewalk to watch through the window as his nimble fingers rolled the dull green leaf to wrap a core of darker tobacco.

title: MURPHY FOE FOUND DISTORTING RECORD
description: David D. Smith, the Republi canConservative candidate for the House of Representatives from the 16th District (Staten Island and Brooklyn), violated the Fair Campaign Practices Code on three counts in his race against the Democratic incumbent, John M. Murphy, the American Arbitration Asso ciation has ruled.

title: NEW ISSUES POST PRICE ADVANCES.
description: The newissue market con tinued to rebound this week from the depressed levels that have prevailed during most of the last six months.

title: Mrs. Bates Is Wed To Thomas Reich
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 30  Mrs. Virginia Avery Bates, daughter of Mrs. John ston Avery and the late Mr. Avery, was married here this noon to Thomas Gwyn Reich, president of the Tom Reich Chevrolet Company in Wil mington.

title: Moscow to Allow Second Visit To Generals by U.S. Officials
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30The So viet Union agreed today to per mit two United States consular officials to make a second vis it to the four officers who have been detained in Soviet Armenia for nine days, since their plane violated Soviet air space and landed in the border town of Leninakan.

title: DETROIT SEEKING ITS 10TH VICTORY
description: Last season, when the Knicks were soaring to their first Na tional Basketball Association championship in 24 years, they met the challenge on every oc casion when excellence was de manded.

title: A Show of Violence
description: Violence has no place in a free, lawful society. It is a contemptible effort to win by force what cannot be earned by reason and persuasion. Violence is repugnant when it is used against anyone, whether poor and defenseless or rich and powerful. It not only injures its victim but it also tears a gaping hole in the web of mutual trust and goodwill that holds society together.

title: British Bill Would Toughen Law on Oil Pollution of Sea
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP)The British Government, alarmed by the pollution of the coun try's coasts by oil, introduced legislation in the House of Commons today to impose tighter controls on ships that dump fuel into the sea.

title: Celtics Sink Suns, 127112
description: BOSTON. Oct. 30 (AP)The Boston Celtics, sparked by John Havlicek, shook off a late chal lenge by the Phoenix Suns to record a 127112 National Bas ketball Association victory to night.

title: Jubilee Ball Will Aid North Shore Hospital
description: The Winter Jubilee Ball, to aid the North Shore Hos pital's community clinic ac tivities, will take place here next Saturday at the Ameri cana Hotel.

title: FIDDLE ISLE IS 45 IN $108,600 STAKE
description: While Shuvee, a 4yearold filly, takes on a kingsized task when she tries to become the first of her sex to win the two mile Gold Cup at Aqueduct to day Fiddle Isle again will be out to prove that the Califor nia grass is greenerat least for himwhen he tries to win the $108,600 Oak Tree Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Fossil May Be Clue to Why First Bird Began to Fly
description: A scientist from Yale Univer sity has found new fossil evi dence that may help settle a longdebated mystery of evolu tion  what sort of life style prompted the first birds to, start flying?

title: Goldberg Doubts Rabbis Back Governor
description: Arthur J. Goldberg chal lenged yesterday the endorse ment of Governor Rockefeller by 12 orthodox rabbis, despite the appearance of 11 of the 12 with the Governor at a news conference on Thursday.

title: Candidates Found Upstate Television Mixed Blessing
description: For the last few days of the campaign, the candidates for statewide offices will, for the most part, confine their campaigning to the New York metropolitan area for one practical reason  the presence of seven television stations here, each eager to present the campaign wind up.

title: 3,000 JOIN PROTEST LED BY YOUNG LORDS
description: Crowds of Young Lords and their supporters marched to Dag Hammarskjold Plaza near the United Nations yesterday and held a demonstration call ing for the independence of Puerto Rico.

title: DR. SOLOMON JACOBS
description: Dr. Solomon Jacobs, a gen eral practitioner in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, for 40 years, died Monday in the University of Washington Hospital in Se attle, where he had gone for treatment. He was 68 years old and lived at 614 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

title: SOL RUBIN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 30Sol Rubin, a lawyer, died today at his home here, 21 Avis Drive. He was 71 years old.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: Aqueduct Jockeys

title: LABOR HEAD URGES AID FOR OTTINGER
description: The president of the State A.F.L.C.LO. said yesterday that organized labor had seri ously underestimated the rank and file's support of James L. Buckley for Senator and urged an 11thhour turnabout against the Conservative.

title: Anthony Baker, Caroline Arbon To Be Married
description: Miss Caroline Alker Arbon and Anthony Kane Baker, a filmmaker she met when they were summer school students at C.W. Post Col lege, plan to be married in May.

title: DR. IRVING J. COHEN, A PEDIATRICIAN, 62
description: Dr. Irvin J, Cohen, who re tired in 1969 as executive vice president of the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. Wash ington, after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: MRS. MEIR GIVES U.N. SOVIET JEWS PLEA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30Premier Golda Meir of Israel today gave Edvard Hambro of Norway, the Presi dent of the General Assembly, a letter addressed to him and signed by 77 Moscow Jews ap pealing for help to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Centuries of Discrimination
description: The one thing that has the badge of insolubility on it is the problem of how we are to live together in harmony and mutual respect. We have boasted for almost 200 years that we are a plural society wherein we achieve unity through diversity and accommodate diversity through unity. But the sins of former years are upon us, and it is my belief that the ques tion of whether we can permanently have such a society is the greatest problem before the American people today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Filion Drives 400th Victor
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 5 (AP)  Herve Filion, one of the nation's leading harness racing drivers, recorded his 400th tri umph of the year at Freehold Raceway today as he continued his assault on the world record of 407 victories he set two years ago.

title: 26,000 MINICARS RECALLED BY FORD
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 30 (UPI)The Ford Motor Com pany announced today that it was recalling 26,000 early pro duction models of its 1971 Pinto with the 1,600cubiccentimeter engine because of an accelera tor linkage problem.

title: Kennedy Presses Despite a Sure Victory
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30  Senator Edward M. Kennedy is ending his reelection campaign with a grinding schedule of appear ances in every cove and hollow of the state in a desperate race aeainst himself.

title: Art: Villon's Prints Yield 2 Surprises
description: The collection of 120 prints by Jacques Villon at Lucien Goldschmidt, Inc., 1117 Madi son Avenue near 84th Street, is a double surprise. Villon's name calls up first associa tions of a sensitive, immacu late, if sometimes rather thin, cubist manner. But in this exhibition we Tina instead a turnofthecentury Parisian stylishness not only sensitive but vigorous. The second sur prise is that in his precubist graphic oeuvre Villon was more imaginatively experi mentalif less obviously so than he became after join ing the revolution with his own variation of cubist the ory in the Section d'Or.

title: The Pictorial Styles of Jan Matulka
description: The American painter Jan Matulka will shortly be ob serving his 80th birthday. In recent decades his work has been exhibited very infre quently, but in the twenties and thirties Mr. Matulka oc cupied a position of influnece and distinction on the New York art scene. As both a painter and a teacher (at the Art Students League) he was a champion of European mod ernism at a time when it was still regarded with suspicion ane contempt.

title: Class 44: Parents Go to School, Too
description: When it was time for the noon recess on the second day of Open School Week, the total number of parents who had come to visit Class 44 seemed to be holding steady at the level of zero.

title: Dr. Dargeon's Mass Monday
description: In an obituary of Dr. Harold W. K. Dargeon, a pediatrician, who specialized in treating can cer in children, in yesterday's New York Times, the date of the funeral mass was incorrect ly given. It will be offered Monday at 10 A.M. at the Ro man Catholic Church of Notre Dame, Morningside Drive and 114th Street. Dr. Dargeon died here Thursday at the age of 73.

title: City Team Takes Early Lead In Playoff Event at Hilton
description: The New York team made a good start in the playoff match to pick a United States team for the 1971 world championship. The playoff started yesterday afternoon at the New York Hilton. After 48 deals of a scheduled 160, Philip Feldesman, Bill Grieve and Jeff Westheimer, all of New York, and Ira Ru bin of Paramus, N. J., led by 44 international match points, 11167, against a Los Angeles foursome made up of Lew Mathe, Don Krauss, Dick Walsh and John Swanson.

title: For a TwoChina Initiative
description: The Nixon Administration drops occasional hints that it might not oppose a twoChina policy at the United Nations. Ronald Ziegler, the President's press secretary, seemed to leave that possibility open when he briefed reporters on the visit to Mr. Nixon of C. K. Yen, Vice President and Premier of the Chinese Nationalist Gov ernment on Taiwan.

title: Cougars, With Caldwell. Lose to Squires, 104 to 98
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 30 (AP)The Virginia Squires ral lied in the fourth quarter to night and handed the Carolina Cougars their seventh straight defeat, 10498, in Joe Caldwell's American Basketball Associ ation debut.

title: 2 INDICTED IN BRONX ON THEFT OF CHECKS
description: Two officials associated with Bronx community action cor porations funded by the city were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges alleging the theft of money from payroll checks.

title: Radio
description: 11:03Noon, WNCN: Recital Stage. Scherzo No. 1 in B minor (Op. 20) Chopin Sonata for Cello and Piano (Op. 199) Prokoflev Sonata No. 13 in E Flat (Op. 27, No. 1) .Beethoven

title: REX COOPER IS DEAD; DANCER LED BALLET
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 30 William Rex Cooper, the dancer known as Rex Cooper, died here on Monday of cancer. He was in his late 40's.

title: A Problem for Voters
description: A woman called a polling organization that had been making voter surveys of the New York Senate race and asked the other day: Tell me how to vote. If I vote for Goodell, will that help elect Buckley?

title: 50,000 Said to Flee Floods in Vietnam
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP)Offi cials estimated today that the heaviest floods in six years in three northern provinces of South Vietnam had left 50,000 people homeless.

title: Adams Expects to Get At Least 700,000 Votes
description: HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 30 Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Con servative candidate for Gov ernor, predicted today that he would win somewhere in excess of 700,000 votes and Possibly a million.

title: MONROE, UNSELD LEAD COMEBACK
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) Trailing by 14 points early in the third quarter, the Balti more Bullets rallied for a 123 110 victory tonight over the Philadelphia 76ers. Earl Mon roe and Wes Unseld paced the Bullets attack.

title: Flashing Wires Trigger Laser
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Jack De Ment, a research chemist, was granted a pat ent this week for a gun barrel method of pumping lasers  stimulating them so that they flash.

title: Agnew Assails Protesters As Misfits and Garbage
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., Oct. 30 Vice President Agnew pointed to a cluster of noisy young demonstrators at a rally here today and said that it was time to sweep that kind of gar bage out of our society.

title: Domingo Performs Like Hero in Role Of Chenier at Met
description: In our time, here and now, when there is a wouldbe Robespierre haranguing us on every other street corner, what more exciting chance would any opera company want than Andrea Chenier? Almost in spite of Giordano, who hacked together a conventional Puccini like score, this tale of the French revolution should give a 1970 listener the chill of rec ognition.

title: Crash Victims Identified
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 30 (AP)An Army colonel and a private have been identified as the victims of a crash of a singleengine airplane on night exercises here Wednesday. The victims were identified as Lieut. Col. Edward E. Crow, deputy commanding officer of Head quarters Command here, and Pvt. Charles R. Grimsinger, of Torrence, Calif.

title: DR. ELIZABETH HINCKLEY
description: Dr. Elizabeth Brennan Hinck ley, former attending pediatri cian at St. Luke's Hospital, died Thursday in YaleNew Haven Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: Other College Football Games on Today's Card
description: Other College Football Games on Today's Card

title: Nathan Winarick, Founder Of Company for Cosmetics
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 30Nathan Winarick, a founder and secretary of Ar Winarick, Inc., cosmetics manu facturers of New York and this city, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 74 years old and lived at 34 Perry Road. Edison.

title: MRS. JOHN G. LANGE
description: Mrs. Minette Buddecke Lange, who ran Minette's restaurant in Macdougal Street from 1944 to 1956, died Oct. 23 in a nursing home in Hanover, N. H. Her age was 71. She was the widow of John George Lange, com poser and conductor.

title: 3 BOMBS DAMAGE BUILDINGS IN CITY
description: Three bombs expiocien wan in 15 minutes early yesterday morning, damaging two armo ries in Queens and the city headquarters for motorcycle policemen, situated in the Bronx. No one was injured or arrested.

title: General Motors and Union Start Talks on Money Issues in Strike
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30  The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Cor poration began probing each other's position on major money issues today. It was the first time they talked about the sub ject since the union struck the company Sept. 14.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: CITY AIDE IS CRITICAL OF NIXON ON HEALTH
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation, said to day that the nation needed a new coalition of doctors and consumers to offset the Nixon Administration's callous disre gard for the health needs of the American people.

title: SAMUEL N. KIRKHAM
description: Samuel N. Kirkham, an actor, singer and stage manager known professionally as Sam Kirkham, was found dead last night in his apartment at 350 East 65th Street. He was 48 years old.

title: SAFEWAY ADOPTS UNIT PRICING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Safeway Stores, Inc., the na tion's secondlargest food chain, announced today that it would list the prices of several hun dred products in 255 supermar kets by the pint or pound as well as by the package.

title: Sonics Stop Blazers. 115104
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30 Seattle held off a Portland rally in the third quarter tonight and handed the Trail blazers a 115104 defeat.

title: In Memoriam
description: BROWNMeyer (Mike). Oct. 31, 1967. We will always love and remember you. Helen, Judi, Sandra and Little Mike

title: 7 LISTED 10 START IN TONIGHT'S PACE
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 30 Although Albatross has been installed as a 1to5 favorite in tomorrow's $92,360 Roose velt Futurity at Roosevelt Raceway, Harry Harvey, the colt's trainerdriver, is far from convinced his pacer should be considered a sure hing.

title: JOHN E. DRUMMOND
description: John E. Drummond, former assistant treasurer of J. P. Stev ens & Co., textile manufacturer, died on Thursday evening of injuries received in an automo bile accident in Ozone Park, Queens. His age was 68.

title: STOCKS MEANDER TO A MIXED CLOSE
description: The stock market ended a week of driftingthe optimists on Wall Street call it price consolidation by drifting bit more yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Nixon Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Nix on's speech at the Anaheim (Calif.) Convention Center last night, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Defense Department to lay identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: That Man From the F.D.A. Is Sometimes a Woman
description: All of them drive a Gov ernment car, wear the same uniform, carry the same equipment and flash the same badee.

title: Arcari Stops Dias of Brazil And Retains Junior Crown
description: GENOA, Italy, Oct. 30 (AP) Bruno Arcari of Italy retained the World Boxing Council's jun ior welterweight title today by knocking out Raimundo Dias of Brazil at 1 minute 45 seconds of the third round.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW A DECLINE
description: Investors continued the prof it taking yesterday on the Lon don Stock Exchange that be gan earlier in the week, but selling appeared to decline to ward the close and the market steadied.

title: Jersey City Presents Case To Wall Street Executives
description: The advantages of Jersey City as a backoffice operations center for Wall Street financial concerns were extolled yester day by officials of that city at a meeting and reception for New York financial executives at Oscar's Delmonico restau rant. The meeting was spon sored by the Jersey City Area Development Council.

title: CON ED RESTORES CUT IN HOSPITALS RATES
description: The Consolidated Edison Company agreed yesterday to rescind an announced increase in electric and gas rates for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation that would have cost the corpora tion an estimated $730,000 a year.

title: AETNA LIFE'S NET SHARPLY HIGHER
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest allline insurance company, re ported yesterday sharply high er earnings for the third quar ter and first nine months of 1970.

title: Goals for Medical Education
description: Major pressures for change in American medical educa tion have been building up among both students and faculty members in recent years. This ferment is reflected in the report issued yesterday by the Carnegie Commis sion on Higher Educationa report deservedly likely to have major impact in the years ahead.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: ROBINSON PLANS TO FREE ACCOUNTS
description: The unfreezing of customer accounts at Robinson & Co., a brokerage house in bankruptcy proceedings, is expected to be gin shortly due to a petition filed yesterday by the firm's courtannointed receiver.

title: Howard W. Foote, 46, Dead; Executive in Textile Industry
description: Howard W. Foote, vice presi dent in charge of textiles of National Distillers and Chemi cal Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven. He was 46 years old and lived at 478 Catamount Road, Fairfield, Conn.

title: Rodriguez Fined $200 For Antics During Play
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 29 Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, the diminutive Puerto Rican professional, was, fined $200 today for conduct unbecom ing a professional golfer fol lowing a protest by Dave Hill.

title: Democrat's Big TV Push Perils Fannin in Arizona
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 30  Sam Grossman, a newcomer to Ari zona, to the Democratic party and to politics, threatens to unseat Senator Paul J. Fannin with an aggressive television campaign financed mainly out of his own Docket.

title: It's the Giants by 9 to Add An Insult to Jets Injuries
description: Tomorrow will bring the first GiantsJets regular sea son game and the last one until 1974. The Giants are favored by 9 points and the blackout has been lifted, so Channel 2 will telecast the contest, starting at 1 P.M. This is one of three inter conference games; the National Conference leads the Ameri can, 113, so far. The Raiders Chiefs game will be on Channel 4 at 4 P.M. Here is a preview of all the games, with won losttied records in paren theses.

title: We Are the Champ
description: ECHO LAKE, Pa, Oct. 29I call him Cassius, he calls me boss, said Yancey Durham, rolling the words like marbles in his mouth, peeking from under hooded lids assay the reaction of the others at the table. Cassius Clay, that's what I call him. If the public wants to see the fight, and the commission gives him a license, we may just give him a shot. That's right, we'll give him a shot. How can he go round claim the title for whipping a man we destroyed') Destroyed. We are the champ.

title: Fashion Goes Soft for Spring
description: Like them or loathe them, spring clothes on Seventh Av enue look a lot different from the way they looked a year ago. It's not just the extra length, either, though, of course length counts.

title: School Football Games Today
description: School Football Games Today

title: Mayor Accuses Beame of Using DoubleStandard on Consultant Contracts
description: Mayor Lindsay charged yes terday that Abraham D. Beame was a doublestandard Con troller who had previously cooperated with a Democratic Mayor in regard to consultant contracts but who now ob structed Mr. Lindsay's efforts.

title: T.W.A. Chief Terms Concorde a Loser
description: GENEVA, Oct. 30Forwood C. Wiser, president of Trans World Airlines, said today that the AngloFrench supersonic jet liner, the Concorde, would lose money unless the traveling pub lic was willing to pay 30 to 40 per cent more than they now pay for firstclass fares across the Atlantic.

title: POLICE IN TRENTON ENFORCE CUR FEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30  Police men ringed downtown Trenton today against marauding bands of black youths and enforced a strict curfew for the second night after a renewal of racial violence.

title: Shakespeare Theater Gets $250,000 Matching Grant
description: ALBANY, Oct. 30The New York Shakespeare Festival Theater in New York City will receive $250,000 in matching grants in aid for historic sites, Governor Rockefeller announced today.

title: Planning to Buy Jergens for $108Million and Enter Soap Field
description: American Brands, Inc., which has substantially broadened its activities into nontobacco prod ucts, is planning to enter the toiletries and soap field through the proposed acquisition of the Andrew Jergens Company for $108million.

title: U.S. IS REVAMPING FUNDING METHOD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Treasury announced today a new technique for borrow ing funds.

title: Choice for California
description: Seeking a second term in California, Republican Gov ernor Ronald Reagan is trying to prove that nothing succeeds like failure. He was elected in 1966 after a campaign in which he denounced crime, campus dis orders, the welfare program and high taxes but without ever making clear what he would do about them.

title: Democrats Worried by Nixon's Campaign Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Democrats are coming to the end of a significant Con gressional election without any national spokesmen or pub licity devices to pit against the massive homestretch efforts of President Nixon and Vice Pres ident Agnew.

title: Rangers Defense Gets Stiffest Test At Boston Tonight
description: Six months after their most penaltyfilled series in the his tory of National Hockey League playoffs, the Rangers and Bru ins will face each other tonight at Boston, in a meeting of the league's strongest clubs.

title: Policy Backer Is Convicted Of Violating Gambling Law
description: Rudolph Prisco, a reputed member of an organized crime family, was found guilty yes terday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx of two felonies involving violation of state eambling laws.

title: LORD WAKEHURST, BRITISH AIDE, 75
description: LONDON, Oct. 30  Lord Wakehurst, a former Covernor of Northern Ireland, died at his London home here last night. He was 75 years old.

title: Angela Davis Sues Over Being Given Solitary Detention
description: Angela Y. Davis, who is be ing held in the Women's House of Detention here on charges of kidnapping and murder in California, sued yesterday to force the city to release her from solitary confinement.

title: Gustav L. Graef, 89, Served Board of Education Here
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 30  Gustav L. Graef, who retired in 1943 as superintendent of school supplies for the New York City Board of Education, died Wednesday in Overlook Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: New Aid on Mortgages Planned for Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Federal National Mortgage. Association and the Ford Foundation announced today a new program for providing cap ital to fledgling mortgage bank ers from minority races.

title: Election in North Kashmir
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 30 About a million residents of northern Kashmir, held by Pakistan, went to the polls today for the first time in 23 years. They will elect a pres ident and a 25member legis lative assembly.

title: McGovern Maneuvering With Eye on 72 Candidacy
description: PONTIAC. Mich., Oct. 26 On his belated, abortive bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1968, Senator George S. McGovern stopped briefly here for a political rally at the modernistic headquarters of the Oakland County Board of Commissioners.

title: An UpsideDown Look Best for Some Voters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Bifocal wearers who have difficulty reading the top lines in voting booths next Tuesday should turn their spectacles upside down, a senior citizens group ad vises.

title: WOR'S SHEPHERD ON VILLAGE STAGE
description: For over a decade there has been a Jean Shepherd thing going that makes the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi look as if he had never left his hermitage.

title: Apartheid Still Won't Work
description: HILLCREST, NatalIt must be ad mitted that the theory of apartheid is in a shocking way. In fact, it lives from day to day. That does not mean that its life is in immediate danger. It means that the facts will not adapt themselves to the theory. Therefore the theory is losing its messianic qual ity. It is losing its validity in the eyes of many whose fathers believed in it.

title: Arnold C. Sherwood, 78; Former Union Pacific Aide
description: Arnold C. Sherwood, who retired as corporate secretary of the Union Pacific Railroad Company in 1960, died Thurs day at Valley Hospital, Ridge wood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived at 1360 Sanford Road, Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Belfast Troops Fired On and Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP)A British Army patrol came under machinegun fire early today as violence broke out in Belfast for the second consecutive night.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment Events

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: U.S. COURT VOIDS JERSEY VOTE LAW
description: NEWARK, Oct. 30A three judge Federal Court panel struck down as unconstitutional today the heart and substance of a New Jersey law that de prives some exconvicts of the rieht to vote.

title: Santa Fe Orders Cars
description: The Santa Fe Failroad an nounced yesterday that it would acquire 2,550 new freight cars at a cost of about $50million. Of this amount, 400 mechanical temperature control cars costing $13.5mil lion will be built at the road's freightcar shops in Topeka, Kan.

title: SEALS ROUT SABRES IN FIRST VICTORY, 61
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 30 (UPI) Bill Hicke and Carol Vadnais tallied two goals each tonight to spark the California Golden Seals to a 61 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Canadian Banks Cul Prime Rate to 7%
description: TORONTO, Oct. 30  Ca nadian banks cut today their prime interest rate on loans by a half point to 7 per cent. Interest paid on savings ac counts also was reduced.

title: P.B.A. FILES APPEAL ON CORRUPTION UNIT
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association asked the Appel late Division of the State Su preme Court yesterday to rule that the Knapp Commission, which is investigating allega tions of corruption among New York policemen, is invalid. Ar ument on the P.B.A.'s motion was scheduled for Dec. 3.

title: GEORGE ANDERSON, PUBLICITY OFFICIAL
description: George Anderson, vice presi dent of DudleyAndersonYutzy Public Relations, Inc., a con cern known in the trade as DAY died yesterday as his home in Brick Town, N. J. He was 59 years old.

title: Letters on Election Campaign
description: To the Editor: Taken together your Oct. 25 edi torials Rockefeller for Governor and Electoral Shadow are a good argu ment fur supporting the ticket of Goldberg and Paterson.

title: Deaths From Drug Abuse Rise Among Vietnam G.I.'s
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Oct. 30The United States Com mand disclosed today a rise in deaths of soldiers from drug use in Vietnam and ascribed the increase to greater use of hard drugs and a more acces sible supply of high potency heroin.

title: NIXON BIDS VOTERS DRAW THE LINE AT VIOLENT YOUTH
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 30 President Nixon called on the nation's voters tonight to reject candidates who had condoned, excused or failed to speak up against permissiveness among America's violent youth.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet representative at the United Nations, called yesterday before the General Assembly for the imme diate and unconditional resumption of Arab Israeli peace talks. He rejected the Ameri can and Israeli contention that ceasefire violations must be rectified by Egypt before the talks could resume. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: GROMYKO CONFERS IN WEST GERMANY
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Oct. 30Andrei A. Gro myko, the first Soviet Foreign Minister to visit West Ger many, held almost six hours of talks today with Bonn's For eign Minister, Walter Scheel.

title: Collapse of Woman's Hoax Embarrasses Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 30 (Reuters)A young Indonesian village woman pretended for 19 months that she was bearing a child that was able to talk and that prayed to Allah five times a day as Moslems do.

title: CORONA RESIDENTS GET STATE BACKING
description: Two high state officials de nounced the city administration yesterday for trying to tear down 69 homes in the Corona section of Queens as part of a plan to build a high school and athletic field there.

title: Bulls Chase Warriors, 10198
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls edged the San Francisco Warriors, 10198, tonight as Jerry Sloan scored 22 points and grabbed 12 rebounds.

title: Two to Stand at Stud
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) Alfred G. Vanderbilt and Mi chael J. Ford said today that Royal Gunner and Umbrella Fella will stand at stud at Van derbilt's Sagamore Farm in nearby Glyndon, Md., during the 1971 season.

title: Tasso, Keswick Win Jumping Trophies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Tasso, from the string of the West German Equestrian Team, ridden by Hartwig Steenken, and Keswick, owned by Mrs. William Hewitt of Palmetto, Fla., won identical but separate jumping classes today at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: 10Year Sentence Of Saigon Deputy Annulled by Court
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Oct. 30The Supreme Court today annulled the 10year sentence imposed on Representative Tran Ngoc Chau, the controversial Deputy jailed earlier this year.

title: Price of Gold Is Lower By as Much as $1 an Ounce
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (UPI)The price of gold slumped today with some dealers slashing the price by as much as $1 an ounce.

title: The House Races
description: Of the 435 members of the House of Representatives, about forty are outstanding because of their generally effective work or their devotion to the public interest in certain fields. Many of them are veterans of considerable service but a few are newcomers. The nation will be wellserved if they are returned to Capitol Hill.

title: ludge Advocate General To Act on Fate of Captain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Army said today that Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, the Judge Advocate General, would appoint an officer to de termine whether Capt. John J. McCarthy Jr. of the Special Forces will be retired for the 1967 murder of an alleged Vietnamese double agent
